passage_content: ויחי יעקב באמ"צ וגו'. פרש"י למה פרשה זו סתומה, לפי שכיון שנפטר יעקב אבינו נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד וכו'. הקשו המפרשים הרי אמרז"ל דכל זמן שאחד מהשבטים היה קיים לא שעבדו המצריים בבנ"י, ואיתא במד"ר פ' שמות עה"פ וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא, ללמדך שכ"ז שהי' קיים א' מאותן ע' נפש שירדו למצרים, לא שעבדו המצרים בישראל, וצ"ב דברי רש"י ז"ל מ"ש שכיון שנפטר ועאע"ה נסתמו עיניהם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, והרי לא היתה עליהם שעבודם של מצרים באותה שעה. גם הקשו המפרשים ז"ל דלפי דרשתם ז"ל אין כאן מקומה של הסתומה, וראוי להיות להלן בסוף הפרשה אצל ויגוע ויאסף אל עמיו.
translation: And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt, etc. Rashi explains why this section is closed, because when our father Jacob passed away, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed due to the anguish of the servitude, etc. The commentators question, however, that our sages have said that as long as one of the tribes was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave the children of Israel. And it is stated in the Midrash, Parashat Shemot, on the verse "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and all that generation," to teach you that as long as one of those seventy souls who went down to Egypt was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel. It is puzzling what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, means when he says that once he passed away, the eyes of Israel were closed due to the anguish of the servitude, when at that time they were not under the Egyptians' servitude. The commentators also question that according to their interpretation, this is not the place for the closed section, and it should be placed later at the end of the section near "and he died and was gathered to his people."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's death and its impact on the Israelites, highlighting that with his passing, their perception and emotional state became clouded due to the impending suffering of slavery in Egypt. It raises questions about the interpretation of the sages regarding the timing of Israel's oppression, noting that as long as one of the original seventy descendants of Jacob was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave them. The text emphasizes the deep connection between the patriarchs and the fate of their descendants, illustrating how the presence of righteous individuals can shield their people from suffering. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound spiritual and emotional implications of loss within the Jewish tradition.

passage_content: ב) ויקרא לבנו ליוסף וגו' שים נא ידך תחת ירכי וגו' פרש"י ז"ל שים נא ידך. והשבע, וכן פרש"י לעיל (פ' חיי) שים נא ידך תחת ירכי, שהוא ציווי על השבועה עיי"ש, אמנם הראב"ע והרשב"ם ז"ל פירשו שם שענינו להראות הכנעה ושעבוד כעבד אל אדוניו, וזה המשפט עדיין בארץ הודו עכ"ד. ואף כאן בפ' ויחי רמזו הראב"ע והרשב"ם ז"ל על פירושם שם, וכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה דכאן מוכרח כפי' הראב"ע והרשב"ם, דא"א לומר שהוא ציווי לשבועה, דהרי אחר שהשיב יוסף אנכי אעשה כדבריך, כתיב ויאמר השבעה לי מכלל דמעיקרא לא לשבועה נאמר עכ"ל ק"ז זלל"ה, וצ"ב ליישב שיטת רש"י ז"ל, דכפל הציווי למה, וכבר צוהו על השבועה במאמר שים נא ידך, ומדוע כפל ציוויו לומר השבעה לי.
translation: B) And he called his son Joseph, etc. "Please place your hand under my thigh," etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains "Please place your hand." And he swore, and so Rashi explained earlier (in Parashat Chayei) "Please place your hand under my thigh," which is a command regarding the oath, as mentioned there. However, the Ra'avad and the Rashbam, of blessed memory, interpreted there that its meaning is to show submission and servitude like a servant to his master, and this practice still exists in the land of India, thus far their words. And even here in Parashat Vayechi, the Ra'avad and the Rashbam, of blessed memory, hinted at their interpretation there, and Rabbi Simcha Moshe, may his memory be blessed, wrote that here it is necessary according to the interpretation of the Ra'avad and the Rashbam, for it cannot be said that it is a command for the oath, since after Joseph replied, "I will do as you have said," it is written, "And he said, 'Swear to me,'" implying that initially it was not said for the oath, thus far his words, may his memory be blessed. And it is necessary to clarify Rashi's interpretation, of blessed memory, why the command is repeated, for he already commanded him regarding the oath with the statement "Please place your hand," and why did he repeat his command to say, "Swear to me."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion revolves around the interpretation of Jacob's command to Joseph regarding the oath, highlighting differing views among commentators. Rashi emphasizes the act of swearing as a significant covenantal moment, while the Ibn Ezra and Rashbam suggest it symbolizes submission and servitude. The text reflects on the complexity of divine commands and human responses, illustrating the tension between obedience and the nature of authority. Ultimately, it raises questions about the necessity of reiterating commands and the deeper implications of faithfulness in the context of familial and divine relationships.

passage_content: ג) עוד הקשה קיז זלל"ה מדוע שינה יעקב את טעמו בשבועתו מאברהם אבינו שמצינו באאע"ה כשהי' רוצה לצוות לאליעזר ולהשביעו, תיכף במאמר ראשון אמר לו ואשביעך. ואח"כ פי' לו ענין השבועה, ויעקב מתחלה אמר ליוסף ענין הציווי, וכשהשיב לו אנכי אעשה כדבריך, אמר לו השבעה לי והי' לו לומר מיד במאמר הראשון השבעה לי אל תקברני במצרים וגו', ולא דבר ריק הוא ההשתנות הזה.
translation: 3) Furthermore, Rabbi Kiz Zal'l"ah questioned why Jacob changed his approach regarding his oath compared to our forefather Abraham, as we find with Abraham when he wanted to command Eliezer and make him swear. Immediately in the first statement, he said to him, "And I will make you swear." Afterwards, he explained the matter of the oath. However, Jacob initially told Joseph the matter of the command, and when Joseph responded, "I will do as you say," Jacob said to him, "Swear to me." He could have said immediately in the first statement, "Swear to me, do not bury me in Egypt," etc. This change is not a trivial matter.
summary: הקטע עוסק בשינוי הגישה של יעקב אבינו בשבועתו ליוסף לעומת אברהם אבינו בשבועתו לאליעזר. בעוד שאברהם השביע את אליעזר מיד עם הציווי, יעקב בחר להסביר את הציווי לפני שהשביע את יוסף. השינוי הזה מצביע על עומק רוחני, שבו יעקב מדגיש את החשיבות של הבנת המשמעות והכוונה מאחורי השבועה, ולא רק את עצם הפעולה. זה משקף את ההבנה החסידית של הקשר בין תוכן לפעולה, והצורך בהכנה רוחנית לפני קבלת החלטות משמעותיות.

passage_content: ד) עו"ק ממ"ש בריש חולין (ב' ע"א) בפלוגתא דר"מ ור"י עה"כ טוב אשר לא תדור משתדור ולא תשלם, דר"מ ס"ל טוב מזה ומזה שאינו נודר כל עיקר, ור"י ס"ל טוב מזה ומזה נודר ומשלם, ומפרש בגמרא דאפילו ר"ו לא קאמר אלא באומר הרי זו, אבל באומר הרי עלי לא, עוד שם בגמרא וכי תחדול לנדור לא יהי' בך חטא, הא אם תדור יהיה בך חטא (ואפילו אם מקיימו, עיי"ש). וא"כ לפי"ז קשה איך צוה יעקב אבינו ליוסף שישבע לו ויעבור על וכי תחדול לנדור לא יהיה בך חטא, והרי קיימו האבוה"ק כל התורה כולה ע"כ תוכן קושיתו ק"ז זלל"ה, וקושיא זו קשה גם על מה שהשביע יוסף את בני ישראל וצ"ב.
translation: 4) Regarding the statement mentioned at the beginning of Chulin (2a) in the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, it is good not to make a vow than to make a vow and not fulfill it. Rabbi Meir holds that it is better not to vow at all, while Rabbi Yehuda holds that it is better to vow and fulfill. The Gemara explains that this is only said regarding one who says "this is a vow," but if one says "it is upon me," it is not the same. Furthermore, the Gemara states, "If you refrain from vowing, there will be no sin upon you," but if you do vow, there will be a sin upon you (even if you fulfill it, see there). Therefore, according to this, it is difficult how our forefather Jacob commanded Joseph to swear to him, thus transgressing "If you refrain from vowing, there will be no sin upon you," and indeed, the forefathers fulfilled the entire Torah. Thus, this is the essence of his question, may his memory be blessed, and this question is also difficult regarding Joseph's oath to the children of Israel, and it requires clarification.
summary: The passage discusses a Talmudic debate between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda regarding the nature of vows, emphasizing that Rabbi Meir believes it is better not to make vows at all, while Rabbi Yehuda sees value in making and fulfilling them. It raises a theological question about Jacob's command to Joseph to swear an oath, seemingly contradicting the principle that one should avoid making vows to prevent sin. This tension highlights the complexity of human commitments and the moral implications of oaths within the framework of Jewish law, suggesting a deeper exploration of faith and obligation in the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content:
ה) במסכת סוטה (ול"ו ע"ב) כל לישנא דאשתעי פרעה בהדי', אהדר לי' (יוסף), אשתעי איהו בלשון הקודש, לא הוה קא ידע מאי הוה אמר, אמר לו אגמרי, אגמרי' ולא גמיר, אמר לו אישתבע לי דלא מגלית (משום דהי' כתוב בנימוסי מצרים שלא ימלוך רק מי שיודע כל הלשונות, וא"כ יעבירוהו ממלכותו) אישתבע לו, כו א"ל אבי השביעני לאמר, א"ל זיל איתשל אשבועתך (פרש"י השאל לחכמים שיתירוה לך) א"ל יוסף ואיתשלי נמי אדידך, ואע"ג דלא ניחא לי' אמר לו עלה וקבור את אביך כאשר השביעך עכ"ד הגמרא. וכן פרש"י להלן (בפרשת ויחי) עה"פ עלה וקבור אביך כאשר השביעך. דאם לא בשביל השבועה לא הייתי מניחך, אבל ירא לומר עבור על השבועה, 
שלא יאמר א"כ אעבור על השבועה שנשבעתי לך שלא אגלה על לה"ק שאינך מכיר בו וכו', עכ"ד רש"י ז"ל, וק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה הביא על דברי הגמרא הנ"ל מקשין העולם איך אמר לי' איתשיל נמי אדידך, הא קיי"ל צריך לפרוט את הנדר, וא"כ קודם שיתירהו איך יעבור על שבועתו, ועוד מקשין מאי נמי אדידך, הלא אם יתיר שבועת פרעה יעבירוהו לפרעה ממלכותו, ובודאי ימלוך יוסף, כי אין מי שיודע ע' לשון וגם לה"ק רק יוסף, ואז ממילא יוכל לקיים שבועת יעקב, א"כ הול"ל איתשיל אדידך. ולשון נמי אדידך משמע שיתיר לשני השבועות, והוא תמוה דלמה יתיר לשניהם ומדוע תלה התרת חדא בחבירתה ע"כ קושית העולם עיי"ש תירוצו.
translation: In the tractate Sotah (36b), every expression that Pharaoh spoke with him, he (Joseph) responded to him in the Holy Language. He did not know what he was saying, and he said to him, "I will learn it," but he did not learn it. He said to him, "Swear to me that you will not reveal (because it was written in the customs of Egypt that only one who knows all the languages may reign, and therefore they would remove him from his kingdom)." He swore to him, etc. He said to him, "My father made me swear to say," and he said to him, "Go fulfill your oath" (Rashi explains that he asked the sages to permit it to him). Joseph said, "And I will also fulfill your oath," and although it was not pleasing to him, he said to him, "Go up and bury your father as you swore to him." Thus concludes the Gemara. And so Rashi explains later (in the portion of Vayechi) on the verse "Go up and bury your father as you swore to him." For if not for the oath, I would not have allowed you, but he was afraid to say to transgress the oath, lest he say, "Then I will transgress the oath that I swore to you that I would not reveal the Holy Language that you do not recognize," etc. Thus concludes Rashi, may his memory be blessed. And so the joyous Moshe, may his memory be blessed, brought on the words of the aforementioned Gemara, the world questions how he said to him, "I will also fulfill your oath," for we hold that one must specify the vow, and therefore before it is permitted to him, how can he transgress his oath? Furthermore, they question what "also fulfill your oath" means; behold, if Pharaoh's oath is permitted, they would remove him from Pharaoh's kingdom, and certainly Joseph would reign, for there is no one who knows seventy languages and also the Holy Language except for Joseph. Then, automatically, he could fulfill Jacob's oath. Therefore, it should have said, "I will fulfill your oath." And the expression "also fulfill your oath" implies that he will permit both oaths, which is puzzling—why permit both, and why did he link the permitting of one to the other? Thus is the world's question; see there for his resolution.
summary: The passage discusses the complexities of Joseph's oath to Pharaoh regarding the use of Hebrew, highlighting the tension between loyalty to his father Jacob's wishes and adherence to Pharaoh's decree. It emphasizes the significance of oaths in Jewish thought, illustrating the potential conflict between divine commandments and earthly authority. The dialogue reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of commitment and the interplay between human obligations and spiritual truths, suggesting that true fidelity may require navigating these intricate moral landscapes. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of understanding the nuances of one's vows within the context of faith and divine will.

passage_content: ו) עוד הקשה ק"ז זלל"ה על שבועה זו שנשבע יוסף ליעקב, ממ"ד בגמרא (שבועות כ"ה ע"א) שבועה שזרק פלוני צרור לים ושלא זרק, רב אמר חייב, איתי' בלאו והן, ושמואל אמר פטור ליתי' בלהבא, פרש"י ליתי' בלהבא יזרוק פלוני או לא יזרוק אין זה שבועת ביטוי אלא שבועת שוא, שהרי און פלוני ברשותו לזרוק ולא לזרוק עכ"ל (ועיין ש"ע יו"ד סימן רל"ו ס"ב). מבואר מכל הנ"ל דבדבר שאין הכרע כלל אם יעשה פלוני או לא יעשה, חייב מלקות הנשבע אף אם יעשה אח"כ פלוני, דמ"מ הוי שוא בשעת השבועה, וא"כ הכא ביוסף שאין בידו. דהא הי' צריך ליטול רשות מפרעה כמבואר בקרא, ואין הכרע כלל אם יתן לו פרעה רשות או לא, א"כ הוי ח"ו כשבועת שוא, והיא קושיא עצומה לענ"ד עכ"ל ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה.
translation: And further, K"Z Z"L questioned this oath that Joseph swore to Jacob, as it is stated in the Gemara (Shevuot 25a) regarding an oath that someone threw a bundle into the sea and did not throw it; Rabbi said he is liable, as it is stated in a prohibition and they (the witnesses), and Shmuel said he is exempt because it is a future event. Rashi explains that "it is a future event" means whether so-and-so will throw or not throw, this is not an oath of expression but an oath of falsehood, since so-and-so has the authority to throw or not to throw. Thus, it is clear from all the above that in a matter where there is no determination at all whether so-and-so will do or not do, he is liable for lashes for the one who swears even if so-and-so does it afterward, for it is still considered falsehood at the time of the oath. And here, in the case of Joseph, he does not have the authority, for he needed to obtain permission from Pharaoh, as it is explained in the verse, and there is no determination at all whether Pharaoh will grant him permission or not. Therefore, it is, Heaven forbid, like an oath of falsehood, and this is a tremendous question in my opinion, thus concluded K"Z the Joyous Moses Z"L.
summary: The passage discusses the complexity of Joseph's oath to Jacob, highlighting a debate in the Talmud regarding the nature of oaths when the outcome is uncertain. It emphasizes that if a person swears about an action that is not definitively in their control, such as Joseph needing Pharaoh's permission, it may be considered a false oath (שבועת שוא). This raises significant theological implications about the nature of commitment and the weight of one's words, particularly in the context of divine will and human agency. Ultimately, it reflects on the tension between human intentions and the unpredictability of outcomes in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: ז) ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת וגו'. פרש"י ז"ל חסד שעושים עם המתים הוא חסד של אמת שאינו מצפה לתשלום גמול, וצ"ב דלהלן פרש"י עה"פ ואני נתתי לך שכם א' וגו', לפי שאתה טורח בקבורתו, גם אני נתתי לך וכו', וא"כ הרי שילם את גמולו ומדוע ביקש מאתו חסד של אמת גם שאמרז"ל יעקב אבינו לא מתל א"כ אין זו בגדר חסד שעושים עם המתים.
translation: And you shall do with me kindness and truth, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that the kindness done for the dead is the kindness of truth, which does not expect a reward in return. However, it is difficult to understand, for below Rashi explains on the verse "And I have given you Shechem, etc.," that since you are involved in his burial, I too have given you, etc. If so, he has already repaid his reward, and why did he ask of him for kindness of truth, especially since our sages have said that Jacob our father did not die? Therefore, this is not considered the kindness done for the dead.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "chesed shel emet" (true kindness) as an act of kindness performed for the deceased, which is done without expectation of reward. Rashi's commentary highlights that even though Jacob was not truly dead, the kindness shown in his burial is still considered true kindness because it reflects selflessness. The inquiry arises regarding the nature of this kindness, as it seems to imply a reward for the effort in burial, yet it remains a profound act of love and respect for the deceased. This illustrates the Hasidic idea that true acts of kindness transcend the expectation of reciprocity, emphasizing the spiritual significance of honoring the dead.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נתחיל לתרץ קושיא הנ"ל, האיך השביע יעקב ליוסף, ויוסף השביע לבני ישראל, והרי כ"ע ס"ל בכה"ג דטוב מי שאינו נודר כל עיקר, והנודר אפילו אם מקיימו ה"ז חוטא (עיין לעיל קושיא ד'). ואפ"ל עפימ"ד במד"ר ותנחומא (פ' מטות) וידבר משה אל ראשי המטות וגו' איש כי ידור נדר לד' וכו', א"ל הקב"ה לישראל לא תהיו סבורים שהותר לכם לישבע בשמי אפילו באמת, אין אתם רשאין לישבע בשמי אלא א"כ יהיו בך כל המדות האלה, שנאמר את ד' אלקיך תירא ואותו תעבוד ובשמו תשבע, עד שתהא כשלשה שנקראו יראי אלקים, אברהם איוב ויוסף וכו', אם יש בך כל המדות הללו אתה יכול להשבע ואם לאו אי אתה יכול להשבע עכ"ד המדרש. ולפי זה יונח בפשטות שועאע"ה השיג וראה צדקתו של יוסף, שהוא מאותן שנקראו יראי אלקים ומותר לו לישבע וא"ש שהשביעו.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will begin to address the aforementioned question: how did Jacob swear to Joseph, and Joseph swore to the children of Israel, when it is universally accepted that in such cases it is better for one not to make a vow at all, and one who vows, even if he fulfills it, is considered a sinner (see above the question). And it can be said according to the Midrash and Tanchuma (Parashat Matot) that Moses spoke to the heads of the tribes, saying, "If a man makes a vow to the Lord," etc. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel: "Do not think that it is permitted for you to swear in My name, even if it is true. You are not permitted to swear in My name unless you possess all these attributes," as it is said, "You shall fear the Lord your God, and Him you shall serve, and in His name you shall swear," until you are like the three who are called God-fearing: Abraham, Job, and Joseph, etc. If you possess all these attributes, you may swear; if not, you may not swear, thus concludes the Midrash. According to this, it is simply understood that Joseph attained and recognized his righteousness, as he is among those who are called God-fearing, and it is permissible for him to swear, and it is clear that he swore to him.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of oaths in the context of Jacob swearing Joseph and Joseph swearing the Israelites. It emphasizes that one should not take oaths lightly, as only those who embody certain virtues, akin to the biblical figures Abraham, Job, and Joseph, are permitted to swear in God's name. The text highlights that Joseph is recognized as a "God-fearing" individual, justifying Jacob's oath to him. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of moral integrity and the conditions under which one may invoke God's name.

passage_content: ובזה יומתק לנו קישור מאמר הכתוב ויאמר השבעה לי וגו' וישתחוו ישראל על ראש המטה, פרש"י על שהיתה מטתו שלימה ולא הי' בה רשע, שהרי יוסף מלך הוא ועוד שנשבה לבין הגוים והרי הוא עומד בצדקו, ויל"ד כו בודאי הכיר והשיג יעאע"ה ביוסף, מאז שראהו ונתודע אליו ברדתו למצרים, כי עדיין עומד בצדקו, ומדוע עכשיו בצוותו השבעה לי נתבונן בו עוה"פ והשתחוה לד' כי עדיין עומד בצדקו וצ"ב הקישור, ולדרכנו א"ש עפ"י פשטות, דעכשיו התבונן בו עוה"פ כי הי' נפק"מ לו להלכה אם רשאי להשביעו, וראה והשיג צדקתו ומיד הודה והשתחוה לד' על שהיתה מטתו שלימה, וא"ש קישור הכתוב.
translation: And with this, the connection of the verse is clarified: "And he said, 'Swear to me...' and Israel bowed on the head of the bed." Rashi explains that his bed was whole and there was no wickedness in it, for Joseph is a king and he was taken among the nations, yet he stands in his righteousness. It is known that he certainly recognized and understood the Divine Presence in Joseph, from the moment he saw him and became acquainted with him upon descending to Egypt, for he still stood in his righteousness. And why now, in commanding him to swear, did he contemplate him in this world and bow to God? Because he still stood in his righteousness, and the connection is questioned. According to our approach, it is understood simply: now he contemplated him in this world because it was significant for him in halacha whether he was permitted to make him swear. And he saw and understood his righteousness, and immediately he acknowledged and bowed to God for his bed was whole. And thus, the connection of the verse is understood.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's integrity and righteousness, as highlighted by the phrase "swear to me" and the act of Israel bowing at the head of the bed. It emphasizes that Joseph, despite his trials and being among the nations, remained steadfast in his righteousness, which led to a recognition of divine justice. The connection between Joseph's unwavering character and Israel's acknowledgment of God's presence illustrates the importance of maintaining faith and integrity in challenging circumstances. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between human righteousness and divine acknowledgment.

passage_content: ומה שהשביע יוסף את בנו ישראל אפשר לתרץ, דהטעם דטוב אשר לא תדור, משום דשמא לא יקיים את נדרו, ואפשר דיש לחלק בזה בין יחיד לרבים, ועל דרך מה שכתב הריטב"א (במסכת יומא פרק טרף בקלפי) שהקשה שם לתנא קמא האיך אמר הכהן גדול לה' חטאת, הא אמרינן בנדרים (דף י' ע"ב) דלא לימא אינש לד' קרבן אלא קרבן לד', דלמא פשע ויאמר לד' ולא יאמר קרבן ונמצא מזכיר שם שמים לבטלה, ותירץ דכיון שיש שם הסגן והאב בי"ד מדכרי ליה, וברבים ליתא להאי חששא שמא לא ישלים אמרו. דרבים מדכרי אהדדי עיי"ש, וכה"ג אמרי' במסכת (שבת י"ב ע"ב) דיחיד אסור לקרות לאור הנר שמא יטה, ובשנים מותר דמדכרי אהדדי, והנה יוסף הצדיק השביע את כל ישראל והעליתם את עצמותי וגו', וליכא מקום לחשוש שמא לא יקיימו את השבועה, דא"א שלא ימצא בכל ישראל אף א' שיקיים צוואתו, ומשו"ה שפיר השביעם.
translation: And regarding what Joseph swore to his son Israel, it is possible to explain that the reason for "it is good that you do not dwell" is because perhaps he will not fulfill his vow. It is possible to differentiate between an individual and the many, in the manner of what the Ritva wrote (in Tractate Yoma, Chapter Treif BeKalpi) where he questioned the first Tanna how the High Priest could say to God, "a sin offering," for we say in Nedarim (Daf 10b) that a person should not say "to God a sacrifice" but rather "a sacrifice to God," lest he err and say "to God" and not say "sacrifice," and thus he would mention the name of Heaven in vain. He answered that since there is the deputy and the father in the court, they mention it to him, and in the case of the many, this concern does not exist that perhaps they will not complete what they said. For the many mention to each other, as stated there. And similarly, we say in Tractate Shabbat (12b) that an individual is forbidden to read by the light of the candle lest he tilt it, but in the case of two, it is permitted because they mention to each other. And behold, Joseph the righteous swore all of Israel, "and you shall carry up my bones," and there is no room to be concerned that perhaps they will not fulfill the oath, for it is impossible that there will not be even one among all of Israel who will fulfill his will, and therefore he rightly swore them.
summary: יוסף הצדיק השביע את בני ישראל להעלות את עצמותיו לארץ ישראל, והדבר מובן בכך שאין חשש שלא יקיימו את השבועה, שכן בכל ישראל תמיד יימצא אחד שיקיים את צוואתו. ההבחנה בין יחיד לרבים מדגישה את הכוח של קהילה, שבה יש עידוד הדדי לקיום מצוות. כמו כן, יש כאן תובנה על האמונה בכוחם של ישראל לשמור על קשר עם הקודש, גם כאשר מדובר בנדרים ובשבועות.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בענין שבועה זו, ויתורצו בזה יתר הקושיות הנ"ל בהקדם מ"ש החת"ס זלל"ה (בפ' ויגש) עה"פ כי פי המדבר אליכם פרש"י בלשון הקודש, והקשה הרמב"ן ז"ל כי איננו ראי' שידבר אדם א' במצרים בלה"ק, כו על דעתו הוא שפת כנען, ורבים במצרים יודעים אותו כי קרוב הוא, ואף כי המושל, שדרך המלכים והמושלים לדעת הלשונות עכ"ד הרמב"ן ז"ל, ועוד הקשה החת"ס ז"ל מ"ט לא ביקש פרעה מיוסף שילמדנו בסתר לה"ק, ולא יהי' נכנע אצל יוסף מפחדו שמא יעבור על שבועתו ויגלה סודו, ותוכן תירוצו שאין לשון עבר נקרא לשון הקודש, כו לשון הקודש הוא לשון התורה כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דע"כ נקראת לה"ק, שכל דברי קדושה הנאמרים מהקב"ה אל נביאיו לא הי' אלא בו עכ"ד ז"ל, גם כי בלה"ק יש בתוכו ותוך תוכו גימטריאות ונוטריקון ותמורת אותיות וצירופי שמות הק', והמדבר באופן זה הוא בעל רוה"ק, והשומע ומבין צריך ג"כ להיות בעל רוה"ק, והיינו דקאמר יוסף אחר שא"ל למחו' שלחני אלקים וגו' לשום לכם שארית בארץ וגו', והם הבינו הטמון בדיבורו כמה תמורות וגימטריאות, וידעו כי ברוה"ק מדבר וזהו ראי' כי אחיהם הוא, כו אין רוה"ק שורה על שפת חלקות, וז"ש כי פי המדבר אליכם בלה"ק, והנה אחר שדיבר יוסף עם פרעה בלשון עבר, שוב דיבר עמו באותו לשון עצמו, והראה לו שיכול לדבר דבר, והמובן ממנו באופן אחר, וזה א"א ללמד לפרעה ולכיוצא בו, עכ"ד החתם סופר זלל"ה.
translation: And I can also add regarding this matter of the oath, that the other questions mentioned above will be resolved by what the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in Parshas Vayigash) on the verse "For the mouth that speaks to you," that Rashi explains in the Holy Tongue, and the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, questioned that this is not a proof that one person would speak in Egypt in the Holy Language, for according to his opinion it is the language of Canaan, and many in Egypt know it because it is close, and even the ruler, for it is the way of kings and rulers to know languages, thus said the Ramban, may his memory be blessed. Furthermore, the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed, questioned why Pharaoh did not ask Joseph to teach him the Holy Language in secret, and not be submissive to Joseph out of fear that he might break his oath and reveal his secret. The essence of his answer is that the language of Hebrew is not called the Holy Language; rather, the Holy Language is the language of the Torah, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, stated, and therefore it is called the Holy Language, for all words of holiness that are spoken from the Holy One, blessed be He, to His prophets were only in it, thus said he, may his memory be blessed. Also, in the Holy Language, there are within it and deep within it gematriot, notarikon, and letter substitutions and combinations of the Holy Names, and one who speaks in this manner is a bearer of the Holy Spirit, and the listener and understander must also be a bearer of the Holy Spirit. This is what Joseph meant when he said to them, "God has sent me before you to establish for you a remnant in the land," and they understood the hidden meaning in his words, how many substitutions and gematriot, and they knew that he was speaking with the Holy Spirit, and this is proof that he is their brother. The Holy Spirit does not rest on a smooth tongue, and this is what is meant by "For the mouth that speaks to you in the Holy Language." And behold, after Joseph spoke with Pharaoh in the language of Hebrew, he again spoke with him in that same language, and showed him that he could speak a matter, and it could be understood from him in another way, and this cannot be taught to Pharaoh or someone like him, thus concluded the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Hebrew language as the "holy tongue" (leshon hakodesh) and its connection to divine communication. It emphasizes that true understanding and interpretation of sacred texts require a spiritual elevation (ruach hakodesh) both from the speaker and the listener. The dialogue between Joseph and Pharaoh illustrates that the depth of meaning in their conversation transcends mere words, revealing hidden insights and divine wisdom. Ultimately, the text underscores that the holy language embodies the essence of Torah and divine revelation, which cannot be fully grasped without spiritual insight.

passage_content: נמצא לפי"ז שהשבטים הק' כולם ידעו מסוד הזה שפרעה אינו יודע לדבר בלה"ק, כו א"א למצרי שיכיר בלה"ק, ומעתה יתורץ קושית העולם שהביא קז הישמח משה זלל"ה (לעיל קושיא ו') דאיך אמר יוסף לפרעה איתשל נמי אדידך, הא קיי"ל דצריך לפרוט הנדר, וקודם שיתירוהו איך יעבור על שבועתו, ולהנ"ל א"ש דהי' יכול להתיר שבועתו אצל השבטים הק' שידעו סודו וא"צ לפרוט להם. ואף אם יפרט להם לא יעבור על שבועתו כי מעיקרא הי' השבועה רק שלא יגלה סודו, ואין בכלל זה אם יאמר אותו למי שיודע, ואפשר שגם פרעה השיג שהשבטים יודעים בו, וע"כ הו' מתיירא ממ"ש לו אתשיל נמי אדידך והניחו לקבור את אביו כפרש"י ז"ל
translation: It is found according to this that all the holy tribes knew this secret that Pharaoh does not know how to speak in the Holy Tongue, and it is impossible for an Egyptian to recognize the Holy Tongue. From now on, the question of the world that was brought by the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed (above, question 6), is resolved: how did Joseph say to Pharaoh, "I will also give you a sign," when we hold that he must interpret the vow, and before it is permitted to him, how can he go against his oath? According to the above, it is clear that he could permit his vow in front of the holy tribes who knew his secret and he does not need to interpret it to them. And even if he were to explain it to them, he would not violate his oath, for initially the oath was only that he would not reveal his secret, and this does not include if he says it to someone who knows. And it is possible that Pharaoh also understood that the tribes know about him, and therefore he was afraid of what was said to him, "I will also give you a sign," and he allowed him to bury his father, as explained by our teacher Rashi, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the understanding of the holy tribes regarding Pharaoh's inability to speak Hebrew, which allows for the resolution of a theological question about Joseph's oath. It suggests that Joseph could have revealed his identity to Pharaoh without violating his oath, as the oath was only against revealing his secret to those who did not know it. The tribes' awareness of this secret provides a unique insight into the nature of oaths and the dynamics of divine providence, highlighting the interplay between human actions and divine will. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the importance of inner knowledge and the spiritual connections among the righteous.

passage_content: אמנם כי כן אם ידעו השבטים, מדוע באמת לא גילו סודו להמצרוים, והרי הם לא נשבעו לו שלא לגלות, ומדוע סבלו מגזירותיו גם שלא רצה ליתן רשות להעלות את אביהם לא"י, והי' בידם להעבירו ממלכותו ע"י שיגלו סודו למצריים, אמנם באמת לא היו רשאין לגלות סודו מטעם שבועה אחרת, שהוא בכלל איסור דחיקת הקץ, כי ניתן קץ וקצבה לגלותם במצרים ד' מאות שנה, ולחד דיעה במדרש כבר התחילה הגלות מלידת יצחק ולא היו רשאים ליקח חרות לעצמם ע"י שיעבירוהו ממלכותו וימלוך יוסף תחתיו, כמ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' וישב) עה"פ ויוסיפו עוד שנוא אותו וזלה"ק מסורת בידם שאין מלך לישראל קודם בני עשו, כמו שמבואר מנבואת רבקה וכו' וגם כתיב ואלה המלכים אשר מלכו באדום לפני מלך מלך בישראל, ובאמת יוסף מלך רק על מצרים, ולא הי' מלך גמור רק משנה עכ"ל, וביארתי בספרי ויואל משה דלוקח מלוכה וממשלה קודם זמנו הוא באיסור העברה על השבועות וביהרג ואל יעבור, ומה"ט דנו את יוסף למיתה, שנסתבב מן השמים טעות זה לידם, שחשבו שרצונו למלוך עליהם עיי"ש, והשתא אלמלא היו מגלים להמצריים שפרעה אינו יודע בלה"ק, והיו מעבירים אותו ממלכותו וימליכו את יוסף, נמצא היו מסייעים בפעולה זו ליקח מלוכה וממשלה קודם הזמן, וזה אסור ביהרג ואל יעבור, ומה"ט לא היו יכולים לגלות. ולפי זה באמת גם יוסף לא הי' יכול ליתשל על שבועתו ולגלות כנ"ל, אלא שאמר לפרעה איתשיל נמי אדידך כדי להפחידו, ופרעה הי' מתיירא מזה שמא לא יעמוד יוסף בנסיון ויגלה, ולטעם זה הרשהו לילך לא"י, אבל יוסף לעצמו לא הי' בדעתו לגלות אף אחר שישאל על נדרו, מטעם דעדיין ארי' רביע עלי' שלא ליקח מלוכה לפני הזמן, וא"ש מ"ש איתשל קנמי" אדודך, דהי' צורך להתרת שניהם, כי אף אם ישאל על שבועתו לפרעה, לא יכול למרוד בו ולעלות לא"י בלי רשותו כנ"ל
translation: Indeed, if the tribes knew, why did they not reveal his secret to the Egyptians? After all, they did not swear to him not to disclose it, and why did they suffer from his decrees, even when he did not want to grant permission to bring their father to the Land of Israel? They had the ability to remove him from his kingdom by revealing his secret to the Egyptians. However, in truth, they were not permitted to disclose his secret due to another oath, which is included in the prohibition of hastening the end, for a limit and a time was set for their exile in Egypt of four hundred years. According to one opinion in the Midrash, the exile began from the birth of Isaac, and they were not permitted to take freedom for themselves by transferring him from his kingdom and having Joseph reign in his place, as it is stated, "The joy of Moses, may his memory be blessed" (in Parashat Vayeshev) regarding the verse "And they continued to hate him," and it is said that it is a tradition in their hands that there is no king for Israel before the sons of Esau, as is explained from the prophecy of Rebecca, etc. It is also written, "And these are the kings who reigned in Edom before a king reigned over Israel." In truth, Joseph was only king over Egypt, and he was not a complete king, only a deputy. I have explained in my book "Vayoeil Moshe" that taking kingship and authority before its time is a prohibition of transgressing the oaths, and it is better to be killed than to transgress. For this reason, they judged Joseph to death, as this mistake was caused from Heaven, for they thought that he desired to reign over them. And now, had they revealed to the Egyptians that Pharaoh does not know Hebrew, and they had transferred him from his kingdom and made Joseph king in his place, they would have been assisting in this action to take kingship and authority before the time, which is forbidden to be killed rather than transgress. For this reason, they could not reveal it. According to this, indeed, Joseph also could not release himself from his oath and reveal as mentioned above, except that he said to Pharaoh, "I will also borrow from you" to frighten him, and Pharaoh was afraid that perhaps Joseph would not withstand the test and would reveal. For this reason, he allowed him to go to the Land of Israel, but Joseph himself did not intend to reveal even after he would be asked about his vow, because there was still a great lion upon him not to take kingship before the time. And it is clear what he meant by "I will borrow also from you," for there was a need to permit both, because even if he is asked about his vow by Pharaoh, he cannot rebel against him and go to the Land of Israel without his permission, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the reasons why the tribes of Israel did not reveal Joseph's secret to the Egyptians, despite not being sworn to silence. It emphasizes the concept of "not pushing the end," as the Israelites were bound by a divine decree regarding their time in Egypt, which was set for 400 years. The text highlights that taking power prematurely is forbidden, and even Joseph, despite his position, could not break his oath or act against this divine timing. Ultimately, the refusal to disclose the secret was rooted in a commitment to uphold these spiritual laws and the sanctity of divine timing.

passage_content: ואפ"ל מה שתלה יוסף התרת ב' השבועות חדא בחבירתא, עפי"ד הגמרא (כתובות ע"ז ע"ב) בר' יהושע בן לוו שאמר למלאך המות אחוי לי דוכתאי, אמר לי' לחיי, א"ל הב לי סכינך דלמא מיבעתת לי באורחה, יהבה ניהלי', כי מטא להתם דליי' קא מחוי לו', שוור נפל לההוא גיסא וכו', א"ל בשבועתא דלא אתינא, אמר הקב"ה אי איתשל אשבועתי' נהדר, אי לא לא ניהדר עכ"ד הגמרא. הרי מבואר דבשביל שלא איתשיל על שבועתו מימיו, ע"כ לא הכריחוהו מן השמים לותשל גם אשבועה זו, ואל"ה היו מכריחין אותו, ועד"ז הי' טענתו של יוסף הצדיק לפרעה, דבאמת אוכל לותשל על שבועתי ולגלות סודך למצריים אלא שמעולם לא שאלתי להתיר שבועתי, כי כן דרך הצדיקים והחסידים כדמצינו בר"י בן לוי, אבל אם תכריחני להתיר שבועת אבא, א"כ אהי' מוכרח להתיר גם שבועתך כדי שאוכל לקיים צוואת אבא על ידי שיעבירוך ממלכותך, וכל זה אז"ל להפחידו בעלמא כנ"ל ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר קרוב לזה, בהקדם מה שהקשו התוספות (סוטה ל"ו ע"ב) על מ"ש יוסף לפרעה איתשיל נמי אדידך, ותימה הלא לא הי' יכול לישאל על נדרו כ"א מדעתו של פרעה, כמו ההוא מעשה דצדקיהו ונבוכדנצר דמייתי בגמרא (נדרים ס"ה ע"א) וכו', ותירצו התוספות דשמא אוקמי' במלתא דגיזום בעלמא שגיזמו כך. מיהו לא הי' יכול לישאל עליו אי לא ניחא לי' לפרעה עכ"ל התוספות. והנה מקור האי דינא במסכת נדרים (ס"ה ע"א) תניא המודר הנאה מחברו אין מתירין לו אלא בפניו, ויליף לו' ממשה רבינו שא"ל הקב"ה במדין נדרת, לך והתר נדרך במדין, וכתב הר"ן שם דבירושלמי פליגי בטעמא דאין מתירין לו אלא בפניו, דאיכא מ"ד דס"ל טעמא דמילתא מפני החשד, כלומר שחבירו שהוא מודר ממנו לא ידע בהתירו, ויחשדנו שעובר על נדרו, ואיכא דיהיב טעמא מפני הבושה, כלומר שיתבייש מחכירו שהנדר הי' להנאתו ועכשיו רוצה שיתירו לו עכ"ד לעניננו,
translation: And even though what Yosef connected the annulment of the two oaths, one with the other, according to the words of the Gemara (Ketubot 77b) regarding Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, who said to the Angel of Death, "Show me my place," and he said to him, "For life," he said to him, "Give me your knife, lest it frighten me on the way," and it was given to him; when he arrived there, he pointed to him, and a bull fell on that side, etc. He said, "By the oath that I will not come," the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "If I will be released from my oath, I will be released; if not, I will not be released." Thus, it is clear that because he did not release himself from his oath in his days, therefore they did not compel him from Heaven to release this oath as well, and otherwise they would have compelled him. And similarly was the claim of Yosef the Righteous to Pharaoh, that in truth, I could release myself from my oath and reveal your secret to the Egyptians, but I have never asked to annul my oath, for this is the way of the righteous and the pious, as we find regarding Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. But if you compel me to annul my father's oath, then I will be compelled to annul your oath as well, so that I can fulfill my father's will by having you removed from your kingdom. All this was said to frighten him in the world, as mentioned. And it can also be said in another way close to this, by prefacing what the Tosafot (Sota 36b) asked on what Yosef said to Pharaoh, "I will also be released from your oath," and it is puzzling, for he could not ask about his vow except with Pharaoh's consent, like the story of Tzidkiyahu and Nebuchadnezzar that is brought in the Gemara (Nedarim 65a), etc. The Tosafot answered that perhaps we establish the matter as a mere trimming, that he trimmed it this way. However, he could not ask him if it was not agreeable to Pharaoh. Now, the source of this law is in the tractate Nedarim (65a), as it teaches that one who prohibits benefit from his friend is not permitted to be released except in his presence, and it is learned from Moshe Rabbeinu, who the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him in Midian, "You have vowed, go and annul your vow in Midian." And the Ran wrote there that the Jerusalem Talmud disagrees on the reason that one is not permitted to be released except in his presence, for there is one opinion that holds the reason of the matter is due to suspicion, meaning that his friend, who is prohibited from him, does not know of his release, and he will suspect him of transgressing his vow. And there is one who gives a reason due to shame, meaning that he will be embarrassed before his friend, since the vow was for his benefit, and now he wants him to release him. Thus, it is relevant to our matter.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of oaths and the integrity of the righteous, particularly through the lens of Joseph's interactions with Pharaoh. It emphasizes that Joseph, despite having the ability to break his oath, refrains from doing so out of respect for his father's vow and the principles upheld by the righteous. The text highlights the idea that divine intervention respects the commitments of the righteous, as seen in the story of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi and the angel of death, illustrating the tension between human obligations and divine will. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining one's word and the moral implications of oaths within the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content: וכתב הטורי זהב (יורה דעה סימן רכ"ח סעיף קטן כ"ח) דנפקא מינה בין הני תרי לישני דלמאן דאמר מפני החשד, דיו אם מודיע ההיתר לחבירו ואז מתירין לו אפילו בעל כרחו של המודר, דתו ליכא חשדא כיון שהודיעו, וללישנא דסבירא ליה מפני הבושה, באם יש להמשביע תועלת בשבועת הנשבע, צריך שיתן המשביע רצונו והסכמתו על התרת השבועה, ואין מתירין בע"כ של הנשבע, דזהו טעם מ"ד מפני הבושה עיי"ש, ובתשו' מהרי"ע (ח"א סימן קי"ח) כתב שהרשב"א הביא בשם ר"ת ז"ל, דהיכא דלא נדר בשביל טובה שעשה לו המודר, א"צ להתיר בפניו ומדעתו דוקא. דאל"כ האיך היה יכול להתיר שבועת יעקב שלא בפניו, ר"ל דהו"ל ליוסף למימר לפרעה שאין יכול להתיר שבועת אביו שלא בפניו, אלא שהקשה המהרי"ט על ר"ת ז"ל הלא פרעה עשה לו טובה אז כשהשביעו, ואיך אמר יוסף איתשיל נמי אדודך, הרי בכה"ג צ"ל מדעתו ורצונו של המשביע, ותירץ דלהפחידו בעלמא אמר כן, אמנם ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה הקשה על תירוצו, דאם באמת לא הי' יכול להתיר שבועתו מבלי דעתו ורצונו א"כ מה יועיל בהפחידו, דלמא לא ירך לבבו, וא"כ הוי שבועת יעקב ליוסף ח"ו כשבועת שוא כיון שאין בידו לקיימה בלי רשות פרעה, (וכמ"ש לעיל קושיא ו') והא תינח אם יכול לותשל על שבועת פרעה, הי' יכול להכריחו בזה, כמ"ש לו א"כ איתשל נמי אדידך ואגלה סודך, אבל אם אליבא דאמת א"א לותשל על שבועתו בלי רצונו א"כ הדרא קושיא לדוכתי', דלא הוי בידו לקיים שבועת יעקב, והוי ח"ו כשבועת שוא, וקושיא זו קשה גם על תירוץ התוספות דלהפחידו בעלמא אמר כן ואוקמי' במלתא דגיזום עיי"ש.
translation: And the Tur Hazahav (Yoreh De'ah 238:28) wrote that the practical difference between these two opinions is regarding the one who says it is due to suspicion, that it suffices if he informs his friend of the permit, and then they permit it to him even against the will of the one who is prohibited, for there is no suspicion since he informed him. And according to the opinion that holds it is due to shame, if the one who imposes the oath has a benefit from the oath of the one who swears, the one who imposes the oath must give his consent and agreement to permit the oath, and they do not permit it against the will of the one who swears, for this is the reason of the one who says it is due to shame, as explained there. And in the responsa of Mahari"t (Part 1, Siman 118) it is written that the Rashba brought in the name of R"T, that where he did not take a vow for the benefit that the prohibited one did for him, he does not need to permit it in his presence and specifically with his knowledge. For otherwise, how could he permit the oath of Jacob without his presence? Meaning, that Joseph should have told Pharaoh that he cannot permit his father's oath without his presence, except that Mahari"t challenged R"T, for Pharaoh did him a favor when he swore him, and how could Joseph say "I will also permit it for your sake," for in such a case it must be with the knowledge and will of the one who imposes the oath. And he answered that he said this merely to frighten him. However, the Yismach Moshe Z"L challenged his answer, for if he truly could not permit his oath without his knowledge and will, then what benefit is there in frightening him, perhaps his heart will not weaken. And if so, the oath of Jacob to Joseph would be, Heaven forbid, like a false oath since he cannot fulfill it without Pharaoh's permission (as mentioned above in question 6). And this is fine if he could permit it on Pharaoh's oath; he could compel him in this matter, as he said to him, "Then I will also permit it for your sake and reveal your secret." But if according to the truth it is impossible to permit it on his oath without his will, then the question returns to its place, that he would not be able to fulfill the oath of Jacob, and it would be, Heaven forbid, like a false oath. And this question is also difficult on the answer of the Tosafot that he said this merely to frighten him, and we establish it in the matter of a trimming, as explained there.
summary: The passage discusses the complexities of oaths and vows within Jewish law, particularly focusing on the conditions under which they can be annulled. It highlights the distinction between annulment due to suspicion versus embarrassment, emphasizing that the consent of the one who imposed the oath is necessary for its annulment in cases of embarrassment. The text also references the story of Joseph and Pharaoh, questioning the validity of an oath if it cannot be upheld without the other party's consent, thus raising theological concerns about the nature of authority and the power of words in the context of divine and human relationships. Ultimately, it reflects on the intricate balance between human agency and divine will in the observance of vows.

passage_content: ונדאה לתרץ בהקדם דברי ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה (בפ' ויגש) במ"ש יהודה ליוסף אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת אדונך. דטעם טענה זו שלא יאמר יוסף מה תועיל אם תשובו את בנימין, הלא גם על תנאי חל הנידוי וכו', לזה אמר יש בידי לקיים על ודי שאהרג אותך ואת אדוניך וכיון שיש בידי לקיים אינו חל הנידוי, וכתב קדושת זקיני זלל"ה שכיון בזה לדברי מהר"ם א"ש בספרו כתנות אור, והוא ז"ל הוסיף שם דבאמת לא הי' יכול לקיים מכח גבורת יוסף ומנשה, וגם שלא הי' יכול לשלוף החרב. רק דהוא הי' סבור שיכול לקיים, ע"כ הי' עצמותיו מגולגלין בארון עכ"ד. ועד"ז אפשר לתרץ גם לעניננו דיוסף הי' יכול להכריח לפרעה שיתן לו רשות להתיר שבועתו, שהי' פחדו ומוראו עליו, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל (בפרשת מקץ) עה"פ לכו אל יוסף אשר יאמר לכם תעשו, לפי שהי' יוסף אומר להם שימולו וכו', אמר להם כל אשר יאמר לכם תעשו, הרי, גזר על התבואה והרקובה, מה אם יגזור עלינו ונמות, עכ"ל רש"י וקיי"ל תלוה וזבין זביני' זבינא, דאגב אונס דמיתה גמר ומקנה לרצונו, וא"כ אף למ"ד דס"ל המשביע ע"ד חבירו אין יכול להתיר כ"א ברצונו, מ"מ הי' יכול להכריחו, ואגב אונסא יתירנו ברצונו, וא"ש דהי' בידו להתיר שבועת פרעה עפ"י הלכה. וא"כ שוב לא הוי שבועת יעקב שוא חיו, כיון דהי' בידו לקיימו ע"ו שיכריח לפרעה להתיר שבועתו.
translation: And we will explain promptly the words of K"Z the holy master, may his memory be a blessing (in Parshat Vayigash), regarding what Judah said to Joseph, "If you will accuse me, I will kill you and your master." The reason for this claim is so that Joseph would not say, "What benefit is there if you return Benjamin? After all, the excommunication applies conditionally, etc." Therefore, he said, "I have the ability to fulfill my word that I will kill you and your master," and since I have the ability to fulfill it, the excommunication does not apply. The holiness of my grandfather, may his memory be a blessing, wrote that he refers here to the words of the Maharam Ash, in his book Ketonot Or, and he, blessed be he, added there that in truth he could not fulfill it due to the might of Joseph and Menashe, and also that he could not draw the sword. Rather, he thought he could fulfill it; therefore, his bones were rolled in the coffin, thus far his words. Similarly, it is possible to explain also in our matter that Joseph could force Pharaoh to grant him permission to annul his oath, for he was afraid of him and in awe of him, as Rashi, may his memory be a blessing, writes (in Parshat Miketz) on the verse "Go to Joseph; whatever he says to you, do," for Joseph was telling them to circumcise, etc. He said to them, "Whatever he says to you, do," behold, he decreed on the grain and the rotten, what if he decrees upon us and we die, thus Rashi concludes. And we hold that one can lend and sell, and due to the coercion of death, he concludes and acquires at his will. Therefore, even according to the opinion that holds that one who administers an oath on behalf of another cannot annul it except at his will, nonetheless, he could force him, and due to the coercion, he would annul it at his will. And it is clear that he had the ability to annul Pharaoh's oath according to halacha. Therefore, it would no longer be that Jacob's oath was in vain, since he had the ability to fulfill it, as he would force Pharaoh to annul his oath.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of Judah's plea to Joseph, emphasizing the concept of authority and the power of intention in fulfilling vows. It suggests that Judah believed he could uphold his threat against Joseph and his master, despite the impossibility of actually carrying it out due to Joseph's strength. The text further explores the idea that Joseph could compel Pharaoh to release him from his oath, thus maintaining the integrity of his vow. Ultimately, it highlights the interplay between human agency, divine providence, and the nature of oaths within the framework of Jewish law.

passage_content: ומתוריז נמי קושייתנו הנ"ל (קושיא ה') דהאיך יתיר שבועתו הא צריך לפרוע השבועה, וקודם שיתיר איך יעבור על שבועתו ולהנ"ל א"ש, דהי' בידו להכריח לפרעה שיפרט שבועתו, ואין נפק"מ להלכה מי יפרט השבועה לפני המתירין, אלא שאליבא דאמת לא הי' רשאי להרגו ולמרוד בו, מטעם האיסור של דחיקת הקץ כנ"ל, אלא שהי' מספיק הפחדה זו לפרעה, כי פרעה חשב שלא יעמוד יוסף בנסיון ולא ימנע משום איסור הנ"ל, ולטעם זה נתן לו רשות וא"ל עלה וקבור את אביך כאשר השביעך, ובזה מתורצים קושיות הנ"ל.
translation: And also regarding our earlier question (question 5) of how he can permit his oath, as he needs to fulfill the oath, and before he permits it, how can he transgress his oath, it is understood as follows: he had the ability to compel him to fulfill his oath, and it does not matter for halacha who will specify the oath before the permitters. However, according to the truth, he was not permitted to kill him and rebel against him, due to the prohibition of pushing off the end, as mentioned above. Nevertheless, this intimidation was sufficient for Pharaoh, for Pharaoh thought that Joseph would not withstand the test and would not refrain from the aforementioned prohibition. For this reason, he granted him permission and said to him, "Go up and bury your father as you swore to him," and with this, the earlier questions are resolved.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between the obligation to fulfill an oath and the concept of "pushing off the end" (דחיקת הקץ) in Hasidic thought. It suggests that while one must honor their commitments, there are circumstances where divine providence allows for exceptions, particularly when faith and trust in God are at play. The fear that Pharaoh had regarding Joseph's potential failure in his trial reflects a deeper understanding of human limitations and the reliance on divine assistance. Ultimately, the resolution of the questions posed lies in the interplay between human agency and divine will, emphasizing the importance of faith in navigating moral dilemmas.

passage_content: ובזה יתורצו יתר הקושיות והדקדוקים הנ"ל, דלכאורה מדוע הוצרך יאע"ה להשביע את יוסף להעלותו ממצרים, וכי זולת השבועה לא היה משתדל לקיים רצון אביו, אתמהה. וכבר העירו המפרשים בזה, ופי' דהשיג יאע"ה ברוה"ק שאילולי השבועה הזאת הי' פרעה מעכב בידו, אלא לפי שהי' רמיא עלי' שבועתו של יעקב, ע"כ הסכים פרעה בע"כ. כמו שפרש"י ז"ל עה"פ עלה וקבור את אביך כאשר השביעך, דאם לא בשביל השבועה לא הייתי מנוחך, אבל ירא לומר עבור על השבועה שלא יאמר א"כ אעבור על השבועה שנשבעתי לך שלא אגלה על לה"ק שאינך מכיר בו, עכ"ל. אמנם באמת הי' אפשרות ליוסף לקיים צוואתו של אביו אף זולת השבועה, ע"י שישאל על שבועתו שנשבע לפרעה, ויגלה סודו שאין מכיר בלה"ק ויעבירוהו לפרעה ממלכותו וימלוך יוסף תחתיו, ושוב יהי' ברשותו לקיים מצות אביו, וא"כ צורך השבועה למה, אולם לא הי' רשאי לעשות כן מטעם איסור של דחיקת הקץ כנ"ל, ומעתה נאמר דבאותה שבועה שהשביע יעקב ליוסף ונשאתני ממצרים וקברתני בקבורתם, גלגל עמה עוד שבועה אחרת על דחיקת הקץ, דאל"כ לא הי' צורך גם לשבועה זו, דלא הי' נחשד יוסף בעיני אביו שלא יקיים צוואתו אף זולת השבועה, והי' בידו לקיימה בכל אופן אף אם לא ירשהו פרעה, ע"ו שיגלה סודו כנ"ל, אלא שהשביעו יעקב אבינו גם על זאת, שלא יעשה שום פעולה של דחיקת הקץ שהוא ביהרג ואל יעבור ויש בו סכנה לכל ישראל ח"ו ולטעם זה הי' צורך לשבועה האחרת כדי להפחיד את פרעה על ידו, וב' השבועות הללו הא' כרוך בצד חבירתה.
translation: And with this, the remaining questions and the aforementioned nuances will be resolved, for it seems that why did Yaakov Avinu need to swear Yosef to take him up from Egypt? Would he not have made an effort to fulfill his father's wishes without the oath? I am astonished. The commentators have already noted this, and they explained that Yaakov Avinu understood through the Holy Spirit that were it not for this oath, Pharaoh would have prevented him. However, since he was bound by the oath of Yaakov, Pharaoh agreed against his will. As Rashi, of blessed memory, explained on the verse "Go up and bury your father as he made you swear," that if not for the oath, I would not have allowed you to rest, but he was afraid to say that he would transgress the oath, lest it be said that he would violate the oath he swore to you not to reveal the Holy Language that you do not recognize. However, in truth, it was possible for Yosef to fulfill his father's command even without the oath, by asking about the oath he swore to Pharaoh, and revealing his secret that he does not recognize the Holy Language, and they would transfer him from Pharaoh's kingdom and Yosef would reign in his place, and then it would be in his power to fulfill his father's command. If so, what was the need for the oath? However, he was not permitted to do so due to the prohibition of hastening the end, as mentioned above. From this, we can say that in that oath that Yaakov swore to Yosef, "And you shall carry me up from Egypt and bury me in their burial," he also included another oath regarding hastening the end, for otherwise there would have been no need for this oath either, as Yosef would not have been suspected in his father's eyes of not fulfilling his command even without the oath, and he would have been able to fulfill it in any case even if Pharaoh would not permit him, through revealing his secret as mentioned above. Rather, Yaakov Avinu also swore him regarding this, that he should not take any action of hastening the end, which is a matter of "be killed and not transgress," and it poses a danger to all of Israel, Heaven forbid. For this reason, there was a need for the other oath to frighten Pharaoh through him, and these two oaths are intertwined with each other.
summary: In this passage, the author explores the necessity of Joseph's oath to his father Jacob regarding his burial in Canaan, emphasizing that without this oath, Pharaoh might have obstructed Joseph's efforts. The text suggests that Joseph could have fulfilled his father's wishes through other means, but he was bound by the prohibition against hastening the end of time (d'chak haketz). Jacob's oath not only secured Joseph's commitment but also implicitly included a vow against taking actions that could jeopardize the future of the Jewish people. Thus, the dual oaths reflect a profound interplay between divine providence and human responsibility within the framework of Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ויתורץ בזה כפל השבועות שבפסוק, באמרו שים נא ידך תחת ירכי, פרש"י והשבע, וה"ה ציווי על השבועה, ואחר שאמר יוסף אנכי אעשה כדבריך כתיב ויאמר השבעה לי, וכבר צוהו על השבועה ומה צורך לכפול ולהשביעו (עיין לעיל קושיא ב'). ולדרכנו ב' שבועות אמורים כאן. שחוץ מהשבועה להעלותו לא"י, השביעו עוד על איסור דחיקת הקץ, וכ"כ בעלי התוספות (סו"פ ויחי) עה"פ ויאמר יוסף אל אחיו אנכי מת ואלקים פקד יפקוד אתכם וגו' וישבע יוסף את בני ישראל לאמר פקד יפקוד אלקים אתכם וגו', תימא למה אמר ב' פעמים פקד יפקוד, הכי הו"ל למכתב אנכי מת והשבעו לי כי כאשר פקד יפקד אלקים אתכם והעליתם את עצמותי וגו', וי"ל דה"ק, יעקב אבינו אמר פקד יפקוד וגו' ולכן כאשר פקד יפקוד אלקים אתכם וגו', והה"ד אנכי אעשה כדבריך דריש סידרא עכ"ד התוספות. ובבעה"ט כתב שם, וז"ל: במדרש יש שהשביעם יוסף שלא ידחקו את הקץ, כי יוסף ידע את הקץ שיעקב גילה לו, עכ"ל. ומפורש כן בתרגום יוב"ע עה"פ וישבע יוסף את בני ישראל וגו' וז"ל ואומי יוסף ית בני ישראל למימר לבניהון הא אתון משתעבדין במצרים, ולא תזידון למיסק ממצרים עד זמן דייתון תרין פרוקין ויימרון לכון מדכר דכיר ד' יתכון, ובעודן דאתון סלקין תסקון ית גרמי מיכא עכ"ל, מבואר שבמ"ש וישבע יוסף את בני ישראל לאמר פקד יפקוד וגו' והעליתם את עצמותי וגו', השביעם בשני שבועות, שלא ידחקו הקץ, ועל העלאת עצמותיו, וכן השביע יעקב את יוסף, וז"ש יוסף אנכי אעשה כדבריך, ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הובא בבעה"ת ויאמר אנכי אעשה כדבריך, כשם שאתה מצוני, כך אני מצוה לאחי בשעת מיתתי וכו' וכן מצינו שאמר לאחיו פקד יפקוד אלקים אתכם וגו' ולדרכנו כל זה הו' נכלל בשבועת ועאע"ה, שלא ידחקו ישראל את הקץ ושלא ימרודו באומות להעלותו בע"כ ושלא ברצונם, וע"ד כן השביע יוסף את בנ"י, שכ"ז היה נכלל בצוואתו של יאע"ה וז"ש אנכי אעשה כדבריך.
translation: The explanation of the doubling of the oaths in the verse is as follows: when he said, "Please place your hand under my thigh," Rashi explains that he swore, and this is also a command regarding the oath. After Joseph said, "I will do as you have spoken," it is written, "And he said, 'Swear to me.'" He was already commanded regarding the oath, so what is the need to double and make him swear? (See above for the question). According to our approach, two oaths are mentioned here. Besides the oath to bring him up to the Land of Israel, he also swore him regarding the prohibition of hastening the end. The Tosafists also wrote (in the end of Vayechi) on the verse, "And Joseph said to his brothers, 'I am dying, and God will surely visit you...'" and "Joseph swore the children of Israel, saying, 'God will surely visit you...'" It is puzzling why he said "surely visit" twice; it would have sufficed to write, "I am dying, and swear to me that as God will surely visit you, you will bring up my bones..." One could say that he meant to say, "Our father Jacob said, 'God will surely visit...'" and therefore, "when God will surely visit you..." and the meaning of "I will do as you have spoken" is derived from the order of the verse, thus explained by Tosafot. In the Be'er HaTev, it is written there, and I quote: "In the Midrash, there are those who say that Joseph swore them not to hasten the end, for Joseph knew the end that Jacob revealed to him." Thus, it is explicitly stated in the Targum Yonatan on the verse, "And Joseph swore the children of Israel..." and it says, "And Joseph said to the children of Israel to tell their children, 'You are enslaved in Egypt, and you shall not hasten to go out of Egypt until the time of your two redeemers, and you will remember the name of the Lord your God.'" And while you are ascending, you will be saved by your own merit. It is clear that in the statement, "And Joseph swore the children of Israel, saying, 'God will surely visit you...'" and "You will bring up my bones..." he swore them with two oaths: not to hasten the end and regarding the raising of his bones, and likewise Jacob swore Joseph. Therefore, Joseph said, "I will do as you have spoken," and this clarifies the words of the Midrash brought in the Be'er HaTev, "And he said, 'I will do as you have spoken,' just as you commanded me, so I command my brothers at the time of my death..." and so we find that he said to his brothers, "God will surely visit you..." According to our approach, all this is included in the oath of the Patriarchs, that Israel should not hasten the end and should not rebel against the nations to bring him up against their will and without their consent. Thus, Joseph swore the children of Israel, for all this was included in the command of the Patriarchs, and that is why he said, "I will do as you have spoken."
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of the oaths made by Joseph to the Israelites, emphasizing the importance of not hastening the redemption and the proper timing for their ascent to the Land of Israel. It highlights that Joseph, aware of the prophetic timeline revealed to Jacob, instructed his brothers to refrain from forcing the end of their exile. This reflects a broader Hasidic teaching on the significance of patience and divine timing in the unfolding of redemption, as well as the interconnectedness of their actions with God's plan. Ultimately, Joseph's oath serves as a reminder of the need for faith and adherence to divine will in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הגמרא יבמות (ס"ג ע"ב) גזרו על ג' מפני ג' (פרש"י מפני ג' עבירות) קא מחטטו שכבי מפני ששמחים ביום אידם, פרש"י מחטטו שכבי מוציאים הנקברים מקבריהם, מפני ששמחים ביום אידם באה עליהם זו הגזירה להתאבל בה. וכתב המהרש"ל שם, נ"ל מדה כנגד מדה דמאחר שאתה משמח עמהם ביום אידם, א"כ אתה אוכל עמהם, אפילו אתה אוכל משלך, מ"מ חשב הכתוב כאילו אתה אוכל מזבחו, שנאמר וקרא לך ואכלת מזבחו אפי' משעת הקריאה, כדאי' במס' ע"ז ישראלים בזמה"ז עוע"ז בטהרה הן וכו', וא"כ מאחר שזבחיהם קרוי זבחי מתים ע"כ באה המדה לשלם ענין המתים עכ"ל המהרש"ל זלל"ה. ובעוה"ר הגיע עלינו הצרה הזאת של חטוטו שכבי, ומעולם לא נעשתה כזאת בישראל, ולא קרה לנו ככה אף בדוחות הגלות בין האומה"ע, ומי הי' יכול לצייר בדורות שלפנינו שימצא כזאת, שאותם המכנים עצמם בשם ישראל מחטטום קברות הקדושים של תנאים ואמוראים, אמנם כבר גילו לנו חז"ל שהוא מידה כנגד מידה בעון ששמחים על יום אידם, וכל אלו שלוקחים חבל באידם של מלכות המינות ושמחים עמהם אפילו אם אינו אוכל עמהם ה"ה כאוכל זבחי מתים כמ"ש המהרש"ל ז"ל, והם הן הגורמים לחטוטי שכבי בעוה"ר.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Gemara in Yevamot (63b): They decreed against three because of three (Rashi explains: because of three transgressions) that they dig up graves because they rejoice on their festival day. Rashi explains that they dig up graves, taking the buried ones out of their graves, because they rejoice on their festival day, this decree comes upon them to mourn. And the Maharsha"l wrote there, it seems to me measure for measure, since you rejoice with them on their festival day, therefore you eat with them, even if you eat from your own, nonetheless the scripture considers it as if you are eating from their sacrifice, as it is said, "And he calls you and you eat from his sacrifice," even from the time of the calling, as it is stated in the tractate Avodah Zarah, that Israelites in this time are idolaters in purity, etc. And therefore, since their sacrifices are called the sacrifices of the dead, thus the measure comes to repay the matter of the dead, so said the Maharsha"l, may his memory be blessed. And woe to us, this distress of digging up graves has come upon us, and such a thing has never been done in Israel, nor has it happened to us even in the pressures of exile among the nations of the world, and who could have imagined in the generations before us that such a thing would be found, that those who call themselves by the name of Israel dig up the holy graves of the Tanaim and Amoraim. Indeed, our sages have already revealed to us that it is measure for measure for the sin of rejoicing on their festival day, and all those who take part in the festival of the kingdom of heresy and rejoice with them, even if they do not eat with them, they are like one who eats the sacrifices of the dead, as the Maharsha"l, may his memory be blessed, has said, and they are the ones who cause the digging up of graves, woe to us.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine retribution, emphasizing the principle of "measure for measure" (מידה כנגד מידה) in relation to the joy expressed by certain individuals on the festivals of idolaters. It highlights that those who partake in the celebrations of the wicked, even indirectly, are considered as if they are consuming offerings to the dead, leading to the tragic consequence of desecrating the graves of the righteous. The author reflects on the unprecedented nature of this calamity in Jewish history, attributing it to the sins of those who align themselves with idolatrous practices. Ultimately, it serves as a warning about the spiritual dangers of associating with non-Jewish celebrations and the resulting consequences on the Jewish community.

passage_content: והנה יעקב אבינו ע"ה השיג ברוח הקודש כל מה שיארע לישראל בכל הדורות עד עת קץ עיקבתא דמשיחא, כמבואר בדרז"ל שמסר לכל שבט ושבט כל מה שיארע להם עד סוף כל הדורות וזה ירמוז באמרו ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, דלכאורה הול"ל ועשית לו חסד ואמת, אמנם יעקב אבינו לא הי' צורך בשבול עצמו לחסד של אמת. כו שילם לו גמולו כאמרם ז"ל, ולזה לא אמר ועשית לי חסד ואמת אלא שבמ"ש שים נא ידך תחת ירכי (והשבע לי) השביעו על איסור של דחיקת הקץ כנ"ל, גם השביעו שישביע גם הוא את בני ישראל בזה ועי"ז יעשה חסד של אמת עם כל המתים של כללות ישראל, שאם יהיו ישראל נשמרים בזה, לא יענשו המתים בעון החיים, וז"ש ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, ר"ל שעמדי ועל ידי תעשה חסד של אמת עם כל מתי ישראל, ע"י שתקיים צוואתי וגם אתה תשביעם כמוני, וגם כי יע"א לא מת ומרגיש בצרתן של ישראל ומבקש עליהם רחמים וע"כ ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, שגם אני אהי' עמהם לעזור להם מצרתם. אלא שישמרו עצמם בדבר זה, ועוד צוהו פעם שנית השבעה לי, זו היתה השבועה השני' להעלותו ממצרים, והי' צורך בו בשביל פרעה דאילולי כן לא הי' מניחו וא"ש כפל השבועות והבן.
translation: And behold, our father Jacob, peace be upon him, attained through the Holy Spirit all that would happen to Israel throughout the generations until the end of days, the footsteps of the Messiah, as explained in the teachings of our sages, that he conveyed to each tribe all that would occur to them until the end of all generations. This is hinted at in his saying, "And you shall do with me kindness and truth," for it could have been said, "And you shall do with him kindness and truth." However, our father Jacob did not need to ask for kindness of truth for himself, for he had already received his reward, as our sages have said. Therefore, he did not say, "And you shall do for me kindness and truth," but rather, in what he said, "Please place your hand under my thigh (and swear to me)," he made him swear regarding the prohibition of hastening the end, as mentioned above. He also made him swear that he would also make the children of Israel swear in this matter, and through this, he would perform kindness of truth with all the dead of the entirety of Israel, for if Israel would guard themselves in this, the dead would not be punished for the sins of the living. And this is what he meant by saying, "And you shall do with me kindness and truth," meaning that through me and by your doing so, you will perform kindness of truth with all the dead of Israel, by fulfilling my command and you will also make them swear like me. Furthermore, may it be said, he does not die and feels the suffering of Israel and asks for mercy for them, and therefore, "And you shall do with me kindness and truth," that I too will be with them to help them in their distress. However, they must guard themselves in this matter. Additionally, he commanded him a second time, "Swear to me," this was the second oath to bring him up from Egypt, and it was necessary for him because of Pharaoh, for otherwise he would not have allowed him. And this explains the repetition of the oaths; understand this.
summary: יעקב אבינו השיג ברוח הקודש את כל מה שיתרחש לישראל עד קץ הימים, ומסר לכל שבט את גורלו. הוא ביקש מהקב"ה חסד ואמת, לא עבור עצמו אלא כדי להבטיח חסד עם המתים, בכך שישראל ישמרו על צוואתו וימנעו מעונש על חטאי החיים. השבעתו של יעקב לשמור על איסור דחיקת הקץ נועדה להבטיח את גאולת ישראל, והוא גם מבקש להישאר עם בניו לעזור להם בצרותיהם. השבעה השנייה נועדה להבטיח את עלייתם ממצרים, כדי להתמודד עם פרעה.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל חסד שעושים עם המתים שהכוונה על כל מתי ישראל, כדרכנו לעיל. דהנה שני דברים הן המה הדוחים ומאחרים קץ גאולתינו, עון של דחיקת הקץ וחטא הידוע כמבואר בדרז"ל. ואילולי כן כבר היינו נגאלים. ובפדר"א (פמ"ח) משמע שבעון בני אפרים שדחקו את הקץ ויצאו קודם הזמן. ניתוסף לישראל השעבוד והגזירה עוד ל' שנים עיי"ש. נמצא במה שישמרו ישראל ולא יעברו על דחיקת הקץ יהיו עושים חסד עם כל מתו ישראל, שלא יתאחר עת תחייתם, וע"כ יעאע"ה בצוותו את יוסף והשביעו על איסור דחיקת הקץ, אמר ועשית עמדי" חסד ואמת ר"ל על ודי. אם תקיים מצותי תעשה חסד של אמת עם המתים של כללות ישראל, שמצפים על עת התחי', ובעוה"ר בעון דחיקת הקץ נתאחר תחייתם. ובזה א"ש למה פרשה זו סתומה. דלכאורה הי' ראוי להיות מקומה של הסתומה להלן אצל ויגוע ויאסף אל עמיו (עיין לעיל קושיא א') ולדרכנו בשעה שהשביעם יעאע"ה על דחיקת הקץ, הרגישו מיד שקץ הגאולה רחוקה ומי יודע אם לא יתארך עוד בעון דחיקת הקץ, אם לא יוכלו ישראל לעמוד בנסיון ח"ו וע"כ מיד נסתמו עיניהם ולבם מצרת השעבוד, אף שבפועל לא הגיע אליהם השעבוד כ"ז שא' מהשבטים הי' קיים, אבל כבר השיגוה בעיני שכלם ונסתמו עיניהם ולבם מיד.
translation:
Another aspect of the kindness done with the dead refers to all the deceased of Israel, as we have explained above. For behold, there are two things that delay and postpone the end of our redemption: the sin of hastening the end and the known sin as explained in the teachings of our sages. Were it not for this, we would have already been redeemed. And in Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer (Chapter 58), it is implied that due to the sin of the sons of Ephraim, who hastened the end and left before the time, an additional forty years of servitude and decree were added to Israel, as stated there. Therefore, when Israel refrains from transgressing the hastening of the end, they are doing kindness with all the deceased of Israel, so that the time of their resurrection will not be delayed. And thus, when he (Joseph) commanded and swore them regarding the prohibition of hastening the end, he said, "And you shall do kindness and truth with me," meaning with certainty. If you fulfill my commandments, you will do true kindness with the dead of all of Israel, who are awaiting the time of resurrection, and due to our sins, the sin of hastening the end has delayed their resurrection. 

And this explains why this section is closed. For it would seem that the place of the closed section should be later, near "and he died and was gathered to his people" (see above, question 1). According to our explanation, at the moment he swore them regarding the hastening of the end, they immediately felt that the end of redemption was far away, and who knows if it would not be prolonged further due to the sin of hastening the end, if Israel would not be able to withstand the trial, Heaven forbid. Therefore, their eyes and hearts were immediately closed due to the distress of servitude, even though in practice the servitude had not yet reached them as long as one of the tribes was still alive. However, it had already been perceived in their minds, and their eyes and hearts were immediately closed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of performing kindness (chesed) towards the deceased, specifically the souls of all Israel, by refraining from actions that hasten the end of days (dachikat haketz). It emphasizes that the sins of pushing the redemption can delay the resurrection of the dead, and by adhering to the commandments, one can ensure that the timing of resurrection is not postponed. The text also highlights the emotional burden felt by the Israelites when reminded of their potential suffering due to these sins, leading to a sense of despair about the redemption's timeline. Ultimately, it underscores the interconnectedness of the living and the dead in the context of redemption and divine timing.

passage_content: באופן אחר יתיישבו הדקדוקים הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי הגמרא (תענית דף ה' ע"ב) ר"נ ור"י הוו יתבי בסעודתא וכו' א"ל הכי אר"י יעקב אבינו לא מת, א"ל וכי בכדי ספדו ספדנוא וחנטו חנטייא וקברו קברייא, א"ל מקרא אני דורש שנאמר ואתה אל תירא עבדי יעקב נאם ד' וגו' כי הנני מושיעך מרחוק ואת זרעך מארץ שביים מקיש הוא לזרעו מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים, עכ"ל הגמרא, והקשו המפרשים דאכתי לא מתורץ שאלתו, וכי בכדי חנטו חנטייא, וק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה דקדק דהו"ל להקשות איך חנטו חנטיא עיי"ש.
translation: In another way, the aforementioned nuances can be clarified by the earlier words of the Gemara (Taanit 5b): "Rabbi Nachman and Rabbi Yitzchak were sitting at a meal, etc. He said to him, 'Is it true that our father Jacob did not die?' He replied, 'Did we not eulogize him, embalm him, and bury him?' He said, 'I derive from a verse, as it is said, "And you, do not fear, My servant Jacob," says the Lord, "for behold, I will save you from afar and your offspring from the land of their captivity." It connects him to his offspring: just as his offspring are alive, so too he is alive.' Thus concludes the Gemara. The commentators have questioned that his question is still not resolved: 'Did they not embalm him?' And thus, Rabbi Moshe Zt"l was precise in asking how they embalmed him, as mentioned there."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the eternal life of the soul, as illustrated by the dialogue between Rabbi Nachman and Rabbi Yochanan regarding Jacob's death. It emphasizes that just as Jacob's descendants are alive, so too is Jacob himself, reflecting the Hasidic belief in the continuity of spiritual existence beyond physical death. The text highlights the importance of understanding the connection between the living and the deceased, suggesting that the spiritual essence remains vibrant and influential. This underscores a key theological insight in Hasidism about the enduring nature of the soul and its relationship to the divine.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים להעיר עוד, דהנה כמו"כ חנוך ואלי' ואליעזר עבד אברהם וריב"ל נכנסו חיים לג"ע ולא הרגישו טעם מיתה כלל, אמנם נשתנה בחי' יעאע"ה מכל אלו. שאף שלא מת והוא בחיים אתנו, אעפ"כ חנטוהו וספדוהו וקברוהו כדי להסתיר ולהעלים הענין, ולכאורה ראוי להבין מדוע הי' צורך והכרח להעלמה זו, ומצינו באליהו כשעלה בסערה השמימה נתפרסם הענין ומפורש בכתובים, וביע"א עשו כל השתדלות להסתיר הענין, ואף הכתוב לא גילהו, לולא קבלת חז"ל שגילו לנו ע"י לימוד גז"ש, ודא ודאי טעמא בעי.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will first point out that, behold, just as Chanokh, Eliyahu, and Eliezer, the servant of Avraham, and Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai entered alive into Gan Eden and did not feel the taste of death at all, so too, the aspect of Ya'akov Avinu is different from all of these. For although he did not die and is alive with us, nevertheless, they embalmed him, eulogized him, and buried him in order to conceal and hide the matter. At first glance, it is appropriate to understand why there was a need and necessity for this concealment. And we find that with Eliyahu, when he ascended in a whirlwind to the heavens, the matter was publicized and explicitly stated in the writings. Yet, in the case of Ya'akov, they made every effort to conceal the matter, and even the scripture did not reveal it, were it not for the tradition of our Sages who revealed it to us through the study of a verbal analogy. And this certainly requires an explanation.
summary: The passage discusses the unique case of Enoch and Elijah, who ascended to heaven without experiencing death, contrasting them with the patriarch Abraham, who was mourned and buried despite being alive. It raises the question of why there was a need to conceal Abraham's true state, noting that while Elijah's ascent was publicly acknowledged, Abraham's was hidden. This concealment serves a deeper theological purpose, suggesting that certain spiritual truths are meant to be obscured from public knowledge, as revealed through the teachings of the sages. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the complexity of life, death, and divine revelation within Hasidic thought.
