passage_content: ומעתה נבוא לבאר סתירת מאמרי רז"ל בענין התחלת השעבוד, והוא שכתב רש"י ז"ל בשם מדרשי חז"ל דמשמת יעקב נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, ובמקו"א אמרו דכ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים וכ"ז שהי' א' מהשבטים קיים לא נשתעבדו המצריים בישראל כלל, וכבר ביארנו בזה בפנים שונים, ואפ"ל בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק פ' ויחי (רט"ז ע"ב) ויחי יעקב באמ"צ אמאי פרשתא דא סתימא ר' יעקב אמר בשעתא דמית יעקב אסתימו עיניהון דישראל (ובניצוצי אורות בפי' על הזוה"ק כתב בשם המפרשים דהכוונה על עסק התורה, שנסתמו מישראל מעיינות החכמה שהי' יעקב מגלה עכ"ל) ר' יהודה אמר דכדין נחתו לגלותא ואשתעבידו בהון עכ"ד הזוה"ק לעניננו, ונל"פ דלא פליגי ר' יעקב ור"י, ואפשר דשניהם מודים דלא נשתעבדו ישראל בעבודת המצרים משמת יעקב, דכ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים הי' מלך ומושל עליהם נמנע מהם האפשרות לשעבד בישראל אף אם הי' רצונם בכך, וכ"ז שא' מהשבטים קיים אמרז"ל שלא נשתעבדו בישראל, אמנם הכוונה בזה לבחי' שעבוד אחרת, עפימ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה בפ' בלק, שאין דבר בעולם מזיק לנפש כמו התחברות עם אדם רשע אף לפי שעה, אף אם אינו ניכר נכנס בנפש כמו העכס וארס וברוב הימים ימצא, וצריך לזה זכות גדול בצירוף העסק בתורה שיצא ממנו העכס והארס כולי האי ואולי אחר זמן רב עכ"ל, ואפ"ל לאידך גיסא כו המצרים לא השתעבדו בישראל כלל כ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים, אדרבה לצד שהם בני משפחתו של יוסף שהי' מלך ומושל עליהם, נהגו בהם נימוס של כבוד כמשפט בני המלכים, והראו להם אותות אהבה ואחוה וריעות, וההתחברות עם רשעים גורם רעה לבחינת הנפש יותר מהשתעבדות עבודתם, והבאנו לעיל מדברי הירושלמי שדרשו ז"ל ונתן עול ברזל על צווארך זה הרעיון, שפגימת כלו המחשבה נקרא עול ברזל ושעבוד קשה, אמנם כל זמן שהי' יעקב אבינו קיים ולמד עמהם תורה וגילה להם מעיינות החכמה, לא פעלו עליהם דיבורם וחלקלקות לשונם של מצרים לרוע ונתבטלו כאפס ואין לנגד השפעת הקדושה שהשפיע יע"א אליהם, אבל בשעתא דמית יעקב נסתמו מהם מעיינות החכמה שהי' מגלה להם, ע"כ כדין נחתו לגלותא ואשתעבודו בהון, ולא שעבוד בעבודה כ"א ע"י דיבוריהם והתחברותם, ולפי"ז דברי ר' יעקב ור' יהודה בזוה"ק הנ"ל על קוטב א' יסובבו, דלפי שנסתמו מהם מעיינות החכמה ע"כ התחילה השעבוד בהם, ומ"ש רז"ל דכ"ז שיוסף קיים וכ"ז שא' מהשבטים קיים לא נשתעבדו בהם בישראל אפ"ל ג"כ עפ"י בחי' הנ"ל, דעכ"פ כ"ז שהי' יוסף וא' מהשבעום קיים, אף שנחלש ונתמעט כח הקדושה בהסתלקות יע"א, מ"מ לגודל קדושתם של השבטים הק' לא יכלו המצריים להתגבר עליהם בכח טומאתם, אלא מדרגא לדרגא השתעבדו בהם בבחי' הנפש תחלה, בהסתלקות יע"א, ואח"כ במיתת יוסף הצדיק ויותר מזה במיתת השבטים, אבל השעבוד בעבודה אולי התחילה רק שלשים שנה לפני יציאתם ממצרים כמ"ש בפרדר"א.
translation: And from now on, we will explain the contradiction in the statements of our Sages regarding the beginning of the servitude. It is written by Rashi, blessed be his memory, in the name of the Midrashim of our Sages that from the time of Jacob, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed to the distress of the servitude. In another place, they said that as long as Joseph was alive and as long as one of the tribes was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel at all. We have already explained this in various contexts, and it can be said that in light of the words of the Zohar in Parashat Vayechi (116b), "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," why is this section closed? Rabbi Jacob said that at the time of Jacob's death, the eyes of Israel were closed (and in the Nitzotzei Orot, in the commentary on the Zohar, it is written in the name of the commentators that the intention is regarding the study of Torah, that the springs of wisdom that Jacob revealed were closed to Israel). Rabbi Judah said that then they descended to exile and were enslaved by them. Thus, the Zohar relates to our matter. It seems that Rabbi Jacob and Rabbi Judah do not disagree, and it is possible that both agree that Israel was not enslaved in the work of the Egyptians from the time of Jacob's death. As long as Joseph was alive, he was a king and ruler over them, preventing them from having the possibility to enslave Israel even if they desired to do so. And as long as one of the tribes was alive, our Sages said that they were not enslaved in Israel. However, the intention here is regarding a different type of servitude, as it is stated in the words of the holy Yismach Moshe in Parashat Balak, that nothing in the world harms the soul like associating with a wicked person, even for a moment, even if it is not noticeable, it enters the soul like poison and venom, and for most days, one will find it. And for this, one needs a great merit in conjunction with the study of Torah to remove the poison and venom completely, and perhaps after a long time. It can also be said on the other hand that the Egyptians did not enslave Israel at all as long as Joseph was alive. On the contrary, since they were the family of Joseph, who was a king and ruler over them, they treated them with the respect due to the sons of kings, and showed them signs of love, brotherhood, and friendship. And the association with the wicked causes more harm to the soul than the servitude of their work. We have brought above from the words of the Jerusalem Talmud that our Sages expounded, "And He put a yoke of iron upon your neck," this idea, that the blemish of the entire thought is called a yoke of iron and hard servitude. However, as long as our father Jacob was alive and learned Torah with them and revealed to them the springs of wisdom, the words and smoothness of the tongue of the Egyptians did not affect them for evil, and they were nullified like nothing against the influence of holiness that he, blessed be He, imparted to them. But at the time of Jacob's death, the springs of wisdom that he revealed to them were closed. Therefore, it was justly that they descended to exile and were enslaved by them, not through labor but through their words and their association. According to this, the words of Rabbi Jacob and Rabbi Judah in the aforementioned Zohar will revolve around one pole, that since the springs of wisdom were closed to them, therefore the servitude began within them. And what our Sages said that as long as Joseph was alive and as long as one of the tribes was alive, they were not enslaved in Israel can also be understood according to the aforementioned aspect, that at least as long as Joseph and one of the tribes were alive, even though the power of holiness weakened and diminished with the departure of the blessed one, nevertheless, due to the great holiness of the holy tribes, the Egyptians could not overpower them with the strength of their impurity. Rather, from level to level, they were enslaved in them, first in the aspect of the soul, with the departure of the blessed one, and afterwards with the death of the righteous Joseph, and more so with the death of the tribes. But the servitude in labor perhaps only began thirty years before their departure from Egypt, as stated in the Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer.
summary: The passage discusses the transition from the period of protection afforded to the Israelites by Joseph and the other tribes to their eventual enslavement in Egypt. It emphasizes that as long as Jacob and Joseph were alive, the Israelites were shielded from the Egyptians' influence and potential subjugation, which was attributed to the spiritual illumination and wisdom imparted by Jacob. However, upon Jacob's death, the loss of this divine wisdom led to a gradual decline in the Israelites' spiritual state, allowing the Egyptians to exert their influence and ultimately enslave them. The text highlights the importance of maintaining spiritual connection and the dangers of associating with the wicked, which can lead to a form of spiritual enslavement even before physical bondage occurs.

passage_content: באופן אחר יתבאר דברי רז"ל למה פרשה זו סתומה וכו' ויתיישבו הדקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר במאמה"כ ואני בבאי מפדן מתה עלי רחל בארץ כנען וגו' פירש"י ז"ל ואע"פ שאני מטריח עליך להוליכנו להקבר בארץ כנען ולא כך עשיתי לאמך וכו', וידעתי שיש בלבך עלי, אבל דע לך שעפ"י הדיבור קברתי' שם שתהא לעזרה לבני' כשיגלה אותם נבוזראדן והיו עוברים דרך שם וכו' עכ"ל, ראוי להבין דכיון שמאמר זה התנצלות ליוסף על שהטריח עליו להוליכו לקברו בארץ כנען למה המתין בזה עד הכא והי"ל לומר דיבורים אלו בשעה שצוהו ונשאתני ממצרים וגו', כי שם מקומם.
translation: In another way, the words of our Sages will be explained as to why this section is closed, etc., and the aforementioned grammatical points will be resolved by first noting the verse, "And as I was coming from Padan, Rachel died upon me in the land of Canaan," etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains, "And although I am troubling you to take us to be buried in the land of Canaan, and I did not do so for your mother, etc., and I know that there is something in your heart against me, but know that according to the word, I buried her there so that she would be a help to her children when Nebuzaradan would reveal them, and they would pass by there," etc. It is fitting to understand that since this statement is an apology to Joseph for troubling him to take him to be buried in the land of Canaan, why did he wait until now to say this? He could have said these words at the time he commanded him, "And you shall carry me out of Egypt," etc., for that is where it belongs.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's request to be buried in Canaan, highlighting the theological concept of divine providence and the importance of burial places in Jewish tradition. It reflects on the emotional burden placed on Joseph, who is tasked with fulfilling this request, and emphasizes that Jacob's intention was to provide spiritual support for his descendants during their future exile. The text suggests that Jacob's choice of burial site serves as a source of strength and connection for the Jewish people, reinforcing the idea that physical locations hold deep spiritual significance in their collective memory and faith.

passage_content: ב) ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת וגו' פירש"י ז"ל חסד שעושין עם המתים הוא חסד של אמת שאינו מצפה לתשלום גמול, הקשו המפרשים הלא מצינו שיע"א שילם ליוסף גמולו כמ"ש ואני נתתי לך שכם אחד על אחיך פי' רש"י לפי שאתה טורח להתעסק בקבורתו וכו'
translation: B) "And you shall do with me kindness and truth," etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that the kindness done with the dead is the kindness of truth, which does not await a reward. The commentators questioned, however, that we find that Yaakov paid Yosef his reward, as it is written, "And I have given you one portion above your brothers," Rashi explains, "because you are diligent in attending to his burial," etc.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "chesed shel emet," or true kindness, which is performed for the deceased without expectation of reward. It highlights the idea that such acts of kindness are the highest form of charity, as they are done selflessly. The reference to Joseph receiving a reward for his efforts in burial underscores the belief that even in acts of kindness towards the dead, there is a divine acknowledgment and recompense. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of altruism and the eternal value of righteous deeds.

passage_content: ונראה ביאור הענין עפי"מ דאיתא בילקוט ראובני (פ' חיי שרה) וז"ל, מערת המכפלה אשר בחברון שם קבורת האבות, וידוע כי הוא מעבר לג"ע התחתון וכו', וכן כל הנפטרים בה והנקברים בה זוכים לעלות נפשיהם ביתד תקוע לעבור לג"ע התחתון בלו עיכוב. ולא מי שימחה בידם וכו', ולבן תקע את אחיו בהר הגלעד, ר"ל שכיון כח במכשפיו להעתיק את אהל יעקב שלא יזכה למערת המכפלה וכו' ולתקוע את אחיו שהם אדום וישמעאל שהם יזכו להעביר דרך המערה לג"ע וכו', ואם ח"ו לא הי' יעקב נקבר שם לא הי' שום אחד מישראל עובר דרך שם, כ"א אומה"ע ח"ו היו עוברים דרך שם, ע"י אחיזת אדום וישמעאל, וזהו אמרז"ל ולבן בקש לעקור את הכל שנאמר ארמי אובד אבי וכו' עיי"ש, מבואר שחסד גדול נעשה לכלל ישראל ע"י שנקבר יע"א במערת המכפלה ובזה יובן אמרם ז"ל חסד שעושין עם המתים, ר"ל עם המתים של כל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, והוא חסד של אמת שאינו מצפה לתשלום גמול, וא"ש מה שאמר חסד ואמת בוא"ו המחלקת דב' בחינות הם ויע"א אמר לו שני דברים ועשית עמדי חסד, פי' לי לעצמי ואין זה חסד של אמת כי שילם לו גמולו כנ"ל, ונוסף לזה תעשה חסד של אמת עם המתים של כל ישראל, והוא חסד של אמת.
translation: And we will explain the matter according to what is stated in Yalkut Reuveni (Parashat Chayei Sarah), as follows: The Cave of Machpelah, which is in Hebron, is the burial place of the Patriarchs, and it is known that it is beyond the lower Garden of Eden, etc. And so all the deceased and those buried there merit for their souls to ascend through a fixed peg to pass to the lower Garden of Eden without delay. And not one who will hinder them, etc. And Laban buried his brother on Mount Gilead, meaning he exerted power with his sorceries to transfer the tent of Jacob so that he would not merit the Cave of Machpelah, etc., and to cause his brothers, who are Edom and Ishmael, to merit to pass through the cave to the Garden of Eden, etc. And if, Heaven forbid, Jacob had not been buried there, no one from Israel would pass through there, but rather the nations of the world, Heaven forbid, would pass through there, due to the hold of Edom and Ishmael. And this is what our Sages of blessed memory said: Laban sought to uproot everything, as it is said, "An Aramean was about to destroy my father," etc. It is clear that a great kindness was done for the entire Jewish people by the fact that he, blessed be He, was buried in the Cave of Machpelah, and this will clarify their statement of blessed memory about the kindness done to the dead, meaning with the dead of all Israel until the end of all generations. And it is a true kindness that does not expect a reward in return. And it is understood why it is said "kindness and truth" with a vav, indicating that there are two aspects, and he, blessed be He, said to him two things: "And you will do kindness with me," meaning for myself, and this is not a true kindness because he repaid him his reward as mentioned above. In addition to this, you will do a true kindness with the dead of all Israel, and this is a true kindness.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Cave of Machpelah in Hebron as a burial site for the patriarchs, emphasizing its role in facilitating the souls of the deceased to ascend to the lower Garden of Eden without delay. It highlights the spiritual struggle against forces like Esau and Ishmael, who sought to prevent Jacob from being buried there, which would have denied the Jewish people access to this sacred site. The text underscores the concept of "chesed shel emet" (true kindness) performed for the dead, which is an act of kindness that expects no reward, contrasting it with acts of kindness that are transactional. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound impact of Jacob's burial on the collective Jewish soul throughout generations.

passage_content: ואיתא במד"ר עה"פ ויאמר לו מה החלום הזה אשר חלמת, ר' לוי בשם ר' חמא בר חנינא כך הי' יע"א סבור שתחה"מ מגעת בימיו, שנאמר הבוא נבוא אני ואמך וכו', ואם יע"א הי' סבור כן ודאי שכל ישראל היו מצפים לזה, ועכשיו ששמעו איך שצוה את יוסף ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת היינו חסד שעושין עם המתים וכו', השיגו מזה שלא יהי' תחה"מ מיד ויהיו המתים צריכין עוד לחסד של אמת, ע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מהשגת ידיעה זו, שעליהם לפרוע שט"ח של ברית בין הבתרים אמנם כ"ז שיע"א הי' חי עמהם היו מצפים עדיין שיבטל גזירת השיעבוד, דצדיקים כל זמן שהם חיים מוסיפים והולכים בעבדות ה' ב"ה, וכוחם גדול להיות גזירתם מתקיימת ע"ד ותגזר אומר ויקום לך, אבל אחר שנסתלק מן העולם אז השיגו שהוחלט הגזירה, והתחלת ההרגשה הי' עוד מזמן שאמר ליוסף ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, ע"כ נרמז הסתימה בריש הפרשה כשאמר ליוסף ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת,
translation: And it is stated in the Midrash on the verse "And he said to him, What is this dream that you have dreamed," Rabbi Levi in the name of Rabbi Chama bar Chanina said: Thus it was, may it be His will, that he thought the resurrection of the dead would occur in his days, as it is said, "Will we come, I and your mother, etc." And if, may it be His will, he thought so, certainly all of Israel were expecting this. And now that they heard how he commanded Joseph, "And you shall do kindness and truth with me," which is the kindness done with the dead, etc., they understood from this that the resurrection of the dead would not happen immediately and that the dead would still need the kindness of truth. Therefore, the eyes and hearts of Israel were sealed from grasping this knowledge, that they must fulfill the obligation of the covenant between the parts. However, as long as may it be His will, he was alive with them, they were still expecting that the decree of servitude would be annulled, for the righteous, as long as they are alive, continue to increase in the service of the Blessed Holy One, and their power is great to have their decree established as it is said, "And you shall decree a thing, and it shall be established for you." But after he departed from the world, they understood that the decree was finalized, and the beginning of the feeling was already from the time he said to Joseph, "And you shall do kindness and truth with me." Therefore, the sealing was hinted at at the beginning of the portion when he said to Joseph, "And you shall do kindness and truth with me."
summary: The passage discusses the anticipation of the resurrection of the dead (Techiyat HaMetim) during the time of Rabbi Levi and Rabbi Chama bar Chanina, highlighting that the Jewish people believed this event was imminent. However, upon hearing Joseph's command to perform acts of kindness and truth towards the deceased, they realized that the resurrection would not occur immediately, as the dead still required acts of kindness. This led to a spiritual blindness among the Israelites regarding their understanding of the divine decree of servitude, which was believed to be upheld by the righteous while they were alive. The text emphasizes the power of the righteous in influencing divine decrees and the shift in perception following their passing.

passage_content: ויתבאר עוד בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ (בפ' שמות) ויאמר משה אל האלקים וגו' ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם ויאמר אלקים אל משה אהי' אשר אהי' ויאמר כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי' שלחני אליכם, פירש"י אהי' עמכם בצרה זאת, אשר אהי' עמם בשיעבוד שאר מלכיות, אמר לפניו רבש"ע מה אני מזכיר להם צרה אחרת, דיים בצרה זו, א"ל יפה אמרת כה תאמר וגו', והקשו המפרשים איך אפשר שמשה השכיל חלילה על דברו השם והקב"ה הצדיק את דבריו, וכבר בארנו בזה אופנים שונים, וכעת נל"פ עפ"י פשטות. דהנה במאמר השם אהי' אשר אהי', אינו מבורר בהחלט שהכוונה על שיעבוד שאר מלכיות, דכמו"כ אפשר לפרש אשר אהי' עמכם בעת הגאולה, והבטיחנו ית' שישרה שכינתו בישראל ודביקותן של ישראל בהבוי"ת יהי' אז בבחי' גבוה יותר, וע"ד שפירשתי אמרינו (בנוסח קדושת כתר) הן גאלתי אתכם אחרית כראשית, דלכאורה הרי אמרז"ל (תענית ז' ע"א) מי נתלה במו, הוי אומר קטן נתלה בגדול, וידוע שגאולה העתידה תהי' בחינתה גדולה הרבה מגאועות הקודמות, ואיך נתלה הגדול בקטן, לומר שיגאל אותנו הבוי"ת אחרית כראשות, וגאולה העתידה אין ערוך אלי' בבחינתה, ואפ"ל דהנה גאולת מצרים הו' ראשיתו טובה, שנגאלו מטומאת מצרים וזכו לקבלת התורה וירושת הארץ, אבל אח"כ נתמעטו הדורות ונחלש כח הקדושה ובחי' השראת השכינה, עד שגרמו עונותינו לחורבן ביהמ"ק וגלות ישראל, א"כ לא הי' האחרית כראשות, אולם בגאולה העתידה לא יהי' כן, והאחרות יהי' טובה כראשות, וישראל יהיו מוסיפין והולכין בבחי' הקדושה והשראת השכינה למעלה עד אין חקר, ויזכו בכל פעם לבחי' חדשה גבוה למעלה מן הקודמים, והאחרית יהי' ג"כ ראשית לבחי' גבוה ממנה, וז"ש הן גאלתי אתכם אחרית כראשית והבן.
translation: And it will be further explained in advance to interpret from the Holy Scriptures (in Parashat Shemot) "And Moses said to God, etc. And they will say to me, 'What is His name? What shall I say to them?' And God said to Moses, 'I will be that I will be.' And He said, 'Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will be has sent me to you.' Rashi explains, 'I will be with you in this trouble, that I will be with them in the servitude of other kingdoms.' Moses said before Him, 'Master of the Universe, why should I mention to them another trouble? This trouble is enough.' He said to him, 'You have spoken well, thus you shall say, etc.' And the commentators have questioned how it is possible that Moses, Heaven forbid, should have been wise about the words of the Name, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, validated his words. We have already explained this in various ways, and now we will explain according to simplicity. Behold, in the statement of the Name, 'I will be that I will be,' it is not definitively clarified that the intention is regarding the servitude of other kingdoms, for it is also possible to interpret 'that I will be with you at the time of redemption,' and He has promised us that His Divine Presence will dwell in Israel, and the attachment of Israel to the Holy One, Blessed be He, will then be in a much higher aspect, in the manner that I have explained in our saying (in the text of the Kedushat Keter), 'Indeed, I have redeemed you, the end as the beginning.' For seemingly, our sages have said (Taanit 7a), 'Who is hung by whom? It must be that the small is hung by the great,' and it is known that the future redemption will be in a much greater aspect than the previous redemptions, and how can the great be hung by the small, to say that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will redeem us in the end as at the beginning, and the future redemption has no comparison to it in its aspect? And it can be said that the redemption from Egypt was a good beginning, as they were redeemed from the impurity of Egypt and merited the receiving of the Torah and the inheritance of the land, but afterwards the generations diminished and the power of holiness and the aspect of the Divine Presence weakened, until our sins caused the destruction of the Holy Temple and the exile of Israel. Therefore, the end was not like the beginning. However, in the future redemption, it will not be so, and the end will be good like the beginning, and Israel will continue to ascend in the aspect of holiness and the Divine Presence to a level beyond measure, and they will merit each time a new aspect higher than the previous ones, and the end will also be a beginning for a higher aspect than it. And this is what is meant by 'Indeed, I have redeemed you, the end as the beginning,' and understand.
summary: The passage discusses God's assurance to Moses that He will be with the Israelites during their suffering, emphasizing the continuity of divine presence from their current bondage to future redemption. It highlights the distinction between the redemption from Egypt, which was a beginning but led to spiritual decline, and the future redemption, which will be of a higher spiritual caliber, ensuring an ever-increasing closeness to God. The future redemption is portrayed as a culmination of spiritual elevation, where each subsequent experience of divine presence will surpass the previous ones, ultimately leading to a state where the end will be as significant as the beginning, if not greater.

passage_content: עכ"פ זה ברור דגם לעת הגאולה יש צורך להבטחה זו אשר אהי"", שהקב"ה ישרה שכינתו בישראל, נמצא שאינו מבורר הכוונה בו על שיעבוד מלכיות, אלא שמשרע"ה השיג גם בחי' המחשבה, וע"ד שפי' ק"ז הושמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' וישלח) אמרם זיל (ב"ב י"ב ע"א) חכם עדיף מנביא: דהצדיקום הגדולים המתדבקים בחכמה העליונה, יוכלו להשיג גם מחשבתו של יוצר בראשית, משא"כ הנביאים אין השגתם רק במה שיצא לפועל הדיבור ולא בחי' מחשבה עיי"ש. ומילתא דתליא בבחירה לא ניתנה להתגלות בבחי' דיבור כ"א בבחי' מחשבה, לפי שהדיבור מכריח הבחירה משא"כ הידיעה, ע"כ משרע"ה השיג בחכמתו שנרמז במאמר השי"ת שיהי' עוד שיעבוד, ובודאי הי' צורך לזה שישיג משרע"ה גלויות העתידים, כדי שיכין כח בתפלתו וזכותו להמתיק ולהקל כח השיעבוד והגלות, אלא שמשרע"ה הי' סבור, שנאמרה לו כן ע"ד שיגלה אותו לישראל, וע"כ שאל די' לצרה בשעתה מה אנו מזכיר להם צרה אחרת והשיב לו הקב"ה ופה אמרת כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי' שלחני אליכם, ותחלת המחשבה כך היתה שלא יגלה לישראל, ורק למשה לבדו נתגלה ולא ע"ד שיאמרנה לישראל, (עיין בדברנו פ' וארא ביאור הענין באריכות
translation:
Nevertheless, it is clear that even at the time of redemption, there is a need for this assurance of "I will be," that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will dwell His Presence in Israel. It is found that the intention is not clarified regarding the subjugation of kingdoms, but rather that Moshe Rabbeinu attained, even in the aspect of thought, as explained in the commentary on Psalm 67, where it is said that Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Vayishlach), stated: "A wise person is preferable to a prophet" (Baba Batra 12a). The great righteous ones who cling to the supreme wisdom can also grasp the thought of the Creator of the world, whereas the prophets only attain what has come to fruition in speech and not in the aspect of thought, as noted there. 

And the matter that depends on free will was not given to be revealed in the aspect of speech, but only in the aspect of thought, because speech compels free will, whereas knowledge does not. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu understood in his wisdom that it was hinted in the statement of the Holy One, Blessed be He, that there would be further subjugation, and certainly there was a need for Moshe Rabbeinu to grasp the future exiles, so that he could prepare the strength in his prayer and merit to sweeten and alleviate the strength of the subjugation and exile. However, Moshe Rabbeinu thought that it was said to him in a manner that he would reveal it to Israel, and therefore he asked, "Why should we mention to them another trouble at this time?" And the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him, "And you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will be' has sent me to you." And the initial thought was such that it would not be revealed to Israel, but only to Moshe alone was it revealed, and not in a manner that it would be said to Israel. (See our discussion in Parashat Va'era for an elaborate explanation of the matter.)
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of divine assurance for the future redemption, emphasizing that God's presence will dwell among Israel. It highlights that Moses, through his profound wisdom, was able to grasp the Creator's thoughts, unlike the prophets who only understood through spoken words. The text suggests that the concept of choice is revealed in thought rather than speech, indicating that Moses's understanding of future exiles was essential for his prayers to mitigate their severity. Ultimately, it conveys that the initial intention of God was not to reveal this to the Israelites, but rather to Moses alone.

passage_content: מבואר מזה יסוד איתן שלא יאות להודיע במוקדם גלות העתידה לבוא, שהרי הבוי"ת הצדיק טענת משרע"ה די' לצרה בשעתה, ואין לגלות כ"א בעת ההכרח ולצורך, כמו שגילה הקב"ה למשרע"ה לטעם זה כנ"ל, ובזה יתורץ קושיא הנ"ל (קושיא ב') מדוע לא התנצל יע"א ליוסף על קבורת רחל בדרך, בעת צוותו להוליכו לא"י בקברת אבותיו, ומאמר זה ואני בבואי מפדן וגו', הי' ראוי להאמר בתחלת הפרשה, לגלות לו טעמו ונימוקו שעפ"י הדיבור הי', אמנם יובן עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, דהרי בהתנצלות הזה גילה לו מחורבן וגלות המעותד לבוא על ישראל, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל שכשיגלה אותם נבוזראדן ויהיו עוברים דרך שם, רחל יצאת ומבקשת עליהם רחמים וכו', ע"כ לא רצה לגלות בחי' הגלות כ"ז שלא הי' הכרח לדבר, רק אח"כ כשחלה יעקב והשיג שהגיע עתו להסתלק, בהכרח גילה בהתנצלותו ליוסף שעשה כן עפ"י הדיבור מפני גזירת הגלות העתידה לבוא על ישראל, אולם השבעים הקדושים השיגו בחכמתם רמז הגלות הנרמז בצוואתו של יעאע"ה ועשית חסד ואמת כנ"ל אלא שהפשוטו עם לא נתגלה להם כ"א סמוך לפטירת יע"א, כשגילה בפירוש במאמר ואני בבאי מפדן, וע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של כל ישראל בהסתלקות יעאע"ה, אבל בני עלי' השיגו גזירת השעבוד בתחלה כשצוה יעקב ליוסף להוליכו לא"י, וע"כ נרמז הסתומה בתחלת הפרשה.
translation: It is clarified from this a firm foundation that it is not appropriate to announce in advance the exile that is to come, for the righteous Baal Shem Tov argued with Moshe Rabbeinu that it is proper to be concerned for trouble at the time it occurs, and one should only reveal it in times of necessity and need, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, revealed to Moshe Rabbeinu for this reason as mentioned above. And with this, the aforementioned question (question 2) is resolved: why did Yaakov Avinu not apologize to Yosef for Rachel's burial along the way, at the time he commanded him to take him to Eretz Yisrael to the burial of his forefathers? This statement, "And I, when I came from Padan," should have been said at the beginning of the section, to reveal to him the reason and justification according to the speech that was. However, it can be understood according to our aforementioned approach, for in this apology he revealed to him the destruction and exile that is destined to come upon Israel, as Rashi, of blessed memory, states that when Nebuzaradan exiles them and they pass by there, Rachel comes out and asks for mercy for them, etc. Therefore, he did not want to reveal the aspect of exile as long as there was no necessity to speak, only afterwards when Yaakov fell ill and realized that his time to depart had come, he was compelled to reveal in his apology to Yosef that he did so according to the speech because of the decree of the future exile that is to come upon Israel. However, the holy seventy understood through their wisdom the hint of the exile hinted at in the command of Yaakov Avinu to do kindness and truth as mentioned above, except that the simple meaning was not revealed to them until close to the passing of Yaakov Avinu, when he explicitly revealed in the statement "And I, when I came from Padan." Therefore, the eyes and hearts of all Israel were closed at the passing of Yaakov Avinu, but the sons of elevation understood the decree of servitude at the beginning when Yaakov commanded Yosef to take him to Eretz Yisrael, and thus the hidden hint is alluded to at the beginning of the section.
summary: The passage emphasizes the principle that the future exile of the Jewish people should not be revealed prematurely, as it could lead to unnecessary distress. It discusses how Jacob's reluctance to explain the burial of Rachel to Joseph was rooted in the desire to avoid disclosing the impending suffering of exile. The text highlights that while the deeper implications of exile were understood by the righteous, the broader community remained unaware until Jacob's passing, when he explicitly mentioned the exile. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of divine timing and the importance of revealing painful truths only when absolutely necessary.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר בהקדם (דברינו בדרושים לשובבי"ם פ' ויחי) לתרץ קושית המפרשים עה"פ ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם וגו' דלא מצינו שהוליד יוסף עוד בנים, ולא זכרם הכתוב בשום מקום. ואיך תהי' ברכת יעאע"ה ומתנתו לבטלה, אמנם מצינו כי ברכותיו של יע"א היו רובם על העתיד, ואמרז"ל (סוטה ל"ו ע"ב) הי' ראוי יוסף לצאת ממנו י"ב שבעים כדרך שיצאו מיעקב אביו, שנא' אלה תולדות יעקב יוסף וכו'. אלא שע"י סיבת וכיון שנכנסת הנסיון נמנעו ממנו עיי"ש, ובאמת לא הי' זה פגם כ"א בערך גודל מדריגתו והפלגת קדושתו ע"ד וסביביו נשערה מאוד, אמנם לעתיד יתוקן הכל ויחזור אל הבחי' שהי' ראוי אלי' מתחילתו, ויעמוד י"ב שבטים שהיו ראויים לצאת ממנו, כי אין טעם למנוע אותם אחרי שיתוקן הפגם, ועוד יתעלו מדריגתם של צדיקים לע"ל, וא"ש מאמה"כ ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם וגו', אע"פ שלא נתקיים כן בשעתו, אבל כל דבריו היו על העתיד, ואז יתקיימו שעתידים לצאת ממנו י"ב שבעים, ועז"א ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם (עיי"ש ביאור הענין באריכות), עכ"פ במאמר זה ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם, נרמז בו סוד הגאולה, דא"א שתהי' נבואת יע"א ופסוקי התורה לבעלה ח"ו, וע"כ שרומז על הבעחת גאולה העתידה.
translation: And I can also explain it in another way, as mentioned in our discourses on Shovavim, Parashat Vayechi, to resolve the difficulty of the commentators on the verse "and your birthplace, where you were born, etc." that we do not find that Joseph fathered any more sons, and the text does not mention them anywhere. How could the blessing of our father Abraham and his gift be in vain? However, we find that most of the blessings of our father Abraham were concerning the future, and our sages have said (Sotah 36b) that it was fitting for Joseph to have twelve tribes, just as there came forth from his father Jacob, as it is said, "These are the generations of Jacob: Joseph, etc." But due to the cause and the fact that he entered into the trial, they were withheld from him, as stated there. In truth, this was not a blemish except in relation to the greatness of his level and the extent of his holiness, as it was greatly diminished around him. However, in the future, everything will be rectified, and he will return to the level that he was worthy of from the beginning, and there will stand twelve tribes that were worthy to come forth from him, for there is no reason to withhold them after the blemish is rectified. Moreover, the levels of the righteous will be elevated in the World to Come, and it is clear from the verse "and your birthplace, where you were born, etc." that although it was not fulfilled at that time, all his words were about the future, and then it will be fulfilled that twelve tribes are destined to come forth from him. Therefore, it is said, "after the names of their brothers they will be called in their inheritance" (see there for an elaborate explanation of the matter). In any case, in this statement "and your birthplace, where you were born," there is hinted the secret of redemption, for it cannot be that the prophecy of our father Abraham and the verses of the Torah be in vain, Heaven forbid. Therefore, it alludes to the hint of the future redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's blessings and the absence of mention of his additional sons, suggesting that while he did not have twelve tribes as Jacob did, this was not a flaw but rather a reflection of his elevated spiritual status. It emphasizes that Joseph's blessings were primarily prophetic, pointing to a future rectification where the twelve tribes will emerge from him, symbolizing the ultimate redemption. The text highlights the idea that divine prophecies and blessings are eternal and will manifest in the future, reinforcing the belief in the eventual fulfillment of God's promises. Additionally, it alludes to the connection between Joseph's lineage and the future redemption, indicating that the Torah's words are always relevant and will not be in vain.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ד במד"ר (איכה פ"ג י"ט) עה"פ זאת אשיב אל לבי על כן אוחיל, ראב"כ בש"ר יוחנן אמר מלה"ד למלך שנשא מטרונא וכתב לה כתובה מרובה וכו', הניחה המלך והלך לו למדינת הים ואיחר לשם. נכנסו שכנותי' אצלה והיו מקניטות אותה, ואומרות לה הניחך המלך והלך לו למדינת הים ושוב אינו חוזר עליך, והיתה בוכה ומתאנחת, לתוך ביתה פותחת ומוציאה כתובתה וקוראת ורואה בכתובתה כך וכך וכו' אני עושה לך, מיד היתה מתנחמת, לימים בא המלך אמר לה בתי אני תמה איך המתנת לי כל אותן השנים, אמרה לו אדוני המלך אלמלא כתובה מרובה שכתבת ונתת לי כבר אבדונו שכנותו, כך האומות מונין את ישראל ואומרין להם אלקיכם הסתיר פניו מכם וכו', וכיון שנכנסין לבתי כנסיות ולבתי מדרשות וקוראין בתורה ומוצאין שכתוב ופניתי אליכם וגו' הן מתנחמין, למחר כשיבוא קץ הגאולה אומר להם הקב"ה לישראל, בני אני תמה מכם היאך המתנתם לו כל אותן השנים, והן אומרים לפניו רבש"ע אלולי תורתך שנתת לנו כבר אבדונו האומות, לכך נאמר זאת אשיב אל לבי על כן אוחיל וכו' עכ"ד המדרש
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Midrash (Lamentations 3:19) on the verse "This I recall to my mind, therefore I have hope." Rabbi Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: It is like a king who married a noblewoman and wrote her a large ketubah, etc. The king left her and went to a distant land and delayed his return. The neighbors came to her and mocked her, saying, "The king has left you and gone to a distant land and will not return to you." And she was crying and sighing. She opened her house, took out her ketubah, read it, and saw in her ketubah such and such promises, etc., and immediately she was consoled. After some time, the king returned and said to her, "My daughter, I am amazed how you waited for me all those years." She said to him, "My lord the king, if not for the large ketubah that you wrote and gave me, I would have already lost hope because of the mockery of my neighbors." Thus, the nations count the Jewish people and say to them, "Your God has hidden His face from you," etc. And when they enter the synagogues and study houses and read in the Torah and find written, "And I will turn to you," etc., they are consoled. The next day, when the time of redemption comes, the Holy One, blessed be He, will say to Israel, "My children, I am amazed at you how you waited for Me all those years." And they will say before Him, "Master of the Universe, if not for the Torah that You gave us, we would have already been lost to the nations." Therefore, it is said, "This I recall to my mind, therefore I have hope," etc. Thus concludes the Midrash.
summary: The passage draws a parallel between a king's promise to a bride and God's covenant with Israel, emphasizing the theme of hope and patience in the face of adversity. Just as the bride finds solace in her marriage contract during the king's absence, the Jewish people find comfort in the Torah amidst their suffering and the nations' scorn. Ultimately, when redemption arrives, God will express wonder at Israel's endurance, attributing their survival to the teachings of the Torah. This reflects a deep theological insight into the enduring relationship between God and Israel, rooted in faith and the power of divine promises.

passage_content: והנה באמת אצל הבוי"ת לא שייך תמי' ופלא, ולפניו ית' גלוי הכל דמה שישראל עדיין מחזיקים באמונתו למרות כל הצרות ואריכות הגלות, הוא רק בכוחו ית', ואלולי כן כבר אבדנו ח"ו אעפ"כ יאמר הקב"ה תמה אני וכו', ויתבאר עפי"מ שפי' המפורשים מאמה"כ והללתם את שם ה אלקיכם אשר עשה עמכם להפליא, עפי"ד הגמ' (סוכה נ"ב ע"א) לע"ל מביאו הקב"ה ליצה"ר ושוחטו בפני הצדיקים ובפני הרשעים, צדיקים נדמה להם כהר גבוה וכו' ובוכין ואומרים האיך יכולנו לכבוש את ההר הגבוה הזה וכו', ואף הקב"ה תמה עמהם, שנא' כי יפלא בעיני שארית העם הזה גם בעיני יפלא עכ"ד הגמ', וביארו הכוונה כי אחרי ראות הצדיקים תוקף היצה"ר ורב חזקו, ישיגו כי לא הי' ביכולת אנושי לכבשו לולי עזר ה', ויחרדו ויאמרו א"כ איפוא נבוא על שכרנו, כיון שלא נעשה דבר מצידנו, והקב"ה ונחמם במה שיאמר גם בעיני יפלא על דבר נצחונם, כדי לתלות הנצחון בהם שלא יהי' שכרם בבחי' נהמא דכסופא, וז"ש והללתם את שם ה' אלקיכם אשר עשה עמכם להפליא, כמאמר הכתוב כי יפלא בעיני שארית העם הזה גם בעיני יפלא, ולא יבושו עמי לעולם, שיעשה הקב"ה כן שלא יהי' שכרם בבחי' נהמא דכסופא עכת"ד ז"ל, ועד"ז יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל שכשיבוא קץ הגאולה יאמר הקב"ה לישראל בני אנו תמה מכם האיך המתנתם לי כל אותן השנים, אף שגלוי וידוע לפניו ית' שאילולי עזרתו ות' לא יכולנו לעמוד ולהתקיים ולהתחזק באמונתו מפני כובד הגלות וגודל הנסיונות, מ"מ יהי' הבוי"ת תמה כדי להגדיל שכרנו ושלא יהי' בבחי' נהמא דכסופא כנ"ל,
translation: And behold, truly with regard to the Ba'alei Teshuvah, there is no place for wonder and amazement, for before Him, blessed be He, everything is revealed. The fact that Israel still holds onto their faith despite all the troubles and the length of the exile is only by His power. Were it not for that, we would have already been lost, Heaven forbid. Nevertheless, the Holy One, blessed be He, will say, "I am amazed," etc. This will be explained according to the interpretation of the commentators on the verse, "And you shall praise the name of the Lord your God, who has done wondrously with you," according to the teaching of the Gemara (Sukkah 52a) that in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will bring the Yetzer Hara and slaughter it before the righteous and before the wicked. The righteous will see it as a high mountain, etc., and they will cry and say, "How could we have conquered this high mountain?" And even the Holy One, blessed be He, will be amazed with them, as it is said, "For it will be amazing in the eyes of this remnant of the people, and it will be amazing in My eyes as well," as stated in the Gemara. The intention is explained that after the righteous see the strength of the Yetzer Hara and its great power, they will realize that it was not within human ability to conquer it were it not for the help of God. They will tremble and say, "Then where will we come to our reward, since we did nothing on our part?" And the Holy One, blessed be He, will comfort them by saying that it will also be amazing in My eyes regarding their victory, in order to attribute the victory to them, so that their reward will not be in the category of "bread of shame." Therefore, it is said, "And you shall praise the name of the Lord your God, who has done wondrously with you," as the verse states, "For it will be amazing in the eyes of this remnant of the people, and it will be amazing in My eyes," and My people will never be ashamed, that the Holy One, blessed be He, will do so that their reward will not be in the category of "bread of shame," as mentioned. Similarly, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be explained that when the end of the redemption comes, the Holy One, blessed be He, will say to Israel, "My children, I am amazed at you, how you waited for Me all those years," even though it is revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, that were it not for His help and support, we could not have stood, existed, and strengthened ourselves in our faith due to the heaviness of the exile and the greatness of the trials. Nevertheless, the Ba'alei Teshuvah will be amazed in order to increase our reward and that it should not be in the category of "bread of shame," as mentioned.
summary: The passage emphasizes that, from the perspective of the Divine, the perseverance of the Jewish people in their faith amidst suffering and exile is solely due to God's assistance. It highlights the future revelation where God will express wonder at the endurance of Israel, despite knowing that their strength came from Him. This divine astonishment serves to elevate their reward, ensuring it is not perceived as mere sustenance of shame, but rather as a recognition of their faithfulness. Ultimately, the text underscores the interplay between divine support and human effort in the context of faith and redemption.

passage_content: ונא"פ בזה מאמר רז"ל והפלה ה' את מכותך, הפלאה זו אינו יודע מה הוא, כשהוא אומר ואבדה חכמת חכמיו וגו'. הוי אומר הפלאה זו מיתת צדיקים, וראוי להבין הפלאה זו מה ענינה, ומדוע נקרא מיתת צדיקים הפלאה, ויתבאר עפי"ד המדרש והגמ' הנ"ל, שיתפלא הקב"ה על ישראל א התחזקו באמונתם בגלות הקשה הזה, ואיך כלו לכבוש היצה"ר שנדמה בתקפו להר גבוה, אמנם כ"ז שהצדיקים חיים אתנו, אין כ"כ מקום לתמיהה זו דבכח קדושתם וצדקתם מאירים בנשמות ולבבות בני ישראל, ומסייעים להם להתגבר על נסיונות הגלות והתגברות היצה"ר, אולם בהסתלקות הצדיקים מן העולם ר"ע אז חזרה הפליאה למקומה, וז"פ אמרם ז"ל והפלא ה' את מכותך, שהבוי"ת יתפלא על רוב המכות שסבלו ישראל בשנות הגלות ולמרות כל הצרות הם מתחזקים באמונתם, וע"ז באה השאלה הפלאה זו אינו יודע מה הוא: דמה פלא יש בדבר, הלא האמונה מושרשת ומוטבעת בלב איש הישראלי משורש האבוה"ק, כשהוא אומר ואבדה חכמת חכמיו וגו', הוי אומר הפלאה זו היא מיתת צדיקים, דבסילוקן של צדיקים ר"ל יגדל הפלא הזה, ורק בעזרתו ית' אנו מתקיימים.
translation: And nevertheless, in this matter, the sages said, "And the Lord will make your plagues wonderful." This wonder is not known for what it is, as it says, "And the wisdom of his wise men shall perish." This means to say that this wonder is the death of the righteous, and it is fitting to understand what this wonder is about, and why the death of the righteous is called a wonder. It will be explained according to the words of the Midrash and the Gemara mentioned above, that the Holy One, blessed be He, is astonished at Israel for having strengthened their faith in this difficult exile, and how they have managed to conquer the evil inclination, which seems to be as strong as a high mountain. However, as long as the righteous are alive with us, there is not so much room for this wonder, for through their holiness and righteousness, they illuminate the souls and hearts of the children of Israel, and assist them in overcoming the trials of exile and the strengthening of the evil inclination. However, with the passing of the righteous from the world, the wonder returns to its place, as our sages said, "And the Lord will make your plagues wonderful," that the Blessed One will be astonished at the many plagues that Israel suffered during the years of exile, and despite all the troubles, they strengthen themselves in their faith. And to this comes the question: what wonder is there in this? Is not faith rooted and ingrained in the heart of a Jewish person from the root of the patriarchs? As it says, "And the wisdom of his wise men shall perish," this means to say that this wonder is the death of the righteous, for with their removal, this wonder will grow, and only with the help of the Blessed One do we endure.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "p'lah" (wonder) in relation to the death of the righteous (tzadikim) and the enduring faith of the Jewish people during their suffering in exile. It suggests that while the tzadikim are alive, their holiness and righteousness provide spiritual support, helping the community withstand challenges and temptations. However, upon their passing, the wonder intensifies, as it raises questions about the strength of faith in the face of adversity. Ultimately, it emphasizes that the Jewish people's faith is deeply rooted and sustained by divine assistance, even amidst the trials of exile.

passage_content: עכ"פ מבואר מדברי המדרש (איכה רבתי) הנ"ל דע"י שישראל קוראין בתורה הבטחת גאולה העתידה, עי"ז מתחזקין באמונתם ומתקוימים בגלות, ואלולי כן כבר אבדונו האומות ח"ו, ובזה א"ש מה שלא אמר יע"א ואני בבאי מפדן וגו' מיד בצוותו להוליכו לא"י (עיין לעיל קושיא ב') אמנם מפני שבזה נרמז סוד הגלות כנ"ל ועדיין לא אמר להם הבטחת הגאולה, וזולת הבטחת הגאולה אין במציאות לסבול גזירת הגלות כנ"ל, ע"כ המתין ועאע"ה עד אחר שא"ל ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם, שיש בו הבטחה על גאולת העתיד, שעתיד יוסף להעמיד שבטים, וזה יהי' בעולם התיקון כנ"ל, ואחר שנתחזק אצלם הבטחת הגאולה, גילה להם סוד הגלות ונא קודם לכן.
translation: Nevertheless, it is explained from the words of the Midrash (Eicha Rabbati) mentioned above that by Israel reading in the Torah the promise of the future redemption, they strengthen their faith and are sustained in exile. Were it not for this, the nations would have already destroyed us, Heaven forbid. And in this, it is understood why it does not say, "And I, when I came from Padan..." immediately upon commanding him to lead him to the Land of Israel (see above, question 2). However, because this hints at the secret of the exile as mentioned above, and he still had not told them the promise of redemption, without the promise of redemption, it is impossible to endure the decree of exile as mentioned above. Therefore, he waited, and may it be His will, until after He said to him, "And your birthplace, which you were born after them," which contains a promise of the future redemption, that Joseph will establish tribes, and this will be in the world of rectification as mentioned above. And after the promise of redemption was strengthened among them, he revealed to them the secret of the exile and not before.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the Jewish people's reading of the Torah, particularly the promise of future redemption, strengthens their faith and sustains them during exile. Without this assurance of redemption, they would have succumbed to the challenges posed by the nations. The text highlights that the revelation of the secret of exile was withheld until the promise of future redemption was firmly established, indicating that the hope for redemption is essential for enduring the hardships of exile. Ultimately, this assurance prepares them for the eventual restoration and the establishment of the tribes in a corrected world.

passage_content: ויחי יעקב בארץ מצרים וגו' פירש"י למה פרשה זו סתומה לפי שכיון שנפטר יעקב אבינו נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד שהתחילו לשעבדם, הקשו המפורשים דהלא כל זמן שיוסף חי לא שעבדו המצרים בישראל כלל כו הי' מלך ומושל על ארץ מצרים, גם אמרז"ל דכ"ז שא' מן השבטים קיים לא שעבדו המצריים בישראל, ותו דאם כוונת הסתומה בשביל פטירת יע"א הי"ל להכתוב לרמז סתימת הפרשה להלן אצל פטירת יע"א ולא כאן אצל ויחי יעקב.
translation: "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt, etc." Rashi explains: Why is this section closed? Because when our father Jacob passed away, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed due to the distress of the servitude that began to oppress them. The commentators question: But as long as Joseph was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel at all, for he was a king and ruler over the land of Egypt. Additionally, our sages have said that as long as one of the tribes was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel. Furthermore, if the reason for the closed section is due to the passing of Jacob, it should have been written to hint at the closing of the section later, near the passing of Jacob, and not here, next to "And Jacob lived."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's death in Egypt and its impact on the Israelites, highlighting that their eyes and hearts became closed to the suffering of enslavement that began after his passing. It raises questions about the timing of their oppression, noting that as long as Joseph, a brother and protector, was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave the Israelites. The text suggests a deeper connection between Jacob's death and the onset of suffering, emphasizing the Hasidic theme of the spiritual and communal ramifications of a leader's passing.

passage_content:
ב) ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת אל נא תקברנו במצרים, פירש"י חסד שעושין עם המתים הוא חסד של אמת שאינו מצפה לתשלום גמול ויל"ד דמצינו שיע"א שילם ליוסף גמולו כמו שפירש"י להלן עה"כ ואני נתתי לך שכם אחד על אחיך וגו', ויותר קשה ממה שאמרו ז"ל (תענית ה' ע"ב) יעקב אבינו לא מת, א"כ אין זה חסד שעושין עם המתים.
ג) אל נא תקברנו במצרים פירש"י סופה להיות עפרה כנים ומרחשין תחת גופי, וכתבו בעלי תוס' לא נהירא לי דמזה לא הי' לו לירא, דהשתא בנימין בנו לא שלטה בו רמה כ"ש אביו וכו' עכ"ל ולו קשה עוד דהרי מזמן שנסתלק יע"א עד שבאו המכות על המצרים הי' לפי החשבון קרוב למאתים שנה, שהיו במצרים רד"ו שנה, צא מהם ויז שנים שהי' ועאע"ה חי שם, נמצא מאתים שנה בקירוב, ובדרך הטבע לא נשאר הגוף קיים זמן ארוך כזה ואין מקום לדאוג מחשש כנים, אלא על כרחך שיע"א ידע שגופו הקדוש ישאר קיים ורמה ותולעה לא ישלוט בו כמו שהבטיח לו ית' אל תירא תולעת יעקב, וא"כ מה טעם ליראתו מהכנים.
translation:
2) "And you shall do kindness and truth with me; do not bury me in Egypt," Rashi explains that the kindness done to the dead is the kindness of truth, which does not expect a reward. And it is known that it is found that Yaakov paid Yosef his reward, as Rashi explains later on the verse, "And I have given you one portion above your brothers," etc. It is even more difficult than what our sages said (Taanit 5b) that our father Yaakov did not die; if so, this is not the kindness done to the dead.

3) "Do not bury me in Egypt," Rashi explains that in the end, its dust will be infested with lice and will stir under my body. And the Tosafists wrote that it is not clear to me that he should have feared this, for now, Benjamin, his son, was not affected by lice, how much more so his father, etc. And it is also difficult for him that from the time that he was taken away until the plagues came upon the Egyptians, it was, according to the calculation, close to two hundred years, as they were in Egypt for 210 years. Subtract from them 17 years that he (Avraham) lived there, and it turns out to be about two hundred years. Naturally, the body would not remain intact for such a long time, and there is no reason to worry about the fear of lice. Rather, you must say that Yaakov knew that his holy body would remain intact and that lice and worms would not have dominion over it, as He promised him, "Do not fear, O worm of Yaakov." If so, what was the reason for his fear of the lice?
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the concept of "chesed shel emet" (true kindness) performed for the deceased, emphasizing that such acts are done without expectation of reward. The text reflects on Jacob's request not to be buried in Egypt, highlighting a belief in the sanctity and preservation of the body, which aligns with the assurance that decay and worms will not prevail over the righteous. The passage raises questions about the nature of Jacob's fears regarding his burial, suggesting a deeper understanding of divine protection and the eternal significance of the righteous in Jewish thought.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי המדרש (לקח טוב) אל נא תקברנו במצרים ושכבתי עם אבותי לפי שאין קוברין צדיק אצל רשע וכו', ובמדרש שוחר טוב (תהלים כ"ו ט') אל תאסוף עם חטאים נפשי אלו הנסקלים והנשרפים, ועם אנשי דמים חיי אלו הנהרגים והנחנקים, ד"א אלו המצרים שכן אמר יעקב אל נא תקברינו במצרים וכו' ודכוותה (מלכים ב' י"ג) ויגע האיש בעצמות אלישע ויחי ויקם על רגליו, תנא על רגליו עמד לביתו לא הלך, אלא שחי לשעה ומת ונקבר במקום אחר שנאמר אל תאסוף עם חטאים נפשי עכ"ד המדרש, וכתב בים של שלמה פ"ג דיבמות (אות ט"ז) וז"ל, ומה שנוהגין העשירים לקנות מקום חשוב לקבורה כדי להיות שוכנים אצל צדיק לפי הסברא יוצא שכרם בהפסדם, כי אולי אינם ראויים לכך ויענשו, כי צר ורע לצדיק שישכב רשע או שאין הגון אצלם, ומעשה דאלישע יוכיח וכו' עכ"ל, ועפי"ז נבין מאמה"כ ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, כו יע"א בשביל עצמו לא הי' צריך לחסד של אמת, כו יע"א לא מת, גם שילם לו גמולו כנ"ל, אבל יעשה חסד של אמת עם שאר המתים כי אלולי הי' יע"א נקבר במצרים אולי יקברו בשכנותו עוד מתים ויענשו בגללו וע"י שיקברוהו במערת המכפלה יעשו חסד של אמת עם מתים דעלמא
translation: And we will explain in advance the words of the Midrash (Lekach Tov) that says, "Do not bury us in Egypt," and "I will lie with my fathers," for the righteous are not buried next to the wicked, etc. And in the Midrash Shocher Tov (Psalms 26:9), it says, "Do not gather my soul with sinners," referring to those who are scorched and burned, "and with men of blood my life," referring to those who are killed and choked. Another interpretation is that these are the Egyptians, as Jacob said, "Do not bury us in Egypt," etc. And similarly (2 Kings 13), "And the man touched the bones of Elisha and lived and stood on his feet." The Tanna says he stood on his feet at his house; he did not walk, but he lived for an hour and died and was buried elsewhere, as it is said, "Do not gather my soul with sinners," thus concludes the Midrash. And it is written in Yam Shel Shlomo, chapter 3 of Yevamot (section 16), as follows: "And what the wealthy are accustomed to do, to purchase an important burial place in order to be buried next to the righteous, according to reason, their reward comes at their loss, for perhaps they are not worthy of it and will be punished, for it is narrow and bad for the righteous to lie next to the wicked or those who are unworthy of them. And the story of Elisha will prove this, etc." Therefore, we understand from the verse, "And You have done with me kindness and truth," etc. For himself, he did not need the kindness of truth, etc. He did not die, and he also received his reward as mentioned above. But he will do kindness of truth with the other dead, for had he not been buried, perhaps they would bury other dead next to him and they would be punished because of him. And by burying him in the Cave of Machpelah, they will do kindness of truth with the dead of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of burial locations in relation to the righteous and the wicked, emphasizing that a righteous person should not be buried among the wicked to avoid spiritual contamination. It references the teachings of the Midrash, highlighting the importance of honoring the dead and ensuring that the righteous are not associated with the sinful. The text illustrates this through the example of Elisha, who, despite being resurrected, was ultimately buried in a place that honored his righteousness. The overarching theme is the concept of "chesed shel emet" (true kindness), which extends beyond the individual to consider the spiritual well-being of all souls, ensuring that the righteous are treated with the dignity they deserve.

passage_content: ובזה יובן מה שפירש"י עה"כ אל נא תקברנו במצרים לפי שסופה להיות עפרה כנים, עפי"מ דמבואר במדרש שכל המכות באו על המצרים מדה כנגד מדה נגד הרעות שעשו. וכמו"כ הכנים נבראו ממעשיהם הרעות ע"ש תיסרך רעתך, וכמו ששורה רוח הטומאה על הרשעים, כמו"כ מה שנברא על ידיהם שורה עליו רוח מסאבה, ומטעם זה בעצמו שאמר יע"א אל נא תקברנו במצרים לפי שאין קוברין רשע אצל צדיק, כמו"כ לטעם זה הי' דואג שעתיד להיות עפרה כנים ומרחשין תחת גופי ויהי' לו צער, דסתם רעה ותולעה הוא בריאה מהקב"ה ולא הי' מתירא יע"א מהם, שלא שלטו בו כלל אבל הכנים שנבראו ממעשה הרשעים לא רצה שירחשין תחת גופו הקדוש מטעם זה בעצמו שאין קוברין רשע אצל צדיק.
translation: And with this, it will be understood what Rashi explained on the verse, "Do not bury us in Egypt," because in the end, it will become dust like lice. According to what is explained in the Midrash, all the plagues came upon the Egyptians measure for measure against the evils they did. Likewise, the lice were created from their evil deeds, as it is said, "He will punish you for your evil." Just as the spirit of impurity rests upon the wicked, so too what was created by their hands is afflicted by a spirit of filth. And for this very reason, he said, "Do not bury us in Egypt," for the wicked are not buried alongside the righteous. Similarly, for this reason, Doeg was concerned that his dust would become lice and would crawl under his body, causing him pain, for a common pest and worm is a creation from the Holy One, blessed be He, and he was not afraid of them, as they had no dominion over him at all. But the lice that were created from the deeds of the wicked, he did not want to have crawling under his holy body for this very reason that the wicked are not buried alongside the righteous.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of not burying the righteous in Egypt, as the land would ultimately become a source of torment due to the plagues that were a direct consequence of the Egyptians' evil deeds. It emphasizes the concept of divine justice, where the creation of lice (כנים) is linked to the wicked actions of the Egyptians, reflecting the idea that impurity and evil are associated with their actions. The text also highlights the distinction between the righteous and the wicked, asserting that the remains of the wicked should not be interred alongside the righteous, as the latter should not suffer from the consequences of the former's sins. Ultimately, it conveys a deep theological insight into the relationship between righteousness, sin, and divine retribution.

passage_content: ובזה יובן מדוע נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מיד כשנפטר יע"א, ואולי שהשיגו בטעם צוואתו אל תקברני במצרים שאין קוברין רשע אצל צדיק, כמבואר בדברי המדרש, ולכאורה אם לטעם זה בלבד הי' יכול לצוות שאף אם יקבר במצרים לא יקברו אצלו רשע ואדם שאינו הגון, ולמה הוצרך להטריח את יוסף להעלותו לא"י. וע"כ השיגו מזה כי יהיו משעובדים תחת יד מצרים ויעשו בהם כרצונם ולא יקיימו צוואתו של יע"א ולזה אף שהי' יוסף הצדיק עדיין חי מ"מ השיגו השעבוד הקשה העתידה לבוא ומשום זה נסתמו עיניהם ולבם מצרת השעבוד מיד בפטירת יע"א וא"ש רמז הסתומה בפרשה זו כשצוה אותם אל נא תקברנו במצרים.
translation: And this will explain why the eyes and hearts of Israel were sealed immediately when the righteous one passed away, and perhaps they understood the reason for his will, "Do not bury me in Egypt," for a wicked person is not buried next to a righteous one, as is explained in the words of the Midrash. And seemingly, if it were only for this reason, he could have commanded that even if he were buried in Egypt, they should not bury a wicked person or an unworthy man next to him. So why did he need to trouble Joseph to bring him to the Land of Israel? Therefore, they understood from this that they would be enslaved under the hand of Egypt and that they would do with them as they wished, and they would not fulfill the will of the righteous one. Because of this, even though Joseph the righteous was still alive, they perceived the harsh servitude that was to come, and for this reason, their eyes and hearts were sealed from the distress of the servitude immediately upon the passing of the righteous one. And this hints at the sealing in this section when he commanded them, "Do not bury me in Egypt."
summary: The passage discusses the immediate emotional and spiritual impact on the Israelites upon the death of Jacob, highlighting their understanding of his final request not to be buried in Egypt. This request symbolizes a deeper concern that their future enslavement in Egypt would prevent them from honoring his wishes, as they foresaw the suffering and oppression that awaited them. The closing of their eyes and hearts signifies their awareness of the impending hardships, reflecting a profound connection between their spiritual state and the physical realities of their existence. Ultimately, it underscores the tension between the righteous legacy of their forefather and the harsh realities of their future in Egypt.

passage_content: אי באופן אחר אפ"ל הדקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם דברי המדרש הובא בבעלי התוס' עה"פ ויאמר גאנכי אעשה כדבריך, כשם שאתה מצונו כך אני מצוה לאחי בשעת מיתתי להעלותי מכאן, וצ"ב איך יסבול מאמה"כ אנכי אעשה כדבריך כוונת דרז"ל, והנ"ל בזה עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר (פ' ק' סימן א') עה"פ ויצו אותם ויאמר אליהם אני נאסף אל עמי, אמר להם אם זכיתם לכם זכיתם בעצמי, ואם לאו משאנו מסתלק אצל אבותי אני הולך וכו', ופי' היפ"ת דאף שהי' מצוה שיקברהו אינו אומר אלא לזכותם, דאיהו לא איכפת לי' בין שיקבר או לא. מיד בהסתלקו מן העולם נאסף עם אבותיו, והענין הוא שאינו מת כשאר מתים וכו' עכ"ל,
translation: In another way, one could say the aforementioned nuances in advance of the words of the Midrash brought by the Ba'alei Tosafot on the verse "And he said, 'I will do as you have spoken.'" Just as you command us, so I command my brother at the time of my death to elevate me from here. And it is difficult to understand how he can endure from the Holy One, Blessed be He, "I will do as you have spoken," the intention of our Sages of blessed memory. The aforementioned is in accordance with what is stated in the Midrash (Parashat K, Section 1) on the verse "And he commanded them and said to them, 'I am being gathered to my people,'" he said to them, "If you have merited, you have merited through me; and if not, my burden departs to my ancestors, I am going," etc. And the explanation is that even though there was a command that he should be buried, he only speaks to merit them, for he does not care whether he is buried or not. Immediately upon his departure from this world, he is gathered with his ancestors, and the matter is that he does not die like other dead, etc. Thus is the conclusion.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of a righteous person's departure from the world, emphasizing that their concern lies not in their own burial but in the spiritual welfare of their descendants. It highlights the idea that a tzaddik (righteous person) transcends the typical experience of death, as their essence remains connected to their ancestors and the community. The text reflects on the notion that the tzaddik's command to his family at the time of death is rooted in the hope that they will merit spiritual elevation, illustrating the deep interconnection between the tzaddik and their lineage. Ultimately, it conveys the belief that the tzaddik's legacy continues to influence and guide their descendants even after their physical departure.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ד במד"ר פ' ויגש ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, אותך ואת כל הצדיקים כיוצא בך, ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך על מנת ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך, ופי' היפ"ת גם עלה מרבה כל הצדיקים שיעלו משם במותן, והיינו כל השבטים שנקברו עצמותיהם ג"כ בארץ כדלקמן, ויתכן שפירושו שכמו שהוא יעלה לארץ לזכות לתחי' שאינו אלא ליושבים בא"י, כן יעשה ה' לכל הצדיקים. אלא שיעקב יעלהו מיד במותו, וכל הצדיקים הנקברים חוצה לארץ יעלו לא"י בעת התחי' ע"ו גלגול מחילות עכ"ל היפ"ת, מבואר מדברי המדרשים הנ"ל שיע"א לא הי' צריך בשביל עצמו להעלותו לא"י, כי בין כך ובין כך הי' נאסף אל אבותיו. ומה שצוה כן, הי' בשביל לכבוש את הדרך לבניו אחריו, וכמו כל מעשה אבות שהי' לתכלית זה וכמ"ש הקב"ה לאאע"ה צא וכבוש הדרך לבניך, ועד"ז צוה יע"א להעלותו לא"י, כדי שגם בניו השבעים הק' יזכו לעלות לארץ. וכל הצדיקים עד סוף כל הדורות יזכו לתחית המתים ע"ו גלגול מחילות, וכ"ז הי' בתנאי ע"מ ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך, שהוא יעסוק בקבורת יע"א להמשיך כח זה לדורות עולם.
translation: And we will precede with what is stated in the Midrash, Parashat Vayigash: "And I will also raise you up, you and all the righteous like you." And Joseph will place his hand upon your eyes, in order that Joseph will place his hand upon your eyes. The explanation is that he will also elevate all the righteous who will rise from there in their merit, and this refers to all the tribes whose bones are also buried in the land, as mentioned below. It is possible that the meaning is that just as he will ascend to the land to merit resurrection, which is only for those who dwell in the Land of Israel, so will the Holy One, blessed be He, do for all the righteous. However, Jacob will elevate him immediately upon his death, and all the righteous who are buried outside the land will ascend to the Land of Israel at the time of resurrection, through the reincarnation of graves, as stated in the explanation. It is clear from the words of the aforementioned Midrashim that he did not need to be raised to the Land of Israel for himself, for he would have been gathered to his ancestors regardless. And the reason he commanded this was to pave the way for his sons after him, just as all the actions of the patriarchs were for this purpose, as the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Abraham: "Go and pave the way for your children." Similarly, he commanded to raise him to the Land of Israel, so that his seventy descendants would merit to ascend to the land. And all the righteous until the end of all generations will merit the resurrection of the dead through the reincarnation of graves, and all this was on the condition that "Joseph will place his hand upon your eyes," meaning that he will be engaged in the burial, in order to extend this power to future generations.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's burial in the Land of Israel, emphasizing that his elevation serves not only his own merit but also paves the way for his descendants and all righteous individuals to attain resurrection. It highlights the belief that while Jacob was destined to join his ancestors, his command to be buried in Israel was intended to ensure that his children and future generations would also have the opportunity for resurrection. The text underscores the idea that Joseph's role in this process is crucial, as he is tasked with the burial, thereby transmitting this spiritual power to future generations. Ultimately, it reflects a deep connection between the righteous, their burial places, and the promise of resurrection in the Holy Land.

passage_content: נמצא שבמעשה הזה עשה יוסף חסד עם כל המתים עד סוף כל הדורות, שיזכו לעלות לעת"ל בעת התחי', וז"ש יע"א ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת דייק לומר עמדי" ולא אמר עמי, שיע"א לא הי' צורך בו לעצמו, ועיקר החסד נעשה בזה לשאר המתים, ע"ו שעסק יוסף בקבורת יעקב, ע"כ אמר ועשית עמדי ר"ל על ידי ועל ידך, יהי' נשלם ונעשה חסד ואמת עם המתים של כל דורות ישראל העתידים, ולזה חלקן לשנים חסד ואמת, דליע"א הי' בבחי' חסד. הגם דלא איכפת לי' וכנ"ל, מ"מ רצונו הק' הי' שיעסקו בו כדי שיהי' בזה טובה לדורות הבאים, וע"י שיעשו רצונו יהי' עושין עמו חסד, אבל לא הי' חסד של אמת כי שילם לו גמולו כנ"ל וחסד של אמת יעשה עם שאר המתים וא"ש דברי המדרש הנ"ל אנכי אעשה כדבריך, כשם שאתה מצוני כך אנו אצוה לאחי בשעת מיתתי, שזה הי' טעם הציווי כדי לכבוש דרך לבניו כנ"ל, ולכך הבטיחו שיעשה רצונו גם יצוה לאחיו והם יצוו לבניהם שיעלו אותם ובזה יהי' נשלם רצונו של יע"א.
translation: It is found that in this act, Joseph did kindness with all the dead until the end of all generations, that they should merit to rise in the future at the time of the resurrection. And this is what is meant by "and you will do kindness and truth with me," it is precise to say "with me" and not "with us," for it was not necessary for him for himself, and the essence of the kindness was done here for the other dead. Therefore, since Joseph was involved in the burial of Jacob, he said "and you will do kindness with me," meaning through me and by your hand, there will be completed and done kindness and truth with the dead of all the generations of Israel to come. And for this reason, he divided it into two: kindness and truth, for the future was in the aspect of kindness. Although it did not concern him, as mentioned above, nevertheless, the Holy One’s will was that they should engage in it so that there would be goodness for the coming generations, and by doing His will, they would be doing kindness with him. However, it was not kindness of truth because he was repaid for his reward as mentioned above, and kindness of truth will be done with the other dead. And the words of the Midrash are clear: "I will do as you say," just as you commanded me, so I will command my brothers at the time of my death. This was the reason for the commandment, to pave the way for his sons, as mentioned above. Therefore, he promised him that he would do his will, and he would also command his brothers, and they would command their sons to elevate them, and in this way, the will of the future will be fulfilled.
summary: In this passage, the author highlights Joseph's act of kindness towards the deceased, ensuring that all future generations of Israel will have the opportunity for resurrection. The phrase "ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת" emphasizes that Joseph's actions were not for his own benefit but rather to fulfill God's will, thereby creating a lasting impact on the souls of the dead. The distinction between "חסד" and "חסד של אמת" reflects the idea that true kindness is directed towards others, particularly the deceased, and that Joseph's obedience to God's command serves to establish a legacy of compassion for future generations. Ultimately, this act of kindness is seen as a means to connect the living with the spiritual needs of the dead, ensuring that God's intentions are realized through the generations.

passage_content: והנה איתא במד"ר פ' וישב עה"פ ויאמר לו מה החלום הזה אשר חלמת כך הי' יע"א סבור שתחה"מ מגעת בימיו וכו', ויתכן שגם השבטים הק' וכל ישראל היו סבורים כ"ז שיע"א הי' חי, שיזכו לתחה"מ בימיהם ולא יהי' שעבוד, ועכשיו ראו שיע"א מצוה ליוסף להתעסק עמו בקבורה אדי לעשות פועל דמיוני לכל המתים אחריו, הבינו מזה שלא יהי' תחה"מ בימיהם, ע"כ מאז הרגישו השעבוד שעתיד להיות אחר זמן, ולזה שפיר נרמז הסתימה אצל ויחי יעקב. דממה שצוה את יוסף על קבורתו, השיגו הגלות המעותד לבוא ונסתמו עיניהם ולבם מצרת השעבוד מיד.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Midrash on Parashat Vayeshev regarding the verse "And he said to him, 'What is this dream that you have dreamed?'" that it was thought that the resurrection of the dead would occur in their days, etc. It is possible that the holy tribes and all of Israel also believed that since Joseph was alive, they would merit the resurrection of the dead in their days and there would be no servitude. And now they saw that Joseph commanded to engage in his burial in order to create a symbolic act for all the dead after him; they understood from this that there would not be a resurrection of the dead in their days. Therefore, from then on, they felt the servitude that was destined to come later, and thus it is appropriately hinted at the conclusion regarding "And Jacob lived." From the fact that he commanded Joseph regarding his burial, they perceived the exile that was destined to come, and their eyes and hearts were closed due to the distress of the servitude immediately.
summary: The passage discusses the belief among the patriarchs and the tribes of Israel that the resurrection of the dead (Techiyat HaMetim) would occur in their time, as indicated by Joseph's dreams. However, upon receiving the command from Jacob to ensure his burial, they realized that this resurrection would not happen in their lifetime, leading them to understand the impending exile and servitude. This realization is symbolically hinted at in the closing of Jacob's life, where the command regarding his burial foreshadows the future suffering and oppression that the Israelites would endure. Thus, the text reflects on the tension between hope for redemption and the harsh reality of exile.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם דברי הגמרא (תענית דף ה' ע"ב) רב נחמן ורב יצחק הוו יתבי בסעודתא, אמר לי' ר"נ לר"י לימא מר מילתא, א"ל הכי אר"י אין מסיחין בסעודה שמא יקדים קנה לושט ויבא לידי סכנה, בתר דסעיד א"ל הכי א"ר יוחנן יעקב אבינו לא מת, א"ל וכי בכדי ספדו ספדנייא וחנטו חנטייא וקברו קברויא א"ל מקרא אני דורש שנא' ואתה אל תירא עבדי יעקב וגו' כי הנני מושיעך מרחוק ואת זרעך מארץ שבים, מקיש הוא לזרעו מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים עכ"ד הגמ'. והקשה הרי"ף בעין יעקב למה השיבו אין מסיחין בסעודה, והלא גם דברים אלו יש בהם איסור מטעם חשש סכנה שמא יקדים וכו', ואדרבה אם הי' משיבו עכשיו מה שא"ל בסוף הסעודה יע"א לא מת. הוא דיבור מועט מדיבור הזה שאמר אין מסיחין בסעודה שמא יקדים קנה לושט, ותירץ דר' יצחק הוכיחו לר"נ על ששאלו בתוך הסעודה, ואין כונתו לומר לו אינו יכול לדבר עכשיו לפי שאין מסיחין, אבל כיון להוכיחו שלא הי' לו לדבר ולשאול בתוך הסעודה שאין מסיחין בסעודה, וכיון שבא להוכיחו הוא סילק את עצמו מלסעוד כדי להשיבו, אבל השואל שהי' שואל והוא עסוק בסעודה, הי' לו לחוש ע"ע שלא יסיח בתוך הסעודה בשאלתו, וגם יחוש על המשיב לו וכו', ואם כוונתו שיפסיק מהאכילה להשיבו על שאלתו, גם זה אינו מהלכות דרך ארץ לומר לאוכל עמו משוך ידך ולא תאכל וכו' עכ"ד הרי"ף, אמנם עדיין צ"ב קישור דברי המימרא יע"א לא מת למה שהתחיל לומר אין מסיחין בסעודה, עוד יל"ד דבמה שהשיב לו ר' יצחק מקרא אני דורש וכו', עדיין לא תירץ כלום על קושיתו, דהתם נמי איכא לאקשויי וכי בכדי חנטו חנטיא וכו', ורש"י פי' ודחגטו חנטייא וכו' נדמה להם שמת אבל חי הי' עכ"ל וקשה דא"כ עיקר חסר מן הספר, ולא נתבאר כוונת התשובה
translation:
In another way, one could say that the aforementioned nuances are preceded by the words of the Gemara (Taanit 5b): Rav Nachman and Rav Yitzchak were sitting at a meal. Rav Nachman said to Rav Yitzchak, "Let the master say something." He replied, "Thus said Rabbi Yochanan: Jacob our father did not die." He asked, "And how could they eulogize him, embalm him, and bury him?" He said, "I derive from a verse, as it is written: 'And you, do not fear, My servant Jacob, etc., for behold, I will save you from afar and your offspring from the land of their captivity.' It connects him to his offspring: just as his offspring are alive, so too he is alive." Thus far the Gemara. 

The Rif in Ein Yaakov questions why he responded that one does not engage in conversation during a meal, for these matters also contain a prohibition due to the concern for danger, lest one’s windpipe be obstructed and come to harm. On the contrary, if he had responded to him now what he told him at the end of the meal, that he did not die, it is a minor statement compared to this one that says one does not engage in conversation during a meal, lest one’s windpipe be obstructed. 

He answered that Rabbi Yitzchak was reproving Rav Nachman for having asked him during the meal, and his intention was not to say that he cannot speak now because one does not engage in conversation, but rather to prove to him that he should not have spoken or asked during the meal, as one does not engage in conversation during a meal. And since he came to reprove him, he removed himself from eating in order to respond to him. However, the one who was asking while he was busy with the meal should have been concerned for himself not to engage in conversation during the meal with his question, and he should also be concerned for the one responding to him, etc. If his intention was that he should stop eating to respond to his question, this too is not in accordance with the ways of the world to say to one eating with him, "Withdraw your hand and do not eat," etc. Thus far the Rif. 

However, it is still difficult to connect the words of the statement "Jacob did not die" to the beginning of the statement that one does not engage in conversation during a meal. It is also necessary to clarify that in what Rabbi Yitzchak responded, "I derive from a verse, etc.," he still did not resolve anything regarding his question, for there too one could ask, "And how could they embalm him, etc.?" Rashi explained that they thought he had died, but he was alive. This is difficult, for if so, the essence is missing from the book, and the intention of the response is not clarified.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between Rabbi Nachman and Rabbi Yitzchak regarding the prohibition of conversation during a meal, highlighting the potential dangers of distraction. Rabbi Yitzchak emphasizes that Jacob is alive, drawing a parallel between Jacob's vitality and the life of his descendants, suggesting a continuity of spiritual presence. The text reflects on the importance of maintaining focus during sacred moments, illustrating a key Hasidic concept of the interconnectedness of life and the divine. Ultimately, it raises questions about the nature of communication and the sanctity of time spent in spiritual engagement.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי הגמ' (שבת צ"ו ע"ב) ת"ר מקושש זה צלפחד וכן הוא אומר ויהיו בנ"י במדבר וגו', ולהלן הוא אומר אבינו מת במדבר מה להלן צלפחד אף כאן צלפחד דברי ר"ע, א"ל ר"י בן בתירא בין כך ובין כך אתה עתיד ליתן את הדין, אם כדבריך התורה כסתו ואתה מגלה אותו, ואם לאו אתה מוצא לעז על אותו צדיק, והקשו בגמ' לר' יהודה בן בתירא ואלא הא גמיר גז"ש, פרש"י וא"כ לא כסהו התורה, ומשני ר' יהודה בן בתירא לא גמיר גז"ש, ואין אדם דן גז"ש מעצמו עכ"ד הגמ', ולכאורה יל"ד לשיטת ר"ע דגמיר גז"ש וא"כ התורה גילהו דגז"ש מסיני נאמרה, ומ"ע לא גילהו הכתוב במקומו, שנא' וימצאו איש מקושש וגו', שם הי"ל לפרש דצלפחד הי', ואז לא הי' צורך לגז"ש כלה גם דגז"ש צריך להיות מופנה ומיותר, וטעמא בעו מה שכיסתו הכתוב במקומו וגילהו במקו"א בפ' נחלות.
translation:
To clarify the matter, we will begin with the words of the Gemara (Shabbat 96b): "Our Rabbis taught: The one who gathered sticks was Tzelafchad, and it is stated, 'And the children of Israel were in the wilderness,' etc. Later it says, 'Our father died in the wilderness.' Just as there, it refers to Tzelafchad, so here it refers to Tzelafchad," these are the words of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said to him, "In any case, you will be held accountable. If, as you say, the Torah concealed it and you are revealing it, and if not, you are finding a slander against that righteous one." The Gemara challenges Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, "But this is a learned tradition of a verbal analogy!" Rashi explains, "And thus the Torah did not conceal it." The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira did not learn a verbal analogy, and no one derives a verbal analogy on their own. Thus far is the Gemara. 

At first glance, it seems to follow the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, who does learn a verbal analogy, and therefore the Torah revealed it, as the verbal analogy was said at Sinai. And the commandment did not reveal it in its place, as it is stated, "And they found a man gathering sticks," etc. There, it should have been explained that it was Tzelafchad, and then there would have been no need for the entire verbal analogy, as the verbal analogy must be directed and superfluous. The reason is needed for what the text concealed in its place and revealed in another place in the portion of the inheritances.
summary: The passage discusses the case of Tzelafchad, who gathered wood on Shabbat, highlighting the tension between revealed and concealed aspects of Torah law. Rabbi Akiva argues that the Torah's silence on Tzelafchad's identity implies a deeper, hidden meaning, while Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira warns against revealing what the Torah has concealed, suggesting that both interpretations carry significant consequences. This dialogue reflects key Hasidic themes of the interplay between divine revelation and human interpretation, emphasizing the importance of humility in understanding sacred texts. Ultimately, it illustrates the complexity of divine justice and the need for careful discernment in matters of faith.
