passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ (בפ' פנחס) ותקרבנה בנות צלפחד וגו' לאמר אבינו מת במדבר והוא לא הי' בתוך העדה וגו' ויקרב משה את משפטן לפני ה' ויאמר ה' אל משה לאמר כן בנות צלפחד דוברות נתן תתן להם אחזת נחלה וגו', ויל"ד דהרי כל משפטי התורה נאמרו למשה בסיני כללותיהן ופרטותיהן ופ' נחלות בכללן, וא"כ מה נשתנה פרשה זו שהוצרך משרע"ה לישאל עלי' מפי הגבורה, גם יל"ד במאמה"כ כן בנות צלפחד דוברות נתן תתן להם וגו', מה צורך להקדמה זו כן בנות צלפחד דוברות, דכשהוא אומר נתן תתן להם ידוע נדע שכנים דבריהם.
translation: And it will be explained in advance to interpret from the verse (in Parshat Pinchas) "And the daughters of Zelophehad approached, saying, 'Our father died in the wilderness, and he was not among the assembly...'" and Moses brought their case before the Lord. And the Lord said to Moses, saying, "The daughters of Zelophehad speak correctly; you shall surely give them a hereditary possession..." It is known that all the laws of the Torah were said to Moses at Sinai, both their generalities and particulars, including the section on inheritances. If so, what is different about this section that Moses needed to ask about it from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He? Also, it is known from the verse, "The daughters of Zelophehad speak correctly; you shall surely give them..." What is the need for this introduction, "The daughters of Zelophehad speak correctly"? For when it says, "You shall surely give them," it is clear that their words are known.
summary: In this passage, the author explores the unique case of the daughters of Zelophehad, who petitioned Moses for their inheritance despite the general laws of the Torah being given at Sinai. The inquiry into their request highlights the dynamic nature of divine law and the importance of individual circumstances in the application of Torah principles. The phrase "yes, the daughters of Zelophehad speak rightly" emphasizes the validity of their claim and suggests that divine justice is responsive to the needs of the people, reflecting a deeper understanding of God's relationship with humanity. This illustrates a key Hasidic concept: the interplay between established law and the evolving needs of the community.

passage_content: ופירשתי עפי"מ שדרשו רז"ל בספרי לאלה תחלק הארץ לכשרים כמותכם, ולפי"ז מי שאינו שומר תו"מ אין לו חלק בארץ, והנה לר"ע דמקושש זה צלפחד א"כ לכאורה אין לו חלק בארץ ואין בטענת בנותיו ממש. אמנם התוס' (ב"ב קי"ט ע"ב) הביאו בשם המדרש שמקושש לש"ש נתכוין וכו' עיי"ש, וזה היתה טענת בנות צלפחד שלא יגרע נחלתם, כי הוא לא הי' בתוך העדה הנועדים על ה', ר"ל בעדת קרח שאין להם חלק בארץ. ובמעשה דמקושש לש"ש נתכוין וע"כ מגיע לו חלק בארץ, אמנם לפי שהמחשבה שבלב אין אדם מכיר בו: ולא נמסר לב"ד של מטה לדון על המחשבה, ע"כ הוצרך משרע"ה להקריב משפטן לפני ה' אם מגיע לצלפחד חלק בארץ או לא, והשיב לו השי"ת שתי תשובות, הא' כן בנות צלפחד דוברות במה שאומרים כי אביהם צדיק הי' ונתכוון לש"ש ומגיע להם חלק בארץ, והב' הודיע לו הלכה לדורות נתן תתן להם וגו' שבמקום שאין בן הבנות יורשים ירושת אביהם, (עיין בדברנו פ' פנחס ביאור הענין באריכות).
translation: And I explained according to the interpretation that our Sages of blessed memory expounded in the Sifrei, "To these shall the land be divided among the righteous like you." According to this, one who does not observe the commandments has no portion in the land. Now, according to Rabbi Akiva, since the one who gathered sticks was Tzelafchad, it seems that he has no portion in the land, and the claim of his daughters is not valid. However, the Tosafot (Baba Batra 119b) brought in the name of the Midrash that the one who gathered sticks intended for the sake of Heaven, etc., see there. This was the claim of the daughters of Tzelafchad, that their inheritance should not be diminished, for he was not among the assembly that gathered against Hashem, meaning in the assembly of Korach, who have no portion in the land. In the case of the one who gathered sticks, he intended for the sake of Heaven, and therefore he is entitled to a portion in the land. However, since the thought in the heart is not known to a person, and it was not entrusted to the lower court to judge based on thought, therefore Moshe Rabbeinu needed to bring his case before Hashem to determine whether Tzelafchad is entitled to a portion in the land or not. And the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him with two responses: the first, that the daughters of Tzelafchad speak correctly in what they say, that their father was righteous and intended for the sake of Heaven, and they are entitled to a portion in the land; and the second, He informed him of the law for future generations, "You shall surely give them," etc., that in a place where there is no son, the daughters inherit their father's inheritance (see our discussion in Parashat Pinchas for a detailed explanation of the matter).
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of inheritance in the Land of Israel, emphasizing that those who do not observe the Torah and mitzvot have no share in the land. It addresses the case of Tzelafchad, whose daughters argue for their inheritance despite their father's actions, suggesting that his intentions were pure and aligned with divine will. The text highlights the importance of intention in spiritual matters, noting that human judgment cannot fully discern one's thoughts, leading to divine clarification that Tzelafchad's daughters are indeed entitled to their father's portion. Ultimately, it underscores the principle that in the absence of male heirs, daughters can inherit their father's legacy.

passage_content: ולפי"ז מה שמקושש לשם שמים נתכוין לא נודע עד עכשיו, שגילהו הקדוש ברוך הוא בפרשת נחלות במאמר כן בנות צלפחד דוברות, אבל מקודם לזה לא נתברר מחשבתו, ועל כן בפרשת מקושש כתיב ויהיו בנו ישראל במדבר וימצאו איש, ולא גילה התורה דמקושש זה צלפחד, שלא להוציא לעז על אותו צדיק, רק בפ' נחלות שנתגלה במאמר השי"ת שלש"ש נתכוין, גילה הכתוב ע"י הגזירה שוה שהמקושש זה צלפחד, ואין בו משום לעז דלש"ש נתכוין. ועד"ז יובן דברי הגמרא הנ"ל הכי א"ר יוחנן יע"א לא מת א"ל וכי בכדי ספדו ספדנייא וכו' וכוונת הקושיא דהתורה כסתו ואתה מגלהו והראי' שלא ניתנה להתגלות מדחנטי חנעיא וספדו ספדניא כדי שיהיו סבורים עליו שמת, וא"כ למה לך לגלהו והשיב לו ר"ו מקרא אנו דורש שנא' ואתה אל תירא עבדי יעקב וגו' וכוונת התשובה דאז הי' עדיין קודם קבלת התורה, והי' צורך לכסות הענין מהמצריים לצורך השעה (כמבואר בדברנו להלן) אבל עכשיו כבר ניתנה התורה, וניתנה הגז"ש לדרוש ולגלות שוע"א לא מת ואין צורך בהעלמת הענין.
translation: According to this, what the one who gathered (the wood) intended for the sake of Heaven is not known until now, as the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed it in the portion of the inheritances in the statement "The daughters of Zelophehad speak," but prior to this, his intention was not clarified. Therefore, in the portion of the gatherer, it is written, "And the children of Israel were in the wilderness, and they found a man," and the Torah did not reveal that this gatherer was Zelophehad, in order not to cast aspersions on that righteous one. Only in the portion of inheritances, where it was revealed in the statement of the Holy One, blessed be He, that he intended for the sake of Heaven, did the text reveal through the principle of a verbal analogy that the gatherer was indeed Zelophehad, and there is no suspicion of aspersion since he intended for the sake of Heaven. Similarly, the words of the Gemara above can be understood: Rabbi Yochanan said, "He did not die," and he said to him, "Did they eulogize him just for that?" The intention of the question is that the Torah concealed it, and you reveal it, and the proof that it was not meant to be revealed is from the fact that Chanaia and his eulogizers eulogized him so that people would think he had died. If so, why do you need to reveal it? And he answered him, "We derive from a verse," as it is said, "And you, do not fear, My servant Jacob," and the intention of the answer is that at that time it was still before the giving of the Torah, and there was a need to conceal the matter from the Egyptians for the sake of the hour (as explained in our discussion below). But now that the Torah has already been given, and the verbal analogy has been given to interpret and reveal that he did not die, there is no need to conceal the matter.
summary: הקטע עוסק בהבנת כוונת המקושש, צלפחד, וההסתרה של שמו עד לפרשת נחלות, כדי למנוע לעז על צדיק. הוא מדגיש את חשיבות הכוונה לשם שמיים, ומסביר שהגילוי של צלפחד נעשה רק לאחר מתן תורה, כאשר ניתן היה לדרוש את הכתוב מבלי להסתיר את האמת. כמו כן, הוא מתייחס לשיח בגמרא על הצורך להסתיר מידע לפני מתן תורה, אך לאחר מכן ניתן לגלות את האמת ללא חשש.

passage_content: ומה ששייך מימרא זו לענין הסעודה נל"פ בהקדם דברי הרמב"ן הק' (פ' בראשית) עה"כ כי ביום אכלך ממנו וגו' וז"ל, ויתכן שפירות גן עדן נבלעים באיברים כמן ומקיימין את אוכליהן, וכאשר גזר עליו ואכלת את עשב השדה וגו' הי' זה סבה להפסד כי עפר הוא ועפר יאכל וכו' עכל"ק ולכאורה יקשה לפי הנחה זו הלא גם ועאע"ה אכל מאכלים הארציים וה"ז סיבה להפסד ואיך יוכל להתקיים לעד. ויתבאר עפ"י דברי הר"י עמדין זלה"ה בענין העצם לוז וז"ל, ועתה בהיותי עוסק בענין הראוני מן השמים וכו'. הענין הוא שידעו חכמי האמת, אחר שבעלי ההוי' עלולים להפסד וכל מורכב מתפרד, אם הי' כל גופו של אדם מורכב בשוה הי' מקבל הזנה כולו כאחד, אז בבוא קצו יתפרד וכו' ולא ישאר ממנו כלום וכו', וע"כ אינו ניזון כדרך שאר העצמות וכו', אמנם הוא נהנה מסעודה שאין בה אכילה גמורה דהיינו סעודת מוצ"ש שנאכלת על השבע ואין אוכלים אותה אכילה גמורה, באופן שאין הנאה מגעת לעצמות האחרים כי אם לזה, כי לא לאכילה הוא צריך רק מכוונת המצוה הוא נהנה ולא מגשמיות האכילה וכו' עייש"ד. והנה יע"א בודאי כל אכילתו הי' רק לעבדות ה' ב"ה, וכל מזונו הי' רק לכוונת המצוה, ועי"ז הי' מהפך חומר המאכל עד שלא יהי' עלול להפסד עוד ויוכל להתקיים.
translation: And regarding how this saying relates to the matter of the meal, it seems appropriate to preface with the words of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed (Parashat Bereishit) on the verse "for on the day you eat of it..." He writes, "It is possible that the fruits of the Garden of Eden are absorbed into the limbs and sustain their eaters, and when he decreed upon him 'and you shall eat the herb of the field,' this was a cause for loss because it is dust, and dust shall eat..." etc. And at first glance, this is difficult according to this assumption, for also our forefather Abraham ate earthly foods, and this is a reason for loss, and how could he exist forever? It can be explained according to the words of Rabbi Yisrael of Shklov, may his memory be blessed, regarding the essence of the Luzz nut, and he writes, "And now, while I am engaged in the matter, I was shown from heaven..." etc. The matter is that the sages of truth know that since beings of existence are subject to loss and everything that is composed will disintegrate, if the entire body of a person were composed equally, it would receive nourishment all at once, then at the end of its time it would disintegrate, etc., and nothing would remain of it, etc. Therefore, it does not receive nourishment like other essences, etc. However, he enjoys a meal that does not involve complete eating, namely the meal of Motzei Shabbat, which is eaten when one is satisfied and is not eaten as a complete meal, in a way that the enjoyment does not reach the essence of the others but only to this one, for he does not need it for eating, but rather he enjoys it from the intention of the commandment and not from the physicality of the eating, etc. And behold, it is certain that all his eating was only for the service of the Blessed Hashem, and all his sustenance was only for the intention of the commandment, and through this, he transforms the material of the food so that it will no longer be subject to loss and can exist.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of sustenance and its spiritual implications, referencing the Ramban's insights on the consumption of earthly food and its potential for decay. It emphasizes that while all physical beings are subject to deterioration, a person can elevate their sustenance through intention and divine service, transforming the material into something eternal. The concept of the "Luz bone" is introduced, symbolizing the part of the body that remains incorruptible, highlighting the idea that true nourishment comes from fulfilling divine commandments rather than mere physical consumption. Ultimately, the text illustrates how the intention behind eating can transcend physicality, allowing for a connection to the eternal.

passage_content: וראיתי בספה"ק לפרש אמרם ז"ל אין מסיחין בסעודה וכו', דהנה עבודת התפלה ולימוד התורה הוא ע"י הגרון, והאכילה ע"ו הוושט, ודרך הצדיקים שגם האכילה אצלם עבודה חשובה כמו התורה ותפלה, ואם מסיחין בסעודה בד"ת עי"ז מראה שאין האכילה עבודה אצלו כל כך כמו התורה ותפלה דהרי לטעם זה מפסיק בה, וע"כ רמז לו אין מסיחין בסעודה שמא יקדים קנה לוושט, היינו שמא יקדים עבודת הקנה שהוא תורה ותפלה לעבודת הוושט שהוא האכילה, ובזה יבואר קישור דברי הגמרא דבאמצע הסעודה השיבו אין מסיחין בסעודה, והטעם שמא יקדים קנה לוושט היינו עבודת הקנה כנ"ל, ואחר הסעודה חיזק לו ד"ז בראי' שוע"א לא מת, וע"כ משום שאצלו הי' גם עבודת אכילה עבודה חשובה וכל אדם צריך להשתדל בזה, וע"ז הוכיחו שלא הי' לו להפסיק בד"ת באמצע הסעודה שהוא ג"כ עבדות השי"ת והראי' מוע"א שלא מת וא"ש הקישור. ובדרך אגב נל"פ מאמר נפלא (באבות דר"נ רפי"א) ר"ט אומר אין אדם מת אלא מתוך הבטלה שנאמר (בראשית מ"ט) ויגוע ויאסף אל עמיו ע"כ וצ"ב, והבנין יהושע נדחק לפרש שהוא דרך רמז בעלמא ויגוע ממלאכה ויאסף אל עמיו וכו' עיי"ש, ונל"פ עפימ"ש רש"י עה"פ ויגוע ויאסף אל עמיו, ומיתה לא נאמרה בו ואמרו רז"ל יעקב אבינו לא מת ע"כ, וזה משמיענו שאין אדם מת אלא מתוך הבטלה ר"ל ביטול תורה ועבדות השי"ת שהאדם בעצמו גורם לנפשו מיתה וכאמרם ז"ל אין מיתה בלא חטא. ואם תקשה הלא המיתה גזירה קדומה הוא, ע"ז הביא ראי' מיע"א שנאמר ויגוע ויאסף אל עמיו ומיתה לא כתיב בי' שוע"א לא מת, הרי שאין אדם מת אלא מתוך הבטלה שאלמלא לא הי' מבטל מתורה ועבדות ה' לא הי' מת כמו שהי' בוע"א.
translation: And I saw in the holy books to explain their saying, may their memory be blessed, that one does not engage in conversation during a meal, etc. Behold, the service of prayer and the study of Torah is through the throat, while eating is through the esophagus. And the way of the righteous is that even eating is for them an important service, just like Torah and prayer. If one engages in conversation during the meal about Torah matters, it shows that eating is not such an important service for him as Torah and prayer, for he interrupts it for that reason. Therefore, it hinted to him that one does not engage in conversation during a meal, lest he prioritize the throat over the esophagus, meaning that he might prioritize the service of the throat, which is Torah and prayer, over the service of the esophagus, which is eating. This clarifies the connection to the words of the Gemara that in the middle of the meal they answered that one does not engage in conversation during a meal, and the reason is lest he prioritize the throat over the esophagus, meaning the service of the throat as mentioned. And after the meal, he strengthened this with the proof that he did not die, and therefore, because for him eating was also an important service, every person should strive for this. And for this, they proved that he should not interrupt for Torah matters in the middle of the meal, which is also service of the Blessed One, and the proof is that he did not die, and this clarifies the connection. Incidentally, I found a wonderful saying (in Avot de-Rabbi Natan, chapter 1) that Rabbi Tanchum says, "A person does not die except through idleness," as it is said (Genesis 49), "and he drew near and was gathered to his people," and this is puzzling. The building of Yehoshua was pressed to explain that it is merely a hint, that he drew near from work and was gathered to his people, etc. See there. And I would like to suggest according to what Rashi says on the verse "and he drew near and was gathered to his people," that death was not said about him, and our sages said that our father Jacob did not die. Therefore, this teaches us that a person does not die except through idleness, meaning the nullification of Torah and the service of the Blessed One, for a person himself causes his soul to die, as our sages said, "There is no death without sin." And if you will ask, "Isn't death an ancient decree?" To this, he brought a proof from the verse that says, "and he drew near and was gathered to his people," and death is not written about him, our father Jacob did not die. Thus, it is clear that a person does not die except through idleness, for if he had not nullified his Torah and the service of the Lord, he would not have died, just as it was with our father Abraham.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of eating as a form of divine service, akin to prayer and Torah study, highlighting that one should not interrupt their meal with discussions of Torah to maintain the sanctity of the act of eating. It suggests that prioritizing spiritual pursuits over physical needs can lead to a disconnection from the essence of life, as seen in the teachings about death stemming from idleness or neglect of spiritual duties. The text also references the idea that true vitality is linked to continuous engagement in divine service, implying that neglecting this can lead to spiritual death, as exemplified by the assertion that Jacob did not die because he remained engaged in his spiritual work.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר אומרו חסד ואמת בהקדם דברי הת"א עה"פ (בראשית ל"ט כ"ב) ואת כל אשר עושים שם הוא הי' עושה, וית כל די עבדין במימרי' הוה מתעביד ע"כ, מבואר דמה שנעשה במימרי' ועפ"י צוואתו נקרא העשי' על שמו, והנה יע"א אמר ליוסף ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, ובאמת לגבי יוסף לא הי' זה חסד של אמת ולא חסד שעושים עם המתים, דהרי ידע שיע"א לא מתק משא"כ המצריים שסברו ונדמה להם שמת, הי' נחשב להם חסד של אמת מה שעשו עם יע"א שנאמר ויעלו אתו וגו' וכל זקני ארץ מצרים וגו' ויספדו שם מספד גדול וכבד, נמצא הי' כאן ב' בחינות ונקראו שניהם ע"ש יוסף כמ"ש ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, לפי שכל זה במימרי' הוה מתעביד על כן נקראת על שמו, וז"ש ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת לרמוז על ב' הבחינות הנ"ל ומה שבקש על חסד של אמת ולכאורה מנפק"מ ומה צורך לו בחסדם של המצריים באיזה בחי' שיהי', ויובן עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר (פרשה זו) א"ר אבהו אותן ע' יום שבין אגרת לאגרת (בין אגרת המן בי"ג בניסן לבין אגרת מרדכי בכ"ג בסיון) כנגד ע' יום שעשו מצריים חסד עם יע"א ע"כ, ובירושלמי מבואר שבאותן ע' ימים שבין אגרת לאגרת הי' שמחה גדולה לעכו"ם על דברי האגרת שכתוב בה להרוג ולאבד וגו', וזה הי' שכרם על אותן הע' ימים שעשו חסד עם יע"א, וע"כ בקש יע"א שיהי' רק חסד של אמת שלא יצפו לתשלום גמול, ואעפ"כ קיבלו שכרם כו אין הקב"ה מקפח שכר כל ברי', אבל אלמלא היו מצפים לתשלום גמול מי יודע מה הי' מדת שכרם, וכמ"ש הגה"ק מבאעשוטש זלל"ה לפרש המאמר ותן שכר טוב וכו' שלתשלום שכר צריך אתערותא דלתתא עייש"ד, וע"כ אם היו מצפין לתשלום גמול הי' ח"ו גרוע לישראל יותר, ע"כ ביקש יע"א שיהי' רק חסד של אמת שלא יצפו לתשלום גמול.
translation: And we will come to explain the saying of "kindness and truth" in light of the words of the Targum on the verse (Genesis 39:22) "and all that they did there, he was doing," and everything that was done in his words was being done. Therefore, it is clear that what was done in his words and according to his command is called the action in his name. And behold, he said to Joseph, "And you will do kindness and truth with me." And in truth, regarding Joseph, this was not kindness of truth, nor kindness done with the dead, for he knew that his father was not dead, unlike the Egyptians who thought and imagined that he was dead; it would be considered for them kindness of truth what they did with Joseph, as it is said, "And they brought him up," etc., "and all the elders of the land of Egypt," etc., "and they mourned there a great and heavy mourning." Thus, there were here two aspects, and both were called by Joseph's name, as it is said, "And you will do kindness and truth with me," since all this was done in his words, therefore it is called by his name. This is what is meant by "And you will do kindness and truth with me," to hint at the two aspects mentioned above and what he requested for kindness of truth. And seemingly, what difference does it make, and what need does he have for the kindness of the Egyptians in any aspect it may be? It can be understood according to what is stated in the Midrash (in this section), Rabbi Abahu said, those forty days between one letter and another (between the letter of Haman on the 13th of Nisan and the letter of Mordechai on the 23rd of Sivan) correspond to the forty days that the Egyptians did kindness with Joseph. And in the Jerusalem Talmud, it is explained that during those forty days between one letter and another, there was great joy among the idolaters regarding the words of the letter that was written in it to kill and to destroy, etc. This was their reward for those forty days that they did kindness with Joseph. Therefore, Joseph requested that it be only kindness of truth, that they should not expect a reward. And nevertheless, they received their reward, for the Holy One, blessed be He, does not withhold the reward of any creature. But if they had not expected a reward, who knows what their measure of reward would have been, as explained by the holy Rabbi from Baashtush, may his memory be blessed, to explain the saying "and give a good reward," etc., that for the payment of reward, there needs to be an awakening from below, as is known. Therefore, if they were expecting a reward, it would have been, Heaven forbid, worse for Israel. Thus, Joseph requested that it be only kindness of truth, that they should not expect a reward.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "chesed ve'emet" (kindness and truth) in relation to Joseph and the Egyptians' treatment of him. It highlights that while the Egyptians performed acts of kindness towards Joseph, their motivations were not entirely pure, as they expected a reward. Joseph's request for "chesed shel emet" signifies a desire for genuine kindness that is not contingent on receiving a reward, emphasizing the importance of selfless acts in the divine economy of reward and punishment. The text illustrates that true kindness, devoid of expectation, holds a higher spiritual value, and that God rewards all acts of kindness, even those done with ulterior motives.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי הגמ' הנ"ל (במס' תענית) בהקדם מה דאיתא בזוה"ק פ' תרומה (דף קמ"א ע"ב) גופיהון דצדיקיא דלא מתענגו בהאי עלמא אלא מתענוגי דמצוה, וסעודתי שבתין וחגיו וזמנין, ההוא רוח מסאבא לא יכיל לשלטאה עלייהו, דהא לא אתענגי מדילי' כלום, והואיל ולא נטלו מדילי' לית לי' רשו עליהון כלל, זכאה איהו מאן דלא אתהני מדילי' כלום וכו', מאן דנשמתו' נפקא לבר מארעא קדישא, וההוא גופא אסתאב בההוא רוח מסאבו וכו', ואי ההוא גופא סלקין לי' לאתקברא גו ארעא קדישא, עלי' כתיב (ירמי' ב') ותבאו ותטמאי את ארצי ונחלתי שמתם לתועבה וכו', יוסף לא שליט על גופי' רוח מסאבו לעלמין אע"ג דנשמתי' נפקת ברשו אחרא, מ"ט בגין דלא אתמשיך בחייו בתר רוח מסאבא, ועם כל דא לא בעא דגופי' יסלקון לי' לאתקברא בארעא קדישא, אלא אמר והעליתם את עצמותי ולא גופי', יעקב לא מות וגופי' אתקיים בקיומא תדיר ולא דחיל לסטרא אחרא, דהא ערסי' הוה שלים בשלימו דנהורא עלאה וכו', ועל דא כתיב בי' ושכבתי עם אבותי ונשאתני ממצרים גופא שלים, וע"ד ויחנטו הרופאים את ישראל, דגופי' יהא קאים בקיומא והכי אצטריך עכ"ד הזוה"ק, חזינן שהזוה"ק מחמיר מאוד בענין זה, מאן דנשמתי' נפקא לבר מארעא קדישא שלא להעלותו לקברו בא"י, דעלי' כתיב ותבאו ותטמאי את ארצי וגו' ומי לנו גדול מיוסף הצדיק דלא שליט על גופי' רוח מסאבא לעלמין, ועם כל דא לא בעא דגופי' יסלקון לי' לאתקברא בארעא קדישא, אלא אמר והעליתם את עצמותי ולא גופי', ויעקב אבינו שצוה להעלות גופי', טעמא רבא איכא בגווי' דהא לא מית וגופי' אתקיים בקיומא תדיר, ובודאי שא"א ללמוד ממנו לכל אדם, כי אין מי שישוה וידמה לערך בחינתו הקדושה.
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the Gemara mentioned above (in Tractate Ta'anit) in light of what is stated in the Zohar, Parashat Terumah (page 141b), regarding the essence of the righteous who do not take pleasure in this world but rather in the pleasures of the mitzvah, and the meals of Shabbat and festivals, that the spirit of impurity cannot rule over them, for they do not derive any pleasure from it. Since they have not taken from it, it has no authority over them at all. Blessed is he who does not derive any benefit from it, etc. One whose soul departs from the holy land, and that very essence is bound to that spirit of impurity, etc. And if that very essence is taken to be buried in the holy land, it is written about it (Jeremiah 2): "And you came and defiled my land, and made my inheritance an abomination," etc. Joseph did not allow the spirit of impurity to rule over his body, even though his soul departed under another authority. Why? Because he did not continue in his life under the spirit of impurity. And despite all this, he did not want his body to be taken to be buried in the holy land, but rather he said, "And you shall carry up my bones, but not my body." Jacob did not die, and his body exists in a constant state of existence and did not fear the other side, for his bed was complete in the completeness of the upper light, etc. Therefore, it is written about him, "And I lay down with my fathers, and you shall carry me up from Egypt," meaning his body is complete. And regarding "And the physicians embalmed Israel," that his body will stand in existence, and thus the Zohar concludes. We see that the Zohar is very strict regarding this matter, that one whose soul departs from the holy land should not be brought to be buried in the land of Israel, for it is written, "And you came and defiled my land," etc. And who is greater than Joseph the righteous, who did not allow the spirit of impurity to rule over his body forever? And despite all this, he did not want his body to be taken to be buried in the holy land, but rather he said, "And you shall carry up my bones, but not my body." And our father Jacob, who commanded to carry up his body, has a great reason in himself, for he did not die, and his body exists in a constant state of existence, and certainly one cannot learn from him for every person, for there is no one who can compare or resemble his holy value.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the physical body and the spiritual essence of the righteous, emphasizing that true pleasure for the tzaddikim comes from the fulfillment of mitzvot rather than worldly enjoyment. It highlights the idea that the soul of a tzaddik, such as Joseph, is not subject to the negative influences of the physical world, allowing them to remain spiritually intact even after death. The text underscores the importance of burial in the Holy Land, yet notes that Joseph preferred the elevation of his bones rather than his body, reflecting a higher spiritual state. Jacob, on the other hand, is portrayed as having a unique status where his body remains in a perpetual state of existence, illustrating the profound spiritual significance of the tzaddik's connection to the divine.

passage_content: אמנם בירושלמי (כלאים פ"ט סוף ה"ג) נראה דפליגי רבנן בהא אי שפיר דמי להעלות המת לא"י לקבורה, וז"ל הירושלמי רבי בר קיריא ורבי לעזר הוון מטיילין באיסטרין. ראו ארונות שהיו באין מחו"ל לארץ, אמר רבי קיריא לרבי לעזר מה הועילו אילו, אני קורא עליהם (ירמי' ב') ונחלתי שמתם לתועבה בחייכם, ותבואו ותטמאי את ארצי במיתתכם, אמר לי' כיון שהן מגיעין לארץ ישראל הן נוטלין גוש עפר ומניחין על ארונן דכתיב וכפר אדמתו עמו עכ"ד הירושלמי, וכיו"ב מצינו בבבלי (כתובות קי"א ע"א) עולא נח נפשי' בחו"ל, אתו אמרו לי' לרבי אלעזר, אמר אנת עולא על אדמה טמאה תמות, אמרו לו ארונו בא. אמר להם אינו דומה קולטתו מחיים לקולטתו לאחר מיתה, ולהלן בגמ' שם רבה ורב יוסף דאמרי תרוייהו כשרין שבבבל ארץ ישראל קולטתן וכו' לענין קבורה, פרש"י של בבל מוליכין ארונותיהם ליקבר בארץ ישראל עכ"ל, מבואר דאיכא מ"ד דס"ל דתקנתא הוא לנפש המת להעלותו לא"י אף אם מת בחו"ל ואיכא דס"ל להיפך דלא הועיל כלום, ואדרבה מועלים ופוגמים ח"ו בקדושת הארץ, והרמב"ם ז"ל (פ"ה מה' מלכים הי"א) כתב וז"ל אמרו חכמים כל השוכן בא"י עוונותיו מחולין וכו', ובפורענות הוא אומר על אדמה טמאה תמות, ואינו דומה קולטתו מחיים לקולעתו אחר מותו, ואעפ"כ גדולי החכמים היו מוליכין את מתיהם לשם, צא ולמד מיעקב אבינו ויוסף הצדיק עכ"ל, הנה בעיקר הדבר לא כתב הרמב"ם ז"ל הלכה ברורה בזה, שכל מי שהיכולת בידו ישתדל לעשות כן, אלא הודיע לנו שגדולי החכמים היו מוליכין את מיתיהם לשם, ואולי הך תקנתא אינו אלא לגדולי החכמים דגופיהון קדוש, ונא שליט עלייהו רוח מסאבו לעלמין ובודאי לאו כל אנפין שווין בזה, אמנם מ"ש צא ולמד מיעקב אבינו ויוסף הצדיק צ"ע לפי"ד הזוה"ק הנ"ל, דיוסף הצדיק גופי' צוה להעלות עצמותיו בלבד, אף דלגודל בחי' קדושתו לא הי' מקום לחששא המבוארת בזוה"ק לגבי רובא דעלמא, מ"מ לגודל ענותנותו נמנע מליעביד עובדא בנפשי', ויעקב אבינו שאני דלא מית וגופי' קיים, ואיך אפשר למילף מיעקב אבינו ויוסף הצדיק, אמנם ידוע שבימי הרמב"ם ז"ל לא נתגלה עדיין ספר הזוה"ק, וע"כ אזיל בתר שיעת הגמ' דידן דרבה ורב יוסף אמרו תרוייהו כשרין שבבבל ארץ ישראל קולטתן וכו', ונראה לו דכשרין דוקא מהך טעמא המבואר לעיל, וע"כ כתב דגדולי החכמים היו עושין כן ועוד נבאר בזה.
translation: Indeed, in the Jerusalem Talmud (Kilayim 9:3), it appears that the Rabbis disagree on whether it is proper to bring a deceased person to the Land of Israel for burial. The Jerusalem Talmud states: Rabbi Bar Kiryah and Rabbi Elazar were walking in the East. They saw coffins coming from abroad to the Land. Rabbi Kiryah said to Rabbi Elazar, "What benefit do these serve? I read about them (Jeremiah 2:7), 'And I gave them a land of desolation in your lifetime, and you come and defile my land with your death.'" He replied to him, "Since they arrive in the Land of Israel, they take a clod of earth and place it on their coffin, as it is written, 'And he shall atone for his land with his people.'" Thus concludes the Jerusalem Talmud. Similarly, we find in the Babylonian Talmud (Ketubot 111a) that Ulla died abroad. They came and told Rabbi Elazar, who said, "You, Ulla, will die on impure land." They said to him, "His coffin has arrived." He said to them, "The reception of the body while alive is not comparable to the reception after death." And later in the Gemara there, both Rabbah and Rav Yosef said that both of them, the righteous ones in Babylonia, are accepted in the Land of Israel, etc., regarding burial. Rashi explains that from Babylonia, they take their coffins to be buried in the Land of Israel. It is clear that there is an opinion that holds it is a remedy for the soul of the deceased to bring him to the Land of Israel even if he died abroad, and there is one who holds the opposite, that it is of no benefit at all, and rather they are detrimental and harm, Heaven forbid, the sanctity of the land. And Rambam, may his memory be blessed (Hilchot Melachim 5:11), wrote: "The Sages said, 'Whoever dwells in the Land of Israel, his sins are forgiven,' etc. And regarding punishment, it says, 'You will die on impure land,' and the reception of the body while alive is not comparable to the reception after death." Nevertheless, the great Sages would bring their dead there. Go and learn from our forefather Jacob and from the righteous Joseph. Thus concludes the Rambam. Here, fundamentally, the Rambam did not write a clear halacha on this matter, that anyone who has the ability should strive to do so, but he informed us that the great Sages would bring their dead there. Perhaps this remedy is only for the great Sages themselves, whose bodies are holy, and the spirit of their ancestors rules over them, and certainly not all people are equal in this regard. However, what he wrote, "Go and learn from our forefather Jacob and from the righteous Joseph," is questionable according to the aforementioned Zohar, that Joseph the righteous himself commanded to bring only his bones, even though due to the greatness of his holiness there was no place for the concern mentioned in the Zohar regarding the majority of the world. Nevertheless, due to his great humility, he refrained from performing an act for himself. And our forefather Jacob is different, as he did not die and his body remained intact. How can we derive from our forefather Jacob and from the righteous Joseph? However, it is known that in the days of Rambam, the Book of the Zohar had not yet been revealed, and therefore he followed the reasoning of our Gemara, where Rabbah and Rav Yosef said that both of them, the righteous ones in Babylonia, are accepted in the Land of Israel, etc. It seemed to him that they are accepted specifically for the reason explained above, and therefore he wrote that the great Sages would do so, and we will elaborate on this.
summary: The passage discusses the debate among sages regarding the burial of the dead in the Land of Israel, highlighting differing opinions on whether transporting a body from abroad is beneficial or detrimental to the sanctity of the land. It references the teachings of the Rambam, who notes that while the sins of those living in Israel are forgiven, there is a distinction between dying in the land and being brought there after death. The text emphasizes the actions of great sages, like Jacob and Joseph, who had their remains transported, suggesting that such practices may be reserved for the righteous. Ultimately, it reflects on the spiritual significance of burial in the Holy Land and the varying levels of holiness associated with different individuals.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לבאר דברי הגמ' דתענית (דף ה' ע"ב) רב נחמן ורב יצחק הוו יתבי בסעודתא, א"ל ר"נ לר"י לימא מר מילתא, א"ל הכי א"ר יוחנן אין מסיחין בסעודה שמא יקדים קנה לושט ויבא לידי סכנה, בתר דסעיד א"ל הכי א"ר יוחנן יעקב אבינו לא מת וכו', וצ"ב הקישור, ואפ"ל דהנה לפי"ד הזוה"ק הנ"ל דגופיהון דצדיקיא לא מתענגי בהאי עלמא אלא מתענוגי דמצוה וסעודתי שבתין וחגין וזמנין וכו' הואיל ולא נעלו מדילי' לית לי' רשו עליהון כלל, ולפי"ז לכאורה לא הי' להם לחוש ולמנוע מלדבר בדברי תורה בתוך הסעודה מחשש סכנה שמא יקדים קנה לושט, ואולי נזהרו קדושים הללו מלסוח בד"ת בתוך הסעודה, שהיו חושדין את עצמם שמא יכוונו אף להנאת הגוף בהדי המצוה ואיכא חשש סכנה, וראי' לדבר זה דכ"א צריך לחשוש על ככה, מדברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל דגופיהון דצדיקיא לא מתענגי בהאי עלמא אלא מתענוגי דמצוה וסעודתי שבתין וחנון. ההוא רוח מסאבא לא יכיל לשלטאה עלייהו, ויוסף הצדיק לא שליט על גופי' רוח מסאבא לעלמין, ועם כל דא לא בעא דגופי' יסלקין לי' לאתקברא בארעא קדישא, אלא אמר והעליתם את עצמותי ולא גופי', ואף דלפי מדריגת קדושתו לא הי' לו לחשוש על ככה, מ"מ דרך הצדיקים לתלות החסרון בעצמם דאולי נתכוון גם להנאתו, ומכ"ש וק"ו שצריכים שאר בנ"א לחשוד א"ע בכך.
translation: And now we will explain the words of the Gemara in Ta'anit (page 5b) where Rav Nachman and Rav Yitzchak were sitting at a meal. Rav Nachman said to Rav Yitzchak, "Let the master say something." He replied, "Thus said Rabbi Yochanan: One should not engage in conversation during a meal, lest one’s throat be choked and come to danger." After they had eaten, he said, "Thus said Rabbi Yochanan: Our forefather Jacob did not die," etc. The connection is puzzling, and it can be said that according to the explanation of the Zohar mentioned above, the very essence of the righteous does not derive pleasure in this world except from the pleasures of mitzvah and the meals of Shabbat and festivals, etc., since they do not take anything for themselves, they have no authority over them at all. According to this, it would seem that they should not have to be concerned and refrain from discussing words of Torah during the meal for fear of danger, lest one’s throat be choked. Perhaps these holy ones were careful not to engage in words of Torah during the meal, as they suspected themselves that they might also intend for the pleasure of the body alongside the mitzvah, and there is a concern for danger. The proof for this is that each person should be cautious about this, from the words of the aforementioned Zohar that the very essence of the righteous does not derive pleasure in this world except from the pleasures of mitzvah and the meals of Shabbat and festivals. That spirit of impurity cannot dominate them, and Joseph the righteous did not allow the spirit of impurity to rule over them in this world. And despite all this, he did not want his body to be removed to be buried in the holy land, but rather he said, "And you shall carry up my bones," not my body. And even though according to the level of his holiness he should not have had to be concerned about this, nevertheless, it is the way of the righteous to attribute the shortcoming to themselves, that perhaps they intended also for their own pleasure, and all the more so that other people should suspect themselves in this regard.
summary: The passage discusses a Talmudic dialogue between Rav Nachman and Rav Yitzchak regarding the prohibition of speaking during a meal due to potential danger, linking it to the concept that the righteous do not derive pleasure from worldly delights but rather from the joy of fulfilling commandments. It emphasizes the idea that even the most elevated individuals, like Joseph, are cautious about their intentions, fearing that they might inadvertently seek physical enjoyment alongside spiritual fulfillment. This reflects a broader Hasidic teaching that one should always be self-reflective and humble, recognizing the potential for personal shortcomings in spiritual pursuits. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining purity of intention in all actions, especially in the context of sacred practices.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר דברי הגמ' הנ"ל, ר"נ ור' יצחק הוו יתבי בסעודתא, א"ל ר"נ לר' יצחק לימא מר מילתא, א"ל הכי א"ר יוחנן אין מסיחין בסעודה שמא יקדים קנה לושט ויבא לידי סכנה, ולכאורה באמת מדוע ביקש ממנו ר"נ לומר לו ד"ת בתוך הסעודה אם יש חשש סכנה בדבר, אלא ודאי מפני שרב נחמן ס"ל דלצדיק גדול כר' יצחק א"צ לחשוש על ככה, כיון שאינם נהנים כ"א מתענוגי דמצוה, אמנם ר' יצחק השיב לו דהכי א"ר יוחנן אין מסיחין בסעודה מפני חשש סכנה, ודייק להודיע דאף ר' יוחנן שהי' בדור קדום ומעולה, מ"מ אמר כלל לכל אדם שאין מסיחין בסעודה מפני הסכנה, ובאמת הי' לו להביא ראי' יותר מבוררת מיוסף הצדיק כנ"ל, אלא שלא רצה להאריך בדיבור בתוך הסעודה מחשש הסכנה, לבתר דסעיד הביא ראי' וחיזוק לדבריו הראשונים, וא"ל הכי א"ר יוחנן יעקב אבינו לא מת, ר"ל דבאמת איכא ראי' מיוסף הצדיק ממה שלא צוה לבניו להעלותו מיד כ"א את עצמותיו לאח"ז, ועכ"ח דכל אדם יש לו לחשוד א"ע בכך דדלמא סעודתי' לאו מצו' הוא ואיכא חשש סכנה כנ"ל, איברא דראי' זו יש לה דחי' ממה שצוה יעאע"ה לבניו להוליך את גופו הקדוש מיד, ואפשר דיוסף הצדיק טעמא אחרינא הי"ל מה שלא צו' לבניו להוליכו מיד, וכמ"ש רש"י ז"ל בפ' בשלח אמר יוסף אני שליט הייתי במצרים והי' סיפק בידי לעשות, אבל בני לא יניחום מצרים לעשות, לכך השביעם לכשיגאלו ויצאו משם שישאוהו, וא"כ אין ראי' ממה שלא צו' יוסף להוליכו מיד, לז"א הכי איר יוחנן יעקב אבינו לא מת, וה"ט שצוה יעאע"ה להוליכו מיד ויוסף לא צוה כן כמבואר בזוה"ק, ואולי דלצד שחשד א"ע שאינו ראוי לכך, חשש ג"כ שמא לא יסתייע מילתא ולא יניחום המצריים ולטעם זה לא השביע לבניו שישאוהו מיד, ושפיר איכא למילף ממנו ק"ו לכל אדם. נמצא דממימרא דר' יוחנן הביא ראי' וחיזוק לדבריו הראשונים דאין מסיחין בסעודה והוא כלל שוה בכל אדם וא"ש הקישור.
translation: And similarly, the words of the aforementioned Gemara will be clarified: Rav Nachman and Rabbi Yitzchak were sitting at a meal. Rav Nachman said to Rabbi Yitzchak, "Let the master say a word." He replied, "Thus said Rabbi Yochanan: One does not engage in conversation during a meal, lest one’s windpipe precede one’s throat and one come to danger." And it seems, why did Rav Nachman ask him to say words of Torah during the meal if there is a concern for danger? Rather, it is certainly because Rav Nachman holds that for a great righteous person like Rabbi Yitzchak, there is no need to be concerned about this, since they derive pleasure only from the delights of the mitzvah. However, Rabbi Yitzchak responded to him that thus said Rabbi Yochanan: One does not engage in conversation during a meal due to the concern for danger, and he emphasized to inform that even Rabbi Yochanan, who was from an earlier and exalted generation, nevertheless stated a general rule for all people that one does not engage in conversation during a meal due to the danger. In truth, he should have brought a clearer proof from Joseph the Righteous as mentioned above, but he did not want to prolong the conversation during the meal out of concern for danger. After the meal, he brought a proof and reinforcement for his initial words, and he said, "Thus said Rabbi Yochanan: Our forefather Jacob did not die," meaning that in truth there is a proof from Joseph the Righteous from the fact that he did not command his sons to take him up immediately, but only his bones afterwards. And thus, every person should suspect themselves in this matter, for perhaps their meal is not a mitzvah and there is a concern for danger as mentioned above. However, this proof can be refuted from the fact that he commanded our forefather Abraham to take his holy body immediately, and it is possible that Joseph the Righteous had a different reason for not commanding his sons to take him immediately, as Rashi explains in Parshat Beshalach: "Joseph said, 'I was a ruler in Egypt and I had the means to do so, but my sons would not allow the Egyptians to do so.' Therefore, he made them swear that when they are redeemed and leave there, they should carry him." Thus, there is no proof from the fact that Joseph did not command to take him immediately. Therefore, Rabbi Yochanan said, "Our forefather Jacob did not die," and this is the reason that our forefather Abraham commanded to take him immediately, and Joseph did not command so, as explained in the Zohar. And perhaps, on the side that he suspected himself that he was not worthy of this, he also feared that perhaps the matter would not be facilitated and the Egyptians would not allow them, and for this reason, he did not make his sons swear to take him immediately. And it is fitting to learn from him a fortiori for every person. Thus, from the statement of Rabbi Yochanan, he brought a proof and reinforcement for his initial words that one does not engage in conversation during a meal, and this is a general rule applicable to all people, and the connection is clear.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between Rabbi Nachman and Rabbi Yitzchak regarding the prohibition of engaging in conversation during a meal due to potential danger. Rabbi Nachman believes that a great tzaddik like Rabbi Yitzchak need not worry about such risks, as their enjoyment comes solely from the mitzvah. However, Rabbi Yitzchak emphasizes that even esteemed figures like Rabbi Yochanan established this rule for all, highlighting the universal application of caution during meals. The text ultimately reinforces the idea that one should always be vigilant and humble, recognizing the potential for danger in spiritual and physical matters alike.

passage_content: והשיב לו ר"נ וכי בכדי חנטו חנעיא וכו' דהנה השיג ר"נ דמה שחנטוהו חנטיא וספדו ספדיא הי' בשביל להסתיר הענין, שיהיו סבורין עליו שהוא מת ויבואר בדברנו להלן כמה טעמים בזה, אלא שהקשה לו דהרי דבר זה נוגע לדינא לידע שיע"א לא מת, ולא יביאו ממנו ראי' להוליך מתיהם לא"י, כי אין מי שישו' אליו בבחינתו, וכמו"כ נלמד ממנו מימרא דר"י דאין מסיחין בסעודה כנ"ל וכיון דאיכא מקום למיטעי לא הי' להם להסתיר הדבר, דלא ליפיק מיני' חורבה, וכעין מ"ש ריש מס' ברכות (דף ב' ע"ב) שהקשו בגמרא ממאי דהאי ובא השמש ביאת השמש והאי וטהר טהר יומא דילמא ביאת אורו הוא ומאי וטהר טהר גברא, ותירצו דא"כ לימא קרא ויטהר מאי וטהר טהר יומא, וכתבו התוס' אע"ג דבכמה מקומות כתיב וטהר, התם ליכא למיטעי אבל הכא דאיכא למיטעי הו"ל למכתב ויטהר ע"כ, וזה שהקשה ר"נ לר"י לדבריך שהבאת ראי' להלכה שאין מסיחין בסעודה ממה שיע"א לא מת, הרי ענין זה נוגע להלכה לידע שלא מת, א"כ למה חנטו חנטיא וספדו ספדיא להסתיר הענין, הלא נפיק מני' חורבה, גם יביאו ראי' לעשות כמותו בענין זה וכנ"ל, והשיב לו ר"י מקרא אני דורש וכו' דאע"פ שחנטו וספדו אותו כדי להסתיר הענין, אמנם הסתרה זו אינו רק לבנ"א שאינן בני תורה לא במקרא ולא במשנה, ואצלם בלא"ה אין חשש שילמדו ממנו, כי אינם בגדר זה כלל ללמוד מיעאע"ה, משא"כ אצל בני תורה שיש מקום להך חששא, לא הוי חנטה והספד בגדר הסתרה, כי חז"ל גילו לנו מדרש הפסוקים שיע"א לא מת, דמקיש הוא לזרעו מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים וכפירש"י שהמתים אינם בשבי', ונלמד מזה שיעאע"ה בחיים חיותו עם הגוף כיון שהוא מוקש לזרעו, וממילא אין כאן הסתרה וחשש טעות כי הפסוק מגלה האמת, ובזה יובן למה לא הביאו חז"ל ראי' מן התורה מדלא הזכיר הכתוב בו לשון מיתה, דאי מהתם אין הכרח שהוא חי עם גופו, דאפשר רק שלא הי' נשמתו הק' בגדר מיתה כמו שפי' המהרש"א, משא"כ מג"ש שהוקש לזרעו ואין היקש למחצה מוכרח שנשאר בחיים עם גופו ושוב אין כאן מקום לטעות ולמילף מני' לשאר בנ"א.
translation: And R' Nachman responded to him, "Is it for the sake of hiding that they embalmed him and mourned for him, etc.? Behold, R' Nachman understood that the reason they embalmed him and mourned for him was to conceal the matter, so that people would think he was dead, and we will explain below several reasons for this. However, he challenged him, saying that this matter is relevant to the law, to know that he did not die, and they would not bring a proof from him to take their dead to the Land of Israel, for there is no one to whom they could refer in this regard. Likewise, we learn from the saying of R' Yochanan that one does not engage in conversation during a meal, as mentioned above, and since there is room for error, they should not have concealed the matter, lest it lead to a ruin. This is similar to what is stated at the beginning of Tractate Berachot (2b), where the Gemara challenges from the verse "And the sun set" and "And he was purified," perhaps it is the coming of his light, and what is "And he was purified," perhaps it is the purification of a person. They answered that if so, the verse should say "and he will be purified," what is "And he was purified"? And the Tosafot wrote that although in many places it is written "and he was purified," there it is not subject to error, but here, since there is room for error, it should have been written "and he will be purified." Therefore, R' Nachman challenged R' Yochanan regarding your words, that you brought a proof to the law that one does not engage in conversation during a meal from the fact that he did not die, this matter is relevant to the law to know that he did not die. If so, why did they embalm him and mourn for him to conceal the matter? Surely it would lead to a ruin, and they would bring a proof to act like him in this matter, as mentioned above. R' Yochanan responded to him, "I derive from a verse, etc." that although they embalmed and mourned him to conceal the matter, this concealment is only for people who are not scholars, neither in Scripture nor in Mishnah, and for them, there is no concern that they will learn from him, for they are not in the category at all to learn from our father Abraham. However, regarding scholars, where there is room for this concern, the embalming and mourning do not constitute a concealment, for our Sages revealed to us the midrash of the verses that our father Abraham did not die, for it is compared to his offspring: just as his offspring are alive, so is he alive, as Rashi explains that the dead are not in captivity. We learn from this that our father Abraham is alive, with his body, since he is compared to his offspring, and consequently, there is no concealment or concern for error, for the verse reveals the truth. And this explains why our Sages did not bring a proof from the Torah, since the text does not mention the term death regarding him, for if from there there is no necessity that he is alive with his body, it is possible that his holy soul was not in the category of death, as the Maharsha explained. However, from the comparison that he is linked to his offspring, and there is no half-comparison, it is necessary that he remains alive with his body, and thus there is no room for error and to learn from him for other people.
summary: In this passage, the discussion revolves around the concealment of the truth regarding the status of a righteous individual, emphasizing that the burial and mourning were intended to mislead those who are not learned in Torah. However, for those knowledgeable in scripture, the connection between the righteous and their descendants reveals that the individual remains alive, as indicated by the teachings of the sages. This highlights the concept that the righteous maintain a vital connection to life even after death, and the Torah provides clarity that dispels any misconceptions about their state. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of understanding the deeper truths within the teachings of the Torah to avoid misinterpretation.

passage_content:
באופן אחר יל"פ קושייתם ז"ל וכי בכדי חנטו חנטיא וכו' דגם ר"נ ידע שטעם החנטה הי' להסתיר הענין כדי שיהיו סבורין עליו שמת, אלא שהקשה לו דהרי הי' בזה נס נפלא שיהיו עסוקין בו זמן רב בחנטה והספד וקבורה, ובכל אריכות הזמן ההוא לא נודע להם מהותו ולא ראו בו סימני חיים, שהוא דבר שא"א אלא בדרך נס, וידוע שקב"ה לא עביד ניסא למגנא, ולכאורה מאי צורך הי' לנס זה שיתעסקו עמו אחרים, וזה שדייק לומר וכי בכדי חנטו ולא שאל למה חנעוהו. אלא וכי בכדי חנטו חנטיא, ר"ל מה צורך הי' לנס במעשה החנטה, והלא קב"ה לא עביד ניסא בכדי, וע"ז השיב לו ר"ו מקרא אני דורש מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים. וכפירש"י שיביאנו בגולה כדי לגאול את בניו לעיניו וכו', וראתה חכמתו ית"ש שהוא צורך הגאולה, שישאר יע"א בחיים ולעיניו הק' יגאלו את בניו בזמן הגאולה, ולפי שהוא מקושר לגאולתן של ישראל ההכרח להסתירו כמו כל העניינים השייכים אל הגאולה, כגון השתלשלות מלכות בית דוד שהי' בסוד נפלא מהמקטריגים כידוע מספה"ק, ובזה מתורץ שלא הי' הנס למגנא, כי צורך גדול 
הי' להסתיר הענין, ומיושב ג"כ בזה למה לא הביאו חז"ל ראי' מן התורה שוע"א לא מת, כקושיתנו לעיל אמנם עיקר כוונתו לתרץ שהי' צורך להסתיר הענין מפני שהוא מקושר עם גאולתן של ישראל, ונתבאר לנו כן ממה שהוקש הוא לזרעו מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים וכפרש"י ז"ל שלעיניו הק' יגאלו את בניו
translation: In another way, their question can be understood: "Did they embalm him for the sake of embalming?" etc. For even Rabbi Nachman knew that the reason for the embalming was to conceal the matter so that they would think he had died. However, he questioned him: "But there was a wonderful miracle in that they were occupied with him for a long time in embalming, eulogy, and burial, and throughout that long time, they did not know his essence and did not see signs of life in him, which is something that cannot happen except through a miracle. And it is known that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not perform miracles for the sake of concealment. Therefore, what was the need for this miracle that others should be occupied with him?" And this is why he precisely stated, "Did they embalm him for the sake of embalming?" meaning what was the need for a miracle in the act of embalming? After all, the Holy One, blessed be He, does not perform miracles for no reason. To this, Rabbi V'Rav answered him: "I derive from a verse: 'As his seed is alive, so he is alive.'" And as Rashi explained, he will bring us from exile to redeem his sons before his eyes, etc. And the wisdom of the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that it was necessary for the redemption that he should remain alive, and before his holy eyes, his sons would be redeemed at the time of redemption. And since he is connected to the redemption of Israel, it is necessary to conceal him like all matters related to redemption, such as the unfolding of the Davidic monarchy, which was in a wonderful secret from the accusers, as is known from the holy books. And this clarifies that the miracle was not for concealment, for there was a great need to hide the matter. It also explains why our Sages did not bring a proof from the Torah that Uzzah did not die, as we questioned above. However, the main intention is to clarify that there was a need to conceal the matter because it is connected to the redemption of Israel, and it has been explained to us in that he is compared to his seed: "As his seed is alive, so he is alive," and as Rashi, blessed be he, explained, that before his holy eyes, his sons will be redeemed.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of concealing the true nature of a certain individual, as it relates to the redemption of the Jewish people. It emphasizes that God's miracles are not performed for mere protection but serve a greater purpose, particularly in connection to the redemption process. The reference to the verse "as his seed is alive, so he is alive" highlights the idea that the individual is intrinsically linked to the future redemption of Israel. Ultimately, the concealment is portrayed as essential for the unfolding of divine plans related to the salvation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: נ עוד יתבאר בדברי הגמ' דתענית הנ"ל בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק (פ' בשלח) (דף מ"ח ע"ב) ות"ח יעקב אחיד באילנא דחיי דלית בי' מותא לעלמין וכו', ובגין כך יעקב לא מת, ואימתי מות בשעתא דכתיב ויאסוף רגליו אל המטה וכו' כדין ויגוע ויאסף אל עמיו עכ"ד הזוה"ק וצ"ב דנראה לכאורה כסתירה מרישא לסיפא, דבראשית דבריו גזר אומר דיע"א אחיד באילנא דחיי דלית בי' מותא לעלמין ובגין כך יע"א לא מית, וסיום דבריו ואימתי מית וכו', וה"ז סתירה.
translation: It will be further explained in the words of the Gemara in Taanit mentioned above, by prefacing the words of the Zohar (Parashat Beshalach) (page 48b), "And the righteous Jacob is united with the Tree of Life, which has no death for eternity," etc. And because of this, Jacob did not die. And when did he die? At the time it is written, "And he gathered his feet onto the bed," etc., just like it is written, "And he expired and was gathered to his people." Thus far the Zohar. And it is puzzling, for it seems at first glance to be a contradiction from the beginning to the end. In the beginning of his words, he decrees that Jacob is united with the Tree of Life, which has no death for eternity, and because of this, Jacob did not die. And at the conclusion of his words, he states, "And when did he die?" etc. This is indeed a contradiction.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of Jacob's immortality as presented in the Zohar, which states that he is united with the Tree of Life, symbolizing eternal life without death. However, it raises a theological question regarding the apparent contradiction between the assertion of Jacob's immortality and the description of his death in the Torah. The text highlights the tension between the idea of spiritual continuity and the physical reality of death, emphasizing the complexity of life, death, and the soul's journey in Hasidic thought. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper understanding of existence beyond mere physicality.

passage_content: ויובן עפי"ד הרמב"ן זאל (סו"פ ויחי) וזלה"ק עה"פ ויגוע ויאסף, ומיתה לא נאמרה בו ואמרו רבותינו יעקב אבינו לא מת לשון רש"י, ולדעת רבותינו הרי יעקב הזכיר מיתה בעצמו הנה אנכי מת והי' אלקים עמכם, ואולי לא ידע בנפשו, או שלא רצה לתת כבוד לשמו וכו', וענין המדרש הזה כו נפשות הצדיקים צרורות בצרור החיים, וזו תחופף עליו כל היום לובשת לבושת השני שלא ופשטנה ערומה כיעקב, או תתלבש לעתים מזומנות, ויובן הענין הזה במס' שבת ובמס' כתובות ע"כ לה"ק (ואולי הכוונה על דברי הגמ' כתובות (ק"ג ע"א) ברבינו הקדוש דכל בי שמשי הוה אתי לביתי' אחר הסתלקותו עיי"ש, עיין בדברנו פ' חיי תנ"ו א' בביאור דברי הגמ' הנ"ל) ומה מאוד עמקו דבריו הק' מלהשיג תכליתם, וכמו שהזהיר הרמב"ן ז"ל בעצמו בפתיחתו על התורה וז"ל ואני הנני מביא בברית נאמנה וכו' לכל מסתכל בספר הזה לבל יסבור סברה ואל יחשוב מחשבות וכו' מכל הרמזים אשר אני כותב בסתרי התורה, כו אני מודיעו נאמנה שלא יושגו דבר ולא יודעו כלל בשום שכל ובינה, זולתי מפי מקובל חכם לאוזן מקובל מבין וכו'.
translation: And it will be understood according to the words of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed (at the end of Vayechi), and thus is the explanation on the verse "and he expired and was gathered," and death is not mentioned regarding him, and our sages said, "Jacob our father did not die," as Rashi states. And according to our sages, Jacob himself mentioned death when he said, "Behold, I am dying," and "God will be with you." Perhaps he did not know in his soul, or he did not want to give honor to his name, etc. And the matter of this Midrash is that the souls of the righteous are bound in the bundle of life, and this will hover over him all day, wearing the second garment, and he will not strip it off naked like Jacob, or it will be worn at certain times. And this matter can be understood in Tractate Shabbat and in Tractate Ketubot, thus is the holy teaching (and perhaps the intention is regarding the words of the Gemara in Ketubot (K.G. 1) about Rabbi the Holy, that every day his servants would come to his house after his passing, see there. Refer to our words in Parashat Chayei, Tana 1, in the explanation of the words of the aforementioned Gemara). And how very profound are the words of the holy one, to grasp their purpose, as the Ramban himself warned at the beginning of the Torah, and he said, "And behold, I bring a faithful covenant, etc., to all who look into this book, lest they should think a thought and not consider thoughts, etc., from all the hints which I write in the secrets of the Torah, I hereby inform him faithfully that nothing will be grasped nor known at all by any intellect and understanding, except from the mouth of a wise receiver to the ear of a wise receiver who understands, etc."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the immortality of the righteous, as illustrated by the figure of Jacob, who is said not to have truly died. It emphasizes the idea that the souls of the righteous are bound in the "bundle of life," suggesting a continuous spiritual presence and connection to the divine. The text also highlights the importance of receiving wisdom from knowledgeable sources, as true understanding of these deep mystical concepts cannot be grasped through mere intellect but requires a tradition of transmission from wise teachers.

passage_content: ואפשר להבין דבה"ק אפס קצהו עפ"י קבלה אמיתית דברי האוהחה"ק ופ' בחקתי) וז"ל כשברא ד' אדה"ר בעוה"ז, לא בראו לשבת בעוה"ז לעולמי עד וכו', כי תכלית המקוה הוא בעולם העליון וכו' אלא היתה הכוונה כו עלה יעלה השמימה ולאוצרות החיים בעת אשר יחפוץ, ויהי' כמי שדר בבית ועלי' על גבה וכמו שעלה אלי' בסערה השמימה, וע"י שחטא אדה"ר הוצרך להפשיט עורו מעליו וכשירצה לעלות לעלי' צריך השתנות הגשם, וזו היא מיתת האדם עכ"ל, ועד"ז יסבר אמרם ז"ל דיע""א לא מת, דלפי שתיקן פגם חטא אדה"ר בשורש נשמתו, ע"כ לא הי' צורך אצלו להשתנות הגשם שהוא בחי' מיתה, אבל הי' כמו שדר בבית ועלי' על גבה, ועלה יעלה השמימה ולאוצרות החיים בעת אשר יחפוץ ופושט צורה ולובש צורה וכמו שעלה אלי' בסערה השמים, ואולי זהו המכוון בדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל לובשת לבושת השני וכו' או תתלבש לעתים מזומנות והבן. והנה קיי"ל כל שבידו לאו כמחוסר מעשה דמו, וע"כ יע"א לא מת דכל אימת בידו הוא להתלבש בלבוש גופו הקדוש, עיין בדברנו פ' חוי בשם הח"ס זלל"ה דאלי' הנביא ז"ל פעם נתגלה לחכמי ישראל בלבוש גופו ולפעמים בלבוש נשמתו עיי"ש, ובס' חסידים (רמז תתשכ"ט) שרבינו הק' כל בי שימשי נתגלה בלבוש גופו עיי"ש.
translation: And it is possible to understand that the Holy One, Blessed be He, according to true Kabbalah, the words of the holy Baal Shem Tov and the portion of Bechukotai, as follows: When God created Adam HaRishon in this world, He did not create him to dwell in this world forever, etc., for the ultimate purpose of creation is in the upper world, etc. Rather, the intention was that he would ascend to the heavens and to the treasures of life at the time that He desires, and he would be like one who dwells in a house and ascends upon it, and as he ascended to the heavens in a whirlwind. And because Adam HaRishon sinned, he needed to strip his skin from him, and when he wishes to ascend to the upper realm, a change in the physical is required, and this is the death of man. Thus, it can be understood what our sages, of blessed memory, said that Eliyahu did not die, for since he rectified the flaw of Adam HaRishon's sin in the root of his soul, therefore there was no need for him to undergo a change in the physical, which is a form of death, but he was like one who dwells in a house and ascends upon it, and he ascends to the heavens and to the treasures of life at the time that he desires, and he sheds form and wears form, just as he ascended to the heavens in a whirlwind. And perhaps this is what is meant in the words of the Ramban, of blessed memory, "wearing a second garment," etc., or that he would be clothed at appointed times, and understand. And behold, we hold that everything that is in his hand is not like one who is lacking in action, therefore Eliyahu did not die, for whenever it is in his hand, he is able to be clothed in the garment of his holy body. Refer to our words in the portion of Chayei Sarah in the name of the Chasam Sofer, of blessed memory, that the prophet Eliyahu, of blessed memory, sometimes revealed himself to the sages of Israel in the garment of his body and sometimes in the garment of his soul, see there. And in the book of Chassidim (hint 569) it is stated that our holy master revealed himself every day in the garment of his body, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the creation of Adam and the intention behind his existence, emphasizing that he was not meant to remain in this world eternally but to ascend to higher realms. It highlights the concept of transformation through sin, where Adam's transgression necessitated a change in his physical form, akin to death. The text also reflects on the idea that certain righteous individuals, like Eliyahu, did not experience death due to their rectification of Adam's sin, allowing them to ascend freely to the heavens. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the dynamic relationship between the physical and spiritual realms, where the soul can manifest in different forms as needed.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו דברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל יעקב אחיד באילנא דחיי דלית בי' מותא לעלמין וכו', ובג"כ יעקב אבינו לא מית, ואימתי מית בשעתא דכתיב ויאסוף רגליו אל המטה וכו', כדין ויגוע ויאסף אל עמיו, ר"ל כשהי' ברצונו הק' לעלות לעלי", הי' נדמה לבני עלמא כבחי' מיתה אצלו, ע"ש שהי' פושט צורה ולובש צורה כנ"ל, אבל באמת חי הוא גם בלבוש גופו כו לא הוצרך להשתנות הגשם, שאין זה אלא בסיבת החטא, ובחי' זו לא הי' בו, והנה לפי"ז מה שחנטוהו הרופאים הי' בדרך נס, כי לא יתכן מלאכת החניטה בגוף חי, וזהו שהקשה (בגמ' דתענית הנ"ל) וכי בכדי ספדו ספדנוא וחנטו חנטיא וקברו קבריא, שהי' כל זה בדרך נס, וצורך הנס למה, ואין הקב"ה חפץ בשינוי הטבע, והרבה דרכים למקום, וע"ז השיב לו ר"ו מקרא אני דורש וכו' ויובן עפי"ד הבית שמואל אחרון הו"ד בישמח משה מק"ז זלה"ה (בפ' תזריע) דלפי שהתורה קדמה לעולם, ע"כ מה שנכתב בתורה הוי כתנאי בשעת הבריאה ולא הוי שינוי הטבע עיי"ש, (הובא בדברנו בכ"מ) ובזה יתבאר כוונת התשובה שא"ל מקרא אני דורש וכו', דלפי שנדרש מן הכתוב מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים, ואין היקש למחצה ע"כ שחי וקיים בלבוש גופו וכתיב ויחנטו הרופאים את ישראל, ע"כ כבר מפורש בכתוב החניטה בגוף חי, מעתה אין זה שינוי בטבע, דהתורה קדמה לעולם וחוקי הטבע משועבדין אלי' והבן.
translation: And with this, the words of the Zohar mentioned above will be clarified: Jacob is unique in the Tree of Life, for there is no death in him for eternity, etc. And in general, our father Jacob did not die, and when did he die? At the time it is written, "and he gathered his feet into the bed," etc., just like it is written, "and he drew near and gathered to his people." This means that when it was the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, for him to ascend on high, it appeared to the people of the world as a form of death for him, because he was shedding form and taking on form as mentioned above. But in truth, he is alive even in the garment of his body; he did not need to change the physical, for this is only due to sin, and in this aspect, he did not have it. Now, according to this, what the doctors did to embalm him was done in a miraculous way, for it is not possible to embalm a living body. This is what was asked (in the Gemara of Taanit mentioned above): "And did we mourn in order to mourn, and did we embalm in order to embalm, and did we bury in order to bury?" All this was done in a miraculous way, and what is the need for a miracle? And the Holy One, blessed be He, does not desire a change in nature, for there are many ways to the place. To this, R. V. responded, "A verse I seek," etc., and it will be understood according to the words of the last Beit Shmuel mentioned in Yismach Moshe from K'Z, blessed be his memory (in Parshat Tazria), that since the Torah preceded the world, therefore what is written in the Torah is like a condition at the time of creation and does not constitute a change in nature, see there (as we have brought in many places). And with this, the intention of the response that he said to him, "A verse I seek," etc., is understood: since it is derived from the verse that as his offspring is alive, so he is alive, and there is no analogy to half, therefore he is alive and existing in the garment of his body, and it is written, "And the doctors embalmed Israel," therefore it is already explicitly stated in the verse that embalming is in a living body. From now on, this is not a change in nature, for the Torah preceded the world, and the laws of nature are subservient to it, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of Jacob's immortality, emphasizing that he did not truly die but rather transformed in a way that appeared as death to the world. It highlights that his physical body remained unchanged due to his lack of sin, and the embalming process was a miraculous event, not a natural occurrence. The text connects this idea to the notion that the Torah predates creation, establishing that the laws of nature are subordinate to divine will, thus allowing for such miracles without altering the natural order. Ultimately, it asserts that Jacob remains alive in his physical form, as indicated by the scriptural interpretation that his descendants are also alive.

passage_content: אל ויקרבו ימי ישראל למות וגו' במד"ר כתיב (ד"ה א' כ"ט) כי גרים אנחנו לפניך וגו' כצל ימינו על הארץ, והלואי כצלו של כותל או כצלו של אילן אלא כצילו של עוף בשעה שהוא עף. דכתיב (תהלים קמד) ימיו כצל עובר וכו' עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב כוונת הדמיון והמשל בצלו של כותל ושל אילן.
translation: "And the days of Israel drew near to die, etc. It is written in the Midrash (I Chronicles 29) that we are strangers before You, etc., like the shadow of our days upon the earth, and may it be like the shadow of a wall or like the shadow of a tree, but rather like the shadow of a bird when it flies. As it is written (Psalms 144) 'Our days are like a fleeting shadow,' etc. Thus far the Midrash, and it is necessary to understand the intention of the analogy and the parable of the shadow of a wall and the shadow of a tree."
summary: The passage reflects on the transient nature of human life, comparing it to shadows that vary in form and significance. It emphasizes that, like the fleeting shadow of a bird in flight, human existence is ephemeral and should inspire a sense of humility and awareness of our mortality. The reference to different types of shadows—those of a wall and a tree—highlights the varying degrees of permanence and impact in life, urging individuals to recognize the deeper spiritual truths behind their earthly experiences. Ultimately, it calls for a mindful approach to life, acknowledging our temporary state as "strangers" in this world.

passage_content: ואפ"ל בדרך רמז מוסר עפי"ד הזוה"ק עה"פ ויקרבו ימי ישראל למות, וז"ל וכי בכמה יומין מית בר נש, והא בשעתא חדא ברגעא חדא מות ונפיק מעלמא, אלא הכי תאנא כד קוב"ה בעי לאתבא רוחי' וכו'. כל אינון יומין דקאים בר נש בהאי עלמא אתפקדן קמי' ועאלין בחושבנא וכו' זכאה חולקי' דההוא בר נש דיומוי אתקריבו גבי מלכא בלא כיסופא, ולא דחי יומא מינייהו לבר דושכח בההוא יומא דאתעביד בי' חובא וכו', והכא ויקרבו ימי ישראל ודאי בלא כיסופא בשלימותא וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק, מבואר כי צדיקים מתפקדן כל יומיהם קמי מלכא ונמצאים כולם שלימים ותמימים א' מהם לא נעדר, ע"כ ימיהם אתקריבו גבי מלכא בלא כיסופא אוי לו לאותו בושה וכלימה מי שימיו חסרים ופגומים. ואצ"ל אם הם מלוכלכים ר"ל בעונות ופשעים, א"א שיתקרבו גבי מלכא, כי אצלו ית' כתיב לא יגורך רע.
translation: And even though it is hinted at in the teaching of the Zohar on the verse "And the days of Israel drew near to die," it says: "And how many days does a person die? For at one moment, in one instant, death comes and he departs from the world. Rather, it is taught that when the Holy One, blessed be He, wishes to take a soul, etc." All those days that a person stands in this world are accounted before Him and they ascend in the reckoning, etc. The righteous are worthy that the days of that person should be brought close to the King without shame, and not a single day should be missing from them, for on that day he will be remembered for the debt that was done to him, etc. And here, "And the days of Israel drew near" certainly without shame, in completeness, etc. Thus says the Zohar, it is clear that the righteous have all their days accounted before the King and they are all found complete and whole; none of them is missing. Therefore, their days are brought close to the King without shame. Woe to that shame and disgrace for one whose days are lacking and flawed. And certainly, if they are defiled, God forbid, by sins and transgressions, it is impossible for them to be brought close to the King, for it is written regarding Him, "Evil shall not dwell with You."
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of the righteous being accounted for each day of their lives before the Divine King, emphasizing that their days are presented without shame or blemish. It highlights that the righteous are complete and whole, and their days are accepted by God without any deficiencies. In contrast, those whose days are marred by sins cannot approach the Divine, as it is stated that evil cannot dwell in His presence. This underscores the importance of living a life of righteousness to attain closeness to the Divine.

passage_content: נתבונן במצבינו איך הוא חשבון ימינו לרבות הלילות, כמה מהם נחסרו וכמה מהם נפגמו ונתלכלכו בעבירות ר"ל ואיך נעול קמי מלכא בחסרון ימים לא יוכלו להמנות. ולא רק שנחסרו לנו ממספר ימי חיינו, אך יותר מזה יש לנו לדאוג ולהתאונן. האם יש לנו ימים בכלל, ואפי' יום א' מימי חיינו שפעלנו בו בעבודת השי"ת בשלימות ובלי מגרעת, וע"כ עכשיו בכניסתנו לימי השובבים קורין בתורה פרשה זו ויקרבו ימי ישראל וגו', לעורר לבבות בנ"י על בחי' זו, איך שכל ימי חייו של אדם נפקדין קמי קוב"ה, וצריך ליתן דין וחשבון על כל יום ועל כל עת וכל שעה, וע"י תשובה שלימה ואמיתית אפשר לתקן ולהחזיר הימים לשלומותן, והבוכ"ע יעזור לנו שנזכה לתקן את אשר פגמנוג ומהיום והלאה לא נפגום עוד.
translation: Let us reflect on our situation, how it accounts for our days, including the nights, how many of them have been lacking and how many have been blemished and soiled by sins, Heaven forbid, and how we are locked before the King with a deficiency of days that cannot be counted. And not only have we lost from the number of days of our lives, but even more than that, we have reason to worry and lament. Do we have days at all, and even one day of our lives in which we served the Blessed Creator in completeness and without any deficiency? Therefore, now as we enter the days of the Shovavim, we read this portion in the Torah, "And the days of Israel were drawn near," to awaken the hearts of the children of Israel regarding this aspect, how all the days of a person's life are accounted before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and one must give a reckoning for every day, every moment, and every hour. And through complete and true repentance, it is possible to rectify and restore the days to their wholeness, and may the Blessed Creator help us that we merit to rectify what we have blemished, and from this day forward, may we not blemish any further.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of reflecting on the value of each day in one's life, particularly in light of the days that have been lost or tainted by sin. It highlights the need for sincere repentance to restore and redeem these days, as every moment is accounted for before God. The reference to the "days of Shovavim" serves as a call to action for the Jewish people to awaken their hearts and strive for spiritual completeness. Ultimately, it conveys a deep theological insight that through genuine repentance, one can rectify past shortcomings and commit to a more righteous future.

passage_content: ועד"ז נבין רמז דחשתם ז"ל במדרש הנ"ל שהסמיכו ואל הפסוק ויקרבו ימי ישראל וגו', כי גרים אנחנו לפניך וגו' כצל ימינו על הארץ, כי זהו ודאי שכ"א נמשלו ימיו כצל, אך ישנם הרבה בחי' בזה, צילו של הקב"ה כביכול כמ"ש ובצל כנפיך נחסה ונתלונן ואשרי הזוכה שימיו אתקריבו גבי מלכא כמ"ש בזוה"ק הנ"ל וכמ"ש ביע"א ויקרבו ימי ישראל, צילו של כותל ירמוז ג"כ על בחי' השראת השכינה, ע"ד הכתוב הנה עומד אחר כתלנו, ודרשו רז"ל מעולם לא זזה שכינה מכותל המערבי, ולמטה ממנו במדריגתה הדמיון לצלו של אילן ירמוז על מעשים טובים וע"ד מ"ש במתני' דאבות כל שמעשיו מרובין הוא דומה לאילן שענפיו מרובין וכו' והצל הזה מתקיים לזמן מרובה, וז"ש במדרש והלואי כצילו של כותל או כצילו של אילן, ובעוה"ר ימינו כצל עובר כצילו של עוף בשעה שהוא עף, שהוא עובר ולא נתקיים רושמו כלל, הבוי"ת יזריח בלבבות בנ"י התעוררות תשובה, ונזכה לעבוד השי"ת באמת ובתמים ולתקן הימים כולם לרבות הלילות ובצלו ית' נחסה ונתלונן ובמהרה נזכה לראות בביאת משיח צדקנו אכיה"ר.
translation: And similarly, we will understand the hint of our sages, of blessed memory, in the aforementioned Midrash, which connects to the verse "And the days of Israel drew near," because we are strangers before You, etc., like the shadow of our days upon the earth. For it is certain that each one's days are likened to a shadow, but there are many aspects to this. The shadow of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is written, "And in the shadow of Your wings we will take refuge," and fortunate is the one who merits that his days are drawn close to the King, as it is written in the aforementioned Zohar and as it is written, "And the days of Israel drew near." The shadow of the wall also hints at the aspect of the Divine Presence, in accordance with the verse, "Behold, He stands behind our wall," and our sages have taught that the Divine Presence never departed from the Western Wall. And below it, in its level, the likeness to the shadow of a tree hints at good deeds, in accordance with what is stated in the Mishnah in Avot: "Anyone whose deeds are abundant is likened to a tree whose branches are abundant," etc. And this shadow endures for a long time, and thus it is stated in the Midrash, "Would that it were like the shadow of a wall or like the shadow of a tree." And in our times, our days are like a fleeting shadow, like the shadow of a bird when it flies, which passes and does not leave any trace at all. May the Blessed One illuminate in the hearts of the children of Israel an awakening to repentance, and may we merit to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, truly and sincerely, and to rectify all the days, including the nights, and in His shadow may we take refuge and complain, and may we quickly merit to see the coming of our righteous Messiah, may He be blessed.
summary: The passage emphasizes the transient nature of human life, likening it to a shadow, while highlighting the enduring presence of God's protection, symbolized by the "shadow" of the Divine. It draws connections between the Divine presence, the Western Wall, and the metaphor of a tree, suggesting that righteous deeds create lasting spiritual merit. The text expresses a yearning for genuine repentance and a deep connection to God, culminating in the hope for the coming of the Messiah. Ultimately, it calls for a sincere commitment to serving God and rectifying the days and nights of existence.

passage_content: ויקרא לבנו ליוסף ויאמר לו אם נא מצאתי חן בעיניך שים נא ידך תחת ירכי ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת וגו', פרש"י ז"ל חסד שעושין עם המתים הוא חסד של אמת שאינו מצפה לתשלום גמול לכאורה ראוי להבין מדוע הי' צורך לצוות ליוסף הצדיק שיעשה חסד של אמת, הלא יוסף הצדיק כל מעשיותיו היו רק לשם שמים ואפילו חסד עם החיים ג"כ לא עשה אותו רק לקיים מצות השי"ת, גם קשה אם הוא הכרח בכל מקום שחסד שעושין עם המתים הוא חסד של אמת, שאינו יכול לצפות לתשלום גמול, מדוע הוצרך לצוותו כאן לעשות חסד של אמת, והרי בלא"ה מוכרח הוא כן בכ"מ.
translation: And he called his son Joseph and said to him, "If now I have found favor in your eyes, please put your hand under my thigh and do kindness and truth with me," etc. Rashi explains that the kindness done for the dead is the kindness of truth, as it does not expect a reward. It seems necessary to understand why there was a need to command the righteous Joseph to do kindness of truth; after all, the righteous Joseph's every action was solely for the sake of Heaven, and even the kindness he did for the living was only to fulfill the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He. It is also difficult to understand if it is a necessity everywhere that the kindness done for the dead is the kindness of truth, which cannot expect a reward, why it was necessary to command him here to do kindness of truth, as he would have to do so anyway in any case.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the concept of "chesed shel emet" (true kindness) as it pertains to acts performed for the deceased, which are done without expectation of reward. The text raises questions about why Joseph, known for his righteous deeds done for the sake of Heaven, needed to be instructed to perform such an act. It emphasizes that true kindness transcends the expectation of recompense, highlighting the intrinsic value of selfless acts, particularly towards those who can no longer reciprocate. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of righteousness and the purity of intention in performing good deeds.

passage_content: ב) בגמרא (תענית ה' ע"ב) איתא רב נחמן ורב יצחק הוו יתבי בסעודתא א"ל ר"נ לר"י לימא מר מילתא, א"ל הכו אר"י אין מסיחין בסעודה שמא יקדים קנה לוושט ויבא לידי סכנה, בתר דסעיד. א"ל הכי אר"י יעקב אבינו לא מת, א"ל וכי בכדי ספדי ספדנייא וחנטו חנטייא וקברו קברייא, א"ל מקרא אני דורש שנאמר ואתה אל תירא עבדי יעקב נאם ה' ואל תחת ישראל כי הנני מושיעך מרחוק ואת זרעך מארץ שבים מקיש הוא לזרעו מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים, וראוי להבין קישור מימרא זו יעקב אבינו לא מת לענין הלכה דאין מסיחין בסעודה, גם צ"ב כוונת התשובה במ"ש לו מקרא אני דורש וכו'
translation: In the Gemara (Taanit 5b), it is stated that Rav Nachman and Rav Yitzchak were sitting at a meal. Rav Nachman said to Rav Yitzchak, "Let the master say something." He replied, "It is said that one does not engage in conversation during a meal, lest one inadvertently cause the food to go down the wrong way and come to danger." After they had eaten, he said, "Thus said Rabbi Yitzchak: Jacob our father did not die." He replied, "Is it possible that we should mourn for him? They mourned for him, they embalmed him, and they buried him." He said, "I derive from a verse, as it is said, 'And you, do not fear, My servant Jacob,' says the Lord, 'and do not be dismayed, O Israel, for behold, I will save you from afar and your offspring from the land of their captivity.' It connects him to his offspring: just as his offspring are alive, so too he is alive." It is fitting to understand the connection of this statement, "Jacob our father did not die," in relation to the halacha that one does not engage in conversation during a meal. It is also necessary to clarify the intent of the response when he said, "I derive from a verse, etc."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion between Rav Nachman and Rav Yitzchak highlights the Hasidic belief in the enduring spiritual presence of the patriarch Jacob, suggesting that he remains alive in a metaphysical sense. The reference to the verse "And you, do not fear, My servant Jacob" emphasizes God's promise of salvation and the connection between Jacob and his descendants, reinforcing the idea that just as his offspring are alive, so too is he. This theological insight underscores the importance of maintaining a spiritual focus during meals, as engaging in idle conversation may distract from the divine presence. The passage invites reflection on the continuity of life and the eternal bond between the Jewish people and their ancestors.
