passage_content: ועפי"ז יתבאר במאמר הכתוב ואת יהודה שלח לפניו להורות לפניו גשנה, מה שכפל הכתוב מלת לפניו, ויובן עפי"מ שדרשו חז"ל להורות לפניו לתקן לו בית תלמוד, שילמדו השבעים בו תורה והוראה, וכתב התרגום יונתן עה"פ ויאחזו בה ויפרו וירבו וגו' ובנו פלטין ובתי מדרשין, ואחסינו בה אחסנת חקלין וכרמין, וע"כ שלח יעקב את יהודה לפניו, להורות בית תלמוד קודם שיבנו בתים ויאחזו בה בדרך התוישבות, ורצה ללמדם על בחינה הנ"ל, דלימוד התורה צריך שיהי' העיקר והראשון במעשה ובמחשבה וההתעסקות בד"א ובעניני העוה"ז צריך שיהי' טפל ולאחרי', כמו שפירשנו לעיל מאמר התנא ופה ת"ת עם ד"א, וז"ש ואת יהודה שלח לפניו, ששלחו יעקב לקדמו לפניו להורות לו בית תלמוד, ולפניו הב' פירושו להורות לפניו, כי רצה ללמדם דרך עבודת ה' בבחי' הנ"ל, כי להורות צריך שיהי' לפניו ומוקדם לעסק עניני עוה"ז, וגם שלחו לראות ולהבחין אם ארץ גשן ראוי לכך. להשיג בחי' זו, שיהי' לימוד התוה"ק עיקר ויוקדם במעשה ובמחשבה וא"ש הכפל.
translation: And according to this, it will be explained in the statement written, "And he sent Judah before him to instruct before him in Goshen," why the text repeats the word "before him." It will be understood according to that which our Sages have interpreted, to instruct before him to establish a house of study, where the seventy would learn Torah and instruction. And Jonathan's translation on the verse "And they seized it and bore fruit and multiplied, etc." states, "And they built palaces and houses of study, and we stored in it the storage of fields and vineyards." Therefore, Jacob sent Judah before him, to instruct in a house of study before they built houses and settled in it, and he wanted to teach them about the aforementioned aspect, that the study of Torah should be the primary and foremost in action and thought, and the engagement in worldly matters should be secondary and afterwards, as we explained above regarding the statement of the Tanna, "and here Torah study with worldly matters." And this is what is meant by "And he sent Judah before him," that Jacob sent him to precede him to instruct him in a house of study, and "before him" means to instruct before him, for he wanted to teach them the way of serving God in the aforementioned aspect, for to instruct, it must be before him and prior to engaging in worldly matters. He also sent him to see and discern if the land of Goshen was suitable for this. To achieve this aspect, that the study of the Holy Torah should be primary and prioritized in action and thought, and this clarifies the repetition.
summary: המאמר מדגיש את החשיבות של לימוד התורה כעיקר בחיים, כאשר יעקב שולח את יהודה לפניו כדי להורות על הקמת בית תלמוד לפני כל עיסוק אחר. הכפל במילה "לפניו" מסמל את הצורך להקדיש את הלימוד לתורה לפני העיסוקים החומריים, וללמד את בני ישראל את הדרך הנכונה בעבודת ה'. בנוסף, ישנה התייחסות לכך שצריך לבדוק אם ארץ גשן מתאימה לכך, מה שמצביע על חשיבות הסביבה התומכת בלימוד התורה.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לבאר ענין שליחות יהודה במ"ש להורות לפניו גשנה וגו', ולכאורה הרי כבר נתברר ארץ גושן להתוושבות יעקב ובניו, שמצינו ששלח לו יוסף בשליחות הראשון וישבת בארץ גושן וגו' וא"כ מלת גושנה מיותרת, וגם ראוי להבין מדוע שלח יעקב את יהודה דווקא שהי' מלך השבעים והי"ל לשלוח שליח אחר, גם למה לא סמך על יוסף בזה, וכבר ידע בצדקו כמ"ש ז"ל, ונקדים עוד מ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בפ' ויגש עה"פ וישבת בארץ גושן וז"ל הו' יוסף יודע באביו, שלא ירצה לעמוד בארץ מצרים אשר שם הבירה למלכות, ע"כ שלח לו מעתה כי בארץ גושן יושיבנו עכ"ל. וכוונת דבריו ז"ל כי כל ארץ מצרים היתה מלאה טומאה וע"ז וכשפים מפה אל פה, ע"כ שלח לו וישבת בארץ גושן, ושם תהי' מובדל ומופרש מתועבת מצרים ומגלוליהם, וכמ"ש הכתוב בעבור תשבו בארץ גושן כי תועבת מצרים כל רועי צאן.
translation: And now we will explain the matter of Judah's mission in saying to instruct before him, "Goshen," etc. At first glance, it seems that the land of Goshen was already clarified for the dwelling of Jacob and his sons, as we find that Joseph sent to him on the first mission, and they settled in the land of Goshen, etc. Therefore, the word "Goshen" appears to be superfluous. It is also appropriate to understand why Jacob specifically sent Judah, who was the king of the seventy, and he could have sent another messenger, and why he did not rely on Joseph in this matter, as he already knew of his righteousness, as it is said by our sages. We will also precede with what the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote in Parashat Vayigash on the verse "and they settled in the land of Goshen," and he said: "Joseph knew about his father, that he would not want to dwell in the land of Egypt, where the capital of the kingdom is." Therefore, he sent to him from now on that he would settle in the land of Goshen. The intent of his words is that all of Egypt was filled with impurity, idolatry, and sorcery from one end to the other. Therefore, he sent to him, "and you shall dwell in the land of Goshen," and there he would be separated and distinct from the abominations of Egypt and their idols, as the verse states, "For you shall dwell in the land of Goshen, for every shepherd of sheep is an abomination to the Egyptians."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Judah's mission to prepare for Jacob and his family’s settlement in the land of Goshen, emphasizing that despite Joseph's prior arrangements, Judah's role was essential. It highlights the spiritual purity of Goshen, contrasting it with the idolatry and impurity of Egypt, as the land was designated to protect the Israelites from the corrupting influences surrounding them. The text reflects on the importance of separation from impurity and the divine intention behind the choice of Judah as the leader in this mission, underscoring themes of holiness and divine providence in the lives of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ולכאורה ראוי להבין מה הי' מעלת גושן שבחר בה יוסף ויע"א, וכי ארץ גושן היו יושביה צדיקים, ולא יתכן לומר שהי' ריק מתושבים, אחרי שמעיד הכתוב שהיתה מיטב הארץ וטוב ארץ מצרים, ואין דרך המדינה להניח שממה מיטב ארצם, ואפשר שיוסף הצדיק ריקן את ארץ גושן מהמצריים, שנא' ואת העם העביר אותו לערים מקצה גבול מצרים ועד קצהו, ופירשיז"ל כן עשה לכל הערים אשר במלכות מצרים מקצה גבולה עד קצהו, ואפשר שבאותה שעה שטלטל אותם מעיר לעיר, ריקן את ארץ גושן ולא הושיב בה אחרים, והכינה לנחלת יעקב ובניו.
translation: And seemingly, it is appropriate to understand what was the merit of Goshen that Joseph chose it, and may it be said, were the inhabitants of the land of Goshen righteous? It cannot be said that it was empty of inhabitants, after the scripture testifies that it was the best of the land and the good of the land of Egypt. It is not the way of the state to leave the best of their land desolate. It is possible that Joseph the Righteous emptied the land of Goshen of the Egyptians, as it is said, "And he removed the people and placed them in cities from one end of the border of Egypt to the other end." And he explained, may his memory be blessed, that he did so for all the cities of the kingdom of Egypt from one end of its border to the other. And it is possible that at that time, while he moved them from city to city, he emptied the land of Goshen and did not settle others there, preparing it for the inheritance of Jacob and his sons.
summary: המאמר עוסק במעלתה של ארץ גושן, שבחר בה יוסף, ושואל האם יושביה היו צדיקים. הוא מציע כי יוסף ריקן את גושן מתושבים מצריים כדי להכין אותה לנחלת יעקב ובניו, מה שמעיד על תכנון אלוהי והכנה רוחנית למעבר של עם ישראל. בכך, ישנה הדגשה על החשיבות של גושן כמרחב קדוש המיועד לעם הנבחר.

passage_content: ויתכן עפימ"ש חכז"ל בפרדר"א שפרעה נתן לשרה אמנו ארץ גושן במתנה, וכתב לה שטר מתנה על זה, לפיכך ישבו בארץ גושן עכ"ל הפדר"א, וע"כ לפי שעלתה בגורלה של אותה הצדיקת, לא ינוח שבט הרשע על גורל הצדיקים: והיתה מוכנת מתחלה להשראת הקדושה ע"ו ישיבת יעקב ובניו, וע"כ הי' אפשר לפנות משם ע"ז ותועבת מצרים, וא"ש מה שבחר יוסף ויעקב אבינו בארץ גושן דווקא.
translation: It is possible, according to the words of our Sages in the Midrash Rabbah, that Pharaoh gave our matriarch Sarah the land of Goshen as a gift, and wrote her a deed of gift for this reason; therefore, they settled in the land of Goshen, thus far the Midrash. And because it was destined for that righteous woman, the wicked scepter shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous: and it was prepared from the beginning for the dwelling of holiness, namely the dwelling of Jacob and his sons; therefore, it was possible to turn away from there idolatry and the abominations of Egypt. And it is understood why Joseph and our father Jacob specifically chose the land of Goshen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the land of Goshen, which Pharaoh gifted to Sarah, emphasizing that this act was divinely orchestrated to ensure that the righteous would not be oppressed by the wicked. It highlights that the land was prepared for the presence of holiness due to the merit of Jacob and his sons, allowing them to distance themselves from the idolatry and abominations of Egypt. This divine selection of Goshen by Joseph and Jacob reflects a deeper theological insight into the protection and sanctity afforded to the righteous amidst a corrupt environment.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד עפימ"ש הרד"ק ז"ל בס' יהושע (י"א ע"ז) שנמנה שם ארץ גושן בין הערים אשר לכד יהושע בכיבוש הארץ וניתנה לנחלה לשבט יהודה, וכתב הוא ז"ל כפי הדרש היתה זו גושן של ארץ מצרים ונבלעת בתוך ערי א"י, כמ"ש ויעל לקראת אביו גשנה, מלמד שהוא בעלי' כלפי א"י, ובזכות שהלך יהודה בשליחות אביו, זכה שיהי' לחלקו ארץ גושן שהיא טובה עכ"ל הרד"ק ז"ל, ואפשר שע"כ היתה מיטב הארץ וטוב אמ"צ. כי הוא נחשבת בין ערי א"י, וא"י טובה מכל הארצות כמו שאמר הכתוב וחברון שבע שנים נבנתה לפני צוען מצרים. ובש"ך עה"ת בפ' ויגש כתוב שנשתלחה רצועה מגושן של ארץ ישראל למצרים, ובאותה רצועה נתיישבו יעקב ובניו, והיתה נעלמת מעיני מצרים, ונודעת רק ליעקב ובניו עיי"ש. עכ"פ היתה ארץ גושן מוכנת וראוי' להשראת הקדושה, ועתידה להיות נחשבת בערי א"ו, וע"ש כן שלח יוסף ליעקב אבינו וישבת בארץ גושן, כי הוא המקום הראוי להרבצת הקדושה, ולהרבצת התוה"ק בקדושה וטהרה, בבחי' שהרחיב יעקב גבול הקדושה בארץ ישראל. ואפשר שאע"פ שידע יעקב בצדקו של יוסף שלח את יהודה להורות לפניו גשנה, לראות ולהבחין אם הוא מבחי' ארץ ישראל, ואם ראוי' להרחיב בה גבול הקדושה ולהרביץ בו תורה בטהרה, שיהיו ישראל מובדלים ומופרשין מטומאת מצרים ומתועבותם, ושלא יטמעו דורות הבאים דור הגלות, ולפי שחן המקום על יושבי', ע"כ חשש יעקב אבינו ע"ה, שמא נדמה ליוסף ארץ גושן למיטב ארץ מצרים, שראוי' לגדל בה דורות ישראל בקדושה וטהרה, ואפשר שאין הארץ ההיא נקי' ומופרשת לגמרי מכל סיג ובחי' ע"ז, וע"כ שלח את יהודה שארז"ל למוד הוא אותו שבט לפנות ולשרש ע"ז, ויש לו כח הבחינה לראות אם ארץ גושן נקי' ומופרשת מכל סיג ובחי' ע"ז, ובזה יתפרש הכתוב ואת יהודה שלח לפניו לפנות לו מקום ולהבחין אם היא ראוי' להתיישבות, לגדל בתוכה דורות ישראל, ופי' לפניו לפנות משם כל בחי' ע"ז. כי למוד הוא אותו שבט לשרש מ"ז ולעקרה. וכפל הכתוב עוה"פ מלת לפניו, להורות כי שלחו לפניו ומוקדם לביאתו, ולא רצה יע"א לבוא לגושן עד שיהי' המקום מובדל ומופרש מכל סיג ע"ז, וא"ש הכפל.
translation: And although it is also stated according to the interpretation of the Radak, may his memory be blessed, in the Book of Joshua (11:17) that the land of Goshen is listed among the cities that Joshua conquered in the conquest of the land and was given as an inheritance to the tribe of Judah, he wrote, may his memory be blessed, according to the interpretation, that this was the Goshen of the land of Egypt and it was absorbed within the cities of the Land of Israel, as it is said, "And he went up to meet his father in Goshen," teaching that it is elevated in relation to the Land of Israel. And due to the merit that Judah went on his father's mission, he was privileged to have the land of Goshen, which is good, thus said the Radak, may his memory be blessed. And it is possible that this is why it was the best of the land and good, for it is considered among the cities of the Land of Israel, and the Land of Israel is better than all the lands, as the scripture says, "And Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt." And in the Shach on the Torah in Parashat Vayigash, it is written that a strip was sent from the Goshen of the Land of Israel to Egypt, and in that strip Jacob and his sons settled, and it was hidden from the eyes of Egypt, and known only to Jacob and his sons, as mentioned there. In any case, the land of Goshen was prepared and suitable for the resting of holiness, and it is destined to be considered among the cities of the world to come. Therefore, Joseph sent to our father Jacob and settled in the land of Goshen, for it is the place suitable for the spreading of holiness and for the spreading of the Torah in holiness and purity, in the aspect that Jacob expanded the boundary of holiness in the Land of Israel. And it is possible that even though Jacob knew of Joseph's righteousness, he sent Judah to instruct before him in Goshen, to see and discern if it is in the aspect of the Land of Israel, and if it is suitable to expand the boundary of holiness there and to spread the Torah in purity, so that Israel would be separated and distinct from the impurity of Egypt and their abominations, and that future generations would not be contaminated in the generation of exile. And because the place has favor for its inhabitants, therefore our father Jacob, peace be upon him, was concerned that perhaps he would mistake the land of Goshen for the best of the land of Egypt, which is suitable for raising generations of Israel in holiness and purity, and it is possible that that land is not completely clean and separated from all dross and aspects of idolatry. Therefore, he sent Judah, as our sages of blessed memory have said, to examine it, for that tribe is learned in uprooting and rooting out idolatry, and he has the power of discernment to see if the land of Goshen is clean and separated from all dross and aspects of idolatry. And in this, the scripture is explained, "And he sent Judah before him to prepare a place for him and to discern if it is suitable for settlement, to raise within it generations of Israel," and "before him" means to remove from there all aspects of idolatry. For that tribe is learned in uprooting from idolatry and in uprooting it. And the scripture repeats the phrase "before him" to indicate that they sent before him and in advance of his coming, and he, may it be His will, did not want to come to Goshen until the place would be separated and distinct from all dross of idolatry, and this explains the repetition.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the land of Goshen, which was granted to the tribe of Judah and is seen as a place prepared for the presence of holiness. It emphasizes the importance of maintaining spiritual purity and separation from the impurities of Egypt, as Jacob sent Judah to assess whether Goshen was suitable for the settlement of the Israelites. The text highlights the role of Judah in ensuring that the land would be free from idolatry, thus allowing for the cultivation of a holy lineage. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the necessity of distinguishing sacred spaces to foster spiritual growth and adherence to divine teachings.

ועתה נחזור לפרש הכ' ויברכם ביום ההוא לאמור בך יברך ישראל לאמור ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, והדקדוקים כבר נפרטו לעיל, ולדרכינו רמז יעקב בזה להורות על בחי' הנ"ל, כי אע"פ שלמדם יע"א להיות מובדלים ומופרשים במצרים. וראשית דרכו הו' ששלח את יהודה לפניו לעשות הבדלה והפרשה, אבל בעסק התורה והחזקת התורה הזהירם על האחדות הגמור, שהמחזיק בשעה שעוסק במשא ומתן ובמלאכה, יהי' דעתו וראשית מחשבתו להחזקת התורה, וצריך שיהיו מקושרים בקשר אמיץ בלי פירוד ביניהם דלא יעלה עבודת הא' לכלום בלי 
סיוע ומעשה חבירו, כי לולי פעולת המחזיק יתבטל הת"ח מלימודו, כי אין לו במה להתפרנס, ואם הת"ח ותרשל מלימודו לא יזכה המחזיק להתברך בגללו ובזכותו וכנ"ל, ולטעם זה לא חלק יעקב את ברכתו לברכם שניהם ביד ימינו בזאח"ז דברכה א' להם וא"א להפריד ביניהם. וע"כ אמר יעקב אבינו בך יברך ישראל לאמור ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, דלכאורה הול"ל בכם יברך ישראל, אבל רצה להורות על בחי' האחדות, שאפרים ומנשה המחזיק והעוסק בתורה, צריכים שיתאחדו באחדות גמור בלי פירוד ביניהם כלל, וע"כ אמר בך יברך ישראל לשון יחיד וכמ"ש חז"ל דיע"א ע' נפש הי' לו, והכתוב קוראם נפש לשון יחיד, מפני שעובדים לה' אחד ושורש נשמתם משורש האחדות, וכמו"כ אמר יעקב בך יברך ושראל לאמור ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, שיהי' נמשך בחי' האחדות לכל ישראל כאפרים וכמנשה שבירכם בברכה א', ונתאחדו על ידו בקשר אמיץ. ובזו הברכה יתברכו ישראל לעולם, ויברכו את בניהם בברכה זו, וז"ש ויברכם ביום ההוא לאמר וגו' ישימך אלקים.
translation: And now we will return to explain the verse, "And he blessed them on that day, saying, 'By you shall Israel bless, saying, "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh."'” The nuances have already been elaborated above, and in our way, Jacob hinted at this to indicate the aforementioned aspect, for although he taught them, may it be His will, to be distinct and separated in Egypt, the beginning of his path was that he sent Judah before him to make a distinction and separation. However, in the matter of Torah and the support of Torah, he warned them about complete unity, that the one who supports while engaged in business and labor should have his mind and initial thought directed towards the support of Torah. They must be bound together with a strong bond without separation between them, for the work of one will amount to nothing without the assistance and action of his friend. For were it not for the action of the supporter, the Torah scholar would cease from his study, as he has no means to sustain himself. And if the Torah scholar neglects his study, the supporter will not merit to be blessed because of him and in his merit, as mentioned above. For this reason, Jacob did not divide his blessing to bless them both with his right hand simultaneously, for it is one blessing for them, and it is impossible to separate between them. Therefore, Jacob our father said, "By you shall Israel bless," saying, "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh," for it could have been said, "By you all shall Israel bless," but he wanted to indicate the aspect of unity, that Ephraim and Manasseh, the ones who support and engage in Torah, need to unite in complete oneness without any separation between them at all. Therefore, he said, "By you shall Israel bless," in the singular form, as our Sages have said, that he had 70 souls, and the scripture calls them "soul" in the singular, because they serve one God and the root of their souls is from the root of unity. Likewise, Jacob said, "By you shall Israel bless," saying, "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh," that the aspect of unity should extend to all of Israel like Ephraim and Manasseh, who were blessed with one blessing, and they united through him with a strong bond. Through this blessing, Israel will be blessed forever, and they will bless their children with this blessing, as it is said, "And he blessed them on that day, saying, 'May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh.'"
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the importance of unity among the Jewish people, as exemplified by the blessing of Ephraim and Manasseh. Jacob's blessing, given in the singular form "בך" (in you), signifies that true strength and success in Torah study and observance arise from a deep, unbreakable connection between individuals. The text highlights that the prosperity of one depends on the support of the other, reinforcing the idea that collective effort in spiritual pursuits is essential for divine blessing. Ultimately, this unity is portrayed as a source of enduring blessing for Israel and future generations.

passage_content: ואפשר שמ"ש ויברכם ביום ההוא לאמור, הכוונה שברכם יעקב אבינו ע"ה שהקדוש ברוך הוא ישים בהם השגת בחינה זו. להקדים את אפרים לפני מנשה, והמחזיק התורה יהי' ראשית כוונתו להחזקת התורה, ויקדים החזקת התורה לפני הנאתו, וז"ש ישימך אלקים, שיהי' שימה בקרבם בחינה זו שיקדימו את אפרים לפני מנשה, ואפשר שמ"ש בך יברך ישראל לאמור וכו' לא צום יע"א שיברכו ישראל בלשון ובנוסח הזה דווקא, אלא שיתברכו ישראל בבחינה זו להמשיך להם השגה ומדריגה זו דאפרים ראוי שיוקדם לפני מנשה ומחזיק התורה יהי' ראשית כוונתו להחזקת התוה"ק. כנ"ל
translation: And it is possible that when it says, "And he blessed them on that day, saying," the intention is that our forefather Jacob, peace be upon him, blessed them, that the Holy One, blessed be He, should place within them the attainment of this quality: to prioritize Ephraim before Manasseh. And the one who holds the Torah should have as his primary intention the strengthening of the Torah, and he should prioritize the strengthening of the Torah over his own enjoyment. And this is what is meant by "May God make you," that there should be a placement within them of this quality, that they should prioritize Ephraim before Manasseh. And it is possible that when it says, "In you shall Israel bless, saying," it does not mean specifically that Israel should bless in this language and formulation, but rather that Israel should be blessed with this quality, to draw down for them this understanding and level that Ephraim is worthy of being prioritized before Manasseh, and the one who holds the Torah should have as his primary intention the strengthening of the Holy Torah, as mentioned above.
summary: המעבר של אפרים לפני מנשה מסמל את החשיבות של החזקת התורה והקדמתה על פני הנאות אישיות. יעקב אבינו מברך את בניו בכך שהוא מדגיש את הצורך להעדיף את הערכים הרוחניים והלימודיים על פני ההנאות הגשמיות. הברכה נועדה להעניק לישראל את ההבנה וההכרה בחשיבות זו, כך שהחזקת התורה תהפוך להיות העדיפות הראשונה בחייהם.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בטעם הענין שהקדים הכתוב זבולן ליששכר, ולכאורה הרי הת"ח גדול בבחינתו מהמחזיק, כמבואר בדברי רז"ל בכ"מ גם הי' יששכר גדול מזבולן בשנים ומ"ט הקדימו הכתוב לזבולן ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המד"ר לר"פ שמות) שדרשו רז"ל שמות כל השבטים והרמזים שבהם, וז"ל יששכר שנתן להם הקב"ה שכר שעבודם ביזת מצרים וביזת הים. לקיים מה שנאמר ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, זבולן ע"ש שהשכין הקב"ה שכינתו בקרבם, שנא' ועשו לי מקדש ושכנתי בתוכם, ואין זבולן אלא ביהמ"ק שנא' (מ"א ח') בנה בניתי בית זבול לך מכון לשבתך עולמים עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה כפי מובן הפשוט הי' ראוי להיות מדת שכרם להיפך, דיששכר שעוסק בתורה לו יאתה שכר רוחני מדה כנגד מדה, ולזבולן השפעת עוה"ז וע"ד שכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשניות (ריש מס' פאה) דהמצות שהם בין אדם למקום, הבוי"ת משלם שכרן לעוה"ב. דשכר מצות בהאי עלמא ליכא. וכשיעשה האדם המצות התלויות בתועלת בנ"א וכו', ימצא טובה גם בעוה"ז עיי"ש, א"כ זבולן שעסק בפרגמטיא והנההו ליששכר מנכסיו, מגיע אליו כמידתו להמשיך השפעת עוה"ז בשכרו, וחז"ל דרשו להיפך שוששכר שעסק בתורה נשפע בזכותו השפעת הממון, דהיינו ביזת מצרים וביזת הים, ובזכות זבולן זכו ישראל לבנין ביהמ"ק שנרמז בשמו, וטעמא בעי.
translation:
The text can be translated as follows:

"Furthermore, one can say regarding the reason that the scripture precedes Zebulun to Issachar, and seemingly, the Torah scholar is greater in his aspect than the one who supports him, as explained in the words of our Sages in many places. Also, Issachar was greater than Zebulun in years, yet the scripture precedes Zebulun. This will be clarified by first mentioning the words of the Midrash on the portion of Shemot, where our Sages expounded the names of all the tribes and the hints within them. It is stated that Issachar was given by the Holy One, blessed be He, the reward for their servitude, the plunder of Egypt and the plunder of the sea, to fulfill what is said, 'And afterward they went out with great wealth.' Zebulun, because the Holy One, blessed be He, established His presence among them, as it is said, 'And they shall make for Me a sanctuary, and I will dwell among them,' and Zebulun is none other than the Holy Temple, as it is said (1 Kings 8), 'I have built a house of habitation for You, a place for Your dwelling forever.' Thus far the Midrash. 

Seemingly, according to the simple understanding, it would be appropriate for their reward to be the opposite, that Issachar, who engages in Torah, should receive a spiritual reward measure for measure, and for Zebulun, the influence of this world. And according to what the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his commentary on the Mishnah (at the beginning of the tractate Pe'ah), that the commandments which are between man and the Omnipresent, the Holy One, blessed be He, pays their reward in the World to Come. For the reward of commandments in this world does not exist. And when a person performs the commandments that are dependent on the benefit of people, etc., he will find goodness also in this world, as stated there. Therefore, Zebulun, who engaged in pragmatism and supported Issachar from his possessions, would seem to receive, according to his measure, the continuation of the influence of this world in his reward. Yet our Sages expounded the opposite: that Issachar, who engaged in Torah, draws down the influence of wealth in his merit, namely, the plunder of Egypt and the plunder of the sea. And in the merit of Zebulun, Israel merited the building of the Holy Temple, which is hinted at in his name. The reason for this is needed."
summary: The passage discusses the precedence of Zebulun over Issachar in the Torah, despite Issachar's greater spiritual stature as a Torah scholar. It highlights that Zebulun's merit lies in his support of Issachar, which led to the Israelites receiving material rewards, such as the spoils of Egypt and the sea, as well as the construction of the Holy Temple. This reflects the Hasidic concept that spiritual pursuits can yield material blessings, emphasizing the interconnectedness of Torah study and practical support in achieving divine favor. Ultimately, it illustrates the idea that both spiritual and material contributions are essential for the collective elevation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ב) אמרז"ל במס' שבת (קי"ד ע"א) תלמידי חכמים נקראים בנאים מפני שעוסקין בבניינו של עולם כל ימיהם עכ"ד הגמ', ראוי להבין דברי חכמים וחידותם מ"ט כינוי להם חז"ל בנאים. הן אמת שקיום העולם הוא ע"י עמוד התורה, אעפ"כ הרי אמרז"ל על שלשה דברים העולם עומד, ולא אמרו העולם נבנה, והבוכ"ע ברא כל העולמות והשלים סל מעשה בראשית על תיקונם הראוי להם, ומסר קיומה לבנ"א שמקיימין אותה ע"י התורה ומעשה המצות, ולכאורה אין זה בונה אלא מקיים וצ"ב הלשון שבחרו חז"ל לכנות לת"ח שם בנאים ע"ש שעוסקין בבניינו של עולם
translation: B) The sages said in Tractate Shabbat (114a) that Torah scholars are called builders because they engage in the building of the world all their days. It is appropriate to understand the words of the sages and their riddles as to why they are referred to as builders. It is true that the existence of the world is sustained by the pillar of the Torah; nevertheless, the sages said that the world stands on three things, and they did not say that the world is built. The Blessed Holy One created all the worlds and completed the work of creation in their proper order, and He entrusted their existence to humanity, who sustain it through the Torah and the performance of commandments. At first glance, this does not seem to be building but rather sustaining, and it is a question why the sages chose to refer to Torah scholars as builders in the context of their engagement in the building of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the designation of Torah scholars as "builders" because they engage in the maintenance and sustenance of the world through their study and observance of the Torah. While the world is upheld by the pillars of Torah, the text emphasizes that it is not merely about building but rather about sustaining existence. The author reflects on the choice of the term "builders" by the sages, suggesting a deeper connection between the act of learning and the ongoing creation and maintenance of the universe. This highlights the integral role of Torah scholars in the divine order and the continuous process of creation through their spiritual endeavors.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המד"ר פ' בהר (פר' ל"ד סי' ט"ז) עה"פ ובנו ממך חרבות עולם מוסדי דור ודור תקומם (ישעי' נ"ח), ובמס' כלה פ"א הוא שנוי' בשינוי לשון קצת, ר"ע יהב לר' עקיבא שית מאה קונטרין דכסף שיקנה לו שדה, ובמס' כלה לקנות לו עיר, והלך ר"ע ויהב יתהון לספרייא ולאילין דלעין באורייתא, לימים מצאו ר"ט לר"ע ושאלו היכן העיירות שלקחת לי, תפסו בידו והביאו לביהמ"ד והביא ספר תהלים וכו', עד שהגיעו לפסוק זה פזר נתן לאביונים וגו' א"ל זו העיר שקניתי לך עמד ר"ט ונשקו על ראשו והוסיף לו, ע"כ, לכאורה הן אמת שחשיבות גדול להחזיק ת"ת ותשב"ר, מ"מ הרי אצלם הי' כל תנועה אמת לאמיתו, ואם ר"ט נתן לו ממון לקנות עיר והוא חלקו למלמדי תינוקות, עפ"י פשטות לא קיים שליחותו, ואיך א"ל זו העיר שקניתי לך, וסוכ"ס לא אמר האמת, אף שגדלה מעלתה ובחי' יותר, מ"מ אינו זה הדבר אשר צוהו ואין זה עיר, והיל"ל שעשה בו דבר יותר חשוב, גם איך נתנן לתשב"ר ושינה מדעת הבעלים שצוהו לקנות עור, ופירשתי הכוונה עפי"ד רז"ל עיר שאין בה תשב"ר מחריבין אותה וי"א מחרימין אותה, נמצא דכל זמן שאין בעיר תשב"ר עומדת הוא ליחרב ר"ל, והכלל הוא דעומד ליחרב כחרוב דמי, נמצא כשמייסדים תלמוד תורה בזה מקיימין העיר ומצילין אותה מן החורבן, וקיי"ל המציל מן הנהר ומן הדליקה הרי אלו שלו, א"כ המציל דבר מאבדון קנאה, ובזה יונח שא"ל ר"ט לקנות עיר, הלך ר"ע ויוסד תלמוד תורה לתשב"ר ובזה קנה העיר, נמצא שקיים ר"ע שליחותו, ומ"ש זו העיר שקניתי לך, אמת אמר וכנים הדברים.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Midrash in Parshat Behar (Parshat 34, Siman 16) on the verse "And your children shall be like the swords of the world, established from generation to generation" (Isaiah 58), and in Masechet Kallah, Perek 1, it is stated with a slight variation in wording, Rabbi Akiva gave to Rabbi Akiva six hundred coins of silver to buy a field for himself, and in Masechet Kallah to buy a city, and Rabbi Akiva went and gave them to the scribes and to those who teach the Torah. After some time, Rabbi Tarfon found Rabbi Akiva and asked him, "Where are the cities you took for me?" He took him by the hand and brought him to the Beit Midrash and brought a Book of Psalms, etc., until they reached this verse: "He scattered, he gave to the poor," etc. He said to him, "This is the city I bought for you." Rabbi Tarfon stood up and kissed him on his head and added to him. Therefore, it seems that it is indeed true that there is great importance in supporting Torah study and the teaching of children, nevertheless, among them every action was true to its essence. And if Rabbi Tarfon gave him money to buy a city and he allocated it to the teachers of children, according to the simple understanding, he did not fulfill his mission, and how could he say, "This is the city I bought for you," and in the end, he did not speak the truth, even though its value increased and it is of a higher category, nonetheless, it is not what he commanded him, and this is not a city. He should have said that he did something more important with it. Also, how did he give it to the teachers of children and change from the will of the owners who commanded him to buy a city? And I explained the intention according to the words of our Sages: a city that does not have Torah study, we destroy it, and some say we excommunicate it. It turns out that as long as there is no Torah study in the city, it stands to be destroyed, God forbid. And the principle is that it stands to be destroyed is like a carob tree. Therefore, when they establish a Torah study in this, they sustain the city and save it from destruction. And we hold that one who saves from the river and from the fire, these are his. Therefore, one who saves something from destruction, it is acquired. And in this, it is established that Rabbi Tarfon told him to buy a city, Rabbi Akiva went and established a Torah study for the teaching of children, and in this, he acquired the city. Thus, Rabbi Akiva fulfilled his mission, and when he said, "This is the city I bought for you," he spoke the truth, and the words are sincere.
summary: In the passage, the author discusses the significance of establishing a Torah study institution (Talmud Torah) as a means of preserving a community and preventing its destruction. The narrative illustrates that Rabbi Akiva, despite not acquiring a physical city as instructed, fulfilled his mission by founding a place of learning, which is deemed more valuable. This act of prioritizing spiritual education over material acquisition highlights the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of Torah and its role in sustaining Jewish life. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that true fulfillment of one's purpose lies in elevating the spiritual state of a community.

passage_content: ונא""פ עוד בחי' בדברי המדרש הנ"ל, ובמאה"כ ובנו ממך חרבות עולם מוסדי דור ודור ובמ"ש חז"ל תלמידי חכמים נקראין בנאין מפני שעוסקין בבניינו של עולם, עפימ"ש הפמ"ג בשו"ע או"ח (ה' ת"ב סי' תקס"א) דכשבא ר"ג קיטווער זלה"ה לא"י וראה ירושלים בבניינה, בכה מאוד ואמר אזכרה אלקים ואהמי' בראותי כל עיר, היינו ירושלים שלמטה על תילה בנוי', ועיר אלקים ירושלים שלמעלה מושפלת עד שאול תחתי' עכ"ד, ועניינו עפי"מ דאיתא בספה"ק זרע קודש (פ' תצא) לפ' מאמרינו יבנה ירושלים עיה"ק במהרה בימינו, דידוע דלעת"ל יבוא מלמעלה ירושלים וביהמ"ק בנוי ומשוכלל כמבואר ברש"י ותוס', ובזוה"ק נראה דכל א"ו יבוא מלמעלה בנוי ומשוכלל, והנה ממה נבנה זה הביהמ"ק, ממצות ומע"ט של צדיקים כמבואר זה בכל הספרים הקודמים, ומביא שהרה"ק הר"ר אלימלך זי"ע עלה עליית נשמה והראו לו הכלים שנבראו על ידו, ואמר הרה"ק זלה"ה שברומי בונין תיפלה ועולין לה אלפים בונים בכל יום, והרה"ק מלובלין מפיל כולן בשמ"ע א' שמתפלל, דלפי ערך מה שנבנה בקדושה נופל הקליפה, וזהו בקשתונו ובנה ירושלים עיה"ק במהרה, ובמה תבנהו עז"א בימינו במה שאנו עושים בהימים שלנו, דהמצות ומעש"ט שצדיקים מסגלין בימיהן בזה נבנה ירושלים שלמעלן עכדה"ק.
translation:
And yet, in the aspect of the words of the aforementioned Midrash, and in the verse "and from you will come forth swords of the world, established from generation to generation," and in what our Sages of blessed memory said that Torah scholars are called builders because they engage in the building of the world, as the Pnei Menachem writes in Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim (Hilchot Taanit, Siman 561) that when Rabbi Gamliel of blessed memory came to the Land of Israel and saw Jerusalem in its building, he wept greatly and said, "I remember God and my soul when I see every city," meaning the Jerusalem below, built upon its foundation, and the city of God, Jerusalem above, is lowered to the depths of the grave. Thus far his words. 

And its essence is as it is written in the holy book Zera Kodesh (Parshat Tetzaveh) regarding our statement, "May Jerusalem, the holy city, be built speedily in our days," for it is known that in the future, Jerusalem will come from above, built and perfected, as explained by Rashi and Tosafot, and in the Zohar it appears that all the "and" will come from above, built and perfected. 

And behold, from what is this Holy Temple built? From the commandments and good deeds of the righteous, as explained in all the previous books. And it is brought that the holy Rabbi Elimelech of blessed memory ascended in a spiritual elevation and was shown the vessels that were created by him, and the holy Rabbi of blessed memory said that in Rome they build a single vessel and thousands ascend to it every day, and the holy Rabbi of Lublin brings them all down with a single prayer that he prays, for according to the measure of what is built in holiness, the klipah falls. 

And this is our request, "And build Jerusalem, the holy city, speedily," and how will it be built? It is said, "In our days," through what we do in our days, for the commandments and good deeds that the righteous acquire in their times, through this Jerusalem above is built. Thus far are his holy words.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the spiritual construction of Jerusalem, both in the physical and metaphysical realms, emphasizing that the actions and merits of the righteous (Tzadikim) contribute to the building of the Heavenly Jerusalem. It highlights the connection between the earthly and divine, illustrating that the fulfillment of mitzvot and good deeds in this world directly influences the construction of the Holy Temple above. The text also references the teachings of revered Hasidic masters, who convey that the spiritual elevation achieved through prayer and righteous actions can counteract negative forces, thereby facilitating the divine restoration of Jerusalem in the Messianic era.

passage_content: והנה אין במציאות בעולם קדושה ועבודה גדולה בבחינתה, מתורתן של תינוקות של בית רבן שהבל פיהם און בו חטא, ולכן א"ל ר"ע שע"י תורתן של תשב"ר בניתי לך עיר, דהיינו עור האלקים ירושלים שלמעלה, ויתכן שר"ט כשא"ל לקנות לו עיר. ג"כ ע"ז הי' כוונתו מעיקרא, וחז"ל דברו בכ"מ ע"ד הרמז והמשל, ולדרכינו אינו משל רק כן הוא בפועל, שבזה בונים עיר ירושלים שלמעלה, ולזה צריך כל אחד להתאמץ בהחזקת התורה, ולהחזיק במוסדות החינוך שהם על טהרת הקודש ולהשתדל בקיומם ולסייע בידינו להעמיד דורות בנ"י, ובזה ה"ה עוסקים בבניינו של עולם ובונים ארץ ישראל וירושלים שלמעלה, וידע כאו"א שאף כמה שהרבה ליתן עדיין זכה למציאה גדולה, ואלמלי היו יודעין מה קונים בזה, ואל מה זוכין בעבורה היו נותנין הרבה יותר, דכל כמה שיתן עדיין הוא שווה יותר, ועשה מקח טוב מאוד, שעי"ז יש לו חלק בתורתן של תשב"ר ויש לו חלק בבניינו של עולם. והרבה בנ"א מויגעון בלקיחת בתים ונחלות להרוויח, וא"א לידע מראש אם לא יפסידו ח"ו, אבל כשלוקחים בניינים אלו ירוויחו בודאי, וה"ה קיום נצחי עדי עד, והבוכ"ע יעזור לכל אלו הנוטלים חלק בהחזקת התורה, במזונא רויחא והרחבת הדעת שיוכלו ליתן עוד, כמ"ש ז"ל ויתן ויחזור ויתן, והעיקר שיהי' לנו סייעתא דשמיא להעמיד דורות בנ"י ישרים ונאמנים לד' ולתוה"ק, ובזה יונח אמרם ז"ל שתלמידי חכמים נקראים בנאים ע"ש שעוסקין בבניינו של עולם, שע"י תורתם ועבודתם בונים ירושלים וא"י שלמעלה והוא יסוד העולם. נמצא שהם העוסקים בבניינו של עולם ע"ד האמת.
translation: And behold, there is no holiness and great service in the world as in the teachings of the children of the house of study, whose mouths utter the breath of their sin. Therefore, Rabbi Akiva said to him, "Through the teachings of the children of the house of study, I have built you a city," meaning the divine light of the upper Jerusalem. It is possible that Rabbi Tarfon, when he said to acquire a city for himself, also had this intention from the beginning. The sages spoke everywhere in terms of hints and parables, and according to our path, it is not a parable but rather so it is in action, that through this we build the upper Jerusalem. For this, everyone needs to strive to support the Torah and to uphold the educational institutions that are on the purity of holiness, and to make an effort to sustain them and assist us in establishing generations of the Jewish people. In this, they are engaged in the building of the world and in building the land of Israel and the upper Jerusalem. And let each one know that even if he gives a lot, he still merits a great acquisition, and if they would know what they are purchasing with this, and what they are meriting for it, they would give much more, for the more one gives, it is still worth more. He has made a very good deal, for through this he has a share in the teachings of the children of the house of study and he has a share in the building of the world. Many people toil in acquiring houses and inheritances to profit, and it is impossible to know in advance if they will not lose, Heaven forbid. But when they take these buildings, they will certainly profit, and this is an eternal existence forever. May the Blessed One help all those who take part in supporting the Torah, with good sustenance and an expansion of understanding so that they can give more, as our sages said, "He gives and returns to give." The main thing is that we should have divine assistance to establish generations of the Jewish people who are upright and faithful to God and to the holy Torah. In this, their saying is established that the scholars are called builders because they are engaged in the building of the world, for through their Torah and service, they build the Jerusalem and the land of Israel above, and this is the foundation of the world. Thus, they are the ones engaged in the building of the world in truth.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound significance of the Torah learned by children, which is seen as a foundational element in building the spiritual Jerusalem above. It highlights the importance of supporting Torah education and institutions dedicated to holiness, asserting that such efforts contribute to the construction of both the physical and spiritual realms of Israel. The text conveys that those who invest in Torah and education are guaranteed eternal rewards, as their contributions are viewed as essential to the world's construction and the continuity of Jewish generations. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that scholars are builders of the world, as their teachings and practices create a lasting impact on both the earthly and heavenly Jerusalem.

passage_content: ויתבאר עוד עפ"י דרכינו הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי קיז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' קרח) מ"ש בשם ס' עיר בנימין על אמרם ז"ל ועשו לי מקדש לי לשמי. דלכאורה קשה הלא כל המצות צריכין להיות נעשים לשמה ולמה פרט הכתוב במקדש דוקא וכו' וביאר עפי"ד הגמ' (פסחים דף נ' ע"ב) רבא רמי כתיב מעל שמים חסדך וכתיב עד שחקים אמיתך, ומשני כאן שעושין לשמה וכאן בעושין שלא לשמה וכו', ופי' המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א שכל העושה מצוה שלא לשמה אינו זוכה רק לרקיע שחקים וכו', אבל העושה לשמה זוכה למעלה משחקים עכ"ד. ולכך במקדש ומשכן דאמרו רז"ל מקדש שלמטה מכוון כנגד מקדש שלמעלה. ומקדש שלמעלה הוא בזבול וכו', הזהירה התורה כאן בפרטיות שיעשו לשמה, כדי שיגיע הזכות עד זבול שהוא למעלה משחקים עכת"ד, והנה עפ"י אמרינו לעיל דת"ח המייגעים בתורה, וכמו"כ המחזיקים לומדי תורה בונים ירושלים וביהמ"ק שלמעלה, והרי בבנין ביהמ"ק צריך להיות לשמה דייקא, ולפי"ז הרי תנאי קשה בדבר, דהלומד והמחזיק צ"ל מעשיהם לשמה דייקא, ורק אז בונין במעשיהם ביהמ"ק שלמעלה, ובחי' זו קשה להשיג עד מאוד, ואף אם המחזיק יתכוין בתמיכתו לשמה, אכתי איכא למיחש שמא לא יכווין הת"ח בלימודו לשמה, נמצא כו לא זכה בהחזקת תורה לשמה.
translation: And it will be further clarified according to our aforementioned approach, by prefacing the words of the Kitzur Yismach Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parshat Korach), regarding what is stated in the name of the Sefer Ir Binyamin on the saying of our Sages, may their memory be blessed, "And they shall make for Me a sanctuary, and I shall dwell among them." At first glance, it is difficult, for all the commandments need to be performed for their own sake, so why does the verse specify the sanctuary specifically, etc. And he explained according to the Gemara (Pesachim 50b) that Rava posed a contradiction: it is written, "Your kindness is above the heavens," and it is written, "Your truth reaches to the clouds." And he answered, "Here, they are done for their own sake, and here, they are done not for their own sake," etc. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, explained in the first part that anyone who performs a commandment not for its own sake only merits the lower heavens, etc., but one who performs it for its own sake merits above the heavens. Therefore, in the case of the sanctuary and the Mishkan, which our Sages, may their memory be blessed, said that the sanctuary below corresponds to the sanctuary above. And the sanctuary above is in the Z'vul, etc. The Torah warns here specifically that they should be done for their own sake, so that the merit reaches Z'vul, which is above the heavens, as stated. And behold, according to what we said above, that Torah scholars who toil in Torah, and likewise those who support Torah learners, build Jerusalem and the Holy Temple above, and indeed, in the building of the Holy Temple, it must be specifically for its own sake. According to this, there is a difficult condition in the matter, that the learner and the supporter must have their actions specifically for its own sake, and only then do they build the Holy Temple above with their actions. And this aspect is very difficult to achieve, and even if the supporter intends in his support for its own sake, there is still concern that the Torah scholar may not intend in his learning for its own sake, thus it turns out that he did not merit supporting Torah for its own sake.
summary: The passage discusses the unique requirement for the construction of the Temple to be done "lishma" (for its own sake), contrasting it with other commandments that can be performed even without this intention. It references the Talmudic teaching that actions done for the sake of Heaven reach higher spiritual realms, specifically the heavenly Temple. The text emphasizes that both Torah scholars and their supporters must ensure their intentions are pure, as only then can their efforts contribute to the building of the heavenly Temple. This highlights the profound connection between intention, action, and spiritual elevation in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: וראיתי להרחוד"א זלה"ה בספרו ראש דוד (פ' קדושים ובפ' ברכה) שהביא בענין זה פלוגתת הקדמונים. דיש מהראשונים דס"ל שהמחזיק לת"ח, אף אם הת"ח לומד שלא לשמה, אבל המחזיק הרי כוונתו ורצונו ליתן על תורה לשמה, לכן יש לו שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, ומהר"ש פרימו חולק על דבריהם, לפי שהוקשה לו מדברי הגמ', שקלל ירמי' הנביא לאנשי ענתות ואמר רבש"ע אפי' בשעה שהם נותנים צדקה הכשילם בבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים שלא יקבלו עליהם שכר, ואי אמרת דאף שאינו המקבל הגון מ"מ הנותן מקבל שכר על כוונתו הטוב כאילו נתן למהוגנים. א"כ מה הועיל ירמי' הנביא בקללתו, אע"כ דהא בהא תליא, ואם המקבלים אינם מהוגנים גם הנותן לא עלה בידו כלום יעיי"ש בדברי החיד"א שמכריע לכאן ולכאן. ובספה"ק צמח דוד להרה"ק מוה"ר דוד מדינוב זי"ע כתב שיש לצדד עוד סברא להקל דגם הת"ח עצמו אף אם עוסק שלא לשמה, זוכה ע"י המחזיק לשכר תורה לשמה, דהרי המחזיק יש לו שכר תורה לשמה לשיטת הראשונים ז"ל, והרי הת"ח הוא המביאו לזה ע"ו גרמא דילי', לכן זוכה גם הוא בשכר תורה לשמה ע"י המחזיקו עכדה"ק.
translation: And I saw that the holy Rabbi Yoel, may his memory be a blessing, in his book "Rosh David" (in Parshas Kedoshim and in Parshas Berachah) brought regarding this a dispute among the early authorities. There are some of the early ones who hold that one who supports a Torah scholar, even if the scholar is learning not for its own sake, since the supporter’s intention and desire is to give for the sake of Torah learning, therefore he has a reward as if he supported Torah learning for its own sake. However, Rabbi Shmuel Primo disagrees with their words, as he was troubled by the words of the Gemara, which included the prophet Jeremiah's curse upon the people of Anathoth, where he said, "Master of the Universe, even at the time they are giving charity, You caused them to stumble with unworthy people so that they would not receive a reward." And if you say that even if the recipient is unworthy, nonetheless the giver receives a reward for his good intention as if he gave to worthy individuals, then what benefit did the prophet Jeremiah achieve with his curse? Rather, it must be that one is dependent on the other, and if the recipients are unworthy, then the giver has not achieved anything either. See there in the words of the Chida, who rules both ways. And in the holy book "Tzemach David" by the holy Rabbi David of Dinov, may his memory be a blessing, it is written that there is another reason to be lenient, that even the Torah scholar himself, even if he is engaged not for its own sake, merits through the supporter a reward for Torah learning for its own sake, for the supporter has a reward for Torah learning for its own sake according to the opinion of the early authorities, and the Torah scholar is the one who brings him to this, thus he also merits the reward for Torah learning for its own sake through the one who supports him.
summary: The passage discusses a debate among early authorities regarding the merit of supporting a Torah scholar who studies for ulterior motives. Some argue that the supporter receives reward as if the scholar were learning for its own sake, while others, like Rabbi Shmuel Primo, contend that if the recipient is unworthy, the donor gains nothing. The Chida offers a resolution, suggesting that the supporter’s intention can still yield merit, and the scholar, despite his motivations, may also benefit from the support, as the act of support itself can elevate the learning to a level of genuine Torah study. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the interconnectedness of intentions and actions in the realm of spiritual reward.

passage_content: ואפשר ליישב שיטת הראשונים ז"ל דלא יקשה עליהם קושית המהר"ש פרימו ז"ל, דהנה יש תרי גווני שלא לשמה כמ"ש התוס' (פסחים נ' ע"ב), והרי ארז"ל לעולם יעסוק בתומ"צ אפי' שלא לשמה שמתוך של"ש בא לשמה, א"כ אף בזה מצוה קא עביד, ואף שכתבו המפרשים דתועלת הלימוד שלא לשמה, הוא רק בשביל שמתו"כ יגיע ללימוד לשמה, ואם לא יביאהו לידי לשמה לא הועיל במעשיו כלום, אבל מ"מ הרי אמרו רז"ל לעולם יעסוק בתומ"צ אפי' שלא לשמה א"כ מצוה קא עביד, ובפשטות אפ"ל דהלומד תורה אף אם אין כוונתו זכה לשמה, ומכווין גם כוונה פני' אחרת, מ"מ באמצע לימודו מגיע לו לפעמים מחשבה טובה וקדושה, ואף שאינו נשאר ומתקיים בזה המדריגה ונופל ממנה. אבל סו"ס יביאהו זה המחשבה קדושה לבחי' לשמה, ואפשר לרמוז זה באמרם ז"ל מתוך שלא לשמה בא לשמה, היינו בתוך ובאמצע לימודו יהי' לו מחשבה טובה, וזה יביאהו אח"כ לידי לשמה, עכ"פ אית בחי' תורה שלא לשמה שמותר ומצוה איכא בגווי', אולם יש גם בחי' שלא לשמה שארז"ל נוח לו שלא נברא ומוטב שנהפכה שלייתו על פניו ולימודו נחשב לו לעון ר"ל, והתוס' שם כתבו דהוא בלומד כדי לקנטר ולקפח את חביריו בהלכה עיי"ש, ובכה"ג עבירה הוא בידו.
translation:
And it is possible to reconcile the opinion of the early authorities, may their memory be blessed, that the question of the Maharsh Primo, may his memory be blessed, should not be difficult for them. Behold, there are two types of learning not for its own sake, as the Tosafot write (Pesachim 50b), and our sages have said that one should always engage in Torah and mitzvot even if not for their own sake, for from not for its own sake one comes to for its own sake. Therefore, even in this case, he is performing a mitzvah. And although the commentators have written that the benefit of learning not for its own sake is only because through it he will come to learn for its own sake, and if it does not bring him to for its own sake, his actions have not helped him at all, nevertheless, our sages have said that one should always engage in Torah and mitzvot even if not for their own sake, thus he is performing a mitzvah. 

And simply put, one can say that the one who learns Torah, even if his intention is not for its own sake, and he is also directing his intention towards something else, nevertheless, in the midst of his learning, he sometimes receives a good and holy thought. And even though he does not remain and sustain that level and falls from it, ultimately this holy thought will bring him to the level of for its own sake. And it is possible to allude to this in their saying, may their memory be blessed, that from not for its own sake he comes to for its own sake, meaning that in the midst of his learning he will have a good thought, and this will later bring him to for its own sake. At least there is a level of Torah not for its own sake that is permitted and there is a mitzvah in it. However, there is also a level of not for its own sake that our sages have said it would have been better for him not to have been created, and it is better that his excrement be turned over his face, and his learning is considered a sin for him, may God save us. And the Tosafot there wrote that this refers to one who learns in order to provoke and to undermine his friends in halacha, see there, and in such a case, it is a transgression in his hands.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of learning Torah "shelo lishma" (not for its own sake) and its potential to lead to "lishma" (for its own sake). It emphasizes that even when one's intentions are not pure, engaging in Torah study can still yield positive spiritual thoughts that may eventually elevate one's intentions. However, it also warns that there are forms of learning that are considered sinful, particularly when done with the intent to harm others or undermine them. Ultimately, the text highlights the transformative power of Torah study, even when initiated from less than ideal motivations.

passage_content: והנה ארז"ל (נזיר כ"ג ע"א) אשה הפרם וד' יסלח לה וכו' רע"ק כי מטא להאי קרא בכי, ומה מי שנתכוון לעלות בידו בשר חזיר ועלה בידו בשר טלה טעון כפרה וסליחה וכו' עוד אמרו שם ומה מי שנתכווין לעלות בידו בשר טלה ועלה בידו בשר חזיר וכו' אמר קרא ונשא עונו וכו' ולפי"ז המחזיק בלומדי תורה ע"מ לקנטר, אף אם לא ידע מהותם ואיכותם, והי' כל כוונתו להחזיק בלימוד תורה לשמה, מ"מ בכגון דא א"א לומר דמגיע להמחזיק שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, אדרבה הרי צריך כפרה דהרי לימודו של זה עבירה הוא, וה"ה כנתכוון לאכול בשר טלה ועלתה בידו של חזיר שצריך כפרה, אבל בבחי' שלא לשמה ע"מ לקבל שכר או פני' אחרת, הרי הלומד אינו עושה עבירה כ"א מצוה. בודאי יקבל המחזיק שכרו כהחזקת תורה לשמה כשיטת הראשונים הנ"ל
translation: And behold, our sages said (Nazir 23a) that a woman who has separated her terumah and her husband forgives her, etc. Rabbi Akiva, when he reached this verse, wept, and what about someone who intended to take in his hand meat of a pig and instead took in his hand meat of a lamb, he requires atonement and forgiveness, etc. They also said there, and what about someone who intended to take in his hand meat of a lamb and instead took in his hand meat of a pig, etc. The verse states, "and he shall bear his iniquity," etc. According to this, one who supports Torah scholars in order to provoke, even if he does not know their essence and quality, and his entire intention is to support the study of Torah for its own sake, nevertheless, in such a case, one cannot say that he deserves the reward of supporting Torah for its own sake; on the contrary, he requires atonement, for his study is a transgression. The same applies if he intended to eat meat of a lamb and instead took in his hand meat of a pig, for he requires atonement. However, in a case where he studies not for its own sake in order to receive reward or for another reason, the learner does not commit a transgression but rather performs a mitzvah. Certainly, the supporter will receive his reward as if he supported Torah for its own sake, according to the opinion of the earlier authorities mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intention in the study of Torah, emphasizing that even if one engages in learning with the aim of disparaging others, it is considered a transgression that requires atonement. It contrasts this with learning done for ulterior motives, which, while not ideal, is still viewed as a mitzvah rather than a sin. The text highlights the importance of one's intentions in spiritual pursuits and the implications for receiving reward or needing forgiveness. Ultimately, it underscores the complexity of motivations in religious practice and their impact on one's spiritual standing.

passage_content: ומעתה לא קשה קושית המהר"ש פרימו ז"ל ממה שקלל ירמי' לאנשי ענתות שיכשלו בבני אדם שאינם מהוגנים, דהתם מיירי בכאלו שאינם מתנהגים על פי התורה כלל, ובכגון דא ודאי לא יקבל שכר המחזיק בידם לתמכם, ולא קשה מידי, וסברת הראשונים אמת וקיים אצל וסתם בעלי תורה, אף אם לומדין בבחי' שלא לשמה ובמחשבה לשם פני', מ"מ המחזיקים בידם מקבלין שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, ובגמ' מיירי בבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים ומתנהגים בתהלוכות מעשיהם היפך התורה, וע"כ התומכום בידן אינם מקבלים עליהם שכר, ומעתה סברת הראשונים קיימת לדברי הכל.
translation: And from now on, the question of the Maharshal Primo, may his memory be blessed, is not difficult regarding what he included in Jeremiah for the people of Anathoth, that they would stumble with individuals who are not proper. For there, it speaks of those who do not conduct themselves according to the Torah at all, and in such a case, certainly, one who supports them to assist them will not receive reward. It is not too difficult, and the reasoning of the early authorities is true and valid among the generality of Torah scholars, even if they study in a manner that is not for its own sake and with the intention for the sake of Heaven. Nevertheless, those who support them receive reward as if they are supporting Torah for its own sake. And in the Gemara, it speaks of individuals who are not proper and conduct themselves in ways that are contrary to the Torah. Therefore, those who support them do not receive reward for it. And from now on, the reasoning of the early authorities stands firm according to everyone's words.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between supporting individuals who do not adhere to Torah principles and those who do, even if their intentions are not entirely pure. It asserts that while those who support the latter group can receive merit for their actions, supporting individuals who act contrary to the Torah does not yield reward. This highlights the importance of aligning one's actions with Torah values and the theological principle that intentions and behaviors significantly impact spiritual merit. Ultimately, it reinforces the validity of earlier rabbinic opinions regarding the nature of reward for supporting Torah observance.

passage_content: ופירשתי בדרך בדיחותא מאמרם ז"ל עבר ושנה הותרה לו וכו' נעשית לו כהיתר, דלכאורה וכי משום שעבר עבירה שנו פעמים איך נעשית לו כהיתר, וגם מהו הלשון עבר הושנה" עבר ומכפלוז היל"ל, ואפ"ל דמלת אושנה" הכוונה בו מלשון לימוד, כמו שנו חכמים בלשון המשנה. והפי' דאם עובר עבירה במזיד והוא גם למדן ולומד ע"מ לקנער, אז מברר לו היתר להצדיק מעשהו עפ"י הלכה, ועי"ז הותרה לו ונעשית לו כהיתר, וע"ז הלימוד אמרז"ל נוח לו שלא נברא ולימודו עבירה ועון פלילי.
translation: And I explained in a humorous manner their saying, may their memory be blessed, "If one transgressed and repeated, it is permitted to him," etc., it becomes to him as a permit. For at first glance, how can it be that because he transgressed a sin twice, it becomes to him as a permit? And what is the meaning of the phrase "transgressed and repeated"? It should have said "transgressed and doubled." And it can be said that the word "repeated" refers to the language of learning, as the sages taught in the language of the Mishnah. The explanation is that if one transgresses a sin intentionally and he is also a scholar learning in order to justify, then he clarifies for himself a permit to justify his actions according to halacha, and thereby it is permitted to him and becomes to him as a permit. And concerning this teaching, our sages said, "It would have been better for him not to have been created than to learn a sin and a criminal offense."
summary: The passage discusses the concept that if a person intentionally commits a sin while being knowledgeable in Torah, they may rationalize their actions as permissible, thus making the sin feel like a legitimate option. The phrase "עבר ושנה" is interpreted as a reference to learning, suggesting that a learned individual who sins may distort their understanding of halacha to justify their behavior. The text emphasizes the gravity of such actions, indicating that it would have been better for them not to have been created than to misuse their learning for sinful purposes. This highlights the tension between knowledge and moral responsibility in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד לתרץ קושית המהר"ש פרימו זלה"ה, דמקללת ירמי' הנביא הכשילם בעניים שאינם מהוגנים לק"מ, דהנה אין ספק שאנשי ענתות היו רשעים ושנואי ד', דאם הי' השי"ת אוהבם לא הי' ירמי' הנביא מקללם, והנה ידוע דמטבע הרשעים לשנוא ליראי ה' וכמ"ש הרבינו יונה זלל"ה בפי' למשלי, לפרש הכתוב מצרף לכסף וכור לזהב ואיש לפי מהללו, דכל דבר יש לו מבחן, והמצרף מובחן לכסף והכור לזהב, והמבחן של אדם הוא לפי מהללו, לראות את מי מהלל, דאם מהלל לצדיקים הוא צדיק וההיפוך בהיפוך, וכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' בלק) דבר זה שימה בטבע שהרשעים ישנאו את הצדיקים גם בלי סיבה יעיי"ש, ולכאורה לפי"ז היו אנשי ענתות שונאים לעניים מהוגנים, ומעצמם ימנעו מליתן להם, ולמה הוצרך ירמי' הנביא לקללם בזה אמנם ירמי' הנביא ראה והשיג שאפשר במציאות דבר כזה, שאף שהם רשעים מ"מ ירצו לתמוך בעניים מהוגנים כדי להמשיך אותם לדעתם הרשעה, וע"ד שפירשתי (בפ' שמות) מ"ד במדרש מתחילה בפה רך שפרעה גזר על עבודה ומתחלה שילם להם שכרם, ושבט לוי לא רצו לקבל שאמרו עתידים אנו לעבוד להשי"ת ולא נעבוד אדם רשע ועי"כ ניצולו מהן, ולכאורה הרי לבסוף עבדו ישראל בכפי' עפ"י גזירת המלכות ואיך ניצולו בני לוי, ואפשר שע"י שהעם קיבלו מתחלה ממון הרשעים עי"ז נמשכו אחרי טומאתם דלא סגי בלא"ה, ובעון זה שלטו בגופן אח"כ, וע"ד מ"ש רש"י ז"ל פ' בהר בשם ת"כ עה"פ לא תעשו לכם אלילים, כנגד זה הנמכר לנכרי, שלא יאמר הואיל ורבי מגלה עריות אף אני כמותו הואיל ורבי עובד ע"ז אף אני כמותו וכו'. ולכאורה מי פתו יאמר כן, ה"ה גוי ואתה ישראל ואיך תחשוב להתדמות אליו, אמנם מפני שירצה לישא חן בעיניו עי"ז מתחיל להתדמות אליו בדבר קטן וקל, והיום אומר לו עשה כך ולמחר אומר לו עשה כך וכו' ויבוא להתדמות אליו לעבוד ע"ז ולגלות עריות כמותו, ועד"ז פרעה רצה להמשיך ולשעבד את ישראל תחת רשותו, וכמ"ש בשלה"ק וירעו אותנו המצרים שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים, לכן שילם להם בתחלה ממון רב. ועי"כ נפלו ממדריגתם והי"ל שליטה עליהן, משא"כ שבט לוי לא רצו לקבל ואף בעד כל כסף וזהב שבעולם לא רצו לעבוד לאדם רשע וע"כ לא הי"ל שליטה עליהן כלל וניצולו מידו
translation: And I can also explain the difficulty of the Maharshal Primo, may his memory be blessed, that the prophet Jeremiah cursed the people of Anathoth for their unworthy poor, for there is no doubt that the people of Anathoth were wicked and hated by God. If the Holy One, blessed be He, loved them, the prophet Jeremiah would not have cursed them. It is known that it is the nature of the wicked to hate those who fear the Lord, as our Rabbi Yonah, may his memory be blessed, explains in his commentary on Proverbs, to interpret the verse "the refiner for silver and the furnace for gold, and a man according to his praise," that everything has a test, and the refiner is for silver and the furnace is for gold, and a person's test is according to his praise, to see whom he praises. If he praises the righteous, he is righteous, and the opposite is true as well. And Rabbi Simcha Moshe, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in Parshat Balak) that it is natural for the wicked to hate the righteous even without reason, as you can see there. And seemingly, according to this, the people of Anathoth would hate the unworthy poor and would refrain from giving to them on their own, so why did the prophet Jeremiah need to curse them for this? However, the prophet Jeremiah saw and understood that it is possible in reality for such a thing to happen, that even though they are wicked, they would still want to support the unworthy poor in order to draw them into their wickedness. This is similar to what I explained (in Parshat Shemot) regarding the Midrash that initially Pharaoh decreed labor and at first paid them their wages, and the tribe of Levi did not want to accept it, as they said, "We are destined to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, and we will not serve a wicked man," and thus they were saved from them. And seemingly, in the end, the Israelites worked according to the decree of the kingdom, and how were the sons of Levi saved? It is possible that by the people initially receiving money from the wicked, they were drawn after their impurity, which was not sufficient without it, and because of this sin, they later had control over them. This is in line with what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in Parshat Behar in the name of the Tanchuma on the verse "You shall not make for yourselves idols," against this, the one sold to a foreigner, so that he should not say, "Since my teacher reveals forbidden relations, I too will be like him; since my teacher serves idols, I too will be like him," etc. And seemingly, who would say such a thing? He is a gentile and you are Israel, and how could you think to resemble him? However, because he wants to find favor in his eyes, he begins to resemble him in a small and easy matter, and today he tells him to do this, and tomorrow he tells him to do that, etc., and he will come to resemble him to serve idols and reveal forbidden relations like him. Similarly, Pharaoh wanted to continue and enslave Israel under his authority, as it is written in the holy books, "And the Egyptians made us evil and sinful," therefore he initially paid them a lot of money. And because of this, they fell from their level, and he had control over them. In contrast, the tribe of Levi did not want to accept, and even for all the money and gold in the world, they did not want to serve a wicked man, and therefore he had no control over them at all, and they were saved from his hand.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of wickedness and its relationship with the righteous, emphasizing that the wicked often despise the righteous without cause. It illustrates how the people of Anathoth, despite their evil, might have been tempted to support the poor to draw them into their corrupt ways. The text highlights the importance of maintaining one's integrity and not succumbing to the allure of the wicked, as exemplified by the Levites who refused to accept rewards from Pharaoh, thereby preserving their spiritual standing and avoiding the influence of sin. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that one's associations and the company one keeps can significantly impact their moral and spiritual state.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר לענינינו דלפי שהיו אנשי ענתות רשעים ושנואי ד"נ היו משתוקקים להמשיך רבים לרשעתם, כמשה"כ לא ישנו אם לא ירעו ונגזלה שנתם אם לא יכשילו. והשתדלו להמשיך אליהם אנשים מהוגנים שיתפתו לדעתם ולא ילחמו נגדן ועוד יתנו להם כת וחיזוק, לכן פרשו רשתם לתמוך לעניים מהוגנים, וע"י שיתנו להן ממון יתפסו לדעתם ועי"ז יקבלו כח וחיזוק, לכן קיללם ירמי' הנביא שיכשלו בבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים והמהוגנים ינצלו מידם, ואף אם ישתדלו לרדוף ולהשיג מהוגנים, יכשלו ויטעו ויזדמן להם בנ"א שאינם מהוגנים, אלא שלמראית העין מתדמין כמהוגנים ובאמת המה צבועים ורשעים.
translation: And similarly, it will be explained regarding our matter that since the people of Anathoth were wicked and hated by the Divine Name, they were eager to draw many into their wickedness, as it is written, "They will not change unless they are harmed, and their sleep will be stolen unless they cause others to stumble." They made efforts to attract respectable people to be swayed by their opinions and not to fight against them, and furthermore, to give them a faction and support. Therefore, they spread their net to support respectable poor people, and by giving them money, they would capture their opinions and thereby gain strength and support. Thus, the prophet Jeremiah cursed them that they would stumble upon people who are not respectable, while the respectable ones would be saved from them. And even if they strive to pursue and attain respectable individuals, they will fail and be misled, and they will encounter people who are not respectable, who, at first glance, appear to be respectable, but in truth, they are hypocrites and wicked.
summary: The passage discusses the dangers posed by the wicked people of Anathoth, who sought to lead others into their corruption. It emphasizes the idea that these individuals would attempt to ensnare the righteous by offering support and financial aid, thereby corrupting their values. The prophet Jeremiah curses them, indicating that despite their efforts to deceive and manipulate, the truly righteous will ultimately be protected from their influence, while the wicked will fail in their pursuits. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of divine protection for the righteous amidst the trials posed by the morally corrupt.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה שרק רע הי' כל כוונתם, ומי שכוונתו לכזה, בוודאי אין מקבל שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, דדי שיקבל שכר אם יזדמן לפניו עניים מהוגנים שעכ"פ עשה מצוה, ואף שהי' כוונתו לרוע אעפ"כ יש לו קצת שכר, וממילא לא יקשה מהתם על שיטת הראשונים ז"ל, וסברתם קיימת דאף המחזיק ביד הלומד שלא לשמה מקבל שכר כעל תורה לשמה, ואין שום קושיא ממאמר רז"ל הנ"ל שקיללם ירמי' הנביא הכשילם בבני אדם שאינם מהוגנים, וג"ז תירוץ מספיק, ובפרט לפי מה שהעליתי לעיל דיש ב' בחינות בתורה שלא לשמה בפשטות לק"מ, דמ"ש הכשילם באינם מהוגנים כוונתו על סוג הגרוע בתורה שלא לשמה וכ"ז אמת ויציב.
translation: What emerges from this is that their entire intention was only for evil, and one whose intention is such certainly does not receive reward like that of one who upholds the Torah for its own sake. It is sufficient for him to receive reward if he encounters respectable poor people, for at least he performed a mitzvah, and even though his intention was for bad, he still has some reward. Therefore, it will not be difficult to reconcile this with the opinion of the earlier authorities, and their reasoning stands that even one who supports the learner not for its own sake receives reward as if it were for the sake of the Torah. There is no difficulty from the aforementioned statement of our sages, which Jeremiah the prophet cursed, that he caused them to stumble with people who are not respectable. This is also a sufficient answer, especially according to what I have raised above that there are two aspects to studying Torah not for its own sake, in simple terms, it is not a difficulty. When he says he caused them to stumble with those who are not respectable, his intention is regarding the inferior type of studying Torah not for its own sake, and all this is true and established.
summary: המעבר מדבריו מצביע על כך שכאשר הכוונה היא רעה, אין האדם מקבל שכר כמו על לימוד תורה לשמה, אך אם הוא עשה מצווה, יש לו שכר מסוים. יש הבחנה בין סוגי הלימוד שלא לשמה, כאשר הכוונה הרעה מתייחסת לסוג הגרוע יותר. המאמר מדגיש שהשיטה של הראשונים מתקבלת, שכן גם מי שמחזיק ביד הלומד שלא לשמה יכול לקבל שכר, ואין סתירה למאמרי חז"ל על כך.

passage_content: נחזור לענינינו דהנה פלוגתת הראשונים במחזיקין ידו ת"ח, שא"א לנו לידע תעלומות לבו עד כמה הוא מכווין לשמה, אבל בתשב"ר אמרו רז"ל שהבל פיהם אין בו חטא, וזהו בוודאי לשמה, ואביי אמר לרבא כגון דידי ודידך מאי, א"ל אינו דומה הבל שיש בו חטא להבל שאין בו חעא, הרי שתורתם גבוה מעל גבוה, ואצלם אין נפק"מ הכוונה בין לשמה ושלא לשמה, שעדיין אינם מצווים ע"ז, והתורה שלהם קיום כל היהדות והוא גבוה יותר מכ"ד, ואם בזה נועלין חלק אזי בוודאי יש להמחזיק חלק בתורה לשמה ונוסף לזה הרי נוטלין גם חלק בהחזקת המלמדים וראשי ישיבות ת"ח לומדי תורה וכבר ביררנו לעיל שגם בזה יש להמחזיקים חלק בתורה לשמה עכ"פ.
translation: Let us return to our topic, for behold, there is a dispute among the Rishonim regarding the one who holds his hand, a Torah scholar, that we cannot know the depths of his heart to what extent he is intent on serving for its own sake. However, in the teachings of our Sages, they said that the words of their mouths contain no sin, and this is certainly for its own sake. And Abaye said to Rava, "What about someone like me and you?" He replied, "The breath that contains sin is not comparable to the breath that contains no sin." Thus, their Torah is high above high, and for them, there is no difference in intention between for its own sake and not for its own sake, as they are not yet commanded regarding this. Their Torah is the fulfillment of all Judaism, and it is higher than the twenty-four. If in this they close off a portion, then certainly the one who holds a portion in the Torah for its own sake has a share, and in addition, they also take a share in the support of the teachers and heads of yeshivas, the Torah scholars who study Torah. And we have already clarified above that even in this, those who support have a share in the Torah for its own sake, at least.
summary: The passage discusses the complexities of intention in Torah study, highlighting the debate among early authorities regarding the sincerity of one's heart in learning. It emphasizes that even if one's study is not entirely for the sake of heaven, as long as it is sincere, it is still valuable and free from sin. The text asserts that the essence of Torah transcends the distinction between pure and impure intentions, and that those who support Torah scholars and institutions also share in the merit of learning, reinforcing the communal aspect of spiritual growth. Ultimately, it underscores the elevated nature of Torah as a fundamental aspect of Jewish identity and practice.

passage_content: ובזה נשיג לדעת מה שהקדים הכתוב זבולן לפני יששכר, כי הנה יששכר ירמוז לת"ח העוסק בתורה, והוא אינו יכול להגיע מיד לבחי' תורה לשמה, שעל כן התירו חז"ל להתחיל בלימוד שלא לשמה, דא"א שיתחיל תיכף לשמה, משא"כ זבולן דאף כ"ז שהת"ח לומד עדיין שלא לשמה, כבר יש לו השכר של תורה לשמה, א"כ ה"ה מגיע לשכרו מוקדם ליששכר. לכן הקדימו הכ' שמח זבולן בצאתך, שתיכף ביציאתך להחזיק ידי ת"ח כבר יש לך חלקך, ויששכר באוהלך רק לאח"כ כנ"ל, וגם בפשטות יוכל המחזיק להשיג בחי' לשמה יותר מהעוסק בתורה, דהנה ארז"ל כל הגדול מחבירו יצרו גדול ממנו, ואמרז"ל שמניח היצה"ר כל העולם ומתגרה בת"ח יותר מכולן, א"כ העוסק בתורה מתגבר עליו היצר הרע ביותר. לכן קשה לו להגיע לבחי' לשמה. משא"כ המחזיק אינו מתגבר עליו היצה"ר כ"כ, לכן בניקל לו יותר להגיע לידי לשמה, והבן.
translation: In this, we will understand why the scripture precedes Zebulun before Issachar. For behold, Issachar alludes to the Torah scholar who engages in Torah study, and he cannot immediately reach the level of Torah lishma (for its own sake). Therefore, the Sages permitted beginning with study that is not lishma, for it is impossible to start immediately with lishma. In contrast, Zebulun, even while the Torah scholar is still learning not lishma, already has the reward of Torah lishma. Thus, he receives his reward earlier than Issachar. Therefore, the verse states, "Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out," for immediately upon your going out to support the hands of the Torah scholar, you already have your share, while Issachar is in your tents only afterwards, as mentioned. Furthermore, simply put, the supporter can attain the level of lishma more easily than the one engaged in Torah study. For our Sages taught that "the greater one is than his friend, his evil inclination is greater than him," and they also said that the evil inclination leaves the entire world and provokes the Torah scholar more than anyone else. Therefore, the one engaged in Torah faces the greatest challenge from the evil inclination. In contrast, the supporter does not struggle against the evil inclination as much, thus it is easier for him to reach the level of lishma. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the precedence of Zebulun over Issachar, highlighting that Issachar represents the Torah scholar who initially studies for ulterior motives, as it is difficult to achieve pure Torah study (lishma) right away. In contrast, Zebulun, who supports the Torah scholar, receives the reward of lishma even while the scholar is still learning for non-pure reasons. This suggests that the supporter can attain a higher spiritual level than the scholar, as the latter faces greater challenges from the evil inclination. Thus, the text emphasizes the value of supporting Torah study and the unique spiritual rewards associated with it.

passage_content: והנה בבנין ביהמ"ק הרי צ"ל לשמה כנ"ל בישמח משהו ולומדי תורה לשמה הרי זעירין אינון דאדם עלול לפניות, ואפילו באלו ההולכים בדרך הישר ורוצים לעשות רצון הבוב"ה, אעפי"כ גדולים הנסיונות וישנם הרבה פניות וקשה להשיג בחי' לשמה. לכן שכיח מאוד שהת"ח לא יזכה בתורתו רק לשכר העוה"ז, כמ"ש ז"ל בשמאלה עושר וכבוד דהיינו בלומדון שלא לשמה, ולכן אמרז"ל שקיבל בשכרו ביזת מצרים וביזת הים, משא"כ בזבולן המחזיק, מגיע תיכף במעשיו לבחי' תורה לשמה, ע"כ זוכה בזכותו לבנין ביהמ"ק, ששרשו למעלה בזבול, וצריך להיות לשמה דייקא כמבואר לעיל בדברי ק"ז זלה"ה, לכן העמידו חז"ל הרמז על זבולן בכתוב בנה בניתי בית זבול לך מכון לשבתך עולמים, שבזכותו יהי' בנין ביהמ"ק ששרשו למעלה בזבול וזבולן המחזיק התוה"ק יוכל להמשיך זאת בכח מצותו שמגיע מעל לשמים.
translation: And behold, in the building of the Holy Temple, it must be for its own sake, as mentioned above regarding joy and those who study Torah for its own sake, they are few among those who are prone to distractions. Even among those who walk in the straight path and wish to do the will of the Blessed One, nevertheless, the trials are great, and there are many distractions, making it difficult to achieve the level of studying for its own sake. Therefore, it is very common that the Torah scholar will not merit his Torah except for the reward of this world, as our sages have said, "On the left, wealth and honor," meaning in studying not for its own sake. Thus, our sages said that he received in return the spoils of Egypt and the spoils of the sea, whereas Zebulun, who supports, immediately reaches in his actions the level of Torah for its own sake. Therefore, he merits through his merit the building of the Holy Temple, whose root is above in Zebul, and it must be specifically for its own sake, as explained above in the words of Kabbalah, blessed be His name. Therefore, our sages established the hint regarding Zebulun in the verse, "I have built a house for You, a dwelling place for Your eternal abode," that through his merit there will be the building of the Holy Temple, whose root is above in Zebul, and Zebulun, who supports the Holy Torah, will be able to draw this down through the power of his commandment that reaches above the heavens.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of learning Torah "lishma" (for its own sake) in the context of building the Holy Temple. It emphasizes that even those who strive to do God's will face significant challenges and temptations, often resulting in learning for personal gain rather than spiritual elevation. The text highlights that true merit, as exemplified by the tribe of Zebulun, comes from supporting Torah study, which leads to a direct connection to the divine and the eventual construction of the Holy Temple. Ultimately, it underscores the necessity of pure intentions in spiritual pursuits to achieve a higher spiritual state.
