passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בענין הנ"ל מ"ט הקדימו לזבולן, והרי התורה צ"ל מוקדם לכל, ויתבאר בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ בפ' בכורים, ושמחת בכל הטוב אשר נתן לך ד' אלקיך וגו', ודרשו חז"ל (בכורים פ"ג) מכאן אמרו אין קורין מקרא בכורים אלא בזמן שמחה מעצרת ועד החג שאדם מלקט תבואתו ופירותיו ויינו ושמנו. אבל מהחג ואילך מביא ואינו קורא, וראוי להבין הכי אין שמחה זולתו לישראל שומר תומ"צ כ"א מה שמלקט תבואתו ופירותיו ויינו, גם יזדמן ח"ו שלא הצליחו תבואתו ועשאה שדהו פחות מכפי ששמוהו לעשות וה"ה עצב, ואיך אמרז"ל כללא שבזמן אסיפת התבואות הוא זמן שמחה ורק אז מביא וקורא ולא בזמן זולתו וטעמא מאי, וכעי"ז יש להעיר מה שקראתו תוה"ק לחג הסוכות חג האסיף, ע"ש הכתוב באספכם את תבואת הארץ תחוגו חג לד', הרי תלה הכתוב ענין החג הקדוש בזמן אסיפת התבואות וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: Further, one can say regarding the aforementioned matter, why Zebulun was given precedence, for the Torah must be prior to all. It will be explained in advance to interpret from the verse in Parashat Bikkurim, "And you shall rejoice in all the good which the Lord your God has given you," and our Sages have derived (Bikkurim 3) from here that one does not read the Bikkurim until the time of joy, from Shavuot until the festival, when a person gathers his produce, fruits, wine, and oil. However, from the festival onward, he brings but does not read. It is appropriate to understand that there is no joy for Israel, who observes the Torah and commandments, except for what he gathers of his produce, fruits, wine, and oil. It may also happen, Heaven forbid, that his produce was not successful and his field yielded less than what he had hoped for, and the same applies to sadness. How then did our Sages say that the general rule is that the time of gathering the produce is a time of joy, and only then does one bring and read, and not at any other time? What is the reason for this? Similarly, one can note that the Torah calls the festival of Sukkot the Festival of Ingathering, as it is written, "When you gather in the harvest of your land, you shall celebrate a festival to the Lord." Thus, the verse ties the matter of the holy festival to the time of gathering the produce, and the intention behind this is to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the timing of the reading of the Bikurim (first fruits) in relation to the joy associated with gathering one's harvest, emphasizing that true joy for the observant Jew is derived from the fruits of their labor. It highlights that the celebration of Sukkot, referred to as the "Festival of Ingathering," is intrinsically linked to the agricultural cycle, suggesting that the spiritual fulfillment and connection to God are realized through the physical act of harvesting. The text raises questions about the nature of joy and sadness in the context of agricultural success or failure, underscoring the importance of gratitude and recognition of divine providence in all circumstances.

translation: In the Midrash, "And you shall rejoice in all the good," there is no good except for the Torah; therefore, Moses warns Israel, "You shall surely tithe." Thus concludes the Midrash, and the question remains.
summary: The passage emphasizes the idea that true goodness is found in the Torah, as highlighted in the Midrash. It suggests that Moses warns the Israelites about the importance of tithing, indicating that their material wealth should be connected to their spiritual obligations. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that material and spiritual realms are intertwined, and that fulfilling commandments enhances one's connection to divine goodness. Ultimately, the teaching underscores the significance of integrating spiritual values into everyday life.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הגמ' שבת (דף י' ע"ב) אסור לאדם שיתן שלו' לחבירו בבית המרחץ משום שנאמר (שופטים ו') ויקרא לו ד' שלום, אלא מעתה הימנותא נמי אסור למימר בבית הכסא דכתיב האל הנאמן וכו' ותירצו התם שם גופי' לא איקרי הכי דמתרגמינן אלהא מהימנא, הכא שם גופי' איקרי שלו' דכתיב ויקרא לו ד' שלום, והקשו התוס' תימא דשלו' נמי מתרגמינן דעבד לי' שלו', וי"ל דהתם קראו שלו' על שם שהוא עושה שלום, דאי לא קראו שלו', אלא בעי למימר וכו' ד' העושה לו שלום, א"כ הול"ל ד' שלומו ע"כ תירוץ התוס'.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Gemara in Shabbat (page 10b) that it is forbidden for a person to give his friend peace in the bathhouse, as it is said (Judges 6) "And the Lord called him Peace." Therefore, it follows that it is also forbidden to say faith in the restroom, as it is written "the faithful God," etc. And they answered there that the name itself is not called this way, as we translate "Elah Mehemena," here the name itself is called peace, as it is written "And the Lord called him Peace." And the Tosafot questioned that peace is also translated as "He has made peace for me," and it can be said that there they called him peace because he makes peace, for if they had not called him peace, but rather wanted to say "the Lord who makes peace for him," it should have been said "the Lord of his peace." Therefore, this is the answer of the Tosafot.
summary: The passage discusses the prohibition against giving one's possessions to another in a bathhouse, based on the verse "And the Lord called him Shalom," highlighting the sanctity of the name "Shalom" as it signifies peace. It contrasts this with the concept of "emunah" (faithfulness), suggesting that while the name of God is associated with peace, the context of faithfulness is not deemed inappropriate in a restroom setting. The Tosefot raises a question about the translation of "Shalom," indicating that it refers to God as the one who creates peace, emphasizing the divine nature of peace. Ultimately, the text reflects on the significance of names and their implications in the context of holiness and divine attributes.

passage_content: וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א וז"ל יש לעיין בזה דגם לפי"ד התוס' שיש לחלק דהכי גבי שלו' מוכח דקראו לשמו ות' שלו', מ"מ טעמא איכא בזה, כיון דשניהם עושה ד' למה איקרי שמו שלו' טפי מנאמן, ועוד בכל הכינויים כגון רחום וחנון אמאי לא קאמרינן הכו, דהכי נמי כתיב ק"ל רחום וחנון, וי"ל בזה עפימ"ש חסד אומר יברא שהוא גומל חסדים, אמת אומר אל יברא שהוא כולו ישקר, צדק אומר יברא שהוא עושה צדקות, שלו' אומר אל יברא שהוא כולו קטטה, והשתא בכל כנויין הנמחקין כגון רחום וחנון ורב חסד וארך אפים וכו', כיון שהאדם משותף בו לעשות חסד ורחמנות וחנינות, אין שמו של הקב"ה נקרא כן. אלא אל רחום וחנון הוי כמו אלהא המרחם וחונן וכמ"ש בהאל הנאמן ושרי לאומרה בבית הכסא, משא"כ שלו' שאין מדה זו באדם כלל, ושמו ית' ב"ה מקרי שפיר שלו' ע"ש שהוא עושה שלו', וכן למדת אמת כיון שאינה באדם, חותמו של הקב"ה נקרא אמת וכו', ובתוס' פ"ק דסוטה מוכח דשלו' אינו נמחק, ומיהו לא הוזכר גבי אמת שיהא אסור לומר בביהכ"ס ושלא נמחק כמו גבי שלו', כיון דשמו ית' ב"ה גופי' לא אקרי אמת רק חותמו עכ"ל המהרש"א ז"ל
translation: The Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his commentary, and I quote: "One should ponder this, for even according to the opinion of the Tosafists, there is a distinction to be made regarding 'Shalom,' as it is evident that it is called by His name, and it is written 'Shalom.' Nevertheless, there is a reason for this, since both are doing good deeds; why is it that His name is called 'Shalom' more than 'Ne'eman'? Furthermore, regarding all the attributes such as 'Rachum' and 'Chanun,' why do we not say the same? For it is also written, 'K'l Rachum and Chanun.' It can be explained based on what is said: 'Chesed' says 'Let Him create,' for He bestows kindness; 'Emet' says 'Let Him not create,' for He is entirely false; 'Tzedek' says 'Let Him create,' for He performs acts of righteousness; 'Shalom' says 'Let Him not create,' for He is entirely strife. And now, regarding all the attributes that are erased, such as 'Rachum' and 'Chanun' and 'Rav Chesed' and 'Erech Apayim,' since a person shares in doing kindness, compassion, and grace, His name is not called by these. Rather, 'El Rachum' and 'Chanun' is like 'The God who has mercy and grants grace,' as it is said regarding 'The Faithful God' and it is permitted to say it in the restroom. In contrast, 'Shalom' is not a measure that exists in a person at all, and His name, blessed be He, is appropriately called 'Shalom' because He brings about peace. Similarly, regarding 'Emet,' since it does not exist in a person, the seal of the Holy One, blessed be He, is called 'Emet,' etc. And in Tosafot, in the first chapter of Sotah, it is evident that 'Shalom' is not erased. However, it was not mentioned regarding 'Emet' that it is forbidden to say in the synagogue and that it is not erased like 'Shalom,' since His name, blessed be He, is not called 'Emet' but rather His seal." Thus concludes the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of divine names and attributes, particularly focusing on the name "Shalom" (peace) and its unique status compared to other attributes like "Rachum" (merciful) and "Chanon" (gracious). It emphasizes that while many divine attributes can be shared with humanity, "Shalom" is distinct as it does not have a human counterpart, thus reflecting God's essence more purely. The text also highlights that "Emet" (truth) is similarly unique, as it represents God's ultimate nature, reinforcing the idea that certain divine qualities are intrinsic to God alone. The Maharsha concludes that while "Shalom" and "Emet" are not subject to erasure, they embody the true nature of God, setting them apart in theological significance.

passage_content: וק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בהפטורה לפ' תצא) כתב ע"ד המהרש"א הנ"ל וז"ל דאף לפי תירוצו היפה אף נעים נשאר הקושיא לכאורה, דמ"ש אמת משלו', ומ"ש זה נמחק וזה אינו נמחק, וזה נאמר בביהכ"ס וזה אסור לאומרו, ומ"ש דשם גופי' לא אקרי אמת, הוא גופי' קשיא כיון שהשי"ת עושה גם שניהם, ואין האדם משותף בשניהם, וכמו שהקשה הוא בעצמו בראש דבריו מ"ש שלו' מנאמן, וכל מה שטרח בו אותו צדיק ליישב הקושיא ההיא ולבסוף לא נמלט ממנה ע"כ קושיתו. וכתב ליישב דלכך אמת מהנמחקין, דלפעמים נמחק מקמי' שלו', דהיינו פעולת האמת שע"ש כך נקרא כן, והוא נדחה מקמי' עשיית השלו' וכו', ואף הקב"ה שינה מפני דרכי שלו' אצל אברהם וכו', וכיון שהפעולה נדחית לפעמים, גם השם שנצמח מהפעולה לא עדיף ולכך נמחק, משא"כ עשיית השלו' שאינה נדחית עכת"ד ז"ל, אמנם איכא להקשות על תירוצו ז"ל דמצינו דגם השלו' נדחית מקמי' האמת, וכמ"ש דהמע"ה הלא משנאיך ד' אשנא ובתקוממיך אתקוטט וגו', ואמר ראיתי בוגדים ואתקוטעה אשר אמרתך לא שמרו, והדרא קושיא מ"ט שם גופי' אקרי שלו', משא"כ אמת רק חותמו ית' אמת ואין זה שם העצם וצ"ב.
translation: And so, Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in the Haftarah for Parshat Tetzaveh), wrote according to the aforementioned Maharsha, and said that even according to his beautiful explanation, the question remains seemingly pleasant, that what is said "the truth from His name," and what is said "this is erased and this is not erased," and "this is said in the synagogue and this is forbidden to say," and what is said that the essence itself is not called truth, is itself a difficulty since the Holy One, Blessed be He, does both, and man is not a partner in both. And as he himself questioned at the beginning of his words, what is said "from the name of the faithful," and all the effort that righteous one exerted to resolve that question, in the end, he did not escape from it, thus is his question. And he wrote to resolve that therefore the truth is from the erased, for sometimes it is erased before His name, meaning the action of the truth, for which it is called so, and it is pushed aside before the action of the peace, etc., and even the Holy One, Blessed be He, changed for the ways of peace with Abraham, etc. And since the action is sometimes pushed aside, also the name that arises from the action is not superior, and therefore it is erased, whereas the action of peace is not pushed aside, thus is his holy word. However, one can challenge his explanation, for we find that also peace is pushed aside before the truth, as it is said, "For I hate you, O Lord, I hate, and with your rising I will contend," etc., and he said, "I saw traitors, and I contended, for they did not keep your word," and the question returns, why there the essence itself is called peace, whereas truth is only His seal, truth, and this is not the essence, and it is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between the concepts of "truth" and "peace" in Hasidic thought, as articulated by the author. It highlights the idea that while truth can sometimes be set aside for the sake of peace, the essence of truth remains unchangeable, as it is rooted in the Divine. The author grapples with the notion that both truth and peace can be seen as actions of God, yet questions the permanence of truth when it can be "erased" in certain contexts. Ultimately, it emphasizes the supremacy of God's truth, which is immutable, in contrast to the more flexible nature of peace.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימ"ד בגמ' (ע"ז דף ד' ע"ב) א"ר יוסף לא לוצלו אינש צלותא דמוספי בתלת שעי קמייתא דיומא, ביומא קמא דריש שתא ביחיד, דלמא כיון דמפקיד דינא דלמא מעייני' בעובדי' ודחפו לי' וכו', והקשו והא אמרת שלש ראשונות יושב הקב"ה ועוסק בתורה, (שניות יושב ודן), ותירצו איפוך, ואיבע"א לעולם לא תיפוך, ותורה דכתיב בי' אמת, דכתיב אמת קנה ואל תמכר, אין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משוה"ד, ודין דלא כתיב בי' אמת עושה הקב"ה לפנים משורת הדין, וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל דהיינו טעמא דאמרי' בפ"ק דסנהדרין (דף ו' ע"ב) משתשמע דברי בעלי דינין ואתה יודע להיכן הדין נוטה, אי אתה רשאי לעשות לפנים משורת הדין, כיון דיודע היכן הדין תורה נוטה שהוא אמת הדין, אי אתה רשאי לעשות לפנים משורת הדין עכ"ד ז"ל. נמצא לפי"ז, דמדת אמת הוא תוקף הדין ואין הקב"ה עושה בו לפנים משורת הדין ואם הקב"ה ידון בתוקף הדין ח"ו א"א לעולם להתקיים, דאין העולם מתקיים בדין כמאמז"ל, וע"כ אין הקב"ה משתמש במדה זו כשהוא ות' דן את העולם, כמבואר בגמ' הנ"ל דראשונות עוסק בתורה דכתיב בי' אמת, שניות יושב ודן.
translation: And even though it is stated in the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 4b) that Rabbi Yosef said: A person should not recite the additional prayers during the first three hours of the day, on the first day of the week, when he is alone, for perhaps since he is entrusted with the law, perhaps he will ponder over the actions and push them away, etc. And they asked: But did you not say that during the first three hours, the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and engages in Torah? (In the second three hours, He sits and judges.) And they answered: Rather the opposite, or alternatively, it should never be the opposite. And the Torah, which is written about Him, is truth, as it is written: "Acquire truth and do not sell it." The Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law, and the law that is not written about Him as truth, the Holy One, blessed be He, acts beyond the letter of the law. And the Maharsha, may his merit protect us, wrote that this is the reason we say in the first chapter of Sanhedrin (6b) that once you hear the words of the litigants and you know where the law leans, you are not permitted to act beyond the letter of the law, since you know where the law of the Torah leans, which is the truth of the law; you are not permitted to act beyond the letter of the law. Thus, it follows that according to this, the measure of truth is the strength of the law, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law. And if the Holy One, blessed be He, were to judge with the strength of the law, Heaven forbid, the world could not exist, for the world does not endure through strict judgment, as our sages have said. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, does not use this measure when He and His attribute of mercy judge the world, as is explained in the aforementioned Gemara, that during the first three hours, He engages in Torah, which is written about Him as truth, and during the second three hours, He sits and judges.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of divine judgment and the concept of truth in relation to God's actions. It emphasizes that God does not operate strictly according to the measure of justice (midat hadin), as this would render the world unsustainable. Instead, God engages in a balance of justice and mercy, particularly during the initial hours of the day when He studies Torah, which embodies truth. The text highlights that while truth is paramount, God's governance of the world incorporates compassion, allowing for a more lenient approach beyond strict justice.

passage_content: אמנם יש אופן שיוכל העולם להתקיים אף במדת הדין והאמת עפימ"ש בפר"ד (דרך צדקה דרוש א"ח) מאי דאמרי' בפ"ח דערובין (דף פ"ו) דרש ובא בר מרי ישב עולם לפני אלקים חסד ואמת מן ינצרוהו, אימתי ישב עולם לפני אלקים. בזמן שחסד ואמת מן ינצרוהו, ויובן עם מאי דאמרי' בב"ר ביום עשות ד' אלקים ארץ ושמים, בתחלה עלה במחשבה לברוא את העולם בדין, כיון שראה שאין העולם מתקיים בדין, שתף עמו מדת הרחמים וכו', ולפי"ז הוקשה לו לרבא היכי קאמר ישב עולם לפני אלקים, דהיכי משכחת לה שיתקיים ויתיישב העולם לפני אלקים שהוא מדת הדין, והא אמרינן שראה הקב"ה שאין העולם מתקיים בדין, לזה אמר רבא אימתי ישב עולם לפני אלקים, בזמן שחסד ואמת מן ינצרוהו, שאם מקיימין מצות צדקה ועושים חסד זע"ז, כח הצדקה מהפכת מדת הדין למדת הרחמים, כמ"ש ז"ל במדרש השקיפה ממעון קדשך וגו' כל השקפה שבתורה הוא לרעה וכו', חוץ מזו שהוא לטובה וכו' ללמדך שגדול כח של מתנת עניים שמהפכת מדת הרוגז למדת הרחמים, וא"כ אפי' בלא שיתוף מדת הרחמים ישב עולם לפני אלקים, לפי שע"י הצדקה אין כאן דין עכ"ד ז"ל.
translation: Indeed, there is a way for the world to exist even in the measure of judgment and truth, as it is stated in Parashat Derashot (the way of charity, Drush A"Ch) regarding what is said in chapter 8 of Eruvin (page 86), that it was taught: "And the son of Mari sat the world before God, mercy and truth shall sustain it." When does the world sit before God? At a time when mercy and truth sustain it. This can be understood in light of what is said in Bereshit Rabbah, that on the day God created the heavens and the earth, initially it was in His thought to create the world with judgment. When He saw that the world could not endure with judgment, He combined with it the attribute of mercy, etc. Therefore, it was difficult for Rava to understand how it is said that the world sits before God, for how can it be found that the world exists and is established before God, which is the attribute of judgment, when it is said that the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that the world could not endure with judgment? To this, Rava said: "When does the world sit before God? At a time when mercy and truth sustain it," for if they fulfill the commandments of charity and do kindness to one another, the power of charity transforms the attribute of judgment into the attribute of mercy, as our sages have said in the Midrash: "Look down from Your holy dwelling, etc.," that every gaze in the Torah is for evil, etc., except for this one, which is for good, etc., to teach you that the power of the gift of the poor transforms the attribute of wrath into the attribute of mercy. Therefore, even without the combination of the attribute of mercy, the world sits before God, for through charity there is no judgment. Thus concludes our sages.
summary: The passage discusses the coexistence of divine justice (Middat HaDin) and mercy (Middat HaRachamim) in the sustenance of the world. It emphasizes that while the initial intention of creation was through strict judgment, the world cannot endure solely under this principle. Instead, acts of charity and kindness can transform judgment into mercy, allowing the world to exist harmoniously before God. The text highlights the powerful role of charity in mitigating divine anger and fostering a compassionate reality.

passage_content: ואפשר להוסיף נופך על דבה"ק, דלפי פירושו אינו מתיישב עדיין המאמר כולו, חסד שואמת" מן ינצרוהו, והוא ז"ל מפרש מלת חסד לבד. שכח החסד מהפכת מדה"ד לרחמים, אולם מלת ואמת צ"ב הכוונה בו, ולדרכנו א"ש הכוונה דכשבנ"א עושים חסד זע"ז, יוכלו לזכות בדין אף במדת אמת, לפי שע"י הצדקה אין כאן דין וז"ש חסד ואמת מן ונצרוהו, שגם האמת והחסד יהיו מזומנים לנצרו (עיין פרש"י שם).
translation: It is possible to add a nuance to the holy discourse, for according to his interpretation, the entire statement is not yet settled, "kindness and truth will preserve him." He, may his memory be blessed, explains the word kindness alone. The essence of kindness transforms the attribute of judgment into mercy; however, the intention of the word truth is questionable. According to our approach, it is clear that when people do kindness to one another, they can merit a favorable judgment even in the attribute of truth, for through charity there is no judgment. And this is what is meant by "kindness and truth will preserve him," that both truth and kindness will be prepared to preserve him (see Rashi's commentary there).
summary: The passage discusses the interplay between kindness (chesed) and truth (emet) in the context of divine judgment. It emphasizes that acts of kindness among people can transform strict judgment into mercy, allowing for a favorable outcome even under the principle of truth. The author suggests that through charity, one can achieve a state where both kindness and truth are present and accessible, highlighting the importance of mutual support and compassion in spiritual life.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר אמרם ז"ל בב"ר מתחלה עלה במחשבה לבראות במדת הדין וראה שאין העולם מתקיים, והקדים מדת הרחמים ושתפה למדת הדין, וכבר הקשו המפרשים דהלא אצל הבוי"ת לא יתכן חזרה ושינוי רצון ח"ו, והעבר וההוה והעתיד הכל ברגע א' ואיך יתכן לומר מתחלה עלה במחשבה בדין, ואח"כ הקדים מדת הרחמים, ואפ"ל לדרכנו עפימ"ד בזוה"ק באורייתא ברא קוב"ה עלמא, ובתנחומא אר"פ בראשית) זש"ה ד' בחכמה יסד ארץ (משלי ג') כשברא הקב"ה את עולמו נתייעץ בתורה וברא בו את העולם, ואמרי' בגמ' דע"ז הנ"ל, תורה דכתיב בי' אמת, אין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משורת הדין, נמצא כי בתחלת הבריאה כשעלה במחשבה לפניו ית' לברוא את העולם אסתכל באורייתא והוא מדת הדין, וראתה חכמתו ית' שאין העולם יכול להתקיים בדין, והקדים מדת הרחמים וכו', שברא מדת החסד ועי"ז יתקיים העולם לפני אלקים דאין כאן דין, ואין כאן חזרה ושינוי רצון דגם תחלת המחשבה קיים, ובזה פירשו המפרשים מ"ש רש"י ז"ל ו)בפ' לך) ואברכך זה שאומרים אלקי אברהם וכו', יכול יהיו חותמין בכולן תלמוד לומר והי' ברכה בך חותמין ולא בהם, וביארו ז"ל שהבטיחו הבוי"ת כי החתימה לפועל המעשה יושלם במדתו של אאע"ה שהוא חסד, כי בדין אין העולם יכול להתקיים, ואף שתחלת הרצון בבריאה הי' בדין, אבל ע"י החסד יומתק ויתהפך לרחמים, ובזה יבוארו דברי המהרש"א ז"ל מה שכתב לחלק דשלו' שם גופי' אקרי שלו' משא"כ אמת שם גופי' לא אקרי הכי רק חותמו, ויובן לדרכנו דאמת היינו דין ואין הקב"ה עושה בו לפנים משורת הדין, וע"כ שם גופי' לא אקרי הכי ע"ש פעולותיו, שאין העולם מתקיים בו, אבל חותמו נקרא אמת כי חותמו ית' תסד ועל ידו נמתק הדין ויכול להתנהג במדת האמת והבן,
translation: And this will clarify their statement, may their memory be blessed, in Bereshit Rabbah: At first, it arose in His thought to create the world with the attribute of judgment, and He saw that the world could not endure, so He preceded the attribute of mercy and combined it with the attribute of judgment. The commentators have already questioned how it is possible that in the case of the Creator, there cannot be a reversal or change of will, Heaven forbid, for the past, present, and future are all in one moment. How can it be said that at first, it arose in His thought regarding judgment, and afterwards He preceded the attribute of mercy? One could say according to our path, as it is explained in the Zohar, "With the Torah, the Holy One, blessed be He, created the world," and in the Tanchuma on the verse "In the beginning" (Genesis), as it is written, "The Lord by wisdom founded the earth" (Proverbs 3:19). When the Holy One, blessed be He, created His world, He consulted the Torah and created the world through it. And it is stated in the Gemara in Avodah Zarah, that the Torah is written with the letter "Yud" which signifies truth; the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law. It follows that at the beginning of creation, when it arose in His thought to create the world, He looked into the Torah, which is the attribute of judgment, and His wisdom saw that the world could not endure with judgment alone. Therefore, He preceded the attribute of mercy, etc., and created the attribute of kindness, and through this, the world can endure before God, for there is no judgment here, and there is no reversal or change of will, for even the initial thought remains intact. In this, the commentators explain what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in Parashat Lech Lecha: "And I will bless you," this refers to the one who says, "The God of Abraham," etc. It could be that they would conclude with all of them, therefore it is stated, "And the blessing will be in you," they conclude and not in them. And they explained, may their memory be blessed, that He promised the Creator that the conclusion of the action will be completed with the attribute of our father Abraham, which is kindness, for with judgment, the world cannot endure. And although the initial will in creation was with judgment, through kindness it will be sweetened and transformed into mercy. And this will clarify the words of the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, regarding what he wrote to differentiate between "truth" and "peace." There, "truth" is not called so, only His seal, and it will be understood according to our path that "truth" means judgment, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law. Therefore, "truth" is not called so regarding His actions, for the world cannot endure in it, but His seal is called "truth" because His seal is established, and through it, the judgment is sweetened, and He can conduct Himself with the attribute of truth. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the initial divine intention to create the world through the attribute of justice (Middat HaDin), which was deemed unsustainable. Consequently, God introduced the attribute of mercy (Middat HaRachamim) to balance justice, allowing for the world's existence. This reflects the Hasidic belief that while divine will may initially align with strict justice, it ultimately transforms through mercy and kindness, ensuring the world's continuity. The text emphasizes that God's actions are rooted in the Torah, which embodies truth and justice, yet His ultimate governance is through mercy, enabling a harmonious existence.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל ושמחת בכל טוב אין טוב אלא תורה לפיכך משה מזהיר את ישראל עשר תעשר, עפימ"ד בתנדב"א (פי"ח) ובילקוט איכה רמז י)תתרל"ד) עה"כ נוכח פני ד', מכאן אמרו כל ת"ח שיושב בינו לבין עצמו וקורא ושונה, כביכול הקב"ה יושב ושונה עמו עכ"ד המדרש, והנה לפי"ז יוכל להתעורר מדת הדין ח"ו, כמ"ש בגמ' דר"ה הנ"ל דבג' ראשונות יושב הקב"ה ועוסק בתורה, ואין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משוה"ד, לפיכך משה מזהיר את ישראל עשר תעשר דגדול מתנות עניים שמהפך מדת הדין לרחמים ואין כאן דין.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash, and joy in all good—there is no good but the Torah. Therefore, Moses warns Israel, "You shall surely tithe." According to the interpretation of the Midrash (Chapter 18) and in the Yalkut Eicha (Remez 574), regarding the verse "Before the face of the Lord," from here they said that any Torah scholar who sits alone and studies and reviews, as if the Holy One, blessed be He, is sitting and studying with him. Thus far the Midrash. And behold, according to this, the attribute of judgment could be aroused, Heaven forbid, as it is stated in the Gemara in Rosh Hashanah, that in the first three hours the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and engages in Torah, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the measure of judgment. Therefore, Moses warns Israel, "You shall surely tithe," for great is the gift to the poor, which transforms the attribute of judgment into mercy, and there is no judgment here.
summary: The passage emphasizes the centrality of Torah in achieving true joy, as indicated by the phrase "אין טוב אלא תורה." It highlights the importance of Torah study, suggesting that when a scholar engages in learning, it is as if God is learning with him, which can mitigate the severity of divine judgment. This is further illustrated by Moses' warning to the Israelites to give tithes, as charitable acts can transform judgment into mercy, underscoring the power of generosity in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: ובזה יובן מאמה"כ באספך את תבואת הארץ תחוגו חג לה', ומה שאמרו דאסיפת התבואות הוא זמן שמחה, דהנה כשישראל השומר תומ"צ מאסף תבואתו ופירותיו ויינו ושמנו, ה"ה מקיים מצות פאה לקט שכחה פרט ועוללות תרומה ומעשרות, ואמחז"ל גדול כח מתנות עניים שמהפך מדת הדין לרחמים, וחוץ מזה דעתו כשהולך לעסקיו שאם יעזור לו השי"ת וירויח יתן להחזקת ת"ח ותשב"ר, ובמחשבה זו הלא הוא מקדים מדת החסד ומהפך מדת הרוגז לרחמים, ועל כן אמרו ז"ל שבזמן אסיפת התבואות הוא זמן שמחה, ולא התבואה והיין הוא סיבת השמחה, כ"א מה שנתבטל מדת הדין ונתהפך מדת הרוגז ואין לך שמחה בעולם גדולה מזו, וז"ש הכתוב באספכם תבואת הארץ תחוגו את חג ד' וגו', דהנה בר"ה ויוכ"פ המה ימי דין ואין השמחה בשלימות, כי יראים וחרדים אנחנו מחרדת הדין, אבל בחג הסוכות עת אסיפת התבואות, נמשך עי"ז כח החסד כנ"ל ונתבטל כח הדין, וע"כ הוא זמן שמחה ואז מביא בכורים וקורא כל הפרשה השקיפה ממעון קדשך וגו' שישקיף ד' לטובה על ישראל, כאמרז"ל דגדול כח מתנות עניים.
translation: And with this, it will be understood from the verse, "When you gather the harvest of your land, you shall celebrate a festival for the Lord," and what they said that the gathering of the harvest is a time of joy. Behold, when Israel, who observes the Torah and commandments, gathers his harvest, fruits, wine, and oil, he is fulfilling the commandments of Pe'ah, Leket, Shikcha, and the gifts of the poor, and our Sages have said that the power of the gifts to the poor transforms the attribute of judgment into mercy. Furthermore, his intention when he goes about his business is that if the Holy One, Blessed be He, helps him and he profits, he will give to support Torah scholars and the poor. With this thought, he is indeed prioritizing the attribute of kindness and transforming the attribute of anger into mercy. Therefore, our Sages said that during the time of gathering the harvest is a time of joy, and it is not the harvest and wine that are the cause of joy, but rather the nullification of the attribute of judgment and the transformation of the attribute of anger. There is no greater joy in the world than this. And this is what the verse means, "When you gather the harvest of your land, you shall celebrate the festival of the Lord," for behold, on Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, these are days of judgment, and joy is not complete, for we are fearful and anxious about the dread of judgment. But during the festival of Sukkot, the time of gathering the harvest, the power of kindness is drawn down, as mentioned, and the power of judgment is nullified. Therefore, it is a time of joy, and then he brings the first fruits and recites the entire passage, "Look down from Your holy dwelling," that the Lord should look favorably upon Israel, as our Sages have said that the power of the gifts to the poor is great.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the gathering of the harvest is a time of joy because it reflects the fulfillment of mitzvot such as leaving the corners of the field for the poor and giving tithes. This act transforms the attribute of judgment into one of mercy, highlighting the power of charity to shift divine decrees. Unlike the days of Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, which are marked by fear of judgment, the festival of Sukkot, coinciding with the harvest, embodies a time of divine favor and joy. Ultimately, the joy stems not from the physical bounty itself, but from the elevation of kindness and the nullification of harsh judgments.

passage_content: תמצית הדברים דהחזקת התורה הוא קיום כל העולם כולו, דעל ידו נמתק מדת הדין כנ"ל, ואפשר דלטובת ותועלת ישראל מסבב הבוי"ת הנהגת העולם בדרך זה, שלהשפעת התורה יהי' נצרך חסד מצד המחזיקים, דלכאורה הרי תכלית העולם הוא התוה"ק, ובפרט תורתן של תשב"ר הבל שאין בו חטא, והבוי"ת יש לו די והותר להספיק כל צרכם מבלי שיצטרכו לחסד בנ"א, אמנם בהכרח שיקדים מדת החסד לכח התורה, וזהו צורך לקיום התורה חוץ מתועלת הגשמי נוסף עליו תועלת הרוחני, דע"י מדת החסד יוכל העולם להתקיים בכח התורה כנ"ל, דתוה"ק כתיב בי' אמת ואין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משוה"ד, וע"י שמקדימין מדת החסד נתקיים העולם בכח התוה"ק, נמצא דחסד ואמת מקושרים המה, וא"א שיתנהג העולם במדת האמת שהוא דין, כ"א שיקדים אלי' מדת החסד, אמנם גם להשיג החסד ישתמש האדם רק במדת האמת, שיהי' חסד של אמת, ובעוה"ר עכשיו הוא להיפך. דכשצרוכים לחסדם של המחזיקים אסור לגלות האמת, ובשפלות המצב של דורנו אין בנמצא חסד של אמת, ואני אומר הקדמה חסד ואמת, כי צריך אני לחסד, אבל רק עם מדת האמת ולא אמנע מלגלות האמת, וזהו אסון הדור בעוה"ר שאין רוצים לגלות האמת.
translation: The essence of the matter is that the preservation of the Torah is the sustenance of the entire world, for through it the attribute of judgment is sweetened, as mentioned above. It is possible that for the benefit and advantage of Israel, the governance of the world is arranged in this manner, that the influence of the Torah requires kindness from those who uphold it. Seemingly, the purpose of the world is the Torah, especially the Torah of the Tzaddikim, which has no sin. The Tzaddik has more than enough to fulfill all their needs without requiring the kindness of human beings. However, it is necessary that the attribute of kindness precedes the power of the Torah. This is essential for the existence of the Torah, aside from the physical benefit, there is an additional spiritual benefit, for through the attribute of kindness, the world can exist through the power of the Torah, as mentioned above. It is written about the Torah that it is truth, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the measure of justice. By prioritizing the attribute of kindness, the world is sustained through the power of the Torah. Thus, kindness and truth are interconnected, and it is impossible for the world to be governed by the attribute of truth, which is judgment, unless it is preceded by the attribute of kindness. However, to attain kindness, a person must only use the attribute of truth, so that it will be a kindness of truth. In our current situation, it is the opposite. When they require the kindness of those who uphold the Torah, it is forbidden to reveal the truth, and in the lowly state of our generation, there is no kindness of truth to be found. I say an introduction of kindness and truth, for I need kindness, but only with the attribute of truth, and I will not refrain from revealing the truth. This is the tragedy of the generation in our times, that they do not wish to reveal the truth.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the preservation of the Torah is essential for the existence of the entire world, as it mitigates the severity of divine judgment. It highlights the necessity of combining the attributes of kindness (chesed) and truth (emet) for the world to function properly, suggesting that while the ultimate purpose is the Torah, the practice of kindness must precede it. The author notes a troubling reality in the current generation, where true kindness is often obscured by the need to conceal the truth, leading to a lack of genuine kindness. Ultimately, the text calls for a balance between kindness and truth, asserting that one must not shy away from revealing the truth, even in the face of needing kindness.

passage_content: נחזור לראש דברינו לפרש מאמה"כ שמח זבולן בצאתך וגו', ומ"ט הקדימו הכתוב לזבולן לפני יששכר, והרי התוה"ק מוקדם לכל דבר. ויתבאר לדרכנו דהרי זבולן ע"י שמחזיק בתורתו של יששכר, ה"ה מקדים מדת החסד בעולם, ועי"ז נמתק כח הדין ומביא שמחה לעולם, ויתקיים העולם בכח התורה, ויכולין עי"ז ללמוד תורה מתוך שמחה כי אין כאן דין כלל וכבר נתהפך לרחמים, ומה"ט הקדימו הכתוב לזבולן מידה כנגד מידה על שהוא מקדים עדת הרחמים למדת הדין, כמו שהקדימו הקדוש ברוך הוא בבריאת העולם, וזה שאמר שמח זבולן בצאתך, שגורם שמחה בעולם על ידי מעשיו ועל ידי זה יששכר באהליך שנתקיים העולם בכח התורה ואין כאן דין, וז"ש הכתוב צדק ומשפע מכון כסאך, חסד ואמת יקדמו פניך, שע"י שיקדמו פניך במדת החסד, יתקיים העולם גם במשפט כי מתבטל מדת הדין ואז יתקיים גם מדת האמת כי אין כאן דין כלל.
translation: We will return to the beginning of our discussion to explain the verse, "Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out," etc. And why does the text precede Zebulun before Issachar? The Torah is always prior to everything. It can be explained according to our path that Zebulun, by supporting the Torah of Issachar, is indeed advancing the attribute of kindness in the world. Through this, the power of judgment is sweetened, bringing joy to the world, and the world is sustained by the strength of the Torah. This allows for the study of Torah with joy, as there is no judgment here, and it has already been transformed into mercy. For this reason, the text precedes Zebulun measure for measure, for he advances the congregation of mercy over the attribute of judgment, just as the Holy One, blessed be He, preceded it in the creation of the world. This is what is meant by "Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out," for he causes joy in the world through his actions, and through this, Issachar dwells in your tents, where the world is sustained by the strength of the Torah, and there is no judgment here. This is what the verse means when it says, "Righteousness and justice are the foundation of Your throne; kindness and truth go before Your face," that by advancing Your face with the attribute of kindness, the world will also be sustained in judgment, for the attribute of judgment is nullified, and then the attribute of truth will also be established, for there is no judgment here at all.
summary: The passage discusses the precedence of the tribe of Zebulun over Issachar, emphasizing that Zebulun's support of Issachar's Torah study embodies the attribute of kindness, which mitigates the harshness of judgment in the world. This dynamic allows for joy and the ability to learn Torah without the constraints of strict judgment, transforming it into mercy. The text highlights that by prioritizing kindness, the world can sustain itself through Torah, leading to a harmonious existence where truth prevails without the severity of law. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound connection between acts of kindness and the maintenance of divine justice and truth in the world.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל בענין הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר עוד במאמר הכתוב ועתה שני בניך הנולדים לך בארץ מצרים עד באי עליך מצרימה לי הם אפרים ומנשה כראובן ושמעון וגו' ומולדתך אשר הולדת וגו' אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, פרש"י ז"ל ומולדתך אשר הולדת אם תוליד עוד וכו', ומלת אשר יתפרש כמו אם, וכ"כ הרא"ם ז"ל שהוא מאמר מסופק, ולא כמשמעו שהוא מורה על הודאי, דאם היו לו בנים עוד, הי' מביא גם אותם לאביו כדי לברכם כמו שהביא את אפרים ומנשה עכת"ד המזרחי, ופירושו צ"ב חדא דלא מצינו אשר במקום אם והרא"ם ז"ל בעצמו נדחק בזה עיי"ש. ועוד דאם יהי' כוונת הכתוב אם תוליד עוד, מדוע אמר הולדת בלשון עבר והול"ל אשר תוליד, ועו"ק דהרי כל דבריו של יע"א בנבואה נאמרו, ואיך אמרה הנבואה דברים מסופקים וספיקא קמי שמיא ליכא, ואיך יכתוב התוה"ק דבר שלא הי', כי לא מצינו שהזכיר הכתוב בשום מקום שהוליד בנים עוד, והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב שהי' ליוסף בנים אחרים ולא זכרם הכתוב, והקשה עליו האברבנאל דראוי שיזכורם הכתוב אילו הי' לו, כמו שהזכיר ער ואונן וסרח בת אשר וכל בניו ובני בניו.
translation: In another way, one could say regarding the aforementioned matter, to preface by noting further in the written article: "And now your two sons, who were born to you in the land of Egypt, until I come to you in Egypt, they are mine, Ephraim and Manasseh, like Reuben and Simeon, etc., and your birthplace, which you gave birth to, etc., their brothers will be called in their inheritance." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: "And your birthplace, which you gave birth to, if you will give birth again, etc.," and the word "which" is to be interpreted like "if." So too, the Ra'ahm, of blessed memory, states that it is a statement of uncertainty, and not as it seems, which indicates certainty. For if he had more sons, he would have brought them to his father to bless them, just as he brought Ephraim and Manasseh, thus said the Mizrachi. However, his explanation is questionable: first, we do not find "which" in the place of "if," and the Ra'ahm, of blessed memory, himself is forced in this matter, as seen there. Furthermore, if the intent of the text is "if you will give birth again," why did it say "which you gave birth" in the past tense? It should have said "which you will give birth." Additionally, all of the words of the prophet were said in prophecy, and how could the prophecy say uncertain things, for there is no uncertainty before Heaven? And how could the Holy Torah write something that did not happen? For we do not find that the text mentioned anywhere that he had more sons. And Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote that Joseph had other sons, but the text did not mention them, and Abarbanel challenged him, saying that it would be appropriate for the text to mention them if he had them, just as it mentioned Er and Onan and Serach the daughter of Asher and all his sons and the sons of his sons.
summary: The passage discusses the biblical verse regarding Joseph's sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, and the implications of the term "אשר" (which can mean "if") in the context of potential additional children. It raises questions about the certainty of prophetic statements and the nature of divine communication, suggesting that the Torah does not express uncertainty. The text emphasizes the importance of lineage and inheritance in Jewish tradition, reflecting on the significance of familial blessings and the continuity of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ב) גם קשה דמאמר לך יהיו מיותר, ופשיטא דלך יהיו וכוונת המאמר לומר דלא והא להם שם בשבעים לענין הנחלה, ולא יקראו שבעים אלא אלו, וכבר אמור במאמר ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, אבל זה דלך יהיו מאי למימרא וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: B) It is also difficult that the statement "to you shall be" is superfluous, and it is obvious that "to you shall be" refers to the intent of the statement that they do not have a share there in the seventy regarding inheritance, and they are not called seventy except for these. And it has already been stated in the saying "after their brothers they shall be called in their inheritance," but what is the meaning of "to you shall be," and the intention behind this is to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "לך יהיו" (they shall be yours) in relation to the inheritance of the Jewish people, emphasizing that it is not merely a redundant statement. It highlights the unique connection between the Jewish people and their inheritance, suggesting that the term "שבעים" (seventy) specifically refers to those who are part of this divine legacy. The inquiry into the meaning of "לך יהיו" reflects a deeper understanding of the relationship between the individual and the collective, as well as the spiritual implications of inheritance within the Hasidic framework.

passage_content: ג) ואני בבואי מפדן מתה עלי רחל וגו', פרש"י ז"ל ואע"פ שאני מעריח עליך בקבורתי ולא כך עשיתי לאמך, דע לך שעפ"י הדיבור קברתיה שם שתהא לעזרה לבניה וכו', והקשו המפרשים דהי' ראוי שיזכיר יע"א ההתנצלות הזאת בשעה שצוהו ונשאתני ממצרים וקברתני בקבורתם, ומדוע המתין עד הכא, ואיך יתקשר אל המאמר ומולדתך אשר הולדת הנסמך אליו.
translation: 3) And I, when I came from Padan, Rachel died upon me, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that although I am delaying you with my burial, and I did not do so with your mother, know that according to the word, I buried her there so that she would be a help to her children, etc. The commentators question why it was fitting for him to mention this excuse at the time when he commanded him, "And you shall carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their burial place," and why he waited until now, and how it connects to the statement "and your birthplace, which gave birth to you," to which it is linked.
summary: בקטע זה מדבר יעקב על מותו של רחל ועל הקבורה שלה בדרך מיוחדת, המיועדת להיות לעזרה לבניה. הוא מתנצל על כך שלא קבר אותה במקום שבו קבר את אמו, ומדגיש את החשיבות של הקבורה של רחל במובן רוחני. המפרשים שואלים מדוע יעקב לא הבהיר את התנצלותו קודם לכן, מה שמעורר שאלות על הקשר בין המילים שלו לבין המורשת המשפחתית. הקטע מדגיש את הקשר העמוק בין משפחה, זיכרון ותפקידים רוחניים בחיי הדורות הבאים.

passage_content: ד) להלן בפרשה ועיני ישראל כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות וגו', והקשה הראב"ע דלעיל אמר וירא ישראל את בני יוסף, ואיך יאמר לא יוכל לראות, רק טעמו לא יוכל לראות היטב שיכירם עכ"ד. אולם קשה ממ"ש להלן וישלח ישראל את ימינו על ראש אפרים והוא הצעיר. ואת שמאלו על ראש מנשה שכל את ידיו כי מנשה הבכור, הרי שידע להכירם, וצ"ב הכוונה במ"ש לא יוכל לראות.
translation: D) Here in the section, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy with age, so that he could not see," the Ra'avad questions, for earlier it is stated, "And Israel saw the sons of Joseph," and how can it be said that he could not see? Rather, his understanding was that he could not see them well enough to recognize them, thus he concluded. However, it is difficult regarding what is stated later, "And Israel sent his right hand upon the head of Ephraim, who was the younger, and his left hand upon the head of Manasseh," even though he crossed his hands, for Manasseh was the firstborn. This indicates that he knew how to recognize them, and the intention of the phrase "could not see" remains unclear.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author addresses the apparent contradiction in the biblical text regarding Jacob's ability to recognize his grandsons, Ephraim and Manasseh. While Jacob initially seems unable to see them clearly due to his old age, he later demonstrates awareness by blessing them in a specific order. This highlights the Hasidic concept of spiritual perception, suggesting that true understanding transcends physical sight and is rooted in deeper, divine insight. The discussion emphasizes the complexity of recognizing spiritual truths, even amidst physical limitations.

passage_content: ה) גם צ"ב כפל הלשון כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות, ויספיק שיאמר לא יוכל לראות מזוקן, ומה תוסיף הודעה זו שכבדו וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: 5) It is also questioned why the phrase is repeated, "He cannot see because of his old age," and it would suffice to say "He cannot see because of his old age." What does this additional statement add, and what is the intention behind the repetition?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות," emphasizing the redundancy in the expression. It suggests that the repetition serves to deepen the understanding of the concept of honor and the limitations of perception associated with age. passage_content: ו) במסכת יומא (כ"ח ע"ב) א"ר חמא ב"ר חנינא מימיהן של אבותינו לא פסקה ישיבה מהם וכו', אברהם זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' שנא' ואברהם זקן בא בימים, יצחק אבינו זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' שנאמר ויהי כי זקן יצחק. יעקב אבינו זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' שנא' ועיני ישראל כבדו מזוקן עכ"ד הגמ', ולכאורה לפי דרשתם ז"ל צ"ב קישור הכתוב כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות, כי מלת זוקן דרשו ז"ל שהי' זקן ויושב בישיבה, ומ"ע כבדו ולא יוכל לראות.
translation: In the tractate Yoma (28b), Rabbi Chama bar Chanina said: "From the days of our forefathers, the study of Torah did not cease from them," etc. Abraham was old and sitting in the study hall, as it is stated, "And Abraham was old, coming with days." Our father Isaac was old and sitting in the study hall, as it is stated, "And it came to pass that when Isaac was old." Our father Jacob was old and sitting in the study hall, as it is stated, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy with age." Thus far the Gemara. And seemingly, according to their interpretation, it is difficult to connect the verse "were heavy with age" to "could not see," for the term "age" they interpreted that he was old and sitting in the study hall, and it is a positive commandment that "he was heavy" and "could not see."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author highlights the significance of the patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—being described as "old" and "sitting in the study hall," emphasizing their dedication to Torah study throughout their lives. The reference to Jacob's eyes being "heavy with age" raises a theological question about the relationship between aging and spiritual insight. The text suggests that true wisdom and understanding come from a life devoted to learning, even as physical sight may diminish with age. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the enduring value of spiritual pursuits over physical limitations.

passage_content: ז) המלאך הגואל אתו מכל רע יברך את הנערים וגו', כבר דקדקנו לעיל מ"ט קראם נערים וכבר היו גדולים, גם הול"ל יברך אתכם בלשון נוכח שהרי עמדו אצלו למול פניו.
translation: The angel who redeems him from all evil shall bless the youths, etc. We have already noted above that he called them youths even though they were grown, and it should have said "He shall bless you" in the second person, since they stood before him face to face.
summary: המלאך הגואל מברך את הנערים, למרות שכבר היו גדולים, מה שמצביע על כך שהברכה נובעת מהותם הפנימית ולא מגילם החיצוני. השימוש בלשון "נערים" מדגיש את התחדשותם הרוחנית והיכולת שלהם להתחבר למדרגות גבוהות של קדושה. בנוסף, השימוש בלשון נוכח היה יכול להדגיש את קרבתם למלאך, אך הבחירה בלשון זכר מעידה על עומק הקשר הרוחני וההכרה במעלתם הפנימית.

passage_content: ח) ויקרא בהם שמי פי' האבן עזרא כי הנה כל בית ישראל יקראו אפרים עכ"ל. ומבואר כן בזוה"ק דאפרים על שמא דישראל אקרי, מנלן דכתיב (יחזקאל ל"ז) בן אדם העצמות האלה כל בית ישראל המה וכו' עיי"ש. אמנם הקשה הרמב"ן ז"ל על פי' הראב"ע כי הכתוב אמר ויקרא שבהם שמי, והנה לא נקראו על שם מנשה, גם צ"ב להלן בפסוק בך יברך ישראל לאמר ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, ולכאורה הול"ל בכם יברך ישראל, אחר שהזכיר שניהם אפרים ומנשה.
translation: (8) "And He will call in them My name." The explanation of the Ibn Ezra is that behold, all the House of Israel will be called Ephraim, thus far his words. And it is clarified so in the Zohar that Ephraim is called by the name of Israel, from where do we know this? It is written (Ezekiel 37) "Son of man, these bones are the whole House of Israel," etc. However, the Ramban, of blessed memory, challenged the explanation of the Ibn Ezra because the verse says "And He will call in them My name," and behold, they are not called after Manasseh. It is also difficult later in the verse "In you shall Israel bless, saying, 'May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh,'" and seemingly it should have said "In you shall Israel bless," after mentioning both Ephraim and Manasseh.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the names Ephraim and Manasseh in relation to the identity of the Jewish people, as highlighted by the Zohar and the commentary of the Ibn Ezra. It emphasizes that all of Israel is referred to as Ephraim, reflecting a deeper spiritual connection to the collective identity of the Jewish nation. The Ramban raises questions about this interpretation, particularly regarding the phrasing in the blessings that mention both Ephraim and Manasseh, suggesting a need for clarity in their roles and significance. Ultimately, the text underscores the unity of Israel through the lens of these two tribes, revealing profound theological insights into the nature of Jewish identity and blessing.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי החיד"א זלל"ה (הובא לעיל) וישם את אפרים לפני מנשה, להורות דתלמיד גדול, דמצינו זאפרים הי' רגיל לפני יעקב בתלמוד, ומנשה הי' הממונה על הבית ומחזיק ידי לומדי תורה, ועל כן וישם את אפרים לפני מנשה לרמוז בזה כו התלמיד חכם גדול בבחינתו מהמחזיק עכ"ד החיד"א זלל"ה. אמנם כבר הבאנו לעיל מתשו' בית שלמה (חלק יור"ד סי' צ"ד) דישנם סתורות ופלוגתא בדברי רז"ל בענין זה, דבקצת מקומות מבואר בדבריהם ז"ל דהמחזיק והת"ח בחינתם ומעלתם שווים המה, ומדברי הזוה"ק משמע דמעלת המחזיק עדיפא והקדימו הכתוב לזבולן בברכאן, על דאפיק פתא מפומי' ויהיב לפומי' דיששכר וכו', אולם בגמ' ברכות (דף ל"ד) אמרו ז"ל כל הנביאים לא נתנבאו אלא לעושי פרגמטיא לת"ח ולמהנה ת"ח מנכסיו וכו', אבל ת"ח עצמן עון לא ראתה אלקים זולתך, הרי דמעלת הת"ח עדיפא ויתירה פי כמה ממעלת המחזיק, עיין בדברנו לעיל (בדרוש הקדום) מה שבארנו בישוב הסתירות ולהשוות המאמרים דלא פליגי.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will precede with the words of the Chida, may his memory be a blessing (as mentioned above), "And he placed Ephraim before Manasseh," to indicate that a great scholar, for we find that Ephraim was accustomed to be before Jacob in the Talmud, and Manasseh was the one in charge of the household and supported the hands of those who study Torah. Therefore, "And he placed Ephraim before Manasseh" hints that the great Torah scholar is superior in his standing compared to the supporter, thus concludes the Chida, may his memory be a blessing. However, we have already brought above from the response of the Beit Shlomo (part Yoreh De'ah, section 94) that there are contradictions and disputes in the words of our Sages regarding this matter, for in some places it is explained in their words that the standing and merit of the supporter and the Torah scholar are equal. And from the words of the Zohar, it seems that the merit of the supporter is greater, and the verse precedes Zebulun in their blessings, for he brings out bread from his mouth and gives it to the mouth of Issachar, etc. However, in the Gemara Berakhot (34a), our Sages said that all the prophets prophesied only for those who engage in practical matters for the Torah scholar and to benefit the Torah scholar from their possessions, etc. But the Torah scholars themselves, "Sin has not been seen, O God, except for You," thus the merit of the Torah scholar is far superior and greater by many times than the merit of the supporter. Refer to our discussion above (in the earlier discourse) where we explained the resolution of the contradictions and the comparison of the statements that they do not disagree.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the roles of a Torah scholar (תלמיד חכם) and a supporter of Torah study (מחזיק), as illustrated by the biblical placement of Ephraim before Manasseh. It highlights differing opinions among rabbinic sources regarding their respective merits, with some suggesting equality and others indicating that the supporter holds a higher status. However, the author ultimately concludes that the Torah scholar's merit is significantly greater, emphasizing the importance of both roles in the spiritual and communal life of the Jewish people.

passage_content: וכעת נל"פ באופן אחר, דהנה באמת לא אמרו חז"ל שהמחזיק גדול במעלתו מהת"ח, כי אם שהקדימו הכתוב לברכה לפי שהוא הגורם לתורתו של יששכר, שלולי זבולן לא הי' יששכר יכול לעסוק בתורה, אבל אה"נ שמעלת הת"ח גדלה ממעלתו, דת"ח עצמן עון לא ראתה אלקים זולתך וגם הנביאים לא השיגו שכחו ומעלתו בעוה"ב כמבואר בפסוק, ומפורש כן במד"ר פ' קדושים (כ"ה סי' א') ר' הונא ור' ירמי' אמרו בש"ר חייא בר אבא עתיד הקב"ה לעשות צל וחופות לבעלי המצות אצל בני תורה בגן עדן וכו' שנא' כי בצל החכמה בצל הכסף וכו', ודכוותה שמח זבולן בצאתך ויששכר באהליך, ולא יששכר גדול הי' מזבולן, אלא ע"ו שהי' זבולן מפרש מיישוב ועוסק בפרגמעיא, ובא ונותן לתוך פיו של יששכר וכו' לפיכך נקרא הפסוק על שמו שנא' שמח זבולן בצאתך וגו' פי' שהקדימו הכתוב וכן אמרו בזוה"ק שהקדימו הכתוב לזבולן בברכאן, אבל לענין המעלה והחשיבות איכא למימר דיששכר עדיף, אלא דזבולן מוקדם לברכה, וכן מוכח ממ"ש עתיד הקב"ה לעשות צל וחופות לבעלי המצות אצל בנו תורה וכו', ומי נתלה במי, הוי אומר הקטן נתלה בגדול, הרי דמעלת הת"ח עדיפא, אמנם כי כן ראוי להבין מ"ט הקדימו הכתוב להמחזיק, והקדמה זו מה טיבה ותועלתה.
translation: And now we will explain in another way, for behold, the sages did not say that the one who supports is greater in his merit than the Torah scholar, but rather that the scripture precedes the blessing for he is the cause of the Torah of Issachar, for without Zebulun, Issachar would not have been able to engage in Torah. However, it is true that the merit of the Torah scholar is greater than his merit, for the Torah scholars themselves have not seen sin, O God, except You, and the prophets did not grasp his strength and merit in the World to Come, as is explained in the verse. And it is explicitly stated thus in the Midrash, Parashat Kedoshim (25:1), Rabbi Huna and Rabbi Yirmiyah said in the name of Rabbi Chiya bar Abba that the Holy One, blessed be He, will make shade and canopies for those who perform commandments alongside the sons of Torah in the Garden of Eden, etc., as it is said, "For in the shade of wisdom is the shade of silver," etc. And similarly, Zebulun rejoices in your going out, and Issachar in your tents, and Issachar was not greater than Zebulun, but rather because Zebulun was engaged in commerce and occupied in trade, and he came and put into the mouth of Issachar, etc. Therefore, the verse is called by his name, as it is said, "Zebulun rejoices in your going out," meaning that the scripture precedes him, and so it is said in the Zohar that the scripture precedes Zebulun in their blessings. But regarding the merit and importance, one can say that Issachar is preferred, yet Zebulun is earlier in the blessing. And it is also evident from what is said that the Holy One, blessed be He, will make shade and canopies for those who perform commandments alongside the sons of Torah, etc. And who is dependent on whom? One must say that the smaller one is dependent on the greater one; thus, the merit of the Torah scholar is superior. However, it is indeed appropriate to understand why the scripture precedes the supporter, and what is the nature and benefit of this precedence.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the Torah scholar (Talmid Chacham) and the supporter of Torah study (Zevulun), emphasizing that while Zevulun is honored for enabling Yissachar's Torah study, the Talmid Chacham holds a greater spiritual stature. It highlights that the merit of supporting Torah study is significant, yet the ultimate value lies in the Torah itself, as indicated by the future rewards in the World to Come for those who fulfill commandments. The text underscores the importance of both roles, with Zevulun's precedence in blessings serving to illustrate the interconnectedness of their contributions to the Torah.

passage_content:
והנ"ל בביאור הענין עפומ"ד בזוה"ק דהמחזיק ת"ח נוחל ב' עולמות ועליו נאמר הון ועושר בביתו בעוה"ז, וצדקתו עומדת לעד לבוא בשכרו לעוה"ב, והנה הת"ח עצמו העוסק בתורה אינו בא בשכרו מצד הדין בעוה"ז, דהרי שכר מצוה בהאי עלמא ליכא, וכל שכרו שמור לעוה"ב, משא"כ המחזיק ת"ח יקבל שכרו גם בעוה"ז, והוא עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בר"פ אלו דברים (פאה פ"א) וז"ל כשיעשה האדם המצות המיוחדות לנפשו, מה שיש בינו ובין בוראו, תחשב לו לצדקה ויגמלהו הקב"ה עלי' לעוה"ב, וכשיעשה האדם המצות התלויות בתועלת בנ"א זה עם זה, כמו"כ תחשב לו לצדקה לעוה"ב, ויקבל שכרו גם בעוה"ז, וכל המצות שבין אדם לחבירו נכנסות בגמ"ח עיוש"ד. והנה מעיקרא דדינא אין לו לת"ח העוסק בתורה כ"א שכר עוה"ב, ולהמחזיק אף שכר עוה"ז, אמנם לפי שנעשין שותפין כיששכר וזבולן, הרי העוסק בתורה מזכהו להמחזיק לזכות על ידו גם לשכר עוה"ב, וכמו"כ מגיע אף לת"ח 
העוסק בתורה שכר עוה"ז כמו שיקבל המחזיק, שהרי הם שותפין וחלק כחלק יאכלו, נמצא שע"י השותפות מגיע לכל א' חלקו בכפלים בעוה"ז ובעוה"ב, ולא ינוכה בשביל זה מחלק חבירו כלום, אלא כל אחד יקבל שכרו משלם וכמו"כ נותן הקב"ה לחבירו השותף כחלקו וכמידתו, ולא יחסר ולא יגרע מחלקו כלום. כו הבוי"ת יש לו די לשלם לכ"א.
translation: And the above is explained in the matter according to the words of the Zohar that one who supports a Torah scholar inherits two worlds, and of him it is said, "Wealth and riches are in his house" in this world, and "His righteousness endures forever" to come in the World to Come. And behold, the Torah scholar himself who engages in Torah does not receive his reward according to the law in this world, for the reward for a mitzvah in this world is not present, and all his reward is reserved for the World to Come. In contrast, the one who supports a Torah scholar will receive his reward also in this world. This is in accordance with what the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, says in the chapter "These are the things" (Peah 1:1), that when a person performs the mitzvot that are specific to himself, what is between him and his Creator, it is considered as charity for him, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will reward him for it in the World to Come. And when a person performs the mitzvot that are related to the benefit of others, it is also considered as charity for him in the World to Come, and he will receive his reward also in this world. All the mitzvot between a person and his fellow enter into the category of acts of kindness, as it is written. And behold, initially according to the law, the Torah scholar who engages in Torah has only the reward of the World to Come, while the supporter also has the reward of this world. However, since they become partners like Issachar and Zebulun, the one who engages in Torah merits the supporter to also receive reward through him for the World to Come. Likewise, the Torah scholar who engages in Torah receives the reward of this world just as the supporter does, for they are partners, and each will partake equally. Thus, through the partnership, each one receives his portion doubled in this world and in the World to Come, and nothing will be deducted from his fellow's portion at all, but each will receive his full reward. Similarly, the Holy One, blessed be He, gives to the fellow partner according to his portion and measure, and nothing will be lacking or diminished from his portion at all. Therefore, the one who supports has enough to pay each one.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that a Torah scholar (Talmid Chacham) and their supporter (machzik) share a unique partnership in spiritual merit. While the scholar primarily receives reward in the World to Come for their Torah study, the supporter benefits from both this reward and also receives blessings in this world. This partnership is likened to the relationship between Issachar and Zebulun, where both parties gain equally without diminishing each other's rewards. Ultimately, this reflects the divine justice of God, ensuring that each partner receives their due share in both worlds.

passage_content: ויתכן לפי"ז דבשכר העוה"ז יוקדם המחזיק לבוא בשכרו, כי הוא הגורם ועל ידו זוכה אף העוסק מדין שותפות, וע"כ הקדימו הכתוב לברכה להיות הוא זוכה ואח"כ מזכה לחבירו השותף, משא"כ בשכר עוה"ב הת"ח מוקדם ועיקר, ועל ידו זוכה גם המחזיק כנ"ל, ומעתה סרו כל הסתירות הנ"ל, דמה שהקדים הכתוב שמח זבולן בצאתך ליששכר מיירי לענין שכר עוה"ז, ובזה זבולן מוקדם כנ"ל, וז"ש בזוה"ק דאקדים לי' בברכאן, היינו לענין שכר עוה"ז, ומ"ש חז"ל דת"ח עצמן עין לא ראתה וכו', הכוונה שם משכר עוה"ב דזהו בחי' עין לא ראתה ובזה מעלת הת"ח עדיפא מהמחזיק, והוא הזוכה תחלה ומזכה לחבירו עמו, ועד"ז יתיישבו כל המימרות חלוקות המובאים בדרז"ל בענין זה, ויש מקום לחלק ביניהם עד"ז, דכ"מ שהכוונה לשכר העולם הזה המחזיק מוקדם, וכשמיירו משכר העולם הבא העוסק מוקדם והכל לפי הענין.
translation: And it is possible according to this that for the reward of this world, the one who holds (the Torah) will be rewarded first, for he is the cause and through him, even the one who engages (in Torah study) merits by the law of partnership. Therefore, the text precedes the blessing for him to be the one who merits and afterwards he merits his fellow partner. In contrast, for the reward of the World to Come, the Torah scholar is prioritized and is the main one, and through him, the holder also merits as mentioned above. From now on, all the aforementioned contradictions are resolved, for what the text precedes, "Zevulun will rejoice in your going out to Yissachar," refers to the reward of this world, and in this regard, Zevulun is prioritized as mentioned. And this is what is said in the Zohar that "I will precede him in their blessings," meaning regarding the reward of this world. And what our Sages said that "no eye has seen" etc., refers there to the reward of the World to Come, which is in the aspect of "no eye has seen," and in this, the merit of the Torah scholar is greater than that of the holder, for he is the one who merits first and also merits his fellow with him. And similarly, all the differing sayings brought in the Midrash regarding this matter can be reconciled, and there is room to distinguish between them in this way: wherever the intention is for the reward of this world, the holder is prioritized, and when it refers to the reward of the World to Come, the one who engages is prioritized, and all is according to the context.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between rewards in this world (Olam Hazeh) and the next (Olam Haba) within the context of partnership in Torah study. It emphasizes that while those who support Torah scholars (the "machzik") receive their reward first in this world, the scholars themselves (the "talmidei chachamim") are prioritized in the next world, highlighting their superior spiritual status. This reflects the Hasidic concept of the interconnectedness of actions and rewards, where the nature of the reward is contingent upon the context—whether it pertains to this world or the next. Ultimately, the text reconciles various teachings by clarifying that the timing of rewards is dependent on the specific realm being discussed.

passage_content: ולפי"ז אפרים הי' לו גם מכוחו וזכותו של מנשה, וכמו"כ למנשה הי' לו זכותו ושל אפרים כו ה"ה שותפין וחלק כחלק יאכלו וכ"א יש לו זכות המחזיק והעוסק וא"ש מאמר הכתוב בך יברך ישראל ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, ואף שהזכיר שניהם אפרים ומנשה, מ"מ יצדק לומר בך יברך ישראל בלשון יחיד, מפני שכ"א משותף בכח וזכות שניהם, ויתכן ברכה זו בכל אחד מהם, לאמר ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, כי כ"א משותף בכח שניהם, וא"ש מאמה"כ ויקרא בהם שמי (עיין לעיל קושיא ח') והכוונה על אפרים כמ"ש בזוה"ק דכל בית ישראל יקראו אפרים, ואעפ"כ אמר הכתוב לשון רבים, לפי שכ"א משותף מכוחות שניהם אפרים ומנשה, ויתכן לומר ויקרא בהם על אפרים לבדו והבו.
translation: According to this, Ephraim also had, through his own power and merit, that of Manasseh, and likewise, Manasseh had his merit and that of Ephraim. They are partners, and each one will partake equally, and each has the merit of holding and engaging. It is clear from the statement of the verse, "In you shall Israel bless," "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh." And although both Ephraim and Manasseh are mentioned, it is still appropriate to say "In you shall Israel bless" in the singular form, because each one shares in the power and merit of both. This blessing can be said for each of them, to say "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh," for each one is shared in the power of both. It is clear from the verse, "And I will call upon them by My name" (see above question 8), and the intention is regarding Ephraim, as stated in the Zohar that all of Israel will be called Ephraim. And nevertheless, the verse uses the plural form, because each one shares in the powers of both Ephraim and Manasseh. It is possible to say "And I will call upon them" regarding Ephraim alone, and so it is.
summary: The passage discusses the shared spiritual merits and strengths of Ephraim and Manasseh, emphasizing their partnership in blessings and divine favor. It highlights that each tribe possesses the combined virtues of both, allowing for individual blessings to be pronounced in the singular form, as they are united in their essence. The reference to Israel being blessed "like Ephraim and Manasseh" signifies the collective strength derived from both tribes, while the mention of calling all of Israel by the name of Ephraim underscores the unity and shared identity among them. This reflects a deep theological insight into the interconnectedness of spiritual legacies within the Jewish tradition.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בענין הנ"ל עפימ"ש הרמ"א ז"ל (ביור"ד סי' רמ"ו ס"א) בש"ר ירוחם וז"ל יכול אדם להתנות עם חבירו שהוא יעסוק בתורה, וחבירו ימציא לו פרנסתו ויחלוק עמו בשכר. אבל אם כבר עסק בתורה אינו יכול למכור לו חלקו בשביל ממון שיתן לו עכ"ל. וציין מקורו מש"ס סוטה (דף כ"א ע"א) אם יתן איש את כל הון ביתו באהבה בוז יבוזו לו, אמר עולא לא כשמעון אחי עזריה ולא כר' יוחנן דבי נשיאה, אלא כהלל ושבנא וכו' הלל ושבנא אחי הוו, הלל עסק בתורה, שבנא עבד עיסקא, לסוף א"ל תא נערוב וליפלוג, יצתה ב"ק ואמר אם יתן איש את כל הון ביתו וגו', ופרש"י דשמעון למד תורה ע"ו שהי' עזרי' מפרנסו לכך הוא נקרא ע"ש עזרי' אחיו, וכן ר' יוחנן למד ע"ו הנשיא שהי' מפרנסו, אבל הלל עסק בתורה מתוך עוני רב, ואח"כ רצה שבנא אחיו לשתף עמו בשכר תורתו שכבר למד וזה א"א עכת"ד. ומהר"ם אלשקר בשם רב האי גאון כתב טעמו, משום דכ"א מגיע בשכרו לפי מעשיו, וא"א למכור מעשיו לאחרים, עייש"ד.
translation: And I can also add regarding the aforementioned matter according to what the Rema, may his memory be blessed, writes (in Yoreh De'ah, Siman 246, Se'if 1) in the name of Rabbi Yerucham, and he said: A person can make a condition with his friend that he will engage in Torah, and his friend will provide for his livelihood and they will share in the reward. But if he is already engaged in Torah, he cannot sell his portion for money that he will receive. Thus far the quote. And he cites his source from the Talmud Sotah (21a): If a man gives all the wealth of his house for love, it will be despised. Ula said: Not like Shimon, the brother of Azariah, nor like Rabbi Yochanan, the son of the Nasi, but like Hillel and Shabna, etc. Hillel was engaged in Torah, while Shabna was involved in business. Eventually, he said to him: Let us partner and divide, and the Mishnah came out and said: If a man gives all the wealth of his house, etc. Rashi explains that Shimon learned Torah on account of the fact that Azariah supported him, and therefore he is called after Azariah, his brother. Similarly, Rabbi Yochanan learned on account of the Nasi who supported him, but Hillel engaged in Torah out of great poverty, and afterwards Shabna, his brother, wanted to share with him in the reward of the Torah he had already learned, and this is impossible. Thus far the quote. And the Maharam Alshakar, in the name of Rabbi Hai Gaon, wrote his reasoning, because each person receives his reward according to his deeds, and it is impossible to sell one's deeds to others. Thus is the explanation.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of dedicating oneself to Torah study while relying on others for sustenance, highlighting the distinction between those who study Torah for its own sake and those who do so for financial gain. It emphasizes that one cannot sell their share of Torah study for monetary compensation, as true spiritual reward is based on individual merit and actions. The examples of Hillel and Shabna illustrate the ideal of studying Torah amidst poverty, contrasting with those who rely on others for their livelihood while learning. Ultimately, the text underscores the intrinsic value of Torah study and the personal responsibility for one's spiritual and material pursuits.

passage_content: ומה שיכול להתנות מעיקרא בתנאי קודם למעשה, משום דבכה"ג לא מיחשב כמכירה כל רק שע"י שמחזיק ביד חבירו להמציא לו פרנסתו כדי שיוכל לעסוק בתורה באין מפריע, ה"ה מסייעהו לעסוק בתורה, וכיון שמסייע בידו יש לו חלק בתורתו כדין שותף, משא"כ לאחריו מה דהוה הוה, וא"א לסייע עוד בדבר שכבר נעשה, ע"כ א"א להשתתף אחר שנגמר העסק והשכר כבר מוכן, ואין זה אלא מדין מכירה, ולא יועיל המכירה לא למוכר ולא להקונה, כו הקונה לא ירוויח ולא יקבל מחלק חבירו כלום, והמוכר נראה כמזלזל במצות יעיי"ש בפוסקים. נמצא לפי"ז דלא יצוייר השותפות רק אם זבולן המחזיק יקדים מעשיו בהחזקת העוסק, לפני תורתו של יששכר, דאח"כ לא יזכה עוד בחלק השותפות, וע"כ מידה כנגד מידה ראוי שיוקדם זבולן בשכרו לפני יששכר, על כי גם מעשיו קדמו, וא"ש אף דמעלת העוסק עדיפא, כמ"ש חז"ל דת"ח עצמן עין לא ראתה וגו', מ"מ הקדימו הכתוב לזבולן בברכאן כמ"ש בזוה"ק ובמד"ר הנ"ל, והיינו טעמא לפי שמעשיו קדמו ע"כ ראוי שיוקדם ג"כ שכרו.
translation: And what can be conditioned from the outset with a condition prior to the action, because in such a case it is not considered a sale, only that by holding onto his friend's property to provide for him so that he can engage in Torah without interruption, he is assisting him in engaging in Torah. And since he is assisting him, he has a share in his Torah like a partner, whereas afterwards, what has been done has been done, and it is impossible to assist in something that has already been completed. Therefore, it is impossible to participate after the business has been concluded and the payment is already prepared, and this is only by the law of sale, and the sale will not benefit either the seller or the buyer; the buyer will not profit nor receive anything from his friend's share, and the seller appears to be belittling the commandments, as seen in the decisors. Thus, according to this, partnership can only be conceived if Zebulun, who holds, precedes his actions in supporting the one who engages in Torah, before the Torah of Issachar, for afterwards he will no longer merit a share in the partnership. Therefore, measure for measure, it is fitting that Zebulun should receive his reward before Issachar, because his actions also preceded. And this is understood even though the merit of the one who engages in Torah is greater, as our Sages said that no eye has seen the Torah scholars, etc. Nevertheless, the Scripture precedes Zebulun in their blessings, as stated in the Zohar and in the Midrash mentioned above, and the reason is that since his actions preceded, it is fitting that his reward should also be prioritized.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of partnership in the context of Torah study, emphasizing that a supporter (Zevulun) must provide assistance to a scholar (Yissachar) before the scholar's work is completed to establish a true partnership. It highlights that once the work is done, the opportunity for shared merit is lost, and the transaction becomes merely a sale, which is not beneficial for either party. The text underscores the principle of "measure for measure," suggesting that since Zevulun's actions precede Yissachar's study, he is entitled to receive his reward first, despite the scholar's higher spiritual status. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the value of supporting Torah study and the dynamics of spiritual merit in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: והנה יש עוד בחי' למעלה ממנו בהחזקת התורה, עפימ"ש ז"ל בגמ' סנהדרין (דף י"ט ע"ב) כל המגדל יתום בתוך ביתו מעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו ילדו וכו' ר"א אמר מהכא דכתיב (תהלים ע"ז) גאלת בזרוע עמך בני יעקב ויוסף סלה, וכי יוסף ילד והלא יעקב ילד, אלא יעקב ילד ויוסף כילכל, לפיכך נקראו על שמו עכ"ד הגמ', ולפי"ז המפרנס ללומדי תורה, לא רק שהוא בא בשכרו בעוה"ז ובעוה"ב חלק כחלק עם העוסק בתורה, אלא גם נקרא הת"ח על שמו כאילו ילדו
translation: And behold, there is another level above this in the support of the Torah, as our sages of blessed memory said in the Gemara Sanhedrin (19b), "Anyone who raises an orphan in his home, the Scripture considers it as if he gave birth to him." Rabbi Eliezer said from here, as it is written (Psalms 77), "You redeemed with Your strong arm, the children of Jacob and Joseph, Selah." And did Joseph give birth? Was it not Jacob who gave birth? Rather, Jacob gave birth and Joseph provided sustenance. Therefore, they are called by his name, thus concludes the Gemara. According to this, one who supports the Torah scholars, not only does he receive his reward in this world and in the World to Come, equally with one who engages in Torah, but he is also called a Torah scholar by his name, as if he gave birth to him.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound merit of supporting Torah scholars, equating this act to the spiritual significance of raising a child. It cites a Talmudic teaching that highlights the connection between nurturing and the continuity of Torah, illustrating that one who sustains Torah learners is considered as if they have given birth to them. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the communal responsibility for Torah study and the deep spiritual bond formed through such support, granting the benefactor a share in the rewards of Torah learning in both this world and the next.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו הפסוקים ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם לך יהיו וגו' (עיין לעיל קושיא א' וב') וא"צ לדחוק ולומר שהוא מאמר מסופק, דלא מצינו שהוליד יוסף תולדות עוד ולא זכרם הכתוב בשום מקום (כקושיתנו לעיל) אמנם לדרכנו יתפרש כוונת הכתוב ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם על הכלל ישראל, שכולם יקראו על שמך כאילו ילדתם, ולז"א שלך יהיו' ר"ל בענין הזכות הם שלך ונקראו על שמך, וע"ד מ"ש בספה"ק סידורו ש"ש לפרש הכתוב ואיש את קדשיו לו יהי', דמה שעושין לתיקון הנשמה נקרא שלו לחלקו וגורלו, משא"כ לצורך הגוף כי קנין שלו אינו שלו יעיי"ש. וז"ש לך יהיו כי ה"ה שלך בענין הזכות ויקראו כולם על שמך, אבל בענין הנחלה על שם אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם ויתחלקו לי"ב שבטים, דלגבי יוסף כל ישראל נקראו בניו וא"כ ה"ה אחיהם של אפרים ומנשה, וז"ש ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם לענין הנחלה, אבל לענין הזכות בזה ובבא, לך יהיו ויקראו על שמך, נמצא דמאמר ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריך נתקיים נבואתו ואצ"ל שהוליד עוד בנים ולא זכרם הכתוב, אבל הכוונה על הכלל ישראל שכלכלם יוסף ונחשב לו כאילו ילדם.
translation: And this will clarify the verses, "And your offspring that you will bear after them shall be yours" (see above question 1 and 2), and there is no need to forcefully say that it is a doubtful statement, for we do not find that Joseph fathered any more descendants, and the scripture does not mention them anywhere (as per our question above). However, according to our approach, the intent of the verse "And your offspring that you will bear after them" refers to the entire Jewish people, who are all called by your name as if you bore them. Therefore, it says "shall be yours," meaning in terms of merit, they are yours and are called by your name. This is in line with what is stated in the holy books, in the order of the Shabbat, to explain the verse "And a man shall have his holy things to him," for what is done for the rectification of the soul is called his, for his portion and lot, whereas for the needs of the body, his acquisition is not truly his, as you can see there. Thus, it says "shall be yours," for they are indeed yours in terms of merit and all will be called by your name. But in terms of inheritance, they will be called by the name of their brothers in their inheritance and will be divided among the twelve tribes, for regarding Joseph, all of Israel are called his sons, and thus they are the brothers of Ephraim and Manasseh. Therefore, it says "by the name of their brothers they will be called in their inheritance" concerning the inheritance, but in terms of merit, in this world and the next, "shall be yours" and they will be called by your name. It turns out that the statement "And your offspring that you will bear after them" fulfills his prophecy, and it is unnecessary to say that he fathered more sons and the scripture did not mention them, but the intent is regarding the entire Jewish people, whom Joseph sustains, and it is considered as if he bore them.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the descendants of Israel are spiritually attributed to Joseph, even if he did not physically father them, emphasizing the idea that all of Israel is considered as his children. It highlights the distinction between spiritual merit and physical inheritance, where the spiritual achievements of the people are credited to Joseph, while their physical inheritance is divided among the tribes. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interconnectedness of the Jewish people and their collective identity, as well as the significance of spiritual lineage over mere biological descent.
