passage_content: ובחינה זו רמז יעקב אע"ה במ"ש האספו ואגידה לכם את אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים, שבאחרית הימים יהיו ישראל נעזבים למקרי הזמן ר"ל, והוא עונש כפול ומכופל שלא בא בהשגחה לכפרת עוונות כנ"ל, אמנם לא ביאר בפרטיות ומפורש כל הדברים שיהיו באחרית הימים, רק הלבישן ורמזן בדבריו, וזה הכוונה בדברי רש"י ז"ל בקש יעקב לגלות את הקץ היינו שבקש לגלות מבואר ומפורש כל מה שיארע לישראל לעת קץ עד אחרית הימים, ונסתלקה ממנו השכינה והתחיל לומר דברים אחרים. כלומר שהלביש כל המאורעות בדברים אחרים דידוע שכל דיבור ודיבור בהתוה"ק רמוזים בה דברים עמוקים ונפלאים למעלה מהשגתינו, ובביאת המשיח ב"ב יתגלה לעינינו ויראו וישיגו דברים הנרמזים בתוה"ק, וכמו"כ בפסוקי פרשה זו רמז יע"א ע"ה כל מה שיארע לישראל עד אחרית הימים אלא שהלבישם בלבושים אחרים ולא אמרם באתגליא, נמצא שנתקיימו דבריו מ"ש בתחילה האספו ואגידה לכם את אשר יקרא אתכם, וגילה ברמז כל מה שיארע לישראל באחרית הימים.
translation: In this aspect, Jacob, may peace be upon him, hinted at what is written, "Gather and I will tell you what will happen to you in the end of days," that in the end of days, Israel will be abandoned to the occurrences of time, God forbid, and this is a double and compounded punishment that does not come through Divine Providence for the atonement of sins, as mentioned above. However, he did not elaborate in detail and explicitly on all the matters that will occur in the end of days, but rather clothed them and hinted at them in his words. This is the intention of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, when he states that Jacob sought to reveal the end, meaning that he sought to reveal clearly and explicitly all that will happen to Israel at the end until the end of days, and the Shechinah withdrew from him, and he began to say other things. This means that he clothed all the events in other words, for it is known that every word in the Torah contains deep and wondrous hints beyond our comprehension. In the coming of the Messiah, may he come speedily, it will be revealed to our eyes, and we will see and comprehend the matters hinted at in the Torah. Likewise, in the verses of this portion, he hinted, may peace be upon him, at all that will happen to Israel until the end of days, but he clothed them in other garments and did not state them explicitly. Thus, his words were fulfilled, as he initially said, "Gather and I will tell you what will happen to you," and he hinted at all that will happen to Israel in the end of days.
summary: בקטע זה, יעקב אבינו רומז על האירועים שיתרחשו לישראל באחרית הימים, כאשר הם ירגישו נטושים על ידי ההשגחה האלוהית, דבר שמהווה עונש כפול על חטאיהם. הוא ביקש לגלות את הקץ, אך השכינה נסתלקה ממנו, ולכן הוא הלביש את הנבואות במילים אחרות, כך שהמשמעות העמוקה שלהן תתגלה רק בביאת המשיח. כל מה שיארע לישראל עד אחרית הימים נרמז בתורה, אך לא נאמר במפורש, ובסופו של דבר, יתגלה הכל לעיני ישראל.

passage_content: נחזור לענינינו דהאמנם שעל חטא הידוע קשה לעשות תשובה שלימה, אולם תשובת הרבים חשובה הוא מאוד ומקובלת לפני השי"ת אף על חטא זה כנ"ל, על כן בהתאסף עם בנ"י בבתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות לתורה ולתפלה ערב ובוקר תמיד, יתאמצו כאו"א להרהר בתשובה אמיתית, ולבקש מהבוכ"ע שינצלו מחטא זה להבא, דבאמת א"א רק ע"ו סייעתא דשמיא, וצריך זהירות יתירה הן כל אחד על עצמו, ויותר צריך כל אב לשמור את בניו בהשגחה יתירה בעוד שהם קטנים שלא יתפסו ח"ו באשמת הדור שהתגברות היצה"ר בענין זה גדול מאוד עד אין לשער, והשי"ת ירחם להאיר עיני ולבות בני ישראל, לקרבם אל קדושתו ית', ונזכה אל הגאולה שלימה ואמיתית מיד, הגם שבעוה"ר אין אנו ראויים אלי' מצד מעשינו, אבל הבוכ"ע יש לו אוצר גדול של מתנת חנם למי שאינו ראוי מצד מעשיו, ע"כ נבקש מהשי"ת שיחונן אותנו מאוצר הגדול של מתנת חנם ובכח זה ירחם עלינו, ובעוה"ר רובא דעלמא משוקעים כ"כ בתאות ובשערי טומאה רח"ל עד שאין מרגישין כלל באיזה מצב הן עומדין, ואפשר לרמז בדברי הושע הנביא במ"ש כרפאי לישראל ונגלה עון אפרים, דהנה כשהאדם משוקע בעונות אינו רואה חוב לעצמו, וכמו שאמרנו לעיל שאף החטא הידוע אינו ידוע אצלו, ואין רואין האמת ע"י גודל סמיות העינים, וכענין מ"ש בספה"ק דרך אמת מהרה"ק ר"פ מזבאריז זלל"ה, עפ"י משל לאחד הנוסע בעגלה ויישן ונרדם, ועלתה העגלה על הר גבוה, וכאשר הגיעה על ראש ההר ויקץ האיש משינתו, ואם יאמרו אליו שהוא נוסע על הר גבוה לא יאמין לבו לדבריהם, כי הוא רואה לפניו הדרך כמישור אולם כשמתחיל העגלה לירד מטה מן ההר, יתוודע לו שהי' מתחלה על ראש ההר, וכן הדבר בענין הגאוה יעיי"ש בדבה"ק, ועד"ז הוא בכל החטאים, דכ"ז שהאדם משוקע בחטאים אינו מרגיש כלל שהוא חוטא, וצריך לרחמי שמים שיאיר השי"ת את עיניו שיראה באיזה מצב הוא עומד, אבל כשמתחילין להתרפאות מהחטאים ע"ו תשובה וחרטה, אז ירגיש שהי' מלא עונות ופשעים עד הנה, וז"ש הכ' כרפאי לישראל כשאתחול לרפאות את ישראל מחטאם, אז ונגלה עון אפרים. יתגלה להם כל מה שחטאו עד עכשיו, דכ"ז שלא התחילו בבחי' התשובה אין מרגישין כלום, ואנו מצפים להשי"ת שנזכה לביאת המשיח ולקיבוץ נדחי ישראל ולא נהי' ח"ו מהנידחים, דעל חטא הידוע כתיב לא יגורך רע שאין זוכין ח"ו לקבלת פנו השכינה כ"ז שלא ניתקן בחי' החטא, והשי"ת יעזור שנהי' מאותן שסייעו לביאת המשיח ולא חלילה מהמעכבים את גאולתן של ישראל, ונזכה לעשות תשובה שלימה לפני הבוכ"ע ולתקן כל אשר פגמנו, ובפרט בימי השובבי"ם אלו הבאים לקראתינו, ובמהרה נזכה לישועה שלימה ואמיתית, בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: We will return to our matter, that indeed it is difficult to make complete repentance for the known sin; however, the repentance of the masses is very important and accepted before the Holy One, Blessed be He, even for this sin as mentioned above. Therefore, when gathering with the children of Israel in synagogues and houses of study for Torah and prayer, morning and evening always, each one should strive to contemplate true repentance and to ask from the Blessed Creator to save them from this sin in the future, for in truth it is only with His assistance from Heaven. Each one must take extra care, and especially every father must guard his children with extra vigilance while they are young, so that they do not fall, Heaven forbid, into the guilt of the generation, as the strength of the evil inclination in this matter is very great, beyond measure. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, have mercy to enlighten the eyes and hearts of the children of Israel, to bring them closer to His holiness, and may we merit complete and true redemption soon, even though, alas, we are not worthy of it due to our deeds. But the Blessed Creator has a great treasure of free gifts for those who are not worthy because of their actions. Therefore, let us ask from the Holy One, Blessed be He, to grant us from the great treasure of free gifts, and with this merit, may He have mercy on us. And alas, the majority of the world is so immersed in desires and gates of impurity, Heaven forbid, that they do not feel at all in what state they stand. It is possible to hint at the words of the prophet Hosea in what he said, "I will heal Israel, and the iniquity of Ephraim will be revealed," for behold, when a person is sunk in sins, he does not see any debt for himself, and as we said above, even the known sin is not known to him. The truth is not seen due to the great blindness of the eyes, and in the manner of what is written in the holy books, in the way of truth, from the holy Rabbi Pinchas of Zbarazh, may his memory be blessed, according to the parable of one who travels in a wagon and falls asleep. The wagon ascends a high mountain, and when it reaches the top of the mountain and the man wakes from his sleep, if they tell him that he is traveling on a high mountain, he will not believe his heart to their words, for he sees before him the road as flat. However, when the wagon begins to descend from the mountain, he will realize that he was indeed at the top of the mountain. So it is with regard to pride, as mentioned there in the holy discourse, and similarly, it is with all sins. As long as a person is sunk in sins, he does not feel at all that he is sinning, and he needs the mercy of Heaven for the Holy One, Blessed be He, to enlighten his eyes to see in what state he stands. But when they begin to heal from sins through true repentance and regret, then he will feel that he has been full of sins and transgressions until now. And this is what the verse says, "I will heal Israel; when I begin to heal Israel from their sin, then the iniquity of Ephraim will be revealed." They will be made aware of all that they have sinned until now, for as long as they have not begun in the aspect of repentance, they do not feel anything. And we await the Holy One, Blessed be He, that we merit the coming of the Messiah and the ingathering of the exiles of Israel, and that we will not be, Heaven forbid, among the exiled. For concerning the known sin, it is written, "No evil shall befall you," for they are not worthy, Heaven forbid, to receive the countenance of the Shechinah as long as the aspect of the sin is not rectified. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, help us to be among those who assisted in the coming of the Messiah and not, Heaven forbid, among those who delay the redemption of Israel. May we merit to make complete repentance before the Blessed Creator and to rectify all that we have blemished, especially in these days of Shovavim that are coming upon us, and may we soon merit complete and true salvation, with the uplifting of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days. Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of communal repentance and the need for individuals to reflect on their sins, particularly in the face of overwhelming temptation. It highlights that true repentance requires divine assistance and that parents must vigilantly guide their children to avoid the pitfalls of sin. The text also conveys a sense of hope, asserting that even those who feel unworthy can receive God's grace and mercy, especially during the times of spiritual reflection, such as the "Shovavim" period. Ultimately, it expresses a yearning for redemption and the coming of the Messiah, urging believers to strive for complete repentance and spiritual elevation.

passage_content: עוד יתבאר במאמה"כ האספו ואגידה לכם את אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים, ודרשו רז"ל ביקש יעקב לגלות את הקץ ונסתלקה ממנו שכינה וכו', ולכאורה אם לא נתקיימה מחשבתו ורצונו, מדוע כתבה תוה"ק הבטחה זו שלא נתקיימה, גם איך יתכן שהבטיח יע"א לבניו להודיעם אשר יקרא אותם באחרית הימים, ולא עלתה בידו לקיים הבטחתו, ויע"א מידתו אמת כמ"ש תתן אמת ליעקב, גם יל"ד אומרו אשר יקרא אתכם וגו', הול"ל אשר יקרא לכם.
translation: It will be further explained in the verse, "Assemble and I will tell you what will happen to you in the end of days," and our sages have interpreted that Jacob wished to reveal the end and the Shechinah withdrew from him, etc. At first glance, if his thought and desire were not fulfilled, why did the Holy Torah write this promise that was not realized? Also, how is it possible that the Blessed One promised his sons to inform them what would happen to them in the end of days, and he was unable to fulfill his promise? And the Blessed One's attribute is truth, as it is said, "You shall give truth to Jacob." Furthermore, it could have said, "what will happen to you," instead of "what will happen to you."
summary: הקטע עוסק בשאלות על כוונת יעקב אבינו לגלות את הקץ, אך השכינה נסתלקה ממנו. הוא מתמודד עם הקונפליקט בין הבטחת התורה לבין אי קיום מחשבתו של יעקב, ושואל מדוע הובטחה הבשורה אם לא התקיימה. כמו כן, הוא מדגיש את מידת האמת של ה' ואת השאלה על ניסוח ההבטחה, המעלה תהיות על משמעותה.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפימ"ש נגד אבותם עשה פלא, שיעמדו האבוה"ק בתחי' לפני הגאולה, ויראו בגאולתן של ישראל, ואמרז"ל בגמ' ו)תענית ה' ע"ב) מקיש הוא לזרעו מה זרעו בחיים אף הוא בחיים, פרש"י ז"ל שיביאנו הקב"ה לוע"א בגולה, כדי לגאול את בניו לעיניו עיי"ש, ועפי"ז יל"פ הרמז באמרו אשר יקרא אתכם ולא אמר לכם עפימ"ש הר"י עמדין זלה"ה בפי' להגש"פ, לתרץ קושית המפרשים מה בין שאלת החכם והרשע, ובין מלת אתכם ולכם, וזל"ק ועתה האירו עיני מן השמים בדבר ברור בעזהשי"ת, שמע דבר ד' בי הפרש גדול יש בין שתי אלה הנפרדות וכו' עפימ"ש רז"ל (סוטה ל"ד ע"א) מאי אותיכם אותי ואתכם, נמצא תסבול מלת אתכם הרכבה זו בכל מקום, אע"פ שהיא חסרה וא"ו, יש אם למסורת ותקראנה בחולם, הוא יורה גם על המדבר בעד עצמו בכלל המדוברים, מה שאין בכח מלת לכם לעולם וכו' עיי"ש, ועד"ז אפ"ל שרמז יע"א באמרו אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים, ר"ל אותי ואתכם, שבאחרית הימים סמוך לזמן הגאולה, יהי' יע"א עמנו בגלות, וזכותו יגן עלינו להחיש גאולתנו ולהקל מעלינו חבלי הגלות. ולטעם זה לא אמר אשר יקרא לכם שלא להוציא עצמו מן הכלל, וזה א' מסימני הגאולה, שאם נזכה לזה שיע"א עמנו יתגלה לעינינו. אז בודאי הוא גאולה אמיתית ולא זולת, ואז יגלה לנו יע"א כל ענין הקץ וסודו
translation: And it is possible to interpret according to the saying of our Sages that against their ancestors, He performed a wonder, that the holy fathers will stand at the beginning before the redemption, and they will see the redemption of Israel. And our Sages said in the Gemara (Taanit 5b) that He compares him to his offspring; just as his offspring are alive, so is he alive. Rashi explains that the Holy One, blessed be He, will bring us to the World to Come in exile, in order to redeem His children before His eyes, as stated there. And according to this, one can explain the hint in His saying "which will call you" and He did not say "to you," according to what Rabbi Yitzchak Amdin, may his memory be blessed, explained in his commentary on the Geulah, to answer the question of the commentators regarding the difference between the question of the wise and the wicked, and between the word "you" and "to you." And it is written: "And now, illuminate my eyes from the heavens with a clear matter, by the grace of the Holy One, blessed be He," I have heard the word of God; there is a great distinction between these two that are separated, etc. According to what our Sages said (Sota 34a), "What is your sign? Me and you." It turns out that the word "you" carries this composition everywhere, even though it is missing a vav. There is a tradition to read it with a cholem, which also indicates the speaker on behalf of himself among all those spoken about, which is not in the power of the word "to you" at all, etc. As stated there. And similarly, one can say that He hinted, may He be blessed, in saying "which will call you in the end of days," meaning me and you, that in the end of days, close to the time of redemption, He will be with us in exile, and His merit will protect us to hasten our redemption and to lighten the burdens of exile from us. And for this reason, He did not say "which will call you" so as not to exclude Himself from the community, and this is one of the signs of redemption, that if we merit this, may He be blessed, He will reveal Himself to our eyes. Then it will certainly be a true redemption and nothing else, and then He will reveal to us, may He be blessed, all matters of the end and its secret.
summary: The passage discusses the profound connection between the Jewish people and their ancestors, emphasizing that the patriarchs will witness the redemption of Israel. It highlights the idea that God's presence will be with the Jewish people during their exile, serving as a source of protection and a catalyst for their ultimate redemption. The distinction between the terms "you" and "you all" signifies a collective experience, indicating that in the end of days, God's presence will be revealed alongside the Jewish people, leading to a true and complete redemption. This revelation will clarify the mysteries of the end times and the nature of redemption itself.

passage_content: ואפ"ל כי יע"א ביקש לגלות את הקץ מיד, עפימ"ש רז"ל במדרש כך הי' יע"א סבור שתחיית המתים מגעת בימיו, ולפי סברתו הי' זמנו לגלות מיד אמנם מן השמים לא הרשוהו לגלות, כי לא היו ישראל ראויים עדיין לתשלום הקץ, עד שיושלם התקון על ידיהם, ואלמלי הו' יע"א מגלה קץ הגאולה, ישיגו על ידו אריכות הגלות והשתלשלות הסיבות שיעברו על ישראל, והי' קשה כח הסבל לסבול צער הידיעה ההוא ולא הי' אפשר לעמוד בה, וכנודע שק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה אמר בדרשתו האחרונה, גלוי וידוע לפני מי שאמר והי' העולם, שאם הייתי יודע מתחלה שיתארך הגלות כ"כ, לא הי' ביכולתי לסבלו ולא הייתי מאריך ימים עד הנה ר"ל, אלא שהיית מעלים ממני וחשבתי שקרובה עת הקץ ויהי' הגאולה מיד עכתדה"ק, אבל לעתיד שיביאנו הקב"ה ליע"א בגולה לפני הגאולה, אז יקיים יע"א הבטחתו מ"ש ואגידה לכם את אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים, וא"ש מ"ש התוה"ק הבעחה זו, כי לא הגביל זמן קיומו ועתידה להתקיים לעתיד, וע"ד שכתב הצל"ח עמ"ש בגמ' ברכות (ד' ע"א) עד יעבור עמך ד' זו ביאה ראשונה (בימי יהושע) עד יעבור עם זו קנית זו ביאה שני' (בימי עזרא) מכאן אמרו חכמים ראויים היו ישראל ליעשות להם נס בימי יהושע בן נון אלא שגרם החטא עכ"ד הגמ', וקשה הרי אמרו רז"ל כל דיבור שיצא מפי הקב"ה לטובה אפי' על תנאי אינו חוזר, וכיון שהיתה הבטחה מאתו ית' לעשות לישראל נס בביאה שני', האיך חזרה הבטחתו ות' ע"ו גרמת החטא, ותירץ כי לא הגביל הבוי"ת זמן ההבטחה אימת תתקיים, ועתידה להתקיים לעתיד בביאת המשיח, שתהי' בהתגלות גדול כמו ביאה הראשונה, וכמו"כ לעניננו הבעחת יע"א לא תתבטל ויתקיים לעתיד ושפיר כתבה התוה"ק הבטחה זו.
translation: And even though it was thought that he (Ye'ach) wished to reveal the end immediately, as our sages said in the Midrash, he (Ye'ach) was of the opinion that the resurrection of the dead would occur in his days, and according to his reasoning, his time was to reveal it immediately. However, from Heaven, they did not allow him to reveal it, for Israel was not yet worthy of the fulfillment of the end, until the rectification would be completed by them. And were it not for Ye'ach revealing the end of redemption, they would experience through him the prolongation of the exile and the unfolding of the causes that would befall Israel, and the strength of suffering would be difficult to bear the pain of that knowledge, and it would not be possible to endure it. And as is known, that which Moshe, peace be upon him, said in his last discourse, is revealed and known before Him who said and the world came into being, that if I had known from the beginning that the exile would be prolonged so much, I would not have been able to bear it, and I would not have lived until now, blessed be He. Rather, You concealed it from me, and I thought that the time of the end was near and that the redemption would be immediate. However, in the future, when the Holy One, blessed be He, brings us to Ye'ach in exile before the redemption, then Ye'ach will fulfill His promise, as it is written, "And I will tell you what will happen to you in the latter days." And I understand what the Holy Torah means by this, for it did not limit the time of its existence, and it is destined to be fulfilled in the future. And as the Tzelach wrote, as mentioned in the Gemara Berakhot (Daf 2a), "Until your people pass, O Lord," this refers to the first coming (in the days of Joshua) until "this people you have acquired," which refers to the second coming (in the days of Ezra). From here, the sages said that Israel was worthy of having a miracle done for them in the days of Joshua ben Nun, but sin caused it, thus the Gemara concludes. And it is difficult, for our sages said that any word that comes from the mouth of the Holy One, blessed be He, for good, even conditionally, does not return. And since there was a promise from Him to perform a miracle for Israel in the second coming, how could His promise return and say that the sin caused it? And it was answered that the Holy One did not limit the time of the promise when it would be fulfilled, and it is destined to be fulfilled in the future with the coming of the Messiah, which will be with a great revelation like the first coming. And likewise, concerning our matter, the promise of Ye'ach will not be nullified and will be fulfilled in the future, and thus the Holy Torah rightly wrote this promise.
summary: The passage discusses the anticipation of the Messiah and the resurrection of the dead, emphasizing that although there was a belief that these events could occur imminently, divine wisdom prevented their revelation due to the unworthiness of the people at that time. It highlights the idea that the suffering of prolonged exile would be unbearable if the full extent of the future hardships were known. The text reassures that God's promises remain intact and will ultimately be fulfilled in the future, particularly through the coming of the Messiah, echoing the belief that divine assurances are not bound by specific timelines but will manifest at the appropriate moment.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד, דהנה ענין הגאולה והקץ תליא בבחירה, דאם יזכו ישראל אחישנה כתיב, ואולי לטעם זה נסתלקה ממנו שכינה כשביקש לגלות הקץ. דאלמלי גילה רמז הקץ כ"ז שהיתה עליו בחי' גדולה של השראת השכינה, הי' דיבורו עושה הכרח לבטל הבחירה, כי בודאי הי' בבחי' שכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו, ודיבורו ית' עושה הכרח למנוע הבחירה, וע"כ נסתלקה ממנו בחי' השראת השכינה באותה שטה, ואז קיים הבטחתו וגילה לבניו מה שיארע לישראל באחרית הימים, וכמ"ש רז"ל במדרש מפלת גוג הראה להם, ובנין ביהמ"ק הראה להם, ועוד אמרז"ל שכל מה שיארע לכל שבט ושבט עד ביאת המשיח גילה להם, אלא שלא הי' אפשר לגלות כל זה בעוד הי' שורה עליו בחי' גדולה של השראת השכינה, כי כ"ז תליא בבחירה כנ"ל ולטעם זה נסתלקה הימנו שכינה, ועכ"פ נתקיים הבטחתו וא"ש.
translation: And even so, behold, the matter of redemption and the end is dependent on choice, for if Israel merits it, it is written "I will hasten it." And perhaps for this reason the Shechinah departed from him when he sought to reveal the end. For had he revealed a hint of the end while he was in a state of great Divine presence, his words would have necessarily compelled the cancellation of choice, for certainly he would have been in a state of the Shechinah speaking from his throat, and his words would have necessitated the prevention of choice. Therefore, the aspect of the Divine presence departed from him in that matter, and then he fulfilled his promise and revealed to his sons what would happen to Israel in the end of days, as our Sages said in the Midrash, he showed them the downfall of Gog, and he showed them the building of the Holy Temple, and our Sages also said that everything that would happen to each tribe until the coming of the Messiah was revealed to them. However, it was not possible to reveal all this while he was still in a state of great Divine presence, for all this is dependent on choice, as mentioned, and for this reason the Shechinah departed from him. Nevertheless, his promise was fulfilled, and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between redemption and human choice, emphasizing that the revelation of the end times is contingent upon Israel's merit. It suggests that the Shechinah (Divine Presence) withdrew from the speaker when he sought to reveal the end, as such a revelation would undermine free will by compelling belief. Despite this withdrawal, the speaker was still able to convey prophecies about Israel's future, indicating that the unfolding of events remains tied to the concept of choice and divine timing. Ultimately, the text highlights the delicate balance between divine revelation and human agency in the context of redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"ל דנרמז באמרו אחרית הימים, מה שבעוה"ר נתאחר קץ גאולתינו עד סוף ימי עמידת העולם, כאמרז"ל שית אלפי שנין הוו עלמא, ואילו זכו ישראל הי' מקדים הקב"ה גאולתם, והי' נתקיים פי' ההבטחה באופן אחר, ובעוה"ר נדחה ונתאחר גאולתינו ונתקיים הרמז כפשוטו, ועכ"פ לא ניתנה להאמר בבחי' דבור ובהתגלות, כי עדיין הי' תליא בבחירה. ולזה הלביש יע"א דברי נבואתו ברמז אמרותיו.
translation: And although it is hinted at by saying "the end of days," what has happened, unfortunately, is that the end of our redemption has been delayed until the end of the days of the world's existence, as our Sages have said, "Six thousand years the world will exist." And if Israel had merited it, the Holy One, blessed be He, would have brought their redemption earlier, and the interpretation of the promise would have been fulfilled in a different manner. But unfortunately, our redemption has been postponed and delayed, and the hint has been fulfilled literally. Nevertheless, it was not given to be said in a manner of speech and revelation, for it was still dependent on choice. Therefore, He clothed His prophetic words in hints of His sayings.
summary: The passage discusses the delay of the Jewish people's redemption, emphasizing that had they merited it, God would have brought their redemption earlier, in accordance with the promise of the end of days. It reflects on the concept of free will, suggesting that the timing of redemption is contingent upon human choices. The author notes that the prophetic words are cloaked in hints and allusions, indicating that the full revelation of redemption remains dependent on the people's actions and spiritual state.

passage_content: ראובן בכורי אתה וגו' במד"ר כיון שבא לברך את ראובן א"ל איני לא מרחקך ולא מקרבך אלא הרי אנו תולה אותך ברפיון עד שיבוא משה שכתוב בו ומשה עלה אל האלקים, מה שדעתו רואה לעשות בך עושה, כיון שבא משה התחיל מקרבו יחי ראובן עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין מדוע תלה אותו ברפיון עד שיבוא משה ומדוע ראוי להיות התקרבותו ע"ו משרע"ה דייקא.
translation: Reuben, you are my firstborn, etc. In the Midrash, when he came to bless Reuben, he said to him, "I am neither distancing you nor drawing you close, but rather we are suspending you in a state of uncertainty until Moses comes, as it is written, 'And Moses went up to God.' Whatever his mind sees fit to do with you, he will do." When Moses came, he began to draw him close, saying, "Long live Reuben." Thus far is the Midrash. It is fitting to understand why he was suspended in uncertainty until Moses came and why it was appropriate for his closeness to be specifically through Moses.
summary: The passage discusses the blessing of Reuven, highlighting the concept of spiritual elevation through the presence of Moses. It emphasizes that Reuven's fate was suspended until Moses arrived, symbolizing the idea that divine intervention and leadership are essential for true spiritual connection. The text suggests that Moses, as a mediator, has the unique ability to bring about closeness to God, illustrating the Hasidic belief in the importance of righteous leaders in facilitating divine blessings. This reflects a broader theological insight into the relationship between human actions, divine will, and the role of spiritual leaders in guiding the community.

passage_content: ב) איתא בספרי (פ' ברכה) יחי ראובן ואל ימות יחי ראובן בעוה"ז ואל ימות לעוה"ב, וצ"ב דהרי כשברכו משרע"ה לא הי' ראובן קיים עוד בעוה"ז, ואיך יתכן לו ברכה זו שיחי' בעוה"ז.
translation: It is stated in the Sifrei (Parashat Berachah) "May Reuven live and not die; may Reuven live in this world and not die in the World to Come." And it is puzzling, for when Moshe Rabbeinu blessed him, Reuven was no longer alive in this world. How is it possible for him to receive this blessing to live in this world?
summary: The passage discusses the blessing given to Reuven by Moshe Rabbeinu, which states "May Reuven live and not die," raising a question about its validity since Reuven was no longer alive in this world at the time of the blessing. This highlights a key Hasidic concept of the eternal nature of the soul and the idea that blessings can transcend physical existence. It suggests that the spiritual essence of a person continues to have relevance and impact beyond their earthly life, emphasizing the connection between the physical and spiritual realms. Ultimately, it reflects on the enduring legacy and spiritual vitality of individuals even after their physical departure.

passage_content:
ג) עוד שם בספרי (הובא בילקו"ש) יחי ראובן במעשה יוסף ולא ימות במעשה בלהה, ר' חנינא בן גמליאל אומר לעולם אין מחליפין לא זכות בחובה ולא חובה בזכות חוץ משל ראובן וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, ופי' בזית רענן (מבעל מג"א זלה"ה) יחי ראובן במעשה יוסף שהצילו, יהי' זה נגד מעשה בלהה, אין מחליפין זכות בחובה שאם חטא 
אדם ועשה גם מצוה, נותנין לו שכר על המצוה וגובין ממנו על העבירה, אבל גבי מעשה ראובן החליפו לו זכות יוסף במעשה בלהה עכ"ד, וראוי להבין דאם כך הוא המדה שאין מחליפין זכות בחובה, וכמ"ש הרא"ם ז"ל ולא יקח שוחד דהיינו שוחד מצוה במקום עבירה, א"כ מדוע החליפו לראובן עבירה במצוה.
translation: 3) Furthermore, it is stated in the books (brought in Yalkut Shimoni) "May Reuven live through the act of Yosef and not die through the act of Bilhah." Rabbi Chanina ben Gamliel says that one does not exchange merit for sin nor sin for merit, except for the case of Reuven, etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. And the explanation in Zayit Raanan (from the author of Magen Avraham, may his memory be blessed) is that Reuven lived through the act of Yosef that saved him; this is against the act of Bilhah. One does not exchange merit for sin, for if a person sinned and also performed a mitzvah, they are given reward for the mitzvah and are held accountable for the sin. However, regarding the act of Reuven, they exchanged for him the merit of Yosef for the act of Bilhah. Thus concludes. It is appropriate to understand that if this is the measure that one does not exchange merit for sin, as the Ra'ah, may his memory be blessed, wrote, "And one shall not take a bribe," meaning a bribe of a mitzvah in place of a sin, then why was Reuven's sin exchanged for a mitzvah?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of merit and sin in the context of Reuben's actions regarding Joseph and Bilhah. It highlights the principle that one cannot exchange merit for sin or vice versa, except in Reuben's case, where his merit in saving Joseph was considered against his sin with Bilhah. This raises a theological question about the nature of divine justice and the unique circumstances that allowed for this exchange, suggesting a deeper understanding of repentance and the complexities of human actions in relation to divine judgment.

passage_content: ד) במד"ר ופ' וישב): א"ל הקב"ה לראובן מעולם לא חטא אדם לפני ועשה תשובה, ואתה פתחת בתשובה תחלה, חייך שבן בנך עומד ופותח בתשובה תחלה, ואו זה זה הושע שנאמר שובה ישראל עד ד' אלקיך, הקשו המפרשים הלא כבר קדמוהו אדה"ר וקין שעשו ג"כ תשובה, ולא הי' ראובן הראשון שפתח בתשובה.
translation: In the Midrash and Parashat Vayeshev, it is said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Reuven, "Never has a person sinned before Me and repented, and you were the first to open with repentance. By your life, your grandson will stand and open with repentance first, and this is Hosea, as it is said, 'Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God.' The commentators have questioned, 'But did not Adam HaRishon and Cain also repent?' And Reuven was not the first to open with repentance."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is highlighted that Reuven is uniquely recognized by God for being the first to initiate repentance, despite the existence of earlier figures like Adam and Cain who also repented. This distinction emphasizes the significance of personal initiative in the process of teshuva (repentance) within Hasidic thought. The text suggests that Reuven's act of repentance sets a precedent for future generations, particularly for his descendant, Hoshea, who calls Israel to return to God. This underscores the transformative power of sincere repentance and its enduring impact on the Jewish people.

passage_content: ה) במדרש ילקוט ופ' וישב) למדתך תורה ד"א שכשהאדם עושה מצוה יהא עושה אותה בלב שמח, שאילו הי' יודע ראובן שהקב"ה כותב אחריו וישמע ראובן ויצילהו מידם, בכתיפיו הי' טוענו ומוליכו אצל אביו, וצ"ב דודאי לא יתכן שעשה ראובן פעולת ההצלה לשם כבוד ח"ו שהתורה יכתוב שבחו, וא"כ מנפק"מ אילו הי' יודע.
translation: In the Midrash Yalkut and Parashat Vayeshev, it teaches you Torah: that when a person performs a mitzvah, he should do it with a joyful heart. For if Reuven had known that the Holy One, Blessed be He, was writing about him, and Reuven would hear and save him from their hands, he would have carried him on his shoulders and brought him to his father. And it is clear that it is impossible that Reuven performed the act of salvation for the sake of honor, Heaven forbid, that the Torah would write his praise. Therefore, what difference would it make if he had known?
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of performing mitzvot with joy and sincerity, highlighting that true devotion comes from a pure heart rather than for the sake of recognition. It illustrates this through the example of Reuven, suggesting that if he had known his actions would be recorded by God, he would have acted with even greater enthusiasm. The underlying message is that awareness of divine observation should inspire a deeper commitment to righteousness, rather than a desire for honor. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of joyful service to God.

This highlights the Hasidic idea of striving to recognize and bring forth the divine spark within oneself and the world, emphasizing the importance of intention and awareness in one's spiritual journey. passage_content: וגר""פ עפימ"ד במד"ר פ' אחרי (פכ"א סי' ה') בזאת יבא אהרן זש"ה כי בתחבולות תעשה לך מלחמה וכו', אם עשית חבילות של עבירות עשה כנגדן חבילות של מצות, עינים רמות, והיו לטוטפות בין עיניך, לשון שקר ולמדתם אותם את בניכם וכו', ועד"ז פורע והולך כל האברים אם עשה בהם עבירה ח"ו יעשה באותו אבר מצוה לתקן פגמו, ולכאו' איך יתוקן העבירה בזה, הלא אין מחליפין מצוה בעבירה ולא עבירה במצוה, וכן הקשה ביפ"ת וז"ל, אם מיירי במי שעשה תשובה מהעבירות, כבר שב ורפא לו מבלי מעשה המצות, ואם הוא מהעבירות שתשובה תולה ויסורין או מיתה ממרקין, מה יועילו המצות, ואם במי שלא שב פשיטא שלא יגונו עליו המצות להצילו מעונש עוה"ב, דאין עבירה מכבה מליטול שכר לעתיד בעוה"ב כדפירש"י בפרק הי' נוטל, וכמו"כ לא יועיל המצוה להצילו מעונש העבירה, וכבר אמרו ז"ל ולא יקח שוחד מצות ע"כ קושיתו, ותוכן תירוצו לבאר דאשמעינן שתו תקנות טובות לבעל תשובה, הא' למה שההרגל על כל דבר שלטון, והנה מי שמורגל בעבירות יהי' בוטח אליהן תמיד בטבעו, ע"ד עבירה גוררת עבירה וכו', וכ"ש בהיות העבירות רבות ותכופות זו לזו שיתחזק כחן במאד וכו' והב' שידוע וכו' שבחטאות האדם באבר מאבריו, ישאר אותו האבר עמא, וטוב לא יהי' לרשע באבר ההוא עד יענש בו וכו', וע"כ אמרז"ל שתקנתו אם עשה חבילות של עבירות שימשכו מזה שתים הרעות הנזכר לחוטא, יעשה כנגדן חבילות של מצות, שבהיותן חבילות יתהפך הרגלן מהעבירות אל המצות, ויתחזק כוחן זב"ז, ובהיותן כנגדן יתוקנו אבריו, כי האבר אשר עשה בו העבירה ירפא במה שיעשה בו מצוה וכו' עכ"ד היפ"ת זלל"ה.
translation: And the Gaon Rabbi Pinchas of Piemont in the Midrash Parashat Acharei (Chapter 21, Section 5) states: "With this shall Aaron come," as it is written, "for with cunning you shall wage war," etc. If you have made bundles of transgressions, make against them bundles of commandments. "Elevated eyes," and they shall be as frontlets between your eyes; "a tongue of falsehood," and you have taught them to your children, etc. And similarly, every limb is punished; if one has sinned with a limb, Heaven forbid, he should perform a commandment with that same limb to rectify its blemish. And it seems, how can the transgression be rectified in this way? Is it not true that one does not exchange a commandment for a transgression, nor a transgression for a commandment? And so the Yefeh Toar asked, saying: If we are speaking of one who has repented from his transgressions, he has already returned and been healed without the act of commandments. And if it is regarding transgressions for which repentance is suspended, and suffering or death atones, what benefit do the commandments provide? And if it is about one who has not repented, it is obvious that the commandments will not protect him from punishment in the World to Come, for a transgression does not extinguish the reward for the future in the World to Come, as Rashi explained in the chapter "He Who Takes." Likewise, the commandment will not help him escape the punishment of the transgression. And our sages have already said, "And he shall not take a bribe of commandments." Thus is their question. The essence of their answer is to explain that we are taught that there are good remedies for the penitent. The first is that habit governs all matters of authority, and behold, one who is accustomed to transgressions will always trust in them by nature, in the manner of "one transgression leads to another," etc. Especially when the transgressions are many and frequent, their power will be greatly strengthened, etc. The second is that it is known, etc., that in the transgressions of a person with one of his limbs, that limb will remain damaged, and it will not be good for the wicked in that limb until he is punished with it, etc. Therefore, our sages said that his remedy, if he has made bundles of transgressions, is that he should draw from this two of the evils mentioned for the sinner, and he should make against them bundles of commandments. When they are bundles, the habit will turn from transgressions to commandments, and their power will strengthen each other. And when they are against each other, his limbs will be rectified, for the limb with which he sinned will be healed by the commandment he performs with it, etc. Thus concludes the Yefeh Toar, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of rectifying sins through the performance of mitzvot, emphasizing that one should counteract the "bundles" of transgressions with "bundles" of commandments. It highlights the idea that habitual sin can create a natural inclination towards wrongdoing, and thus, engaging in mitzvot can help transform this inclination. The text also addresses the notion that even if one has sinned, performing good deeds can lead to healing and restoration of the body and soul, as each mitzvah can rectify the damage caused by specific sins. Ultimately, it underscores the transformative power of repentance and the importance of actively engaging in positive actions to counteract past misdeeds.

passage_content: ואפשר להרחיב הביאור בזה, עפי"מ שגילה האר"י ז"ל מספר הצומות והסיגופום שיסגף האדם א"ע בהם על כל עבירה במשקל, והחיד"א זלה"ה כתב ע"ד האריז"ל דהעיקר הוא התשובה והחרטה, אך מפני שהאברים עדיין מלוכלכים ונשארו עוד כתמי הנפש, וע"ז מענישים בגיהנם לזכך ולהסיר כתמי הנפש, ועל דבר זה מועילים התענית והסיגופים עכת"ד ז"ל, ועד"ז אפ"ל לעניננו שעל דבר זה יועילו מעשה המצות, ויובן מ"ש ז"ל עשה כנגדן חבילות של מצות, דלעולם מיירי בשעשה תשובה על חטאיו, אלא שעדיין נשארו כתמי הנפש והאברים מלוכלכים ר"ל ואינם מזדככין כ"א ע"י תעניתים וסיגופים כדברי האריז"ל, ולזה נתנו חז"ל עצה ותקנה במ"ש בתחבולות תעשה לך מלחמה, שבאותו האבר עצמו שחטא ירבה בו חבילות של מצות, ויזדככו אבריו וכתמי הנפש כמו ע"י התעניתים וסיגופים, וכמ"ש בספה"ק סור מרע בשם החרדים זלה"ה דהעוסק בתורה מועיל לו לימוד התוה"ק במקום התענית וסיגופים, ואדרבה התענית חסרון הוא לגבי', שנתבטל על ידו מעסק התורה עיי"ש.
translation: And it is possible to expand the explanation on this, according to what the Ari, may his merit protect us, revealed regarding the number of fasts and the self-denials that a person should impose upon himself for every sin in proportion. And the Chida, may his merit protect us, wrote in the manner of the Ari that the main thing is repentance and regret. However, since the limbs are still defiled and there remain stains of the soul, for this they are punished in Gehenna to purify and remove the stains of the soul. And regarding this, fasting and self-denial are beneficial, as he stated. Similarly, it can be said concerning our matter that the deeds of the commandments will be beneficial for this purpose. It can be understood from what they said, "Do against them bundles of commandments," that it always refers to one who has repented for his sins, yet there still remain stains of the soul and the limbs are defiled, so to speak, and they are not purified except through fasting and self-denial, as the Ari stated. For this reason, our Sages gave advice and a remedy in saying, "With cunning you shall wage war," that in the very limb that sinned, one should increase bundles of commandments, and his limbs and the stains of the soul will be purified just as through fasting and self-denial. And as it is written in the holy books, "Turn away from evil," in the name of the Charedim, may their merit protect us, that one who engages in Torah benefits from the study of the Holy Torah in place of fasting and self-denial, and on the contrary, fasting is a deficiency for him, since through it he is prevented from engaging in Torah, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of repentance and regret in the process of spiritual purification, as emphasized by the teachings of the Arizal. It highlights that while repentance is essential, residual impurities in the soul and body remain, which can be cleansed through fasting and self-denial. The text suggests that performing mitzvot, particularly in the areas where one has sinned, serves as a remedy to purify these impurities, akin to the effects of fasting. Additionally, it notes that engaging in Torah study can be a substitute for fasting, as it also contributes to spiritual elevation.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל עפימ"ש הטו"ז (ריש הל' שבת) על מ"ד בגמ' פרק כל כתבי כל המשמר שבת כהלכתו אפי' עוע"ז כדור אנוש מוחלין לו, לכאורה איכא למידק או לא עשה תשובה שבת מאי מהני, ואי עשה תשובה שבת ל"ל, ונראה דמיירי שעשה תשובה, אלא דהתשובה לא מהני שיהא מוחלין לו, כדאיתא בפ' יוה"כ עבר על כריתות ומיתות בי"ד, תשובה תולה ומיתה ממרקת, קמ"ל כאן דאם בעשותו תשובה שומר שבת כהלכתו מהני תשובה שיהא נמחל לו עכ"ל, ועד"ז אפ"ל בדברי המדרש הנ"ל אם עשית חבילות עבירות עשה כנגדן חבילות של מצות, ובאותו האבר שחטא בו יתרצה ע"ו מעשה המצות, ומיירי בשעשה תשובה על חעטאיו, אלא שג"ז צורך לתקון נשמתו, שע"י שירבה בחבילות של מצות יתכפר לו עונו מיד, ולא יהי' התשובה תולה אלא יתמרקו כתמי הנפש מיד ע"י מעשה המצות כנ"ל.
translation: Furthermore, it can be said according to the words of the Taz (beginning of the laws of Shabbat) on the opinion in the Gemara, in the chapter "All Writings," that anyone who observes Shabbat properly, even if he is an idolater like the generation of Enosh, is forgiven. At first glance, one might wonder whether if he did not repent, what benefit is there? And if he did repent, it is unnecessary. It seems that it is speaking of one who has repented, but the repentance does not suffice for him to be forgiven, as it is stated in the chapter of Yom Kippur regarding one who transgressed the prohibitions of excision and death on the fourteenth [of Nisan]: repentance suspends [the punishment] and death atones. Here it teaches us that if, in his repentance, he observes Shabbat properly, the repentance is effective for him to be forgiven. Thus, it can also be said regarding the words of the aforementioned Midrash: if you have committed bundles of sins, do against them bundles of commandments, and in the same limb in which he sinned, let him find satisfaction through the actions of the commandments. It speaks of one who has repented for his sins, but this too is necessary for the rectification of his soul, for by increasing in bundles of commandments, his sin will be atoned for immediately, and the repentance will not be merely a suspension, but the stains of the soul will be rectified immediately through the actions of the commandments, as stated.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of repentance (teshuva) in relation to observing the Sabbath and the efficacy of good deeds (mitzvot) in atoning for sins. It emphasizes that true repentance must be accompanied by proper observance of commandments, and that engaging in numerous good deeds can counterbalance previous transgressions. The text highlights the idea that while repentance may suspend punishment, it is through the performance of mitzvot that one's soul can be purified and sins can be fully atoned. Ultimately, the act of increasing good deeds serves as a means to rectify one's spiritual state and achieve forgiveness.

passage_content: ועפי"ז אפ"ל כוונת דברי הזוה"ק באמרם זיל שאינו מועיל תשובה על חטא הידוע, וה"מ כד לא עביד תיובתא שלימתא דאיהו אתחזויא לחפאה על כל עובדוי, דידוע שזה החטא הוא בכח כל האברים ר"ל, נמצא כו נפגמו על ידו כל איבריו ב"מ, וע"כ קשה התשובה ע"ז ואינו מועיל בתשובה לחוד, כי צריך עוד למרק כתמי הנפש וכתמי כל אבריו שנתלככו בחטא זה ר"ל, אבל ע"י חבילות מצות שיעשה בכל איבריו וגידיו בצירוף התשובה יועיל לו שיתמרקו הכתמים מיד ויתכפר לו.
translation: And according to this, one can say the intention of the words of the Zohar when they say that it is not effective to repent for a known sin, and this is said when he has not completed a full repentance, for he has been revealed to be entangled in all his deeds. It is known that this sin affects all the limbs, so all his limbs are blemished through it. Therefore, repentance for this is difficult and does not help by itself, because it is necessary to also cleanse the stains of the soul and the stains of all his limbs that have become sullied by this sin. However, through bundles of mitzvot that he performs with all his limbs and sinews, in conjunction with repentance, it will help him that the stains will be cleansed immediately and he will be atoned for.
summary: The passage discusses the difficulty of repentance for a specific sin that affects all parts of the body, indicating that the sin leaves stains on both the soul and the limbs. It emphasizes that mere repentance is insufficient; rather, one must also engage in the performance of mitzvot (commandments) with all their limbs to cleanse these stains. Through this combination of sincere repentance and the fulfillment of mitzvot, one can achieve atonement and purification. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the interconnectedness of actions and their spiritual consequences.

passage_content: ובזה נבוא לבאר דברי הספרי הנ"ל שאצל ראובן החליפו זכות בחובה, וכפי' הזית רענן שהצלה של יוסף עמד לו לזכות נגד מעשה בלהה, ויובן עפימ"ש ז"ל דצדיקים במה שחוטאים בו מתרצים, ואמרו ז"ל (שבת נ"ה ע"ב) כל האומר ראובן חטא אינו אלא טועה וכו', ומה אנו מקיים וישכב את בלהה פלגש אביו. מלמד שבלבל מצעו של אביו ומעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו שכב עמה, תניא רשב"א אומר מוצל אותו צדיק מאותו עון ולא בא מעשה זו לידו וכו', עכ"ד הגמ', נמצא מבואר שחטאו של ראובן הי', מה שפגע בדעתו הקדושה של יעאע"ה וגרם לו צער לעשות היפך דעתו ורצונו, עוד שם בגמ' אחרים אומרים שתי מצעות בלבל, אחת של שכינה ואחת של אביו, עכ"ד הגמרא, אמנם ע"י הצלת יוסף תיקן שניהם מידה כנגד מידה, שגרם נחת רוח לאביו, ועי"ז שרתה עליו שכינה כמ"ש ז"ל ותחי רוח יעקב אביהם ששרתה עליו שכינה שפירשה ממנו, וכ"ז ניגרם ע"ו ראובן שהשתדל להצילו מידם, ובזה א"ש דברי הספרי הנ"ל לעולם אין מחליפין זכות בחובה חוץ משל ראובן, שהרי הזכות הי' באותו הענין עצמו שחטא, ועקר בזה שורש החטא לגמרי, ונוסף לזה עשה תשובה שלימה ומעולה כאמרז"ל עסוק הי' בשקו ותעניתו, אלא שעדיין צורך למרק כתמי הנפש, ולזה הועיל לו זכות הצלת יוסף שתיקן מידה כנגד מידה במה שחטא, ובאם יחסרו מהתנאים הנ"ל ע"ז נתנו חז"ל כללא דאין מחליפין זכות בחובה והבן.
translation: And with this, we will come to explain the words of the aforementioned Sifrei regarding Reuven, who exchanged merit for obligation. As the fresh olive tree explains, the salvation of Yosef stood for him as a merit against the act with Bilhah. This will be understood according to what our sages of blessed memory said, that the righteous, in what they sin, they are appeased, and they said (Shabbat 55b) that anyone who says Reuven sinned is merely mistaken, etc. And how do we uphold "and he lay with Bilhah, his father's concubine"? It teaches that he confused his father's bed, and the scripture considers it as if he lay with her. It is taught that Rabbi Shimon ben Azzai says that that righteous one was saved from that sin and this act did not come to him, etc. Thus, it is clear that Reuven's sin was what he disturbed the holy mind of our father Yaakov and caused him pain by acting contrary to his mind and will. Furthermore, there in the Gemara, others say he confused two beds, one of the Shechinah and one of his father, etc. However, through the salvation of Yosef, he rectified both, measure for measure, as he caused his father satisfaction, and as a result, the Shechinah rested upon him, as our sages of blessed memory said, "And the spirit of their father Yaakov revived," which rested upon him, having departed from him. All this was brought about by the sin of Reuven, who endeavored to save him from their hands. And with this, the words of the aforementioned Sifrei are explained: "One does not exchange merit for obligation except in the case of Reuven," for the merit was in that very matter in which he sinned, and fundamentally, he uprooted the root of the sin entirely. In addition to this, he made complete and excellent repentance, as our sages of blessed memory said, he was occupied with his fasting and afflictions, yet he still needed to cleanse the stains of the soul. For this, the merit of saving Yosef helped him, as he rectified measure for measure in what he sinned. And if any of the aforementioned conditions are lacking, our sages established the principle that one does not exchange merit for obligation, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the unique case of Reuven, who, despite his sin of being with Bilhah, was able to exchange his transgression for merit through his act of saving Yosef. It emphasizes the Hasidic concept that righteous individuals can rectify their wrongdoings by performing good deeds that align with their original sin, thus restoring their spiritual standing. The text highlights that Reuven's repentance and his efforts to save Yosef not only brought joy to his father, Yaakov, but also allowed the Shechinah to dwell with him again. Ultimately, it asserts that while generally merits cannot replace sins, Reuven's situation exemplifies a rare exception due to the nature of his actions and their direct connection to his sin.

passage_content: ויל"פ בזה מאמה"כ למען הציל אותו מידם להשיבו אל אביו, דלכאורה להשיבו אל אביו מיותר, ולדרכנו ר"ל שנתכוין בהצלה זו להשיבו אל אביו כדי להפיס דעתו ולהפוג צערו, או יאמר להשיבו אל אביו מוסב על ראובן, שע"י הצלת יוסף נתקרב אל אביו שבשמים ונותקן חטאו כמבואר בספרי הנ"ל, וזה אומרו למען הציל אותו מידם ובזה הועיל לעצמו להשיבו אל אביו שבשמים. ואפשר שלא השיג ראובן בשעה שהשתדל בהצלתו שעי"ז יהי' לו תקנה על מעשה בלהה, ומן השמים העלימו ממנו ידיעה זו, שהי' הכרח שירד יוסף למצרים כידוע מדברי חכמז"ל, וע"כ חשב ראובן שבמה שצוה להשליכו הבורה כבר השלים כל הצורך להצלת יוסף, וכמבואר בזוה"ק שהי' ההצלה בזה להצילו מיד בעלי בחירה, ואח"כ שב לשקו ולתעניתו כמ"ש חז"ל וישב ראובן אל הבור והיכן הי' עסוק הי' בשקו ובתעניתו על שבלבל יצועי אביו, ולא השתדל בהצלה יתירה להשיב את יוסף לאביו דייקא, ואולי רצה לתקן חטא של מעשה בלהה תחלה, כי רצה להסיר בחי' הרע תחלה ואח"כ לקיים ועשה טוב, כמ"ש ז"ל דהמצות שעושין בעודן מלוכלכים בעבירות ר"ל הם קרובים אל ההיזק יותר מאל התועלת, אך במה שהוא מצוה עוברת וחשש פקו"נ אין לשהות המצוה ולמנוע ממנה בשביל טעם הנ"ל, אולם חשב ראובן שכבר השלים מצות ההצלה במה שצוה להשליך את יוסף אל הבור להצילו מידי בעלי בחירה, ולא ידע שהצלה זו יהי' לו לתיקון חטאו, דאילו הי' יודע, על כתיפו הי' טוענו ומוליכו אצל אביו. לעשות ההצלה בשלימות לתקן החעא בשרשו מידה כ"מ.
translation: And it can be explained here from our holy sources that it was in order to save him from their hands to return him to his father. At first glance, the return to his father seems unnecessary, and according to our way of understanding, it means that this salvation was intended to return him to his father in order to calm his mind and alleviate his sorrow. Alternatively, it can be said that the return to his father refers to Reuben, who through the salvation of Joseph drew closer to his Father in Heaven, and his sin was rectified as explained in the aforementioned texts. This is the meaning of "in order to save him from their hands," and in this way, he benefited himself by returning him to his Father in Heaven. It is possible that Reuben did not realize at the time he was striving for his salvation that this would be a rectification for his act with Bilhah, and from Heaven, this knowledge was hidden from him, as it was necessary for Joseph to descend to Egypt, as is known from the words of our sages. Therefore, Reuben thought that by commanding to throw him into the pit, he had already fulfilled all that was needed for Joseph's salvation, as is explained in the Zohar that the salvation here was to save him from those with free will. Afterwards, he returned to his mourning and fasting, as our sages said, "And Reuben returned to the pit," and where was he occupied? He was in his mourning and fasting for having disturbed his father's bed, and he did not strive for an additional salvation to return Joseph specifically to his father. Perhaps he wanted to first rectify the sin of the act with Bilhah, as he wished to remove the evil aspect first and then to do good, as our sages said that the commandments performed while one is still entangled in sins are closer to harm than to benefit. However, in the case of a passing commandment and the concern for saving a life, one should not delay the commandment or refrain from it for the aforementioned reason. Nevertheless, Reuben thought that he had already completed the commandment of salvation by commanding to throw Joseph into the pit to save him from the hands of those with free will, and he did not know that this salvation would serve as a rectification for his sin. For had he known, he would have carried him on his shoulders and brought him to his father, to complete the salvation and rectify the sin at its root, measure for measure.
summary: The passage discusses Reuven's intention to save Yosef from his brothers, emphasizing that this act was not merely to return Yosef to their father, but also to alleviate the father's sorrow and to rectify Reuven's own sin regarding Bilhah. It suggests that Reuven may not have realized that his efforts to save Yosef would also serve as atonement for his past misdeed, as he believed he had fulfilled his duty by initially throwing Yosef into the pit. The text highlights the Hasidic concept of divine providence, where actions taken for one purpose can lead to unexpected spiritual rectifications, and underscores the importance of intention in fulfilling mitzvot.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש אילו הי' יודע ראובן שהכתוב כותב אחריו וישמע ראובן ויצילהו מידם וגו' להשיבו אל אביו, וכפירוש הנ"ל שזה היה תקנה לראובן להתקרב אל אביו שבשמים, על כתיפו הי' טוענו ומוליכו אצל אביו, אולם לצורך השעה העלימו מן השמים ממנו ידיעה זו וכנ"ל, כדי שירד יוסף למצרים ויתקיים גזירת ידע תדע, ואחר שנמכר יוסף נתוודע לראובן השגה זו שבהצלת יוסף הי' תלוי תקון חטאו כנ"ל ובזה יובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל הילד איננו ואני אנה אני בא ממעשה בלהה, כי הצלת יוסף הי' הזכות שעמד לו לכפר על מעשה בלהה כמבואר בספרי הנ"ל, וע"כ כשראה שהילד איננו ואין כאן הצלה. הי' מתיירא לנפשו שחזרה פגם החטא למקומו, ואיך יהי' לו תיקון על מעשה בלהה.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash: If Reuven had known that the scripture was writing about him, "And Reuven heard and rescued him from their hands," to return him to his father, and according to the above interpretation, this was a rectification for Reuven to draw closer to his Father in Heaven, for he was carrying him on his shoulders and leading him to his father. However, for the sake of the moment, this knowledge was concealed from him by Heaven, as mentioned, so that Yosef would descend to Egypt and the decree of "You shall surely know" would be fulfilled. And after Yosef was sold, this understanding was revealed to Reuven, that in the salvation of Yosef was dependent the rectification of his sin, as mentioned above. And thus, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be understood: "The child is not here, and where shall I go from the deed of Bilhah?" For the salvation of Yosef was the merit that stood for him to atone for the deed of Bilhah, as explained in the aforementioned texts. Therefore, when he saw that the child was not there and there was no salvation, he was afraid for his soul that the blemish of the sin had returned to its place, and how would he have a rectification for the deed of Bilhah.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that Reuven's actions to save Yosef were divinely orchestrated to facilitate his spiritual rectification for his past sin involving Bilhah. It suggests that Reuven was unaware of the heavenly plan that required Yosef's descent to Egypt, which was essential for fulfilling God's decree. Upon realizing that Yosef was lost, Reuven feared that his previous transgression would resurface without the opportunity for atonement. This highlights the Hasidic concept of divine providence and the interconnectedness of individual actions and spiritual redemption.

passage_content: ח"ש למדתך תורה דרך ארץ שכשהאדם עושה מצוה יהא עושה אותה בלב שמח, שאילו הי' יודע ראובן וכו', והכוונה בזה לדרכנו דהנה בעוה"ר אנו מלוכלכים בחטאים ועונות מרובים. ואם מרבים בחבילות מצות ומע"ט יזדמן לעשות ג"כ מצוה כזאת שיהי' מידה כ"מ לתיקון גמור על עונותינו, וכמ"ש בראובן שאילו הי' יודע שהצלת יוסף הוא תיקון על מעשה בלהה. הי' עוסק בה יותר בשלימות להשיבו אל אביו, אלא שאצלו הי' סיבה מן השמים להעלים ממנו ידיעה זו וכנ"ל אבל עכ"פ נלמד מזה שצריך להרבות במצות ומע"ט. וכמ"ש במדרש לעשות חבילות מצות ולעשות המצות בשלימות ובלב שמח ובזה יעשה תיקון לנפשו ויתכפרו עונותיו.
translation: In the merit of your learning Torah, the way of the land is that when a person performs a mitzvah, he should do it with a joyful heart. For if Reuven had known, etc., the intention here is to our path, for behold, in this unfortunate time we are sullied with numerous sins and transgressions. And if we increase in bundles of mitzvot and good deeds, it will also happen that we will perform such a mitzvah that will serve as a complete rectification for our sins, as it is written regarding Reuven that if he had known that saving Yosef was a rectification for the act with Bilhah, he would have engaged in it more completely to return him to his father. However, for him, there was a reason from Heaven to conceal this knowledge from him, as mentioned above. Nevertheless, we learn from this that we should increase in mitzvot and good deeds. As it is said in the Midrash, to make bundles of mitzvot and to perform the mitzvot with completeness and with a joyful heart, and through this, he will make a rectification for his soul and his transgressions will be atoned.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of performing mitzvot (commandments) with joy and completeness, as this can lead to spiritual rectification for one's sins. It draws a parallel to the biblical figure Reuven, suggesting that had he known the significance of saving Yosef, he would have engaged in the act with greater dedication. The text encourages the accumulation of mitzvot and good deeds, highlighting that such efforts can lead to atonement and healing for the soul. Ultimately, it reflects a Hasidic belief in the transformative power of joyful and intentional religious practice.

passage_content: והנה ידוע הההוכחות שבין הקב"ה וכנסת ישראל, שהקב"ה אומר לישראל שובו אלי ואשובה אליכם, וכנסת ישראל אומרת השיבני ה' אליך ונשובה, וכוונת הענין שהקב"ה רוצה שהתעוררות התשובה יבוא מצד ישראל תחלה והוא חשובה יותר, וכנסת ישראל טוענת שאין בכוחנו להתחיל בתשובה תחלה ובקשתינו שהקב"ה יעורר אותנו ויתן בלבנו רצון וכח נפשי לשוב אליו באמת, ועפי"ד ז"ל נראה לפרש סיום הפסוק השיבנו ה' אליך ונשובה חדש ימינו כקדם, דהנה קודם שיחטא האדם יש מציאות לזה שיתחיל התעוררות הרצון מצידנו, משא"כ אחר שנכשל בחטאים ונבראו ע"י מעשיו מזיקים משחיתים ומלאכים רעים, אז כמעט מן הנמנע שיבוא התעוררות תשובה מצדו, שאותן מלאכים שחורים שנבראו מן החטאים מסמין עיני האדם ולוחמים נגדו ואין נותנים מקום להתעוררות קדושה, משא"כ קודם שנכשל בחטאים אע"פ שיש יצה"ר לאדם מצד הבריאה, אעפ"כ יש מציאות שהאדם עצמו יתעורר בתשובה תחלה, וזה בקשתינו חדש ימינו כקדם, היינו כבחי' הזמן שהיינו בו תחלה קודם שנכשלנו בחטאים, ואז יהי' מציאות שנתעורר מעצמינו לשוב אליו ית"ש.
translation: And behold, it is known the proofs between the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the Congregation of Israel, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, says to Israel, "Return to Me, and I will return to you," and the Congregation of Israel says, "Bring me back, O Lord, to You, and we will return." The intention of the matter is that the Holy One, Blessed be He, wants the awakening of repentance to come from Israel first, and this is more significant. The Congregation of Israel argues that we do not have the strength to begin repentance on our own, and our request is that the Holy One, Blessed be He, should awaken us and place in our hearts the desire and spiritual strength to truly return to Him. According to our sages, it seems appropriate to interpret the conclusion of the verse "Bring us back, O Lord, to You, and we will return" as follows: Before a person sins, there is a possibility for the awakening of desire to begin from our side. However, after one has stumbled in sins and has created through his actions harmful and destructive forces and evil angels, it is almost impossible for the awakening of repentance to come from him, as those dark angels that were created from the sins blind a person's eyes and fight against him, leaving no room for a holy awakening. In contrast, before one has stumbled in sins, even though there is an evil inclination in a person due to creation, there is still a possibility for the person himself to awaken to repentance first. This is our request: "Renew our days as of old," meaning in the state of time that we were in before we stumbled in sins, and then there will be a possibility for us to awaken on our own to return to Him, Blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the dynamic relationship between God and the Jewish people regarding repentance. It emphasizes that while God desires the initial awakening to repentance to come from Israel, the people argue that they lack the strength to initiate this process due to the negative influences of their sins. The text highlights the struggle against the "evil forces" created by sin, which hinder the ability to return to God, contrasting this with the potential for self-initiated repentance before sinning. Ultimately, the plea is for a renewal of spiritual vitality akin to the state before transgressions, allowing for genuine self-driven repentance.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל מעולם לא חטא אדם לפני ועשה תשובה וכו', דהנה באדה"ר וקין שעשו תשובה אין רבותא כ"כ, שהרי הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו דיבר עמהם לעוררם על התשובה, וכמו שאמרו ז"ל (במד"ר פכ"א) ועתה פן ישלח ידו וגו' אין ועתה אלא תשובה מלמד שפתח לו הקב"ה פתח של תשובה, וכן בקין אמר לו הקב"ה אם תטיב שאת וגו' שפתח לו הקב"ה פתח של תשובה, משא"כ ראובן פתח בתשובה תחלה והתחיל באתערותא דלתתא וזה חשוב יותר, וז"פ המדרש מעולם לא חטא אדם לפני ועשה תשובה ואתה פתחת דייקא בתשובה תחלה, רצה לומר שאתה בעצמך היית הפותח טפח. בבחינת שובו אלי ואשובה אליכם, חייך שבן בנך עומד ופותח בתשובה תחלה, שנאמר שובה ישראל עד ה' אלקיך, ודרשו רז"ל במדרש שובה ישראל עד ה"נ עד שהוא במדת רחמים ואם לאו אלקיך, עד לא יתעביד סנגוריא קטגוריא, ולדרכינו יאמר שובה ישראל עד ה' אלקיך היינו עד שלא יבוא ההתעוררות מה', תשתדל לשוב תחלה ומעצמך תתעורר לתשובה והיינו מידה כ"מ כמו שעשה ראובן שפתח בתשובה תחלה.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash, that no man ever sinned before Me and repented, etc. Behold, with Adam HaRishon and Cain, who repented, there is not so much greatness, for the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself spoke with them to awaken them to repentance, as our Sages of blessed memory said (in Midrash Rabba, Parashat 21), "And now, lest he send forth his hand, etc." — "And now" refers only to repentance, teaching that the Holy One, blessed be He, opened for him a door of repentance. Likewise, with Cain, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "If you do well, will you not be accepted?" — the Holy One, blessed be He, opened for him a door of repentance. In contrast, Reuben opened with repentance first and began with an awakening from below, and this is more significant. Thus, the Midrash states that no man ever sinned before Me and repented, and you specifically opened with repentance first, meaning that you yourself were the one to open a handbreadth. In the aspect of "Return to Me, and I will return to you," as surely as your grandson stands and opens with repentance first, as it is said, "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God," and our Sages of blessed memory expounded in the Midrash, "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God" — this means until he is in a state of mercy, and if not, "your God," until he does not act as a defense attorney and an accuser. And according to our path, it is said, "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God," meaning that until the awakening does not come from the Holy One, blessed be He, you should strive to return first and awaken yourself to repentance, and this is a measure everywhere, as Reuben did, who opened with repentance first.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of individual initiative in repentance, contrasting the responses of Adam and Cain, who were directly prompted by God, with Reuben, who initiated his own repentance. It highlights the idea that true repentance begins with a personal awakening, as illustrated by the verse "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God," which suggests that one should strive to return to God independently before divine intervention occurs. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the power of human agency in the process of teshuva (repentance) and the importance of self-motivation in spiritual growth.

passage_content: ונקדים מ"ש בספה"ק בני יששכר (מאמרי חודש סיון מאמר ב') על מ"ש רז"ל (בתנחומא פ' האזינו) כתיב ישא ד' פניו אליך וכתיב אשר לא ישא פנים, עשה תשובה ישא ד' פניו, יכול לכל ת"ל אליך ולא לאומה"ע עכ"ד המדרש, הרי שהתשובה אינה מועלת רק לישראל ולא לאומה"ע, עיי"ש שהביא בשם הרב בעל לימודי ד' הרבה טעמים ע"ז. ואפ"ל עוד טעם לדבר זה עפי"ד הרמ"ע מפאנו זלה"ה בספרו עשרה מאמרות, שהקשה על מה דאמרו רז"ל (קידושין מ' ע"ב) לעולם יראה אדם עצמו כאילו חציו חייב וחציו זכאי, עשה מצוה אחת אשריו שהכריע עצמו לכף זכות, והלא הם אמרו (ב"ק דף נ' ע"ב) כל האומר הקב"ה וותרן הוא יוותרו חייו וכו', וא"כ איך נדון האדם לזכות לפי רוב הזכיות ועכ"פ יש בידו עבירות, ותירץ דדין התורה כן הוא אחרי רבים להטות ואין זה ויתור, דדינא הכי עפ"י תורה, ובספה"ק בני יששכר הביא בשם הרה"ק הר"ר זושא זלה"ה לפרש בזה נוסח הפיוט באין מליץ יושר מול מגיד פשע תגיד ליעקב דבר חוק ומשפט וצדקנו וכו', דלפי שישראל מקיימין החקים שבתורה אע"פ שאין יודעים טעם בדבר, כמו"כ מדה כנגד מדה צריך הקב"ה לכפר חטאינו אף בלי טעם, דכך הוא המדה בתורה לדון מדה כנגד מדה, וז"פ באין מליץ יושר מול מגיד פשע, תגיד ליעקב דבר חוק ומשפט, מה שישראל מקיימין החקים בלו שום טעם, ועי"ז וצדקנו במשפט המלך המשפט, ואין זה נקרא ויתור כיון שכך הוא משפט התורה את"ד ז"ל, הרי מבואר שעפ"י דיני התוה"ק ובכח שמירת התוה"ק הקב"ה מכפר עונותיהם של ישראל, וא"כ אין מידה זו נוהגת כ"א לישראל מקיימי התוה"ק ולא לאומה"ע,
translation:
And we will precede with what is written in the holy book Bnei Yissachar (Ma'amarim of the month of Sivan, Ma'amar 2) regarding what our sages of blessed memory said (in Tanchuma, Parashat Ha'azinu): It is written, "The Lord will lift His face to you," and it is written, "He does not lift faces." If one repents, He will lift His face to him; one might think this applies to all nations, but it does not. Thus, the Midrash concludes, it is clear that repentance is effective only for Israel and not for the nations of the world. There, it brings in the name of the Rabbi, the author of Limudei D', many reasons for this. 

And I can suggest another reason for this according to the words of the Ram'a of Pano, may his memory be blessed, in his book "Ten Sayings," who questioned what our sages of blessed memory said (Kiddushin 40b): "A person should always see himself as if half of him is guilty and half is meritorious. If he performs one mitzvah, fortunate is he, for he has tilted himself to the side of merit." But they also said (Baba Kamma 50b) that anyone who says that the Holy One, blessed be He, is lenient, his life will be lenient, etc. If so, how can a person be judged for merit based on the majority of merits when he still has transgressions? He answered that the law of the Torah is such that we follow the majority, and this is not leniency, for this is the law according to the Torah.

And in the holy book Bnei Yissachar, he brought in the name of the holy Rabbi, Rabbi Zusha, may his memory be blessed, to explain the wording of the piyyut: "There is no advocate for righteousness against the accuser of sin; declare to Jacob the word of law and justice, and our righteousness," etc. This is because Israel fulfills the statutes in the Torah even though they do not know the reason for the matter. Likewise, measure for measure, the Holy One, blessed be He, must atone for our sins even without a reason, for this is the measure in the Torah to judge measure for measure. And thus, in the phrase "There is no advocate for righteousness against the accuser of sin," declare to Jacob the word of law and justice, what Israel fulfills the statutes without any reason, and through this, "and our righteousness in the judgment of the King," the judgment, and this is not called leniency since this is the law of the Torah, as you said, may your memory be blessed. 

It is clear that according to the laws of the holy Torah and by the merit of observing the holy Torah, the Holy One, blessed be He, atones for the sins of Israel. Therefore, this measure applies only to Israel who observe the holy Torah and not to the nations of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the unique relationship between God and the Jewish people regarding repentance and forgiveness, emphasizing that true repentance leads to divine favor specifically for Israel, not for other nations. It references the concept that while individuals may feel burdened by their sins, the Torah's principles allow for a favorable judgment based on one's merits, as God responds to the observance of His commandments. The text highlights that Israel's commitment to the Torah, even without understanding its reasons, invokes divine mercy, illustrating a reciprocal relationship where adherence to the commandments leads to forgiveness. Ultimately, this theological insight underscores that the divine justice system operates distinctly for those who uphold the Torah, reinforcing the special status of the Jewish people in the eyes of God.

passage_content: וכמו כן לענין התשובה דאיתא במדרש ילקוט תהלים כ"ה) שאלו לחכמה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל חטאים תרדוף רעה, שאלו לנבואה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל הנפש החוטאת היא תמות, שאלו לתורה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל יביא אשם ויתכפר לו וכו', עכ"ד המדרש, וכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל (הל' תשובה פ"ז ה"ה) אין ישראל נגאלין אלא בתשובה, וכבר הבטיחה תורה שסוף ישראל לעשות תשובה בסוף גלותן ומיד הן נגאלין שנאמר והי' כי יבואו עליך כל הדברים וגו' ושבת עד ה' אלקיך ושב ה"א וגו', ועכ"פ התשובה מועלת רק בכח התוה"ק, והבטחת התשובה ניתנה לנו בתורה והתינח לישראל שקיבלו את התורה דין הוא שיועיל להם תשובה, משא"כ האומות שלא רצו לקבל את התורה מהיכי תיתי יועיל להם תשובה, ובאותן המצות שנצטוו בני נח לא מצינו בהם רמז על תשובה, א"כ התשובה הוא רק בכח התורה ומי שקיבל את התורה יש לו חלק בה משא"כ אומה"ע.
translation: And likewise regarding repentance, as it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut Tehillim (25): They asked wisdom, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" She said, "Evil shall pursue sinners." They asked prophecy, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" She said, "The soul that sins shall die." They asked the Torah, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" She said, "He shall bring a guilt offering and he shall be atoned for," etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. And the Rambam, may his memory be blessed (Hilchot Teshuvah 7:5), wrote that Israel is not redeemed except through repentance, and the Torah has already promised that in the end, Israel will repent at the end of their exile, and immediately they will be redeemed, as it is said, "And it shall be when all these things come upon you... and you return to the Lord your God and obey His voice," etc. Nevertheless, repentance is effective only through the power of the Holy Torah, and the promise of repentance was given to us in the Torah. It is reasonable that for Israel, who received the Torah, it is just that repentance should be effective for them, whereas for the nations who did not wish to accept the Torah, how can it be that repentance should be effective for them? And in those commandments that the children of Noah were commanded, we do not find any hint of repentance. Therefore, repentance is only through the power of the Torah, and whoever has accepted the Torah has a share in it, unlike the nations of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of repentance (teshuva) in Jewish thought, emphasizing that true redemption for the Jewish people is contingent upon their return to God through teshuva, as promised in the Torah. It cites various sources, including a Midrash and Maimonides, to illustrate that while the Torah guarantees the efficacy of repentance for Israel, it does not extend the same assurance to the nations who did not accept the Torah. The text underscores that the power of repentance is intrinsically linked to the Torah, which serves as the foundation for Israel's spiritual restoration. In contrast, the nations, bound by the Noahide laws, lack a similar framework for repentance.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הגמ' (ע"ז דף ט' ע"א) תנדב"א ששת אלפים שנה הוי עלמא, ב' אלפים תוהו ב' אלפים תורה ב' אלפים ימות המשיח וכו', ב' אלפים תורה מאימת, או נימא ממתן תורה עד השתא ליכא כולי האי וכו', אלא מואת הנפש אשר עשו בחרן, פירש"י ומתרגמינן דשעבידו לאורייתא, שאברהם אבינו הדריך את בניו לשמור את דרך ה' ועשה הכנה לקבלת התורה ע"כ ממנו התחילו ב' אלפים תורה, אמנם עיקר קבלת התורה לא הי' רק אחר שיצאו ישראל ממצרים ומשה קבל את התורה מסיני, מאז ניתן לישראל כח התורה בתוקפו, ומאאע"ה עד קבלת התורה הי' רק בבחי' הכשר מצוה, ואעפ"כ נחשבו הב' אלפים תורה מאברהם אבינו שהוא התחיל בה, וה"ה כמו הכשר והכנה לקבלת התורה, והנה ראובן עשה תשובה, אלא שעדיין הי' לפני קבלת התורה ולא הי' אצלם כח התורה בשלימות כ"א בבחי' הכנה, ע"כ לא הי' אפשר להעלות תשובתו של ראובן במקום שצדיקים גמורים אינן יכולין לעמוד, ובזה יובנו דברי המדרש הנ"ל כיון שבא לברך את ראובן א"ל איני לא מרחקך ולא מקרבך, והכוונה כיון שעדיין אין כח התורה בשלימותו, איני יכול לקרבך ולהעמידך במקום שבעלי תשובה עומדים, אלא הרי אנו תולה אותך ברפיון עד שיבא משה שכתוב בו ומשה עלה אל האלקים והוריד התורה לישראל. ושם כתוב מפורש הבטחת התשובה, ע"כ הוא יכול לקרבך ולהעלותך עד מקום שבעלי תשובה עומדין, כיון שבא משם התחיל מקרבו יחי ראובן ואל ימות.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 9a) that states: "Six thousand years is the duration of the world; two thousand years of chaos, two thousand years of Torah, and two thousand years of the Messianic era," etc. The two thousand years of Torah, from when? Or should we say from the giving of the Torah until now, there is not so much? Rather, from the souls that were made in Haran, Rashi explains, and we translate that they were enslaved to the Torah, that our forefather Abraham guided his sons to keep the way of the Lord and made preparations to receive the Torah. Therefore, from him began the two thousand years of Torah. However, the main acceptance of the Torah was only after Israel left Egypt and Moses received the Torah at Sinai. Since then, the power of the Torah was given to Israel in its fullness, and from Abraham until the giving of the Torah, it was only in the aspect of preparation for the commandment. Nevertheless, the two thousand years of Torah are considered from our forefather Abraham, who initiated it, and it is the same as the preparation and readiness to receive the Torah. And behold, Reuben repented, but he was still before the giving of the Torah, and the power of the Torah was not complete with them, only in the aspect of preparation. Therefore, it was not possible to elevate Reuben's repentance to a place where complete righteous individuals cannot stand. And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash, for when he came to bless Reuben, he said to him, "I am neither distancing you nor bringing you closer," meaning that since the power of the Torah is not in its completeness, I cannot bring you closer and place you in the place where penitents stand. Rather, we are holding you in a state of slackness until Moses comes, as it is written, "And Moses ascended to God and brought down the Torah to Israel." And there it is explicitly written the promise of repentance; therefore, he can bring you closer and elevate you to the place where penitents stand, since he came from there. Let Reuben live and not die.
summary: The passage discusses the progression of spiritual history in terms of the six thousand years of the world, divided into periods of chaos, Torah, and the Messianic era. It emphasizes that while Abraham initiated the path of Torah observance, the full power of the Torah was only realized after the Israelites received it at Sinai. The text highlights that prior to this revelation, even acts of repentance, like that of Reuven, lacked the complete strength of the Torah, which is necessary for true elevation. Ultimately, it asserts that only through Moses, who brought the Torah to the people, can one achieve the status of a true penitent.

passage_content: ומ"ש יחי ראובן ואל ימות לכאורה הוא כפל לשון, ועוד שהרי כבר לא הי' ראובן בעוה"ז, אמנם יבואר עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, דהנה ראובן עשה תשובה שלימתא, והחליפו לו זכות בחובה, שע"י הצלת יוסף נתמרק לגמרי הפגם של מעשה בלהה כמבואר בספרי הנ"ל, ועי"ז הי' תיקון לנפשו בעודו בחיים חיותו ולא הוצרך לתקנת המיתה כדי למרק פגמי הנפש, וז"ש משרע"ה וחי ראובן ואל ימות, שנתקבלה תשובתו בחייו ולא יצטרך למיתה בשביל למרק כתמי הנפש, ואף שלראובן לא הי' נפק"מ בזה בימי משרע"ה, מ"מ נכתבה בתוה"ק להורות לדורות הבאים שבחי' תשובה כזו בצירוף חבילות של מצות מועלת אף בחיים הבוי"ת יזכנו לזה בב"א.
translation: And what is meant by "Let Reuben live and not die" is seemingly a redundancy, and moreover, since Reuben was no longer in this world. However, it can be explained according to our earlier approach, that Reuben made a complete repentance, and his merit was exchanged for a liability, for through the salvation of Joseph, the blemish of the act with Bilhah was entirely rectified, as explained in the aforementioned texts. And as a result, there was a rectification for his soul while he was still alive, and he did not need the rectification of death to atone for the blemishes of the soul. This is what Moshe Rabbeinu said, "And let Reuben live and not die," that his repentance was accepted in his lifetime, and he would not need to die in order to atone for the stains of the soul. And although for Reuben this was not relevant in the days of Moshe Rabbeinu, it was nonetheless written in the Torah to instruct future generations that such a life of repentance, combined with bundles of mitzvot, is effective even in the life of this world. May we be worthy of this in the future, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "Let Reuben live and not die," highlighting that Reuben achieved complete repentance, which allowed him to rectify his past sins without needing death as a means of atonement. This reflects the idea that sincere repentance, combined with the performance of mitzvot, can lead to spiritual rectification while one is still alive. The text emphasizes that Reuben's repentance was accepted during his lifetime, serving as a lesson for future generations about the power of repentance and good deeds in achieving spiritual elevation.
