passage_content: ואולי הטעם שהי' הכרח להעלמה הזאת, הוא מפני גזירת הגלות שהיתה מוכרחת. כי אלמלא הו' יע"א חי בתוך בנ"י באתגליא היו ישראל בטוחים בכחו וזכותו, ולא היו נכנעים לקבל על עצמם עול גלות ושעבוד, וכמו שמצינו במעשה דשכם שנא' ויבואו על העיר בטח, ואמרז"ל במד"ר בטוחים היו על כחו של זקן, ואף שלא קבלו ממנו רשות הסכימו להרוג כל אנשי העיר ולא פחדו מיושב הארץ הכנעני והפריזי כו הוו בטוחים בזכותו הרם של יע"א, גם כי אלמלא הי' חי בתוכנו באתגליא היו האומה"ע נכנעים מפני גאון קדושתו ולא היו מעיזים פניהם לשעבד בהם בישראל, ולפי שהיתה גזירת הגלות מוכרחת ע"כ הי' הכרח להעלמה הזאת לטעם הגלות, והנה השבעים הקדושים למדו והשיגו התורה קודם שניתנה, וראו ששנותיו של יע"א נמנו בתורה שלא על הסדר רק באמצע שנות חייו, השיגו מזה בחי' הסתר והעלמה משנות חייו שהוא לטעם הגלות, וע"כ נסתם עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, וא"ש מקום הסתומה אצל ויחי יעקב, שממה שמנה הכתוב כאן שנות חייו, השיגו השעבוד והגלות המעותד לבוא אליהם, ונסתמו עיניהם ולבם מיד, ולפי"ז א"ש דכל הני ג' טעמי שהזכירו חז"ל בטעם הסתומה חדא נינהו. ומ"ש רז"ל שסתם ממנו כל הצרות שבעולם, יתפרש לדרכנו על בחי' הנ"ל, דבאמת אמרז"ל במדרש ילקוט (הובא לעיל) שיע"א מרגיש בצערן של ישראל במערת המכפלה יותר מכל האבות, ולכאורה כיון שנסתמו עיניהם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד איך יצדק לומר שסתם מיע"א כל הצרות שבעולם. אמנם הכוונה שמה שמרגיש בצרתם של ישראל הוא בדרך הסתר והעלמה, ואלמלי הי' חי בתוכנו באתגליא, היו ישראל בטוחים בזכותו ולא היו נכנעים לגזירת השעבוד, כי בצרתם לו צר וראויים להוושע בזכותו, וע"כ סתם ממנו כל הצרות, ר"ל שהם לגבי' בבחי' סתומה והעלמה, והשבטים הקדושים השיגו בחי' העלמה זו כנ"ל וע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם מצרת השעבוד, ולטעם זה רצה יע"א לנחמם ולגלות להם בחי' הגאולה, אלא שלא הי' רצון העליון בכך ונסתם ממנו, נמצא דכל הני טעמי על קוטב א' נאמרו בטעם הסתומה והבן.
translation: And perhaps the reason for this concealment was due to the decree of exile that was necessary. For if the Holy One, blessed be He, were revealed among the Children of Israel, they would have been secure in His power and merit, and they would not have submitted to accept upon themselves the yoke of exile and servitude, as we find in the story of Shechem, where it is said, "And they came upon the city securely," and our Sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah that they were secure in the strength of the elder, and even though they did not receive permission from him, they agreed to kill all the inhabitants of the city and were not afraid of the Canaanite and Perizzite who dwelled in the land, for they were secure in the great merit of the Holy One, blessed be He. Also, if He were alive among us in revelation, the nations of the world would submit before the glory of His holiness and would not dare to oppress Israel. And since the decree of exile was necessary, therefore this concealment was essential for the reason of the exile. Behold, the holy seventy learned and grasped the Torah before it was given, and they saw that the years of the Holy One, blessed be He, were counted in the Torah not in order but in the middle of His years, and they understood from this the aspect of concealment and hiding from His years, which is for the reason of the exile. Therefore, the eyes and hearts of Israel were sealed from the distress of servitude, and it is clear why the sealing is mentioned in connection with "And Jacob lived," for from the fact that the scripture here enumerates his years, they understood the servitude and the exile that was destined to come upon them, and their eyes and hearts were sealed immediately. According to this, it is clear that all these three reasons mentioned by our Sages of blessed memory regarding the reason for the sealing are one. And what our Sages of blessed memory said that he sealed from him all the troubles of the world can be explained in our way regarding the above aspect, for indeed our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash Yalkut (as mentioned above) that the Holy One, blessed be He, feels the pain of Israel in the Cave of Machpelah more than all the patriarchs. And seemingly, since the eyes of Israel were sealed from the distress of servitude, how can it be said that he sealed from the Holy One, blessed be He, all the troubles of the world? However, the intention is that what he feels regarding the distress of Israel is in a manner of concealment and hiding, and if He were alive among us in revelation, Israel would be secure in His merit and would not submit to the decree of servitude, for in their distress He is not distressed, and they are worthy of salvation in His merit. Therefore, he sealed from him all the troubles, meaning that they are regarding him in a manner of concealment and hiding. And the holy tribes grasped this aspect of concealment as mentioned above, and therefore their eyes and hearts were sealed from the distress of servitude. For this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to comfort them and reveal to them the aspect of redemption, but the Divine will was not so, and it was sealed from him. Thus, all these reasons were stated on one pole regarding the reason for the sealing, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of divine concealment during the exile, suggesting that had God's presence been openly felt among the Jewish people, they would not have accepted the yoke of oppression. It highlights the idea that the suffering of the Jewish people is perceived by the patriarch Jacob in a hidden manner, reflecting a deeper understanding of their plight. The text emphasizes that this concealment serves a purpose, allowing for the eventual revelation of redemption, while also illustrating the interconnectedness of suffering and divine compassion. Ultimately, it conveys that the concealment of God's presence is integral to the experience of exile and the anticipation of future redemption.

passage_content: ב או"י בדרך רמז מוסר לפרש אמרם ז"ל נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, בהקדם דברי המדרש כל הולך על גחון שם מת יעקב ע"כ והוא פלא, ויתבאר עפימ"ש בספה"ק דחטאת נעורים ר"ל מסמין עיני האדם ועיני שכלו מלראות האמת, גם נסתם לבו מלהרגיש ולכוין לומר דיבורים אמיתיים לפני הבוי"ת, והנה היו ישראל בגלות מצרים ערות הארץ מקום מזוהם מאוד, והיו הנסיונות גדולים מאוד בענין שמירת הברית, עד שלא הי' אפשר בדרך הטבע להנצל, אך אמרז"ל בזכות יוסף שגדר עצמו מן הערוה, בזכותו נגדרו כל ישראל מן העריות ובזכות שרה אמנו נגדרו כל הנשים מן הערוה עיי"ש, ובזכותם הגדול סייעו להם מן השמים להתגבר על הנסיונות העצומים ולהיגדר מן העריות, אמנם כל זמן שהי' יעקב אבינו קיים, לגודל שלימותו במידה זו, שלא פגם בה מעולם ובן פ"ד שנים אמר כחו וראשית אוני, כל אותו הדור שזכו להיות עמו בצוותא חדא היו מושללים מבחי' תאוה וחמדה והרהור וראי' האסורה, אבל אחרי הסתלקות יעאע"ה אף שניצולו ישראל מבחי' הרע במעשה כאמרז"ל א' היתה ופרסמה הכתוב, אולם אם מידי עבירה יצאו מידי הרהור לא יצאו וע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם מצרת השעבוד הרוחנית, כי כשלון העינים גורם ר"ל להרהור הלב, כאומרם ז"ל עין רואה והלב חומד, ועי"ז נסתם הלב ונסמית העין מבחי' הקדושה, וזהו נרמז בטעם הסתומה שאמרו רז"ל שנסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד של מצרים, ונרמז הסתומה אצל ויחי יעקב, כי דבר זה שהיו מרגישים בסתימת העינים והלב, בעומאת מצרים ערות הארץ אינו בדרך הטבע וזכו לזה רק מפני שהיו מסתופפים בצל הקודש של יע"א, ועל שהי' יעקב אבינו במצרים י"ז שנה החליש כח הטומאה ועל כן נשאר בגופם הרגש קודש שהרגישו מיד סתומת העינים והלב, והגורם לזה הי' ויחי יעקב וגו', וע"כ נרמז הסתומה אצל ויחי יעקב,
translation: In the way of allusion, it is taught that the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed due to the distress of servitude. To preface the words of the Midrash, "Whoever goes on their belly, there lies the dead of Jacob," and this is a wonder. It will be explained according to what is written in the holy books that the sin of youth, God forbid, blinds the eyes of a person and the eyes of their intellect from seeing the truth. Also, their heart is closed from feeling and directing themselves to speak true words before the Blessed One. Behold, Israel was in the exile of Egypt, a land very defiled, and the trials were exceedingly great regarding the matter of guarding the covenant, to the extent that it was not possible by natural means to be saved. However, our sages said that through the merit of Joseph, who guarded himself from immorality, all of Israel was safeguarded from illicit relations, and through the merit of our matriarch Sarah, all the women were safeguarded from immorality, as stated there. And through their great merit, they were assisted from the heavens to overcome the immense trials and to guard themselves from immorality. However, as long as our forefather Jacob was alive, due to his great perfection in this measure, that he never blemished it, and at the age of 147 he said, "My strength and the beginning of my might," all that generation who were privileged to be with him together were exempt from the aspect of desire, greed, and forbidden thoughts and sights. But after the passing of Jacob, even though Israel was saved from the aspect of evil in action, as our sages said, "One was and the scripture publicized it," however, if they were saved from sin, they were not saved from thought. Therefore, their eyes and hearts were closed due to the distress of spiritual servitude, for the failure of the eyes causes, God forbid, the heart to ponder, as they said, "The eye sees and the heart covets." And thus, the heart was closed and the eye was sealed from the aspect of holiness. This is alluded to in the reason for the closing, as our sages said, that the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed due to the distress of the servitude of Egypt. The closing is alluded to in "And Jacob lived," for this matter that they felt the closing of the eyes and heart, in the depth of Egypt, the land of nakedness, is not by natural means, and they merited this only because they were sheltered in the shadow of holiness of our forefather. And because Jacob our forefather was in Egypt for 17 years, he weakened the power of impurity, and therefore, the feeling of holiness remained in their bodies, which made them immediately aware of the closing of the eyes and heart. The cause of this was "And Jacob lived," and therefore, the closing is alluded to in "And Jacob lived."
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual blindness and heart's closure of the Israelites during their enslavement in Egypt, attributed to the overwhelming challenges and moral decay of the environment. It emphasizes that while they were physically safe from sin due to the merit of figures like Joseph and Sarah, their spiritual struggles persisted after Jacob's passing. Jacob's presence in Egypt had weakened the forces of impurity, allowing the Israelites to maintain a sense of holiness, which was lost after his departure. The text highlights the connection between spiritual awareness and the presence of righteous individuals, illustrating the profound impact of Jacob's life on the spiritual state of his descendants.

passage_content: והעצה להינצל מן החטא והרהור הרע, ע"י שידבק האדם מחשבתו ולבו בתוה"ק, כמ"ש הרמב"ם אין ההרהור מצוי אלא בלב פני מן החכמה, והאמת כי יעקב אבינו לא מת אלא שנעלם ונסתר מעינינו ובזכותו אנו מתקיימים בנסיונות הגלות ואמרז"ל ההולך בדרכי אבות הקב"ה מתקומם עליו בזכות אבות (הובא בישמח משה פ' עקב) והגודר א"ע מן העריות ומשמר עיניו ולבו מן החטא אצלו לא מת יעקב, ובזכותו ינצל ויתקיים ויזכה לתוס' קדושה מן השמים, אך מי שהולך ר"ל אחר תאות לבו בעצת היצה"ר, תמן מת יעקב ונפסק הקשר ר"ל וז"ש במדרש כל הולך על גחון היינו בעצת הנחש הוא הס"מ תמן מת יעקב, השי"ת יזכנו להתדבק בו ות' ובתוה"ק באמת ובתמים, ויראו עינינו וישמח לבנו בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And the advice to be saved from sin and evil thoughts is for a person to attach his mind and heart to the Holy Torah, as the Rambam states that evil thoughts are only found in the heart that is distant from wisdom. And the truth is that our forefather Jacob did not die, but rather he was hidden and concealed from our eyes, and in his merit we are sustained through the trials of exile. And our sages of blessed memory said that one who walks in the ways of the Holy One, blessed be He, is upheld by the merit of the fathers (as brought in Yismach Moshe, Parashat Eikev). And one who guards himself from immorality and protects his eyes and heart from sin, for him Jacob has not died, and in his merit he will be saved and sustained and will merit an increase of holiness from Heaven. However, one who, heaven forbid, follows the desires of his heart by the counsel of the evil inclination, there Jacob has died, and the connection is severed, heaven forbid. And this is what is said in the Midrash: "Anyone who crawls on his belly" refers to the counsel of the serpent, which is the evil inclination; there Jacob has died. May the Holy One, blessed be He, grant us the merit to cling to Him and to the Torah in truth and sincerity, and may our eyes see and our hearts rejoice in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of connecting one's thoughts and heart to the Torah as a means to avoid sin and negative thoughts. It highlights the belief that Jacob, our forefather, remains spiritually alive and present, providing strength and support during the challenges of exile, particularly for those who adhere to the ways of the patriarchs. Those who guard themselves from immoral desires and focus on holiness are assured of Jacob's continued influence, while succumbing to base desires leads to a severed connection with him. Ultimately, the text expresses a yearning for divine closeness and the revelation of God's glory.

passage_content: ויחי יעקב בארץ מצרים שבע עשרה שנה וגו', פי' רש"י ז"ל למה פרשה זו סתומה לפי שכשמת יע"א נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד עכ"ל אמנם יש סתירה לזה ממה דאיתא במד"ר (פ' שמות) ואלה שמות בנ"י הבאים מצרימה וכי היום באים, והלא ימים רבים היו להם שבאו למצרים, אלא כ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים לא הי' להם משוי של מצרים, מת יוסף נתנו עליהם משוי של מצרים, לפיכך כתיב הבאים כאילו אותו יום נכנסו למצרים ע"כ, הרי שלא התחיל השעבוד כ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים. וצ"ב אמרם ז"ל שמשמת יעקב מיד התחיל השעבוד, ועוד יש סתירה ממה דאיתא במד"ר כ"ז שאחד מן השבטים הי' קיים לא התחיל השעבוד, עוד איתא במדרש עה"פ וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא, כ"ז שהי' אחד מן הדור קיים היינו אחד מע' נפש שירדו למצרים לא הי' שעבוד, ובפדר"א משמע שלא התחיל השעבוד עד ל' שנה לפני יציאתם ממצרים. וכשיצאו בנו אפרים אז התחילה השעבוד, הרי לך חמש זמנים חלוקים בדברי רז"ל בענין התחלת השעבוד וצ"ב להשוותם, גם ראוי להבין שיטת הפרדר"א דתינח שנענשו בני אפרים לפי שמיהרו את הקץ ויצאו בלא רשות ועברו על שבועת הגלות, אבל כל ישראל מה חטאו והרי לא נעלו חלק בחטאם ומדוע נענשו בעונם שהתחילה בהם השעבוד מזמן ההוא וצ"ב.
translation: And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt for seventeen years, etc. Rashi explains why this section is closed: because when he passed away, may his memory be blessed, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed due to the distress of the servitude. However, there is a contradiction to this from what is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot): "And these are the names of the children of Israel who came to Egypt." And is it today that they came? Were they not many days in coming to Egypt? Rather, as long as Joseph was alive, they did not have the burden of Egypt upon them. When Joseph died, they placed upon them the burden of Egypt. Therefore, it is written "the coming" as if they entered Egypt that very day. Thus, the servitude did not begin as long as Joseph was alive. It is puzzling what our sages said that immediately upon Jacob's death, the servitude began. Furthermore, there is a contradiction from what is stated in the Midrash: as long as one of the tribes was alive, the servitude did not begin. It is also stated in the Midrash regarding the verse "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and all that generation": as long as one from that generation was alive, meaning one of the seventy souls who went down to Egypt, there was no servitude. And in Pesiqta Rabbati, it seems that the servitude did not begin until thirty years before their departure from Egypt. When Ephraim's son went out, then the servitude began. Here you have five different times mentioned by our sages regarding the beginning of the servitude, and it is puzzling to reconcile them. It is also appropriate to understand the opinion of Pesiqta Rabbati: this can be understood that the children of Ephraim were punished because they hastened the end and left without permission, violating the oath of exile. But what sin did all of Israel commit, as they did not partake in their sin? And why were they punished with the consequence that the servitude began with them at that time? This is also puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses the complexities surrounding the onset of the Egyptian servitude of the Israelites, highlighting differing opinions among the sages regarding when this oppression began. It emphasizes that as long as Joseph was alive, the Israelites did not experience the burdens of servitude, suggesting a protective influence of righteous individuals. The text raises questions about the collective punishment of the Israelites for the actions of the tribe of Ephraim, who hastened the redemption, and seeks to reconcile these theological discrepancies. Ultimately, it reflects on the interplay between divine providence, human actions, and the unfolding of historical events in the context of Jewish suffering and redemption.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הגמ' (פסחים פ"ז ע"ב) א"ר אושעיא מאי דכתיב (שופטים ה') צדקת פרזונו בישראל, צדקה עשה הקב"ה בישראל שפזרן לבין האומות עכ"ד הגמ', לכאורה לפי דרשתם ז"ל צ"ב קישור רישא דקרא שם (שופטים ה') מקול מחצצים בין משאבים שם יתנו צדקות ד' צדקת פרזונו בישראל, ועיין פירש"י והמפרשים שפי' בו עפ"י פשועו, שהוא שיר והודי' להקב"ה על מפלת סיסרא עיי"ש, אולם לפי דרשתם ז"ל רישא דקרא אין לו ביאור וקישור.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Gemara (Pesachim 87b): Rabbi Oshaya said, "What is written (Judges 5): 'The righteousness of His rulers in Israel'? The Holy One, blessed be He, did a kindness for Israel by scattering them among the nations." Thus far the Gemara. At first glance, according to their interpretation, it is difficult to connect the beginning of the verse there (Judges 5) with the sound of the trumpets between the wells, where they will give the tithes of the Lord, the righteousness of His rulers in Israel. And see Rashi's explanation and the commentators who explained it according to its simple meaning, that it is a song and a praise to the Holy One, blessed be He, for the downfall of Sisera. However, according to their interpretation, the beginning of the verse has no explanation or connection.
summary: The passage discusses a Talmudic interpretation of the verse "צדקת פרזונו בישראל" (Judges 5:11), highlighting that God's act of scattering the Jewish people among the nations is seen as a form of righteousness. It raises a question about the connection between the beginning of the verse and the subsequent themes of praise and gratitude to God for the defeat of Sisera. The text emphasizes the complexity of understanding divine justice and the relationship between Israel and the nations, reflecting key Hasidic themes of faith and the hidden workings of divine providence.

passage_content: עוד דרשו רז"ל בהאי קרא (בתנדב"א פ"י) אמר הקב"ה לבית דוד מה אתם יושבים, אם אתם מבקשים את ימות בן דוד ואתם מבקשים לגאול את ישראל עשו משפט וצדקה, שנא' וכו' מקול מחצצים אלו האומרים על טמא טמא ועל טהור טהור, הכל במקומו ובזמנו, והלכות שבת בשבת והלכות מועד במועד והלכות חגיגה ומעילות ודיני חצצים באדם וכו', בין משאבים מתוך שלומדין ושואבין דברי תורה וכו' לכך נאמר שם יתנו צדקות ד' צדקות פרזונו בישראל, חסד גדול עשה הקב"ה שפיזר את ישראל לבין העכו"ם עכ"ד המדרש וראוי להבין איך נשמע כל זאת ממאה"כ מקול מחצצים, ובישועת יעקב פי' מקול מחצצים מלשון מחיצה וחציצה ונכלל בזה הלכות שבת שצריך מחיצה להתיר המבוי, והלכות טומאה וטהרה וטבילה ונע"ו דפוסל בהן חציצה, אמנם הקשה בשם מהר"ש לאניודו ז"ל דהרי בחגיגות ומעילות לא שייך זה ואיך נלמדו כולם מהאי קרא עיי"ש, ובאמת אין פירושו מספיק אף על הלכות שבת וטומאה וטהרה, שמרובים הלכותי' מלבד חציצה ומחיצה, ואיך נלמד ממאמר הכתוב מקול מחצצים כל אלו וצ"ב דרשתם ז"ל, גם איך יתקשר סוף הכתוב צדקת פרזונו בישראל חסד גדול עשה הקב"ה שפיזר את ישראל וכו' ואין לו קישור לרישא דקרא עפ"י דרשתם ז"ל.
translation: The sages further expounded on this verse (in Tana d'Bei Eliyahu, chapter 10): The Holy One, blessed be He, said to the House of David, "Why are you sitting? If you seek the days of the Messiah, and you seek to redeem Israel, perform justice and righteousness," as it is stated, etc. "From the voice of the separators," those who say "impure, impure" and "pure, pure," everything in its place and at its time, and the laws of Shabbat on Shabbat, and the laws of festivals on the festival, and the laws of the pilgrimage and the laws of misappropriation and the laws of separation in a person, etc., whether they are drawn from the peace of those who study and draw forth words of Torah, etc. Therefore, it is said there, "Let them give charity, four charities of the poor in Israel." The Holy One, blessed be He, performed a great kindness by scattering Israel among the nations, thus concludes the Midrash. It is fitting to understand how all this is heard from the verse "from the voice of the separators." And in the salvation of Jacob, it is explained that "from the voice of the separators" is from the language of separation and division, and this includes the laws of Shabbat, which require a partition to permit the alleyway, and the laws of impurity and purity and immersion, and so forth, which are invalidated by separation. However, it was difficult in the name of the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, that in the laws of pilgrimage and misappropriation this does not apply, and how are they all learned from this verse, as noted there. And indeed, its explanation is not sufficient even for the laws of Shabbat and impurity and purity, as there are many laws besides separation and partition. How can we learn from the statement of the verse "from the voice of the separators" all these, and it is a question on your interpretation, may your memory be blessed? Also, how does the end of the verse connect "the righteousness of the poor in Israel" with "the Holy One, blessed be He, performed a great kindness by scattering Israel," etc., and it has no connection to the beginning of the verse according to your interpretation, may your memory be blessed?
summary: The passage discusses the divine call to the House of David to engage in justice and righteousness as a prerequisite for the redemption of Israel, emphasizing the importance of proper observance of Torah laws, including those related to purity and communal boundaries. It highlights the concept of "חציצה" (separation) as a metaphor for the necessary distinctions in religious practice, while questioning how various laws can be derived from the phrase "מקול מחצצים." The text reflects on God's kindness in scattering Israel among the nations, suggesting that this dispersion serves a greater purpose in the divine plan for redemption. Ultimately, it invites deeper contemplation on the interconnectedness of Jewish law and the overarching themes of justice and mercy in the pursuit of spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: עוד שם בתנדב"א שם יתנו צדקת ה' צדקת פזרונו בישראל, עור קטנה שבישראל עמדו ובנו בה"כ וביהמ"ד ושכרו להם חזנים ושכרו להם מלמדי תינוקות, נמצא בתו מדרשות מרובים בישראל וכו', אמר הקב"ה בני בנה לו בית המדרש ששכר הגדול שוש לי באוצרי שלך הואל ובשבילך אנו מציל את ישראל ע"כ, וצ"ב איך למדו כל זה מהאי קרא צדקת פזרונו בישראל, גם למה אמרו עיר קטנה בנו ביה"כ וכו' וכי עיר גדולה אין בונים בתי כנסיות
translation: In that place, in the Tana d'Bei Eliyahu, it is stated that they will give the righteousness of the Lord, the righteousness of His distribution in Israel. A small city in Israel stood and built a synagogue and a house of study, and they hired cantors and they hired teachers for the children. It is found that there are many teachings in Israel, etc. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "My children, build for Me a house of study, for the great reward is Mine; in Your merit, we save Israel." Therefore, it is questioned how they learned all this from the verse "the righteousness of His distribution in Israel," and also why they said a small city builds a synagogue, etc., and is there not a large city that builds synagogues?
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of communal efforts in establishing places of worship and study, highlighting that even a small community can build a synagogue and a house of study, thereby fulfilling divine will. It reflects the Hasidic belief that such acts of devotion and charity are treasured by God, who promises to protect and save Israel in return. The reference to "צדקת פזרונו בישראל" underscores the idea that the righteousness of the Jewish people is manifested through their collective actions and commitment to spiritual growth. The text raises questions about the implications of building in small towns versus larger cities, suggesting a deeper understanding of community and divine favor.

passage_content: ונבא אל הביאור ליישב סתירת דרז"ל בענין התחלת השעבוד, עפימ"ש בס' מעשי ד' לפרש המאמר עבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים וכו' ואילו לא הוציא הקב"ה את אבותינו ממצרים הרי אנו ובנינו ובני בנינו משועבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים, דלכאורה מה משמיענו בזה שאילו לא הוציא הקב"ה אותנו היינו עבדים, גם קשה שמתחיל בלשון עבדים ומסיים משועבדים, שהול"ל אילו לא הוציא וכו' עבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים, ופי' הוא ז"ל דלכאורה למה הוצרך הקב"ה להוציא את ישראל משם ביד חזקה, הרי השי"ת כל יכול והי' לו להטות את לב פרעה שישלח את ישראל מרצונו הטוב, אכן טעמו של הקב"ה בזה הי', דאם הי' פרעה שולח את ישראל מרצונו, היו ישראל חייבים אליו הכרת טובה על ששחררם בטובתו, וזה מזיק מאוד לבחי' הנפש אם יש לאדם התחייבות והשתעבדות לרשע, ע"כ הוציאם הקב"ה ביד חזקה כדי שלא יהי' לישראל שום התחייבות והשתעבדות אליו, וז"פ עבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים ויוציאנו ה"א משם ביד חזקה ובזרוע נטוי' שלא מרצונו, ואילו לא הוציא הקב"ה את אבותינו ממצרים ר"ל ביד חזקה, אלא שפרעה ברצונו הי' משלחם הרי אנו ובנינו ובני בנינו משועבדים היינו לפרעה וכו' ר"ל השתעבדות של הכרת טובה.
translation: And let us turn to the explanation to resolve the contradiction of our Sages regarding the beginning of the servitude, as it is stated in the book "Ma'aseh D'" to explain the saying "We were slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt," etc. And if the Holy One, blessed be He, had not taken our forefathers out of Egypt, then we and our children and our children's children would be enslaved to Pharaoh in Egypt. At first glance, what does this teach us that if the Holy One, blessed be He, had not taken us out, we would be slaves? It is also difficult that it begins with the term "slaves" and ends with "enslaved," as it could have said, "If He had not taken us out, we would be slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt." The explanation is that, at first glance, why did the Holy One, blessed be He, need to take Israel out from there with a strong hand? After all, the Blessed One is all-powerful and could have inclined Pharaoh's heart to send Israel of his own good will. However, the reason of the Holy One, blessed be He, in this matter was that if Pharaoh had sent Israel of his own will, the Israelites would have owed him gratitude for having freed them by his kindness. This is very damaging to the aspect of the soul if a person has an obligation and servitude to a wicked one. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, took them out with a strong hand so that the Israelites would have no obligation or servitude to him. Thus, it is explained: "We were slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt," and He took us out with a strong hand and an outstretched arm, not of his own will. And if the Holy One, blessed be He, had not taken our forefathers out of Egypt, meaning with a strong hand, but if Pharaoh had willingly sent them, then we and our children and our children's children would be enslaved to Pharaoh, etc., meaning the servitude of gratitude.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of God's powerful intervention in freeing the Israelites from Egyptian bondage, emphasizing that had Pharaoh released them willingly, the Israelites would have been indebted to him, creating a harmful spiritual obligation. This highlights the concept that true freedom must come without any ties to the oppressor, ensuring that the Israelites remain solely beholden to God. The text underscores the idea that divine redemption is essential to prevent any form of subjugation or gratitude towards a wicked ruler, reinforcing the notion of God's sovereignty and the purity of the Israelites' liberation.

passage_content: והנה איתא במדרש שכשבא יע"א למצרים פסק הרעב בזכותו, וכשנסתלק חזר הרעב, ולפי"ז כ"ז שוע"א חי, לא היו המצריים יכולין להתפאר שעושין לישראל טובה במה שמחזיקין אותם בארצם שהרי ראו והשיגו שכולם הם חיים וניזונים רק בזכותו של יע"א, נמצא שלא הי' לישראל חיוב השתעבדות להמצריים כלל משא"כ אחר הסתלקותו של יע"א אע"פ שיוסף הי' מלך, מ"מ התחילה השעבוד שהרגישו ישראל בחי' השתעבדות להמצריים על שנותנין להם זכות התיישבות בארצם, וז"ש כשמת יע"א נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, ואין זה שעבוד הגוף בעבודה כ"א שהי' להם חיוב השתעבדות כנ"ל. אמנם כ"ז שיוסף הצדיק חי בעולם לא הי' השעבוד שוה מכל המצריים, ורק המנהיגים והמושלים ידעו שאין כחו של יוסף גדול כ"כ שהוא רק שני למלך, ע"כ התנהגו עם ישראל בדרך שררה, משא"כ ההמון עם הי' יראים משליטת יוסף, אבל אחר שנסתלק יוסף התחילה השעבוד בדרך כלל שוה מכל המצריים, אבל עדיין לא הי' עליהם שעבוד הגוף, דכ"ז שהשבטים הק' היו בעולם הגינו בזכותם הגדול על ישראל ואחר שנסתלקו השבטים התחילה השעבוד בפועל ממש.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Midrash that when Joseph came to Egypt, the famine ceased because of him, and when he departed, the famine returned. According to this, as long as Joseph was alive, the Egyptians could not boast that they were doing good for Israel by keeping them in their land, for they saw and understood that all were alive and sustained only by the merit of Joseph. Thus, Israel had no obligation of servitude to the Egyptians at all. However, after Joseph's departure, even though he was a king, the servitude began, as Israel felt a kind of subjugation to the Egyptians for granting them the right to settle in their land. Therefore, it is said that when Joseph died, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed to the distress of servitude, and this was not a physical servitude in labor, but rather that they had an obligation of subjugation as mentioned. However, as long as the righteous Joseph was alive in the world, the servitude was not equal among all the Egyptians; only the leaders and rulers knew that Joseph's power was not so great, as he was only second to the king. Therefore, they treated Israel with authority, while the common people feared Joseph's rule. But after Joseph departed, the servitude began in a general manner among all the Egyptians, yet there was still no physical servitude upon them, for as long as the holy tribes were in the world, they protected Israel by their great merit, and after the tribes departed, the servitude began in actual practice.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Yosef (Joseph) and his role in protecting the Israelites during their time in Egypt. It emphasizes that as long as Yosef was alive, the Israelites were not truly enslaved, as their sustenance and existence were sustained by his merit. However, after his passing, the Israelites began to feel a sense of subjugation, as they perceived their dependence on the Egyptians for their settlement in the land. The text highlights the transition from a protective leadership under Yosef to a more generalized oppression by the Egyptians, particularly after the departure of the righteous patriarchs, which marked the beginning of their actual servitude.

passage_content: ומה שאמרו דכ"ז שאחד מן הדור הי' קיים לא הי' השעבוד, נל"פ עפ"י מה דאיתא במדרש שהי' לישראל פטרונום במצרים ולא רצו לצאת, וע"כ הביא הקב"ה מכת חושך כדי שימותו באותן הימים ולא יראו המצריים במפלתן כמבואר במדרש (פ' בא), ולכאורה הרי יש דעה במדרש שיצאו רק א' מס' רבוא והשאר מתו בג' ימי אפילה, ואיך אפשר שכולם הי' להם פטרונים, דלפי"ז הי' מלוכה ישראלית ולא נשאר למצריים שררה כלל, אמנם אין הכוונה שכולם הי' להם פטרונים, רק שהי' למקצתם פטרונות, והי' להם כח להמשיך את הכלל ישראל לדעתם, ולפתותם שלא ישמעו למשה ולאהרן, וע"כ נתלה החסרון והעונש באותם הפטרונום שהיו מסיתים את ישראל מאחרי משה ואהרן, בבחינת ורדו בכם שונאיכם שדרשו חכז"ל איני מעמיד שונאים אלא מכם ובכם.
translation: And what they said, that as long as one from the generation was alive, there was no subjugation, can be understood according to what is stated in the Midrash, that Israel had their patrons in Egypt and did not want to leave. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, brought the plague of darkness so that they would die during those days and the Egyptians would not see their downfall, as explained in the Midrash (Parashat Bo). And seemingly, there is an opinion in the Midrash that only one out of six hundred thousand left, and the rest died during the three days of darkness. How is it possible that they all had patrons? According to this, there would have been a Jewish monarchy, and the Egyptians would have had no authority at all. However, the intention is not that they all had patrons, but that some of them had patronage, and they had the power to influence the entire Jewish people according to their opinion, and to entice them not to listen to Moses and Aaron. Therefore, the deficiency and the punishment are attributed to those patrons who were inciting Israel against Moses and Aaron, in the sense of "Your enemies shall rule over you," as our Sages of blessed memory explained, "I do not establish enemies except from among you and within you."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of leadership and influence within the Jewish people during their time in Egypt, emphasizing that while some individuals had the potential to act as protectors (petrunim) for the Israelites, their negative influence led many to resist Moses and Aaron. It suggests that the presence of these dissenting voices contributed to the suffering and eventual punishment of the Israelites, as they were swayed away from divine guidance. The text highlights the theological idea that internal divisions can lead to collective consequences, illustrating the importance of unity and adherence to spiritual leadership. Ultimately, it reflects on the interplay between divine providence and human agency in the context of redemption.

passage_content: אמנם כ"ז נסתבב רק אחר מיתת הדור הראשון יורדי מצרים כמ"ש במדרש וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא ובנ"י פרו וגו' ותמלא הארץ אותם שמילאו בתו טיאטראות ובתי קרקסאות, דכל זמן שהדור הישן הי' קיים לא נתערבו ישראל בין המצריים ולא הי' להם התחברות עמהם כלל, רק אחר שנסתלק כל הדור אז התחיל להתחבר עמהם ועי"ז קבלו שררה ופטרונות מהם, נמצא שבהסתלקות כל הדור התחילה בחי' גלות אחרת, דמשעת פטירת השבעים התחילו המצריים לשעבדם אבל הכלל ישראל היו עדיין בשלימות קדושתן ולא נתערבו עם המצריים אבל אחר מיתת כל הדור ההוא התחילה הגלות גם מישראל עצמם, מאותם שנעשו פטרונים אצל המצריים, ומתורץ בזה ד' הזמנים שנתנו רז"ל בהתחלת השעבוד.
translation: Indeed, this only became entangled after the death of the first generation of those who descended to Egypt, as it is written in the Midrash: "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and all that generation," and the children of Israel multiplied, etc. The land was filled with them, as they filled it with theaters and circuses. For as long as the old generation was alive, the Israelites did not intermingle with the Egyptians, and they had no connection with them at all. Only after the entire generation departed did they begin to associate with them, and through this, they received authority and patronage from them. Thus, with the departure of the entire generation, a different kind of exile began, for from the moment of the passing of the seventy, the Egyptians began to enslave them. However, the generality of Israel still maintained their sanctity and did not intermingle with the Egyptians. But after the death of that entire generation, the exile also began from among the Israelites themselves, from those who became patrons among the Egyptians. This explains the four times that our Sages mentioned at the beginning of the servitude.
summary: The passage discusses the transition from the era of the first generation of Israelites in Egypt to their subsequent subjugation, emphasizing that as long as the original generation remained, the Israelites maintained their distinct identity and holiness. With the death of this generation, the Israelites began to intermingle with the Egyptians, leading to a new form of exile characterized by their acceptance of Egyptian authority. This shift marks the beginning of a spiritual decline, as the Israelites, once pure and separate, started to lose their sanctity and became entangled in the oppressive system of their oppressors. The text highlights the significance of generational continuity in preserving spiritual integrity and the dangers of assimilation.

passage_content: ועכשיו נבא לתרץ זמן חמישי המבואר בפדר"א שהתחיל השעבוד משעת יציאת בני אפרים דלכאורה קשה למה נענשו כל ישראל בשביל בני אפרים שעברו על השבועה, ואפ"ל דהנה אינו מבואר בדברי רז"ל שהיו ישראל מוחים ביד בנו אפרים כשרצו לצאת, ואפשר דאף שלא התחברו עמהם לצאת, מ"מ לא היו מוחים ופסחו על שתו סעיפים, וע"ד דאיתא במדרש הביאו רש"י ז"ל עה"פ ע"פ תרח אביו, כשהשליך נמרוד את אברם לכבשן האש, הי' הרן יושב ואומר בלבו אם אברם נוצח אני משלו, ואם נמרוד נוצח אני משלו, וכשניצל אברם אמרו לו להרן משל מו אתה, אמר להם הרן משל אברם אני השליכוהו לכבשן האש ונשרף. ולכאורה אינו מובן מה חטא הרן בזה, הרי אחד הי' אברהם ואם הי' נשרף על קודה"ש לא הי' נשאר בעולם דוגמתו להיות לו למסייע, וגם זה שאמר אם אברם נוצח אני משלו, שהכיר והודה בנסו שהוא מהקב"ה ג"כ הו' נסיון גדול בדור ההוא, שלא האמינו בניסי השי"ת, וכמו"ש הרמב"ן הק' שע"כ אינו מבואר בתורה הנס של אור כשדים מפני שלא הביא שום תועלת לעולם שהיו אומרים מעשה כשפים הוא, א"כ כיון שהרן הודה בנס שהוא מן השמים דבר גדול הוא ולמה הגיע לו עונש זה, אמנם מפני שתלה ענין האמונה בהשי"ת בדבר הנצחון, שיטפל אל מי שנוצח, ואם חלילה הי' נמרוד נוצח הי' מתחבר אליו ולדעתו אין זה אמונה כלל כיון שאינו חזק אצלו כיתד שלא תמוט, והאמונה האמיתית הוא שאפי' אם ח"ו אברם נשרף ג"כ אין לזוז מלהאמין בהשי"ת וע"ד שהשריש אאע"ה בזרעו אחריו, זה הוא אמונה אמיתית, משא"כ אם תולין אמונה בנצחון אין זה נקרא אמונה כל ובחי' זו אפשר שהי' גם במצרים, שהיו בון הכלל ישראל כאלו שפסחו על שנו הסעיפים שאף שלא נתחברו עם בני אפרים, חשבו בדעתם שיראו איך יפול דבר ואם ינצחו בני אפרים יצאו גם הם, נמצא שמה שלא יצאו לפני הזמן לא נמנעו מחמת איסור העברת השבועה שלא לצאת מגלות לפני הזמן. רק שהמתינו לראות מי יהי' הנוצח וע"כ נענשו בעונש המר שנאמר על מי שעובר על השבועה הריני מתיר את בשרכם כצבאות וכאילות השדה, ואינו כשאר עונשים שבא במידה ובחשבון מדוייק רק נעשין ר"ל הפקר ממש, וע"כ מאז התחילה עליהם שעבוד הקשה, ואין כאן שום סתירה בהתחלת הזמנים אלא שבכל א' מהזמנים הנ"ל התחילה שעבוד וגלות באופן ובבחינה אחרת.
translation: And now let us explain the fifth time mentioned in Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer, that the servitude began from the moment the children of Ephraim left, for it seems difficult why all of Israel were punished for the actions of the children of Ephraim who transgressed the oath. And it could be said that it is not explained in the words of our Sages that the Israelites protested against the children of Ephraim when they wanted to leave. It is possible that even though they did not join them in leaving, nonetheless they did not protest and skipped over two sections. And as it is stated in the Midrash, Rashi brings regarding the verse "according to Terach his father," when Nimrod threw Abram into the fiery furnace, Haran was sitting and saying to himself, "If Abram is victorious, I am with him; and if Nimrod is victorious, I am with him." And when Abram was saved, they said to Haran, "Whose side are you on?" He said to them, "I am with Abram; they threw him into the fiery furnace and he was saved." And at first glance, it is not understood what sin Haran committed in this, for there was only one Abram, and if he had been burned for the sanctification of the Name, there would not have remained in the world anyone like him to assist him. And also this that he said, "If Abram is victorious, I am with him," that he recognized and acknowledged that his salvation was from the Holy One, blessed be He, is also a great test in that generation, for they did not believe in the miracles of the Holy One, blessed be He. And as Nachmanides questions, therefore the miracle of the fiery furnace is not explained in the Torah because it did not bring any benefit to the world, as they would say it was an act of sorcery. Therefore, since Haran acknowledged the miracle that it was from Heaven, it is a great thing, and why did he deserve this punishment? However, because he tied the matter of faith in the Holy One, blessed be He, to the matter of victory, he would attach himself to whoever was victorious. And if, Heaven forbid, Nimrod had been victorious, he would have joined him, and in his opinion, this is not faith at all, since it is not strong for him like a peg that does not bend. And true faith is that even if, Heaven forbid, Abram had been burned, one should not waver from believing in the Holy One, blessed be He, as our forefather Abraham instilled in his descendants after him. This is true faith, whereas if one ties faith to victory, this is not called faith at all. And in this aspect, it is possible that there was also in Egypt, where there were among all of Israel those who skipped over two sections, that even though they did not join with the children of Ephraim, they thought in their minds to see how things would turn out, and if the children of Ephraim would be victorious, they would also go out. Thus, the reason they did not leave before the time was not because they were prevented by the prohibition of violating the oath not to leave the exile before the time, but rather they waited to see who would be victorious. Therefore, they were punished with the bitter punishment that is said about one who transgresses the oath: "I will permit your flesh like the flesh of the armies and like the deer of the field." And it is not like other punishments that come in measure and precise calculation, but they became, so to speak, completely abandoned. And therefore, from then on, the harsh servitude began upon them, and there is no contradiction in the beginning of the times, but rather in each of the aforementioned times, the servitude and exile began in a different manner and aspect.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the punishment of the Israelites for the actions of the tribe of Ephraim, who violated their oath not to leave Egypt prematurely. It emphasizes the concept of true faith, which should not be contingent on visible victories or outcomes, as exemplified by the story of Haran and Abraham. The text suggests that the Israelites' failure to fully commit to their faith, by waiting to see the outcome of Ephraim's actions, led to their collective punishment and the beginning of their harsh servitude. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of unwavering belief in God, regardless of circumstances.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר מאמר חכז"ל הנ"ל צדקת פזרונו בישראל צדקה עשה הקב"ה בישראל שפזרן לבין האומות, דהנה רצונו של הקב"ה שיהיו ישראל מפוזרין בכל העולם, כדי לברר הניצה"ק הנמצאים בשבי' בארצות הגלות, ולהשריש בכל מקום תורה וקדושה, וכמ"ש ז"ל במדרש חזית (שה"ש ב' י"ט) קול דודי הנה זה בא זה מלך המשיח, בשעה שהוא אומר לישראל בחודש הזה אתם נגאלים, אומרים האיך אנו נגאלים, ולא כבר נשבע הקב"ה שהוא משעבדנו בע' אומות, והוא משיבן ב' תשובות ואומר להם, אחד מכם. גולה לברבריא וכו' דומה כמי שגליתם כולכם וכו', ובחודש הזה אתם נגאלים עכ"ד המדרש, מבואר שאף אחר ביאת המשיח יהיו ישראל חוששים ויראים שמא לא נתקיימה עדיין שבועתו של הקב"ה בגזירת הגלות, וא"א שתהי' גאולה אמיתית כ"א עזו השלמת גזירת הגלות, והאר"י ז"ל בשער המצות (פ' ראה) האריך טובא בטעם הגלות שהוא לברר ניצה"ק אשר בשבי' בון האומות, וכתב לחלק בין הד' גלויות שהם בבל מדי יון אדום לשאר גלויות, כו אלו הד' המה השרשים וע"כ מוכרח להיות שם גלות מרובה מכל ישראל, משא"כ גלות שאר האומות כיון שגלה שם אחד מישראל נחשב כאילו גלו כולם, כי המה רק ענפים ורק אותן אשר נפלו נצוצות נשמותיהם באומה ההוא צריכים להגלות שמה, כדי להוציא ולברר משם ניצה"ק השייכים לשורשם עיי"ש.
translation: And we will come to explain the statement of our Sages mentioned above: "The righteousness of the scattered ones in Israel." The Holy One, blessed be He, has done righteousness with Israel by scattering them among the nations. Behold, it is the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, that Israel be dispersed throughout the world, in order to refine the sparks of holiness that are in captivity in the lands of exile, and to instill Torah and holiness in every place, as our Sages have said in the Midrash Hazit (Song of Songs 2:19): "The voice of my beloved! Behold, he comes, this is the King Messiah." At the time when he tells Israel, "In this month you will be redeemed," they say, "How will we be redeemed? Has not the Holy One, blessed be He, sworn that He has enslaved us among the forty nations?" And He answers them with two responses and says to them, "One of you is exiled to Barbaria," etc., it is like one who says, "You have all been exiled," etc., "and in this month you will be redeemed." Thus concludes the Midrash. It is clear that even after the coming of the Messiah, Israel will be concerned and fearful that perhaps the Holy One, blessed be He’s oath regarding the decree of exile has not yet been fulfilled, and it is impossible for there to be true redemption unless the decree of exile is completed. And the holy Ari, may his merit protect us, in the Gate of the Commandments (Parashat Re'eh), elaborated greatly on the reason for the exile, which is to refine the sparks of holiness that are in captivity among the nations. He wrote to distinguish between the four exiles: Babylon, Media, Greece, and Edom, and the other exiles. These four are the roots, and therefore it is necessary for there to be a great exile of all Israel there, whereas in the exile of the other nations, since one from Israel is exiled there, it is considered as if they have all been exiled, for they are only branches, and only those whose sparks of their souls have fallen into that nation need to be exiled there, in order to extract and refine from there the sparks of holiness that are connected to their root.
summary: The passage discusses the divine purpose behind the dispersion of the Jewish people among the nations, emphasizing that this scattering is intended to redeem the holy sparks (nitzotzot) trapped in exile. It highlights the belief that even after the coming of the Messiah, the Jewish people may still fear that God's promise of redemption has not been fulfilled due to the ongoing nature of their exile. The text references the teachings of the Arizal, who distinguishes between the four primary exiles (Babylon, Media, Greece, and Edom) and other nations, asserting that the primary exiles require a more significant presence of Jews to facilitate the redemption of these holy sparks. Ultimately, the passage underscores the theological concept that the ultimate redemption is intertwined with the rectification of these divine sparks scattered throughout the world.

passage_content: ובגמרא (ע"ז ו' ע"ב) דרשו רז"ל עה"פ (זכרי' ב') כו כארבע רוחות השמים פרשתי אתכם, האי כארבע רוחות לארבע רוחות מבעי' לי', אלא כשם שא"א לעולם בלא רוחות כך א"א לעולם בלא ישראל וכו', וביאר המהרש"א ז"ל דענין הדמיון כי ברוחות הם קיומו של עולם וכו' שהוא מייבש את הארץ, ולולא הרוח הי' העולם כולו טובעים מים במים לפי הטבע וכו', כן הם ישראל שאלולא הם הי' העולם חוזר לתוהו ובוהו וכו', וע"י שפירש ופיזר אותם בד' רוחות התפרסם בכל העולם אמונתו ותורתו והוא קיומו של עולם עכ"ל, ועוד טעמים הרבה בדרז"ל בענין הגלות, (הובא בדברינו במקו"א עיי"ש) והחולק על דבר זה ה"ה חולק על דברי הנביאים ודברי חז"ל.
translation: In the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 6b), our Sages expounded on the verse (Zechariah 2) "As the four corners of the heavens I have spread you," questioning why it says "as the four corners" instead of "to the four corners." Rather, just as the world cannot exist without winds, so too the world cannot exist without Israel, etc. The Maharsha explained that the analogy is that the winds are the sustenance of the world, as they dry the land, and without the wind, the entire world would be submerged in water according to nature, etc. Similarly, Israel, for without them the world would revert to chaos and void, etc. And by scattering and dispersing them to the four corners, His faith and Torah became known throughout the world, and this is the sustenance of the world. Thus far the text. There are many other reasons in the teachings of our Sages regarding the exile (as mentioned in our writings in various places, see there), and one who disputes this is indeed disputing the words of the prophets and the words of our Sages.
summary: The passage discusses the essential role of the Jewish people in the world, drawing a parallel between the four winds and the necessity of Israel for the world's existence. It emphasizes that just as the winds sustain the earth by preventing it from being overwhelmed by water, so too do the Jewish people maintain the world's order and purpose. The dispersion of Israel across the four corners of the earth serves to spread faith and divine teachings, highlighting their integral role in the continuity of creation. Disputing this concept is seen as a challenge to the words of the prophets and the teachings of the sages.

passage_content: והאוהחה"ק (פ' בחקותי) עה"פ והבאתי אותם בארץ אויביהם כתב לשון מפליא, וזל"ק ורשע הוא כי יאמר למה ה' יוציאם מארצם ויגלם בין האומות לפרעון עוונם. ייסרם תוך ארצותם ולא יגלם בין האומות, כי אדרבה זה יסובב היפך תיקון המבוקש, שאם המבוקש הוא להטיב מעשיהם, הנה כשיזרה אותם בארצות יגמרו לעשות רע ויתערבו בגוים וילמדו מעשיהם וכו', והאריך שם לבאר טעם הגלות עיי"ש, ולכאורה ראוי להבין למה נקרא בשביל זה רשע, הרי באמת שאל קושיא חזקה, ומדוע לא ישמיענו הכתוב טעמו של דבר למה הוציאם ד' מארצו וכו', אמנם הוא ז"ל ראה ברוח קדשו שרק הרשעים ישאלו קושיא זו, ומי שמאמין בתוה"ק ובדברי חכז"ל אסור לו להקשות קושיות אלא להאמין באמונה פשוטה שכך צריך להיות: ואף אם רוב העולם יאמרו להיפך, אסור להימשך אחר הרוב בדבר הזה, דהרוצה להיות דבוק בדרך התורה האמיתית אין לו להשגיח על רוב העולם, וכמו שפי' האוהחה"ק עה"פ כי יסיתך אחיך בן אמך וגו' לאמר נלכה ונעבדה אלקים אחרים אשר לא ידעת אתה ואבותוך מאלהי העמים אשר סביבותיכם הקרובים אליך או הרחוקים ממך מקצה הארץ ועד וגו', דלכאורה מה זה שחושב הפסוק כל אלה הפרטים הקרובים או הרחוקים מקצה הארץ וגו' מאי נפק"מ באיזה מקום שיהי' הע"ז קרוב או רחוק מ"מ הוא אסורה, ופי' שהמסית יבא בטענה להוכיח הוכחה גדולה, והוא כשתהי' ע"ז שנתפשטה בעולם, שכל העולם או רובו עובדים אותה וכו' וז"ש מקצה הארץ ועד קצה הארץ כולם עובדים ע"ז, א"כ יש לך ג"כ לילך אחריהם. והסתה זו עמה טענה להוכיח כי יש בה ממש ח"ו, אעפ"כ אמר הפסוק לא תאבה לו ולא תשמע אליו וגו' ולא תכסה עליו.
translation:
And the holy author (in Parshat Bechukotai) on the verse "And I will bring them into the land of their enemies" wrote a wondrous expression, and it is as follows: "And a wicked person is he who says, 'Why does the Lord bring them out of their land and exile them among the nations for the payment of their sins?' He should chastise them within their own lands and not exile them among the nations, for on the contrary, this will bring about the opposite of the desired correction. If the goal is to improve their deeds, then when He scatters them among the lands, they will end up doing evil and will mix with the nations and learn their ways, etc." He elaborated there to explain the reason for the exile, as mentioned there. 

At first glance, it is appropriate to understand why he is called wicked for this, as he indeed asked a strong question. Why does the scripture not inform us of the reason why the Holy One, Blessed be He, took them out of their land, etc.? However, he, of blessed memory, saw in his holy spirit that only the wicked would ask this question, and one who believes in the Torah and in the words of our sages is forbidden to pose questions but must believe with simple faith that it must be this way. Even if the majority of the world says otherwise, one should not follow the majority in this matter, for one who wishes to be attached to the true path of the Torah should not pay attention to the majority of the world. 

And as the holy author explained on the verse "If your brother, the son of your mother, entices you, saying, 'Let us go and serve other gods that you have not known, you and your forefathers, of the gods of the peoples that are around you, near to you or far from you, from one end of the earth to the other end,'" it is seemingly puzzling why the verse considers all these details, whether close or far from the ends of the earth, for in any case, idolatry is forbidden. He explained that the enticer will come with a claim to prove a great proof, and it is when the idolatry has spread in the world, that all or most of the world worships it, etc. Therefore, it is also said, "from one end of the earth to the other end, they all serve idolatry," and thus you also have to follow them. And this enticement comes with a claim to prove that there is substance to it, Heaven forbid. Nevertheless, the verse says, "You shall not listen to him, nor shall you cover for him."
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the theological implications of exile and the questioning of divine justice. He emphasizes that only the wicked would challenge God's actions in exiling the Jewish people, as true believers should accept divine will with simple faith, regardless of the majority opinion. The text highlights the danger of being swayed by the majority, particularly in matters of idolatry, and underscores the importance of adhering to the Torah and its teachings despite external influences. Ultimately, it conveys a message of steadfastness in faith and the necessity of remaining true to one's beliefs in the face of societal pressures.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר דברי התנדב"א הנ"ל, מקול מחצצים אלו האומרים על טמא טמא ועל טהור טהור הכל במקומו ובזמנו, והלכות שבת בשבת וכו' ודיני חצצים באדם וכו' שם יתנו צדקות ה' צדקות פזרונו בישראל, חסד גדול עשה הקב"ה שפיזר את ישראל לבין העכו"ם, עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב קישור המאמר גם איך נלמד כל זה ממאמר הכתוב מקול מחצצים, ופי' הישועות יעקב אינו מספיק דלא כל הלכות התורה בדיני חציצה ומחיצה תליין (עיין קושייתנו לעיל), אמנם אפ"ל עפ"י דרכו שפי' מקול מחצצים מלשון חציצה ומחיצה, והכוונה לדרכנו שעושים חציצה ומחיצה בון טומאה לטהרה, ואומרים על טמא עמא ועל טהור טהור הכל במקומו ובזמנו. ובאופן זה יתקיימו אצלם כל הלכות התורה שבת ומועדים חגיגות ומעילות וכו', דכל קיום התוה"ק תלוי' בזה, דאם אין חציצה בון טומאה לטהרה אז עוברין על כולם פעם על זה ופעם עה זה, משא"כ אם מקיימין חציצה זו יתקיימו כולם על ידו, ועל ידי זה צדקת פזרונו בישראל שמצדיקין דרכי השי"ת ומאמינים שצדקה עשה הקב"ה בישראל שפזרן לבין האומות, משא"כ אם מתחברין עם הטמאים באין לידי דעות נפסדות להקשות קושיות על הנהגת הבוי"ת למה הי' צריך לגלות את ישראל. ואין מאמינים בדברי חכז"ל שאמרו שיש הכרח בגלות כדי להשריש כח התורה וקדושה בכל המקומות, ורק אם ישנו לקול מחצצים שעושין חציצה בין טומאה לטהרה אז צדקת פזרונו בישראל והא בהא תליא.
translation: And we will come to explain the words of the aforementioned "Tendav'a," from the voice of these separators who say "impure, impure" and "pure, pure," all in its place and time, and the laws of Shabbat on Shabbat, etc., and the laws of separation in a person, etc. There they will give the righteousness of the Lord, the righteousness that He has scattered among Israel. The Holy One, blessed be He, has done a great kindness by scattering Israel among the nations, thus concludes the Midrash. And it is necessary to connect the article also to how we learn all this from the statement "from the voice of the separators," and the explanation of Yeshuot Yaakov is not sufficient, for not all the laws of the Torah regarding the laws of separation and partition depend on this (see our question above). However, it can be said according to his way that the term "from the voice of the separators" is from the language of separation and partition, and the intention is to our path that they create separation and partition between impurity and purity, and they say "impure, impure" and "pure, pure," all in its place and time. In this way, all the laws of the Torah will be fulfilled for them: Shabbat, festivals, celebrations, and misappropriations, etc., for the entire existence of the Torah depends on this. For if there is no separation between impurity and purity, then they transgress all of them, sometimes on this and sometimes on that. Whereas if they maintain this separation, all will be fulfilled through it, and through this, the righteousness of His scattering among Israel is that they justify the ways of the Holy One, blessed be He, and believe that the Holy One, blessed be He, has done righteousness among Israel by scattering them among the nations. Conversely, if they connect with the impure, they come to flawed opinions that challenge the governance of the Holy One, blessed be He, asking why it was necessary to exile Israel. And they do not believe in the words of our Sages, who said that there is a necessity for exile in order to root the power of the Torah and holiness in all places. Only if there is the voice of the separators who create a separation between impurity and purity, then the righteousness of His scattering among Israel, and this is dependent on that.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of separation (חציצה) between purity and impurity, emphasizing its importance for the observance of Torah laws. It highlights that the dispersion of the Jewish people among the nations serves a divine purpose, allowing for the sanctification of God's name and the establishment of holiness in all places. The text asserts that maintaining this separation is crucial for upholding the integrity of Jewish law and belief, and that without it, one risks falling into erroneous beliefs about divine governance and the necessity of exile. Ultimately, the passage underscores the theological significance of recognizing God's justice in the scattering of Israel among the nations.

passage_content: ובזה יובן המשך דברי התנדב"א ד"א עיר קענה וכו' ויובן עפ"י מאמר הקדום לו מקול מחצצים וגו' שמוכרח לעשות חציצה בין טומאה לטהרה, ולהצדיק צדקת פזרונו בישראל אמנם בדרך זה ישארו ורק מיעוטא דמיעוטא מכל העולם, וא"כ יפול לב האדם מלילך בדרך הזה, משום הכו אמר עור קטנה וכו' דאה"נ לגבי העולם הוא עיר קטנה ואנשים בה מעט כפשוטו, דמועטין הם המקבלים עליהם דרך הזה וע"כ נקרא עיר קטנה, ומסיים ע"ז התנדב"א אמר הקב"ה בני בנה לי ביהמ"ד וכו' ובשבילך אני מציל את ישראל, שאלו מועטים מישראל הם המקיימין את העולם ומצילין את ישראל.
translation: And with this, the continuation of the words of the "Tana D'Bei Eliyahu" will be understood, that a city is small, etc., and it will be understood according to the earlier saying from "Kol Machatzitzim," etc., that it is necessary to create a separation between impurity and purity, and to justify the righteousness of our dispersion among Israel. However, through this way, only a small minority of the entire world will remain, and therefore the heart of man will falter in going this way, for thus it is said, "a small city," etc. Indeed, in relation to the world, it is a small city, and there are few people in it, as it is simple, for the few are those who accept this path, and therefore it is called a small city. And in conclusion, the "Tana D'Bei Eliyahu" states, "The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: 'My children, build for Me a House of Study,' etc., and for your sake, I will save Israel," for these few among Israel are those who sustain the world and save Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of creating a separation between impurity and purity, emphasizing that only a small minority of individuals truly embrace this path. It highlights the idea that these few righteous individuals, referred to as a "small city," are essential for sustaining the world and redeeming Israel. The text concludes with the notion that God values these individuals, as they are the ones who uphold the world and ensure the salvation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ובשפלות המצב בדורנו שנאבד מאתנו שמנה וסלתה של הכלל ישראל ולא נשארו כ"א מיעוטא דמיעוטא שומרי תורה ומצות, צריך לידע שעיקר כל העיקרים להאמין בי"ג העיקרים וכמו שמבאר הרמב"ם ז"ל בספרו, וצריך להחזיק בדרך הזה של קול מחצצים ופרשה זה של קול מחצצים צריכים הת"ח ללמדה לבני ישראל כי הוא עיקר גדול בעבודת השי"ת, ועכשיו גם הרשעים עושין חציצה זו שאין רוצים בקישור כל דהוא עמנו, וזהו מחסדי השי"ת עמנו שאינם מסייעים לנו בהחזקת התורה, ועד"ז יהי' יסוד קיומם של מוסדות התורה רק מישראל שומרי התוה"ק, ואין לנו חיוב השתעבדות להם.
translation: In the lowliness of the state in our generation, when we have lost the essence and the best of the entire Jewish people, and only a minority of a minority remain as guardians of the Torah and commandments, it is necessary to know that the foundation of all foundations is to believe in the thirteen principles, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, explains in his book. It is essential to uphold this path of separation, and this section of separation must be taught by the Torah scholars to the children of Israel, for it is a great principle in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And now, even the wicked create this separation, as they do not wish to have any connection with us. This is one of the Holy One's kindnesses towards us, that they do not assist us in upholding the Torah. Similarly, the foundation of the existence of the institutions of Torah will only be from Israel who are guardians of the holy Torah, and we have no obligation to be subservient to them.
summary: In the current low state of the Jewish people, where only a small minority remains committed to Torah and mitzvot, it is essential to uphold the thirteen principles of faith as outlined by Maimonides. The concept of "kol machatzitzim" emphasizes the importance of separation from those who do not align with the values of Torah observance. This separation is seen as a divine kindness, as it allows the preservation of Torah institutions to rely solely on those who are faithful to the commandments, freeing the faithful from obligation to those who oppose them.

passage_content: ופירשתי במאמה"כ (פ' ראה) איש כמתנת ידו וגו' דלכאורה צ"ב הלשון כמתנת ידו בכ"ף הדמיון, ונל"פ דהנה הקב"ה פורע לכל ישראל מה שנותן לצדקה, וכמו שאמרו ז"ל און אדם נעשה עני מצדקה, ולכאורה כיון שהקב"ה מחזיר הכל אל הנותן א"כ און זה מתנת ידו ורק משל הקב"ה הוא נותן, אמנם הקב"ה מחשיבו אליו כאילו הי' מתנת ידו, ומתברך על ידו כאילו הי' נותן משלו ממש, וז"פ איש כמתנת ידו שנחשב אצל הקב"ה כאילו הו' מתנת ידו כברכת ה"א אשר נתן לך ר"ל דלענין זה נחשב כמתנת ידו שהשי"ת יברך אותו בשביל הנתינה.
translation: And I explained in the verse (Parshat Re'eh) "a man according to the gift of his hand," that seemingly the expression "according to the gift of his hand" is puzzling. It appears that the Holy One, blessed be He, repays all of Israel for what they give to charity, as our sages have said, "A person becomes poor through charity." And seemingly, since the Holy One, blessed be He, returns everything to the giver, then this is indeed a gift of his hand, and it is only a metaphor that the Holy One, blessed be He, is giving. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, considers it as if it were truly a gift of his hand, and He blesses him through it as if he were giving from his own. Thus, it is explained "a man according to the gift of his hand," which is regarded by the Holy One, blessed be He, as if it were a gift of his hand, as a blessing of the Holy One, blessed be He, that He has given you. In this regard, it is considered a gift of his hand, for the Blessed One will bless him for the giving.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that when a person gives charity, it is viewed by God as if the gift is His own, reflecting a deep connection between the giver and the Divine. The phrase "as a gift of his hand" suggests that God considers the act of giving as a personal offering from Himself, thereby blessing the giver in return. This highlights the reciprocal relationship between divine providence and human generosity, emphasizing that charity not only benefits the recipient but also elevates the giver in the eyes of God. Ultimately, the act of giving is transformed into a divine exchange, where the giver is rewarded as if they were directly giving from God's own resources.

passage_content: ובפסיקתא עשר תעשר איני מבקש ממך משלך אלא משלי שנא' כבד את ה' מהונך א"ת מהונך אלא ממה שחוננך. ואפשר לומר עוד מלבד הפשוטו עפי"ד הנ"ל דכל מה שנותנין להחזקת התורה הקב"ה מחזירו ופורע לו בשלימות וז"ש איני מבקש משלך אלא משלי, דהרי הקב"ה מחזירו לו בשלימות נמצא דמעיקרא נותן משל הקב"ה, אלא שהקב"ה מחשבו לו כאילו נתן משלו, עוד דרשו בפסיקתא הנ"ל כבד את ה' מהונך ד"א בקולך וכו' ואפשר לרמוז בזה עוד בחי' במצות הצדקה דאמרו ז"ל גדול המעשה יותר מן העושה, ואף שאין כ"א יכול ליתן יותר מיכולתו, אבל עכ"פ כ"א בכוחו להרבות תומכין דאורייתא ולהמשיך אנשים זולתו למצוה רבא זו, וכ"א מוטל עליו לעשות כל מה דאפשר להרבות פעלים לתורה, וז"ש כבד את ה' מהונך, ד"א בקולך, היינו כי מה שא"א לך לעשות ע"י הונך. תעשה בקולך ע"י דיבורך עם בנ"א להרבות פעלים לקיום התורה, גם כתיבה כדיבור דמי וע"י מכתב אפשר להרבות פעלים לקיום התורה, וזה מוטל על כאו"א לעשות במשך כל השנה
translation:
In the Pesikta, "You shall surely tithe," I do not ask of you from your own, but from Mine, as it is said, "Honor the Lord with your wealth." Do not read "with your wealth," but rather "with what He has granted you." And it can be said further, aside from its simple meaning, according to the above explanation, that all that is given for the support of the Torah, the Holy One, blessed be He, returns it to him in full. This is what is meant by "I do not ask from you from your own, but from Mine," for the Holy One, blessed be He, returns it to him in full, thus initially he is giving from the Holy One, blessed be He, but the Holy One, blessed be He, considers it as if he gave from his own. 

Furthermore, they expounded in the aforementioned Pesikta, "Honor the Lord with your wealth," meaning also with your voice, etc. It is possible to hint here also to the aspect of the mitzvah of charity, as our sages of blessed memory said, "The act is greater than the doer." And although not everyone can give beyond their means, nevertheless, everyone has the ability to increase supporters of the Torah and to bring others to this great mitzvah. Each person is obligated to do all that is possible to increase actions for the Torah. This is what is meant by "Honor the Lord with your wealth," meaning also with your voice, that is, what you cannot do through your wealth, you should do with your voice by speaking with people to increase actions for the fulfillment of the Torah. Writing is also considered like speaking, and through a letter, it is possible to increase actions for the fulfillment of the Torah. This is incumbent upon each and every one to do throughout the entire year.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept that when one gives to support the Torah, it is not merely from their own possessions but rather from what God has granted them. It highlights the idea that God rewards those who contribute to the Torah's sustenance, treating their donations as if they were given from their own resources. Additionally, it underscores the importance of using one's voice and influence to encourage others to engage in charitable acts and support the Torah, suggesting that every individual has a role in amplifying the impact of these mitzvot throughout the year.

passage_content: ובפשטות אפ"ל מה שאמר עיר קטנה שבישראל עמדו ובנו ביהכ"נ וביהמ"ד וכו' נמצא בתיו מדרשות מרובים בישראל, דהנה לפני איזה שנים כשהתחלנו לייסד הישיבה והת"ת, היינו עוד עיר קטנה והי' בין הכל כעשרים תלמידים, וב"ה בכל שנה ושנה ניתוספו כשתי מאות או ג' מאות תלמידים בליעה"ר ויכולין לעשות מהתלמידים של כל שנה ושנה עיר בפ"ע, דשני מאות לומדי תורה הוא עיר חשובה בישראל, ממילא מובן בפשטות עיר קטנה שבישראל עמדו ובנו ביהכ"נ וביהמ"ד ושכרו להם מלמדי תינוקות בעוד שהוא עיר קטנה, שהיו רק מועטים אבל אח"כ נמצא שמרבין בתי מדרשות בישראל, ונצפה שהשי"ת יעזור גם להלאה, וכמ"ש רז"ל בהבאת הבכורים בת קול מברכת יה"ר שתעשה כן לשנה הבאה.
translation: In simple terms, one could say that what is mentioned about a small city in Israel is that they stood and built a synagogue and a house of study, etc. It is found that there are many study houses in Israel. Behold, a few years ago, when we began to establish the yeshiva and the Talmud Torah, we were still a small city, and there were about twenty students among us. Thank God, each year we have added about two hundred or three hundred students, and it is possible to make from the students of each year a city in itself, for two hundred Torah learners is a significant city in Israel. It is therefore understood simply that a small city in Israel stood and built a synagogue and a house of study and hired teachers for the children while it was still a small city, as there were only a few. But afterwards, it was found that there are increasing study houses in Israel, and we hope that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will continue to help, as our Sages of Blessed Memory said regarding the bringing of the first fruits, a heavenly voice proclaims, "May it be His will that it be so for the coming year."
summary: The passage reflects on the growth of a small community in Israel that established a synagogue and study hall, emphasizing the significance of even a small number of Torah students as a vital part of Jewish life. It highlights the divine blessing and support that has enabled the community to expand significantly over the years, illustrating the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of learning and communal dedication to Torah. The text also expresses hope for continued growth and divine assistance, drawing on traditional teachings that affirm the importance of such endeavors in the Jewish faith.

passage_content: והשי"ת ישלם לכל מי שנעל חלק במצוה הגדולה הזאת, וזכותו גדול מאוד שעל זה נאמר צדקתו עומדת לעד, שאם נותנין צדקה לתשב"ר, צדקתו עומדת לעד, שנמשכין עי"ז דורי דורות עד אין הפסק והבורא עולם יעזור שנזכה להגדיל תורה ולהאדירה ולהרביץ תורה וטהרה בישראל, ובמהרה נזכה לראות הגאולה שלימה בביאת משיח צדקינו ונזכה לקבל אותו באנפין נהירין בנחת ובשמחה בקדושה ובטהרה ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And may the Holy One, blessed be He, repay everyone who has a share in this great mitzvah, and his merit is very great, for it is said, "His righteousness endures forever." For when one gives tzedakah to Teshb'ar, his righteousness endures forever, and through this, generations upon generations are drawn without interruption. May the Creator of the world help us merit to enhance the Torah and glorify it, to spread Torah and purity in Israel, and may we soon merit to see the complete redemption with the coming of our righteous Messiah, and may we merit to receive him with shining faces, with ease and joy, in holiness and purity, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days. Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound merit of participating in the great mitzvah of charity, particularly in support of Torah study and dissemination. It highlights the eternal nature of righteousness, as contributions to such causes ensure a lasting legacy across generations. The text expresses a hopeful prayer for the ultimate redemption and the coming of the righteous Messiah, envisioning a time of divine revelation and joy for the Jewish people.

passage_content: אי באופן אחר אפ"ל דקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר עוד במאמה"כ בסוף הפרשה ויצוו אל יוסף לאמר אביך צוה לפני מותו לאמר כה תאמרו ליוסף אנא שא נא פשע אחיך וחטאתם וגו', פרש"י מדברי רז"ל אביך צוה, שינו בדבר מפני השלו', כי לא צוה יעקב כן שלא נחשד יוסף בעיניו, ויל"ד איך יתכן לקדושים כאלו להוציא מפיהם דבר שלא הי', גם הוא מוכחש בחוש, דאלמלא הי' רצונו של יעקב אבינו לצוות את יוסף על ככה, הי' אומר אליו בעצמו פא"פ ולא ע"י שליח. ואיך לא חשו שלא יאמין יוסף לדבריהם לטעם זו.
translation: In another way, one could say that the aforementioned nuances should be prefaced by noting further in the Holy Scripture at the end of the portion, "And they commanded Joseph, saying, 'Your father commanded before his death, saying, "Thus shall you say to Joseph: Please forgive the transgression of your brothers and their sin..."' Rashi explains from the words of our Sages that 'your father commanded' was altered for the sake of peace, for Jacob did not command this, as Joseph was not suspected in his eyes. It is difficult to understand how such holy ones could utter something that was not true, and it is also contradicted by experience, for if it were Jacob our father’s will to command Joseph in this manner, he would have said it to him directly and not through a messenger. And how did they not realize that Joseph would not believe their words for this reason?
summary: The passage discusses the complexities of communication and intention in the context of Jacob's instructions to Joseph regarding his brothers' transgressions. It highlights the idea that Jacob did not genuinely command Joseph to forgive his brothers, as he did not suspect Joseph of wrongdoing. This raises questions about the nature of truth and the integrity of holy figures, suggesting that even in their actions, there may be layers of meaning and intention that reflect deeper theological insights about forgiveness and the dynamics of familial relationships. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of direct communication and the potential misunderstandings that can arise from indirect messages.

passage_content: ב) ויבך יוסף בדברם אליו, ראוי להבין מדוע בכה יוסף והלא הוא ודע בעצמו שאינו נוטר שנאה עליהם ונראה לכאורה בכי' זו כלא צורך, גם אומרו בדברם אליו מלת אליו מיותרת, וכבר נזכר שאליו דיברו.
translation: And Joseph wept when they spoke to him; it is fitting to understand why Joseph wept, for he knows himself that he does not harbor hatred against them, and this weeping seems, at first glance, unnecessary. Also, his saying "when they spoke to him," the word "to him" is superfluous, as it has already been mentioned that they spoke to him.
summary: יוסף בוכה כאשר מדברים אליו, מה שמעורר שאלות על סיבת בכיו, במיוחד כאשר הוא יודע שאינו שונא את האחים. בכיו נתפס כלא הכרחי, וההדגשה על המילה "אליו" מצביעה על עומק הקשר הרגשי והנפשי בין יוסף לאחיו. התגובה הרגשית שלו משקפת את הכאב והקושי שבקשרים משפחתיים, גם כאשר יש הבנה ושחרור מהשנאה. זה מדגיש את המורכבות של רגשות אנושיים ואת הצורך בריפוי ובסליחה בתוך הקשרים הקרובים.

passage_content: ונא"פ בדרך רמז מוסר וכבר הקדמנו בדברנו לעיל כי הקריאה בפרשיות אלו של שעבוד וגאולת מצרים מעורר הזמן, ומסוגלום ימים אלו לתקון חטא הידוע יותר, והנה ראוי להתבונן מ"ט כינוהו רז"ל לחטא זה חטא הידוע והרי כל מי שלמד תורה ויש לו ידיעת בית רבו כל החטאים ידועים לו, וכי חלול שבת אינו חטא ידוע, ואדרבה בחטא זה של שמירת היסוד בנ"א נכשלים בו יותר משאר חטאים, ונשלל מהם ידיעת חומר העון והפגם עד היכן הדברים מגיעים בשורשן, וא"כ מדוע נקרא זה חטא הידוע יותר משאר חטאים.
translation: And yet, in a hint of moral teaching, we have already mentioned above that the reading of these sections of the servitude and redemption of Egypt awakens the time, and these days are capable of rectifying the more well-known sin. It is appropriate to contemplate why our Sages referred to this sin as the more well-known sin. Indeed, anyone who has studied Torah and has knowledge of his teacher's house knows all the sins, and is the desecration of Shabbat not a well-known sin? On the contrary, in this sin of safeguarding the foundation of humanity, people stumble more than in other sins, and they are deprived of the knowledge of the gravity of the transgression and the flaw, to what extent the matters reach at their root. Therefore, why is this called the more well-known sin compared to other sins?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the readings related to the enslavement and redemption of Egypt, emphasizing their ability to rectify a specific sin known as the "known sin." It highlights that while those who study Torah are aware of various sins, the desecration of the Sabbath is often overlooked, despite being a fundamental transgression. The text suggests that this particular sin is termed "known" because it reflects a deeper understanding of the spiritual ramifications and the essence of sin, which many fail to grasp. Ultimately, it calls for a deeper contemplation of the nature of sin and its impact on one's spiritual state.

passage_content: ואפ"ל הכוונה עפי"ד ק"ז הייטב לב זלל"ה אשר צוה קודם הסתלקותו שלא יכתבו על מצבתו תואר גאון או צדיק, כי אם כזה יכתבו הרב המפורסם נודע בשערים וכו' עד כאן לשון קדשו. וענינו נראה כי למעלה בעולמות העליונים ישנם שערים הרבה, כ"א מיוחד לבחי' השפעה מיוחדת, כמו שהזכירו חז"ל בגמ' (ב"מ נ"ט ע"א) אלעזר מיום שחרב ביהמ"ק ננעלו שערי תפלה וכו' ואע"פ ששערי תפלה ננעלו, שערי דמעות לא ננעלו וכו', עוד שם א"ר חסדא כל השערים ננעלים חוץ משערי אונאה וכו', ומקצת השערים הנם מפורטים בספר הזוה"ק ובדברי רז"ל בכ"מ ובתפלה למוצש"ק הנם מסודרים בסדר אלפא ביתא שערי אורה וכו' שערי בינה וכו' וכל שער ושער יש לו מלאך הממונה עליו, וזהו פי' נודע בשערים כי הצדיק לרוב קדושתו וצדקתו שמו נודע בשערים עליונים לשבח, והמלאכים הממונים על השערים מעריצים קדושתו, כי אמרז"ל גדולים הצדיקים יותר ממלאכי השרת
translation: And even though the intention is according to the words of the holy Rabbi Yoel, may his memory be a blessing, who commanded before his passing that no title of Gaon or Tzaddik should be written on his tombstone, but rather that they should write "the renowned Rabbi known in the gates," etc., thus far is his holy language. And its meaning is that above, in the higher worlds, there are many gates, each one designated for a specific type of influence, as our Sages mentioned in the Gemara (Baba Metzia 59a) that from the day the Holy Temple was destroyed, the gates of prayer were locked, etc. And although the gates of prayer were locked, the gates of tears were not locked, etc. Furthermore, there it is stated that Rabbi Chisda said all gates are locked except for the gates of oppression, etc. And some of the gates are detailed in the Book of Zohar and in the words of our Sages everywhere, and in the prayer for Motzei Shabbat, they are arranged in the order of the alphabet: the gates of light, etc., the gates of understanding, etc., and each gate has an angel appointed over it. And this is the meaning of "known in the gates," for the Tzaddik, due to his great holiness and righteousness, his name is known in the upper gates for praise, and the angels appointed over the gates revere his holiness, for our Sages said that the Tzaddikim are greater than the ministering angels.
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the significance of the title "noda b'shaarim" (known in the gates) for a righteous person, as opposed to titles like "gaon" or "tzaddik." It highlights the existence of various spiritual gates in the higher realms, each associated with specific divine influences, and notes that while some gates, such as those of prayer, may be closed, others, like the gates of tears, remain open. The passage underscores the elevated status of the righteous, whose holiness is recognized and revered by the angels overseeing these gates, illustrating the profound connection between the righteous and the divine.
