passage_content: ואולי לטעם זה כינו חז"ל חטא זה חטא הידוע, כי המלוכלך ר"ל בחטא הנורא הזה, שמו נודע בכל השערים לגנאי והמלאכים הממונים על השערים יודעין ומכירין בו ע"ו כתות מלאכי משחית שנבראו על ידו וסובבין אותו, וצריך לזכות גדול ומליצי יושר שלא יהיו השערים ננעלים בפניו ולפני תפלתו שלא ידחפוהו וירחקוהו ר"ל, ואמרז"ל כי שערי דמעות לעולם לא ננעלו, וע"כ עצה היחידה למי שנכשל ר"ל בחטא הנורא הזה שיתמרמר ויתחרט מעומק הלב על אשר הכעיס להבוות"ש, וירבה בתשובה ובתחנונים בדמעות של אמת להבוית"ש שיקבל תשובתו, ווש לנו הבטחה מדברי רז"ל כי שערי דמעות לא ננעלו, ואף באיזה מצב שהוא עומד ואף אם שמו ידוע תפלתו נכנסת בשערי דמעות והבוי"ת מרחם עליו לקבל תפלתו, ונזכה באלו הימים של שובבים לעשות תשובה שלימה על חטא הנורא הזה, ולשפוך דמעות של אמת להבוית"ש, והבוכ"ע יקבל תשובתונו, ובפרט תשובת הרבים דכתיב קל כביר לא ימאס, והבאנו לעיל מדברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה דתשובת הרבים אף אם הוא מיראה, מתקבלת בבחי' תשובה מאהבה, ונזכה עוד לעשות רצון הבוב"ה ולהרבות כבוד שמים על ידינו כי זהו תכלית הכל.
translation: And perhaps for this reason our Sages referred to this sin as the known sin, for the one who is defiled, meaning by this terrible sin, his name is known in all the gates for disgrace, and the angels appointed over the gates know and recognize him, along with the 46 groups of destructive angels that were created by him and surround him. He needs a great merit and intercessors so that the gates will not be locked before him and before his prayer, so that they do not push him away and distance him, so to speak. And our Sages said that the gates of tears are never locked, and therefore the only advice for one who has stumbled, so to speak, in this terrible sin is to become bitter and regret from the depths of his heart for having angered the Blessed One, and to increase in repentance and supplications with true tears to the Blessed One that He should accept his repentance. And we have the promise from the words of our Sages that the gates of tears are not locked, and even in whatever state he stands, and even if his name is known, his prayer enters through the gates of tears, and the Blessed One has mercy on him to accept his prayer. May we merit in these days of Shovavim to make complete repentance for this terrible sin, and to shed true tears to the Blessed One, and may the Blessed One accept our repentance, especially the repentance of the masses, as it is written, "A mighty God will not despise." And we brought above from the words of the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed, that the repentance of the masses, even if it is out of fear, is accepted in the aspect of repentance out of love. May we merit to do the will of the Blessed One and to increase the honor of Heaven through us, for this is the ultimate purpose of everything.
summary: The passage emphasizes the gravity of sin, particularly the "known sin," which tarnishes one's spiritual standing and is recognized by both angels and divine forces. It highlights the importance of sincere repentance, characterized by heartfelt remorse and tears, as a means to access the "gates of tears," which are always open to genuine supplication. The text reassures that even in dire circumstances, sincere prayers can penetrate these gates, and collective repentance, even if motivated by fear, can be elevated to a level of love. Ultimately, the goal is to fulfill God's will and enhance His glory through sincere repentance and devotion.

passage_content: נחזור לעניננו בביאור מאמה"כ אנא שא נא פשע אחיך וחטאתם וגו', כי השבטים הקדושים התחרטו על חטא מכירת יוסף והשתדלו לעשות תשובה ולפיוס את יוסף, ואף שהי' סיבה מן השמים בגזירת נורא עלילה כדי לקיים גזירת ידוע תדע, מ"מ הוי' קצת פגם בדבר (כמו שהארכנו בדברנו לעיל) והי' מעין בחי' פגם הברית, כי יוסף הצדיק הוא מדת היסוד כידוע, ובפגעם בו קלקלו בשורש המדה ההוא למעלה, גם כי על ודם נזדמן לו הנסיון הגדול באשת פוטיפר וופוזו זרועי ידיו שאבד עשר טפין כאמרז"ל, וע"כ נתאספו יחדיו בעשרה לעשות תשובת הרבים ולפייסו וכבר פירשנו בדברנו במקו"א דברי המדרש (הובא בפר"ד) לו ישטמנו יוסף והשב ישיב לנו וגו', השב זה יוסף ישיב זה עשו, כי לא הי' יוסף הצדיק נחשד בעיניהם שינקום נקמתו מהם, אך כל יראתם הי' מקטרוג הס"מ שרו של עשו, שכל זמן שרושם החטא קיימת, יש מקום לקטרוג ח"ו, וע"כ השתדלו בפיוסו לתקן פגם החטא, ובזה נבין מה שלא צוה יע"א ליוסף דברים האלה שא נא פשע אחיך וגו', כי לא הי' יוסף נחשד בעיניו על ככה, והתכלית המבוקש הו' שהשבטים הק' ישתדלו בתשובה לתקן הפגם. וא"א שיושלם התיקון הזאת ע"י זולתו, כ"א החוטא בעצמו צריך להתוודות על עונו ולעשות תשובה, ומעתה אף אלמלי אמר יע"א ליוסף אנא שא פשע אחיך וגו', לא הי' מועלת לתקון חטאם, והוכרחו הם בעצמם להתוודות על חטאם.
translation: We will return to our topic with the explanation of the verse, "Please bear the sin of your brothers and their transgression," etc. For the holy tribes regretted the sin of selling Joseph and endeavored to do repentance and reconcile with Joseph. And although there was a reason from Heaven due to a terrible decree in order to fulfill the known decree, nevertheless, there was somewhat of a blemish in the matter (as we elaborated in our previous discussion), and it was a kind of blemish of the covenant, for Joseph the righteous is the attribute of Yesod, as is known, and by blemishing him, they corrupted the root of that attribute above. Also, because of this, he encountered the great trial with Potiphar's wife, and his arms were bound, losing ten fingers, as our sages have said. Therefore, they gathered together in a group of ten to do public repentance and to appease him. We have already explained in our discussions in various places the words of the Midrash (brought in Parashat Devarim), "If Joseph would hate us, he would return to us," etc. The "return" refers to Joseph, and "return" refers to Esau, for Joseph the righteous was not suspected in their eyes of taking revenge on them. Rather, all their fear was from the accusation of the Satan, the angel of Esau, for as long as the impression of the sin remains, there is room for accusation, Heaven forbid. Therefore, they endeavored to appease him to rectify the blemish of the sin. In this, we understand why it was not commanded to Joseph these words, "Please bear the sin of your brothers," etc., for Joseph was not suspected in his eyes in this regard. The ultimate goal was that the holy tribes should strive in repentance to rectify the blemish. And it is impossible for this rectification to be completed by another, but rather the sinner himself must confess his sin and do repentance. From now on, even if it were said to Joseph, "Please bear the sin of your brothers," etc., it would not have been effective for the rectification of their sin, and they were compelled to confess their sin themselves.
summary: The passage discusses the repentance of the holy tribes for the sin of selling Joseph and their efforts to reconcile with him. It emphasizes that despite divine decrees, there was a flaw in their actions, akin to a breach of the covenant, as Joseph represents the attribute of foundation. The text highlights that true atonement requires the sinner to confess and repent personally, as external forgiveness would not suffice to rectify their wrongdoing. Ultimately, the tribes' sincere efforts to seek forgiveness from Joseph were essential for their spiritual restoration.

passage_content: וז"ש אביך צוה לפני מותו לאמר, דיע"א הוכיחן סמוך למיתתו כמבואר בפרשה, וכמ"ש רש"י ז"ל טעמו ר"פ דברים ומתוך דבריו נתעוררו לתקן פגם חטא זה והו"ל כאילו צום בפירוש לאמר ליוסף אנא שא פשע אחיך, וז"ש אביך צוה לפני מותו שלאמר" ר"ל שדברי תוכחות אשר צום לפני מותו, משמעותם לאמר כה תאמרון ליוסף וגו', וע"ד שאמרז"ל לאו בפירוש איתמר אלא מכללא איתמר, ומענה אמת היתה בפיהם אלא שדיברו בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין, ובכגון דא מותר לשנות מפני דרכי שלו' וכמ"ש בספה"ק באמ"ח ופ' תולדות הו"ד לעיל) ויוסף הצדיק כששמע דבריהם השיג בחי' תשובתם בתיקון מדת היסוד ע"כ רצה גם הוא להצטרף עמהם בתשובת הרבים, כי אדם אין צדיק בארץ אשר יעשה טוב ולא יחטא, ומדרך הצדיקים תמיד לפשפש במעשיהם ולתלות חסרון בעצמם, ע"כ ויבך יוסף בדברם חאליו" שדברי ווידויים בפגם החטא נוגע שאליו" במדת היסוד שהוא שורש מידתו, וע"כ בכה והרבה בתשובה להכלל עמהם בתשובת הרבים.
translation: And this is what your father commanded before his death, saying, "Know that he admonished them close to his death, as explained in the portion, and as Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote in the beginning of Deuteronomy. From his words, they were stirred to rectify the flaw of this sin, and it would be as if he fasted explicitly to say to Joseph, 'Please bear the sin of your brothers.' And this is what your father commanded before his death, meaning that the words of admonition which he fasted before his death imply, 'Thus shall you say to Joseph,' etc. This is in accordance with what our Sages of blessed memory said, not explicitly stated but implied. And the truthful answer was in their mouths, but they spoke in a manner that could be understood in two ways. In such a case, it is permissible to alter for the sake of peace, as mentioned in the holy books in the section of the generations. And Joseph the righteous, when he heard their words, grasped their response in rectifying the attribute of foundation. Therefore, he also wanted to join with them in the communal repentance, for there is no righteous person on earth who does good and does not sin. And it is the way of the righteous to always scrutinize their deeds and to attribute shortcomings to themselves. Therefore, Joseph wept at their words, for the words of confession regarding the flaw of sin pertained to him in the attribute of foundation, which is the root of his attribute. And thus he wept and greatly repented to be included with them in the communal repentance.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's final instructions to his sons, emphasizing the importance of repentance and self-reflection in the face of sin. It highlights that even the righteous, like Joseph, must acknowledge their shortcomings and strive for collective atonement. The text illustrates the Hasidic belief that true righteousness involves a constant examination of one's actions and a willingness to join in communal repentance, as demonstrated by Joseph's emotional response to his brothers' confessions. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that the process of teshuva (repentance) is essential for spiritual growth and connection to the divine.

passage_content: והנה איתא בזוה"ק בכ"מ דלא מהני תשובה על חטא זה ר"ל, אולם הקשו המפורשים ממ"ש רז"ל און לך דבר שעומד בפני התשובה, וכבר תירצנו דברי הזוה"ק בכמה אנפין, וכעת נל"פ עפי"ד בגמ' ערכין (ט"ו ע"ב) א"ר חמא ב"ר חנינא מה תקנתו של מספרי לה"ר, אם תלמיד חכם הוא יעסוק בתורה וכו' ר' אחא ברבי חנינא אומר סיפר אין לו תקנה שכבר כרתו דוד ברוה"ק, שנא' יכרת ד' כל שפתי חלקות וגו', פרש"י שכבר כרתו לשון כרת עכ"ל, ולכאורה בודאי א"א לומר דלא מהני תקנה למספרי לה"ר, דלא יהא מדת ענשם חמור מחייבי כריתות, דמני להו חז"ל בד' חלוקי כפרה (יומא פ"ו ע"א) עבר על כריתות ומיתות ב"ד ועשה תשובה, תשובה ויוכ"פ תולין ויסורין ממרקין, מבואר דאף חייבי כריתות ר"ל יש להם תקנה ולא ידחו עולמית, וא"א שמספרי לה"ר אין להם תקנה כלל, ופירשתי דאולי כוונת המאמר סובב על דברי ר' חמא בר' חנינא דקדים לוה, דאמר מה תקנתו של מספרי לשון הרע וכו' יעסוק בתורה, וה"ז תקנה קלה ונוחה דבלא"ה נתחייב האדם להשלים חקו בתורה, וע"ז פליג ר' אחא ואמר סיפר אין לו תקנה, ר"ל דלא מהני לי' תקנה הנ"ל, שכבר כרתו דוד ברוה"ק וע"כ מידת ענשו כחייבי כריתות, ונתכפר לו רק בתשובה ובצירוף יסורין כחייבי כריתות.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Zohar that there is no remedy for this sin, meaning, however, the commentators have questioned this based on what our Sages said, "There is a matter that stands before repentance." We have already explained the words of the Zohar in several ways, and now we will explain according to the Gemara in Erchin (15b). Rabbi Chama bar Chanina said: What is the remedy for one who speaks evil? If he is a Torah scholar, he should engage in Torah, etc. Rabbi Acha bar Rabbi Chanina says: One who speaks evil has no remedy, for David was already cut off by the Holy Spirit, as it is stated, "The Lord will cut off all flattering lips," etc. Rashi explains that "cut off" refers to the language of being cut off. And seemingly, it is certainly impossible to say that there is no remedy for one who speaks evil, that the measure of their punishment should be more severe than those liable for being cut off, for our Sages have categorized them into four levels of atonement (Yoma 86a): One who transgresses the prohibitions of being cut off and the death penalties of the court and repents, repentance and suffering atone for him. It is clear that even those liable for being cut off, meaning, they have a remedy and will not be rejected forever, and it is impossible that those who speak evil have no remedy at all. I have explained that perhaps the intent of the statement revolves around the words of Rabbi Chama bar Rabbi Chanina, who precedes him, for he said: What is the remedy for one who speaks evil? He should engage in Torah, and this is an easy and accessible remedy, for otherwise, a person is obligated to fulfill his duty in Torah. And to this, Rabbi Acha disagrees and says: One who speaks evil has no remedy, meaning that the aforementioned remedy is not effective for him, for David was already cut off by the Holy Spirit, and therefore his measure of punishment is like that of those liable for being cut off, and he is atoned only through repentance and the addition of suffering, like those liable for being cut off.
summary: The passage discusses the severity of the sin of gossip (lashon hara) and its implications for repentance, referencing the Zohar and Talmudic sources. It contrasts the views of Rabbi Chama and Rabbi Acha regarding the possibility of atonement for those who speak lashon hara, suggesting that while there is a general path to repentance for most sins, the gravity of this particular sin aligns it with the severity of those subject to the punishment of karet (excision). The author posits that the only remedy for such transgressors is through sincere repentance coupled with suffering, emphasizing the profound spiritual consequences of harmful speech.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל לעניננו דמ"ד בזוה"ק דלא סגי בתשובה לחטא זה, אין הכוונה לומר דלית לי' תקנה כלל, דא"א לומר כן, דהרי בגמ' דיומא הנ"ל חשיב ד' חלוקי כפרה והחמור שבכולן מו שיש בידו חילול השם, אין כח בתשובה לתלות ולא ביוהכ"פ לכפר ולא ביסורין למרק, אלא כולן תולין ומיתה ממרקת שנא' אם יכופר העון הזה לכם עד תמותון, ועכ"פ ע"ו המיתה בצירוף התשובה נתכפר עונו, וא"א שתהי' חטא הידוע חמור ממנו דלא מנו חז"ל כ"א ד' חלוקי כפרה ולא יותר, וע"כ אפ"ל דמ"ש בזוה"ק דלא סגי בתשובה, ר"ל דתשובה לחוד לא מהני, אבל לא ידחה עולמית ויום המיתה בצירוף התשובה ודאי מהני.
translation: And similarly, it can be said regarding our matter that the opinion in the Zohar that repentance is not sufficient for this sin does not mean to say that there is no remedy at all, for it is impossible to say such a thing. For in the Gemara of Yoma mentioned above, four categories of atonement are enumerated, and the most severe of them is one who has the ability to desecrate the Name. Repentance cannot atone, nor can Yom Kippur, nor can suffering cleanse, but all of them are dependent on death for atonement, as it is stated, "If this sin will be atoned for you until you die." Nevertheless, through death combined with repentance, his sin is atoned for. And it is impossible for there to be a known sin that is more severe than this, for the Sages only enumerated four categories of atonement and no more. Therefore, it can be said that what is mentioned in the Zohar that repentance is not sufficient means that repentance alone is not effective, but it will not be eternally rejected, and the day of death combined with repentance is certainly effective.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of repentance (teshuva) in relation to severe sins, emphasizing that while teshuva alone may not suffice for certain transgressions, it is not without hope for atonement. It references the Talmud's classification of four levels of atonement, highlighting that the gravest sin, which involves desecration of God's name, requires a combination of teshuva and death for atonement. The Zohar's assertion that teshuva alone is insufficient is clarified to mean that it must be accompanied by the ultimate consequence of death to achieve atonement. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of both repentance and divine justice in the process of forgiveness.

passage_content: והשתא דאתינא להכי דמתכפר לו ע"י המיתה, ע"כ המקבל עליו מסירת נפש באמת ובלב שלם ה"ה נחשב לו כמיתה ונתכפר לו, כמ"ש בזוה"ק (סו"פ במדבר) וז"ל אית חובין דלא מתכפרין עד דאתפטר בר נש מעלמא, הה"ד אם יכופר העון הזה לכם עד תמותון, והאי יהיב גרמי' ודאי למותא ומסור נפשי' וכו' כמאן דאתפטיר מהאי עלמא ודאי, כדין קוב"ה מרחם עלוי ומכפר לי' לחובי' עכ"ל, הרי מבואר דמסנ"פ ברעותא ובכוונה אמיתית, אתחשיב לי' כיום המיתה ומכפרת על כל עבירות, וכ"כ בספה"ק דברי חיים (פ' נח) דלכן קשה התשובה על חטא זה, דצריך לתקן אבר הנפגם בסיבת החטא, ובחטא הידוע כל איבריו נעשו פגומים ר"ל, שבחי' החטא בכח כל האיברים וע"כ קשה התשובה בזה והעצה היעוצה לעבוד השי"ת במסנ"פ אמיתית וזהו תקנה לכולם עיי"ש, וכיון שהוא פסק כן ודאי הלכתא הכו, אך צריך שלא ישטה האדם א"ע, אלא שיקבל ע"ע מסנ"פ ברעותא דלבא וכוונה אמיתית ובאמת בדור שפל כדורנו צריך מסנ"פ לתורה ולמצות ולכל עובדא טבא, וזולת זה א"א לעמוד בנסיונות הקשים מאוד.
translation: And now that we have come to this, that one is atoned for through death, therefore one who accepts upon himself the sacrifice of his soul truly and with a complete heart is considered as if he has died and is atoned for, as it is written in the Zohar (Parashat Bamidbar), and it says: There are sins that are not atoned for until a person departs from this world, as it is said, "If this sin is atoned for you until you die." And this gives oneself certainly to death and to the sacrifice of one's soul, etc., as one who has departed from this world certainly, thus the Holy One, blessed be He, has mercy on him and atones for his sins. It is clear that with a true and sincere sacrifice of the soul, it is considered for him as the day of death and atones for all transgressions. And so it is written in the holy book Divrei Chaim (Parashat Noach) that therefore repentance for this sin is difficult, for one must rectify the limb that was damaged due to the sin, and in the known sin, all his limbs have become blemished, so to speak, since the essence of the sin involves the power of all the limbs, and therefore repentance is difficult in this matter. The advised remedy is to serve the Blessed Creator with a true sacrifice of the soul, and this is a remedy for all, as stated there. And since he has ruled thus, it is certainly the halacha, but one must not deceive oneself, rather one should accept upon oneself a true sacrifice of the soul with the intention of the heart, etc. And truly, in a lowly generation like ours, a sacrifice of the soul is needed for Torah and mitzvot and for every good deed, and without this, it is impossible to withstand the very difficult trials.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of self-sacrifice (mesirat nefesh) in achieving atonement for sins, equating genuine commitment to this principle with the experience of death, which brings forgiveness. It cites the Zohar to illustrate that certain transgressions require a profound spiritual release from the world, and that true repentance is challenging when multiple aspects of the self are affected by sin. The text advocates for sincere devotion to God as a remedy for spiritual shortcomings, particularly in a morally compromised generation, highlighting the necessity of authentic intention in one's service to God to withstand severe trials.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל מאמה"כ ובפ' ויגש) יש לנו אב זקן וילד זקנים קטן ואחיו מת פרש"י מפני היראה הי' מוציא דבר שקר מפיו וכו', ולכאורה קשה לומר על השבטים הק' כזה, וכבר הבאנו לעיל מדברי הבמ"יח זלה"ה דמה שהתירו חז"ל לשנות כגון מפני דרכי שלום ואידך, היינו לומר בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין, ורק לשנות התירו ולא לשקר ח"ו, ובפרט השבטים הק' שהיו אחוזים ודבוקים במדת האמת בשרשו, ודאי לא יתכן בחי' זו אצלם, ועפ"י פשטות אפשר לתרץ עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל דנאבד זכרו אשתו מותרת ומדמה לו' למים שאין להם סוף שאשתו מותרת להנשא, וע"כ עפ"י הלכה ה"ה נחשב כמת וא"ש דמ"ש ואחיו מת לא הי' בדיבורם שקר, ולדרכנו אפ"ל עפימ"ש האוהחה"ק פ' ויגש עה"פ אמותה הפעם אחרי ראותי פניך כי עודך חי וזלה"ק הגם שנתבשר כי עודנו חי, זה הועיל לדעת שישנו במציאות, אבל עדיין לבו דוי עליו לצד היותו בון האומות שפל עבד מושלים, אם עודנו בצדקתו וכו', או לצד היותו מובדל ממנו ונותן בתוך הקליפות ובפרט טומאת מצרים וכו', ודבר ידוע כו הצדיקים יותר יחפצו בהעדר הבן בהיותו בן מביש וכו' אשר ע"כ לא היתה שמחתו שלימה מספק זה, עד וירא אליו והכיר בו בפניו וכו' עיי"ש. ואולי מה"ט ויפג לבו כי לא האמין להם, כו בדרך הטבע לא הי' במציאות שיתקיים בצדקתו שהוא חיים הנצחיים, ורק ע"ו גודל מסנ"פ שהוא ג"כ בחי' מיתה נשאר חי וקים בצדקתו, וק"ז זלל"ה בייט"פ פי' ושבח אני את המתים שכבר מתו מן החיים אשר עודנה חיים, ר"ל הצדיקים אשר בחיים חיותם נחשבים כמתים ע"י מסנ"פ להבוית"ש, ועי"ז אשר עודנה חיים נשארים חיים וקיימים וא"צ לבחי' מיתה, ובזה א"ש מ"ש יהודה ואחיו מת דממנ"פ אם נלכד ונתקלקל ח"ו בחבורת רשעים ה"ה חשוב כמת, דרשעים בחייהם קרויים מתים, ואם עמד ונתקיים בצדקתו, א"א כ"א בכח מסנ"פ, אמיתית, וה"ה מן המתים אשר כבר מתו, ובכל אופן לא הוציא דיבור שקר מפיו, אלא שדיבר בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין, וע"כ אמרז"ל דמפני היראה עשה כן, ובכגון דא מותר לומר בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין כנ"ל
translation:
And similarly, one could say from the verse (in Parshat Vayigash) that we have a father who is old and a young child, and his brother is dead. Rashi explains that out of fear, he was speaking falsehood, etc. At first glance, it is difficult to say such a thing about the holy tribes. We have already brought earlier from the words of the Baal HaMaor, may his memory be blessed, that what the Sages permitted to alter, such as for the sake of peace and the like, means to say in a manner that can be understood in two ways. They permitted to alter but not to lie, Heaven forbid, especially the holy tribes who were bound and attached to the attribute of truth at their root; certainly, this cannot be the case with them. According to the simple interpretation, one could explain based on what Rambam, may his memory be blessed, said that if a man's wife is lost, he is permitted to marry, and he compares it to water that has no end, meaning that his wife is permitted to marry. Therefore, according to halacha, he is considered as if he is dead, and it is clear that what was said, "and his brother is dead," was not a false statement. 

And according to our path, one could explain based on what the holy Avraham said in Parshat Vayigash regarding the verse, "I will die this time after seeing your face, for you are still alive." The meaning is that although he was informed that he is still alive, this helped him to know that he exists in reality. However, his heart was still pained because he was a lowly servant among the nations, if he is still in his righteousness, etc., or because he is separated from him and placed among the shells, especially the impurity of Egypt, etc. It is well known that the righteous desire more the absence of a son when he is a son of shame, etc., and therefore his joy was not complete due to this doubt, until "and he saw him and recognized him in his face," etc. 

And perhaps for this reason, "his heart failed him because he did not believe them," etc. By the way of nature, it was not possible that he would remain in his righteousness, which is eternal life, and only due to the greatness of the aspect of death, which is also a form of death, he remained alive and established in his righteousness. And this is what is said, "I praise the dead who have already died from the living who are still alive," meaning the righteous who in their living are considered as dead due to the aspect of death, and thus those who are still alive remain alive and established and do not need the aspect of death. 

And in this, it is clear what Judah said, "and his brother is dead," for from the aspect of the dead, if he was caught and corrupted, Heaven forbid, among a group of wicked, he is considered as dead. The wicked in their lives are called dead, and if he stood and remained in his righteousness, it is only through the true aspect of death. And so it is with the dead who have already died, and in any case, he did not speak a falsehood from his mouth, but rather spoke in a manner that can be understood in two ways. Therefore, our Sages said that out of fear, he did so, and in such a case, it is permitted to speak in a manner that can be understood in two ways, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of truth and the nature of speech among the holy tribes of Israel, emphasizing that they were deeply rooted in the attribute of truth. It suggests that when they spoke of their brother as "dead," it was not a lie but rather a nuanced expression reflecting their understanding of his spiritual state, particularly in relation to the challenges of living righteously amidst adversity. The text highlights the idea that true life is found in righteousness, and those who stray from it are considered spiritually dead, even if they are physically alive. Ultimately, it affirms that the tribes did not utter falsehoods but communicated in a way that could be interpreted in multiple ways, especially in the context of fear and the complexities of their situation.

passage_content: ועד"ז יל"פ במאמה"כ (סו"פ מקץ) אשר ימצא אתו מעבדוך ומת, ולכאורה מדוע הוציאו דינו למיתה, ואין דינו של גניבה בכך. ואפ"ל לדרכנו דעל עון חילול השם אמרז"ל בגמ' דיומא הנ"ל דאין כח בתשובה לתלות ולא ביוכ"פ לכפר ולא ביסורין למרק, אלא כולן תולין ומיתה ממרקת שנא' אם יכופר העון לכם עד תמותון, ואין לך חילול השם גדול מזה אם ימצא בעבדי ד' שעברו על איסור גניבה, ע"כ יפה אמרו אשר ימצא אתו מעבדיך (שהוא גנבו) ומת אין לו תקנה אלא במיתה ר"ל, ולא היתה כוונתו שהוא ימיתהו אלא שתקנתו במיתה או במסנ"פ שנחשב למיתה, ואף שמשמעות פשוטו מורה שדינו למיתה, לא חשו לזה, כי הי' ברור בידם שלא עבר שום א' מהם על גניבה ולא על חילול השם והאמת כן הי', היוצא לנו מזה דחטא הידוע אין לו תקנה כ"א ע"ו מסנ"פ להבוית"ש ולקיום התוהה"ק, ובפרט ברבות הנסיונות שבדורנו א"א להתקיים ולהתחזק כ"א בכח מסנ"פ, והתחלת גדר המסנ"פ הוא לוותר על תאוותיו ורצוניותיו בשביל רצון הבוי"ת וקיום התומ"צ, דאם אין מוותרין מאומה אין זה בגדר מסנ"פ כלל.
translation: And similarly, it can be explained in the context of the verse (in Parashat Miketz) that if one finds his servant who has stolen and dies, seemingly, why is his judgment one of death, as theft does not warrant such a punishment. And it can be said in our way that regarding the sin of desecrating the Name, our sages have said in the Gemara of Yoma that there is no power in repentance to atone, nor on Yom Kippur to forgive, nor in suffering to cleanse, but all are dependent on death to atone, as it is said, "If the sin is not atoned for, you shall die." There is no greater desecration of the Name than if it is found among the servants of God that they have transgressed the prohibition of theft. Therefore, it is well said that if he finds him among your servants (who is the thief) and he dies, he has no remedy except through death, so to speak. And his intention was not that he should kill him, but that his remedy is through death or through suffering, which is considered as death. And even though the simple meaning indicates that his judgment is death, they did not regard this, for it was clear to them that none of them had transgressed theft or desecrated the Name, and indeed it was so. What emerges from this is that a known sin has no remedy except through suffering and repentance for the sake of Heaven and the fulfillment of the Torah and commandments, especially with the many trials in our generation; it is impossible to endure and strengthen oneself except through the power of suffering. And the beginning of the boundary of suffering is to forgo one's desires and wishes for the will of the Creator and the fulfillment of the Torah and commandments, for if one does not forgo anything, it is not within the realm of suffering at all.
summary: The passage discusses the severe consequences of חילול השם (desecration of God's name) in the context of theft, emphasizing that true repentance and atonement are insufficient without the ultimate sacrifice of death or suffering. It highlights that the only remedy for such a grave sin is through a form of self-sacrifice (מסנ"פ), which involves relinquishing personal desires for the sake of fulfilling God's will and adhering to the Torah. The text underscores the importance of this self-denial, especially in the face of contemporary challenges, as a means to maintain spiritual strength and commitment to divine commandments.

passage_content: ודרך אגב נל"פ מאמרז"ל במס' ערובין (כ"א ע"ב) דרש רבא מאי דכתיב (שה"ש ז') לכה דודי נצא השדה וגו', אמרה כנסת ישראל לפני הקב"ה רבש"ע אל תדיננו כיושבי כרכים שיש בהן גזל ועריות ושבועת שוא ושבועת שקר, נצא השדה בא ואראך תלמידי חכמים שעוסקין בתורה מתוך הדחק, פרש"י כרכים מקום שווקים הן ויישוב גדול ורגל רוכלין וסוחרין מצוי' שם לפיכך גזל ועריות נוהג בהן, השדה בני באגא ועובדי אדמה ועוסקין בתורה מתוך דוחק עכ"ל, ולכאורה ראוי להבין דהן אמת שוושבו כרכים מצוי בהם גזל ועריות יותר, הן לצד ריבוי העם בהתערבות מינים ממינים שונים, והן לצד ריבוי התאוות וההפקרות שהשיגם קרובה בכרכים יותר מבשדה, אולם מ"מ לאו כללא הוא, והרי בכרכים מצוי ג"כ עוסקי תורה וישיבות, וגם בשדה ימצא עוברי עבירה ר"ל, והול"ל אל תדינני כעוסקי בגזל ועריות אלא כעוסקו בתורה, ומדוע פסק והחליט דינם של כל יושבי כרכים לריעותא, ומה יעשה האדם אם נסתבב לו מאת המסבב כל הסיבות ית"ש להיות דירתו בכרכים.
translation:
And incidentally, it seems to me that the sages of blessed memory in the tractate Eruvin (21b) expounded on what is written (Song of Songs 7): "Come, my beloved, let us go out to the field," etc. The congregation of Israel said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: "Master of the Universe, do not judge us like the inhabitants of cities, where there is theft, immorality, false oaths, and lies. Let us go out to the field, and I will show you students of the sages who engage in Torah despite hardship." Rashi explains that cities are places of markets and large settlements, where merchants and traders are commonly found, and therefore theft and immorality are prevalent there. The field represents the sons of the land, farmers, and those who engage in Torah despite difficulties. 

However, it is appropriate to understand that although it is true that cities are more prone to theft and immorality, both due to the large population with a mix of different kinds and due to the abundance of desires and lawlessness that are more prevalent in cities than in the field, nonetheless, this is not a general rule. For in cities, there are also those who engage in Torah and yeshivas, and in the field, one can also find transgressors, Heaven forbid. It should have been stated: "Do not judge me like those who engage in theft and immorality, but like those who engage in Torah." Why then did they rule and decide that the judgment of all the inhabitants of cities is negative? And what is a person to do if he finds himself, due to the circumstances caused by the One who causes all causes, living in a city?
summary: The passage discusses a teaching from the Talmud regarding the distinction between the moral conditions of city dwellers and those living in the fields. It highlights the plea of the Jewish people to God, asking not to be judged like the inhabitants of cities, which are associated with sin and corruption due to their density and temptations. The text emphasizes that while cities may have more transgressions, there are also righteous individuals engaged in Torah study within them, suggesting a nuanced understanding of human behavior and divine judgment. Ultimately, it raises questions about the nature of sin and righteousness in different environments, reflecting on the complexities of spiritual life in both urban and rural settings.

passage_content: ואפ"ל בדרך רמז מוסר עפימ"ש בדברנו בכ"מ, כי ההתיישבות בעוה"ז גורם נזק גדול לעבדות הבוית"ש, וצריך האדם להתבונן ולזכור כל ימי חייו כי דירתו בעוה"ז אינו אלא עראי ופרוזדור ליכנס לטרקלין הוא חיי עוה"ב, משא"כ אם יעשה את הטפל לעיקר. ימשך ויגרר אח"כ מהמותרות אל תאווות האסורות ר"ל, וישכח תכלית שליחותו ותפקידו בעוה"ז, והעיקר יהי' בעיניו לטפל, וכתב ק"ז הייט"ל בשם ארי' דבי עילאה זלה"ה לפרש אמרם ז"ל יציבא בארעא גיורא בשמי שמיא, דמי שעושה עצמו כתושב בעוה"ז, ה"ה גיורא בשמי שמיא ויחשב כגר בעולם העליון, וז"ש כנס"י רבש"ע אל תדינני אכיושבי" כרכים: ולא אמרו כדרי כרכים, אלא כיושבי כרכים, אותן הרודפים אחר ההתיישבות בכרכים שהמותרות והתאוות שכיח ומצוי בהן לרוב, והזיקם קרובה שעי"ז יכשלו ח"ו בגזל ועריות ושבועת שוא ושקר, וכמ"ש לעיל שא"א להתקיים ולהתחזק בשמירת התומ"צ כ"א בכח מסנ"פ, והתחלת גדר מסנ"פ לוותר על המותרות ותאווות ולהתרחק מצ"ט שערי היתר שלא יכשל בשער א' של איסור, נצא השדה שנזכה להיות מאותן שעוסקין בתורה, והעוה"ז נחשב בעיניהם לדירת עראי כשדה.
translation: And even though it is hinted as a moral teaching, as we have discussed elsewhere, that the settlement in this world causes great damage to the service of the Master of the Universe, a person must contemplate and remember throughout his life that his dwelling in this world is nothing but temporary and a corridor to enter the hall, which is the life of the World to Come. Conversely, if he makes the secondary the primary, he will be drawn and dragged from the permissible to the forbidden desires, Heaven forbid, and he will forget the purpose of his mission and role in this world, and the primary will become secondary in his eyes. And it is written, as it is stated in the name of the Holy Lion of the Upper House, to explain what our Sages said: "A resident in the land is like a convert in the heavens," that one who makes himself like a resident in this world is indeed a convert in the heavens and is considered like a convert in the upper world. And this is what the Holy Congregation says: "Master of the Universe, do not judge me like the inhabitants of cities." They did not say "like the dwellers of cities," but "like the inhabitants of cities," those who pursue settlement in cities where luxuries and desires are abundant and prevalent, and the danger is close that through this they will stumble, Heaven forbid, in theft, illicit relations, false oaths, and lies. As mentioned above, it is impossible to exist and strengthen oneself in the observance of the Torah and commandments except through the power of the righteous. The beginning of the fence of the righteous is to forgo luxuries and desires and to distance oneself from the 24 gates of permissibility so that he does not stumble at one gate of prohibition. Let us go out to the field so that we merit to be among those who engage in Torah, and this world will be considered in their eyes as a temporary dwelling like a field.
summary: The passage emphasizes that one's life in this world is merely a temporary dwelling, serving as a corridor to the eternal life of the World to Come. It warns against becoming overly attached to worldly comforts and desires, which can lead to spiritual downfall and distraction from one's true purpose. The text highlights the importance of prioritizing spiritual pursuits over materialism, suggesting that those who immerse themselves in the allure of worldly living risk being considered as outsiders in the spiritual realm. Ultimately, it calls for a commitment to Torah study and a lifestyle that recognizes the transient nature of earthly existence.

passage_content: ומעתה נבוא לבאר סתירת מאמרי רז"ל בענין התחלת השעבוד, והוא שכתב רש"י ז"ל בשם מדרשי חז"ל דמשמת יעקב נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השעבוד, ובמקו"א אמרו דכ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים וכ"ז שהי' א' מהשבטים קיים לא נשתעבדו המצריים בישראל כלל, וכבר ביארנו בזה בפנים שונים, ואפ"ל בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק פ' ויחי (רט"ז ע"ב) ויחי יעקב באמ"צ אמאי פרשתא דא סתימא ר' יעקב אמר בשעתא דמית יעקב אסתימו עיניהון דישראל (ובניצוצי אורות בפי' על הזוה"ק כתב בשם המפרשים דהכוונה על עסק התורה, שנסתמו מישראל מעיינות החכמה שהי' יעקב מגלה עכ"ל) ר' יהודה אמר דכדין נחתו לגלותא ואשתעבידו בהון עכ"ד הזוה"ק לעניננו, ונל"פ דלא פליגי ר' יעקב ור"י, ואפשר דשניהם מודים דלא נשתעבדו ישראל בעבודת המצרים משמת יעקב, דכ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים הי' מלך ומושל עליהם נמנע מהם האפשרות לשעבד בישראל אף אם הי' רצונם בכך, וכ"ז שא' מהשבטים קיים אמרז"ל שלא נשתעבדו בישראל, אמנם הכוונה בזה לבחי' שעבוד אחרת, עפימ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה בפ' בלק, שאין דבר בעולם מזיק לנפש כמו התחברות עם אדם רשע אף לפי שעה, אף אם אינו ניכר נכנס בנפש כמו העכס וארס וברוב הימים ימצא, וצריך לזה זכות גדול בצירוף העסק בתורה שיצא ממנו העכס והארס כולי האי ואולי אחר זמן רב עכ"ל, ואפ"ל לאידך גיסא כו המצרים לא השתעבדו בישראל כלל כ"ז שהי' יוסף קיים, אדרבה לצד שהם בני משפחתו של יוסף שהי' מלך ומושל עליהם, נהגו בהם נימוס של כבוד כמשפט בני המלכים, והראו להם אותות אהבה ואחוה וריעות, וההתחברות עם רשעים גורם רעה לבחינת הנפש יותר מהשתעבדות עבודתם, והבאנו לעיל מדברי הירושלמי שדרשו ז"ל ונתן עול ברזל על צווארך זה הרעיון, שפגימת כלו המחשבה נקרא עול ברזל ושעבוד קשה, אמנם כל זמן שהי' יעקב אבינו קיים ולמד עמהם תורה וגילה להם מעיינות החכמה, לא פעלו עליהם דיבורם וחלקלקות לשונם של מצרים לרוע ונתבטלו כאפס ואין לנגד השפעת הקדושה שהשפיע יע"א אליהם, אבל בשעתא דמית יעקב נסתמו מהם מעיינות החכמה שהי' מגלה להם, ע"כ כדין נחתו לגלותא ואשתעבודו בהון, ולא שעבוד בעבודה כ"א ע"י דיבוריהם והתחברותם, ולפי"ז דברי ר' יעקב ור' יהודה בזוה"ק הנ"ל על קוטב א' יסובבו, דלפי שנסתמו מהם מעיינות החכמה ע"כ התחילה השעבוד בהם, ומ"ש רז"ל דכ"ז שיוסף קיים וכ"ז שא' מהשבטים קיים לא נשתעבדו בהם בישראל אפ"ל ג"כ עפ"י בחי' הנ"ל, דעכ"פ כ"ז שהי' יוסף וא' מהשבעום קיים, אף שנחלש ונתמעט כח הקדושה בהסתלקות יע"א, מ"מ לגודל קדושתם של השבטים הק' לא יכלו המצריים להתגבר עליהם בכח טומאתם, אלא מדרגא לדרגא השתעבדו בהם בבחי' הנפש תחלה, בהסתלקות יע"א, ואח"כ במיתת יוסף הצדיק ויותר מזה במיתת השבטים, אבל השעבוד בעבודה אולי התחילה רק שלשים שנה לפני יציאתם ממצרים כמ"ש בפרדר"א.
translation: And from now on we will explain the contradiction in the sayings of our Sages regarding the beginning of the servitude. It is written by Rashi, blessed be his memory, in the name of the Midrashim of our Sages that from the time of Jacob's passing, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed to the suffering of the servitude. In another place, they said that as long as Joseph was alive and as long as one of the tribes was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel at all. We have already explained this in various ways, and it can be said that in light of the words of the Zohar in Parashat Vayechi (116b), "And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt," why is this section closed? Rabbi Jacob said that at the time of Jacob's death, the eyes of Israel were closed (and in the Nitzotzei Orot, in the commentary on the Zohar, it is written in the name of the commentators that the intention is regarding the study of Torah, that the springs of wisdom that Jacob revealed were closed to Israel). Rabbi Judah said that indeed they descended to exile and were enslaved by them. Thus, the Zohar relates to our matter. It seems that Rabbi Jacob and Rabbi Judah do not disagree, and it is possible that both agree that Israel was not enslaved in the work of the Egyptians from the time of Jacob's passing. As long as Joseph was alive, he was a king and ruled over them, preventing them from having the possibility to enslave Israel even if they desired to do so. And as long as one of the tribes was alive, our Sages said that they were not enslaved in Israel. However, the intention here is regarding a different type of servitude, as it is stated in the words of the holy Yismach Moshe in Parashat Balak, that nothing in the world harms the soul like associating with a wicked person, even for a moment, even if it is not noticeable, it enters the soul like poison and venom, and for most days, one will find it, and one needs a great merit in conjunction with the study of Torah to remove the poison and venom completely, and perhaps after a long time. And it can also be said on the other hand that the Egyptians did not enslave Israel at all as long as Joseph was alive; rather, because they were the family of Joseph, who was a king and ruled over them, they treated them with the respect due to the sons of kings, and showed them signs of love, brotherhood, and friendship. And the association with the wicked causes more harm to the soul than the servitude of their work. We have brought above from the words of the Jerusalem Talmud that our Sages expounded, "And He put a yoke of iron upon your neck," this idea, that the blemish of the entire thought is called a yoke of iron and hard servitude. However, as long as our father Jacob was alive and learned Torah with them and revealed to them the springs of wisdom, the words and smoothness of the tongue of the Egyptians did not affect them for evil and were nullified as nothing against the influence of holiness that he, blessed be He, imparted to them. But at the time of Jacob's death, the springs of wisdom that he revealed to them were closed, therefore they indeed descended to exile and were enslaved by them, not through labor but through their words and their association. According to this, the words of Rabbi Jacob and Rabbi Judah in the aforementioned Zohar will revolve around one pole, that since the springs of wisdom were closed to them, therefore the servitude began within them. And what our Sages said that as long as Joseph was alive and as long as one of the tribes was alive, they were not enslaved in Israel can also be understood according to the aforementioned aspect, that at least as long as Joseph and one of the tribes were alive, even though the power of holiness weakened and diminished with the departure of the blessed one, nevertheless, due to the great sanctity of the holy tribes, the Egyptians could not overpower them with the strength of their impurity. Rather, they were enslaved gradually, first in the aspect of the soul, with the departure of the blessed one, and afterwards with the death of the righteous Joseph, and even more so with the death of the tribes. But the servitude in labor perhaps only began thirty years before their departure from Egypt, as stated in the Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Jewish people's subjugation in Egypt, emphasizing that their suffering began only after the death of Jacob, which led to a cessation of divine wisdom and protection. It highlights that as long as Joseph and one of the tribes were alive, the Egyptians could not fully oppress the Israelites due to their inherent holiness. The text suggests that the true spiritual bondage began with the loss of Jacob's teachings and the subsequent weakening of the Israelites' connection to divine wisdom, leading to a gradual decline in their spiritual state and eventual subjugation. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound impact of righteous leadership and the importance of maintaining a connection to Torah to counteract spiritual degradation.

passage_content: באופן אחר יתבאר דברי רז"ל למה פרשה זו סתומה וכו' ויתיישבו הדקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר במאמה"כ ואני בבאי מפדן מתה עלי רחל בארץ כנען וגו' פירש"י ז"ל ואע"פ שאני מטריח עליך להוליכנו להקבר בארץ כנען ולא כך עשיתי לאמך וכו', וידעתי שיש בלבך עלי, אבל דע לך שעפ"י הדיבור קברתי' שם שתהא לעזרה לבני' כשיגלה אותם נבוזראדן והיו עוברים דרך שם וכו' עכ"ל, ראוי להבין דכיון שמאמר זה התנצלות ליוסף על שהטריח עליו להוליכו לקברו בארץ כנען למה המתין בזה עד הכא והי"ל לומר דיבורים אלו בשעה שצוהו ונשאתני ממצרים וגו', כי שם מקומם.
translation: In another way, the words of our Sages will be explained as to why this section is closed, etc., and the aforementioned grammatical points will be resolved by first noting the verse, "And as I was coming from Padan, Rachel died upon me in the land of Canaan," etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains, "And although I am troubling you to take us to be buried in the land of Canaan, and I did not do so for your mother, etc., and I know that there is something in your heart against me, but know that according to the word, I buried her there so that she would be a help to her children when Nebuzaradan would reveal them, and they would pass through there," etc. It is fitting to understand that since this statement is an apology to Joseph for troubling him to take him to be buried in the land of Canaan, why did he wait until now to say this? He could have said these words at the time he commanded him, "And you shall carry me out of Egypt," etc., for that is where it belongs.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Rachel's burial in Bethlehem, emphasizing that her grave serves as a source of comfort and assistance for her descendants during their future exile. It reflects on the idea that even in moments of distress, divine providence is at work, as Rachel's burial place is strategically chosen to provide solace to the Jewish people when they face hardship. The text highlights the importance of understanding the deeper reasons behind biblical events, suggesting that every action has a purpose in the divine plan. Ultimately, it conveys a message of hope and reassurance amidst suffering, rooted in the belief that God is aware of and responsive to the struggles of His people.

passage_content: ב) ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת וגו' פירש"י ז"ל חסד שעושין עם המתים הוא חסד של אמת שאינו מצפה לתשלום גמול, הקשו המפרשים הלא מצינו שיע"א שילם ליוסף גמולו כמ"ש ואני נתתי לך שכם אחד על אחיך פי' רש"י לפי שאתה טורח להתעסק בקבורתו וכו'
translation: B) "And you shall do with me kindness and truth," etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that the kindness done with the dead is the kindness of truth, which does not await a reward. The commentators questioned, however, that we find that Yaakov paid Yosef his reward, as it is written, "And I have given you one portion above your brothers," Rashi explains, "because you are troubled with the burial," etc.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "chesed shel emet," or true kindness, which is performed for the deceased without expectation of reward. Rashi explains that this form of kindness is the highest level of altruism, as it is done solely for the sake of the act itself. The text also references the idea that even in the context of kindness towards the living, such as Joseph's reward for his efforts in burial, the essence of true kindness remains selfless and unreciprocated. This highlights the Hasidic emphasis on the purity of intention in acts of kindness, particularly towards those who can no longer repay.

passage_content: ונראה ביאור הענין עפי"מ דאיתא בילקוט ראובני (פ' חיי שרה) וז"ל, מערת המכפלה אשר בחברון שם קבורת האבות, וידוע כי הוא מעבר לג"ע התחתון וכו', וכן כל הנפטרים בה והנקברים בה זוכים לעלות נפשיהם ביתד תקוע לעבור לג"ע התחתון בלו עיכוב. ולא מי שימחה בידם וכו', ולבן תקע את אחיו בהר הגלעד, ר"ל שכיון כח במכשפיו להעתיק את אהל יעקב שלא יזכה למערת המכפלה וכו' ולתקוע את אחיו שהם אדום וישמעאל שהם יזכו להעביר דרך המערה לג"ע וכו', ואם ח"ו לא הי' יעקב נקבר שם לא הי' שום אחד מישראל עובר דרך שם, כ"א אומה"ע ח"ו היו עוברים דרך שם, ע"י אחיזת אדום וישמעאל, וזהו אמרז"ל ולבן בקש לעקור את הכל שנאמר ארמי אובד אבי וכו' עיי"ש, מבואר שחסד גדול נעשה לכלל ישראל ע"י שנקבר יע"א במערת המכפלה ובזה יובן אמרם ז"ל חסד שעושין עם המתים, ר"ל עם המתים של כל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, והוא חסד של אמת שאינו מצפה לתשלום גמול, וא"ש מה שאמר חסד ואמת בוא"ו המחלקת דב' בחינות הם ויע"א אמר לו שני דברים ועשית עמדי חסד, פי' לי לעצמי ואין זה חסד של אמת כי שילם לו גמולו כנ"ל, ונוסף לזה תעשה חסד של אמת עם המתים של כל ישראל, והוא חסד של אמת.
translation: And we will see the explanation of the matter according to what is stated in Yalkut Reuveni (Parashat Chayei Sarah), and it says: The Cave of Machpelah, which is in Hebron, is the burial place of the Patriarchs, and it is known that it is beyond the lower Garden of Eden, etc. And so all the deceased and those buried there merit to have their souls ascend through a fixed peg to pass to the lower Garden of Eden without delay. And not one who will hinder them, etc. And Laban buried his brother on Mount Gilead, meaning he exerted power with his sorceries to transfer the tent of Jacob so that he would not merit the Cave of Machpelah, etc., and to cause his brothers, who are Edom and Ishmael, to merit to pass through the cave to the Garden of Eden, etc. And if, Heaven forbid, Jacob had not been buried there, no one from Israel would pass through there, but rather the nations of the world, Heaven forbid, would pass through there, due to the hold of Edom and Ishmael. And this is what our Sages said: Laban sought to uproot everything, as it is said, "An Aramean was about to destroy my father," etc. It is clear that a great kindness was done for all of Israel by the fact that he, blessed be He, was buried in the Cave of Machpelah, and this will clarify their saying, blessed be they, about the kindness done to the dead, meaning with the dead of all Israel until the end of all generations, and it is a true kindness that does not expect a reward. And it is understood why it is said "kindness and truth" with a vav, indicating that there are two aspects, and blessed be He said to him two things, "and you will do kindness with me," meaning for myself, and this is not a true kindness because he paid him his reward as mentioned above. In addition to this, you will do a true kindness with the dead of all Israel, and this is a true kindness.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Cave of Machpelah in Hebron as a burial site for the patriarchs, emphasizing its role in facilitating the souls of the deceased to ascend to the lower Garden of Eden without delay. It highlights the spiritual struggle against forces like Esau and Ishmael, who sought to prevent Jacob from being buried there, which would have denied the Jewish people access to this sacred site. The text underscores the concept of "chesed shel emet" (true kindness) performed for the dead, which is an act of kindness that expects no reward, contrasting it with acts of kindness that are transactional. Ultimately, the burial of Jacob in the Cave of Machpelah is portrayed as a profound act of grace that benefits all of Israel throughout generations.

passage_content: ואיתא במד"ר עה"פ ויאמר לו מה החלום הזה אשר חלמת, ר' לוי בשם ר' חמא בר חנינא כך הי' יע"א סבור שתחה"מ מגעת בימיו, שנאמר הבוא נבוא אני ואמך וכו', ואם יע"א הי' סבור כן ודאי שכל ישראל היו מצפים לזה, ועכשיו ששמעו איך שצוה את יוסף ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת היינו חסד שעושין עם המתים וכו', השיגו מזה שלא יהי' תחה"מ מיד ויהיו המתים צריכין עוד לחסד של אמת, ע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מהשגת ידיעה זו, שעליהם לפרוע שט"ח של ברית בין הבתרים אמנם כ"ז שיע"א הי' חי עמהם היו מצפים עדיין שיבטל גזירת השיעבוד, דצדיקים כל זמן שהם חיים מוסיפים והולכים בעבדות ה' ב"ה, וכוחם גדול להיות גזירתם מתקיימת ע"ד ותגזר אומר ויקום לך, אבל אחר שנסתלק מן העולם אז השיגו שהוחלט הגזירה, והתחלת ההרגשה הי' עוד מזמן שאמר ליוסף ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת, ע"כ נרמז הסתימה בריש הפרשה כשאמר ליוסף ועשית עמדי חסד ואמת,
translation: And it is stated in the Midrash on the verse "And he said to him, What is this dream that you have dreamed," Rabbi Levi in the name of Rabbi Chama bar Chanina said: Thus it was, may it be His will, that he thought the resurrection of the dead would occur in his days, as it is said, "Will we come, I and your mother, etc." And if he, may it be His will, thought so, certainly all of Israel were expecting this. And now that they heard how he commanded Joseph, "And you shall do kindness and truth with me," which is the kindness done with the dead, etc., they understood from this that the resurrection of the dead would not happen immediately and that the dead would still need the kindness of truth. Therefore, the eyes and hearts of Israel were sealed from grasping this knowledge, that they must fulfill the obligation of the covenant between the parts. However, as long as he, may it be His will, was alive with them, they were still expecting that the decree of servitude would be annulled, for the righteous, as long as they are alive, continue to increase in the service of the Blessed Holy One, and their power is great to have their decree established as it is said, "And you shall decree a thing, and it shall be established for you." But after he departed from the world, they understood that the decree had been finalized, and the beginning of the feeling was already from the time he said to Joseph, "And you shall do kindness and truth with me." Therefore, the sealing is hinted at at the beginning of the portion when he said to Joseph, "And you shall do kindness and truth with me."
summary: The passage discusses the anticipation of the resurrection of the dead (Techiyat HaMetim) during the time of Rabbi Yochanan, highlighting the belief that the presence of righteous individuals can influence divine decrees. It reflects on the disappointment of the Jewish people upon realizing that the resurrection would not occur immediately, as indicated by Joseph's request for kindness and truth, which signifies the need for continued acts of kindness towards the deceased. The text emphasizes the power of the righteous while alive to mitigate suffering and the eventual acceptance of the harsh realities of exile and servitude after their passing. This illustrates the deep connection between faith, divine justice, and the role of righteous individuals in shaping the spiritual landscape.

passage_content: ויתבאר עוד בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ (בפ' שמות) ויאמר משה אל האלקים וגו' ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אליהם ויאמר אלקים אל משה אהי' אשר אהי' ויאמר כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי' שלחני אליכם, פירש"י אהי' עמכם בצרה זאת, אשר אהי' עמם בשיעבוד שאר מלכיות, אמר לפניו רבש"ע מה אני מזכיר להם צרה אחרת, דיים בצרה זו, א"ל יפה אמרת כה תאמר וגו', והקשו המפרשים איך אפשר שמשה השכיל חלילה על דברו השם והקב"ה הצדיק את דבריו, וכבר בארנו בזה אופנים שונים, וכעת נל"פ עפ"י פשטות. דהנה במאמר השם אהי' אשר אהי', אינו מבורר בהחלט שהכוונה על שיעבוד שאר מלכיות, דכמו"כ אפשר לפרש אשר אהי' עמכם בעת הגאולה, והבטיחנו ית' שישרה שכינתו בישראל ודביקותן של ישראל בהבוי"ת יהי' אז בבחי' גבוה יותר, וע"ד שפירשתי אמרינו (בנוסח קדושת כתר) הן גאלתי אתכם אחרית כראשית, דלכאורה הרי אמרז"ל (תענית ז' ע"א) מי נתלה במו, הוי אומר קטן נתלה בגדול, וידוע שגאולה העתידה תהי' בחינתה גדולה הרבה מגאועות הקודמות, ואיך נתלה הגדול בקטן, לומר שיגאל אותנו הבוי"ת אחרית כראשות, וגאולה העתידה אין ערוך אלי' בבחינתה, ואפ"ל דהנה גאולת מצרים הו' ראשיתו טובה, שנגאלו מטומאת מצרים וזכו לקבלת התורה וירושת הארץ, אבל אח"כ נתמעטו הדורות ונחלש כח הקדושה ובחי' השראת השכינה, עד שגרמו עונותינו לחורבן ביהמ"ק וגלות ישראל, א"כ לא הי' האחרית כראשות, אולם בגאולה העתידה לא יהי' כן, והאחרות יהי' טובה כראשות, וישראל יהיו מוסיפין והולכין בבחי' הקדושה והשראת השכינה למעלה עד אין חקר, ויזכו בכל פעם לבחי' חדשה גבוה למעלה מן הקודמים, והאחרית יהי' ג"כ ראשית לבחי' גבוה ממנה, וז"ש הן גאלתי אתכם אחרית כראשית והבן.
translation: And it will be further explained in advance to interpret from the Holy Scriptures (in Parashat Shemot) "And Moses said to God, etc. And they will say to me, 'What is His name? What shall I say to them?' And God said to Moses, 'I will be that I will be.' And He said, 'Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will be has sent me to you.' Rashi explains, 'I will be with you in this trouble, that I will be with them in the servitude of other kingdoms.' Moses said before Him, 'Master of the Universe, why should I mention to them another trouble? This trouble is enough.' He said to him, 'You have spoken well, thus you shall say, etc.' The commentators have questioned how it is possible that Moses, Heaven forbid, should have been wise about the words of the Name, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, validated his words. We have already explained this in various ways, and now we will interpret according to simplicity. Behold, in the statement of the Name, 'I will be that I will be,' it is not definitively clarified that the intention is regarding the servitude of other kingdoms, for it is also possible to interpret 'that I will be with you at the time of redemption,' and He has promised us that His Divine Presence will dwell in Israel, and the attachment of Israel to the Holy One, Blessed be He, will then be in a much higher state, in the manner that I have explained in our saying (in the text of the Kedushat Keter), 'Indeed, I have redeemed you, the end as the beginning.' For seemingly, our sages have said (Taanit 7a), 'Who is hung by whom? It must be that the small is hung by the great,' and it is known that the future redemption will be of a much greater nature than the previous redemptions, and how can the great be hung by the small, to say that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will redeem us at the end as at the beginning, and the future redemption has no comparison to it in its nature? And it can be said that the redemption from Egypt was indeed a good beginning, as they were redeemed from the impurity of Egypt and merited the receiving of the Torah and the inheritance of the land, but afterwards the generations diminished and the power of holiness and the aspect of the Divine Presence weakened, until our sins caused the destruction of the Holy Temple and the exile of Israel, thus the end was not like the beginning. However, in the future redemption, it will not be so, and the end will be good like the beginning, and Israel will continue to ascend in the aspect of holiness and the dwelling of the Divine Presence to a level beyond measure, and they will merit each time a new aspect higher than the previous ones, and the end will also be a beginning for a higher aspect than it. And this is what is meant by 'Indeed, I have redeemed you, the end as the beginning,' and understand.
summary: The passage discusses God's assurance to Moses that He will be with the Israelites during their suffering, emphasizing the continuity of divine presence from their current bondage to future redemption. It highlights the distinction between the redemption from Egypt, which was a beginning but led to spiritual decline, and the future redemption, which will be of a higher spiritual caliber, ensuring an ever-increasing closeness to God. The future redemption is portrayed as a culmination of spiritual elevation, where each subsequent experience of divine presence will surpass the previous ones, ultimately leading to a state where the end will be as significant as the beginning, if not greater.

passage_content: עכ"פ זה ברור דגם לעת הגאולה יש צורך להבטחה זו אשר אהי"", שהקב"ה ישרה שכינתו בישראל, נמצא שאינו מבורר הכוונה בו על שיעבוד מלכיות, אלא שמשרע"ה השיג גם בחי' המחשבה, וע"ד שפי' ק"ז הושמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' וישלח) אמרם זיל (ב"ב י"ב ע"א) חכם עדיף מנביא: דהצדיקום הגדולים המתדבקים בחכמה העליונה, יוכלו להשיג גם מחשבתו של יוצר בראשית, משא"כ הנביאים אין השגתם רק במה שיצא לפועל הדיבור ולא בחי' מחשבה עיי"ש. ומילתא דתליא בבחירה לא ניתנה להתגלות בבחי' דיבור כ"א בבחי' מחשבה, לפי שהדיבור מכריח הבחירה משא"כ הידיעה, ע"כ משרע"ה השיג בחכמתו שנרמז במאמר השי"ת שיהי' עוד שיעבוד, ובודאי הי' צורך לזה שישיג משרע"ה גלויות העתידים, כדי שיכין כח בתפלתו וזכותו להמתיק ולהקל כח השיעבוד והגלות, אלא שמשרע"ה הי' סבור, שנאמרה לו כן ע"ד שיגלה אותו לישראל, וע"כ שאל די' לצרה בשעתה מה אנו מזכיר להם צרה אחרת והשיב לו הקב"ה ופה אמרת כה תאמר לבנ"י אהי' שלחני אליכם, ותחלת המחשבה כך היתה שלא יגלה לישראל, ורק למשה לבדו נתגלה ולא ע"ד שיאמרנה לישראל, (עיין בדברנו פ' וארא ביאור הענין באריכות
translation:
Nevertheless, it is clear that even at the time of redemption, there is a need for this assurance of "I will be," that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will dwell His Presence in Israel. It is found that the intention is not clarified regarding the subjugation of kingdoms, but rather that Moshe Rabbeinu attained also a level of thought, as explained in the commentary on Psalm 67, where it is said that Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Vayishlach), stated: "A wise person is preferable to a prophet" (Baba Batra 12a). For the great righteous ones who cling to the supreme wisdom can attain even the thought of the Creator of the world, whereas the prophets can only grasp what has come to fruition in speech and not in the realm of thought, as noted there. 

And the matter that depends on free will was not given to be revealed in the form of speech, but rather in the form of thought, since speech compels choice, whereas knowledge does not. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu understood in his wisdom, as hinted in the statement of the Holy One, Blessed be He, that there would still be subjugation, and certainly there was a need for Moshe Rabbeinu to grasp the future exiles, so that he could prepare the strength in his prayer and merit to sweeten and alleviate the power of subjugation and exile. However, Moshe Rabbeinu thought that it was said to him in a manner that he would reveal it to Israel, and therefore he asked, "Why should we mention to them another trouble at this time?" And the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him, "And you shall say to the children of Israel, 'I will be' has sent me to you." And the initial thought was such that it would not be revealed to Israel, but only to Moshe alone, and not in a manner that he would say it to Israel. (See our discussion in Parashat Va'era for an elaboration on the matter.)
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of divine assurance for the future redemption, emphasizing that God's presence will dwell among Israel. It highlights that Moses, through his profound wisdom, was able to grasp the thoughts of the Creator, unlike the prophets who only understood the spoken word. The text suggests that the concept of choice is revealed through thought rather than speech, indicating that Moses's understanding of future exiles was essential for his prayers to mitigate their severity. Ultimately, it conveys that the revelation of God's intentions was initially meant only for Moses and not for the broader Israelite community.

passage_content: מבואר מזה יסוד איתן שלא יאות להודיע במוקדם גלות העתידה לבוא, שהרי הבוי"ת הצדיק טענת משרע"ה די' לצרה בשעתה, ואין לגלות כ"א בעת ההכרח ולצורך, כמו שגילה הקב"ה למשרע"ה לטעם זה כנ"ל, ובזה יתורץ קושיא הנ"ל (קושיא ב') מדוע לא התנצל יע"א ליוסף על קבורת רחל בדרך, בעת צוותו להוליכו לא"י בקברת אבותיו, ומאמר זה ואני בבואי מפדן וגו', הי' ראוי להאמר בתחלת הפרשה, לגלות לו טעמו ונימוקו שעפ"י הדיבור הי', אמנם יובן עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, דהרי בהתנצלות הזה גילה לו מחורבן וגלות המעותד לבוא על ישראל, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל שכשיגלה אותם נבוזראדן ויהיו עוברים דרך שם, רחל יצאת ומבקשת עליהם רחמים וכו', ע"כ לא רצה לגלות בחי' הגלות כ"ז שלא הי' הכרח לדבר, רק אח"כ כשחלה יעקב והשיג שהגיע עתו להסתלק, בהכרח גילה בהתנצלותו ליוסף שעשה כן עפ"י הדיבור מפני גזירת הגלות העתידה לבוא על ישראל, אולם השבעים הקדושים השיגו בחכמתם רמז הגלות הנרמז בצוואתו של יעאע"ה ועשית חסד ואמת כנ"ל אלא שהפשוטו עם לא נתגלה להם כ"א סמוך לפטירת יע"א, כשגילה בפירוש במאמר ואני בבאי מפדן, וע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של כל ישראל בהסתלקות יעאע"ה, אבל בני עלי' השיגו גזירת השעבוד בתחלה כשצוה יעקב ליוסף להוליכו לא"י, וע"כ נרמז הסתומה בתחלת הפרשה.
translation: It is clarified from this a firm foundation that it is not appropriate to announce in advance the exile that is to come, for the righteous Baal Shem Tov argued with Moshe Rabbeinu that it is proper to be concerned for trouble at the time it occurs, and one should only reveal it in times of necessity and need, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, revealed to Moshe Rabbeinu for this reason as mentioned above. And with this, the aforementioned question (question 2) is resolved: why did Yaakov Avinu not apologize to Yosef for Rachel's burial along the way, at the time he commanded him to take him to Eretz Yisrael to the burial of his forefathers? This statement, "And I, when I came from Padan, etc.," should have been said at the beginning of the section, to reveal to him the reason and justification according to the speech that was. However, it can be understood according to our aforementioned approach, for in this apology he revealed to him the destruction and exile that is destined to come upon Israel, as Rashi, of blessed memory, states that when Nebuzaradan exiles them and they pass by there, Rachel comes out and asks for mercy for them, etc. Therefore, he did not want to reveal the aspect of exile as long as there was no necessity to speak, only afterwards when Yaakov fell ill and realized that his time to depart had come, he was compelled to reveal in his apology to Yosef that he did so according to the speech because of the decree of the future exile that is to come upon Israel. However, the holy seventy understood with their wisdom the hint of the exile alluded to in the command of Yaakov Avinu to do kindness and truth as mentioned above, except that the simple meaning was not revealed to them until close to the passing of Yaakov Avinu, when he explicitly revealed in the statement, "And I, when I came from Padan," and therefore the eyes and hearts of all Israel were closed at the passing of Yaakov Avinu. But the sons of elevation understood the decree of servitude at the beginning when Yaakov commanded Yosef to take him to Eretz Yisrael, and therefore the hidden hint is alluded to at the beginning of the section.
summary: The passage emphasizes the principle that the future exile of the Jewish people should not be revealed prematurely, as it could lead to unnecessary distress. It discusses how Jacob's reluctance to explain the burial of Rachel to Joseph was rooted in the desire to avoid disclosing the impending suffering of exile. The text highlights that while the deeper implications of Jacob's words were understood by the righteous, the broader community remained unaware of the exile's significance until Jacob's passing, illustrating the tension between divine revelation and human understanding in the context of suffering and redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר בהקדם (דברינו בדרושים לשובבי"ם פ' ויחי) לתרץ קושית המפרשים עה"פ ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם וגו' דלא מצינו שהוליד יוסף עוד בנים, ולא זכרם הכתוב בשום מקום. ואיך תהי' ברכת יעאע"ה ומתנתו לבטלה, אמנם מצינו כי ברכותיו של יע"א היו רובם על העתיד, ואמרז"ל (סוטה ל"ו ע"ב) הי' ראוי יוסף לצאת ממנו י"ב שבעים כדרך שיצאו מיעקב אביו, שנא' אלה תולדות יעקב יוסף וכו'. אלא שע"י סיבת וכיון שנכנסת הנסיון נמנעו ממנו עיי"ש, ובאמת לא הי' זה פגם כ"א בערך גודל מדריגתו והפלגת קדושתו ע"ד וסביביו נשערה מאוד, אמנם לעתיד יתוקן הכל ויחזור אל הבחי' שהי' ראוי אלי' מתחילתו, ויעמוד י"ב שבטים שהיו ראויים לצאת ממנו, כי אין טעם למנוע אותם אחרי שיתוקן הפגם, ועוד יתעלו מדריגתם של צדיקים לע"ל, וא"ש מאמה"כ ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם וגו', אע"פ שלא נתקיים כן בשעתו, אבל כל דבריו היו על העתיד, ואז יתקיימו שעתידים לצאת ממנו י"ב שבעים, ועז"א ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם (עיי"ש ביאור הענין באריכות), עכ"פ במאמר זה ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם, נרמז בו סוד הגאולה, דא"א שתהי' נבואת יע"א ופסוקי התורה לבעלה ח"ו, וע"כ שרומז על הבעחת גאולה העתידה.
translation: And I can also explain it in another way, as mentioned in our discourses on Shovavim, Parashat Vayechi, to resolve the difficulty of the commentators regarding the verse "and your birthplace, where you were born after them," etc. For we do not find that Joseph fathered any more sons, and the text does not mention them anywhere. How could the blessing of our father Abraham and his gift be in vain? However, we find that most of the blessings of our father Abraham were concerning the future, and our sages of blessed memory said (Sotah 36b) that it was fitting for Joseph to have twelve tribes emerge from him, just as they emerged from his father Jacob, as it is said, "These are the generations of Jacob: Joseph," etc. Rather, due to the cause and the fact that he entered into the trial, they were withheld from him, as stated there. In truth, this was not a blemish except in relation to the greatness of his level and the extent of his holiness, as it was greatly diminished around him. However, in the future, everything will be rectified, and he will return to the level that he was worthy of from the beginning, and there will stand twelve tribes that were worthy to emerge from him, for there is no reason to withhold them after the blemish is rectified. Moreover, the levels of the righteous will be elevated in the World to Come, and it is clear from the verse "and your birthplace, where you were born after them," even though it was not fulfilled at that time, but all his words were about the future, and then it will be fulfilled that twelve tribes are destined to emerge from him. Therefore, it is said, "after the names of their brothers they will be called in their inheritance" (see there for an elaborate explanation of the matter). In any case, in this statement "and your birthplace, where you were born after them," the secret of redemption is hinted at, for it cannot be that the prophecy of our father Abraham and the verses of the Torah be in vain, Heaven forbid. Therefore, it hints at the hint of the future redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's blessings and the absence of mention of his additional sons, suggesting that while he did not have twelve tribes as Jacob did, this was not a flaw but rather a reflection of his elevated spiritual status. It emphasizes that Joseph's blessings were primarily prophetic, pointing to a future rectification where the twelve tribes will emerge from him, symbolizing the ultimate redemption. The text highlights the idea that divine prophecies and blessings are eternal and will manifest in the future, reinforcing the belief in the eventual fulfillment of God's promises. Additionally, it alludes to the connection between Joseph's lineage and the future redemption, indicating that the Torah's words are always relevant and will come to fruition.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ד במד"ר (איכה פ"ג י"ט) עה"פ זאת אשיב אל לבי על כן אוחיל, ראב"כ בש"ר יוחנן אמר מלה"ד למלך שנשא מטרונא וכתב לה כתובה מרובה וכו', הניחה המלך והלך לו למדינת הים ואיחר לשם. נכנסו שכנותי' אצלה והיו מקניטות אותה, ואומרות לה הניחך המלך והלך לו למדינת הים ושוב אינו חוזר עליך, והיתה בוכה ומתאנחת, לתוך ביתה פותחת ומוציאה כתובתה וקוראת ורואה בכתובתה כך וכך וכו' אני עושה לך, מיד היתה מתנחמת, לימים בא המלך אמר לה בתי אני תמה איך המתנת לי כל אותן השנים, אמרה לו אדוני המלך אלמלא כתובה מרובה שכתבת ונתת לי כבר אבדונו שכנותו, כך האומות מונין את ישראל ואומרין להם אלקיכם הסתיר פניו מכם וכו', וכיון שנכנסין לבתי כנסיות ולבתי מדרשות וקוראין בתורה ומוצאין שכתוב ופניתי אליכם וגו' הן מתנחמין, למחר כשיבוא קץ הגאולה אומר להם הקב"ה לישראל, בני אני תמה מכם היאך המתנתם לו כל אותן השנים, והן אומרים לפניו רבש"ע אלולי תורתך שנתת לנו כבר אבדונו האומות, לכך נאמר זאת אשיב אל לבי על כן אוחיל וכו' עכ"ד המדרש
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Midrash (Lamentations 3:19) on the verse "This I recall to my mind, therefore I have hope." Rabbi Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: It is like a king who married a noblewoman and wrote her a large ketubah, etc. The king left her and went to a distant land and delayed his return. The neighbors came to her and mocked her, saying, "The king has left you and gone to a distant land and will not return to you." And she was crying and sighing. She opened her house, took out her ketubah, read it, and saw in her ketubah such and such promises, etc., and immediately she was consoled. After some time, the king returned and said to her, "My daughter, I am amazed how you waited for me all those years." She said to him, "My lord the king, were it not for the large ketubah that you wrote and gave me, I would have already been lost to my neighbors." Thus, the nations count the days of Israel and say to them, "Your God has hidden His face from you," etc. And when they enter the houses of prayer and the houses of study and read in the Torah and find written, "And I will turn to you," etc., they are consoled. The next day, when the time of redemption comes, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will say to Israel, "My children, I am amazed at you how you waited for Me all those years." And they will say before Him, "Master of the Universe, were it not for the Torah that You gave us, we would have already been lost to the nations." Therefore, it is said, "This I recall to my mind, therefore I have hope," etc. Thus concludes the Midrash.
summary: The passage draws a parallel between a king's promise to a woman and God's covenant with Israel, emphasizing the theme of hope and patience in the face of adversity. Just as the woman finds comfort in her marriage contract during her loneliness, the Jewish people find solace in the Torah amidst their suffering and the nations' scorn. Ultimately, when redemption arrives, God will express wonder at Israel's endurance, attributing their survival to the teachings of the Torah. This reflects a deep theological insight into the enduring relationship between God and Israel, rooted in faith and the power of divine promises.

passage_content: והנה באמת אצל הבוי"ת לא שייך תמי' ופלא, ולפניו ית' גלוי הכל דמה שישראל עדיין מחזיקים באמונתו למרות כל הצרות ואריכות הגלות, הוא רק בכוחו ית', ואלולי כן כבר אבדנו ח"ו אעפ"כ יאמר הקב"ה תמה אני וכו', ויתבאר עפי"מ שפי' המפורשים מאמה"כ והללתם את שם ה אלקיכם אשר עשה עמכם להפליא, עפי"ד הגמ' (סוכה נ"ב ע"א) לע"ל מביאו הקב"ה ליצה"ר ושוחטו בפני הצדיקים ובפני הרשעים, צדיקים נדמה להם כהר גבוה וכו' ובוכין ואומרים האיך יכולנו לכבוש את ההר הגבוה הזה וכו', ואף הקב"ה תמה עמהם, שנא' כי יפלא בעיני שארית העם הזה גם בעיני יפלא עכ"ד הגמ', וביארו הכוונה כי אחרי ראות הצדיקים תוקף היצה"ר ורב חזקו, ישיגו כי לא הי' ביכולת אנושי לכבשו לולי עזר ה', ויחרדו ויאמרו א"כ איפוא נבוא על שכרנו, כיון שלא נעשה דבר מצידנו, והקב"ה ונחמם במה שיאמר גם בעיני יפלא על דבר נצחונם, כדי לתלות הנצחון בהם שלא יהי' שכרם בבחי' נהמא דכסופא, וז"ש והללתם את שם ה' אלקיכם אשר עשה עמכם להפליא, כמאמר הכתוב כי יפלא בעיני שארית העם הזה גם בעיני יפלא, ולא יבושו עמי לעולם, שיעשה הקב"ה כן שלא יהי' שכרם בבחי' נהמא דכסופא עכת"ד ז"ל, ועד"ז יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל שכשיבוא קץ הגאולה יאמר הקב"ה לישראל בני אנו תמה מכם האיך המתנתם לי כל אותן השנים, אף שגלוי וידוע לפניו ית' שאילולי עזרתו ות' לא יכולנו לעמוד ולהתקיים ולהתחזק באמונתו מפני כובד הגלות וגודל הנסיונות, מ"מ יהי' הבוי"ת תמה כדי להגדיל שכרנו ושלא יהי' בבחי' נהמא דכסופא כנ"ל,
translation: And behold, truly with regard to the Baal Teshuvah, there is no place for wonder and amazement, for before Him, blessed be He, everything is revealed. The fact that Israel still holds onto their faith despite all the troubles and the length of the exile is only by His power. Were it not for that, we would have already been lost, Heaven forbid. Nevertheless, the Holy One, blessed be He, will say, "I am amazed," etc. This will be explained according to the interpretation of the commentators on the verse, "And you shall praise the name of the Lord your God, who has done wondrously with you," according to the teaching of the Gemara (Sukkah 52a) that in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will bring the Yetzer Hara and slaughter it before the righteous and before the wicked. The righteous will see it as a high mountain, etc., and they will cry and say, "How could we have conquered this high mountain?" And even the Holy One, blessed be He, will be amazed with them, as it is said, "For it will be amazing in the eyes of the remnant of this people; it will also be amazing in My eyes," as stated in the Gemara. The intention is explained that after the righteous see the strength of the Yetzer Hara and its great power, they will realize that it was not within human ability to conquer it were it not for the help of God. They will tremble and say, "Then where will we come to our reward, since we did nothing on our part?" And the Holy One, blessed be He, will comfort them by saying that it will also be amazing in My eyes regarding their victory, in order to attribute the victory to them, so that their reward will not be in the category of "bread of shame." Therefore, it is said, "And you shall praise the name of the Lord your God, who has done wondrously with you," as the verse states, "For it will be amazing in the eyes of the remnant of this people; it will also be amazing in My eyes," and My people will never be ashamed, that the Holy One, blessed be He, will do so that their reward will not be in the category of "bread of shame," as mentioned. Similarly, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be explained that when the end of the redemption comes, the Holy One, blessed be He, will say to Israel, "My children, I am amazed at you, how you waited for Me all those years," even though it is revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, that were it not for His help and support, we could not have stood, existed, and strengthened ourselves in our faith due to the heaviness of the exile and the greatness of the trials. Nevertheless, the Baal Teshuvah will be amazed in order to increase our reward and that it should not be in the category of "bread of shame," as mentioned.
summary: The passage emphasizes that, from the perspective of the Divine, the perseverance of the Jewish people in their faith amidst suffering and exile is solely due to God's assistance. It highlights the future revelation where God will express wonder at the endurance of Israel, despite knowing that their strength came from Him. This divine astonishment serves to enhance their reward, ensuring it is not diminished to mere bread of shame. Ultimately, the text illustrates the profound relationship between divine support and human faith, underscoring the importance of recognizing God's role in spiritual victories.
