passage_content: והנה אין במציאות בעולם קדושה ועבודה גדולה בבחינתה, מתורתן של תינוקות של בית רבן שהבל פיהם און בו חטא, ולכן א"ל ר"ע שע"י תורתן של תשב"ר בניתי לך עיר, דהיינו עור האלקים ירושלים שלמעלה, ויתכן שר"ט כשא"ל לקנות לו עיר. ג"כ ע"ז הי' כוונתו מעיקרא, וחז"ל דברו בכ"מ ע"ד הרמז והמשל, ולדרכינו אינו משל רק כן הוא בפועל, שבזה בונים עיר ירושלים שלמעלה, ולזה צריך כל אחד להתאמץ בהחזקת התורה, ולהחזיק במוסדות החינוך שהם על טהרת הקודש ולהשתדל בקיומם ולסייע בידינו להעמיד דורות בנ"י, ובזה ה"ה עוסקים בבניינו של עולם ובונים ארץ ישראל וירושלים שלמעלה, וידע כאו"א שאף כמה שהרבה ליתן עדיין זכה למציאה גדולה, ואלמלי היו יודעין מה קונים בזה, ואל מה זוכין בעבורה היו נותנין הרבה יותר, דכל כמה שיתן עדיין הוא שווה יותר, ועשה מקח טוב מאוד, שעי"ז יש לו חלק בתורתן של תשב"ר ויש לו חלק בבניינו של עולם. והרבה בנ"א מויגעון בלקיחת בתים ונחלות להרוויח, וא"א לידע מראש אם לא יפסידו ח"ו, אבל כשלוקחים בניינים אלו ירוויחו בודאי, וה"ה קיום נצחי עדי עד, והבוכ"ע יעזור לכל אלו הנוטלים חלק בהחזקת התורה, במזונא רויחא והרחבת הדעת שיוכלו ליתן עוד, כמ"ש ז"ל ויתן ויחזור ויתן, והעיקר שיהי' לנו סייעתא דשמיא להעמיד דורות בנ"י ישרים ונאמנים לד' ולתוה"ק, ובזה יונח אמרם ז"ל שתלמידי חכמים נקראים בנאים ע"ש שעוסקין בבניינו של עולם, שע"י תורתם ועבודתם בונים ירושלים וא"י שלמעלה והוא יסוד העולם. נמצא שהם העוסקים בבניינו של עולם ע"ד האמת.
translation: And behold, there is no holiness and great service in the world in its essence, like the Torah of the children of the house of study, whose mouths utter vanity and in it is sin. Therefore, Rabbi Akiva said to him, "Through the Torah of the children of the house of study, I have built you a city," meaning the divine light of the Holy Jerusalem above. It is possible that Rabbi Tarfon, when he said to acquire a city for himself, also had this intention from the beginning. The sages spoke everywhere in terms of hints and parables, and according to our path, it is not a parable but rather it is so in practice, that through this we build the city of Jerusalem above. For this, everyone needs to strive to support the Torah and to uphold the educational institutions that are on the purity of holiness, and to make an effort to maintain them and assist us in establishing generations of the Jewish people. In this, they are engaged in the building of the world and building the land of Israel and the Jerusalem above. And let everyone know that even if they give a lot, they still merit a great acquisition, and if they knew what they were buying with this, and what they merit for it, they would give much more, for the more one gives, it is still worth more. They have made a very good deal, for through this they have a share in the Torah of the children of the house of study and they have a share in the building of the world. Many people toil in acquiring houses and inheritances to profit, and it is impossible to know in advance if they will not lose, Heaven forbid. But when they take these buildings, they will certainly profit, and this is an eternal existence forever. May the Blessed One help all those who take part in supporting the Torah, with good sustenance and an expansion of mind so that they can give more, as our sages said, "And he gives and returns to give." The main thing is that we should have divine assistance to establish generations of the Jewish people who are upright and faithful to God and to the Holy Torah. In this, their saying is established that the scholars are called builders because they are engaged in the building of the world, for through their Torah and service, they build Jerusalem and the land of Israel above, and this is the foundation of the world. Thus, they are the ones engaged in the building of the world in truth.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound significance of the Torah learned by children, which is seen as a foundational element in building the spiritual Jerusalem above. It highlights the importance of supporting Torah education and institutions dedicated to holiness, as this effort contributes to the construction of both the physical and spiritual realms of Israel. The text conveys that those who invest in Torah study and education are guaranteed eternal rewards, as their contributions are essential for the continuity and integrity of Jewish generations. Ultimately, it asserts that scholars are builders of the world, as their teachings and dedication create a lasting impact on the divine structure of existence.

passage_content: ויתבאר עוד עפ"י דרכינו הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי קיז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' קרח) מ"ש בשם ס' עיר בנימין על אמרם ז"ל ועשו לי מקדש לי לשמי. דלכאורה קשה הלא כל המצות צריכין להיות נעשים לשמה ולמה פרט הכתוב במקדש דוקא וכו' וביאר עפי"ד הגמ' (פסחים דף נ' ע"ב) רבא רמי כתיב מעל שמים חסדך וכתיב עד שחקים אמיתך, ומשני כאן שעושין לשמה וכאן בעושין שלא לשמה וכו', ופי' המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א שכל העושה מצוה שלא לשמה אינו זוכה רק לרקיע שחקים וכו', אבל העושה לשמה זוכה למעלה משחקים עכ"ד. ולכך במקדש ומשכן דאמרו רז"ל מקדש שלמטה מכוון כנגד מקדש שלמעלה. ומקדש שלמעלה הוא בזבול וכו', הזהירה התורה כאן בפרטיות שיעשו לשמה, כדי שיגיע הזכות עד זבול שהוא למעלה משחקים עכת"ד, והנה עפ"י אמרינו לעיל דת"ח המייגעים בתורה, וכמו"כ המחזיקים לומדי תורה בונים ירושלים וביהמ"ק שלמעלה, והרי בבנין ביהמ"ק צריך להיות לשמה דייקא, ולפי"ז הרי תנאי קשה בדבר, דהלומד והמחזיק צ"ל מעשיהם לשמה דייקא, ורק אז בונין במעשיהם ביהמ"ק שלמעלה, ובחי' זו קשה להשיג עד מאוד, ואף אם המחזיק יתכוין בתמיכתו לשמה, אכתי איכא למיחש שמא לא יכווין הת"ח בלימודו לשמה, נמצא כו לא זכה בהחזקת תורה לשמה.
translation: And it will be further explained according to our aforementioned approach, by prefacing the words of the Kitzur Yismach Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parshat Korach), regarding what is stated in the name of the Sefer Ir Binyamin on the saying of our Sages, may their memory be blessed, "And they shall make for Me a sanctuary, and I shall dwell among them." At first glance, it is difficult, for all the commandments need to be performed for their own sake, so why does the verse specify the sanctuary specifically, etc. And he explained according to the Gemara (Pesachim 50b) that Rava posed a contradiction: it is written, "Your kindness is above the heavens," and it is written, "Your truth reaches to the clouds." And he answered, "Here, they are doing it for its own sake, and here, they are doing it not for its own sake," etc. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, explained in the first part that anyone who performs a commandment not for its own sake only merits the lower heavens, etc., but one who does it for its own sake merits above the heavens. Therefore, in the sanctuary and the Mishkan, as our Sages, may their memory be blessed, said, the sanctuary below is aligned with the sanctuary above. And the sanctuary above is in the Z'vul, etc. The Torah warns here specifically that they should do it for its own sake, so that the merit should reach Z'vul, which is above the heavens. Thus, according to what we said above, that Torah scholars who toil in Torah, and likewise those who support Torah learners, build Jerusalem and the Holy Temple above, and indeed, in the building of the Holy Temple, it must be specifically for its own sake. According to this, there is a difficult condition in the matter, that the learner and the supporter must have their actions specifically for its own sake, and only then do they build the Holy Temple above with their actions. And this aspect is very difficult to achieve, and even if the supporter intends in his support for its own sake, there is still concern that perhaps the Torah scholar does not intend in his learning for its own sake, thus it turns out that he did not merit the support of Torah for its own sake.
summary: The passage discusses the unique requirement for the construction of the Temple to be done "lishma" (for its own sake), contrasting it with other commandments that can be performed without this intention. It references the Talmudic teaching that actions done for the sake of Heaven reach higher spiritual realms, specifically the heavenly Temple. The text emphasizes that both scholars and their supporters must ensure their intentions align with this ideal, as only then can their efforts contribute to the building of the heavenly Temple. This highlights the profound connection between intention, action, and spiritual elevation in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: וראיתי להרחוד"א זלה"ה בספרו ראש דוד (פ' קדושים ובפ' ברכה) שהביא בענין זה פלוגתת הקדמונים. דיש מהראשונים דס"ל שהמחזיק לת"ח, אף אם הת"ח לומד שלא לשמה, אבל המחזיק הרי כוונתו ורצונו ליתן על תורה לשמה, לכן יש לו שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, ומהר"ש פרימו חולק על דבריהם, לפי שהוקשה לו מדברי הגמ', שקלל ירמי' הנביא לאנשי ענתות ואמר רבש"ע אפי' בשעה שהם נותנים צדקה הכשילם בבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים שלא יקבלו עליהם שכר, ואי אמרת דאף שאינו המקבל הגון מ"מ הנותן מקבל שכר על כוונתו הטוב כאילו נתן למהוגנים. א"כ מה הועיל ירמי' הנביא בקללתו, אע"כ דהא בהא תליא, ואם המקבלים אינם מהוגנים גם הנותן לא עלה בידו כלום יעיי"ש בדברי החיד"א שמכריע לכאן ולכאן. ובספה"ק צמח דוד להרה"ק מוה"ר דוד מדינוב זי"ע כתב שיש לצדד עוד סברא להקל דגם הת"ח עצמו אף אם עוסק שלא לשמה, זוכה ע"י המחזיק לשכר תורה לשמה, דהרי המחזיק יש לו שכר תורה לשמה לשיטת הראשונים ז"ל, והרי הת"ח הוא המביאו לזה ע"ו גרמא דילי', לכן זוכה גם הוא בשכר תורה לשמה ע"י המחזיקו עכדה"ק.
translation: And I saw that the holy Rabbi Yoel, may his memory be blessed, in his book "Rosh David" (in Parshas Kedoshim and in Parshas Berachah), brought regarding this a dispute among the early authorities. There are some of the early authorities who hold that one who supports a Torah scholar, even if the scholar is learning not for its own sake, since the supporter’s intention and desire is to give for the sake of Torah learning, therefore he has a reward as if he supported Torah learning for its own sake. However, Rabbi Shmuel Primo disagrees with their words, as he was troubled by the words of the Gemara, which included the prophet Jeremiah’s curse upon the people of Anathoth, where he said, "Master of the Universe, even at the time they are giving charity, You caused them to stumble with unworthy people so that they would not receive reward." And if you say that even though the recipient is unworthy, nonetheless the giver receives reward for his good intention as if he gave to worthy individuals, then what benefit did the prophet Jeremiah achieve with his curse? Rather, it must be that one is dependent on the other, and if the recipients are unworthy, then the giver has not accomplished anything. See there in the words of the Chida, who rules both ways. And in the holy book "Tzemach David" by the holy Rabbi David of Dinov, may his memory be blessed, it is written that there is another reason to be lenient, that even the Torah scholar himself, even if he is engaged in learning not for its own sake, merits through the supporter a reward for learning for its own sake, for the supporter has a reward for learning for its own sake according to the opinion of the early authorities, and the Torah scholar is the one who brings him to this, thus he also merits the reward for learning for its own sake through the one who supports him.
summary: The passage discusses a debate among early authorities regarding the merit of supporting a Torah scholar who studies for ulterior motives. Some argue that the supporter receives reward as if the scholar were learning for the right reasons, while others contend that if the scholar's intentions are flawed, the supporter gains nothing. The text also introduces a perspective that even if the scholar learns without pure intent, the supporter's good intentions can still lead to a shared reward, as the scholar's learning is indirectly facilitated by the supporter. This highlights the interconnectedness of intentions and actions in the realm of spiritual merit within Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ואפשר ליישב שיטת הראשונים ז"ל דלא יקשה עליהם קושית המהר"ש פרימו ז"ל, דהנה יש תרי גווני שלא לשמה כמ"ש התוס' (פסחים נ' ע"ב), והרי ארז"ל לעולם יעסוק בתומ"צ אפי' שלא לשמה שמתוך של"ש בא לשמה, א"כ אף בזה מצוה קא עביד, ואף שכתבו המפרשים דתועלת הלימוד שלא לשמה, הוא רק בשביל שמתו"כ יגיע ללימוד לשמה, ואם לא יביאהו לידי לשמה לא הועיל במעשיו כלום, אבל מ"מ הרי אמרו רז"ל לעולם יעסוק בתומ"צ אפי' שלא לשמה א"כ מצוה קא עביד, ובפשטות אפ"ל דהלומד תורה אף אם אין כוונתו זכה לשמה, ומכווין גם כוונה פני' אחרת, מ"מ באמצע לימודו מגיע לו לפעמים מחשבה טובה וקדושה, ואף שאינו נשאר ומתקיים בזה המדריגה ונופל ממנה. אבל סו"ס יביאהו זה המחשבה קדושה לבחי' לשמה, ואפשר לרמוז זה באמרם ז"ל מתוך שלא לשמה בא לשמה, היינו בתוך ובאמצע לימודו יהי' לו מחשבה טובה, וזה יביאהו אח"כ לידי לשמה, עכ"פ אית בחי' תורה שלא לשמה שמותר ומצוה איכא בגווי', אולם יש גם בחי' שלא לשמה שארז"ל נוח לו שלא נברא ומוטב שנהפכה שלייתו על פניו ולימודו נחשב לו לעון ר"ל, והתוס' שם כתבו דהוא בלומד כדי לקנטר ולקפח את חביריו בהלכה עיי"ש, ובכה"ג עבירה הוא בידו.
translation:
And it is possible to reconcile the opinion of the early authorities, may their memory be blessed, that the question of the Maharsh Primo, may his memory be blessed, should not be difficult for them. Behold, there are two types of learning not for its own sake, as the Tosafot write (Pesachim 50b), and our sages have said that one should always engage in Torah and mitzvot even if not for their own sake, for from not for its own sake one comes to for its own sake. Therefore, even in this case, he is performing a mitzvah. And although the commentators have written that the benefit of learning not for its own sake is only because through it he will come to learn for its own sake, and if it does not bring him to for its own sake, his actions have not helped him at all, nevertheless, our sages have said that one should always engage in Torah and mitzvot even if not for their own sake, thus he is performing a mitzvah. 

And simply put, one can say that the one who learns Torah, even if his intention is not for its own sake, and he is also directing his intention towards another purpose, nevertheless, in the midst of his learning, he sometimes receives a good and holy thought. And even though he does not remain and sustain this level and falls from it, ultimately this holy thought will bring him to the level of for its own sake. And it is possible to allude to this in their saying, may their memory be blessed, that from not for its own sake he comes to for its own sake, meaning that in the midst of his learning, he will have a good thought, and this will later bring him to for its own sake. At least there is a level of Torah not for its own sake that is permitted and there is a mitzvah in it. However, there is also a level of not for its own sake that our sages have said it would have been better for him not to have been created, and it is better that his excrement be turned over his face, and his learning is considered a sin for him, may God save us. And the Tosafot there wrote that this refers to one who learns in order to provoke and to undermine his friends in halacha, as mentioned there, and in such a case, it is a transgression in his hands.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of learning Torah "shelo lishma" (not for its own sake) and its potential to lead to "lishma" (for its own sake). It emphasizes that even when one's intentions are not pure, engaging in Torah study can still yield positive spiritual thoughts that may eventually elevate one's intentions. However, it also warns that there are forms of learning that are considered sinful, particularly when done with the intent to harm others or undermine them. Ultimately, the text highlights the transformative power of Torah study, even when initiated from less than ideal motivations.

passage_content: והנה ארז"ל (נזיר כ"ג ע"א) אשה הפרם וד' יסלח לה וכו' רע"ק כי מטא להאי קרא בכי, ומה מי שנתכוון לעלות בידו בשר חזיר ועלה בידו בשר טלה טעון כפרה וסליחה וכו' עוד אמרו שם ומה מי שנתכווין לעלות בידו בשר טלה ועלה בידו בשר חזיר וכו' אמר קרא ונשא עונו וכו' ולפי"ז המחזיק בלומדי תורה ע"מ לקנטר, אף אם לא ידע מהותם ואיכותם, והי' כל כוונתו להחזיק בלימוד תורה לשמה, מ"מ בכגון דא א"א לומר דמגיע להמחזיק שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, אדרבה הרי צריך כפרה דהרי לימודו של זה עבירה הוא, וה"ה כנתכוון לאכול בשר טלה ועלתה בידו של חזיר שצריך כפרה, אבל בבחי' שלא לשמה ע"מ לקבל שכר או פני' אחרת, הרי הלומד אינו עושה עבירה כ"א מצוה. בודאי יקבל המחזיק שכרו כהחזקת תורה לשמה כשיטת הראשונים הנ"ל
translation: And behold, our sages said (Nazir 23a) that a woman who has separated her vows, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will forgive her, etc. Rabbi Akiva, when he reached this verse, wept, and what about someone who intended to take in his hand meat of a pig and instead took in his hand meat of a lamb, he requires atonement and forgiveness, etc. They also said there, and what about someone who intended to take in his hand meat of a lamb and instead took in his hand meat of a pig, etc. The verse states, "and he shall bear his iniquity," etc. According to this, one who supports Torah scholars in order to provoke, even if he does not know their essence and quality, and his entire intention is to support the study of Torah for its own sake, nevertheless, in such a case, one cannot say that he deserves the reward of supporting Torah for its own sake; on the contrary, he requires atonement, for his study is a transgression. The same applies if he intended to eat meat of a lamb and instead took in his hand meat of a pig, for he requires atonement. However, in a case where he studies not for its own sake in order to receive reward or for another purpose, the learner does not commit a transgression but rather performs a mitzvah. Certainly, the supporter will receive his reward as if he supported Torah for its own sake, according to the opinion of the earlier authorities mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intention in the study of Torah, emphasizing that even if one engages in learning with the aim of disparaging others, it is considered a transgression that requires atonement. It contrasts this with learning done for ulterior motives, which, while not ideal, is still viewed as a mitzvah rather than a sin. The text highlights the importance of one's intentions in spiritual pursuits and the implications for receiving reward or needing forgiveness. Ultimately, it underscores the complexity of motivations in religious practice and their impact on one's spiritual standing.

passage_content: ומעתה לא קשה קושית המהר"ש פרימו ז"ל ממה שקלל ירמי' לאנשי ענתות שיכשלו בבני אדם שאינם מהוגנים, דהתם מיירי בכאלו שאינם מתנהגים על פי התורה כלל, ובכגון דא ודאי לא יקבל שכר המחזיק בידם לתמכם, ולא קשה מידי, וסברת הראשונים אמת וקיים אצל וסתם בעלי תורה, אף אם לומדין בבחי' שלא לשמה ובמחשבה לשם פני', מ"מ המחזיקים בידם מקבלין שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, ובגמ' מיירי בבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים ומתנהגים בתהלוכות מעשיהם היפך התורה, וע"כ התומכום בידן אינם מקבלים עליהם שכר, ומעתה סברת הראשונים קיימת לדברי הכל.
translation: And from now on, the question of the Maharshal Primo, may his memory be blessed, is not difficult regarding what he included in Jeremiah for the people of Anathoth, that they would stumble with individuals who are not proper. For there, it speaks of those who do not conduct themselves according to the Torah at all, and in such a case, certainly, one who supports them to assist them will not receive reward. It is not too difficult, and the reasoning of the earlier authorities is true and valid among the generality of Torah scholars, even if they study in a manner that is not for its own sake and with the intention for the sake of Heaven. Nevertheless, those who support them receive reward as for the support of Torah for its own sake. And in the Gemara, it speaks of individuals who are not proper and conduct themselves in ways that are contrary to the Torah. Therefore, those who support them do not receive reward for it. And from now on, the reasoning of the earlier authorities stands firm according to everyone's words.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between supporting individuals who do not adhere to Torah principles and those who, despite their shortcomings, engage in Torah study. It emphasizes that while supporting the former does not yield reward, supporting the latter, even if their intentions are not entirely pure, is still considered a merit. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the value of Torah study and the importance of intention, suggesting that the act of supporting Torah scholars carries inherent spiritual significance. Ultimately, it affirms the validity of earlier interpretations regarding the nature of reward in relation to one's actions and intentions.

passage_content: ופירשתי בדרך בדיחותא מאמרם ז"ל עבר ושנה הותרה לו וכו' נעשית לו כהיתר, דלכאורה וכי משום שעבר עבירה שנו פעמים איך נעשית לו כהיתר, וגם מהו הלשון עבר הושנה" עבר ומכפלוז היל"ל, ואפ"ל דמלת אושנה" הכוונה בו מלשון לימוד, כמו שנו חכמים בלשון המשנה. והפי' דאם עובר עבירה במזיד והוא גם למדן ולומד ע"מ לקנער, אז מברר לו היתר להצדיק מעשהו עפ"י הלכה, ועי"ז הותרה לו ונעשית לו כהיתר, וע"ז הלימוד אמרז"ל נוח לו שלא נברא ולימודו עבירה ועון פלילי.
translation: And I explained in a humorous manner their saying, may their memory be blessed, "If one transgressed and repeated, it is permitted to him, etc." It becomes to him as a permit. For at first glance, how can it be that because he transgressed a sin twice, it becomes to him as a permit? And what is the meaning of the phrase "transgressed and repeated"? It should have said "transgressed and doubled." And it can be said that the term "repeated" refers to the language of learning, as the sages taught in the language of the Mishnah. The explanation is that if one transgresses a sin intentionally and he is also a scholar learning in order to justify, then he clarifies for himself a permit to justify his actions according to halacha, and thereby it is permitted to him and becomes to him as a permit. And concerning this teaching, our sages said, "It would have been better for him not to have been created, and his learning is a sin and a criminal offense."
summary: The passage discusses the concept that if a person intentionally commits a sin while being knowledgeable in Torah, they may rationalize their actions as permissible, thus making the sin feel like a legitimate option. The phrase "עבר ושנה" is interpreted as a reference to learning, suggesting that a learned individual who sins may distort their understanding of halacha to justify their behavior. This leads to the idea that it would have been better for such a person not to have been created than to misuse their learning for sinful purposes. Ultimately, the text highlights the danger of intellectualizing sin and the moral responsibility that comes with knowledge.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד לתרץ קושית המהר"ש פרימו זלה"ה, דמקללת ירמי' הנביא הכשילם בעניים שאינם מהוגנים לק"מ, דהנה אין ספק שאנשי ענתות היו רשעים ושנואי ד', דאם הי' השי"ת אוהבם לא הי' ירמי' הנביא מקללם, והנה ידוע דמטבע הרשעים לשנוא ליראי ה' וכמ"ש הרבינו יונה זלל"ה בפי' למשלי, לפרש הכתוב מצרף לכסף וכור לזהב ואיש לפי מהללו, דכל דבר יש לו מבחן, והמצרף מובחן לכסף והכור לזהב, והמבחן של אדם הוא לפי מהללו, לראות את מי מהלל, דאם מהלל לצדיקים הוא צדיק וההיפוך בהיפוך, וכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' בלק) דבר זה שימה בטבע שהרשעים ישנאו את הצדיקים גם בלי סיבה יעיי"ש, ולכאורה לפי"ז היו אנשי ענתות שונאים לעניים מהוגנים, ומעצמם ימנעו מליתן להם, ולמה הוצרך ירמי' הנביא לקללם בזה אמנם ירמי' הנביא ראה והשיג שאפשר במציאות דבר כזה, שאף שהם רשעים מ"מ ירצו לתמוך בעניים מהוגנים כדי להמשיך אותם לדעתם הרשעה, וע"ד שפירשתי (בפ' שמות) מ"ד במדרש מתחילה בפה רך שפרעה גזר על עבודה ומתחלה שילם להם שכרם, ושבט לוי לא רצו לקבל שאמרו עתידים אנו לעבוד להשי"ת ולא נעבוד אדם רשע ועי"כ ניצולו מהן, ולכאורה הרי לבסוף עבדו ישראל בכפי' עפ"י גזירת המלכות ואיך ניצולו בני לוי, ואפשר שע"י שהעם קיבלו מתחלה ממון הרשעים עי"ז נמשכו אחרי טומאתם דלא סגי בלא"ה, ובעון זה שלטו בגופן אח"כ, וע"ד מ"ש רש"י ז"ל פ' בהר בשם ת"כ עה"פ לא תעשו לכם אלילים, כנגד זה הנמכר לנכרי, שלא יאמר הואיל ורבי מגלה עריות אף אני כמותו הואיל ורבי עובד ע"ז אף אני כמותו וכו'. ולכאורה מי פתו יאמר כן, ה"ה גוי ואתה ישראל ואיך תחשוב להתדמות אליו, אמנם מפני שירצה לישא חן בעיניו עי"ז מתחיל להתדמות אליו בדבר קטן וקל, והיום אומר לו עשה כך ולמחר אומר לו עשה כך וכו' ויבוא להתדמות אליו לעבוד ע"ז ולגלות עריות כמותו, ועד"ז פרעה רצה להמשיך ולשעבד את ישראל תחת רשותו, וכמ"ש בשלה"ק וירעו אותנו המצרים שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים, לכן שילם להם בתחלה ממון רב. ועי"כ נפלו ממדריגתם והי"ל שליטה עליהן, משא"כ שבט לוי לא רצו לקבל ואף בעד כל כסף וזהב שבעולם לא רצו לעבוד לאדם רשע וע"כ לא הי"ל שליטה עליהן כלל וניצולו מידו
translation:
And I can also explain the question of the Maharsh Primo, may his memory be blessed, regarding the curse of the prophet Jeremiah upon the people of Anathoth, who led the poor astray with their unworthy actions. There is no doubt that the people of Anathoth were wicked and hated by God; for if the Holy One, blessed be He, loved them, the prophet Jeremiah would not have cursed them. It is well known that it is the nature of the wicked to hate those who fear the Lord, as our teacher Jonah, may his memory be blessed, explains in his commentary on Proverbs, interpreting the verse "As silver is refined and gold is tested, so a man is tested by his praise." Every matter has its test, and the refiner is for silver and the tester is for gold, and a person's test is according to whom he praises. If he praises the righteous, he is righteous, and the opposite is true as well. Rabbi Simcha Moshe, may his memory be blessed, wrote this in Parshat Balak, that it is natural for the wicked to hate the righteous even without cause, as you can see there. 

Seemingly, according to this, the people of Anathoth would hate the worthy poor and would refrain from giving to them on their own. So why did the prophet Jeremiah need to curse them for this? However, the prophet Jeremiah saw and understood that it is possible in reality for such a thing to occur, that even though they are wicked, they might still want to support the worthy poor in order to draw them into their wickedness. This is similar to what I explained in Parshat Shemot regarding the Midrash that initially Pharaoh decreed labor and at first paid them their wages, and the tribe of Levi did not want to accept it, as they said, "We are destined to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, and we will not serve a wicked man," and thus they were saved from them. 

Seemingly, in the end, the Israelites worked according to the decree of the kingdom, and how were the sons of Levi saved? It is possible that by the people initially receiving money from the wicked, they were drawn after their impurity, which was not sufficient without it, and because of this sin, they later had control over them. This is in line with what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in Parshat Behar in the name of the Tanchuma on the verse "You shall not make for yourselves idols," against one who sells himself to a foreigner, so that he should not say, "Since my teacher reveals forbidden relations, I too will be like him; since my teacher serves idols, I too will be like him," etc. 

Seemingly, who would say such a thing? He is a gentile, and you are Israel; how could you think to resemble him? However, because he wishes to find favor in his eyes, he begins to resemble him in small and trivial matters. Today he tells him to do this, and tomorrow he tells him to do that, and he will come to resemble him in serving idols and revealing forbidden relations like him. Similarly, Pharaoh wanted to continue and enslave Israel under his authority, as it is written in the holy books, "And the Egyptians made us evil and sinful," therefore he initially paid them a great sum of money. Because of this, they fell from their level, and he had control over them. In contrast, the tribe of Levi did not want to accept, and even for all the money and gold in the world, they did not want to serve a wicked man, and therefore he had no control over them at all, and they were saved from his hand.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of wickedness and its relationship with the righteous, emphasizing that the wicked often despise the righteous without cause. It illustrates how the people of Anathoth, despite their evil, might have been tempted to support the poor to draw them into their corrupt ways. The text highlights the importance of maintaining one's integrity and not succumbing to the allure of the wicked, as exemplified by the Levites who refused to accept rewards from Pharaoh, thereby preserving their spiritual standing and avoiding subjugation. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that one's associations and the influences they accept can lead to moral degradation.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר לענינינו דלפי שהיו אנשי ענתות רשעים ושנואי ד"נ היו משתוקקים להמשיך רבים לרשעתם, כמשה"כ לא ישנו אם לא ירעו ונגזלה שנתם אם לא יכשילו. והשתדלו להמשיך אליהם אנשים מהוגנים שיתפתו לדעתם ולא ילחמו נגדן ועוד יתנו להם כת וחיזוק, לכן פרשו רשתם לתמוך לעניים מהוגנים, וע"י שיתנו להן ממון יתפסו לדעתם ועי"ז יקבלו כח וחיזוק, לכן קיללם ירמי' הנביא שיכשלו בבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים והמהוגנים ינצלו מידם, ואף אם ישתדלו לרדוף ולהשיג מהוגנים, יכשלו ויטעו ויזדמן להם בנ"א שאינם מהוגנים, אלא שלמראית העין מתדמין כמהוגנים ובאמת המה צבועים ורשעים.
translation: And similarly, it will be explained regarding our matter that since the people of Anathoth were wicked and hated by the Divine Name, they were eager to draw many into their wickedness, as it is written, "They will not change unless they are harmed, and their sleep will be stolen unless they cause others to stumble." They made efforts to attract respectable people to be swayed by their opinions and not to fight against them, and furthermore, to give them a faction and support. Therefore, they spread their net to support respectable poor people, and by giving them money, they would capture their opinions and thereby gain strength and support. Thus, the prophet Jeremiah cursed them that they would stumble upon people who are not respectable, while the respectable ones would be saved from them. And even if they strive to pursue and attain respectable individuals, they will fail and be misled, and they will encounter people who are not respectable, who, at first glance, appear to be respectable, but in truth, they are hypocrites and wicked.
summary: The passage discusses the dangers posed by the wicked people of Anathoth, who sought to lead others into their corruption. It emphasizes the idea that these individuals would attempt to ensnare the righteous by offering support and financial aid, thereby corrupting their values. The prophet Jeremiah curses them, indicating that despite their efforts to deceive and manipulate, the truly righteous will ultimately be protected from their influence, while the wicked will fail in their pursuits. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine protection for the righteous amidst the trials posed by the morally corrupt.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה שרק רע הי' כל כוונתם, ומי שכוונתו לכזה, בוודאי אין מקבל שכר כהחזקת תורה לשמה, דדי שיקבל שכר אם יזדמן לפניו עניים מהוגנים שעכ"פ עשה מצוה, ואף שהי' כוונתו לרוע אעפ"כ יש לו קצת שכר, וממילא לא יקשה מהתם על שיטת הראשונים ז"ל, וסברתם קיימת דאף המחזיק ביד הלומד שלא לשמה מקבל שכר כעל תורה לשמה, ואין שום קושיא ממאמר רז"ל הנ"ל שקיללם ירמי' הנביא הכשילם בבני אדם שאינם מהוגנים, וג"ז תירוץ מספיק, ובפרט לפי מה שהעליתי לעיל דיש ב' בחינות בתורה שלא לשמה בפשטות לק"מ, דמ"ש הכשילם באינם מהוגנים כוונתו על סוג הגרוע בתורה שלא לשמה וכ"ז אמת ויציב.
translation: What emerges from this is that their entire intention was only for evil, and one whose intention is such certainly does not receive reward like that of one who upholds the Torah for its own sake. It is sufficient for him to receive reward if he encounters respectable poor people, for at least he performed a mitzvah, and even though his intention was for bad, he still has some reward. Therefore, it will not be difficult to reconcile this with the opinion of the earlier authorities, and their reasoning stands that even one who supports the learner not for its own sake receives reward as if it were for the sake of the Torah. There is no difficulty from the aforementioned statement of our sages, which Jeremiah the prophet cursed, that he caused them to stumble with people who are not respectable. This is also a sufficient answer, especially according to what I have raised above that there are two aspects to studying Torah not for its own sake, in simple terms, there is no difficulty. When he says he caused them to stumble with those who are not respectable, his intention is regarding the inferior type of studying Torah not for its own sake, and all this is true and established.
summary: המעבר מדבריו מצביע על כך שכאשר הכוונה היא רעה, אין האדם מקבל שכר כמו על לימוד תורה לשמה, אך אם הוא עשה מצווה, יש לו שכר מסוים. יש הבחנה בין סוגי לימוד תורה שלא לשמה, כאשר הכוונה הרעה מתייחסת לסוג הגרוע יותר. המאמר מתמודד עם קושיות על שיטות ראשונים ומסביר שהשכר על לימוד תורה שלא לשמה יכול להתקבל גם אם הכוונה לא הייתה טהורה, כל עוד ישנה עשייה חיובית.

passage_content: נחזור לענינינו דהנה פלוגתת הראשונים במחזיקין ידו ת"ח, שא"א לנו לידע תעלומות לבו עד כמה הוא מכווין לשמה, אבל בתשב"ר אמרו רז"ל שהבל פיהם אין בו חטא, וזהו בוודאי לשמה, ואביי אמר לרבא כגון דידי ודידך מאי, א"ל אינו דומה הבל שיש בו חטא להבל שאין בו חעא, הרי שתורתם גבוה מעל גבוה, ואצלם אין נפק"מ הכוונה בין לשמה ושלא לשמה, שעדיין אינם מצווים ע"ז, והתורה שלהם קיום כל היהדות והוא גבוה יותר מכ"ד, ואם בזה נועלין חלק אזי בוודאי יש להמחזיק חלק בתורה לשמה ונוסף לזה הרי נוטלין גם חלק בהחזקת המלמדים וראשי ישיבות ת"ח לומדי תורה וכבר ביררנו לעיל שגם בזה יש להמחזיקים חלק בתורה לשמה עכ"פ.
translation: Let us return to our matter, for behold, there is a dispute among the early authorities regarding the one who holds his hand, a Torah scholar, that we cannot know the depths of his heart to what extent he is intent on serving for its own sake. However, in the teachings of our Sages, they said that the breath of their mouth contains no sin, and this is certainly for its own sake. And Abaye said to Rava, "What about someone like me and you?" He replied, "The breath that contains sin is not comparable to the breath that contains no sin." Thus, their Torah is high above high, and for them, there is no difference in intention between for its own sake and not for its own sake, as they are not yet commanded regarding this. Their Torah is the fulfillment of all Judaism, and it is higher than the twenty-four. If in this they close off a portion, then certainly the one who holds a portion in the Torah for its own sake has a share, and in addition, they also take a share in the support of the teachers and heads of yeshivas, the Torah scholars who study Torah. And we have already clarified above that even in this, those who support have a share in the Torah for its own sake, at least.
summary: The passage discusses the debate among early authorities regarding the intentions behind studying Torah, emphasizing that while human understanding of one's inner motivations is limited, the concept of "hevel peh" (the breath of the mouth) is considered pure and without sin. It highlights that the Torah's essence transcends the distinction between studying for its own sake or not, as true Torah study embodies the entirety of Jewish existence. Furthermore, it asserts that those who support Torah scholars and institutions also partake in the merit of studying for its own sake, reinforcing the communal aspect of Torah learning and its elevated status.

passage_content: ובזה נשיג לדעת מה שהקדים הכתוב זבולן לפני יששכר, כי הנה יששכר ירמוז לת"ח העוסק בתורה, והוא אינו יכול להגיע מיד לבחי' תורה לשמה, שעל כן התירו חז"ל להתחיל בלימוד שלא לשמה, דא"א שיתחיל תיכף לשמה, משא"כ זבולן דאף כ"ז שהת"ח לומד עדיין שלא לשמה, כבר יש לו השכר של תורה לשמה, א"כ ה"ה מגיע לשכרו מוקדם ליששכר. לכן הקדימו הכ' שמח זבולן בצאתך, שתיכף ביציאתך להחזיק ידי ת"ח כבר יש לך חלקך, ויששכר באוהלך רק לאח"כ כנ"ל, וגם בפשטות יוכל המחזיק להשיג בחי' לשמה יותר מהעוסק בתורה, דהנה ארז"ל כל הגדול מחבירו יצרו גדול ממנו, ואמרז"ל שמניח היצה"ר כל העולם ומתגרה בת"ח יותר מכולן, א"כ העוסק בתורה מתגבר עליו היצר הרע ביותר. לכן קשה לו להגיע לבחי' לשמה. משא"כ המחזיק אינו מתגבר עליו היצה"ר כ"כ, לכן בניקל לו יותר להגיע לידי לשמה, והבן.
translation: In this, we will understand why the scripture precedes Zebulun before Issachar, for behold, Issachar alludes to the Torah scholar who engages in Torah study, and he cannot immediately reach the level of Torah lishma (for its own sake). Therefore, the Sages permitted beginning with study that is not lishma, for it is impossible to start immediately with lishma. In contrast, Zebulun, even while the Torah scholar is still learning not lishma, already has the reward of Torah lishma. Thus, he receives his reward earlier than Issachar. Therefore, the verse states, "Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out," for immediately upon your going out to support the hands of the Torah scholar, you already have your share, while Issachar is in your tents only afterwards, as mentioned. Furthermore, simply put, the supporter can attain the level of lishma more easily than the one engaged in Torah study, for our Sages said, "Anyone greater than his friend, his evil inclination is greater than him," and they also said that the evil inclination leaves the entire world and provokes the Torah scholar more than anyone else. Therefore, the one engaged in Torah struggles against the evil inclination the most. In contrast, the supporter does not struggle against the evil inclination as much, thus it is easier for him to reach the level of lishma. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the precedence of Zebulun over Issachar, highlighting that Issachar represents the Torah scholar who initially studies for ulterior motives, while Zebulun, by supporting the scholar, receives the reward of studying for its own sake even while the scholar is still learning for personal gain. This suggests that those who support Torah study can attain a higher spiritual level more readily than the scholars themselves, as the latter face greater challenges from their evil inclination. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the value of supporting Torah scholars and the unique spiritual rewards associated with such support.

passage_content: והנה בבנין ביהמ"ק הרי צ"ל לשמה כנ"ל בישמח משהו ולומדי תורה לשמה הרי זעירין אינון דאדם עלול לפניות, ואפילו באלו ההולכים בדרך הישר ורוצים לעשות רצון הבוב"ה, אעפי"כ גדולים הנסיונות וישנם הרבה פניות וקשה להשיג בחי' לשמה. לכן שכיח מאוד שהת"ח לא יזכה בתורתו רק לשכר העוה"ז, כמ"ש ז"ל בשמאלה עושר וכבוד דהיינו בלומדון שלא לשמה, ולכן אמרז"ל שקיבל בשכרו ביזת מצרים וביזת הים, משא"כ בזבולן המחזיק, מגיע תיכף במעשיו לבחי' תורה לשמה, ע"כ זוכה בזכותו לבנין ביהמ"ק, ששרשו למעלה בזבול, וצריך להיות לשמה דייקא כמבואר לעיל בדברי ק"ז זלה"ה, לכן העמידו חז"ל הרמז על זבולן בכתוב בנה בניתי בית זבול לך מכון לשבתך עולמים, שבזכותו יהי' בנין ביהמ"ק ששרשו למעלה בזבול וזבולן המחזיק התוה"ק יוכל להמשיך זאת בכח מצותו שמגיע מעל לשמים.
translation: And behold, in the building of the Holy Temple, it must be for its own sake, as mentioned above regarding joy in something and those who study Torah for its own sake, they are few among those who are prone to distractions. Even among those who walk in the straight path and wish to do the will of the Blessed One, nevertheless, the trials are great, and there are many distractions, making it difficult to achieve the level of studying for its own sake. Therefore, it is very common that the Torah scholar will not merit his Torah except for the reward of this world, as our sages have said, "On the left, wealth and honor," meaning in studying not for its own sake. Therefore, our sages said that he received in return the spoils of Egypt and the spoils of the sea, whereas Zebulun, who supports, immediately reaches in his actions the level of Torah for its own sake. Thus, he merits through his merit the building of the Holy Temple, whose root is above in Zebul, and it must be specifically for its own sake, as explained above in the words of K.Z. Z"L. Therefore, our sages established the hint regarding Zebulun in the verse, "I have built a house of dwelling for You, a place for Your eternal abode," that through his merit there will be the building of the Holy Temple, whose root is above in Zebul, and Zebulun, who supports the Holy Torah, will be able to continue this through the power of his commandment that reaches above the heavens.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of learning Torah "lishma" (for its own sake) in the context of building the Holy Temple. It emphasizes that even those who strive to do God's will face significant challenges and temptations, often resulting in learning for personal gain rather than spiritual elevation. The text highlights the merit of the tribe of Zebulun, who support Torah scholars, as they are able to achieve a higher spiritual connection and contribute to the construction of the Temple through their righteous actions. Ultimately, it underscores the necessity of pure intentions in spiritual pursuits to attain true divine connection and fulfillment.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בענין הנ"ל מ"ט הקדימו לזבולן, והרי התורה צ"ל מוקדם לכל, ויתבאר בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ בפ' בכורים, ושמחת בכל הטוב אשר נתן לך ד' אלקיך וגו', ודרשו חז"ל (בכורים פ"ג) מכאן אמרו אין קורין מקרא בכורים אלא בזמן שמחה מעצרת ועד החג שאדם מלקט תבואתו ופירותיו ויינו ושמנו. אבל מהחג ואילך מביא ואינו קורא, וראוי להבין הכי אין שמחה זולתו לישראל שומר תומ"צ כ"א מה שמלקט תבואתו ופירותיו ויינו, גם יזדמן ח"ו שלא הצליחו תבואתו ועשאה שדהו פחות מכפי ששמוהו לעשות וה"ה עצב, ואיך אמרז"ל כללא שבזמן אסיפת התבואות הוא זמן שמחה ורק אז מביא וקורא ולא בזמן זולתו וטעמא מאי, וכעי"ז יש להעיר מה שקראתו תוה"ק לחג הסוכות חג האסיף, ע"ש הכתוב באספכם את תבואת הארץ תחוגו חג לד', הרי תלה הכתוב ענין החג הקדוש בזמן אסיפת התבואות וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: Further, one can say regarding the aforementioned matter, why Zebulun was given precedence, for the Torah must be prior to all. It will be explained in advance to interpret from the verse in Parashat Bikkurim, "And you shall rejoice in all the good which the Lord your God has given you," and our Sages have derived (Bikkurim 3) from here that one does not read the Bikkurim until the time of joy, from Shavuot until the festival, when a person gathers his produce, fruits, wine, and oil. However, from the festival onward, he brings but does not read. It is appropriate to understand that there is no joy for Israel, who observes the Torah and commandments, except for what he gathers of his produce, fruits, wine, and oil. It may also happen, Heaven forbid, that his produce was not successful and his field yielded less than what he had hoped for, and the same applies to sadness. How then did our Sages say that the general rule is that the time of gathering the produce is a time of joy, and only then does one bring and read, and not at any other time? What is the reason for this? Similarly, one can note that the Torah calls the festival of Sukkot the Festival of Ingathering, as stated in the verse, "When you gather the produce of the land, you shall celebrate a festival to the Lord." The verse ties the matter of the holy festival to the time of gathering the produce, and the intention behind this is to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the timing of the reading of the Bikurim (first fruits) in relation to the joy associated with gathering one's harvest, emphasizing that true joy for the observant Jew is derived from the fruits of their labor. It highlights that the celebration of Sukkot, referred to as the "Festival of Ingathering," is intrinsically linked to the agricultural cycle, suggesting that the spiritual fulfillment and connection to God are realized through the physical act of harvesting. The text raises questions about the nature of joy and sadness in the context of agricultural success or failure, underscoring the importance of gratitude and recognition of divine providence in all circumstances.

passage_content: ב) במדרש ושמחת בכל הטוב, אין טוב אלא תורה, לפיכך משה מזהיר את ישראל עשר תעשר עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב.
translation: In the Midrash, "And you shall rejoice in all the good," there is no good except for the Torah; therefore, Moses warns Israel, "You shall surely tithe." Thus concludes the Midrash, and the question remains.
summary: The passage emphasizes that true goodness is found in the Torah, as highlighted in the Midrash. It suggests that Moses warns the Israelites about the importance of tithing, indicating that their material wealth should be connected to their spiritual obligations. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that material and spiritual realms are intertwined, and fulfilling one's duties in the physical world enhances one's spiritual life. Ultimately, the teaching underscores the significance of aligning one's actions with divine commandments to achieve true fulfillment.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הגמ' שבת (דף י' ע"ב) אסור לאדם שיתן שלו' לחבירו בבית המרחץ משום שנאמר (שופטים ו') ויקרא לו ד' שלום, אלא מעתה הימנותא נמי אסור למימר בבית הכסא דכתיב האל הנאמן וכו' ותירצו התם שם גופי' לא איקרי הכי דמתרגמינן אלהא מהימנא, הכא שם גופי' איקרי שלו' דכתיב ויקרא לו ד' שלום, והקשו התוס' תימא דשלו' נמי מתרגמינן דעבד לי' שלו', וי"ל דהתם קראו שלו' על שם שהוא עושה שלום, דאי לא קראו שלו', אלא בעי למימר וכו' ד' העושה לו שלום, א"כ הול"ל ד' שלומו ע"כ תירוץ התוס'.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Gemara in Shabbat (page 10b) that it is forbidden for a person to give his friend peace in the bathhouse, as it is said (Judges 6) "And the Lord called him Peace." Therefore, it follows that it is also forbidden to say faith in the restroom, as it is written "the faithful God," etc. And they answered there that the name itself is not called this way, as we translate "Elah Mehemena," here the name itself is called peace, as it is written "And the Lord called him Peace." And the Tosafot questioned that peace is also translated as "He made peace for me," and it can be said that there they called him peace because he makes peace, for if they did not call him peace, but rather wanted to say "the Lord who makes peace for him," it should have said "the Lord of his peace." Therefore, this is the answer of the Tosafot.
summary: The passage discusses the prohibition against giving one's possessions to another in a bathhouse, based on the verse "And the Lord called him Shalom," highlighting the sanctity of the name "Shalom" as it signifies peace. It contrasts this with the concept of faithfulness, suggesting that while the name of God is associated with peace, the essence of faithfulness is not diminished in impure places. The Talmudic discussion emphasizes the importance of context in interpreting names and their meanings, illustrating the depth of divine attributes in relation to human actions. Ultimately, it reflects on the interplay between holiness, names, and the nature of divine attributes in everyday life.

passage_content: וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א וז"ל יש לעיין בזה דגם לפי"ד התוס' שיש לחלק דהכי גבי שלו' מוכח דקראו לשמו ות' שלו', מ"מ טעמא איכא בזה, כיון דשניהם עושה ד' למה איקרי שמו שלו' טפי מנאמן, ועוד בכל הכינויים כגון רחום וחנון אמאי לא קאמרינן הכו, דהכי נמי כתיב ק"ל רחום וחנון, וי"ל בזה עפימ"ש חסד אומר יברא שהוא גומל חסדים, אמת אומר אל יברא שהוא כולו ישקר, צדק אומר יברא שהוא עושה צדקות, שלו' אומר אל יברא שהוא כולו קטטה, והשתא בכל כנויין הנמחקין כגון רחום וחנון ורב חסד וארך אפים וכו', כיון שהאדם משותף בו לעשות חסד ורחמנות וחנינות, אין שמו של הקב"ה נקרא כן. אלא אל רחום וחנון הוי כמו אלהא המרחם וחונן וכמ"ש בהאל הנאמן ושרי לאומרה בבית הכסא, משא"כ שלו' שאין מדה זו באדם כלל, ושמו ית' ב"ה מקרי שפיר שלו' ע"ש שהוא עושה שלו', וכן למדת אמת כיון שאינה באדם, חותמו של הקב"ה נקרא אמת וכו', ובתוס' פ"ק דסוטה מוכח דשלו' אינו נמחק, ומיהו לא הוזכר גבי אמת שיהא אסור לומר בביהכ"ס ושלא נמחק כמו גבי שלו', כיון דשמו ית' ב"ה גופי' לא אקרי אמת רק חותמו עכ"ל המהרש"א ז"ל
translation: The Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his commentary, and I quote: "One should ponder this, for even according to the opinion of the Tosafists, there is a distinction, as regarding 'Shalom' it is evident that it is called by His name, and it is written 'Shalom.' Nevertheless, there is a reason for this, since both are associated with the act of creation. Why then is His name 'Shalom' more trustworthy than 'Ne'eman'? Furthermore, in all the appellations such as 'Rachum' and 'Chanun,' why do we not say the same? For it is also written, 'K'l Rachum and Chanun.' It can be explained based on what is said: 'Chesed' says 'Let Him create,' for He bestows kindness; 'Emet' says 'Let Him not create,' for He is entirely truthful; 'Tzedek' says 'Let Him create,' for He performs acts of righteousness; 'Shalom' says 'Let Him not create,' for He is entirely strife. And now, in all the appellations that are erased, such as 'Rachum' and 'Chanun' and 'Rav Chesed' and 'Erech Apayim,' since a person shares in performing kindness, compassion, and grace, His name is not called thus. Rather, 'El Rachum' and 'Chanun' is like 'The God who has mercy and grants grace,' as it is written regarding 'The Faithful God' and it is permitted to say it in the restroom. In contrast, 'Shalom' is not a quality that exists in a person at all, and His name, blessed be He, is appropriately called 'Shalom' because He brings about peace. Similarly, 'Emet' is learned, since it does not exist in a person; the seal of the Holy One, blessed be He, is called 'Emet,' etc. And in Tosafot, in the first chapter of Sotah, it is evident that 'Shalom' is not erased. However, it was not mentioned regarding 'Emet' that it is forbidden to say in the synagogue and that it is not erased like 'Shalom,' since His name, blessed be He, is not called 'Emet' but rather His seal." Thus concludes the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of divine names and attributes, particularly focusing on the name "Shalom" (peace) and its unique status compared to other attributes like "Rachum" (merciful) and "Chanon" (gracious). It emphasizes that while many divine attributes can be shared with humanity, "Shalom" represents a quality that is solely divine, as it embodies completeness and harmony without human conflict. The text also highlights that "Emet" (truth) is similarly unique, as it reflects the essence of God, distinguishing it from other attributes that can be partially realized in human behavior. Ultimately, the passage underscores the idea that certain divine names reflect God's inherent qualities that transcend human experience.

passage_content: וק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בהפטורה לפ' תצא) כתב ע"ד המהרש"א הנ"ל וז"ל דאף לפי תירוצו היפה אף נעים נשאר הקושיא לכאורה, דמ"ש אמת משלו', ומ"ש זה נמחק וזה אינו נמחק, וזה נאמר בביהכ"ס וזה אסור לאומרו, ומ"ש דשם גופי' לא אקרי אמת, הוא גופי' קשיא כיון שהשי"ת עושה גם שניהם, ואין האדם משותף בשניהם, וכמו שהקשה הוא בעצמו בראש דבריו מ"ש שלו' מנאמן, וכל מה שטרח בו אותו צדיק ליישב הקושיא ההיא ולבסוף לא נמלט ממנה ע"כ קושיתו. וכתב ליישב דלכך אמת מהנמחקין, דלפעמים נמחק מקמי' שלו', דהיינו פעולת האמת שע"ש כך נקרא כן, והוא נדחה מקמי' עשיית השלו' וכו', ואף הקב"ה שינה מפני דרכי שלו' אצל אברהם וכו', וכיון שהפעולה נדחית לפעמים, גם השם שנצמח מהפעולה לא עדיף ולכך נמחק, משא"כ עשיית השלו' שאינה נדחית עכת"ד ז"ל, אמנם איכא להקשות על תירוצו ז"ל דמצינו דגם השלו' נדחית מקמי' האמת, וכמ"ש דהמע"ה הלא משנאיך ד' אשנא ובתקוממיך אתקוטט וגו', ואמר ראיתי בוגדים ואתקוטעה אשר אמרתך לא שמרו, והדרא קושיא מ"ט שם גופי' אקרי שלו', משא"כ אמת רק חותמו ית' אמת ואין זה שם העצם וצ"ב.
translation: And so, Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in the Haftarah for Parshat Tetzaveh), wrote according to the aforementioned Maharsha, and said that even according to his beautiful explanation, the question remains seemingly pleasant, that what is said "truth from His own," and what is said "this is erased and this is not erased," and "this is said in the synagogue and this is forbidden to say," and what is said that the essence itself is not called truth, is itself a difficulty since the Holy One, blessed be He, does both, and man is not a partner in both. And as he himself questioned at the beginning of his words, what is said "from the faithful," and all the effort that righteous one exerted to resolve that question, in the end, he did not escape from it, thus is his question. And he wrote to resolve that therefore truth is from the erased, for sometimes it is erased before His own, meaning the action of truth, for which it is called so, and it is pushed aside before the action of His own, etc. And even the Holy One, blessed be He, changed for the ways of His own concerning Abraham, etc. And since the action is sometimes pushed aside, also the name that arises from the action is not superior, and thus it is erased, whereas the action of His own is not pushed aside, thus he concluded, may his memory be blessed. However, one can challenge his explanation, for we find that also the own is pushed aside before the truth, as it is said, "For I hate you, O Lord, I will hate, and with your rising I will contend," etc. And he said, "I saw traitors, and I contended," which you said they did not keep, and the question returns, why there the essence itself is called His own, whereas truth is only His seal, the Holy One, blessed be He, is truth, and this is not the essence itself, and it is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between the concepts of "truth" and "peace" in Hasidic thought, particularly in relation to the actions of God and human understanding. It highlights a debate on why certain truths can be "erased" while peace remains steadfast, suggesting that truth can sometimes be set aside for the sake of peace, as seen in biblical examples. However, it also raises questions about the nature of peace, indicating that even peace can be compromised in the face of truth. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the complexity of divine actions and the interplay between these fundamental values in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימ"ד בגמ' (ע"ז דף ד' ע"ב) א"ר יוסף לא לוצלו אינש צלותא דמוספי בתלת שעי קמייתא דיומא, ביומא קמא דריש שתא ביחיד, דלמא כיון דמפקיד דינא דלמא מעייני' בעובדי' ודחפו לי' וכו', והקשו והא אמרת שלש ראשונות יושב הקב"ה ועוסק בתורה, (שניות יושב ודן), ותירצו איפוך, ואיבע"א לעולם לא תיפוך, ותורה דכתיב בי' אמת, דכתיב אמת קנה ואל תמכר, אין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משוה"ד, ודין דלא כתיב בי' אמת עושה הקב"ה לפנים משורת הדין, וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל דהיינו טעמא דאמרי' בפ"ק דסנהדרין (דף ו' ע"ב) משתשמע דברי בעלי דינין ואתה יודע להיכן הדין נוטה, אי אתה רשאי לעשות לפנים משורת הדין, כיון דיודע היכן הדין תורה נוטה שהוא אמת הדין, אי אתה רשאי לעשות לפנים משורת הדין עכ"ד ז"ל. נמצא לפי"ז, דמדת אמת הוא תוקף הדין ואין הקב"ה עושה בו לפנים משורת הדין ואם הקב"ה ידון בתוקף הדין ח"ו א"א לעולם להתקיים, דאין העולם מתקיים בדין כמאמז"ל, וע"כ אין הקב"ה משתמש במדה זו כשהוא ות' דן את העולם, כמבואר בגמ' הנ"ל דראשונות עוסק בתורה דכתיב בי' אמת, שניות יושב ודן.
translation: And even though it is stated in the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 4b) that Rabbi Yosef said: A person should not recite the additional prayers during the first three hours of the day, on the first day of the week, when he is alone, perhaps since he is entrusted with the law, maybe he will ponder over the actions and push them away, etc. And they asked: But you said that during the first three hours, the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and engages in Torah (during the second three hours, He sits and judges). And they answered: It is the opposite, and if you wish, you can say that it will never be the opposite. And the Torah, which is written about it, is truth, as it is written: "Acquire truth and do not sell it." The Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law, and the law that is not written about it as truth, the Holy One, blessed be He, acts beyond the letter of the law. And the Maharsha, may his merit protect us, wrote that this is the reason we say in the first chapter of Sanhedrin (6b) that once you hear the words of the litigants and you know where the law leans, you are not permitted to act beyond the letter of the law, since you know where the law of the Torah leans, which is the truth of the law; you are not permitted to act beyond the letter of the law. Thus, it follows that according to this, the measure of truth is the strength of the law, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law. And if the Holy One, blessed be He, were to judge with the strength of the law, Heaven forbid, the world could not exist, for the world does not endure through strict judgment, as our sages have said. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, does not use this measure when He and His throne judge the world, as is explained in the aforementioned Gemara, that during the first three hours, He engages in Torah, which is written about it as truth, and during the second three hours, He sits and judges.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of divine judgment and the concept of truth in relation to God's actions. It emphasizes that God does not operate strictly according to the measure of justice (midat hadin), as this would render the world unsustainable. Instead, God employs a more compassionate approach, particularly during the initial phases of judgment, where He engages in Torah study, reflecting a balance between truth and mercy. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the importance of divine mercy and the sustaining power of compassion in the world.

passage_content: אמנם יש אופן שיוכל העולם להתקיים אף במדת הדין והאמת עפימ"ש בפר"ד (דרך צדקה דרוש א"ח) מאי דאמרי' בפ"ח דערובין (דף פ"ו) דרש ובא בר מרי ישב עולם לפני אלקים חסד ואמת מן ינצרוהו, אימתי ישב עולם לפני אלקים. בזמן שחסד ואמת מן ינצרוהו, ויובן עם מאי דאמרי' בב"ר ביום עשות ד' אלקים ארץ ושמים, בתחלה עלה במחשבה לברוא את העולם בדין, כיון שראה שאין העולם מתקיים בדין, שתף עמו מדת הרחמים וכו', ולפי"ז הוקשה לו לרבא היכי קאמר ישב עולם לפני אלקים, דהיכי משכחת לה שיתקיים ויתיישב העולם לפני אלקים שהוא מדת הדין, והא אמרינן שראה הקב"ה שאין העולם מתקיים בדין, לזה אמר רבא אימתי ישב עולם לפני אלקים, בזמן שחסד ואמת מן ינצרוהו, שאם מקיימין מצות צדקה ועושים חסד זע"ז, כח הצדקה מהפכת מדת הדין למדת הרחמים, כמ"ש ז"ל במדרש השקיפה ממעון קדשך וגו' כל השקפה שבתורה הוא לרעה וכו', חוץ מזו שהוא לטובה וכו' ללמדך שגדול כח של מתנת עניים שמהפכת מדת הרוגז למדת הרחמים, וא"כ אפי' בלא שיתוף מדת הרחמים ישב עולם לפני אלקים, לפי שע"י הצדקה אין כאן דין עכ"ד ז"ל.
translation: Indeed, there is a way for the world to exist even in the measure of judgment and truth, as it is stated in Parashat Derashot (the way of charity, Drush A”H), regarding what is said in chapter 8 of Eruvin (page 86), that it was taught: "And the son of the master sat the world before God, mercy and truth will sustain it." When does the world sit before God? At a time when mercy and truth will sustain it. This can be understood in light of what is said in Bereshit Rabbah, that on the day God created the heavens and the earth, initially it was in His thought to create the world with judgment. When He saw that the world could not endure with judgment, He combined with it the attribute of mercy, etc. Therefore, it was difficult for Rava to understand how it is said that the world sits before God, as how can it be found that the world exists and is established before God, which is the attribute of judgment, when it is said that the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that the world could not endure with judgment? To this, Rava said: When does the world sit before God? At a time when mercy and truth will sustain it, for if they fulfill the commandments of charity and do kindness to one another, the power of charity transforms the attribute of judgment into the attribute of mercy, as our sages have said in the Midrash: "Look down from Your holy dwelling, etc.," that every gaze in the Torah is for evil, etc., except for this one, which is for good, etc., to teach you that the power of the gift of the poor is so great that it transforms the attribute of wrath into the attribute of mercy. Therefore, even without the combination of the attribute of mercy, the world can sit before God, for through charity there is no judgment. Thus concludes our sages.
summary: The passage discusses the balance between divine justice (Middat HaDin) and mercy (Middat HaRachamim) in the sustenance of the world. It emphasizes that while the initial intention of creation was through strict justice, the world cannot endure without the inclusion of mercy. The text highlights the transformative power of acts of charity (tzedakah) and kindness, which can convert the harshness of judgment into compassion, allowing the world to exist harmoniously under divine oversight. Ultimately, it asserts that through the practice of charity, even in the presence of strict justice, the world can find stability and favor before God.

passage_content: ואפשר להוסיף נופך על דבה"ק, דלפי פירושו אינו מתיישב עדיין המאמר כולו, חסד שואמת" מן ינצרוהו, והוא ז"ל מפרש מלת חסד לבד. שכח החסד מהפכת מדה"ד לרחמים, אולם מלת ואמת צ"ב הכוונה בו, ולדרכנו א"ש הכוונה דכשבנ"א עושים חסד זע"ז, יוכלו לזכות בדין אף במדת אמת, לפי שע"י הצדקה אין כאן דין וז"ש חסד ואמת מן ונצרוהו, שגם האמת והחסד יהיו מזומנים לנצרו (עיין פרש"י שם).
translation: And it is possible to add a nuance to the holy discourse, for according to his interpretation, the entire statement is not yet settled, "kindness and truth" from "they will preserve him," and he, may his memory be blessed, explains the word kindness alone. The essence of kindness transforms the attribute of judgment into mercy; however, the meaning of the word truth is questionable. According to our approach, it is clear that when people do kindness to one another, they can merit a favorable judgment even in the attribute of truth, for through charity there is no judgment, and this is what is meant by "kindness and truth" from "they will preserve him," that both truth and kindness will be prepared to preserve him (see Rashi's commentary there).
summary: The passage discusses the interplay between kindness (chesed) and truth (emet) in the context of divine judgment. It suggests that when individuals perform acts of kindness towards one another, they can merit a favorable judgment even in the realm of truth. The author emphasizes that through acts of charity, the harshness of judgment is transformed into mercy, allowing both kindness and truth to coexist harmoniously. This reflects a key Hasidic teaching on the transformative power of compassion in the divine evaluation of human actions.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר אמרם ז"ל בב"ר מתחלה עלה במחשבה לבראות במדת הדין וראה שאין העולם מתקיים, והקדים מדת הרחמים ושתפה למדת הדין, וכבר הקשו המפרשים דהלא אצל הבוי"ת לא יתכן חזרה ושינוי רצון ח"ו, והעבר וההוה והעתיד הכל ברגע א' ואיך יתכן לומר מתחלה עלה במחשבה בדין, ואח"כ הקדים מדת הרחמים, ואפ"ל לדרכנו עפימ"ד בזוה"ק באורייתא ברא קוב"ה עלמא, ובתנחומא אר"פ בראשית) זש"ה ד' בחכמה יסד ארץ (משלי ג') כשברא הקב"ה את עולמו נתייעץ בתורה וברא בו את העולם, ואמרי' בגמ' דע"ז הנ"ל, תורה דכתיב בי' אמת, אין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משורת הדין, נמצא כי בתחלת הבריאה כשעלה במחשבה לפניו ית' לברוא את העולם אסתכל באורייתא והוא מדת הדין, וראתה חכמתו ית' שאין העולם יכול להתקיים בדין, והקדים מדת הרחמים וכו', שברא מדת החסד ועי"ז יתקיים העולם לפני אלקים דאין כאן דין, ואין כאן חזרה ושינוי רצון דגם תחלת המחשבה קיים, ובזה פירשו המפרשים מ"ש רש"י ז"ל ו)בפ' לך) ואברכך זה שאומרים אלקי אברהם וכו', יכול יהיו חותמין בכולן תלמוד לומר והי' ברכה בך חותמין ולא בהם, וביארו ז"ל שהבטיחו הבוי"ת כי החתימה לפועל המעשה יושלם במדתו של אאע"ה שהוא חסד, כי בדין אין העולם יכול להתקיים, ואף שתחלת הרצון בבריאה הי' בדין, אבל ע"י החסד יומתק ויתהפך לרחמים, ובזה יבוארו דברי המהרש"א ז"ל מה שכתב לחלק דשלו' שם גופי' אקרי שלו' משא"כ אמת שם גופי' לא אקרי הכי רק חותמו, ויובן לדרכנו דאמת היינו דין ואין הקב"ה עושה בו לפנים משורת הדין, וע"כ שם גופי' לא אקרי הכי ע"ש פעולותיו, שאין העולם מתקיים בו, אבל חותמו נקרא אמת כי חותמו ית' תסד ועל ידו נמתק הדין ויכול להתנהג במדת האמת והבן,
translation: And this will clarify their statement, may their memory be blessed, in Bereshit Rabbah: At first, it arose in His thought to create the world with the attribute of judgment, and He saw that the world could not endure, so He preceded the attribute of mercy and combined it with the attribute of judgment. The commentators have already questioned how it is possible that in the case of the Creator, there cannot be a reversal or change of will, Heaven forbid, for the past, present, and future all exist in one moment. How can it be said that at first, it arose in His thought regarding judgment, and afterwards He preceded the attribute of mercy? One could say according to our path, as it is explained in the Zohar, "With the Torah, the Holy One, blessed be He, created the world," and in the Tanchuma on the verse "In the beginning" (Genesis), as it is stated, "The Lord founded the earth with wisdom" (Proverbs 3:19). When the Holy One, blessed be He, created His world, He consulted the Torah and created the world through it. And it is said in the Gemara in Avodah Zarah, that the Torah is written with the letter 'truth'; the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law. Thus, at the beginning of creation, when it arose in His thought to create the world, He looked into the Torah, which is the attribute of judgment, and His wisdom saw that the world could not endure with judgment, so He preceded the attribute of mercy, etc. He created the attribute of kindness, and through this, the world will endure before God, for there is no judgment here, and there is no reversal or change of will, for even the initial thought remains intact. And with this, the commentators explain what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in Parashat Lech Lecha: "And I will bless you," this refers to the one who says, "The God of Abraham," etc. It could be that they would conclude with all of them, therefore it is stated, "And the blessing will be in you," they conclude and not in them. And they explained, may their memory be blessed, that He promised the Creator that the conclusion of the action will be completed with the attribute of our father Abraham, which is kindness, for with judgment, the world cannot endure. And although the initial will in creation was with judgment, through kindness it will be sweetened and transformed into mercy. And with this, the words of the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified regarding what he wrote to differentiate between "truth" and "peace." There, "peace" is called "peace," whereas "truth" is not called so, only its seal. And it will be understood according to our path that "truth" means judgment, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the letter of the law. Therefore, "truth" is not called so regarding His actions, for the world cannot endure in it, but His seal is called "truth" because His seal is established, and through it, the judgment is sweetened, and He can conduct Himself with the attribute of truth. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the initial divine intention to create the world through the attribute of justice (din), which was deemed unsustainable. Consequently, God introduced the attribute of mercy (rachamim) to balance justice, allowing for the world's existence. It emphasizes that while the initial thought of creation was rooted in justice, the ultimate reality is governed by mercy and kindness (chesed), which transforms and mitigates strict judgment. This reflects the Hasidic belief that divine attributes interact to ensure the world's continuity and that true fulfillment comes from the integration of mercy within the framework of justice.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל ושמחת בכל טוב אין טוב אלא תורה לפיכך משה מזהיר את ישראל עשר תעשר, עפימ"ד בתנדב"א (פי"ח) ובילקוט איכה רמז י)תתרל"ד) עה"כ נוכח פני ד', מכאן אמרו כל ת"ח שיושב בינו לבין עצמו וקורא ושונה, כביכול הקב"ה יושב ושונה עמו עכ"ד המדרש, והנה לפי"ז יוכל להתעורר מדת הדין ח"ו, כמ"ש בגמ' דר"ה הנ"ל דבג' ראשונות יושב הקב"ה ועוסק בתורה, ואין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משוה"ד, לפיכך משה מזהיר את ישראל עשר תעשר דגדול מתנות עניים שמהפך מדת הדין לרחמים ואין כאן דין.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash, and joy in all good—there is no good but the Torah. Therefore, Moses warns Israel, "You shall surely tithe." According to the interpretation of the Midrash (Chapter 18) and in the Yalkut Eicha (Remez 574), regarding the verse "Before the face of the Lord," from here they said that any Torah scholar who sits alone and studies and reviews, as if the Holy One, blessed be He, is sitting and studying with him. Thus far the Midrash. And behold, according to this, the attribute of judgment could be aroused, Heaven forbid, as it is stated in the Gemara in Rosh Hashanah, that in the first three hours the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and engages in Torah, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the measure of judgment. Therefore, Moses warns Israel, "You shall surely tithe," for great is the gift to the poor, which transforms the attribute of judgment into mercy, and there is no judgment here.
summary: The passage emphasizes the centrality of Torah in achieving true joy, as indicated by the phrase "אין טוב אלא תורה." It highlights the importance of Torah study, suggesting that when a scholar engages in learning, it is as if God is learning with him, which can mitigate the severity of divine judgment. This is further illustrated by Moses' warning to the Israelites to give tithes, as charitable acts can transform harsh judgment into mercy, underscoring the power of generosity in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: ובזה יובן מאמה"כ באספך את תבואת הארץ תחוגו חג לה', ומה שאמרו דאסיפת התבואות הוא זמן שמחה, דהנה כשישראל השומר תומ"צ מאסף תבואתו ופירותיו ויינו ושמנו, ה"ה מקיים מצות פאה לקט שכחה פרט ועוללות תרומה ומעשרות, ואמחז"ל גדול כח מתנות עניים שמהפך מדת הדין לרחמים, וחוץ מזה דעתו כשהולך לעסקיו שאם יעזור לו השי"ת וירויח יתן להחזקת ת"ח ותשב"ר, ובמחשבה זו הלא הוא מקדים מדת החסד ומהפך מדת הרוגז לרחמים, ועל כן אמרו ז"ל שבזמן אסיפת התבואות הוא זמן שמחה, ולא התבואה והיין הוא סיבת השמחה, כ"א מה שנתבטל מדת הדין ונתהפך מדת הרוגז ואין לך שמחה בעולם גדולה מזו, וז"ש הכתוב באספכם תבואת הארץ תחוגו את חג ד' וגו', דהנה בר"ה ויוכ"פ המה ימי דין ואין השמחה בשלימות, כי יראים וחרדים אנחנו מחרדת הדין, אבל בחג הסוכות עת אסיפת התבואות, נמשך עי"ז כח החסד כנ"ל ונתבטל כח הדין, וע"כ הוא זמן שמחה ואז מביא בכורים וקורא כל הפרשה השקיפה ממעון קדשך וגו' שישקיף ד' לטובה על ישראל, כאמרז"ל דגדול כח מתנות עניים.
translation: And with this, it will be understood from the verse, "When you gather the harvest of your land, you shall celebrate a festival for the Lord," and what they said that the gathering of the harvest is a time of joy. Behold, when Israel, who observes the Torah and commandments, gathers his harvest, fruits, wine, and oil, he is fulfilling the commandments of Pe'ah, Leket, Shikcha, and the gifts of the poor, and our Sages have said that the power of the gifts to the poor transforms the attribute of judgment into mercy. Furthermore, his intention when he goes about his business is that if the Holy One, blessed be He, helps him and he profits, he will give to support Torah scholars and those who study Torah. With this thought, he is indeed prioritizing the attribute of kindness and transforming the attribute of anger into mercy. Therefore, our Sages said that during the time of gathering the harvest is a time of joy, and it is not the harvest and wine that are the cause of joy, but rather the nullification of the attribute of judgment and the transformation of the attribute of anger. There is no greater joy in the world than this. And this is what the verse means, "When you gather the harvest of your land, you shall celebrate the festival of the Lord," for behold, on Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, these are days of judgment, and joy is not complete, for we are fearful and anxious about the dread of judgment. But during the festival of Sukkot, the time of gathering the harvest, the power of kindness is drawn down, as mentioned, and the power of judgment is nullified. Therefore, it is a time of joy, and then he brings the first fruits and recites the entire passage, "Look down from Your holy dwelling," that the Lord should look favorably upon Israel, as our Sages have said that the power of the gifts to the poor is great.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the gathering of the harvest is a time of joy because it reflects the fulfillment of mitzvot such as leaving the corners of the field for the poor and giving tithes. This act transforms the attribute of judgment into one of mercy, highlighting the power of charity to shift divine decrees. Unlike the days of Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, which are marked by fear of judgment, the festival of Sukkot, coinciding with the harvest, embodies a time of divine favor and joy. Ultimately, the joy stems not from the physical bounty itself, but from the elevation of kindness and the nullification of harsh judgments.

passage_content: תמצית הדברים דהחזקת התורה הוא קיום כל העולם כולו, דעל ידו נמתק מדת הדין כנ"ל, ואפשר דלטובת ותועלת ישראל מסבב הבוי"ת הנהגת העולם בדרך זה, שלהשפעת התורה יהי' נצרך חסד מצד המחזיקים, דלכאורה הרי תכלית העולם הוא התוה"ק, ובפרט תורתן של תשב"ר הבל שאין בו חטא, והבוי"ת יש לו די והותר להספיק כל צרכם מבלי שיצטרכו לחסד בנ"א, אמנם בהכרח שיקדים מדת החסד לכח התורה, וזהו צורך לקיום התורה חוץ מתועלת הגשמי נוסף עליו תועלת הרוחני, דע"י מדת החסד יוכל העולם להתקיים בכח התורה כנ"ל, דתוה"ק כתיב בי' אמת ואין הקב"ה עושה לפנים משוה"ד, וע"י שמקדימין מדת החסד נתקיים העולם בכח התוה"ק, נמצא דחסד ואמת מקושרים המה, וא"א שיתנהג העולם במדת האמת שהוא דין, כ"א שיקדים אלי' מדת החסד, אמנם גם להשיג החסד ישתמש האדם רק במדת האמת, שיהי' חסד של אמת, ובעוה"ר עכשיו הוא להיפך. דכשצרוכים לחסדם של המחזיקים אסור לגלות האמת, ובשפלות המצב של דורנו אין בנמצא חסד של אמת, ואני אומר הקדמה חסד ואמת, כי צריך אני לחסד, אבל רק עם מדת האמת ולא אמנע מלגלות האמת, וזהו אסון הדור בעוה"ר שאין רוצים לגלות האמת.
translation: The essence of the matter is that the preservation of the Torah is the sustenance of the entire world, for through it the attribute of judgment is sweetened, as mentioned above. It is possible that for the benefit and advantage of Israel, the governance of the world is arranged in this manner, that the influence of the Torah requires kindness from those who uphold it. Seemingly, the purpose of the world is the Torah, especially the Torah of the Tzaddikim, which has no sin. The Tzaddik has more than enough to provide for all their needs without requiring the kindness of human beings. However, it is necessary that the attribute of kindness precedes the power of the Torah. This is essential for the sustenance of the Torah, aside from the physical benefit, there is an additional spiritual benefit, for through the attribute of kindness, the world can exist through the power of the Torah, as mentioned above. It is written about the Torah that it is truth, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act beyond the measure of justice. By prioritizing the attribute of kindness, the world is sustained through the power of the Torah. Thus, kindness and truth are interconnected, and it is impossible for the world to be governed by the attribute of truth, which is judgment, unless it is preceded by the attribute of kindness. However, to attain kindness, a person must only use the attribute of truth, so that it will be a kindness of truth. In our current situation, it is the opposite. When they require the kindness of those who uphold the Torah, it is forbidden to reveal the truth, and in the lowly state of our generation, there is no kindness of truth to be found. I say an introduction of kindness and truth, for I need kindness, but only with the attribute of truth, and I will not refrain from revealing the truth. This is the tragedy of the generation in our times, that they do not wish to reveal the truth.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the preservation of the Torah is essential for the existence of the entire world, as it mitigates the severity of divine judgment. It highlights the necessity of combining the attributes of kindness (chesed) and truth (emet) for the world to function properly, asserting that while the ultimate purpose is the Torah, the world requires the precedence of kindness to sustain it. The author notes a troubling reality in the current generation, where true kindness is lacking, and the truth is often concealed, leading to a spiritual crisis. Ultimately, the text calls for a balance between revealing the truth and practicing genuine kindness, underscoring the interconnectedness of these divine attributes.

passage_content: נחזור לראש דברינו לפרש מאמה"כ שמח זבולן בצאתך וגו', ומ"ט הקדימו הכתוב לזבולן לפני יששכר, והרי התוה"ק מוקדם לכל דבר. ויתבאר לדרכנו דהרי זבולן ע"י שמחזיק בתורתו של יששכר, ה"ה מקדים מדת החסד בעולם, ועי"ז נמתק כח הדין ומביא שמחה לעולם, ויתקיים העולם בכח התורה, ויכולין עי"ז ללמוד תורה מתוך שמחה כי אין כאן דין כלל וכבר נתהפך לרחמים, ומה"ט הקדימו הכתוב לזבולן מידה כנגד מידה על שהוא מקדים עדת הרחמים למדת הדין, כמו שהקדימו הקדוש ברוך הוא בבריאת העולם, וזה שאמר שמח זבולן בצאתך, שגורם שמחה בעולם על ידי מעשיו ועל ידי זה יששכר באהליך שנתקיים העולם בכח התורה ואין כאן דין, וז"ש הכתוב צדק ומשפע מכון כסאך, חסד ואמת יקדמו פניך, שע"י שיקדמו פניך במדת החסד, יתקיים העולם גם במשפט כי מתבטל מדת הדין ואז יתקיים גם מדת האמת כי אין כאן דין כלל.
translation: We will return to the beginning of our discussion to explain the verse, "Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out," etc. And why does the text precede Zebulun before Issachar? The Torah is always prior to everything. It can be explained according to our path that Zebulun, by supporting the Torah of Issachar, is indeed advancing the attribute of kindness in the world. Through this, the power of judgment is sweetened, bringing joy to the world, and the world is sustained by the strength of the Torah. This allows for the study of Torah with joy, as there is no judgment here at all, and it has already been transformed into mercy. For this reason, the text precedes Zebulun measure for measure, for he advances the congregation of mercy over the attribute of judgment, just as the Holy One, blessed be He, preceded it in the creation of the world. This is what is meant by "Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out," for he causes joy in the world through his actions, and through this, Issachar will dwell in your tents, as the world is sustained by the strength of the Torah and there is no judgment here. This is what the verse means when it says, "Righteousness and justice are the foundation of Your throne; kindness and truth go before Your face," that by advancing Your face with the attribute of kindness, the world will also be sustained in judgment, for the attribute of judgment is nullified, and then the attribute of truth will also be established, for there is no judgment here at all.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the tribes of Zebulun and Issachar, emphasizing that Zebulun's support of Issachar's Torah study embodies the principle of kindness, which mitigates the harshness of judgment in the world. By prioritizing acts of kindness, Zebulun brings joy and transforms the nature of divine judgment into mercy, allowing for a joyful engagement with Torah. This reflects the idea that when kindness precedes judgment, the world can sustain itself through Torah without the weight of strict justice, aligning with the divine creation where mercy is favored. Ultimately, the text illustrates how the interplay of kindness and truth sustains the world and fosters a harmonious existence.
