passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל בענין הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר עוד במאמר הכתוב ועתה שני בניך הנולדים לך בארץ מצרים עד באי עליך מצרימה לי הם אפרים ומנשה כראובן ושמעון וגו' ומולדתך אשר הולדת וגו' אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, פרש"י ז"ל ומולדתך אשר הולדת אם תוליד עוד וכו', ומלת אשר יתפרש כמו אם, וכ"כ הרא"ם ז"ל שהוא מאמר מסופק, ולא כמשמעו שהוא מורה על הודאי, דאם היו לו בנים עוד, הי' מביא גם אותם לאביו כדי לברכם כמו שהביא את אפרים ומנשה עכת"ד המזרחי, ופירושו צ"ב חדא דלא מצינו אשר במקום אם והרא"ם ז"ל בעצמו נדחק בזה עיי"ש. ועוד דאם יהי' כוונת הכתוב אם תוליד עוד, מדוע אמר הולדת בלשון עבר והול"ל אשר תוליד, ועו"ק דהרי כל דבריו של יע"א בנבואה נאמרו, ואיך אמרה הנבואה דברים מסופקים וספיקא קמי שמיא ליכא, ואיך יכתוב התוה"ק דבר שלא הי', כי לא מצינו שהזכיר הכתוב בשום מקום שהוליד בנים עוד, והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב שהי' ליוסף בנים אחרים ולא זכרם הכתוב, והקשה עליו האברבנאל דראוי שיזכורם הכתוב אילו הי' לו, כמו שהזכיר ער ואונן וסרח בת אשר וכל בניו ובני בניו.
translation: In another way, one could say regarding the aforementioned matter, to preface by noting further in the written article: "And now your two sons, who were born to you in the land of Egypt, until I come to you in Egypt, they are mine, Ephraim and Manasseh, like Reuben and Simeon, etc., and your birthplace, which you gave birth to, etc., their brothers will be called by their inheritance." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: "And your birthplace, which you gave birth to, if you will give birth again, etc.," and the word "which" is to be interpreted like "if." So too, the Ra'ah, of blessed memory, states that it is a statement of doubt, and not as it seems, which indicates certainty. For if he had more sons, he would have brought them to his father to bless them, just as he brought Ephraim and Manasseh, thus far the Mizrachi. His explanation is questionable for one reason: we do not find "which" in the place of "if," and the Ra'ah, of blessed memory, himself is forced into a corner regarding this, as seen there. Furthermore, if the intent of the verse is "if you will give birth again," why did he say "which you gave birth" in the past tense? It should have said "which you will give birth." Additionally, it is known that all the words of the prophet were said in prophecy, and how could the prophecy say uncertain things, for there is no doubt before Heaven? And how could the Holy Torah write something that did not happen? For we do not find that the text mentions anywhere that he had more sons. And Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote that Joseph had other sons, but the text did not mention them, and the Abarbanel challenged him, saying that it would be fitting for the text to mention them if he had them, just as it mentioned Er and Onan and Serach the daughter of Asher and all his sons and grandsons.
summary: The passage discusses the biblical verse regarding Joseph's sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, and raises questions about the interpretation of the term "אשר" (which can mean "if") in relation to the potential for Joseph to have more children. It highlights the tension between the certainty of prophetic statements and the ambiguity of human circumstances, suggesting that the Torah does not record any additional children of Joseph. This reflects a Hasidic emphasis on the divine plan and the significance of lineage, as well as the importance of understanding the nuances in scriptural language.

passage_content: ב) גם קשה דמאמר לך יהיו מיותר, ופשיטא דלך יהיו וכוונת המאמר לומר דלא והא להם שם בשבעים לענין הנחלה, ולא יקראו שבעים אלא אלו, וכבר אמור במאמר ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, אבל זה דלך יהיו מאי למימרא וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: B) It is also difficult that the statement "to you shall be" is superfluous, and it is obvious that "to you shall be" refers to them in the context of inheritance, and they will not be called seventy except for these. And it has already been stated in the teaching that "according to their brothers they shall be called in their inheritance," but what is the intention of "to you shall be," and the meaning of this is to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "לך יהיו" (they shall be yours) in relation to the inheritance of the Jewish people, emphasizing that it is not merely a redundant statement. It highlights the unique connection between the Jewish people and their inheritance, suggesting that the term "שבעים" (seventy) specifically refers to those who are part of this divine legacy. The text raises questions about the deeper meaning of this phrase, indicating a need for further exploration of its implications within the context of communal identity and spiritual heritage.

passage_content: ג) ואני בבואי מפדן מתה עלי רחל וגו', פרש"י ז"ל ואע"פ שאני מעריח עליך בקבורתי ולא כך עשיתי לאמך, דע לך שעפ"י הדיבור קברתיה שם שתהא לעזרה לבניה וכו', והקשו המפרשים דהי' ראוי שיזכיר יע"א ההתנצלות הזאת בשעה שצוהו ונשאתני ממצרים וקברתני בקבורתם, ומדוע המתין עד הכא, ואיך יתקשר אל המאמר ומולדתך אשר הולדת הנסמך אליו.
translation: 3) "And I, when I came from Padan, Rachel died upon me, etc." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: "And although I am delaying you with my burial, and I did not do so with your mother, know that according to the word, I buried her there so that she would be a help to her children, etc." The commentators question why it was fitting for him to mention this excuse at the time he commanded, "And you carried me out of Egypt and buried me in their burial place," and why he waited until now, and how it connects to the statement "and your birthplace from which you were born."
summary: בקטע זה מדבר יעקב על מותו של רחל ועל הקבורה שלה, ומסביר כי למרות שהקבורה שלו תהיה במקום אחר, הוא קבר את רחל בדרך זו כדי שתהיה לעזרה לבניה בעת צרה. המפרשים שואלים מדוע יעקב לא הבהיר את התנצלותו בזמן שציווה על קבורתו במצרים, ומדגישים את הקשר בין המילים שלו לבין מקורותיו. יש כאן רעיון עמוק על הקשר בין משפחה, זיכרון ותמיכה רוחנית, הממחיש את החשיבות של הקבורה והזיכרון בהקשר החסידי.

passage_content: ד) להלן בפרשה ועיני ישראל כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות וגו', והקשה הראב"ע דלעיל אמר וירא ישראל את בני יוסף, ואיך יאמר לא יוכל לראות, רק טעמו לא יוכל לראות היטב שיכירם עכ"ד. אולם קשה ממ"ש להלן וישלח ישראל את ימינו על ראש אפרים והוא הצעיר. ואת שמאלו על ראש מנשה שכל את ידיו כי מנשה הבכור, הרי שידע להכירם, וצ"ב הכוונה במ"ש לא יוכל לראות.
translation: D) Here in the section, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy with age, so that he could not see," the Ra'avad questions, for previously it is stated, "And Israel saw the sons of Joseph," and how can it be said that he could not see? Rather, his understanding was that he could not see them well enough to recognize them, thus he concluded. However, it is difficult regarding what is stated later, "And Israel sent his right hand upon the head of Ephraim, who was the younger, and his left hand upon the head of Manasseh," for he crossed his hands because Manasseh was the firstborn, which indicates that he knew how to recognize them. Therefore, the intention of the phrase "could not see" remains unclear.
summary: In the passage, the author addresses the apparent contradiction in the biblical text regarding Jacob's ability to recognize his grandsons, Ephraim and Manasseh. While Jacob initially seems unable to see them clearly due to his old age, he later demonstrates awareness by blessing them in a specific manner. This highlights the Hasidic concept of spiritual perception, suggesting that true recognition transcends physical sight and involves deeper, divine insight. The discussion emphasizes the complexity of understanding one's spiritual lineage and the nuances of divine providence in familial relationships.

passage_content: ה) גם צ"ב כפל הלשון כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות, ויספיק שיאמר לא יוכל לראות מזוקן, ומה תוסיף הודעה זו שכבדו וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: 5) It is also necessary to understand the repetition of the phrase "he cannot see due to his old age," and it would suffice to say "he cannot see due to his old age." What does this additional statement add, that he is heavy and it is necessary to understand the intention behind this?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות," emphasizing the redundancy in the expression. It suggests that the repetition serves to deepen the understanding of the concept of honor and the limitations of perception associated with age. This reflects a Hasidic perspective on the interplay between respect for elders and the spiritual blindness that can accompany aging, highlighting the need for humility and awareness in one's spiritual journey.

passage_content: ו) במסכת יומא (כ"ח ע"ב) א"ר חמא ב"ר חנינא מימיהן של אבותינו לא פסקה ישיבה מהם וכו', אברהם זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' שנא' ואברהם זקן בא בימים, יצחק אבינו זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' שנאמר ויהי כי זקן יצחק. יעקב אבינו זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' שנא' ועיני ישראל כבדו מזוקן עכ"ד הגמ', ולכאורה לפי דרשתם ז"ל צ"ב קישור הכתוב כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות, כי מלת זוקן דרשו ז"ל שהי' זקן ויושב בישיבה, ומ"ע כבדו ולא יוכל לראות.
translation: In the tractate Yoma (28b), Rabbi Chama bar Chanina said: "From the days of our forefathers, the study of Torah did not cease from them, etc. Abraham was old and sitting in the study hall, as it is said, 'And Abraham was old, coming with days.' Our father Isaac was old and sitting in the study hall, as it is said, 'And it came to pass that when Isaac was old.' Our father Jacob was old and sitting in the study hall, as it is said, 'And the eyes of Israel were heavy with age.' Thus far the Gemara. And seemingly, according to their interpretation, it is difficult to connect the verse 'were heavy with age' to 'could not see,' for the term 'with age' they interpreted that he was old and sitting in the study hall, and it is stated 'heavy' and 'could not see.'"
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as figures who were deeply engaged in study and spiritual pursuits throughout their lives, symbolized by their being "old and sitting in the study hall." It highlights the connection between aging and wisdom, suggesting that their advanced years did not hinder their ability to perceive spiritual truths. The mention of Jacob's dimmed eyesight serves as a metaphor for the challenges of physical limitations, yet it underscores the enduring value of their scholarly and spiritual contributions. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that true insight and understanding transcend physical capabilities.

passage_content: ז) המלאך הגואל אתו מכל רע יברך את הנערים וגו', כבר דקדקנו לעיל מ"ט קראם נערים וכבר היו גדולים, גם הול"ל יברך אתכם בלשון נוכח שהרי עמדו אצלו למול פניו.
translation: The angel who redeems him from all evil shall bless the youths, etc. We have already noted above that he called them youths even though they were grown, and it should have said "He shall bless you" in the second person, since they stood before him face to face.
summary: המלאך הגואל מברך את הנערים, למרות שכבר היו גדולים, מה שמצביע על ההבנה החסידית של התפתחות רוחנית מתמדת. השימוש בלשון "נערים" מדגיש את הצורך בשמירה על תמימות ופתיחות, גם בגילאים מתקדמים. בנוסף, השאלה מדוע לא נברכו בלשון נוכח, למרות שהיו נוכחים, מצביעה על הקשר העמוק בין הברכה לבין ההכרה בנוכחות האלוהית. זהו ביטוי לתהליך של חיבור בין האדם לאלוהות, שבו הברכה היא לא רק פעולה חיצונית אלא גם חוויה פנימית.

passage_content: ח) ויקרא בהם שמי פי' האבן עזרא כי הנה כל בית ישראל יקראו אפרים עכ"ל. ומבואר כן בזוה"ק דאפרים על שמא דישראל אקרי, מנלן דכתיב (יחזקאל ל"ז) בן אדם העצמות האלה כל בית ישראל המה וכו' עיי"ש. אמנם הקשה הרמב"ן ז"ל על פי' הראב"ע כי הכתוב אמר ויקרא שבהם שמי, והנה לא נקראו על שם מנשה, גם צ"ב להלן בפסוק בך יברך ישראל לאמר ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, ולכאורה הול"ל בכם יברך ישראל, אחר שהזכיר שניהם אפרים ומנשה.
translation: (8) "And He will call upon them My name." The stone of Ezra explains that indeed all of the House of Israel will be called Ephraim, thus far his words. And it is clarified so in the Zohar that Ephraim is called by the name of Israel, from where do we know this? It is written (Ezekiel 37) "Son of man, these bones are the whole House of Israel," etc. However, Ramban, may his memory be blessed, challenged the explanation of the Ra'avad because the verse says "And He will call upon them My name," and they were not called after Manasseh. It is also difficult later in the verse "In you shall Israel bless, saying, 'May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh,'" and seemingly it should have said "In you shall Israel bless," after mentioning both Ephraim and Manasseh.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the names Ephraim and Manasseh in relation to the identity of the Jewish people, as highlighted by the Zohar and the commentary of the Ibn Ezra. It emphasizes that all of Israel is referred to as Ephraim, reflecting a deeper spiritual connection to the collective identity of the nation. The Ramban raises a question regarding the phrasing in the text, suggesting a need for clarity on why Ephraim is emphasized over Manasseh, particularly in the context of blessings. This highlights the theological theme of unity and the centrality of Ephraim in the spiritual lineage of Israel.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי החיד"א זלל"ה (הובא לעיל) וישם את אפרים לפני מנשה, להורות דתלמיד גדול, דמצינו זאפרים הי' רגיל לפני יעקב בתלמוד, ומנשה הי' הממונה על הבית ומחזיק ידי לומדי תורה, ועל כן וישם את אפרים לפני מנשה לרמוז בזה כו התלמיד חכם גדול בבחינתו מהמחזיק עכ"ד החיד"א זלל"ה. אמנם כבר הבאנו לעיל מתשו' בית שלמה (חלק יור"ד סי' צ"ד) דישנם סתורות ופלוגתא בדברי רז"ל בענין זה, דבקצת מקומות מבואר בדבריהם ז"ל דהמחזיק והת"ח בחינתם ומעלתם שווים המה, ומדברי הזוה"ק משמע דמעלת המחזיק עדיפא והקדימו הכתוב לזבולן בברכאן, על דאפיק פתא מפומי' ויהיב לפומי' דיששכר וכו', אולם בגמ' ברכות (דף ל"ד) אמרו ז"ל כל הנביאים לא נתנבאו אלא לעושי פרגמטיא לת"ח ולמהנה ת"ח מנכסיו וכו', אבל ת"ח עצמן עון לא ראתה אלקים זולתך, הרי דמעלת הת"ח עדיפא ויתירה פי כמה ממעלת המחזיק, עיין בדברנו לעיל (בדרוש הקדום) מה שבארנו בישוב הסתירות ולהשוות המאמרים דלא פליגי.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will precede with the words of the Chida, may his memory be a blessing (as mentioned above), "And he placed Ephraim before Manasseh," to indicate that a great scholar, for we find that Ephraim was accustomed to be before Jacob in the Talmud, and Manasseh was the one in charge of the household and supported the Torah scholars. Therefore, "And he placed Ephraim before Manasseh" hints that the great Torah scholar is superior in his standing compared to the supporter, thus concludes the Chida, may his memory be a blessing. However, we have already brought above from the response of the Beit Shlomo (part Yoreh De'ah, section 94) that there are contradictions and disputes in the words of our Sages regarding this matter, for in some places it is explained in their words that the standing and merit of the supporter and the Torah scholar are equal. And from the words of the Zohar, it seems that the merit of the supporter is greater, and the verse precedes Zebulun in their blessings, for he brings out bread from his mouth and gives it to the mouth of Issachar, etc. However, in the Gemara Berakhot (34a), our Sages said that all the prophets prophesied only for those who engage in practical matters for the Torah scholar and for the benefit of the Torah scholar from their possessions, etc., but the Torah scholars themselves, "Sin has not seen, O God, except You," thus the merit of the Torah scholar is far superior and greater by many measures than the merit of the supporter. Refer to our discussion above (in the earlier discourse) where we explained the resolution of the contradictions and the comparison of the statements that they do not disagree.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the roles of a Torah scholar (תלמיד חכם) and a supporter of Torah study (מחזיק), as illustrated by the biblical placement of Ephraim before Manasseh. It highlights differing opinions among rabbinic sources regarding their respective merits, with some suggesting equality while others elevate the supporter’s role. However, the author ultimately concludes that the Torah scholar holds a superior status, emphasizing the importance of both roles in the spiritual and communal life of the Jewish people. The discussion reflects a deeper theological insight into the value of learning and supporting Torah study within Hasidic thought.

passage_content: וכעת נל"פ באופן אחר, דהנה באמת לא אמרו חז"ל שהמחזיק גדול במעלתו מהת"ח, כי אם שהקדימו הכתוב לברכה לפי שהוא הגורם לתורתו של יששכר, שלולי זבולן לא הי' יששכר יכול לעסוק בתורה, אבל אה"נ שמעלת הת"ח גדלה ממעלתו, דת"ח עצמן עון לא ראתה אלקים זולתך וגם הנביאים לא השיגו שכחו ומעלתו בעוה"ב כמבואר בפסוק, ומפורש כן במד"ר פ' קדושים (כ"ה סי' א') ר' הונא ור' ירמי' אמרו בש"ר חייא בר אבא עתיד הקב"ה לעשות צל וחופות לבעלי המצות אצל בני תורה בגן עדן וכו' שנא' כי בצל החכמה בצל הכסף וכו', ודכוותה שמח זבולן בצאתך ויששכר באהליך, ולא יששכר גדול הי' מזבולן, אלא ע"ו שהי' זבולן מפרש מיישוב ועוסק בפרגמעיא, ובא ונותן לתוך פיו של יששכר וכו' לפיכך נקרא הפסוק על שמו שנא' שמח זבולן בצאתך וגו' פי' שהקדימו הכתוב וכן אמרו בזוה"ק שהקדימו הכתוב לזבולן בברכאן, אבל לענין המעלה והחשיבות איכא למימר דיששכר עדיף, אלא דזבולן מוקדם לברכה, וכן מוכח ממ"ש עתיד הקב"ה לעשות צל וחופות לבעלי המצות אצל בנו תורה וכו', ומי נתלה במי, הוי אומר הקטן נתלה בגדול, הרי דמעלת הת"ח עדיפא, אמנם כי כן ראוי להבין מ"ט הקדימו הכתוב להמחזיק, והקדמה זו מה טיבה ותועלתה.
translation: And now we will explain in another way, for behold, the sages did not say that the one who supports is greater in his merit than the Torah scholar, but rather that the scripture precedes the blessing for he is the cause of the Torah of Issachar, for without Zebulun, Issachar would not have been able to engage in Torah. However, it is true that the merit of the Torah scholar is greater than his merit, for the Torah scholars themselves have not seen sin, O God, except You, and the prophets did not grasp his strength and merit in the World to Come, as is explained in the verse. And it is explicitly stated thus in the Midrash, Parashat Kedoshim (25:1), Rabbi Huna and Rabbi Yirmiyah said in the name of Rabbi Chiya bar Abba that the Holy One, blessed be He, will make shade and canopies for those who perform commandments alongside the sons of Torah in the Garden of Eden, etc., as it is said, "For in the shade of wisdom is the shade of silver," etc. And similarly, Zebulun rejoices in your going out, and Issachar in your tents, and Issachar was not greater than Zebulun, but rather because Zebulun was engaged in commerce and occupied with trade, and he came and put into the mouth of Issachar, etc. Therefore, the verse is called by his name, as it is said, "Zebulun rejoices in your going out," meaning that the scripture precedes him, and so it is said in the Zohar that the scripture precedes Zebulun in their blessings. But regarding the merit and importance, one can say that Issachar is preferred, yet Zebulun is earlier in the blessing. And it is also evident from what is said that the Holy One, blessed be He, will make shade and canopies for those who perform commandments alongside the sons of Torah, etc. And who is dependent on whom? You would say the smaller is dependent on the greater; thus, the merit of the Torah scholar is superior. However, it is indeed appropriate to understand why the scripture precedes the supporter, and what is the nature and benefit of this precedence.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the Torah scholar (Talmid Chacham) and the supporter of Torah study (Zevulun), emphasizing that while Zevulun is honored for enabling Yissachar's Torah study, the intrinsic value and spiritual elevation of the Torah scholar surpass that of the supporter. It highlights that the Torah scholar's merit is recognized in the World to Come, and the text suggests that the support provided by Zevulun is essential, yet ultimately, the Torah scholar holds a greater status. The early mention of Zevulun in blessings serves to illustrate the importance of support in the pursuit of Torah, while still affirming the superior spiritual standing of the scholar.

passage_content:
והנ"ל בביאור הענין עפומ"ד בזוה"ק דהמחזיק ת"ח נוחל ב' עולמות ועליו נאמר הון ועושר בביתו בעוה"ז, וצדקתו עומדת לעד לבוא בשכרו לעוה"ב, והנה הת"ח עצמו העוסק בתורה אינו בא בשכרו מצד הדין בעוה"ז, דהרי שכר מצוה בהאי עלמא ליכא, וכל שכרו שמור לעוה"ב, משא"כ המחזיק ת"ח יקבל שכרו גם בעוה"ז, והוא עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בר"פ אלו דברים (פאה פ"א) וז"ל כשיעשה האדם המצות המיוחדות לנפשו, מה שיש בינו ובין בוראו, תחשב לו לצדקה ויגמלהו הקב"ה עלי' לעוה"ב, וכשיעשה האדם המצות התלויות בתועלת בנ"א זה עם זה, כמו"כ תחשב לו לצדקה לעוה"ב, ויקבל שכרו גם בעוה"ז, וכל המצות שבין אדם לחבירו נכנסות בגמ"ח עיוש"ד. והנה מעיקרא דדינא אין לו לת"ח העוסק בתורה כ"א שכר עוה"ב, ולהמחזיק אף שכר עוה"ז, אמנם לפי שנעשין שותפין כיששכר וזבולן, הרי העוסק בתורה מזכהו להמחזיק לזכות על ידו גם לשכר עוה"ב, וכמו"כ מגיע אף לת"ח 
העוסק בתורה שכר עוה"ז כמו שיקבל המחזיק, שהרי הם שותפין וחלק כחלק יאכלו, נמצא שע"י השותפות מגיע לכל א' חלקו בכפלים בעוה"ז ובעוה"ב, ולא ינוכה בשביל זה מחלק חבירו כלום, אלא כל אחד יקבל שכרו משלם וכמו"כ נותן הקב"ה לחבירו השותף כחלקו וכמידתו, ולא יחסר ולא יגרע מחלקו כלום. כו הבוי"ת יש לו די לשלם לכ"א.
translation: And the above is an explanation of the matter according to the words of the Zohar that one who supports a Torah scholar inherits two worlds, and of him it is said, "Wealth and riches are in his house" in this world, and "His righteousness endures forever" to come in the World to Come. Now, the Torah scholar himself who engages in Torah does not receive his reward according to the law in this world, for there is no reward for a mitzvah in this world, and all his reward is reserved for the World to Come. In contrast, the one who supports a Torah scholar will receive his reward also in this world. This is in accordance with what the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, says in the chapter "These are the things" (Peah 1:1), that when a person performs the mitzvot that are specific to himself, which are between him and his Creator, it is considered as charity for him, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will reward him for it in the World to Come. Likewise, when a person performs the mitzvot that are related to the benefit of others, it is also considered as charity for the World to Come, and he will receive his reward also in this world. All the mitzvot between a person and his fellow enter into the category of acts of kindness, as it is written. Now, initially, according to the law, the Torah scholar who engages in Torah has only the reward of the World to Come, while the supporter receives reward in this world as well. However, since they become partners like Issachar and Zebulun, the one who engages in Torah merits the supporter to also receive reward for him in the World to Come. Similarly, the Torah scholar who engages in Torah receives reward in this world just as the supporter does, for they are partners, and each will partake equally. Thus, through the partnership, each one receives his portion doubly in this world and in the World to Come, and nothing will be deducted from his fellow's portion at all. Rather, each one will receive his full reward, and likewise, the Holy One, blessed be He, gives to his fellow partner according to his portion and measure, and nothing will be lacking or diminished from his portion at all. Therefore, the one who supports has enough to pay each one.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that a Torah scholar (Talmid Chacham) who engages in study does not receive his reward in this world, as the reward for mitzvot is reserved for the World to Come. In contrast, one who supports a Torah scholar is rewarded in both this world and the next, akin to the partnership of Yissachar and Zevulun. This partnership allows the scholar to also benefit from the rewards of the supporter, creating a mutual sharing of spiritual and material blessings without diminishing each other's portions. Ultimately, both partners receive their full rewards, reflecting the divine justice and generosity of God.

passage_content: ויתכן לפי"ז דבשכר העוה"ז יוקדם המחזיק לבוא בשכרו, כי הוא הגורם ועל ידו זוכה אף העוסק מדין שותפות, וע"כ הקדימו הכתוב לברכה להיות הוא זוכה ואח"כ מזכה לחבירו השותף, משא"כ בשכר עוה"ב הת"ח מוקדם ועיקר, ועל ידו זוכה גם המחזיק כנ"ל, ומעתה סרו כל הסתירות הנ"ל, דמה שהקדים הכתוב שמח זבולן בצאתך ליששכר מיירי לענין שכר עוה"ז, ובזה זבולן מוקדם כנ"ל, וז"ש בזוה"ק דאקדים לי' בברכאן, היינו לענין שכר עוה"ז, ומ"ש חז"ל דת"ח עצמן עין לא ראתה וכו', הכוונה שם משכר עוה"ב דזהו בחי' עין לא ראתה ובזה מעלת הת"ח עדיפא מהמחזיק, והוא הזוכה תחלה ומזכה לחבירו עמו, ועד"ז יתיישבו כל המימרות חלוקות המובאים בדרז"ל בענין זה, ויש מקום לחלק ביניהם עד"ז, דכ"מ שהכוונה לשכר העולם הזה המחזיק מוקדם, וכשמיירו משכר העולם הבא העוסק מוקדם והכל לפי הענין.
translation: And it is possible according to this that for the reward of this world, the one who holds (the Torah) will be rewarded first, for he is the cause, and through him, even the one who engages (in Torah study) merits by the law of partnership. Therefore, the text precedes the blessing for him to be the one who merits, and afterwards, he merits his fellow partner. In contrast, regarding the reward of the World to Come, the Torah scholar is prioritized and is the main one, and through him, the holder also merits as mentioned above. From now on, all the aforementioned contradictions are resolved, for what the text precedes "Simcha" (joy) for Zebulun upon your going out to Issachar refers to the reward of this world, and in this, Zebulun is prioritized as mentioned. And this is what is said in the Zohar that "I will precede him in their blessings," meaning regarding the reward of this world. And what our Sages said that "no eye has seen" etc., refers to the reward of the World to Come, which is in the aspect of "no eye has seen," and in this, the merit of the Torah scholar is greater than that of the holder, for he is the one who merits first and also merits his fellow with him. Similarly, all the differing sayings brought in the Midrash regarding this matter can be reconciled, and there is room to distinguish between them in this way: wherever the intention is for the reward of this world, the holder is prioritized, and when it refers to the reward of the World to Come, the one who engages is prioritized, and all is according to the context.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between rewards in this world (Olam Hazeh) and the next (Olam Haba) within the context of partnership in Torah study. It emphasizes that while those who support Torah scholars (the "machzik") receive their reward first in this world, the scholars themselves (the "talmidei chachamim") are prioritized in the next world, highlighting their superior spiritual status. This reflects a broader theological insight that the nature of reward is contingent upon the context, with different principles applying to each realm. Ultimately, the text reconciles various teachings by clarifying that the timing of rewards is based on the specific focus of the discussion—whether it pertains to worldly or spiritual compensation.

passage_content: ולפי"ז אפרים הי' לו גם מכוחו וזכותו של מנשה, וכמו"כ למנשה הי' לו זכותו ושל אפרים כו ה"ה שותפין וחלק כחלק יאכלו וכ"א יש לו זכות המחזיק והעוסק וא"ש מאמר הכתוב בך יברך ישראל ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, ואף שהזכיר שניהם אפרים ומנשה, מ"מ יצדק לומר בך יברך ישראל בלשון יחיד, מפני שכ"א משותף בכח וזכות שניהם, ויתכן ברכה זו בכל אחד מהם, לאמר ישימך אלקים כאפרים וכמנשה, כי כ"א משותף בכח שניהם, וא"ש מאמה"כ ויקרא בהם שמי (עיין לעיל קושיא ח') והכוונה על אפרים כמ"ש בזוה"ק דכל בית ישראל יקראו אפרים, ואעפ"כ אמר הכתוב לשון רבים, לפי שכ"א משותף מכוחות שניהם אפרים ומנשה, ויתכן לומר ויקרא בהם על אפרים לבדו והבו.
translation: According to this, Ephraim also had the power and merit of Manasseh, and likewise, Manasseh had his merit and that of Ephraim. They are partners, and each one will partake equally, and each has the merit of holding and engaging. It is clear from the statement of the verse, "In you shall Israel bless," "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh." And even though both Ephraim and Manasseh are mentioned, it is still appropriate to say "In you shall Israel bless" in the singular form, because each one shares in the power and merit of both. This blessing can be said for each of them, to say "May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh," for each one shares in the power of both. It is also clear from the verse "And I will put My name upon them" (see above question 8), and the intention is regarding Ephraim, as it is stated in the Zohar that all of Israel will be called Ephraim. Nevertheless, the verse uses the plural form, because each one shares in the powers of both Ephraim and Manasseh. It is possible to say "And I will put My name upon them" regarding Ephraim alone, and so it is.
summary: The passage discusses the shared spiritual merits and strengths of Ephraim and Manasseh, emphasizing their partnership in blessings and divine favor. It highlights that each tribe possesses the combined virtues of both, allowing for individual blessings to be pronounced in the singular form, as they are united in their essence. The text also references the idea that all of Israel is collectively identified with Ephraim, yet acknowledges the duality of their contributions, reinforcing the concept of unity within diversity in the context of divine blessings.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בענין הנ"ל עפימ"ש הרמ"א ז"ל (ביור"ד סי' רמ"ו ס"א) בש"ר ירוחם וז"ל יכול אדם להתנות עם חבירו שהוא יעסוק בתורה, וחבירו ימציא לו פרנסתו ויחלוק עמו בשכר. אבל אם כבר עסק בתורה אינו יכול למכור לו חלקו בשביל ממון שיתן לו עכ"ל. וציין מקורו מש"ס סוטה (דף כ"א ע"א) אם יתן איש את כל הון ביתו באהבה בוז יבוזו לו, אמר עולא לא כשמעון אחי עזריה ולא כר' יוחנן דבי נשיאה, אלא כהלל ושבנא וכו' הלל ושבנא אחי הוו, הלל עסק בתורה, שבנא עבד עיסקא, לסוף א"ל תא נערוב וליפלוג, יצתה ב"ק ואמר אם יתן איש את כל הון ביתו וגו', ופרש"י דשמעון למד תורה ע"ו שהי' עזרי' מפרנסו לכך הוא נקרא ע"ש עזרי' אחיו, וכן ר' יוחנן למד ע"ו הנשיא שהי' מפרנסו, אבל הלל עסק בתורה מתוך עוני רב, ואח"כ רצה שבנא אחיו לשתף עמו בשכר תורתו שכבר למד וזה א"א עכת"ד. ומהר"ם אלשקר בשם רב האי גאון כתב טעמו, משום דכ"א מגיע בשכרו לפי מעשיו, וא"א למכור מעשיו לאחרים, עייש"ד.
translation: And even further on the matter mentioned above, according to what the Rema, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in Yoreh De'ah, Siman 256, Se'if 1) in the name of Rabbi Yerucham, and it is written: A person can make a condition with his friend that he will engage in Torah, and his friend will provide for his livelihood and they will share in the reward. But if he has already engaged in Torah, he cannot sell his portion for money that he will receive. Thus far the text. And he cited his source from the Talmud Sotah (21a): If a man gives all the wealth of his house in love, he will be despised. Ula said: Not like Shimon, the brother of Azariah, nor like Rabbi Yochanan, the son of the Nasi, but like Hillel and Shabna, etc. Hillel engaged in Torah, Shabna worked in business. Eventually, he said to him: Let us partner and divide, and the Mishnah came out and said: If a man gives all the wealth of his house, etc. Rashi explained that Shimon learned Torah on account of the fact that Azariah supported him, therefore he is called after Azariah, his brother. Similarly, Rabbi Yochanan learned on account of the Nasi who supported him, but Hillel engaged in Torah out of great poverty, and afterwards Shabna, his brother, wanted to share with him in the reward of the Torah he had already learned, and this is impossible. Thus far the text. And the Maharam Alshakar, in the name of Rabbi Hai Gaon, wrote his reason, because each person receives his reward according to his deeds, and it is impossible to sell one's deeds to others. Thus is the explanation.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of dedicating oneself to Torah study while relying on others for sustenance, highlighting the distinction between those who study Torah for its own sake and those who do so for financial gain. It emphasizes that one cannot sell their share of Torah study for monetary compensation, as true spiritual reward is based on individual merit and actions. The examples of Hillel and Shabna illustrate the ideal of studying Torah amidst poverty, contrasting with those who rely on others for their livelihood while learning. Ultimately, the text underscores the intrinsic value of Torah study and the personal responsibility for one's spiritual and material pursuits.

passage_content: ומה שיכול להתנות מעיקרא בתנאי קודם למעשה, משום דבכה"ג לא מיחשב כמכירה כל רק שע"י שמחזיק ביד חבירו להמציא לו פרנסתו כדי שיוכל לעסוק בתורה באין מפריע, ה"ה מסייעהו לעסוק בתורה, וכיון שמסייע בידו יש לו חלק בתורתו כדין שותף, משא"כ לאחריו מה דהוה הוה, וא"א לסייע עוד בדבר שכבר נעשה, ע"כ א"א להשתתף אחר שנגמר העסק והשכר כבר מוכן, ואין זה אלא מדין מכירה, ולא יועיל המכירה לא למוכר ולא להקונה, כו הקונה לא ירוויח ולא יקבל מחלק חבירו כלום, והמוכר נראה כמזלזל במצות יעיי"ש בפוסקים. נמצא לפי"ז דלא יצוייר השותפות רק אם זבולן המחזיק יקדים מעשיו בהחזקת העוסק, לפני תורתו של יששכר, דאח"כ לא יזכה עוד בחלק השותפות, וע"כ מידה כנגד מידה ראוי שיוקדם זבולן בשכרו לפני יששכר, על כי גם מעשיו קדמו, וא"ש אף דמעלת העוסק עדיפא, כמ"ש חז"ל דת"ח עצמן עין לא ראתה וגו', מ"מ הקדימו הכתוב לזבולן בברכאן כמ"ש בזוה"ק ובמד"ר הנ"ל, והיינו טעמא לפי שמעשיו קדמו ע"כ ראוי שיוקדם ג"כ שכרו.
translation: And what can be conditioned from the outset with a condition prior to the action, because in such a case it is not considered a sale, only that by holding onto his friend's property to provide for him so that he can engage in Torah without interruption, he is assisting him in engaging in Torah. And since he is assisting him, he has a share in his Torah like a partner, whereas afterwards, what has been has been, and it is impossible to assist in something that has already been done. Therefore, it is impossible to participate after the business has been completed and the payment is already prepared, and this is only by the law of sale, and the sale will not benefit either the seller or the buyer; the buyer will not profit nor receive anything from his friend's share, and the seller appears to be belittling the commandments, as seen in the decisors. Thus, according to this, partnership can only be conceived if Zebulun, who holds, precedes his actions in supporting the one who engages, before the Torah of Issachar, for afterwards he will no longer merit a share in the partnership. Therefore, measure for measure, it is fitting that Zebulun should receive his reward before Issachar, because his actions also preceded. And this is understood even though the merit of the one who engages is greater, as our Sages said that no eye has seen the Torah scholars, etc. Nevertheless, the Scripture precedes Zebulun in their blessings, as stated in the Zohar and in the Midrash mentioned above, and the reason is that since his actions preceded, it is fitting that his reward should also be prioritized.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of partnership in the context of Torah study, emphasizing that a supporter (Zevulun) must act before the scholar (Yissachar) to establish a valid partnership. It highlights that the support provided enables the scholar to engage in Torah without interruption, granting the supporter a share in the scholar's merit. The text underscores the principle of "measure for measure," where the timing of actions influences the distribution of rewards, indicating that even though the scholar's role is superior, the supporter is prioritized in receiving blessings due to their proactive involvement.

passage_content: והנה יש עוד בחי' למעלה ממנו בהחזקת התורה, עפימ"ש ז"ל בגמ' סנהדרין (דף י"ט ע"ב) כל המגדל יתום בתוך ביתו מעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו ילדו וכו' ר"א אמר מהכא דכתיב (תהלים ע"ז) גאלת בזרוע עמך בני יעקב ויוסף סלה, וכי יוסף ילד והלא יעקב ילד, אלא יעקב ילד ויוסף כילכל, לפיכך נקראו על שמו עכ"ד הגמ', ולפי"ז המפרנס ללומדי תורה, לא רק שהוא בא בשכרו בעוה"ז ובעוה"ב חלק כחלק עם העוסק בתורה, אלא גם נקרא הת"ח על שמו כאילו ילדו
translation: And behold, there is another aspect above this in the support of the Torah, as our sages of blessed memory said in the Gemara Sanhedrin (19b), "Anyone who raises an orphan in his home, the Scripture considers it as if he gave birth to him," etc. Rabbi Eliezer said from here, as it is written (Psalms 77), "You redeemed with Your strong arm, the children of Jacob and Joseph, Selah." And did Joseph give birth? Was it not Jacob who gave birth? Rather, Jacob gave birth and Joseph provided sustenance. Therefore, they are called by his name, thus concludes the Gemara. According to this, one who supports the Torah scholars, not only does he receive his reward in this world and in the World to Come, equally with one who engages in the Torah, but he is also called a Torah scholar by his name, as if he gave birth to him.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound spiritual merit of supporting Torah scholars, equating this act to the significance of raising a child. It cites a Talmudic teaching that highlights the connection between nurturing and spiritual lineage, illustrating that just as Jacob is credited with Joseph's sustenance, so too is a benefactor recognized as a spiritual parent to those they support. This underscores the idea that both the supporter and the scholar share equal reward in the World to Come, reinforcing the communal responsibility in the preservation and transmission of Torah.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו הפסוקים ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם לך יהיו וגו' (עיין לעיל קושיא א' וב') וא"צ לדחוק ולומר שהוא מאמר מסופק, דלא מצינו שהוליד יוסף תולדות עוד ולא זכרם הכתוב בשום מקום (כקושיתנו לעיל) אמנם לדרכנו יתפרש כוונת הכתוב ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם על הכלל ישראל, שכולם יקראו על שמך כאילו ילדתם, ולז"א שלך יהיו' ר"ל בענין הזכות הם שלך ונקראו על שמך, וע"ד מ"ש בספה"ק סידורו ש"ש לפרש הכתוב ואיש את קדשיו לו יהי', דמה שעושין לתיקון הנשמה נקרא שלו לחלקו וגורלו, משא"כ לצורך הגוף כי קנין שלו אינו שלו יעיי"ש. וז"ש לך יהיו כי ה"ה שלך בענין הזכות ויקראו כולם על שמך, אבל בענין הנחלה על שם אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם ויתחלקו לי"ב שבטים, דלגבי יוסף כל ישראל נקראו בניו וא"כ ה"ה אחיהם של אפרים ומנשה, וז"ש ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם לענין הנחלה, אבל לענין הזכות בזה ובבא, לך יהיו ויקראו על שמך, נמצא דמאמר ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריך נתקיים נבואתו ואצ"ל שהוליד עוד בנים ולא זכרם הכתוב, אבל הכוונה על הכלל ישראל שכלכלם יוסף ונחשב לו כאילו ילדם.
translation: And this will clarify the verses, "And your offspring that you will bear after them shall be yours" (see above question 1 and 2), and there is no need to forcefully say that it is a doubtful statement, for we do not find that Joseph fathered any more descendants, and the scripture does not mention them anywhere (as per our question above). However, according to our approach, the intent of the verse "and your offspring that you will bear after them" refers to the entire Jewish people, who are all called by your name as if you had given birth to them. Therefore, it says "shall be yours," meaning in terms of merit, they are yours and are called by your name. This is in line with what is stated in the holy books, in the order of the Shabbat, to explain the verse "and a man shall have his holy things to him," for what is done for the rectification of the soul is called his, for his portion and his lot, whereas for the needs of the body, his acquisition is not truly his, as you can see there. Thus, it says "shall be yours," for they are indeed yours in terms of merit and all will be called by your name. But in terms of inheritance, they will be called by the name of their brothers in their inheritance and will be divided among the twelve tribes, for regarding Joseph, all of Israel are called his sons, and thus they are the brothers of Ephraim and Manasseh. Therefore, it says "by the name of their brothers they will be called in their inheritance" concerning the inheritance, but in terms of merit, in this world and the next, "shall be yours" and they will be called by your name. It turns out that the statement "and your offspring that you will bear after them" fulfills his prophecy, and it is unnecessary to say that he fathered more sons and the scripture did not mention them, but the intent is regarding the entire Jewish people, whom Joseph sustains, and it is considered as if he had given birth to them.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of the biblical verse regarding Joseph's descendants, emphasizing that all of Israel is considered as his children, thus attributing to him a collective spiritual legacy. It highlights the concept that the merits and spiritual achievements of the Jewish people are credited to Joseph, while their physical inheritance is divided among the tribes. This duality illustrates the distinction between spiritual lineage, which is linked to Joseph, and the material inheritance, which is allocated according to tribal affiliation. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that Joseph's role encompasses the nurturing and sustenance of the entire nation, making him a spiritual father to all of Israel.

passage_content: ויתורץ לדרכנו קישור הסמיכות ואני בבאי מפדן עיין לעיל קושיא ג') דלכאורה לא יספיק ההתנצלות הזה ליוסף, דעל כן נקברה אמו רחל בדרך בית לחם. שתהא לעזרה לבני' כשיגלה אותם נבוזראדן, והיה עדיין מקום ליוסף להרהר דמדוע נבחרה אמו לכך. וכמו כן היה אפשר להיות העזרה והתפלה ע"י לאה או א' מהאמהות שיבקשו עליהם רחמים, אבל אחר שא"ל יעקב ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם לך יהיו, שכל ישראל יקראו ע"ש יוסף כאילו ילדם, א"כ כל ישראל נחשבים לבניה של רחל, וא"ש דרחל נבחרה לכך שתהי' נכנסת בעובי הקורה יותר לאפושי ברחמין, וא"ש דכאן מקומה של התנצלות הזאת (עיין בדברנו פ' מקץ בביאור יותר).
translation: And it will be explained according to our path the connection of the proximity, and I, in my coming from Padan, refer to the above question (3) that seemingly this excuse is not sufficient for Yosef, for that is why his mother Rachel was buried on the way to Bethlehem. That she should be a help to her children when Nebuzaradan will reveal them, and there was still room for Yosef to ponder why his mother was chosen for this. And likewise, it could have been the help and prayer through Leah or one of the matriarchs who would plead for them for mercy, but after Jacob told him, "And your birthplace, which you were born after them, shall be for you," that all of Israel would be called by the name of Yosef as if he had given birth to them, therefore all of Israel are considered the children of Rachel. And it is understood that Rachel was chosen for this, to be more deeply involved in the essence of mercy, and it is understood that here is the place of this excuse (refer to our discussion in Parashat Miketz for a more detailed explanation).
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Rachel's burial near Bethlehem, emphasizing her role as a spiritual intercessor for the Jewish people during their exile. It highlights the idea that all of Israel is considered as her children, as Jacob declared that Joseph's lineage would carry her name. This connection underscores Rachel's unique position in the divine plan, allowing her to plead for mercy on behalf of her descendants. The text reflects on the deeper theological implications of maternal influence and the enduring bond between the matriarchs and their offspring.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר במאמה"כ ועיני ישראל כבדו מזוקן וגו', ובמה שדרשו רז"ל (יומא כ"ח) יעקב אבינו זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' שנא' ועיני ישראל כבדו מזוקן, ולכאורה לפי דרשתם איך יתבאר קישור הכתוב כבדו מזוקן לא יוכל לראות (עיין לעיל קושיא ו') ואפ"ל בדרך רמז לעניננו דליכא מידי דלא רמיזא באורייתא, דהנה אמרו ז"ל אברהם זקן ויושב בישיבה הי' וכן יצחק וכן יעקב. אמנם הבדל גדול הי' בין ישיבתו של יע"א לישיבתו של אברהם ויצחק, כי בימי אאע"ה עדיין לא היו זרע ישראל בעולם, ולמד תורה עם הנפש אשר עשו בחרן אלו הגרים שגיירם, וכן יצחק גייר גרים ולמד עמהם תורה, ומכל אלו לא נשאר אף א' להיות נכללים באומה הישראלית, כי כאשר ירד יע"א למצרים ירדו עמו ע' נפש כולם יוצאי יריכו בלבד, בניו וב"ב כאשר העיד הכתוב, וכל אלו הגרים נאבדו או חזרו ונטמעו באומות, ונתגיירו רק לפי שעה שהי' צורך בדבר כמבואר בדרז"ל, אמנם ביעקב אבינו אמרו רז"ל לא נסתלק יע"א עד שראה ס' רבוא מבניו, כולם זרע ישר ראל שורש נשמות של כל דורות ישראל, ומאלו נמשך ההשתלשלות של דור מקבלי התורה וכל דורות ישראל עד עולם, ועמהם למד יעקב אבינו תורה, נמצא הי' לו ישיבה גדולה של ס"ר ישראל, והוא עבודה גדולה וכבידה להשגיח בעינא פקיחא על ריבוי עם כזה, ולהמשיך להם ידיעת התורה ומסורת האבות וקדושה וטהרה שתמשך לדורי דורות עד עולם, וז"ש ועיני ישראל כבדו, וע"ד שאמה"כ ואברהם כבד מאוד במקנה בכסף ובזהב, ואף שזכה לזה ע"צ הברכה שברכו ד' ואברכך בממון, מ"מ להפלגת הרבוי הי' כבד עליו משאו והוצרך לילך לאט למסעיו, ועד"ז יתפרש כאן אועיני' ישראל כבדו, שהשגחתו ועיונו של יעקב אבינו כבד עליו, ולעבודה גדולה נהייתה לו להדריך ישיבה גדולה כזו ולהשגיח עליהם בעינא פקיחא, אמזוקן" לסיבת היותו זקן ויושב בישיבה גדולה של ס"ר שורש נשמות של כל הדורות.
translation: And we will explain the verse, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy with age," and regarding what our Sages of blessed memory have said (Yoma 28) that our forefather Jacob was old and sitting in the study hall, as it is stated, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy with age." At first glance, according to their interpretation, how can the connection of the verse "heavy with age" be understood as he could not see (see above question 6)? And it can be said in a hint regarding our matter that there is nothing that is not hinted at in the Torah. Behold, our Sages said that Abraham was old and sitting in the study hall, and so was Isaac, and so was Jacob. However, there was a great difference between the sitting of Jacob and the sitting of Abraham and Isaac, for in the days of our forefather Abraham, the seed of Israel was not yet in the world, and he learned Torah with the souls he made in Haran, those converts he converted. Likewise, Isaac converted converts and learned Torah with them, and from all these, not one remained to be included in the Israelite nation, for when Jacob descended to Egypt, he descended with seventy souls, all of them his direct descendants, as the scripture testified. And all those converts were lost or returned and were absorbed into the nations, and they converted only temporarily when there was a need for it, as explained by our Sages. However, concerning our forefather Jacob, our Sages said that he did not depart until he saw six hundred thousand of his children, all of them the seed of Israel, the root of the souls of all the generations of Israel, and from these the chain of generations of the Torah recipients and all generations of Israel until the end of time continued. And with them, our forefather Jacob learned Torah, thus he had a great study hall of six hundred thousand Israelites, and it was a great and heavy task for him to watch over such a multitude with a keen eye, to impart to them the knowledge of the Torah and the tradition of the fathers and holiness and purity that would continue for generations until the end of time. Therefore, it is said, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy," and in the same way that it is written, "And Abraham was very heavy in cattle, in silver, and in gold," and even though he merited this through the blessing that God blessed him, "And I will bless you with wealth," nevertheless, the burden of the abundance was heavy upon him, and he needed to go slowly on his journeys. Similarly, it can be explained here, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy," that the watchfulness and attention of our forefather Jacob was heavy upon him, and it became a great task for him to guide such a great study hall and to watch over them with a keen eye, "because of his being old" due to being an elder and sitting in a great study hall of six hundred thousand root souls of all the generations.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's old age and his role as a teacher of Torah to the numerous descendants of Israel, emphasizing that unlike Abraham and Isaac, who taught converts without establishing a lasting lineage, Jacob witnessed the emergence of a substantial and enduring Jewish nation. It highlights the weighty responsibility Jacob bore in guiding and nurturing this large community, which is symbolized by the phrase "עיני ישראל כבדו" (the eyes of Israel were heavy), indicating the profound spiritual and educational burden he carried. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the continuity of Jewish tradition and the importance of leadership in transmitting holiness and knowledge through generations. Ultimately, Jacob's legacy is portrayed as foundational for the Jewish people, ensuring the transmission of Torah and values throughout history.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד לפרש מאמה"כ ובפ' ויגש) ויאמר אלקים לישראל במראות הלילה וגו' אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה ואנכי אעלך גם עלה ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך, ולפי פשוטו הבטיחו הקב"ה שלא יצטרך להיות מוטרד בהשגת פרנסתו וצרכי ביתו, אבל יוסף ישגיח עליהם להמציא להם כל צרכם, כך פי' המפרשים עפ"י פשוטו, אולם לפי"ז צ"ב הלשון ישית ידו על שעיניך' הול"ל על עניניך או על פרנסתך וצרכך, ולמה דוקא על עיניך. ועוד דרשו ז"ל שיש בזה הבעחה על הקבורה יעיי"ש, אמנם לפי פשוטו צ"ב, וע"ד הרמז הבטיחו הבוי"ת אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, ותזכה לראות ס"ר מבניך כאמרם ז"ל לא נסתלק יעקב אבינו עד שראה ס' רבוא מבניו, ומאלו ימשך הגוי גדול אשר זכו למתן תורה שנא' ומי גוי גדול וגו', וכל דורות ישראל ישתלשלו מאלו הנשמות שהדריך יע"א והשתיל בהם תורה ויראה ומסורת האבות, ולז"א ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, שעלי' גדולה יהי' לך על ידן, ובמד"ר דרשו רז"ל גם עלה אותך ואת כל הצדיקים כיוצא בך, שהעלם יע"א לבחי' עין לא ראתה ע"י שלמד עמהם תורה, כאמרז"ל דת"ח עצמן עין לא ראתה אלקים זולתך, והנה הי' מקום ליע"א לידאג כי יהי' כבד עליו המשא להשגיח על ריבוי עם כזה חוץ מעניני הרוחניות להשתיל בהם תורה ויראה קדושה וטהרה, נוסף לזה במצב הכלכלה לפרנסתם ולהזמין להם כל צרכיהם שיוכלו לעסוק בתורה, ע"כ הבטיחו הקב"ה ויוסף ישית שידו' על עיניך, ידו רומז על החזקת הפרנסה מלשון פתח תפתח את ידך, שיוסף יכלכל את כל בית ישראל, ואתה תשים עיניך ועיונך על השפעת הרוחני, וז"ש ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך, שבמקום שאתה תשים עינך להשגיח בעניני הרוחני. הוא ישית ידו לפרנסם ולהקל עולך מעליך, ואף זו בלבד היתה כבד על יע"א, וז"ש ועיני ישראל כבדו מזוקן כנ"ל, לא יוכל לראות, לצד שהעלה אותם לבחי' לא יוכל לראות, היינו עין לא ראתה ואף עין הנביאים לא השיגו בחינתה, וזו משא גדולה וכבידה לרבוי עם עצום כזה.
translation: And we will further explain from the Holy Scriptures, in Parashat Vayigash: "And God said to Israel in visions of the night, 'Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you a great nation there. I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also surely bring you up again, and Joseph will place his hand on your eyes.'" According to the simple meaning, the Holy One, Blessed be He, assured him that he would not need to be troubled about obtaining his livelihood and the needs of his household, but rather Joseph would oversee them to provide for all their needs. This is how the commentators explain according to the simple meaning. However, according to this, the wording "he will place his hand on your eyes" is puzzling; it should have said "on your matters" or "on your livelihood and needs," and why specifically "on your eyes"? Furthermore, our sages have interpreted that this hints at burial, as mentioned there. Nevertheless, according to the simple meaning, this is puzzling. And according to the hint, the Holy One, Blessed be He, assured him, "Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you a great nation there," and you will merit to see sixty myriads of your children, as our sages said, "Jacob our father did not depart until he saw sixty myriads of his children," and from these will emerge the great nation that merited the giving of the Torah, as it is said, "And what great nation is there..." and all the generations of Israel will stem from these souls that Jacob guided and instilled in them Torah, fear, and the tradition of the fathers. Therefore, it says, "And I will also bring you up," that a great ascent will be for you through them. And in the Midrash, our sages interpreted that "He will also bring you up" refers to you and all the righteous ones like you, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will elevate them to a level that "no eye has seen" through the learning of Torah with them, as our sages said, "The eyes of the righteous have not seen God besides You." And indeed, there was a reason for Jacob to be concerned that the burden of overseeing such a multitude would be heavy upon him, aside from the spiritual matters of instilling in them Torah, fear, holiness, and purity. In addition to this, in the economic situation, to provide for them and supply all their needs so that they could engage in Torah. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, assured him, "And Joseph will place his hand on your eyes," his hand alludes to the sustenance, as in the phrase "You shall surely open your hand," that Joseph will sustain all the house of Israel, and you will set your eyes and your focus on the spiritual influence. This is what is meant by "And Joseph will place his hand on your eyes," that in the place where you will set your eyes to oversee spiritual matters, he will place his hand to provide for them and lighten your burden. And even this alone was heavy upon Jacob, as it says, "And the eyes of Israel were heavy with age," he could not see, because he elevated them to a level that he could not see, meaning "no eye has seen," and even the eyes of the prophets did not grasp its essence, and this is a great and heavy burden for such a vast multitude.
summary: In this passage, the author explores the divine assurance given to Jacob that he need not fear descending to Egypt, as God will accompany him and ensure his family's needs are met through Joseph's oversight. The phrase "Joseph will place his hand upon your eyes" signifies that while Jacob focuses on spiritual matters, Joseph will handle their material needs, alleviating Jacob's burdens. The text emphasizes the continuity of the Jewish people and their spiritual legacy, highlighting the importance of Torah and tradition passed down through generations. Ultimately, it reflects the profound relationship between divine providence and the responsibilities of leadership within the Jewish community.

passage_content: ויל"פ בזה מאמה"כ המלאך הגואל אותי מכל יברך את הנערים (עיין לעיל קושיא ז'), בהקדם מאמר הנביא (הושע י"א א') כי נער ישראל ואהבהו וממצרים קראתי לבני, וראוי להבין למה נקראו ישראל נער ומדוע במצרים דוקא, אמנם לפי שראשית ושורש התקרבותן של ישראל להקב"ה הי' בצאתם ממצרים, ע"כ נקראו בחינתם של אז ע"ד השאלה נער, כמו שימי הנערות הם יסוד ושורש כל ימי הבנין, והוא שאמר הכתוב (ירמי' ב') זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך וגו' לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, והקב"ה זוכר לישראל זכות הזאת עד סוף כל הדורות כמבואר בדרז"ל, והכח של זה החסד נעוריך, נמשך להם מיוסף הצדיק שעל ידו ובזכותו נתקיימו בקדושתם, כמ"ש ז"ל במדרש בזכות יוסף שעמד בנסיון נגדרו כל ישראל בעריות, ועי"ז בנ"י עאלו ובנ"י נפקו, וגם בגשמיות נתקיימו על ידו שכלכלם ופרנסם והחזיק בישיבתו של יע"א ס"ר שורש נשמות ישראל כנ"ל, נמצא שהחסד נעורים של ישראל נמשך מיוסף הצדיק ובניו. שהוא השורש להתקרבותן של ישראל להקב"ה, והנה כשבירך יע"א את יוסף התכוין בברכתו גם לכל ישראל, שהם נקראים כולם בני יוסף כמשה"כ בני יעקב ויוסף, ע"ש שכלכלם יוסף נחשב לו כאילו ילדם כנ"ל וז"ש יברך את הנערים, שיזכר לעולם חסד נעורים זה שנמשך מיוסף הצדיק ובניו. וכל ישראל יוושעו בזכותן, והן עצמן לא כ"ש, כמ"ש בגמ' סנהדרין (ק"י ע"ב) לגבי דור המדבר אם אחרים באין בזכותן הן עצמן לא כ"ש עיי"ש, וה"ז ברכה פרטית לבני יוסף וכללית לכל ישראל והבן.
translation: And it is explained here from our holy teacher, the angel who redeemed me from all, bless the youths (see above question 7), by prefacing the saying of the prophet (Hosea 11:1) "When Israel was a youth, I loved him, and from Egypt I called My son." It is fitting to understand why Israel is called a youth and why specifically in Egypt. Indeed, since the beginning and root of Israel's closeness to the Holy One, Blessed be He, was at the time of their exodus from Egypt, therefore they were referred to in that state as a youth, just as the days of youth are the foundation and root of all the days of building. This is what the verse says (Jeremiah 2:2) "I remember for you the kindness of your youth... to follow you in the wilderness, in a land not sown." And the Holy One, Blessed be He, remembers this merit of Israel until the end of all generations, as explained in the teachings of our sages. The power of this kindness of your youth is drawn from Joseph the Righteous, through whom and by his merit they were sustained in their holiness, as our sages said in the Midrash, "By the merit of Joseph who stood in temptation, all of Israel were safeguarded from immorality." And thus the children of Israel entered and the children of Israel exited, and also in physical sustenance they were sustained by him, as he provided for them and supported the seat of the Holy One, Blessed be He, the root of the souls of Israel, as mentioned above. It follows that the kindness of the youth of Israel is drawn from Joseph the Righteous and his sons, who are the root of Israel's closeness to the Holy One, Blessed be He. And behold, when the Holy One, Blessed be He, blessed Joseph, He intended in His blessing also for all of Israel, who are all called the sons of Joseph, as it is written "the sons of Jacob and Joseph," because since Joseph provided for them, he is considered as if he had given birth to them, as mentioned above. And this is what is meant by "He will bless the youths," that he should remember forever this kindness of youth that is drawn from Joseph the Righteous and his sons. And all of Israel will be saved by their merit, and they themselves, how much more so, as it is said in the Gemara Sanhedrin (K.Y. 72b) regarding the generation of the wilderness, if others come by their merit, they themselves, how much more so, see there. And this is a specific blessing for the sons of Joseph and a general blessing for all of Israel, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the term "נער" (youth) in relation to the Israelites, emphasizing that their initial closeness to God began with their exodus from Egypt. This connection is rooted in the "חסד נעוריך" (the kindness of youth) that God remembers throughout generations, particularly linked to the merit of Joseph, who upheld the sanctity of Israel. The blessing given to Joseph is seen as encompassing all of Israel, as they are all considered his children due to his sustenance and protection. Thus, the text highlights the enduring impact of Joseph's righteousness on the collective fate of the Jewish people.

passage_content: תמצית הדברים כל המסייע להחזקת התורה ולקיים מוסדות חינוך על טהרת הקודש וע"ד ישראל סבא. שאנו מקווים שיצא מהם זרע בירך ודורות ישרים. חוץ ממה שביררנו לעיל שנעשה שותף ומקבל שכרו בעוה"ז ובעוה"ב, ויוקדם בשכרו לפני העוסק, נוסף לזה יש לו חלק בהלידה להיות נקרא על שמו כאילו ילדם, והרי הוא נעשה ליסוד ושורש כל הבנין, ומי לא ירצה לזכות בכל אלה. והשי"ת יעזור לכל המסייעין שיתקיים בהם ברכת יע"א בך יברך ישראל כאפרים וכמנשה, ויגיע להם כח וזכות שניהם כנ"ל ויהי' לנח"ר ולרצון להשי"ת ויתרבה גבול הקדושה וכ"ש בעולם, ונזכה לקבל פני משיח צדקינו בנחת ובשמחה ולראות בישועת ישראל ושמחתן בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: The essence of the matter is that all who assist in the strengthening of the Torah and in establishing educational institutions on the purity of holiness and in the manner of Israel our forefather, we hope that from them will come forth a blessed seed and righteous generations. Besides what we clarified above, that he becomes a partner and receives his reward in this world and in the World to Come, and he will be advanced in his reward before the one who is engaged, in addition to this, he has a share in the birth to be called by his name as if he had given birth to them, and thus he becomes the foundation and root of the entire building, and who would not want to merit all of this. And may the Holy One, Blessed be He, help all those who assist that the blessing of "May He bless you, Israel, like Ephraim and Manasseh" be fulfilled in them, and may they receive the strength and merit of both as mentioned, and may it be for the pleasure and will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and may the boundaries of holiness increase, and certainly in the world, and may we merit to greet the face of our righteous Messiah with ease and joy, and to see the salvation of Israel and their joy in the uplifting of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, may it be soon.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of supporting Torah study and maintaining holy educational institutions, rooted in the teachings of Israel Saba. It highlights the spiritual rewards for those who assist in these endeavors, including a share in the merit of future generations and a connection to the divine as if they had given birth to them. The text expresses a hope for divine assistance in these efforts, invoking blessings for the community and a desire for the coming of the Messiah, along with the ultimate redemption of Israel and the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: אי ויקח יוסף את שניהם את אפרים בימינו משמאל ישראל ואת מנשה בשמאלו מימין ישראל וגו', וישלח ישראל את ימינו וישת על ראש אפרים והוא הצעיר וגו' שיכל את ידיו כי מנשה הבכור, ויאמר יוסף לא כן אבי כי זה הבכור שים ימינך על ראשו, וימאן אביו ויאמר ידעתי בני ידעתי וגו' ואולם אחיו הקטן יגדל ממנו וזרעו יהי' מלא הגוים, פרש"י שעתיד יהושע לצאת ממנו שינחיל את הארץ וילמד תורה לישראל, ראוי להבין למה האריך הכתוב לבאר בכמה פסוקים בטענות ההתוכחות שבין יעאע"ה ויוסף, ובודאי לא דבר ריק הוא, גם לא יתכן לחשוב שיוסף הצדיק טעה ח"ו, ובלי ספק דברי שניהם תורה שלימה הוא וצ"ב הכוונה.
translation: And Joseph took both of them, Ephraim in his right hand to the left of Israel, and Manasseh in his left hand to the right of Israel, etc. And Israel stretched out his right hand and laid it on the head of Ephraim, who was the younger, etc., and he crossed his hands, for Manasseh was the firstborn. And Joseph said to his father, "Not so, my father, for this one is the firstborn; place your right hand on his head." And his father refused and said, "I know, my son, I know," etc. "However, his younger brother will be greater than he, and his seed will be full of the nations." Rashi explains that Joshua will come forth from him, who will inherit the land and teach Torah to Israel. It is fitting to understand why the text elaborates in several verses on the arguments and rebukes between Yaakov Avinu and Joseph, and certainly it is not an empty matter. It is also not conceivable to think that the righteous Joseph erred, Heaven forbid, and without a doubt, the words of both are complete Torah, and the intention remains to be clarified.
summary: In this passage, the tension between Jacob and Joseph regarding the blessing of Ephraim and Manasseh highlights the significance of divine providence and the unexpected elevation of the younger over the elder. Jacob's insistence on placing his right hand on Ephraim symbolizes the idea that spiritual potential and leadership can arise from unexpected sources. The reference to Joshua, who will lead Israel and teach Torah, underscores the theme of divine selection and the fulfillment of God's plans through seemingly paradoxical choices. This narrative invites reflection on the deeper wisdom within the apparent conflict between Jacob and Joseph, suggesting that both perspectives hold profound truth.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הגמ' (יומא נ"ג ע"ב) המתפלל צריך שופסוע ג' פסיעות לאחוריו ואח"כ יתן שלום וכו', משום ר' שמעי' אמרו שנותן שלו' לימין ואח"כ לשמאל שנא' מימינו אש דת למו וכו', רבא חזייא לאביי דיהיב שלמא לימיני' ברישא, א"ל מו סברת לימין דידך ולשמאל דידך, לשמאל דידך שהוא ימינו של הקב"ה, פרש"י שהמתפלל רואה עצמו כאילו השכינה למול פניו שנא' שויתי ד' לנגדי תמיד עכ"ל. ובטור או"ח (סי' צ"ז) כתב בשם הירושלמי הנזדמן לו רוק בתפלתו ואינו יכול להבליעו בכסותו זורקו לאחוריו או לשמאלו, אבל לא לפניו ולא לימינו, וכתב ב"ו רבינו הגדול מהר"י אבוהב כתב מדברי רבינו הטור משמע דימין ושמאל דידי' קאמר, והוקשה לו מאי שנא מדין ג' פסיעות שחולק כבוד יותר לשמאלו, מפני שהוא ימין דשכינה, והניח הדבר בצ"ע. ובדרכי משה תירץ כו מאחר שאסור לרוק בתפלתו אם לא לאסטניס, לא רצו להורות ברקיקה שהשכינה נגדו, כו אדרבה עזו רקיקתו שכינה מסתלקת ממנו, ולכן ירוק לשמאלו כי אין השם לנגד עיניו, אבל כשפוסע לאחוריו ג' פסיעות כתלמיד הנפטר מרבו, א"כ משים השכינה לנגד עיניו ולכן חולק כבוד לשמאלו לימין השכינה שהיא לנגדו עכ"ל, נמצא לפי"ז דענין ימין ושמאל תליא לפי בחינתו, דכשמשים השכינה לנגדו צריך שיחלוק כבוד לשמאלו ולהקדימו ברישא שהוא ימינו של הקב"ה, וח"ו כשהשכינה מסתלקת ממנו אז צריך לחלוק כבוד לימין דהוא עדיפא וכמ"ש ברקיקה כנ"ל.
translation:
And it will be explained in advance the words of the Gemara (Yoma 53b) that a person praying needs to take three steps back and then give peace, etc., because Rabbi Shmuel said that he gives peace to the right and then to the left, as it is said, "From His right came a fire of law for them," etc. Rava saw Abaye that he gave peace to his right first. He said to him, "What is your reasoning for your right and your left? Your left is the right of the Holy One, Blessed be He." Rashi explains that the one praying sees himself as if the Shechinah is before him, as it is said, "I have set the Lord before me always." Thus far the text. 

And in the Tur Orach Chaim (Siman 97) it is written in the name of the Jerusalem Talmud that if one has saliva during his prayer and cannot conceal it with his garment, he should throw it behind him or to his left, but not in front of him or to his right. And it is written in the "Beit Yosef" that our great teacher Rabbi Yitzchak Abuhav wrote from the words of our teacher the Tur that it seems that he is speaking of his own right and left, and he was troubled by what is different from the law of three steps, which shows more honor to his left, because it is the right of the Shechinah, and he left the matter as an open question. 

And in the Darchei Moshe, he explained that since it is forbidden to spit during prayer unless one is a fastidious person, they did not want to instruct to spit when the Shechinah is opposite him; rather, his spitting is a sign that the Shechinah is departing from him. Therefore, he should spit to his left because the name is not before his eyes. But when he takes three steps back like a student departing from his teacher, then he places the Shechinah before his eyes, and therefore he shows honor to his left, which is the right of the Shechinah that is before him. Thus, according to this, the matter of right and left depends on his perspective, that when he places the Shechinah before him, he must show honor to his left and give it precedence first, which is the right of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And God forbid, when the Shechinah departs from him, then he must show honor to the right, which is superior, as stated regarding spitting, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the directionality in prayer, emphasizing that a worshiper must take three steps back to honor the Divine Presence, which is perceived as facing them. It highlights the concept that the left side represents the Divine's presence, while the right side symbolizes the worshiper's own perspective. The text suggests that when the Shechinah (Divine Presence) is before the worshiper, they should show greater respect to the left, as it is the Divine's right, whereas when the Shechinah is absent, the worshiper should honor their own right side. This reflects a deeper understanding of the relationship between the individual and the Divine, illustrating the dynamic of reverence and respect in prayer.

passage_content: ואל"פ בזה אמרם ז"ל עה"פ לא תסור מן הדבר אשר יגידו לך וגו' ימין ושמאל, ודרשו חז"ל אפי' אומר לך על ימין שהוא שמאל ועל שמאל שהוא ימין, ולכאורה איך יתכן שחכמי הסנהדרין יאמרו על ימין שהוא שמאל, שהוא מוכחש המציאות, ומדוע יתחייב האדם להאמין נגד המבורר במציאות להיפך וצריך ביאור כוונת דרז"ל, ולדרכנו יל"פ כי חכמי ישראל לפי מדריגתם הרמה שהם דבוקים בו ית' תמיד ומקיימין שויתי ד' לנגדי בכל עת ובכל רגע, נמצא צריכים לחלוק כבוד לשמאלם שהוא ימינו של הקב"ה, ועושים לשמאל שלהם ימין ולימינם שמאל, והוא הנכון לפי מדריגתם, שכ דבריהם ומעשיהם מול השכינה לייחד קוב"ה ושכינתוי, אמנם האיש הרחוק ממדריגתם חושב שאומרים על ימין שהוא שמאל ועל שמאל שהוא ימין, ע"כ בא הכתוב והזהיר לבל יתלה האדם הטעות בדברי החכמים, כ"א יתלה החסרון בעצמו שרחוקה מדריגתו ממדריגתם והשגתו מהשגתו, ואפי' יאמר לך על ימין שהוא שמאל מחוייב אתה לשמוע להם.
translation: And in this regard, our sages, of blessed memory, said on the verse "You shall not turn aside from the word that they tell you... right or left," and the sages interpreted that even if they tell you that the right is left and the left is right, it seems difficult how the sages of the Sanhedrin could say that the right is left, which contradicts reality. Why should a person be obligated to believe against what is clear in reality, the opposite? This requires clarification of the intent of our sages. According to our path, it can be explained that the sages of Israel, due to their elevated level, are always attached to the Blessed One and fulfill "I have set the Lord before me at all times," thus they must show respect to their left, which is the right of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and they make their left into a right and their right into a left, and this is correct according to their level, as their words and actions are before the Shechinah to unify the Holy One, Blessed be He, and His Shechinah. However, a person who is distant from their level thinks that they are saying that the right is left and the left is right. Therefore, the scripture comes and warns that a person should not attribute the error to the words of the sages, but rather attribute the shortcoming to himself, for he is far from their level and his understanding is distant from their understanding. Even if they tell you that the right is left, you are obligated to listen to them.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of adhering to the teachings of the sages, even when their guidance seems contrary to one's understanding of reality. It suggests that the sages, due to their elevated spiritual status and closeness to the Divine, perceive truth differently, where what appears as left to the ordinary person may be right in their perspective. This highlights the need for humility and recognition of one's own limitations in understanding, urging individuals to trust the wisdom of the sages rather than question it based on personal perception. Ultimately, it conveys a profound respect for the authority of the learned in the context of divine truth.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר לעניננו דהנה גם יוסף ראה והשיג ברוה"ק שאפרים יהי' גדול ממנשה, שעתיד יהושע לצאת ממנו שינחול את הארץ וילמד תורה לישראל, ולזה שם את אפרים משמאל ישראל שהוא ימין דשכינה הק', כי בודאי בשעה שהמשיך ועאע"ה את הברכה, הי' רואה השכינה הקדושה מול פניו כמו בתפלה, וכמ"ש רש"י ז"ל שהמתפלל רואה עצמו כאילו השכינה למול פניו, ואת מנשה שם לימינו של ועאע"ה לא לטעם החשיבות, כי אדרבה לפי בחינתו של יעאע"ה דשמאל עדיפא שהוא ימין דשכינה, ולטעם זה חלק כבוד לאפרים לשימו משמאל ישראל כנ"ל, אולם חשב כי ישית יעקב אבינו יד ימינו על ראש מנשה שהוא הבכור, ויהי' גם למנשה קדימה וחלק ופה בהמשכת הברכה לצד מעלתו בבכורה, ולכל אחד יגיע חלקו בברכה כפי הראוי לו, ולזה טען ואמר כי זה הבכור שים ימינך על ראשו, אמנם יעאע"ה שיכל את ידיו כמשה"כ וישלח ישראל את ימינו וישת על ראש אפרים וגו', ונתן לאפרים קדימה בשניהם, לשימו משמאלו שהוא ימין דשכינה, וגם לברכו ביד ימינו, ולז"א ידעתי בני ידעתי וגו' אולם אחיו הקטן יגדל ממנו וזרעו יהי' מלא הגוים, וכפרש"י ז"ל שעתיד יהושע לצאת ממנו שינחיל את הארץ וילמד תורה לישראל, וע"כ מוכרח שיהי' המשכת הברכה אליו בכל צד ובחי' של ימין, דענין כיבוש וירושת הארץ לישראל א"א שתהי' אפי' עם נדנוד כח של צד שמאל, כי אם עפ"י התורה שניתנה מימינו של הקב"ה שנא' מימינו אש דת וגו', ויבואר בזה אמרם ז"ל במד"ר עה"פ ידעתי בני ידעתי וגו' מה דברים שלא נתגלו לך נתגלו לי, דברים שנתגלו לך על אחת כמה וכמה עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה לפי הפשטות שקאי על ידיעת הבכורה צ"ע ענין התגלות זו מה ענינה, ומה צורך להתגלות לדבר זה, ולדרכנו אפ"ל שרמז לו יעאע"ה שהשיג כל מה שיארע לישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, והנסיונות העצומים שיעברו עליהם בסוף יומיא בענין כיבוש הארץ לפני הזמן ח"ו, ולא השיג כהשגתו שום אדם בעולם, וזה נתינת טעם מה שהקדים לאפרים שתהי' המשכת הברכה אליו בכל צד ובחי' של ימין, מפני שירושת הארץ לישראל יהי' ע"י זרעו, וללמד לדורות העתידים שא"א להיות ירושת הארץ אפי' עם נדנוד כח של צד שמאל כנ"ל.
translation: And this will clarify our matter, for behold, even Yosef saw and understood through the Holy Spirit that Ephraim would be greater than Menasheh, as Yehoshua, who would inherit the land and teach Torah to Israel, would come from him. Therefore, he placed Ephraim to the left of Israel, which is the right of the Holy Shechinah, for certainly at the time that he, may his merit protect us, extended the blessing, he would see the Holy Shechinah before him, as in prayer, and as Rashi, of blessed memory, states that one who prays sees himself as if the Shechinah is before him. And he placed Menasheh to his right not for the reason of importance, for rather according to the evaluation of him, may his merit protect us, the left is preferable, which is the right of the Shechinah. And for this reason, he honored Ephraim by placing him to the left of Israel, as mentioned. However, he thought that Jacob our father would place his right hand upon the head of Menasheh, who is the firstborn, and that Menasheh would also receive precedence and a portion in the continuation of the blessing due to his merit of being the firstborn, and to each one would reach his portion in the blessing as is fitting for him. Therefore, he argued and said, "This is the firstborn; place your right hand upon his head." However, he, may his merit protect us, crossed his hands as it is written, "And Israel sent his right hand and placed it upon the head of Ephraim," etc., and he gave precedence to Ephraim with both hands, placing him to his left, which is the right of the Shechinah, and also to bless him with his right hand. And thus he said, "I know, my son, I know," etc., but his younger brother will be greater than him, and his seed will be full of the nations, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that Yehoshua will come from him to inherit the land and teach Torah to Israel. Therefore, it is necessary that the continuation of the blessing should be to him in every aspect and in the aspect of the right, for the matter of conquering and inheriting the land for Israel cannot be even with a slight nod of strength from the left side, but only according to the Torah that was given from the right hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, "From His right hand a fire of law," etc. And this will clarify their statement, of blessed memory, in the Midrash on the verse "I know, my son, I know," etc., "What things that were not revealed to you were revealed to me; things that were revealed to you, all the more so," thus concludes the Midrash. And seemingly, according to the simple understanding, which pertains to the knowledge of the firstborn, it is difficult to understand the matter of this revelation, and what need is there for this revelation regarding this matter? And according to our path, it can be said that he hinted to him, may his merit protect us, that he comprehended all that would happen to Israel until the end of all generations, and the immense trials that would befall them at the end of days regarding the conquest of the land before the time, Heaven forbid. And no one in the world comprehended as he comprehended, and this provides a reason for why he preceded Ephraim, that the continuation of the blessing should be to him in every aspect and in the aspect of the right, because the inheritance of the land for Israel will be through his seed, and to teach future generations that it is impossible for there to be an inheritance of the land even with a slight nod of strength from the left side, as mentioned.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the prophetic insight of Joseph regarding Ephraim's future prominence over Manasseh, emphasizing that Joshua, who would lead Israel in conquering the land and teaching Torah, would descend from Ephraim. The placement of Ephraim to Joseph's left, representing the divine left hand associated with the Shechinah, signifies the importance of spiritual elevation over mere birthright. The text highlights that the inheritance of the land for Israel must come through the right side, symbolizing divine favor and the necessity of Torah guidance, as opposed to relying on the strength of the left. Ultimately, it conveys that the blessings and leadership destined for Ephraim are essential for Israel's future, particularly in the context of their trials and the fulfillment of their divine mission.
