passage_content: ועפי"ז אפ"ל כוונת דברי הזוה"ק באמרם זיל שאינו מועיל תשובה על חטא הידוע, וה"מ כד לא עביד תיובתא שלימתא דאיהו אתחזויא לחפאה על כל עובדוי, דידוע שזה החטא הוא בכח כל האברים ר"ל, נמצא כו נפגמו על ידו כל איבריו ב"מ, וע"כ קשה התשובה ע"ז ואינו מועיל בתשובה לחוד, כי צריך עוד למרק כתמי הנפש וכתמי כל אבריו שנתלככו בחטא זה ר"ל, אבל ע"י חבילות מצות שיעשה בכל איבריו וגידיו בצירוף התשובה יועיל לו שיתמרקו הכתמים מיד ויתכפר לו.
translation: And according to this, one can say the intention of the words of the Zohar when they say that it is not effective to repent for a known sin, and this is said when he has not completed a full repentance, for he has been revealed to be entangled in all his deeds. It is known that this sin affects all the limbs, so all his limbs are blemished through it. Therefore, repentance for this is difficult and does not help by itself, because it is necessary to also cleanse the stains of the soul and the stains of all his limbs that have become entangled in this sin. However, through bundles of mitzvot that he performs with all his limbs and sinews, in conjunction with repentance, it will help him that the stains will be cleansed immediately and he will be atoned for.
summary: The passage discusses the difficulty of repentance for a specific sin that affects all parts of the body, indicating that the sin leaves stains on both the soul and the limbs. It emphasizes that mere repentance is insufficient; one must also purify the spiritual blemishes caused by the sin. However, by performing a multitude of mitzvot (commandments) with all one's limbs in conjunction with repentance, one can effectively cleanse these stains and achieve atonement. This highlights the interconnectedness of actions and spiritual purification in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ובזה נבוא לבאר דברי הספרי הנ"ל שאצל ראובן החליפו זכות בחובה, וכפי' הזית רענן שהצלה של יוסף עמד לו לזכות נגד מעשה בלהה, ויובן עפימ"ש ז"ל דצדיקים במה שחוטאים בו מתרצים, ואמרו ז"ל (שבת נ"ה ע"ב) כל האומר ראובן חטא אינו אלא טועה וכו', ומה אנו מקיים וישכב את בלהה פלגש אביו. מלמד שבלבל מצעו של אביו ומעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו שכב עמה, תניא רשב"א אומר מוצל אותו צדיק מאותו עון ולא בא מעשה זו לידו וכו', עכ"ד הגמ', נמצא מבואר שחטאו של ראובן הי', מה שפגע בדעתו הקדושה של יעאע"ה וגרם לו צער לעשות היפך דעתו ורצונו, עוד שם בגמ' אחרים אומרים שתי מצעות בלבל, אחת של שכינה ואחת של אביו, עכ"ד הגמרא, אמנם ע"י הצלת יוסף תיקן שניהם מידה כנגד מידה, שגרם נחת רוח לאביו, ועי"ז שרתה עליו שכינה כמ"ש ז"ל ותחי רוח יעקב אביהם ששרתה עליו שכינה שפירשה ממנו, וכ"ז ניגרם ע"ו ראובן שהשתדל להצילו מידם, ובזה א"ש דברי הספרי הנ"ל לעולם אין מחליפין זכות בחובה חוץ משל ראובן, שהרי הזכות הי' באותו הענין עצמו שחטא, ועקר בזה שורש החטא לגמרי, ונוסף לזה עשה תשובה שלימה ומעולה כאמרז"ל עסוק הי' בשקו ותעניתו, אלא שעדיין צורך למרק כתמי הנפש, ולזה הועיל לו זכות הצלת יוסף שתיקן מידה כנגד מידה במה שחטא, ובאם יחסרו מהתנאים הנ"ל ע"ז נתנו חז"ל כללא דאין מחליפין זכות בחובה והבן.
translation: And with this, we will come to explain the words of the aforementioned Sifrei regarding Reuven, who exchanged merit for obligation. As the fresh olive tree explains, the salvation of Yosef stood for him as a merit against the act with Bilhah. This will be understood according to what our sages of blessed memory said, that the righteous, in what they sin, they are appeased, and they said (Shabbat 55b) that anyone who says Reuven sinned is merely mistaken, etc. And how do we uphold "and he lay with Bilhah, his father's concubine"? It teaches that he confused his father's bed, and the scripture considers it as if he lay with her. It is taught that Rabbi Shimon ben Azzai says that that righteous one was saved from that sin and this act did not come to him, etc. Thus, it is clear that Reuven's sin was what he disturbed the holy mind of our father Yaakov and caused him pain by acting contrary to his mind and will. Furthermore, there in the Gemara, others say he confused two beds, one of the Shechinah and one of his father, etc. However, through the salvation of Yosef, he rectified both, measure for measure, as he caused his father satisfaction, and as a result, the Shechinah rested upon him, as our sages of blessed memory said, "And the spirit of their father Yaakov revived," which rested upon him, having departed from him. All this was caused by the sin of Reuven, who endeavored to save him from their hands. And with this, the words of the aforementioned Sifrei are explained: "One does not exchange merit for obligation except for the case of Reuven," for the merit was in that very matter in which he sinned, and fundamentally, he uprooted the root of the sin entirely. In addition to this, he made complete and excellent repentance, as our sages of blessed memory said, he was occupied with his fasting and affliction, yet there was still a need to cleanse the stains of the soul. For this, the merit of saving Yosef helped him, as he rectified measure for measure in what he sinned. And if any of the aforementioned conditions are lacking, for this, our sages established the principle that one does not exchange merit for obligation, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the unique case of Reuven, who, despite his sin of being with Bilhah, was able to exchange his transgression for merit through his act of saving Yosef. It emphasizes the Hasidic concept that righteous individuals can rectify their wrongdoings by performing good deeds that counterbalance their sins, illustrating the principle of "measure for measure." The text highlights that Reuven's repentance and his efforts to alleviate his father's sorrow restored the Divine presence, demonstrating the profound connection between actions, repentance, and spiritual elevation. Ultimately, it asserts that while generally merits cannot replace sins, Reuven's situation exemplifies a rare exception due to the nature of his actions and their impact.

passage_content: ויל"פ בזה מאמה"כ למען הציל אותו מידם להשיבו אל אביו, דלכאורה להשיבו אל אביו מיותר, ולדרכנו ר"ל שנתכוין בהצלה זו להשיבו אל אביו כדי להפיס דעתו ולהפוג צערו, או יאמר להשיבו אל אביו מוסב על ראובן, שע"י הצלת יוסף נתקרב אל אביו שבשמים ונותקן חטאו כמבואר בספרי הנ"ל, וזה אומרו למען הציל אותו מידם ובזה הועיל לעצמו להשיבו אל אביו שבשמים. ואפשר שלא השיג ראובן בשעה שהשתדל בהצלתו שעי"ז יהי' לו תקנה על מעשה בלהה, ומן השמים העלימו ממנו ידיעה זו, שהי' הכרח שירד יוסף למצרים כידוע מדברי חכמז"ל, וע"כ חשב ראובן שבמה שצוה להשליכו הבורה כבר השלים כל הצורך להצלת יוסף, וכמבואר בזוה"ק שהי' ההצלה בזה להצילו מיד בעלי בחירה, ואח"כ שב לשקו ולתעניתו כמ"ש חז"ל וישב ראובן אל הבור והיכן הי' עסוק הי' בשקו ובתעניתו על שבלבל יצועי אביו, ולא השתדל בהצלה יתירה להשיב את יוסף לאביו דייקא, ואולי רצה לתקן חטא של מעשה בלהה תחלה, כי רצה להסיר בחי' הרע תחלה ואח"כ לקיים ועשה טוב, כמ"ש ז"ל דהמצות שעושין בעודן מלוכלכים בעבירות ר"ל הם קרובים אל ההיזק יותר מאל התועלת, אך במה שהוא מצוה עוברת וחשש פקו"נ אין לשהות המצוה ולמנוע ממנה בשביל טעם הנ"ל, אולם חשב ראובן שכבר השלים מצות ההצלה במה שצוה להשליך את יוסף אל הבור להצילו מידי בעלי בחירה, ולא ידע שהצלה זו יהי' לו לתיקון חטאו, דאילו הי' יודע, על כתיפו הי' טוענו ומוליכו אצל אביו. לעשות ההצלה בשלימות לתקן החעא בשרשו מידה כ"מ.
translation: And it can be explained here from our holy sources that it was in order to save him from their hands to return him to his father. At first glance, the return to his father seems unnecessary, and according to our way, it means that this salvation was intended to return him to his father in order to calm his mind and alleviate his sorrow. Alternatively, it can be said that the return to his father refers to Reuben, who through the salvation of Joseph drew closer to his Father in Heaven, and his sin was rectified as explained in the aforementioned texts. This is the meaning of "to save him from their hands," and in this way, he benefited himself by returning him to his Father in Heaven. It is possible that Reuben did not realize at the time he was striving for his salvation that this would be a rectification for his act with Bilhah, and from Heaven, this knowledge was hidden from him, as it was necessary for Joseph to descend to Egypt, as is known from the words of our sages. Therefore, Reuben thought that by commanding to throw him into the pit, he had already fulfilled all that was needed for Joseph's salvation, as is explained in the Zohar that the salvation here was to save him from those with free will. Afterwards, he returned to his mourning and fasting, as our sages said, "And Reuben returned to the pit," and where was he occupied? He was in his mourning and fasting for having disturbed his father's bed, and he did not strive for an additional salvation to return Joseph specifically to his father. Perhaps he wanted to rectify the sin of the act with Bilhah first, as he wanted to remove the evil aspect first and then to do good, as our sages said that the commandments performed while one is still stained with sins are closer to harm than to benefit. However, in a case where it is a passing commandment and there is a concern for saving a life, one should not delay the commandment or refrain from it for the aforementioned reason. Nevertheless, Reuben thought that he had already completed the commandment of salvation by commanding to throw Joseph into the pit to save him from the hands of those with free will, and he did not know that this salvation would serve as a rectification for his sin. For had he known, he would have carried him on his shoulders and brought him to his father, to complete the salvation and rectify the sin at its root, measure for measure.
summary: The passage discusses Reuven's intention to save Yosef from his brothers, emphasizing that this act was not merely to return Yosef to their father, but also to alleviate the father's sorrow and to rectify Reuven's own sin regarding Bilhah. It suggests that Reuven may not have realized that his efforts to save Yosef would also serve as atonement for his past misdeed, as he believed he had fulfilled his duty by merely throwing Yosef into the pit. The text highlights the Hasidic concept of divine providence, where actions taken with good intentions can lead to spiritual rectification, even if the individual is unaware of the deeper implications of their actions. Ultimately, it illustrates the interconnectedness of personal redemption and the fulfillment of mitzvot.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש אילו הי' יודע ראובן שהכתוב כותב אחריו וישמע ראובן ויצילהו מידם וגו' להשיבו אל אביו, וכפירוש הנ"ל שזה היה תקנה לראובן להתקרב אל אביו שבשמים, על כתיפו הי' טוענו ומוליכו אצל אביו, אולם לצורך השעה העלימו מן השמים ממנו ידיעה זו וכנ"ל, כדי שירד יוסף למצרים ויתקיים גזירת ידע תדע, ואחר שנמכר יוסף נתוודע לראובן השגה זו שבהצלת יוסף הי' תלוי תקון חטאו כנ"ל ובזה יובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל הילד איננו ואני אנה אני בא ממעשה בלהה, כי הצלת יוסף הי' הזכות שעמד לו לכפר על מעשה בלהה כמבואר בספרי הנ"ל, וע"כ כשראה שהילד איננו ואין כאן הצלה. הי' מתיירא לנפשו שחזרה פגם החטא למקומו, ואיך יהי' לו תיקון על מעשה בלהה.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash: If Reuven had known that the scripture was writing about him, "And Reuven heard and saved him from their hands," to return him to his father, and according to the above interpretation, this was a rectification for Reuven to draw closer to his Father in Heaven, for he was carrying him on his shoulders and leading him to his father. However, for the sake of the moment, this knowledge was concealed from him by Heaven, as mentioned, so that Yosef would descend to Egypt and the decree of "You shall surely know" would be fulfilled. And after Yosef was sold, this understanding was revealed to Reuven, that in saving Yosef, his rectification for his sin was dependent, as mentioned. And thus, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be understood: "The child is not here, and where shall I go from the deed of Bilhah?" For the saving of Yosef was the merit that stood for him to atone for the deed of Bilhah, as explained in the aforementioned texts. Therefore, when he saw that the child was not there and there was no salvation, he was afraid for his soul that the blemish of the sin had returned to its place, and how would he have a rectification for the deed of Bilhah?
summary: The passage discusses the idea that Reuven's actions to save Yosef were divinely orchestrated to facilitate his spiritual return to his heavenly Father. It emphasizes that Reuven was initially unaware of the significance of his intervention, which was meant to rectify his previous sin involving Bilhah. Upon realizing that Yosef was lost, Reuven feared that his past transgression would resurface without the opportunity for atonement. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of actions and divine providence in the process of repentance and spiritual elevation.

passage_content: ח"ש למדתך תורה דרך ארץ שכשהאדם עושה מצוה יהא עושה אותה בלב שמח, שאילו הי' יודע ראובן וכו', והכוונה בזה לדרכנו דהנה בעוה"ר אנו מלוכלכים בחטאים ועונות מרובים. ואם מרבים בחבילות מצות ומע"ט יזדמן לעשות ג"כ מצוה כזאת שיהי' מידה כ"מ לתיקון גמור על עונותינו, וכמ"ש בראובן שאילו הי' יודע שהצלת יוסף הוא תיקון על מעשה בלהה. הי' עוסק בה יותר בשלימות להשיבו אל אביו, אלא שאצלו הי' סיבה מן השמים להעלים ממנו ידיעה זו וכנ"ל אבל עכ"פ נלמד מזה שצריך להרבות במצות ומע"ט. וכמ"ש במדרש לעשות חבילות מצות ולעשות המצות בשלימות ובלב שמח ובזה יעשה תיקון לנפשו ויתכפרו עונותיו.
translation: In the teachings of the Baal Shem Tov, you have learned that the way of the Torah is to conduct oneself with joy when performing a mitzvah. For if Reuven had known, etc., the intention here is to guide us, for behold, in our times we are sullied with numerous sins and transgressions. And if we increase in bundles of mitzvot and good deeds, it will also happen that we will perform such a mitzvah that will serve as a complete rectification for our sins, as it is written regarding Reuven that if he had known that saving Yosef was a rectification for the act with Bilhah, he would have engaged in it more completely to return him to his father. However, for him, there was a reason from Heaven to conceal this knowledge from him, as mentioned above. Nevertheless, we learn from this that we should increase in mitzvot and good deeds. As it is stated in the Midrash, to make bundles of mitzvot and to perform the mitzvot with completeness and with a joyful heart, and through this, one will achieve rectification for their soul and their sins will be atoned.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of performing mitzvot (commandments) with joy and completeness, as this can lead to spiritual rectification for one's sins. It draws a parallel to the biblical figure Reuven, suggesting that had he known the significance of saving Yosef, he would have acted with greater dedication. The text encourages the accumulation of mitzvot and good deeds, highlighting that such efforts can lead to atonement and healing for the soul. Ultimately, it teaches that a joyful and committed approach to fulfilling commandments can bring about profound spiritual repair.

passage_content: והנה ידוע הההוכחות שבין הקב"ה וכנסת ישראל, שהקב"ה אומר לישראל שובו אלי ואשובה אליכם, וכנסת ישראל אומרת השיבני ה' אליך ונשובה, וכוונת הענין שהקב"ה רוצה שהתעוררות התשובה יבוא מצד ישראל תחלה והוא חשובה יותר, וכנסת ישראל טוענת שאין בכוחנו להתחיל בתשובה תחלה ובקשתינו שהקב"ה יעורר אותנו ויתן בלבנו רצון וכח נפשי לשוב אליו באמת, ועפי"ד ז"ל נראה לפרש סיום הפסוק השיבנו ה' אליך ונשובה חדש ימינו כקדם, דהנה קודם שיחטא האדם יש מציאות לזה שיתחיל התעוררות הרצון מצידנו, משא"כ אחר שנכשל בחטאים ונבראו ע"י מעשיו מזיקים משחיתים ומלאכים רעים, אז כמעט מן הנמנע שיבוא התעוררות תשובה מצדו, שאותן מלאכים שחורים שנבראו מן החטאים מסמין עיני האדם ולוחמים נגדו ואין נותנים מקום להתעוררות קדושה, משא"כ קודם שנכשל בחטאים אע"פ שיש יצה"ר לאדם מצד הבריאה, אעפ"כ יש מציאות שהאדם עצמו יתעורר בתשובה תחלה, וזה בקשתינו חדש ימינו כקדם, היינו כבחי' הזמן שהיינו בו תחלה קודם שנכשלנו בחטאים, ואז יהי' מציאות שנתעורר מעצמינו לשוב אליו ית"ש.
translation: And behold, it is known the proofs between the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the Congregation of Israel, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, says to Israel, "Return to Me, and I will return to you," and the Congregation of Israel says, "Bring me back, O Lord, to You, and we will return." The intention of the matter is that the Holy One, Blessed be He, wants the awakening of repentance to come from Israel first, and this is more significant. The Congregation of Israel argues that we do not have the strength to begin repentance on our own, and our request is that the Holy One, Blessed be He, should awaken us and place in our hearts the desire and spiritual strength to truly return to Him. According to our sages, it seems appropriate to interpret the conclusion of the verse "Bring us back, O Lord, to You, and we will return" as follows: Before a person sins, there is a possibility for the awakening of desire to begin from our side. However, after one has stumbled in sins and has created through his actions harmful and destructive forces and evil angels, it is almost impossible for the awakening of repentance to come from him, as those dark angels created from the sins blind a person's eyes and fight against him, not allowing any space for a holy awakening. In contrast, before one has stumbled in sins, although there is an evil inclination within a person due to creation, there is still a possibility for the person himself to awaken to repentance first. This is our request: "Renew our days as of old," meaning as in the state of time we were in before we stumbled in sins, and then there will be a reality that we will awaken of our own accord to return to Him, Blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the dynamic relationship between God and the Jewish people regarding repentance. It emphasizes that while God desires the initial awakening of repentance to come from Israel, the people argue that they lack the strength to initiate this process due to the negative influences of their sins. The text highlights the importance of divine assistance in rekindling their desire to return to God, suggesting that before sinning, individuals have the potential to initiate their own repentance, unlike after they have sinned when they are hindered by the negative forces created by their actions. Ultimately, the plea is for a renewal of their spiritual state to enable genuine self-driven repentance.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל מעולם לא חטא אדם לפני ועשה תשובה וכו', דהנה באדה"ר וקין שעשו תשובה אין רבותא כ"כ, שהרי הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו דיבר עמהם לעוררם על התשובה, וכמו שאמרו ז"ל (במד"ר פכ"א) ועתה פן ישלח ידו וגו' אין ועתה אלא תשובה מלמד שפתח לו הקב"ה פתח של תשובה, וכן בקין אמר לו הקב"ה אם תטיב שאת וגו' שפתח לו הקב"ה פתח של תשובה, משא"כ ראובן פתח בתשובה תחלה והתחיל באתערותא דלתתא וזה חשוב יותר, וז"פ המדרש מעולם לא חטא אדם לפני ועשה תשובה ואתה פתחת דייקא בתשובה תחלה, רצה לומר שאתה בעצמך היית הפותח טפח. בבחינת שובו אלי ואשובה אליכם, חייך שבן בנך עומד ופותח בתשובה תחלה, שנאמר שובה ישראל עד ה' אלקיך, ודרשו רז"ל במדרש שובה ישראל עד ה"נ עד שהוא במדת רחמים ואם לאו אלקיך, עד לא יתעביד סנגוריא קטגוריא, ולדרכינו יאמר שובה ישראל עד ה' אלקיך היינו עד שלא יבוא ההתעוררות מה', תשתדל לשוב תחלה ומעצמך תתעורר לתשובה והיינו מידה כ"מ כמו שעשה ראובן שפתח בתשובה תחלה.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash, that no man ever sinned before and repented, etc. Behold, with Adam HaRishon and Cain, who repented, there is not so much greatness, for the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself spoke with them to awaken them to repentance, as our Sages of blessed memory said (in Midrash Rabba, Parashat 21), "And now, lest he send forth his hand, etc." — "And now" refers only to repentance, teaching that the Holy One, blessed be He, opened for him a door of repentance. And similarly, with Cain, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "If you do well, will you not be accepted?" — that the Holy One, blessed be He, opened for him a door of repentance. In contrast, Reuben opened with repentance first and began with an awakening from below, and this is more significant. Thus, the Midrash states that no man ever sinned before and repented, and you opened specifically with repentance first, meaning that you yourself were the one to open a handbreadth. In the aspect of "Return to Me, and I will return to you," I swear that your grandson stands and opens with repentance first, as it is said, "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God," and our Sages of blessed memory expounded in the Midrash, "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God" — this means until he is in a state of mercy, and if not, "your God," until he does not act as a defense attorney and an accuser. And according to our path, it is said, "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God," meaning until the awakening does not come from the Holy One, blessed be He, you should strive to return first and awaken yourself to repentance, and this is a measure everywhere, as Reuben did, who opened with repentance first.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of individual initiative in repentance, contrasting the responses of Adam and Cain, who were directly prompted by God, with Reuben, who initiated his own repentance. It highlights the idea that true repentance begins with a personal awakening, as illustrated by the verse "Return, O Israel, to the Lord your God," which suggests that one should strive to return to God independently before divine intervention occurs. This underscores the Hasidic concept of self-driven spiritual awakening as a vital aspect of the repentance process.

passage_content: ונקדים מ"ש בספה"ק בני יששכר (מאמרי חודש סיון מאמר ב') על מ"ש רז"ל (בתנחומא פ' האזינו) כתיב ישא ד' פניו אליך וכתיב אשר לא ישא פנים, עשה תשובה ישא ד' פניו, יכול לכל ת"ל אליך ולא לאומה"ע עכ"ד המדרש, הרי שהתשובה אינה מועלת רק לישראל ולא לאומה"ע, עיי"ש שהביא בשם הרב בעל לימודי ד' הרבה טעמים ע"ז. ואפ"ל עוד טעם לדבר זה עפי"ד הרמ"ע מפאנו זלה"ה בספרו עשרה מאמרות, שהקשה על מה דאמרו רז"ל (קידושין מ' ע"ב) לעולם יראה אדם עצמו כאילו חציו חייב וחציו זכאי, עשה מצוה אחת אשריו שהכריע עצמו לכף זכות, והלא הם אמרו (ב"ק דף נ' ע"ב) כל האומר הקב"ה וותרן הוא יוותרו חייו וכו', וא"כ איך נדון האדם לזכות לפי רוב הזכיות ועכ"פ יש בידו עבירות, ותירץ דדין התורה כן הוא אחרי רבים להטות ואין זה ויתור, דדינא הכי עפ"י תורה, ובספה"ק בני יששכר הביא בשם הרה"ק הר"ר זושא זלה"ה לפרש בזה נוסח הפיוט באין מליץ יושר מול מגיד פשע תגיד ליעקב דבר חוק ומשפט וצדקנו וכו', דלפי שישראל מקיימין החקים שבתורה אע"פ שאין יודעים טעם בדבר, כמו"כ מדה כנגד מדה צריך הקב"ה לכפר חטאינו אף בלי טעם, דכך הוא המדה בתורה לדון מדה כנגד מדה, וז"פ באין מליץ יושר מול מגיד פשע, תגיד ליעקב דבר חוק ומשפט, מה שישראל מקיימין החקים בלו שום טעם, ועי"ז וצדקנו במשפט המלך המשפט, ואין זה נקרא ויתור כיון שכך הוא משפט התורה את"ד ז"ל, הרי מבואר שעפ"י דיני התוה"ק ובכח שמירת התוה"ק הקב"ה מכפר עונותיהם של ישראל, וא"כ אין מידה זו נוהגת כ"א לישראל מקיימי התוה"ק ולא לאומה"ע,
translation:
And we will precede with what is written in the holy book Bnei Yissachar (Ma'amarim of the month of Sivan, Ma'amar 2) regarding what our sages of blessed memory said (in Tanchuma, Parashat Ha'azinu): It is written, "The Lord will lift up His countenance upon you," and it is written, "He does not lift faces." If one repents, He will lift His countenance, but one might think this applies to you and not to the nations of the world. Thus concludes the Midrash. Here it is evident that repentance is effective only for Israel and not for the nations of the world. It is noted there that the Rabbi, the author of Limudei Da'at, brought many reasons for this. 

And I can suggest another reason for this according to the Ram'a of Pano, may his memory be blessed, in his book "Ten Statements," who questioned what our sages of blessed memory said (Kiddushin 40b): "A person should always see himself as if half of him is guilty and half is meritorious. If he performs one mitzvah, fortunate is he, for he has tilted himself to the side of merit." But they also said (Baba Kamma 50b) that anyone who says that the Holy One, blessed be He, is lenient, his life will be lenient, etc. Therefore, how can a person be judged for merit based on the majority of merits when he still has transgressions? He answered that the law of the Torah is such that we follow the majority, and this is not leniency, for this is the law according to the Torah.

And in the holy book Bnei Yissachar, he brought in the name of the holy Rabbi R' Zusha, may his memory be blessed, to explain the wording of the piyyut: "There is no advocate for righteousness against the accuser of sin; declare to Jacob the word of law and justice, and our righteousness, etc." This is because Israel fulfills the statutes of the Torah even though they do not know the reason for the matter. Likewise, measure for measure, the Holy One, blessed be He, must atone for our sins even without reason, for this is the measure in the Torah to judge measure for measure. Thus, it is explained in "There is no advocate for righteousness against the accuser of sin; declare to Jacob the word of law and justice," that what Israel fulfills the statutes without any reason, and through this, "and our righteousness in the judgment of the King," the judgment, and this is not called leniency since this is the law of the Torah, as you have said, may your memory be blessed. 

It is clear that according to the laws of the holy Torah and by the merit of observing the holy Torah, the Holy One, blessed be He, atones for the sins of Israel. Therefore, this measure applies only to Israel who observe the holy Torah and not to the nations of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the unique relationship between God and Israel regarding repentance and forgiveness, emphasizing that true repentance leads to divine favor specifically for the Jewish people, as opposed to the nations of the world. It highlights the concept that Israel's adherence to the Torah, even without understanding its reasons, invokes God's mercy and forgiveness, reflecting the principle of "measure for measure" in divine judgment. The text asserts that this special status is rooted in the Torah's laws, which dictate that God's forgiveness is contingent upon Israel's commitment to its commandments, distinguishing them from other nations. Ultimately, it underscores the theological belief that the covenant between God and Israel grants them a unique avenue for atonement that is not available to others.

passage_content: וכמו כן לענין התשובה דאיתא במדרש ילקוט תהלים כ"ה) שאלו לחכמה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל חטאים תרדוף רעה, שאלו לנבואה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל הנפש החוטאת היא תמות, שאלו לתורה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל יביא אשם ויתכפר לו וכו', עכ"ד המדרש, וכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל (הל' תשובה פ"ז ה"ה) אין ישראל נגאלין אלא בתשובה, וכבר הבטיחה תורה שסוף ישראל לעשות תשובה בסוף גלותן ומיד הן נגאלין שנאמר והי' כי יבואו עליך כל הדברים וגו' ושבת עד ה' אלקיך ושב ה"א וגו', ועכ"פ התשובה מועלת רק בכח התוה"ק, והבטחת התשובה ניתנה לנו בתורה והתינח לישראל שקיבלו את התורה דין הוא שיועיל להם תשובה, משא"כ האומות שלא רצו לקבל את התורה מהיכי תיתי יועיל להם תשובה, ובאותן המצות שנצטוו בני נח לא מצינו בהם רמז על תשובה, א"כ התשובה הוא רק בכח התורה ומי שקיבל את התורה יש לו חלק בה משא"כ אומה"ע.
translation: And likewise regarding repentance, as it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut Tehillim (25): They asked wisdom, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" It replied, "Evil shall pursue sinners." They asked prophecy, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" It replied, "The soul that sins, it shall die." They asked the Torah, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" It replied, "He shall bring a guilt offering and he shall be atoned for," etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. And the Rambam, may his memory be blessed (Hilchot Teshuvah 7:5), wrote that Israel is not redeemed except through repentance, and the Torah has already promised that in the end, Israel will repent at the end of their exile, and immediately they will be redeemed, as it is said, "And it shall be when all these things come upon you... and you return to the Lord your God and obey His voice," etc. Nevertheless, repentance is effective only through the power of the Holy Torah, and the promise of repentance was given to us in the Torah. It is reasonable that for Israel, who received the Torah, it is just that repentance should be effective for them, whereas for the nations who did not wish to accept the Torah, how can it be that repentance should be effective for them? And in those commandments that the children of Noah were commanded, we do not find any hint of repentance. Therefore, repentance is only through the power of the Torah, and whoever has accepted the Torah has a share in it, unlike the nations of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of repentance (teshuva) in relation to Jewish theology, emphasizing that true redemption for Israel is contingent upon their repentance, as promised in the Torah. It cites various sources, including a Midrash and Maimonides, to illustrate that while the Jewish people are assured of the efficacy of teshuva, this is not the case for the nations who did not accept the Torah. The text underscores that the power of repentance is intrinsically linked to the Torah, which serves as the foundation for Israel's spiritual restoration, contrasting their situation with that of the non-Jewish nations.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הגמ' (ע"ז דף ט' ע"א) תנדב"א ששת אלפים שנה הוי עלמא, ב' אלפים תוהו ב' אלפים תורה ב' אלפים ימות המשיח וכו', ב' אלפים תורה מאימת, או נימא ממתן תורה עד השתא ליכא כולי האי וכו', אלא מואת הנפש אשר עשו בחרן, פירש"י ומתרגמינן דשעבידו לאורייתא, שאברהם אבינו הדריך את בניו לשמור את דרך ה' ועשה הכנה לקבלת התורה ע"כ ממנו התחילו ב' אלפים תורה, אמנם עיקר קבלת התורה לא הי' רק אחר שיצאו ישראל ממצרים ומשה קבל את התורה מסיני, מאז ניתן לישראל כח התורה בתוקפו, ומאאע"ה עד קבלת התורה הי' רק בבחי' הכשר מצוה, ואעפ"כ נחשבו הב' אלפים תורה מאברהם אבינו שהוא התחיל בה, וה"ה כמו הכשר והכנה לקבלת התורה, והנה ראובן עשה תשובה, אלא שעדיין הי' לפני קבלת התורה ולא הי' אצלם כח התורה בשלימות כ"א בבחי' הכנה, ע"כ לא הי' אפשר להעלות תשובתו של ראובן במקום שצדיקים גמורים אינן יכולין לעמוד, ובזה יובנו דברי המדרש הנ"ל כיון שבא לברך את ראובן א"ל איני לא מרחקך ולא מקרבך, והכוונה כיון שעדיין אין כח התורה בשלימותו, איני יכול לקרבך ולהעמידך במקום שבעלי תשובה עומדים, אלא הרי אנו תולה אותך ברפיון עד שיבא משה שכתוב בו ומשה עלה אל האלקים והוריד התורה לישראל. ושם כתוב מפורש הבטחת התשובה, ע"כ הוא יכול לקרבך ולהעלותך עד מקום שבעלי תשובה עומדין, כיון שבא משם התחיל מקרבו יחי ראובן ואל ימות.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 9a) that states: "Six thousand years is the duration of the world; two thousand years of chaos, two thousand years of Torah, and two thousand years of the Messianic era," etc. The two thousand years of Torah, from when? Or should we say from the giving of the Torah until now, there is not so much? Rather, from the souls that were made in Haran, Rashi explains, and we translate that they were enslaved to the Torah, that our forefather Abraham guided his children to keep the way of the Lord and made preparations to receive the Torah. Therefore, from him began the two thousand years of Torah. However, the main acceptance of the Torah was only after Israel left Egypt and Moses received the Torah at Sinai. Since then, the power of the Torah was given to Israel in its fullness, and from Abraham until the giving of the Torah, it was only in the aspect of preparation for the commandment. Nevertheless, the two thousand years of Torah are considered from our forefather Abraham, who initiated it, and it is the same as the preparation and readiness to receive the Torah. And behold, Reuben repented, but he was still before the giving of the Torah, and the power of the Torah was not complete with them, only in the aspect of preparation. Therefore, it was not possible to elevate Reuben's repentance to a place where complete righteous individuals cannot stand. And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash, for when he came to bless Reuben, he said to him, "I am neither distancing you nor drawing you close," meaning that since the power of the Torah is not in its completeness, I cannot draw you close and place you in the place where penitents stand. Rather, we are holding you in a state of slackness until Moses comes, as it is written, "And Moses went up to God and brought down the Torah to Israel." And there it is explicitly written the promise of repentance; therefore, he can draw you close and elevate you to the place where penitents stand, since he came from there. Let Reuben live and not die.
summary: The passage discusses the progression of spiritual history through the lens of the six thousand years of creation, emphasizing the two thousand years of Torah that began with Abraham, who prepared his descendants for the eventual giving of the Torah. It highlights that true acceptance of the Torah and its full power only occurred after the Exodus and at Sinai, where Moses received the Torah. The text illustrates that prior to this, even acts of repentance, like that of Reuben, lacked the full strength of the Torah, which is necessary for elevating a penitent to the level of the righteous. Ultimately, it conveys that only through Moses, who brought the Torah to Israel, can true repentance and elevation be achieved.

passage_content: ומ"ש יחי ראובן ואל ימות לכאורה הוא כפל לשון, ועוד שהרי כבר לא הי' ראובן בעוה"ז, אמנם יבואר עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, דהנה ראובן עשה תשובה שלימתא, והחליפו לו זכות בחובה, שע"י הצלת יוסף נתמרק לגמרי הפגם של מעשה בלהה כמבואר בספרי הנ"ל, ועי"ז הי' תיקון לנפשו בעודו בחיים חיותו ולא הוצרך לתקנת המיתה כדי למרק פגמי הנפש, וז"ש משרע"ה וחי ראובן ואל ימות, שנתקבלה תשובתו בחייו ולא יצטרך למיתה בשביל למרק כתמי הנפש, ואף שלראובן לא הי' נפק"מ בזה בימי משרע"ה, מ"מ נכתבה בתוה"ק להורות לדורות הבאים שבחי' תשובה כזו בצירוף חבילות של מצות מועלת אף בחיים הבוי"ת יזכנו לזה בב"א.
translation: And what is said, "Let Reuben live and not die," seemingly is a redundancy, and moreover, Reuben was no longer in this world. However, it can be explained according to our earlier approach, that behold, Reuben made complete repentance, and his merit was exchanged for a liability, for through the salvation of Joseph, the blemish of the act with Bilhah was entirely rectified, as explained in the aforementioned books. And through this, there was a rectification for his soul while he was still alive, and he did not need the rectification of death to atone for the blemishes of the soul. This is what Moshe Rabbeinu said, "And let Reuben live and not die," that his repentance was accepted in his lifetime, and he would not need to die in order to atone for the stains of the soul. And although for Reuben this was not relevant in the days of Moshe Rabbeinu, nonetheless, it was written in the Torah to instruct future generations that such a life of repentance, combined with bundles of mitzvot, is effective even in the life of this world. May we be worthy of this in the future, amen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "Let Reuben live and not die," highlighting that Reuben achieved complete repentance (teshuvah) through his actions in saving Joseph, which rectified his previous sin involving Bilhah. This repentance allowed for the purification of his soul while he was still alive, negating the need for posthumous atonement. The text emphasizes that Reuben's merit was recognized during his lifetime, serving as a lesson for future generations about the power of sincere repentance combined with good deeds to achieve spiritual elevation in this world.

passage_content: ראובן בכורי אתה וגו' אז חללת יצועי עלה, במד"ר רבנן אמרי איני לא מרחקך ולא מקרבך, אלא הרי אני תולה אותך ברפיון עד שיבא משה וכו', מה שדעתו רואה לעשות בך עושה, כיון שבא משה התחיל מקרבו יחי ראובן עכ"ד המדרש. וראוי להבין מדוע לא קירבו יעאע"ה, והניחו ברפיון עד שיבא משרע"ה דוקא וטעמא בעי.
translation: Reuben, you are my firstborn, etc. Then you have desecrated my bed. In the Midrash, the Rabbis say: I do not distance you nor draw you close, rather I suspend you in a state of uncertainty until Moses comes, etc. What his mind intends to do with you, he does. Once Moses came, he began to draw him close: "Long live Reuben." Thus far is the Midrash. It is fitting to understand why he did not draw him close, and left him in uncertainty until Moses specifically came, and the reason is needed.
summary: The passage discusses the status of Reuven as the firstborn and the tension surrounding his position, as expressed in the Midrash. It highlights that Reuven's fate is suspended until Moses arrives, indicating a divine plan that unfolds through human leadership. The delay in Moses' intervention suggests a deeper spiritual significance, emphasizing the importance of timing and the role of divine providence in shaping events. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of individual actions and the overarching divine will.

passage_content: והנ"ל בהקדם דברי האוה"ח הק' עה"כ ויברך אותם איש אשר כברכתו ברך אותם, וז"ל הגם שראינו שלא ברך ראובן ולא שמעון ולא לוי, יגיד הכתוב כי דבורו הקשה להם הוא ברכתם, והוא אומרו אשר דבר וגו' ויברך וגו', ומה שאמר לראובן דברי קנטור שם צוה את הברכה, ע"ד שאז"ל עתידה עבודה שתחזור לבכורות, וכפי"ז כיון שקבע לו שם הבכורה, עתיד הוא לעמוד לשרת לע"ל וכו', והגם שנתנה העבודה ללוים שקולים הם ויבואו שניהם לעבוד עבודת הקודש כי מעלין בקודש ולא מורידין וכו' עכל"ק. נמצא מבואר דראובן אחר שעשה תשובה מעולה, ראוי שיתקרב ויחזור אליו בכורתו מטעמא דאין מורידין בקודש כנ"ל, והנה הך דינא דאין מורידין יליף לי' בגמ' מנחות (צ"ט ע"א) מנלן דאין מורידין אמר רבי דאמר קרא ויקם משה את המשכן, פרש"י דלא סויעוהו אחיו הכהנים בהקמת העמודים והאדנים ש"מ דאין מורידין וכו' עיי"ש. הרי דדין זה דאין מורידין ניתנה להתגלות ע"ו משרע"ה, דמיני' ילפינן לי' בגמ' ולא מצאו רמז אחר בתוה"ק, ואמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' יתרו) עה"פ וידבר אלקים את כל הדברים האלה וגו', דכל מה שהנביאים עתידים להתנבאות וכל מה שהחכמים עתידים לחדש בתוה"ק, כל א' ואחד קבל את שלו מסיני, אלא שלא ניתנה להתגלות עד בא זמנו, ומבואר בספה"ק דכל א' מנשמות ישראל יש לו אחיזה בתוה"ק, וכל החידושים והרמזים וסודות ששייכים לשורש נשמתו צריך שיבא להתגלות על ידוו וא"א שיתגלו אורות אלו ע"י אחר, וז"ש במדרש הנ"ל כיון שבא משה התחיל מקרבו יחי ראובן. לפי שנתגלה על ידו הך דינא דאין מורידין, אבל יעקב אבינו לא הי' אפשר שיבוא התגלות זה על ידו, ולא הגיע זמנו שיתגלה כ"א ע"ו משרע"ה, וע"כ אמר יעאע"ה איני לא מרחקך ולא מקרבך אלא הרי אני תולה אותך ברפיון עד שיבא משה, כי אז יתגלה הך דינא דאין מורידין, כיון שבא משה התחיל מקרבו והבן.
translation: And the above is preceded by the words of the holy Ohr HaChaim on the verse, "And he blessed them, each man according to his blessing he blessed them." He writes that although we see that Reuven, Shimon, and Levi were not blessed, the text indicates that his difficult words to them are their blessing, as it says, "which he spoke... and he blessed..." And regarding what he said to Reuven, the words of rebuke, there he commanded the blessing, in accordance with what our sages of blessed memory said, that the service is destined to return to the firstborns. And according to this, since he established for him the name of the firstborn, he is destined to stand to serve in the future, etc. And although the service was given to the Levites, they are equal, and both will come to serve in the holy service, for they elevate in holiness and do not diminish, etc. Thus, it is clear that Reuven, after he repented greatly, is worthy to draw close and return to his birthright for the reason that one does not diminish in holiness, as mentioned above. And behold, this law of not diminishing is learned from the Gemara in Menachot (Tzadi Tet Amud Aleph), from where do we know that one does not diminish? Rabbi said, as the verse states, "And Moshe erected the Mishkan." Rashi explains that his brothers, the Kohanim, did not assist him in erecting the pillars and the bases, which teaches us that one does not diminish, etc. There we see that this law of not diminishing was revealed through Moshe Rabbeinu, from whom we learn it in the Gemara, and no other hint was found in the Torah. And our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Yitro) on the verse, "And God spoke all these words..." that everything the prophets are destined to prophesy and everything the sages are destined to innovate in the Torah, each and every one received his portion from Sinai, but it was not given to be revealed until its time came. It is explained in the holy books that each of the souls of Israel has a connection to the Torah, and all the innovations, hints, and secrets that pertain to the root of his soul must come to be revealed through him, and it is impossible for these lights to be revealed through another. Therefore, it is said in the aforementioned Midrash that when Moshe came, he began with, "Long live Reuven." Since this law of not diminishing was revealed through him. However, it was not possible for our forefather Yaakov to bring about this revelation, for his time had not yet come for it to be revealed, except through Moshe Rabbeinu. Therefore, Yaakov said, "I am neither distancing you nor drawing you close, but behold, I am suspending you in a state of slackness until Moshe comes," for then the law of not diminishing will be revealed. When Moshe came, he began with him, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual elevation and the idea that one cannot be demoted in holiness, as illustrated by the case of Reuben, who, after sincere repentance, is deemed worthy of reclaiming his birthright. It emphasizes that the principle of "one cannot be lowered in holiness" was revealed through Moses, highlighting the unique role of each soul in the unfolding of divine truths. The text also notes that all prophetic insights and innovations in Torah were received at Sinai, with each soul having a specific connection to these revelations. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of timing in spiritual revelations, as certain truths can only emerge through designated individuals at the appropriate moment.

passage_content: ואפ"ל בזה מ"ד במד"ר פ' פקודי עה"פ ויביאו את המשכן אל משה הה"ד (משלי ל"א) עוז והדר לבושה ותשחק ליום אחרון עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב הקישור. ויתבאר בהקדם לפרש מה שיסד הפייטן בקינות לט"ב אש תוקד בקרבי בהעלותו על לבי בצאתי ממצרים, קינים אעירה וכו' בצאתי מירושלים, והאריך שם לספר גדולת תפארתינו בצאתנו ממצרים, ולכאורה מה דהו' הו' ומה ענינו להזכרת החורבן, אמנם זאת נחמתינו בעוני הגלות, בהעלותינו על לבינו גודל תפארתינו בצאתי ממצרים, וכל זה ראוי שיחזור אלינו, דדינא הכי מעלין בקודש ואין מורידין, והך מילתא ילפינן לי' מהקמת המשכן ע"ו משרע"ה כנ"ל, וז"ש המדרש ויביאו המשכן אל משה הה"ד עוז והדר לבושה ותשחק ליום אחרון והכוונה על כנסת ישראל שיחזרו לגדלותן ותפארתן כימי קדם בב"א.
translation: And even though regarding this, the Midrash in Parashat Pekudei explains the verse "And they brought the Tabernacle to Moses," as it is written (Proverbs 31) "Strength and dignity are her clothing, and she laughs at the time to come," this is the end of the Midrash, and the connection is questioned. It will be explained in advance to interpret what the poet established in the lamentations for the good, "A fire burns within me" as he brings to my heart upon my departure from Egypt, "I will awaken lamentations" etc., upon my departure from Jerusalem, and he elaborated there to recount the greatness of our glory upon our exodus from Egypt. At first glance, what is the connection and what relevance does it have to the mention of the destruction? However, this is our comfort in the poverty of exile, as we elevate in our hearts the greatness of our glory upon our exodus from Egypt, and all this is worthy of returning to us, for the law is that we elevate in holiness and do not lower. And this matter we learn from the establishment of the Tabernacle by Moses, as mentioned above. And this is what the Midrash means by "And they brought the Tabernacle to Moses," as it is written "Strength and dignity are her clothing, and she laughs at the time to come," and the intention is regarding the congregation of Israel that they will return to their greatness and glory as in the days of old, may it be soon.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the construction of the Mishkan (Tabernacle) and the future redemption of the Jewish people, emphasizing the idea that despite the current state of exile and destruction, there is hope for restoration and return to greatness. It highlights the significance of recalling the glory of the Exodus from Egypt as a source of comfort during times of suffering. The reference to the verse "Strength and dignity are her clothing" suggests that Israel will ultimately regain its splendor and honor, akin to its former state. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the cyclical nature of spiritual elevation and the enduring promise of redemption.

passage_content: שמעון ולוי אחים וגו' בסודם אל תבא נפשי בקהלם אל תחד כבודי. פירש"י בסודם אל תבא נפשי זה מעשה זמרי וכו' בקהלם כשיקהיל קרח שהוא משבעו של לוי את כל העדה על משה ואהרן אל תחד כבודי שם אל יתייחד עמהם שמי וכו' ע"כ. ומקורו במד"ר, ובגמ' (סנהדרין ק"ט ע"ב) דרשו בענין אחר בסודם אל תבא נפשי אלו מרגלים ובקהלם אל תחד כבודי זה עדת קרח, והקשה המהרש"א ז"ל מה ענין מרגלים לשבט לוי, הרי משבט לוי לא הי' במרגלים, ואם על שבט שמעון אמר, קשה למה נקטו יותר משאר י' שבטים, ואולי קבלה הי' בידם שהמרגל משבט שמעון, הוא הי' בעל המעשה ביניהם עכ"ל, אמנם קשה דלא מצינו בשום מקום רמז לזה שהמרגל משבט שמעון הי' בעל המעשה בעצת מרגלים יותר משאר שבטים, והעונש הי' שוה לכל ישראל ולא נשתנה שבט שמעון משאר השבטים.
translation: Shimon and Levi are brothers, etc. "In their secret, let not my soul come" (Genesis 49:6). Rashi explains: "In their secret, let not my soul come" refers to the act of Zimri, etc. "In their assembly" when Korach, who is from the tribe of Levi, gathers the entire congregation against Moshe and Aharon, "let not my glory be united with them" means my name should not be associated with them, etc. Thus far. And its source is in Midrash Rabba. In the Gemara (Sanhedrin 109b), they expound on another matter: "In their secret, let not my soul come" refers to the spies, and "in their assembly, let not my glory be united with them" refers to the congregation of Korach. The Maharsha asks what connection the spies have to the tribe of Levi, as there were no spies from the tribe of Levi. If it refers to the tribe of Shimon, it is difficult why they specified it more than the other ten tribes. Perhaps it was a tradition that the spy from the tribe of Shimon was the one who was the instigator among them, thus far. However, it is difficult as we do not find any hint anywhere that the spy from the tribe of Shimon was the instigator in the counsel of the spies more than the other tribes, and the punishment was equal for all of Israel, and the tribe of Shimon was not distinguished from the other tribes.
summary: The passage discusses the biblical figures of Shimon and Levi, emphasizing the idea that their actions and the consequences of their deeds should not tarnish the honor of the Divine. It references interpretations from Rashi and the Midrash, highlighting the connection between their actions and the rebellion of Korach, as well as the spies sent to scout the land. The text raises questions about the involvement of the tribe of Shimon in the sin of the spies, suggesting a deeper theological reflection on collective responsibility and the sanctity of God's name amidst communal transgressions. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining divine honor in the face of human failings.

passage_content: ב) גם צ"ב לפי"ד המדרש שהביא רש"י ז"ל מדוע הקדים הכתוב את המאוחר בזמן, והרי מעשה קרח הי' מוקדם זמן רב למעשה זמרי, והי' לו להקדים מעשה דקרח, ויותר תמוה מ"ד במדרש ילקוט בסודם אל תבא נפשי אלו מרגלים בקהלם אל תחד כבודי אלו עדת קרח כשחטאו השבטים האלה בקהלם לא יזכר שמי שם כתיב זמרי בן סלוא וגו' וכן קרח בן יצהר וכו' עכ"ד המדרש. וצ"ב דפתח במרגלים ועדת קורח ומסיים במעשה זמרי והאוהחה"ק מפרשו בדרך פשט כי כל הכתוב ידבר במעשה יוסף. ואמר בסודם פו' מעת שהתחילו לשנאותו והי' הדבר ביניהם בסוד, כשיערימו סוד אל תבא נפשי וכו', בקהלם כשנקהלו עליו להרגו דכתיב לכו ונהרגהו וגו' אל תחד כבודי לא יקראו על שמי בנו יעקב כל עיקר באותה שעה עכ"ל. ולפירושו יקשה כפל הלשונות, ויספיק לומר בסודם אל תבא נפשי כי באפם הרגו איש וגו', והרד"ק פו' כל הענין על מעשה שכם, וכתב שכפל הענין במלות שונות, וגם לפי' קשה דא"א שיהי' בתוה"ק אפי' אות א' מיותר ושלא לצורך וצ"ב הכוונה בכפל הלשונות.
translation: B) It is also difficult according to the interpretation of the Midrash that Rashi, may his memory be blessed, brought regarding why the text precedes the later event in time, for the incident of Korach occurred long before the incident of Zimri, and it should have preceded the matter of Korach. It is even more puzzling what is stated in the Midrash Yalkut: "In their secret, let not my soul come," these are the spies; "in their assembly, let not my glory be," these are the congregation of Korach. When these tribes sinned in their assembly, my name will not be mentioned there, as it is written, Zimri son of Salu, etc., and likewise Korach son of Izhar, etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. It is puzzling that it begins with the spies and the congregation of Korach and ends with the incident of Zimri, and the Holy One, blessed be He, explains it in a straightforward manner that all that is written speaks of the matter of Yosef. And he said, "In their secret," from the time they began to hate him, and the matter was among them in secret, when they conspired, "Let not my soul come," etc., "in their assembly," when they gathered against him to kill him, as it is written, "Come, let us kill him," etc. "Let not my glory be," they will not be called by my name, the sons of Yaakov, at that time. Thus concludes his words. According to his interpretation, the repetition of the phrases is difficult, and it would suffice to say, "In their secret, let not my soul come," for in their anger they killed a man, etc. And the Radak explains the entire matter regarding the incident of Shechem, and he wrote that the repetition of the matter is in different words. Also, according to his explanation, it is difficult, for it is impossible that there should be even one letter in the Torah that is superfluous and unnecessary, and it is puzzling what the intention is in the repetition of the phrases.
summary: The passage discusses the chronological order of events in the Torah, specifically addressing why the story of Korach is mentioned after the incident of Zimri, despite its earlier occurrence. It highlights the theological implications of the names and actions of the individuals involved, suggesting that the collective sin of the spies and Korach's rebellion led to a divine distancing, as indicated by the phrase "אל תחד כבודי." The text emphasizes the interconnectedness of these narratives, reflecting on the consequences of sin and the importance of maintaining divine honor within the community. The repetition of phrases raises questions about the precision of the Torah's language, underscoring the belief that every word has profound significance.

passage_content: ונא"פ בהקדם מה שפירשתי במאה"כ אל תזכר לנו עונות ראשונים, דלכאורה צ"ב בקשתינו על עונות ראשונים בלבד, והרי גם האחחונים צריכים כפרה, אמנם הכל בתר רישא גרירא, ועיקר גרמא בנזקין הוא ההתחלה, דאחר שנכשל האדם בחטא ר"ל, נברא על ידו מלאך מקטרג המביאו אח"כ לחטוא עוד, ורק בס"ד וע"י תפלות ותחנונים בהשתפכות הלב לפניו ית"ש אפשר להנצל מחטאים אח"כ, ובפרט בחטא הידוע שהוא יסוד כל האדם, והיצה"ר מתגבר ע"ז עוד טרם שבא האדם לכלל דעת, צריך בזה זהירות יתירה שלא להכשל, כו אחר שנכשל האדם קשה מאוד להנצל מיצה"ר ורק בתיובתא סגי מתכפר לו, ולכן עיקר הנזק הוא החטא הראשון ואח"כ עבירה גוררת עבירה, וע"ז אנו מתפללים אל תזכור לנו עונות ראשונים, כי עיקר העונש הוא על עונות הראשונים כי אז עדיין לבו ברשותו ובידו להתגבר על יצרו, משא"כ אחר שכבר חטא ר"ל ה"ה בבחינת שוגג.
translation: And nevertheless, as I explained in the previous letter, do not remember to us the sins of the early ones, for it seems that our request is only regarding the sins of the early ones, and indeed the later ones also need atonement. However, everything follows the initial cause, and the main cause of damages is the beginning. After a person has stumbled in sin, God forbid, a prosecuting angel is created by him that later brings him to sin again. Only with God's help and through prayers and supplications, with the outpouring of the heart before Him, may one be saved from subsequent sins, especially from the known sin which is the foundation of all humanity, and the evil inclination strengthens itself over this even before a person reaches full understanding. One must be especially careful not to stumble in this. For after a person has stumbled, it is very difficult to be saved from the evil inclination, and only through repentance is he atoned. Therefore, the main damage is the first sin, and afterwards one transgression leads to another. And for this we pray, do not remember to us the sins of the early ones, for the main punishment is for the early sins, for then his heart was still in his control and he had the ability to overcome his inclination, whereas after he has already sinned, God forbid, he is in the category of an unintentional sinner.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the initial sin, which creates a negative spiritual force that leads to further transgressions. It highlights the idea that once a person sins, they become vulnerable to the yetzer hara (evil inclination), making it increasingly difficult to resist future temptations. The prayer "אל תזכור לנו עונות ראשונים" reflects a plea for forgiveness for these initial sins, as they are seen as the root cause of subsequent failings. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of vigilance and heartfelt prayer to overcome the challenges posed by the yetzer hara, particularly before one has fully developed moral awareness.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד לבאר במאה"כ (פ' מקץ) ויזכור יוסף את החלומות אשר חלם להם ויאמר אליהם מרגלים אתם וגו' ויאמרו אליו וגו' לא היו עבדיך מרגלים, ראוי להבין לכאורה מדוע חשד אותם יוסף למרגלים, ועפ"י פשוטו כתבו בספה"ק בטעם הענין כי יוסף נתכוין לטובתם שיכופר להם עוונם בזה, אבל עדיין צ"ב דבודאי לא דיבר יוסף הצדיק דברים שאין בהם ממשש ובל"ס שיש טעמים כמוסים בדבר עד אין חקר, אולם גם על פי פשוטו צ"ב להבין מדוע אמר להם מרגלים אתם שלא היו כן אליבא דאמת.
translation: And we will further explain in the verse (Parshat Miketz) "And Joseph remembered the dreams which he had dreamed about them, and he said to them, 'You are spies...'" And they said to him... "Your servants are not spies." It is appropriate to understand, seemingly, why Joseph suspected them of being spies. According to the simple interpretation, the holy books have written regarding the reason for the matter that Joseph intended for their good, that their sin would be atoned for through this. However, it is still puzzling, for certainly Joseph the righteous did not speak words that have no substance, and certainly there are hidden reasons in the matter that are beyond comprehension. Nevertheless, even according to the simple interpretation, it is puzzling to understand why he said to them, "You are spies," when they were not so, according to the truth.
summary: בקטע זה מדבר המחבר על המקרה שבו יוסף חשד את האחים במרגלים, ומסביר כי כוונתו הייתה לטובתם, כדי שיכופר להם עוונם. עם זאת, הוא מציין שיש להבין מדוע יוסף, שהיה צדיק, דיבר דברים שאינם תואמים את האמת. יש כאן רמז לעומק המחשבה החסידית, המצביעה על כך שלפעמים יש סיבות נעלמות לפעולות שנראות לא מובנות, והן נובעות ממקום של רחמים ותיקון.

passage_content: ואפ"ל הענין עפ"י מ"ד במדרש ילקוט (פ' דברים רמז תשצ"ט) עה"פ אחד עשר יום מחורב, אלו זכו ישראל לאחד עשר יום היו נכנסין לארץ, אלא מתוך שקלקלו מעשיהם גלגל עליהם המקום לארבעים יום ארבעים שנה, שנאמר במספר הימים אשב תחתם וגו', ר"י אומר אלו זכו ישראל לשלשה ימים היו נכנסין לארץ וכו', ר' בנאה אומר אלו זכו ישראל ליום אחד היו נכנסין לארץ וכו', אבא וכו' משום אבא כהן ברדלא אלו זכו ישראל כיון שעלו פרסות רגליהם מן הים היו נכנסין לארץ, שנאמר עלה רש מיד עכ"ד המדרש. ולכאורה ראוי להבין דמה שגלגל עליהם המקום ארבעים שנה נגד ארבעים יום, הי' בשביל חטא המרגלים, וא"כ מ"ט נתעכבה כניסתן לארץ ישראל בתחילה, ועדיין הי' לפני חטא המרגלים, אמנם מבואר במדרשי חז"ל ובזוה"ק פ' זו, דבשביל חטא מכירת יוסף נגזר עליהם גלות מצרים, ולא נתמרק עונם שם לגמרי, אלא שזכר להם הקב"ה זכות אבות והוציא את ישראל משם ביד רמה לטעם כו לא יכלו להתמהמה כמאמה"כ, ועון זה דמכירת יוסף גרם לון דיגלון מארעיהון וכו' וגרם לון דאתאחריב בית מקדשא וכו', (וכ"כ בס' הקנה בשם הזוה"ק) נמצא מבואר דבשביל חטא מכירת יוסף נגזר עליהם גלות, ואולי שנתעכבה כניסתן לארץ ג"כ מטעם זה, כי לא נתמרק עונם בצאתם ממצרים, ולא השיגו ישראל שלומותן ליכנס לארץ מיד, ובסיבה זו נתגלגל שליחת המרגלים, ובעון המרגלים נתאחר עוד זמן כניסתן לא"י מ' שנה כנגד מ' יום של הליכת המרגלים, נמצא דהשתלשלות חטא המרגלים היתה בסיבת חטא מכירת יוסף, הגם דמן השמים נסתבב מעשה זו לידם כמבואר בדברי רז"ל שהי' הכרח כן לקיים גזירת ברית בון הבתרים, מ"מ פגם הי' בדבר והיו צריכים כפרה ע"ז, כמ"ש האוהחה"ק (סו"פ ויחי) עה"פ לו ישטמנו יוסף וגו' הלואי שיהי' כן שיהי' משיב להם, והוא אומרו ישיב לנו את כל הרעה והיו מצטערים כשיעור שנצטער יוסף מצידם וכו' עיי"ש.
translation:
And even though the matter is according to what is said in the Midrash Yalkut (Parashat Devarim, Remez 795) on the verse "Eleven days from Chorev," if Israel had merited eleven days, they would have entered the land, but because they spoiled their deeds, the Holy One, blessed be He, turned them around for forty days and forty years, as it is said, "In the number of the days I sat under them," etc. Rabbi Yochanan says if Israel had merited three days, they would have entered the land, etc. Rabbi Bena'ah says if Israel had merited one day, they would have entered the land, etc. Abba, etc., in the name of Abba Cohen Bardela says if Israel had merited, as soon as their hooves rose from the sea, they would have entered the land, as it is said, "Rise up, O Lord," etc. Thus far the Midrash. 

And at first glance, it is appropriate to understand that the reason the Holy One, blessed be He, turned them around for forty years against forty days was because of the sin of the spies. Therefore, why was their entry into the land of Israel delayed at first, especially since it was still before the sin of the spies? However, it is explained in the Midrashim of our Sages and in the Zohar on this Parashah that because of the sin of the sale of Joseph, exile in Egypt was decreed upon them, and their sin was not completely atoned for there, but the Holy One, blessed be He, remembered the merit of the Patriarchs and took Israel out of there with a mighty hand, for they could not delay as it is written. And this sin of the sale of Joseph caused them to be exiled from their land, etc., and caused the destruction of the Holy Temple, etc. (And so it is written in the Book of the Canna in the name of the Zohar.) It is thus clarified that because of the sin of the sale of Joseph, exile was decreed upon them, and perhaps their entry into the land was also delayed for this reason, for their sin was not atoned for upon leaving Egypt, and Israel did not achieve their peace to enter the land immediately. For this reason, the sending of the spies was delayed, and because of the sin of the spies, their entry into the land of Israel was further delayed for forty years, corresponding to the forty days of the spies' journey. Thus, it is evident that the chain of the sin of the spies was due to the sin of the sale of Joseph, even though from Heaven this matter was arranged for them, as explained in the words of our Sages that it was necessary for this to fulfill the decree of the covenant between the parts. Nevertheless, there was a flaw in the matter, and they needed atonement for it, as it is said in the holy Zohar (Parashat Vayechi) on the verse "If Joseph is hated by us, etc., may it be so that he will respond to them," and he says, "He will return to us all the evil," and they were distressed to the extent that Joseph was distressed because of them, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the consequences of Israel's sins, particularly the sin of selling Joseph, which led to their prolonged exile in Egypt and delayed entry into the Promised Land. It emphasizes that had the Israelites not sinned, they could have entered the land much sooner, with various opinions on the duration of this delay. The text highlights the interconnectedness of sins and their repercussions, illustrating that the sin of the spies was a continuation of the unresolved guilt from the sale of Joseph, necessitating atonement. Ultimately, it reflects on the divine justice and the need for repentance to rectify past transgressions.

passage_content: וז"ש להם יוסף מרגלים אתם, שהשיג את הנולד שיגרם ע"ו מכירתו השתלשלות חטא המרגלים, ותלה החטא בהם לפי שעיקר שורש החטא הוא בראשיתו. וכמ"ש חכז"ל (סנהדרין ק"ב) מפני מה תלה הכתוב בירבעם מפני שהוא הי' תחלה לקלקלה, וע"ד שביארנו לעיל במאמה"כ אל תזכור לנו עונות ראשונים דהכל בתר רישא גרירא, וע"כ אמר להם מרגלים אתם, שגרמתם במעשיכם לחטא המרגלים ולחורבן הנורא הנצמח על ודם לישראל דור המדבר, והשבטים הקדושים התחרטו על מכירתו ועשו תשובה ע"ז, כמשה"כ אבל אשמים אנחנו על אחינו וגו' על כן באה אלינו הצרה הזאת, אבל הי' סיבה מאת ה' להעלים מהם פנימיות הדיבורים שרמז יוסף אליהם, כמו שביארנו (בדברנו לעיל פ' ויגש) שהי' רצון הבוי"ת שלא יכירוהו, עד שיסתבב הענין שירדו כולם למצרים ונתקיימו חלומותיו, ועד שישלמו הכ"ב שנים שנגזר על יעקב שיצטער בשביל שלא קיים כיבוד אב, וע"כ היתה סיבה מהשי"ת שלא שמו על לבם לחקור בפנימיות הדיבורים אלא קבלו אותן כפשוטן ולזה השיבו לא היו עבדיך מרגלים ו)עייש"ד לעיל פ' ויגש).
translation: And this is what Joseph said to them: "You are spies," for he understood the consequence that would arise from his sale, the unfolding of the sin of the spies, and he attributed the sin to them because the root of the sin is in its beginning. As our sages have said (Sanhedrin 102), "Why did the scripture attribute it to Jeroboam? Because he was the first to cause the corruption." And as we explained above regarding the verse, "Do not remember to us the iniquities of our forefathers," for everything follows the beginning. Therefore, he said to them, "You are spies," for you caused through your actions the sin of the spies and the terrible destruction that arose from it for Israel in the wilderness. And the holy tribes regretted their sale and repented for it, as it is written, "But we are guilty concerning our brother..." Therefore, this distress has come upon us. However, it was a reason from the Holy One, blessed be He, to conceal from them the inner meanings of the words that Joseph hinted to them, as we explained (in our discussion above in Parashat Vayigash) that it was the will of the Creator that they should not recognize him, until the matter would unfold that they all descended to Egypt and his dreams would be fulfilled, and until the twenty-two years that were decreed upon Jacob for his suffering due to not fulfilling the honor of his father. Therefore, there was a reason from the Holy One, blessed be He, that they did not pay attention to investigate the inner meanings of the words but accepted them at face value, and thus they replied, "Your servants are not spies."
summary: יוסף מאשים את האחים במעשי מרגלים, כי חטא המרגלים נגרם מהשתלשלות מכירתו, שהיא שורש החטא. הוא מציין שהאחים התחרטו על מכירתו והכירו באשמתם, אך ה' רצה להסתיר מהם את פנימיות הדברים כדי לממש את חלומותיו. בכך, הם לא חקרו את כוונותיו של יוסף וקיבלו את דבריו כפשוטם, מה שמוביל לתהליך הגשמת הגזירה על יעקב.

passage_content: ויתורץ בזה קושית המהרש"א ז"ל (בקושיא א') ומה ענין המרגלים לשבט לוי, הרי לא בי' במרגלים משבט לוי, ואם על שבט שמעון אמר, קשה למה נקטו יותר משאר י' שבעים, ולדרכינו א"ש כי השיג ועאע"ה בסודן של דברים שמחטא מכירת יוסף יסתבב חטא המרגלים, ולזה הוכיח לשמעון ולוי על חטא המרגלים לפי שהם היו העיקר במכירתו, והכל נמשך אחר ההתחלה וחטא הראשון כנ"ל.
translation: And this resolves the question of the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed (in question A): What is the connection of the spies to the tribe of Levi, since there were no spies from the tribe of Levi? And if it refers to the tribe of Simeon, it is difficult why they were mentioned more than the other ten of the seventy. According to our approach, it is understood that he grasped, and may peace be upon him, the secret of the matter that the sin of the sale of Joseph is intertwined with the sin of the spies. Therefore, he reproached Simeon and Levi for the sin of the spies, as they were the main ones in his sale, and everything follows from the beginning and the first sin, as mentioned.
summary: The passage addresses the question of why the tribe of Levi is mentioned in connection with the sin of the spies, despite not having representatives among them. It suggests that the sin of the spies is intrinsically linked to the earlier sin of selling Joseph, implicating both Simeon and Levi as central figures in that transgression. This connection highlights the idea that all subsequent sins are rooted in the original sin, emphasizing the theological concept of collective responsibility and the continuity of sin within the narrative of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל עפ"י דרך הרד"ק ז"ל שביאר כל הענין על מעשה שכם, ואפשר שמשורש אותו החטא נמשך ונסתבב עוד חטאים ועונשים על ישראל ר"ל, וכבר ביארנו שהקפדת יע"א עליהם היתה לטעם כי לא הגיע עדיין זמנם לכבוש את הארץ, ובודאי שכל מעשיהם של השבטים הק' היתה לשם שמים, אעפ"כ פגם הי' בדבר שמצינו שהקפיד יעקב על מעשיהם, ואמר עכרתם אותי להבאישנו ביושב הארץ וגו' ואני מתי מספר ונאספו עלי והכוני ונשמדתי אני וביתי, ובאמת לא הי' מקום ליראתו בשביל עצמו ובניו, כי הי' רב חילי' וקדושתו ויראו מפניו כל יושבי הארץ, כמ"ש ויהי תחת אלקים על הערים אשר סביבותיהם ולא רדפו אחר בני יעקב, ואף שי"ל עפ"י פשוטו שהי' יעאע"ה מתיירא שמא יגרום החטא ויתמעעו זכיותיו, כדרך הצדיקים שאין בוטחים בזכותם ובמעשוהם הטובים, אבל מ"מ קשה למה נכתב בתוה"ק מאמר זה ונאספו עלי והכוני ונשמדתי וגו' כיון שסוף כל סוף לא נתקיים דבר זה, וקמי שמיא גליא שלא יכלו לנגוע ביעקב וזרעו, אמנם כל דיבוריו של יעאע"ה ויראתו היתה בשביל דורות העתידים, שהשיג יעאע"ה שיגיע משורש חטא זה קלקול לדורות הבאים. וכתב בס' גליא רזיא כשקמו בני יעקב והרגו בשכם וכו', עלה ס"מ לפני ב"ד עליון וביקש דין על בני יעקב וכו', והי' קטרוג גדול מצד שרי אומה"ע עליהם, אלא שהי' רב חיליהון ולגודל קדושתם וזכותם לא מצאה הקטרוג מקום לחול עליהם, אולם שורש הפגם נמשך לדורות, ואפשר שגם זאת גרם שלא זכו ישראל ליכנס לא"י מיד, ונסתבב לידם חטא המרגלים ועוד, ולזה הוכיח יעאע"ה לשמעון ולוי לפי שהם היו העיקר במכירת יוסף ובמעשה שכם, ומזה נסתבב חטא המרגלים.
translation: And similarly, one can say according to the way of the Radak, may his memory be blessed, who explained the entire matter regarding the act of Shechem, and it is possible that the root of that sin extended and caused further sins and punishments upon Israel, Heaven forbid. And we have already explained that Jacob's concern was because their time had not yet come to conquer the land. Certainly, all the actions of the holy tribes were for the sake of Heaven; nevertheless, there was a flaw in the matter, as we find that Jacob was particular about their actions, and he said, "You have troubled me to make me odious among the inhabitants of the land... and I am few in number, and they gathered against me and struck me, and I and my house were destroyed." In truth, there was no reason for his fear for himself and his sons, for he had great might and holiness, and all the inhabitants of the land feared him, as it is said, "And he was under God over the cities that were around them," and they did not pursue the sons of Jacob. Even though one might say according to the simple meaning that he, may peace be upon him, was afraid that perhaps the sin would cause his merits to diminish, as is the way of the righteous who do not rely on their merits and good deeds, nevertheless, it is difficult to understand why this statement was written in the Holy Torah, "and they gathered against me and struck me, and I was destroyed," since ultimately this did not come to pass, and before Heaven it is clear that they could not touch Jacob and his seed. However, all of Jacob's words and his fear were for the sake of future generations, for Jacob foresaw that from the root of this sin, corruption would come to future generations. And it is written in the book "Gilyon Raziyah" that when the sons of Jacob rose and killed in Shechem, etc., the Accuser ascended before the Heavenly Court and sought judgment against the sons of Jacob, etc., and there was a great accusation from the ministers of the nations against them, but their might was great, and due to their holiness and merit, the accusation found no place to take effect upon them. However, the root of the flaw extended to generations, and it is possible that this also caused that Israel did not merit to enter the Land of Israel immediately, and the sin of the spies came upon them, and for this reason Jacob reproved Simeon and Levi, as they were the main ones in the sale of Joseph and in the act of Shechem, and from this the sin of the spies ensued.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the sin of Shechem and its lasting effects on the Jewish people. It emphasizes that although the actions of the tribes were intended for the sake of Heaven, Jacob's concern stemmed from the potential repercussions for future generations. The text highlights that Jacob's fears were not for himself but were prophetic, recognizing that the root of this sin would lead to further transgressions, such as the sin of the spies. Ultimately, it suggests that the consequences of these actions delayed Israel's entry into the Promised Land and perpetuated a cycle of sin and punishment throughout history.

passage_content: וזה שאמר בסודם אל תבא נפשי וגו', ולפי פשוטו וכוונתו הנגלה קאי על מכירת יוסף ומעשה דשכם, כפי' האוהחה"ק והרד"ק ז"ל אבל בסודן של דברים רמז יעאע"ה על כל אותן החטאים שנסתבבו בסובתן, דהיינו חטא המרגלים ועדת קרח ומעשה זמרי, וכבר נתבאר בדברנו במקו"א כו לא הי' מעשה זמרי ענין תאו' כפשוטו, אלא שטעה בחזיונו כמבואר בספה"ק, עיין מ"ש בס' עשרה מאמרות להרמ"ע זלל"ה, כשנשאת דינה לשמעון ילדה לו את זמרי שהוא גלגול שכם וכזבי הוא גלגול דינה וכו', ונתקן לבסוף ע"י ר' עקיבא שהי' גלגול שמעון ונשא אשת טורנוסרופוס גלגול כזבי עיי"ש. עכ"פ כל דברי חז"ל שרירים וקיימים והתכוין יעאע"ה כדברי כולם. על מעשה דשכם ומכירת יוסף. והחטאים שנגרמו בסובתן מעשה דמרגלים וזמרי וכו', וא"ש מה שבמדרש ילקוט מרכיב כולם יחדיו דפתח במרגלים וסיים במעשה זמרי, ולדרכנו הנ"ל כל אלה מקושרים יחדיו, ושורש כולם נמשך מחטא מכירת יוסף ומעשה דשכם, וע"כ הוכיח יעקב אבינו בזה לשמעון ולוי יותר משאר השבעים.
translation: And this is what is said, "In their secret, do not come my soul," etc. According to its simple meaning and its revealed intention, it refers to the sale of Joseph and the matter of Shechem, as explained by the holy commentators and the Radak, may their memory be blessed. But in the secret of the matter, it alludes, may it be His will, to all those sins that were entangled in their intoxication, namely the sin of the spies, the congregation of Korach, and the act of Zimri. It has already been explained in our discussions in various places that the act of Zimri was not a matter of lust in its simple sense, but rather he was mistaken in his vision, as is explained in the holy books. Refer to what is written in the book "Ten Utterances" by the Ramak, may his memory be blessed, that when Dina was married to Shimon, she bore him Zimri, who is the reincarnation of Shechem, and Kozbi is the reincarnation of Dina, etc. Ultimately, it was rectified by Rabbi Akiva, who was the reincarnation of Shimon and married the wife of Turnus Rufus, the reincarnation of Kozbi, see there. In any case, all the words of our Sages are valid and enduring, and the intention, may it be His will, aligns with all of them regarding the matter of Shechem and the sale of Joseph, and the sins that resulted from their intoxication, the act of the spies and Zimri, etc. It is clear why in the Midrash Yalkut they connect them all together, starting with the spies and concluding with the act of Zimri, for according to our aforementioned path, all these are interconnected, and their root all stems from the sin of the sale of Joseph and the act of Shechem. Therefore, Jacob our father rebuked Shimon and Levi more than the other seventy.
summary: The passage discusses the interconnectedness of various sins in Jewish history, particularly focusing on the sale of Joseph and the actions of Shimon and Levi. It suggests that these events, including the sins of the spies and Zimri, are rooted in the original sin of the sale of Joseph, indicating a deeper spiritual and theological significance. The text emphasizes that all these transgressions are linked, with Jacob's rebuke of Shimon and Levi serving as a critical reflection on their actions. Ultimately, it highlights the idea that these historical events and their consequences are part of a larger divine narrative.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר להשוות דברי הגמרא דסנהדרין הנ"ל עם דברי המד"ר דבגמ' דרשי חז"ל בסודם אל תבא נפשי אלו מרגלים, בקהלם וגו' על מעשה קרח, ובמד"ר דרשוהו על מעשה זמרי ומעשה קרח, ובילקוט מרכיב כולהו כחדא, ויתבאר עפי"ד הרמב"ן ז"ל (בר"פ קרח) וז"ל הנה ישראל בהיותם במדבר סיני לא אירע להם שום רעה, כי גם בדבר העגל שהי' החטא גדול ומפורסם, היו המתים מועטים ונצולו בתפלתו של משה, שהתנפל מ' יום ומ' לילה לבקש עליהם רחמים, והנה היו אוהבים אותו כנפשם ושומעים אליו, ואלו הי' אדם מורד על משה בזמן ההוא היו העם סוקלין אותו, ולכן סבל קרח גדולת אהרן וסבלו הבכורים מעלת הלוים וכל מעשיו של משה, אבל בבואם אל מדבר פארן ונשרפו באש תבערה וכו' וכאשר חטאו במרגלים לא התפלל משה עליהם וכו'. ונגזר על כל העם שיתמו במדבר ושם ימותו, אז היתה נפש כל העם מרה, והיו אומרים בלבם כי יבואו להם בדברי משה תקלות, ואז מצא קרח לחלוק על מעשיו, וחשב כו ישמעו אליו העם, וזה טעם להמיתנו במדבר וכו' עכ"ד הרמב"ן ז"ל. נמצא מבואר דמחלקותו של קרח נמשך בסיבת חטא המרגלים, והנה כמו"כ מעשה זמרי מבואר בספה"ק שלא נתכוין לחטא של תאווה כ"א טעה בחזיונו, אבל איך שיהי' יצא לחלוק על משרע"ה, כמבואר בדברי רז"ל ששאל זו אסורה או מותרת את"ל אסורה בת יתרו מי התיר לך, ולא הי' במציאות למרוד על משרע"ה כ"א אחר מעשה המרגלים כדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל נמצא דכל אלה מקושרים כאחד, וחטא המרגלים הו' סיבה להם.
translation: And even if we say in another way to compare the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin mentioned above with the words of the Midrash that in the Gemara the Sages interpreted in their secret, "Let not my soul come into their council," referring to the spies, in their gathering, etc., regarding the matter of Korach, and in the Midrash they interpreted it regarding the matter of Zimri and the matter of Korach, and in the Yalkut they combine them all as one. And it will be explained according to the words of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Korach), and he said: "Behold, Israel, while they were in the wilderness of Sinai, did not experience any evil, for even in the matter of the golden calf, which was a great and well-known sin, the dead were few and they were saved through the prayer of Moses, who fell down for forty days and forty nights to ask for mercy for them, and behold, they loved him as their own soul and listened to him. And if a person had rebelled against Moses at that time, the people would have stoned him. Therefore, Korach bore the greatness of Aaron and the firstborns bore the superiority of the Levites and all the deeds of Moses. But when they came to the wilderness of Paran and were burned by the fire of the burning, etc., and when they sinned with the spies, Moses did not pray for them, etc. And it was decreed upon all the people that they would perish in the wilderness and there they would die. Then the souls of all the people were bitter, and they said in their hearts that they would encounter troubles from the words of Moses, and then Korach found an opportunity to dispute his actions, and he thought that the people would listen to him. And this is the reason for us to be killed in the wilderness, etc." Thus said the Ramban, may his memory be blessed. It is clear that Korach's dispute stemmed from the sin of the spies, and likewise, the matter of Zimri is explained in the holy books that he did not intend to sin out of desire but rather erred in his vision. However it may be, he went out to dispute against Moshe Rabbeinu, as is explained in the words of our Sages, who asked, "Is this forbidden or permitted?" If you say it is forbidden, who permitted you from Yitro? And it was not possible to rebel against Moshe Rabbeinu except after the act of the spies, according to the words of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed. Thus, all these are connected as one, and the sin of the spies was the cause for them.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the rebellion of Korach and the sin of the spies, emphasizing that the latter's failure led to a loss of faith in Moses' leadership. It highlights that during their time in the desert, the Israelites experienced divine protection, but after the sin of the spies, they became disillusioned and resentful, which allowed for dissent against Moses. The text suggests that both Korach's and Zimri's actions were influenced by the collective trauma of the spies' sin, illustrating a deeper theological insight into the consequences of communal sin and the fragility of faith. Ultimately, it portrays how the challenges faced by the Israelites were intertwined, with the sin of the spies serving as a catalyst for further rebellion.
