passage_content: ואפשר דחטא המרגלים נמשך מחטא מכירת יוסף עפומ"ד במדרש רבה (פ' וישב) עה"פ ויאמרו ואיש אל אחיו הנה בעל החלומות הלזה וגו' א"ר לוי זה עתיד להשיאם לבעלים, ופי' המפרשים שכוונו על ירבעם העתיד לצאת ממנו שישיא את ישראל להימשך אחר ע"ז ובשביל כך דנוהו למיתה על שם העתיד (עיין בדברנו פ' וישב ביאור הענין באריכות) ואולי כי טעותם של המרגלים היתה ג"כ עד"ז, עפי"ד היפ"ת (פ' מקץ) שהקשה מה צורך הי' בבנין בית שני שלא הי' נצחי וסופו ליחרב, ולכאורה הי' טוב יותר להמתין על בנין המקוה שתהי' נצחית ועומדת לעד. ומה בצע בבנינו ולסבול אח"כ מחרבנו עיי"ש שהאריך בתירוצו, ובאמת קושיא זו יקשה כמו"כ על בנין בית ראשון שלא הי' נצחי, וכבר ביארנו במקו"א עפי"ד ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (פ' בשלח) כו הב' מקדשות שנחרבו בעוה"ר לא היו פעולה ריקנית ח"ו, כ"א צורך בהם להכנת בית השלישי המקוה בב"א, כי הארץ הגשומה הלזו א"א שתסבול קדושת בית המקדש, כ"א אחר שהוכן טבע הארץ ע"ו קדושת ב' המקדשות הראשונים עיי"ש שהסביר בנועם דבריו עפ"י משל. ואולי כי מזה נמשך טעותם של המרגלים כי היו אנשים צדיקים נשיאי ישראל שנתמנו עפ"י ה', אלא שטעו בחזיונם שכאשר באו לארץ ישראל הרגישו בקדושתה שאינה נצחית ועתידה ליחרב וישראל יגלו ממנה, ואולי לטעם זה רצו להניא את לב בני ישראל שלא יעלו לירשוה, כי מה בצע לסבול צער חרבנו, יותר עוב להמתין עד עת קץ וגאולה הנצחית, אבל איך שיהי' לא היו צודקים בטענותם, כי היו' צריכים לבטל דעתם לדעתו של משרע"ה שהי' נביא אמת ונצטוה מפי הגבורה לומר לישראל עלה רש וגו', ואין להתחכם נגד גזירתו של מקום ית"ש.
translation: And it is possible that the sin of the spies stemmed from the sin of the sale of Joseph, as stated in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Vayeshev) on the verse "And they said to one another, 'Here comes this dreamer'" (Genesis 37:19). Rabbi Levi said, "He is destined to lead them to their masters," and the commentators explain that they were referring to Jeroboam, who would come from him and lead Israel to follow idolatry. For this reason, they condemned him to death on account of the future (see our discussion in Parashat Vayeshev for a detailed explanation of the matter). Perhaps the error of the spies was also similar to this, according to the question raised in Parashat Miketz, which asked what was the need for the building of the Second Temple, which was not eternal and would ultimately be destroyed. At first glance, it would have been better to wait for the construction of the Mikdash that would be eternal and stand forever. What benefit is there in its construction if we must then suffer its destruction? There, he elaborated on his answer, and indeed this question could also be posed regarding the building of the First Temple, which was not eternal. We have already explained elsewhere according to the words of the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed (Parashat Beshalach), that the two sanctuaries that were destroyed in our times were not a futile act, Heaven forbid, but rather necessary for the preparation of the Third Temple, which is to come. For this physical land cannot bear the sanctity of the Holy Temple except after the nature of the land has been prepared through the sanctity of the two previous Temples, as he explained sweetly in his words through a parable. And perhaps from this arose the error of the spies, for they were righteous men, leaders of Israel, appointed by God, but they erred in their vision. When they came to the Land of Israel, they sensed its sanctity, which is not eternal and is destined to be destroyed, and that Israel would be exiled from it. Perhaps for this reason they wanted to dissuade the hearts of the children of Israel from ascending to inherit it, for what benefit is there in suffering the pain of its destruction? It would be better to wait until the end of days and the eternal redemption. However, regardless of how it may be, they were not correct in their claims, for they should have nullified their opinions in favor of the opinion of Moshe Rabbeinu, who was a true prophet and was commanded by the Holy One, blessed be He, to tell Israel, "Go up and inherit" (Numbers 13:30), and one should not be clever against the decree of the Omnipresent, may He be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the sin of the spies as stemming from the earlier sin of selling Joseph, suggesting that their error was rooted in a misunderstanding of the permanence of the Land of Israel. The spies, despite being righteous leaders, misjudged the sanctity of the land, believing it was destined for destruction and thus discouraged the Israelites from entering. This reflects a broader theological insight that the temporary nature of the First and Second Temples served a divine purpose in preparing for the eventual Third Temple. Ultimately, the spies' failure to accept Moses' prophetic guidance highlights the importance of adhering to divine will, even in the face of perceived challenges.

passage_content: ומבואר בדרז"ל שחורבן בית ראשון הי' בעון ע"ז, וירבעם הי' הראשון שהתחיל להמשיך את ישראל לע"ז ונתלה הקלקלה בו, כאמרז"ל (סנהדרין ק"ב ע"ב) א"ר יוחנן קלות שעשה אחאב כחמורות שעשה ירבעם, ומפני מה תלה הכתוב בירבעם מפני שהוא הי' תחלה לקלקלה, נמצא כי הי' הגורם לחורבן בית ראשון, ומזה נצמח טעותם של המרגלים כנ"ל, ואולי למדו לעשות כן ממה שרצו שמעון ולוי להרוג את יוסף בשביל העתיד, כדי למנוע השתלשלות ירבעם שעתיד להחטיא את ישראל בע"ז, ומזה נמשכה טעותם של המרגלים למנוע כל הענין לטעם זה, ומתורץ קושית המהרש"א דמה ענין מרגלים לשבט לוי, שהרי לא הוו עם המרגלים משבט לוי וכו', ולדרכינו שורש הענין נמשך מחטא מכירת יוסף, וא"ש דברי הגמ'.
translation: It is explained in the teachings of our Sages that the destruction of the First Temple was due to the sin of idolatry, and Jeroboam was the first to lead Israel into idolatry, and the blame is placed upon him, as our Sages said (Sanhedrin 102b), Rabbi Yochanan said: The light sins that Achav committed were like the severe sins that Jeroboam committed. And why does the scripture attribute it to Jeroboam? Because he was the first to cause the corruption. Thus, he was the cause of the destruction of the First Temple, and from this arose the error of the spies, as mentioned above. Perhaps they learned to do so from what Shimon and Levi wanted to do to kill Yosef for the future, in order to prevent the chain of Jeroboam who was destined to lead Israel astray into idolatry. From this, the error of the spies continued to prevent the entire matter for this reason. This resolves the question of the Maharsha regarding what connection the spies have to the tribe of Levi, since they were not from the tribe of Levi, etc. According to our path, the root of the matter extends from the sin of the sale of Yosef, and this clarifies the words of the Gemara.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the First Temple's destruction, attributing it to the sin of idolatry initiated by Jeroboam. It suggests that Jeroboam's actions set a precedent for future transgressions, including the mistakes of the spies, who may have been influenced by the desire to prevent a future where Jeroboam would lead Israel astray. The text connects these events to the earlier sin of selling Joseph, indicating a continuous thread of moral failure that leads to communal consequences. This highlights the Hasidic view of interconnectedness in sin and its repercussions across generations.

passage_content: ולפרש דברי המדרש הובא ברש"י ז"ל בסודם אל תבא נפשי זה מעשה זמרי בקהלם אל תחד כבודי זה מעשה קרח, ולכאורה מעשה קורח הו' מוקדם בזמן טובא (עיין לעיל קושיא ב') אפשר לתרץ עפי"ד הגמ' (סנהדרין פ"ב ע"ב) א"ר יוחנן ה' שמות יש לו זמרי ובן סלוא ושאול ובן הכנענית ושלומיאל בן צורישדי, וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א וז"ל: ודע דלפי הדרש צ"ל דלכל הפחות הי' זמרי במעשה ההוא בן ר"נ שנה, דקא חשיב לי' לשאול בן הכנענית מיורדי מצרים ורד"ו שנה היו במצרים ובשנת מ' ליציאתם נהרג זמרי הרי ר"נ עכ"ד. ובפ' ויגש הוא נמנה בע' נפש שבאו למצרים עם יעקב ויתכן לפי"ז כי בשעה שהוכיח יעאע"ה לשמעון ולוי בסודם אל תבא נפשי ורמז על מעשה זמרי כדרשת חז"ל, הי' זמרי עומד שם לפניו או סמוך לו. אלא שלא גילה יעאע"ה בפירוש שהתכוין עליו, כי מילתא דתליא בבחירה לא ניתנה להאמר בהתגלות כ"א בבחי' המחשבה וע"ד הרמז כידוע, וז"ש בסודם אל תבא נפשי שהרמז בו הוא בחי' סוד ולא ניתנה להיגלות, ועכ"פ ל"ק כלל מה שהקדים לרמוז על מעשה זמרי לפני מעשה קרח, דדרך הרגיל בבנ"א להקדים הענין העומד לפניו ורואהו, יותר ממה שנעלמה מראייתו אף שמוקדם בזמן, ואפ"ל עוד דלפי שחטא זמרי הי' נאחז בפגם הברית, ע"כ תקיף לי' להזכירו תחלה, לפי שהוא היסוד לכל המידות כידוע.
translation: And to explain the words of the Midrash, it is brought in Rashi, may his memory be blessed: "In their secret, let not my soul come" refers to the act of Zimri; "Let not my honor be united" refers to the act of Korach. And seemingly, the act of Korach occurred much earlier in time (see above, question 2). It is possible to answer according to the words of the Gemara (Sanhedrin 82b) where Rabbi Yochanan said: Zimri has five names: Zimri son of Salu, Shaul son of the Canaanite, and Shlomi'el son of Tzurishaddai. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the first part: "And know that according to the interpretation, at the very least, Zimri was 25 years old at that incident, for he counts Shaul son of the Canaanite among those who descended from Egypt, and they were 210 years in Egypt, and in the 40th year of their exodus, Zimri was killed, hence he was 25." Thus, in Parashat Vayigash, he is counted among the 70 souls who came to Egypt with Jacob. It is possible, according to this, that at the time when Yaakov Avinu rebuked Shimon and Levi, "In their secret, let not my soul come," and hinted at the act of Zimri as the Sages have interpreted, Zimri was standing there before him or close to him. However, Yaakov Avinu did not explicitly reveal that he intended him, for a matter that depends on choice is not meant to be revealed openly, but rather in the aspect of thought and in the manner of allusion, as is known. Therefore, it is said, "In their secret, let not my soul come," that the allusion therein is in the aspect of secret and is not meant to be revealed. And in any case, it is not at all difficult why he alluded to the act of Zimri before the act of Korach, for it is the way of a person to first mention the matter that is before him and that he sees, more than that which is hidden from his sight, even if it is earlier in time. And it can also be said that since Zimri sinned, he was caught in the blemish of the covenant; therefore, it was fitting for him to be mentioned first, as it is the foundation of all attributes, as is known.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the actions of Zimri and Korach, emphasizing that Zimri's sin, rooted in the breach of the covenant, is highlighted first due to its foundational significance in shaping character traits. It suggests that the mention of Zimri before Korach reflects a deeper understanding of human choice and the hidden nature of sin, which is often not revealed explicitly but rather hinted at through subtle allusions. The text underscores the idea that the acknowledgment of sin is essential for spiritual growth and moral rectitude within the Hasidic framework.

passage_content: ולהסביר הענין מה שהתפלל יע"א שלא יזכר שמו על מעשה זמרי ובמחלקותו של קרח, כ"א על הטובה כשותייחסו על הדוכן, נל"פ עפי"מ דאיתא בגמ' (שבת נ"ה ע"א) שמואל אמר תמה זכות אבות ור' יוחנן אמר תחון זכות אבות וכו', מאימתי תמה זכות אבות אמר רב מימות הושע בן בארי וכו', ושמואל אמר מימי חזאל וכו' ור' יוחנן אמר מימי חזקי', וכתבו התוס' אומר ר"ת דזכות אבות תמה אבל ברית אבות לא תמה, דהא כתיב וזכרתי את בריתי יעקב אף לאחר גלות, ואנן אין מזכירין זכות אבות אלא הברית וכו', ולר"י נראה דלא פליגי שמואל ור' יוחנן, אלא שמואל קאמר דלרשעים תמה אבל לצדיקים לא תמה, ובצדיקים איירי ר' יוחנן ועל זה אנו סומכין להזכיר זכות אבות עכ"ד התוס', ודבריהם ז"ל צריך ביאור, לשיטת רבינו תם שמחלק בין זכות אבות לברית אבות קשה הלא מצינו בהרבה מקומות שמזכירין זכות אבות וכדאיתא במשנה פ"ג דיומא אמר להם הממונה וכו' האיר כל פני המזרח עד שבחברון וכתבו בירושלמי (פ"ג ה"א) דכדי להזכיר זכות אבות מזכירין חברון, ועוד בהרבה מקומות, ולשיטת הר"י דלצדיקים לא תמה, ועל זה אנו סומכין להזכיר זכות אבות, לכאורה בודאי לא יתכן שנחזיק עצמינו לצדיקים, כמ"ש בתפלה שאין אנו עזו פנים וכו' לומר לפניך וכו' צדיקים אנחנו ולא חטאנו, וא"כ איך אנו יכולים להזכיר זכות אבות, ופלוגתא זו איתא גם במד"ר (סו"פ בחקותי פ' ל"ו) וביפ"ת שם הביא שיטת ר"ת ור"י ומקשה עליהם חבילות קושיות עיי"ש. והוא פי' דמה שאמרו זכות אבות תמה, היינו שיהי' הצלה גמורה בזכות אבות זה תמה, אבל אעפ"כ הצלה פורתא הוי עיי"ש. ובאמת גם לפירושו קשה ואיכא למיפרך טובא ולא נאריך פה, ובעיקר קשה דהוי נגד שיטת ר"ת ור"י בעלי תוספות.
translation: And to explain the matter of what he prayed, may it be His will, that his name should not be mentioned regarding the act of Zimri and in the dispute of Korach, but rather for the good that will be related on the platform, we can learn according to what is stated in the Gemara (Shabbat 55a) that Shmuel said that the merit of the ancestors has ceased, and Rabbi Yochanan said that the merit of the ancestors is still present, etc. From when has the merit of the ancestors ceased? Rav said from the days of Hoshea ben Beeri, etc., and Shmuel said from the days of Hazael, etc., and Rabbi Yochanan said from the days of Chizkiyahu. And the Tosafot wrote, according to R. Tam, that the merit of the ancestors has ceased, but the covenant of the ancestors has not ceased, for it is written, "And I will remember My covenant with Jacob" even after exile, and we do not mention the merit of the ancestors except for the covenant, etc. And according to Rabbi Yochanan, it seems that Shmuel and Rabbi Yochanan do not disagree, but rather Shmuel says that for the wicked the merit has ceased, but for the righteous it has not ceased, and Rabbi Yochanan is discussing the righteous, and on this we rely to mention the merit of the ancestors. Thus far the Tosafot. And their words require explanation. According to the opinion of R. Tam, who distinguishes between the merit of the ancestors and the covenant of the ancestors, it is difficult, for we find in many places that the merit of the ancestors is mentioned, as it is stated in the Mishnah (Yoma 3:3) that the overseer said, etc., "The entire eastern horizon was illuminated until Hebron," and it is written in the Jerusalem Talmud (Yoma 3:1) that in order to mention the merit of the ancestors, they mention Hebron, and also in many other places. And according to the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan, that for the righteous it has not ceased, and on this we rely to mention the merit of the ancestors, it seems that it is certainly not possible for us to consider ourselves as righteous, as we say in prayer that we are not brazen-faced, etc., to say before You, etc., "We are righteous and we have not sinned." If so, how can we mention the merit of the ancestors? And this dispute is also found in the Midrash (Parashat Bechukotai, Parashah 36), and in Yefet there he brought the opinion of R. Tam and Rabbi Yochanan and challenges them with bundles of questions, see there. And the explanation is that what they said, "The merit of the ancestors has ceased," means that there will be complete salvation through the merit of the ancestors, this has ceased, but nevertheless, a partial salvation exists, see there. And indeed, even according to his explanation, it is difficult, and there are many challenges to be made, and we will not elaborate here, and fundamentally it is difficult as it contradicts the opinion of R. Tam and Rabbi Yochanan, the masters of Tosafot.
summary: The passage discusses the theological debate regarding the status of the merit of the Patriarchs (Zchut Avot) in relation to the covenant (Brit Avot) and its implications for prayer. It highlights differing opinions among sages about whether the merit of the Patriarchs has ceased, particularly for the righteous versus the wicked. The text emphasizes that while the complete salvation through the merit of the Patriarchs may have ended, there remains a possibility for partial salvation. This reflects a deeper understanding of the relationship between divine mercy, human righteousness, and the enduring nature of the covenant with the Patriarchs.

passage_content: וסיום דברי המד"ר שם א"ר אחא לעולם זכות אבות קיימת, לעולם מזכירין ואומרין כי אדל רחום ה' אלקיך לא ירפך ולא ישחיתך ולא ישכח את ברית אבותיך וגו' וכתב היפ"ת שר' אחא חולק על האמוראים הקודמים, שהרי הם סוברים תמה זכות אבות עכ"ד. אולם לכאורה אין נראה מלשון המדרש כן דא"כ הול"ל ר' אחא אומר, ומדנקט א"ר אחא נראה שאינו חולק עליהם, וצ"ב להשוות דברי רז"ל שלא יהי' פלוגתא ביניהם, גם לשיטת ר"ת שמחלק בין זכות אבות לברית אבות, לכאורה יקשה איך הביא ר' אחא ראי' שזכות אבות לא תמה מדכתיב ולא ישכח את ברית אבותיך, דהרי ברית אבות ודאי לא תמה לדברי הכל, ולי קשה עוד קושיא עצומה הלא מקרא מלא דיבר הכתוב ועושה חסד לאלפים לאוהבי ולשומרי מצותי ואיך אפשר לומר תמה זכות אבות.
translation: And the conclusion of the words of the Midrash there states: Rabbi Acha said, "The merit of the ancestors is always present; we always mention and say that 'the Lord, your God, is a merciful God; He will not forsake you, nor destroy you, nor forget the covenant of your ancestors,' etc." And the Yefeh Toar writes that Rabbi Acha disagrees with the earlier Amoraim, who hold that the merit of the ancestors has ceased. However, it does not seem from the language of the Midrash that this is so, for it should have said, "Rabbi Acha says," and since it states "Rabbi Acha said," it appears that he does not disagree with them. It is necessary to reconcile the words of our Sages so that there will not be a dispute among them. Also, according to the opinion of Rashi, who distinguishes between the merit of the ancestors and the covenant of the ancestors, it seems difficult how Rabbi Acha brought a proof that the merit of the ancestors has not ceased from the verse "nor forget the covenant of your ancestors," for the covenant of the ancestors certainly has not ceased according to all opinions. Furthermore, I have another significant difficulty: the verse clearly states, "and He does kindness for thousands, for those who love Me and keep My commandments," and how can one say that the merit of the ancestors has ceased?
summary: The passage discusses the enduring nature of the merit of the ancestors (Zchut Avot) as articulated by Rabbi Acha, who asserts that this merit never ceases, contrasting with earlier Amoraim who believed it could diminish. Rabbi Acha's interpretation emphasizes that God's covenant with the ancestors remains intact, suggesting a distinction between the merit itself and the covenant. The text raises questions about the relationship between the merit of the ancestors and the covenant, highlighting the theological complexity of divine mercy and the enduring impact of the ancestors' righteousness on their descendants.

passage_content: ונראה לפרש עפי"מ שכתוב בספר הק' נועם אלימלך (בפ' קרח) ויקח קרח בן יצהר בן קהת בן לוו, פרש"י ולא הזכיר בן יעקב שביקש יעקב וכו', והיכן נזכר שמו על קרח בהתיחסם על הדוכן, ויל"ד על קושית רש"י ז"ל והיכן וכו' מה הו' קשה אם לא הי' נזכר שמו בשום מקום, ויש לפרש שרש"י ז"ל כיוון בקושייתו להורות לנו דבר גדול, כי הי' קשה לרש"י בהפסוק מה לנו ליחוסו בן יצהר וכו', אלא פירושו הוא שלקח את היחוס הזה למחלוקתו וחלק עליהם מחמת יחוסו, ולא זכר את יחוס של יעקב במחלוקתו שביקש רחמים וכו' ושורש הדבר שזכות אבות הוא דבר גדול ועומדת לו לאדם בשעה שהוא רוצה לעבוד את ה' שיהי' לו סייעתא דשמיא לעשות המצוה בשלימות, וזאת אינו אלא כשלא לקח מעלת היחוס לצד אחר, אזי בודאי עומדת לו לעבודת הבורא, וזה שפירש"י ולא הזכיר בן יעקב וכיון שלא נזכר שמו על המחלוקת אזי בודאי שנזכר שמו לעבודת הבורא, והיכן נזכר שמו ומפרש שנזכר שמו על הדוכן, עכדה"ק.
translation: And it seems appropriate to explain according to what is written in the holy book Noam Elimelech (in Parshat Korach) regarding the verse "And Korach the son of Yitzhar, the son of Kehat, the son of Levi took." Rashi explains that he did not mention the son of Jacob, whom Jacob requested, etc. And where is his name mentioned regarding Korach in relation to the dispute? It seems difficult on Rashi's question, and where, etc., what is difficult if his name was not mentioned anywhere? It can be explained that Rashi intended with his question to teach us something great, for it was difficult for Rashi in the verse, what is the significance of his lineage as the son of Yitzhar, etc. Rather, his explanation is that he took this lineage for his dispute and opposed them because of his lineage, and he did not mention the lineage of Jacob in his dispute, for he sought mercy, etc. The root of the matter is that the merit of the forefathers is a great thing and stands for a person at the time he wants to serve the Holy One, Blessed be He, that he should have divine assistance to fulfill the commandment in completeness. This is only when he does not take the merit of the lineage to the other side; then certainly it stands for him in the service of the Creator. And this is why Rashi explains that he did not mention the son of Jacob, and since his name was not mentioned in the dispute, then certainly his name was mentioned in the service of the Creator. And where is his name mentioned? It is explained that his name is mentioned regarding the dispute. Thus is the holy text.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of lineage in the context of Korach's rebellion, highlighting that while Korach is identified by his ancestry, the omission of Jacob's name signifies a deeper theological insight. Rashi's question emphasizes that true merit and divine assistance in serving God come from a pure intention, untainted by pride in one's lineage. The text suggests that when one does not leverage their ancestry for personal gain, they are more likely to receive divine support in their spiritual endeavors. Ultimately, the mention of Jacob's name in relation to service to God underscores the importance of humility and the proper use of one's heritage in the pursuit of holiness.

passage_content: וכתב האוהחה"ק פ' קרח עה"כ ויאמר אל ה' אל תפן אל מנחתם וגו' וזלה"ק: לצד שראה הפלאת שנאת הרשעים עמו וכו'. ולזה אמר אל ה' אל תפן אל מנחתם, והכוונה בזה לצד שאין לך אדם שאין בידו מצות ומע"ט, וכבר קדם לנו שאין הקב"ה מקפח שכר כל ברי' וברי' ואפילו של רשעים וכו' וצא ולמד משכר פסיעותיו של אותו רשע, אשר ע"כ חש משה שתעמוד להם איזה מצוה שבידם שהזכות תולה, לזה ביקש מה' וכו' יעיי"ש באורך, וכבר ביארתי (ויואל משה מאמר ב' סי' ג') דאף שכל מצותיו ומעשיו של רשע אינם רצויים לפני הקב"ה, מ"מ כך היא המדה לשלם להם שכר על כל מצוה, ויכולין בכח הזה להרע ח"ו לישראל, וזאת מביא להם אח"כ אבדון בעוה"ב ולפעמים גם בעוה"ז, וכמו שאמרו חכז"ל (סנהדרין צ"ו) על נבוכדנאצר מה שהצליח וכבש ירושלים הי' בשכר ד' פסיעות שרץ אחר כבודו ית' עיי"ש, ובודאי שאותו השכר שקבל הי' לרעתו ומרה אחריתו כו הקב"ה ינקום נקמת עמו מכל המצירין לישראל.
translation: And the holy author writes in Parshat Korach on the verse "And he said to the Lord, do not turn to their offering, etc." and thus he says: Because he saw the astonishing hatred of the wicked against him, etc. Therefore, he said to the Lord, do not turn to their offering, and the intention here is because there is no person who does not have mitzvot and good deeds in their hands, and it has already been established that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not withhold the reward of any creature, even that of the wicked, etc. Go and learn from the reward of the steps of that wicked one, for this is why Moses feared that there would be some mitzvah in their hands that would grant them merit; therefore, he requested from the Lord, etc. See there at length. And I have already explained (in Yoel Moshe, Article 2, Section 3) that although all the mitzvot and deeds of a wicked person are not desired before the Holy One, blessed be He, nevertheless, this is the measure to reward them for every mitzvah, and with this power, they can, Heaven forbid, harm Israel. And this brings them destruction in the World to Come and sometimes even in this world, as our sages, of blessed memory, said (Sanhedrin 96) regarding Nebuchadnezzar, that his success and conquest of Jerusalem was due to the reward for four steps he took in pursuit of His honor, see there. And certainly, that reward he received was to his detriment, and bitter will be his end. May the Holy One, blessed be He, take vengeance for His people from all those who oppress Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that even the wicked possess merits through their good deeds, which can lead to their success and cause harm to Israel. It emphasizes that God does not overlook any mitzvot, rewarding even the unrighteous for their actions, but ultimately, this reward can lead to their downfall in the afterlife. The text illustrates this with the example of Nebuchadnezzar, whose temporary success was a result of his minor merits, yet it ultimately brought him destruction. The overarching theme is the divine justice that balances reward and punishment, ensuring that God's vengeance will ultimately prevail against those who oppress Israel.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה דע"י שוש לרשע איזה זכות בשכר מצותיו שעשה ומסייע בו לרשעתו, נעשה לו למוקש כי עי"ז בא לאבדון נורא, וע"כ כשראו חז"ל קלקול הדורות שישתמשו בזכות אבות לרשעתם, גזרו אומר שתמה זכות אבות שלא יעמוד להם זכות אבות לרשעתם, ומן השמים מקיימים ומקבלים גזירתם כמ"ש חז"ל עה"פ לקל גומר עלי, אבל אה"נ דלרחמים ולטובה נשאר וקיים זכות אבות, וזהו כוונת הר"י שאמר דלרשעים תמה זכות אבות ולצדיקים לא תמה, ואין הכוונה לצדיקים ממש דא"כ איך אנו מתפללים על זכות אבות, אולם הכוונה שאם רוצין לעשות צדקות ולהתקרב להקב"ה במצות ומעש"ט יועיל זכות אבות להסתייע בזכותם, אבל לרשעים תמה זכות אבות, ר"ל שלא יסתייע להם למעשה רשעתם.
translation: The conclusion we draw from this is that through the merit of the wicked, what merit do they have in reward for the commandments they performed, which assist them in their wickedness? It becomes a snare for them, as through this they come to a terrible destruction. Therefore, when the Sages saw the corruption of the generations, that they would use the merit of the ancestors for their wickedness, they decreed that the merit of the ancestors should be nullified and not stand for their wickedness. And from Heaven, they uphold and accept their decree, as the Sages said regarding the verse "to the light, He completes upon me." However, it is indeed true that for mercy and for good, the merit of the ancestors remains and is upheld. This is the intention of Rabbi Yoel, who said that for the wicked, the merit of the ancestors is nullified, while for the righteous, it is not nullified. This does not mean the righteous in the absolute sense, for if so, how do we pray for the merit of the ancestors? Rather, the intention is that if they wish to perform acts of charity and draw closer to the Holy One, Blessed be He, through commandments and good deeds, the merit of the ancestors will assist them in their merit. But for the wicked, the merit of the ancestors is nullified, meaning it will not assist them in their wicked actions.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the merit of the ancestors (Zchut Avot) can be a double-edged sword; while it can support the righteous in their good deeds, it does not assist the wicked in their wrongdoing. The sages recognized the potential for the wicked to misuse this merit, leading to a decree that it would not aid them in their evil actions. However, the merit of the ancestors remains intact for the righteous, allowing them to draw upon it when striving to perform good deeds and connect with God. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that the merit of the ancestors is effective for those who seek to do good, while it is rendered ineffective for the wicked.

passage_content: ואפשר שזהו ג"כ כוונת ר"ת שמחלק בין זכות אבות לברית אבות, דהנה זכות מהני בין לטוב ובין לרע, דכך היא המדה שאין הקב"ה מקפח שכר כל ברי', וגם לרשעים משלם הקב"ה שכרם אעפ"י שעושין על ידו רעה, משא"כ ברית אבות שכרת הקב"ה ברית עם אאע"ה והבטיחו לדורות הבאים אינו מועיל רק לטובה ולא לרעה, וע"כ ברית אבות הוא רק ע"צ הטובה, וז"ש ברית אבות לא תמה היינו לטובה וכשיטת הר"י דלצדיקים לא תמה והיינו לסייע לצדקות ולהתקרב להשי"ת, ולפי"ז לא יקשה מהפסוק ועושה חסד לאלפים, דהרי אם הזכות אבות הוא ע"צ החסד והטובה אז משלם הקב"ה שכר לאלפים דור, אבל לא ח"ו לרעה, ולפי זה יובן דר' אחא אינו חולק על דברי המ"ד שסוברים תמה זכות אבות, דמה שאמרו תמה היינו לרעה כמו מעשה קרח כנ"ל בנועם אלימלך, ולענין זה תמה זכות אבות למר כדאית לי' ולמר כדאית ליי, וז"ש ר' אחא לעולם זכות אבות קיימת ולעולם מזכירין ואומרין וכו' ולא ישכח את ברית אבותיך דלטובה לא תמה זכות אבות לעולם, ובזה כ"ע מודים דא"א שיחלוקו על פסוק מפורש בתורה ולא ישכח את ברית אבותיך ועל הפסוק ועושה חסד לאלפים כנ"ל,
translation: And it is possible that this is also the intention of the acronym R"T, which distinguishes between the merit of the Patriarchs and the covenant of the Patriarchs. Behold, merit is effective both for good and for evil, for this is the measure that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not withhold the reward of any creature, and even for the wicked, the Holy One, Blessed be He, pays them their reward, even though they do evil through Him. In contrast, the covenant of the Patriarchs, with which the Holy One, Blessed be He, made a covenant with our forefather Abraham and promised him for future generations, is only beneficial for good and not for evil. Therefore, the covenant of the Patriarchs is only for the sake of good, and this is what is meant by "the covenant of the Patriarchs does not cease," meaning for good. And according to the opinion of Rabbi Yitzchak, for the righteous it does not cease, and this is to assist in righteousness and to draw closer to the Holy One, Blessed be He. According to this, it will not be difficult regarding the verse "and He does kindness for thousands," for if the merit of the Patriarchs is for the sake of kindness and goodness, then the Holy One, Blessed be He, pays reward to thousands of generations, but not, Heaven forbid, for evil. According to this, it can be understood that Rabbi Acha does not disagree with the words of the sages who hold that the merit of the Patriarchs has ceased, for what they said has ceased means for evil, like the case of Korach, as mentioned in the Noam Elimelech. And regarding this matter, the merit of the Patriarchs has ceased for some, as it is fitting for them, and for others, as it is fitting for them. And this is what Rabbi Acha said: "The merit of the Patriarchs is eternal, and we always mention and say, etc., and He will not forget the covenant of your forefathers," that for good, the merit of the Patriarchs does not cease forever. And in this, all agree that it is impossible for them to disagree on a clear verse in the Torah, "and He will not forget the covenant of your forefathers," and on the verse "and He does kindness for thousands," as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the merit of the Patriarchs (Zchut Avot) and the covenant with the Patriarchs (Brit Avot). It emphasizes that while the merit can benefit both the righteous and the wicked, the covenant is solely for good and does not apply to negative outcomes. The text asserts that the covenant remains in effect for the righteous, ensuring divine kindness and support, and highlights that the merit of the Patriarchs is eternal and will not be forgotten, reinforcing the idea of God's enduring commitment to His people.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד הכוונה במ"ש תמה זכות אבות עפימ"ש השלה"ק ובפ' בחקותי) עה"פ וזכרתי את בריתי יעקב, קשה זה הפסוק הוא של נחמה ועדיין לא גמר הקללות, ואיך הפסיק בפסוק של נחמה בתוך הקללות, וקבלתי כי אף זה הפסוק הוא מתוכחת מוסר, כי אינו דומה רשע בן רשע החוטא לרשע בן צדיק, כי הרשע בן צדיק עונשו מרובה, שראה אביו מתנהג בחסידות והוא אין מנהג אבותיו בידיו וכו', ע"ז אמר אני אזכור לך וכו' שאתה מזרע אבות הקדושים אברהם יצחק ויעקב וכו' ועל כ"ז לא הלכת בדרך ישר עכ"ד. ובזה יובן דכשראו חז"ל קלקול הדורות השיגו שע"י שיזכרו להם זכות אבות, יתעורר ח"ו קטרוג על שאין הולכים בדרכיהם, ולכן גזרו אומר תמה זכות אבות, כי מוטב שלא יזכר ולא יתעורר עליהם קטרוג מצד יחוסיהם אל האבות הקדושים, ומה שאנו מתפללים ומבקשים שיזכר לנו זכות אבות, כוונתינו רק ע"צ הטובה, וכעין שכתב בספה"ק אור לישרים דהמצות שעושים בעודם מלוכלכים בעבירות ר"ל, חוטפין אותם החיצונים: ר"ל, וע"כ טוב לומר לשם יחוד קודם עשיית כל מצוה, וזהו תקנה שלא יחטפו החיצונים את המצות, דאנן קיימא לן מצות צריכות כוונה, ואף למ"ד אין צריכות כוונה, מ"מ אם אומר בפירוש שאינו רוצה לצאת, בודאי אינו יוצא כמבואר בר"ן ובפוסקים, ועד"ז כוונתינו לומר אני עושה מצוה זו רק לשם יחוד קוב"ה, אבל אם ח"ו יגרמו עונותי שאין המצוה רצוי' לפניו ית"ש אז איני רוצה לצאת כלל. וכמו כן בענין זכות אבות אנו מתפללים להשי"ת שיזכור לנו זכות אבותינו הק' לטובה, ובתנאי שאם יתעורר על ידו קטרוג ח"ו במה שידמו מעשינו למעשה האבות, אז לא יעמוד זכות אבות, ורק לטובה יזכור לנו ה' זכותם, והשי"ת הוא כל יכול דאעפ"י שאנו מתפללים בזכות אבות והקב"ה ישמע תפלתינו בזכותם אעפ"כ לא יתעורר עלינו קטרוג ע"י הזכרת זכותם.
translation: And even if there is another intention in what is said, "I wonder at the merit of the ancestors," as mentioned in the Sefer HaLikutim and in Parashat Bechukotai (on the verse "And I will remember My covenant with Jacob"), it is difficult because this verse is one of comfort, and the curses have not yet been completed. How can it be interrupted with a verse of comfort in the midst of the curses? I have received that this verse is also a rebuke, for the wicked son of a wicked person who sins is not comparable to the wicked son of a righteous person, for the punishment of the wicked son of a righteous person is greater, as he saw his father behaving with piety, and he does not have the ways of his ancestors in his hands, etc. For this, it is said, "I will remember for you," etc., that you are from the seed of the holy ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, etc., and despite all this, you did not walk in the straight path. Thus, it is understood that when the Sages saw the corruption of the generations, they realized that by mentioning the merit of the ancestors, Heaven forbid, a prosecution would be aroused for not walking in their ways. Therefore, they decreed to say, "I wonder at the merit of the ancestors," for it is better not to mention it and not to arouse a prosecution against them due to their lineage to the holy ancestors. And what we pray and request is that He should remember for us the merit of the ancestors, our intention is only for the good, similar to what is written in the holy book "Or L'Yashar," that the commandments they perform while still stained with sins, Heaven forbid, are snatched by the external forces. Therefore, it is good to say "for the sake of unity" before performing any commandment, and this is a remedy so that the external forces do not snatch the commandments, for we hold that commandments require intention, and even according to the opinion that they do not require intention, nonetheless, if one explicitly states that he does not want to fulfill it, he certainly does not fulfill it, as explained in the Ran and in the poskim. Similarly, our intention is to say, "I am performing this commandment only for the sake of the unity of the Holy One, Blessed be He," but if, Heaven forbid, my sins cause that the commandment is not desirable before Him, then I do not want to fulfill it at all. Likewise, regarding the merit of the ancestors, we pray to the Holy One, Blessed be He, that He should remember for us the merit of our holy ancestors for good, on the condition that if a prosecution is aroused through Him, Heaven forbid, regarding our actions being similar to the actions of the ancestors, then the merit of the ancestors will not stand, and only for good will the Lord remember their merit. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, is all-powerful, for even though we pray in the merit of the ancestors and the Holy One, Blessed be He, will hear our prayer in their merit, nonetheless, a prosecution will not be aroused against us through the mention of their merit.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "Zchut Avot" (merit of the ancestors) and its implications in the context of divine judgment. It emphasizes that while invoking the merit of the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob can be beneficial, it may also lead to scrutiny if one's actions do not align with their righteous legacy. The author suggests that prayers for the merit of the ancestors should be made with the intention of avoiding any negative repercussions, ensuring that the merit is remembered only for good. Ultimately, it highlights the balance between seeking divine favor through ancestral merit and the responsibility to uphold the values exemplified by the ancestors.

passage_content:
ומעתה ל"ק מפסוק עושה חסד לאלפים, דרק כשנצמח חסד מזכות אבות אז יגן זכותם לאלף דור, אבל לא ח"ו ע"צ הקערוג, והעצה מ"ז להתפלל להשי"ת בהכנעה גדולה ולהתוודות בפה, דזה הוא טעם הווידוי כדי להקדים את המקטרג ושוב לא יקטרג על החטאים, אחר שכבר הודה עליהם בעל המעשה ולא יתעורר קטרוג מ"י הזכרת זכות אבות ויועיל לטובה, וזהו כוונת הפסוק באומרו כי אדל רחום ה' אלקיך לא ירפך ולא ישחיתך ולא ישכח את ברית אבותיך וגו' ר"ל שלא יתעורר קטרוג ע"י הזכרת זכות אבות, כ"א יועיל לטובם: ואמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' בחקותי) ראית זכות אבות שמטה וזכות אמהות שנתמטטה, לך והטפל בחסדים הה"ד כי ההרים ימושו והגבעות תמוטינה הרים 
אלו האבות והגבעות אלו אמהות ואח"כ וחסדי מאתך לא ימוש.
translation: And from now on, it is not difficult from the verse "He does kindness to thousands," for only when we merit kindness through the merit of the ancestors will their merit protect for a thousand generations, but not, Heaven forbid, through the opposite. And the advice is to pray to the Holy One, Blessed be He, with great humility and to confess verbally, for this is the reason for confession: to precede the accuser so that he will no longer accuse regarding the sins, after the doer has already acknowledged them, and there will be no awakening of accusation from the mention of the merit of the ancestors, and it will be beneficial for good. And this is the intention of the verse when it says, "For the Lord your God is a merciful God; He will not forsake you, nor destroy you, nor forget the covenant of your ancestors," meaning that there will be no awakening of accusation through the mention of the merit of the ancestors, but rather it will be beneficial for them. And our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabba (Parashat Bechukotai) that if you see the merit of the ancestors has waned and the merit of the mothers has diminished, go and engage in acts of kindness, as it is written, "For the mountains may depart and the hills be removed, but My kindness shall not depart from you." The mountains refer to the ancestors, and the hills refer to the mothers, and afterwards, "and My kindness shall not depart from you."
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of invoking the merit of the Patriarchs and Matriarchs in prayer, particularly through sincere confession, to prevent heavenly accusations against one's sins. It highlights that true kindness (chesed) can only flourish when rooted in the merits of the ancestors, ensuring their protection for future generations. The text also reassures that God's compassion will not wane, as He remembers the covenant with the ancestors, thus transforming potential judgment into benevolence. Ultimately, it underscores the enduring power of ancestral merit in safeguarding the community.

passage_content: ועד"ז התפלל יע"א בסודם אל תבא נפשי זה מעשה זמרי וכו' שלא יתייחד שמו עליהם כו עזו העונות נעשה מזכות אבות קטרוג ח"ו, ומוטב להם שלא יזכר שמו עליהם כלל, כי זכות אבות ראוי שיזכר רק לטובה, וכמו"כ אנחנו מתפללים על זכות אבות וכוונתינו שיזכר זכות אבות רק לטובה ולא יתחלל ח"ו ש"ש על ידינו, וכבוד שמים הוא שנוכל לעבוד את השי"ת בהרחבת הדעת וננצל בזכותם מכל צרה שלא תבא ר"ל.
translation: And similarly, he prayed, may it be His will, in their secret, "Let not my soul come into their council," etc., that His name should not be associated with them, for the iniquities are strong, and we have made a claim on the merit of the forefathers, Heaven forbid, and it is better for them that His name should not be mentioned upon them at all, for the merit of the forefathers should only be remembered for good. Likewise, we pray for the merit of the forefathers, and our intention is that the merit of the forefathers should only be remembered for good and not be desecrated, Heaven forbid, through us. And it is a matter of the honor of Heaven that we should be able to serve the Blessed One with expanded understanding and be saved through their merit from any trouble that may come, Heaven forbid.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of invoking the merit of the ancestors (Zchut Avot) in a positive light, highlighting that their legacy should not be tarnished by the sins of their descendants. It reflects a deep concern for the sanctity of God's name, suggesting that it is preferable for God's name not to be associated with wrongdoing. The prayer is directed towards ensuring that the merit of the ancestors is remembered only for good, allowing for a connection to God that is expansive and beneficial, ultimately seeking protection from harm through their merit.

passage_content: אי ויראו ואחי יוסף כי מת אביהם ויאמרו לו ישטמנו יוסף והשב ישיב לנו את כל הרעה אשר גמלנו אותו, במדרש ו)הביאו הפר"ד, דרך מצפה, דרוש כ"ו) והשב זה יוסף ישיב זה עשו, עכ"ד המדרש. והוא תמוה דעשו מאן דכר שמיה, גם יל"ד בפסוק את כל הרעה, ומה בא לרבות במלת את כל. ב) ויאמר אליהם יוסף אל תראו כי התחת אלקים אני, צ"ב הכוונה במ"ש התחת אלקים אני, ובתרגום פי' ארי דחלא דה' אנא, וצ"ב דפירוש זה אינו יוצא מפשוטו של מקרא התחת אלקים אני, ובוודאי הי' יוסף הצדיק ירא הי, אלא שבפסוק זה לכאורה אין בו רמז לזה. ג) ואתם חשבתם עלי רעה אלקים חשבה לטובה למען עשה כיום הזה להחיות עם רב, צריך להבין למה הזכיר להם אתם חשבתם עלי רעה ואיך ניחם אותם בהזכירם רעתם והול"ל אלקים חשבה לטובה, גם אומרו למען עשה כיום הזה צ"ב, דמחזי כמיותר לכאורה
translation:
And when Joseph's brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, "Perhaps Joseph will hate us and will surely repay us for all the evil that we did to him." In the Midrash (brought in the par'da, through the lookout, Drush 26), it says, "And the one who will repay is Joseph, and the one who will repay is Esau," thus concludes the Midrash. It is puzzling that Esau is mentioned, and also it is difficult to understand the phrase "all the evil," and what it adds with the words "all." 

And Joseph said to them, "Do not be afraid, for am I in the place of God?" The intention of the phrase "in the place of God" is questioned, and in the translation, it is explained as "for I am the one who fears God," but this explanation does not seem to align with the simple meaning of the verse "for am I in the place of God," and certainly, Joseph the righteous feared God, yet in this verse, there seems to be no hint of that.

And you thought evil against me, but God thought it for good, in order to bring about as it is this day to save a great nation. It is necessary to understand why he mentioned to them, "You thought evil against me," and how he comforted them by reminding them of their evil, and it could have simply said, "God thought it for good." Also, his saying "in order to bring about as it is this day" is questioned, as it seems superfluous at first glance.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the complex dynamics of forgiveness and divine providence as exemplified by Joseph's response to his brothers after their father's death. Joseph reassures them that he is not vengeful, stating, "Am I in the place of God?" which emphasizes the belief in God's overarching control over human actions. He acknowledges their wrongdoing but reframes it within the context of divine intention, asserting that their evil thoughts were transformed by God into a greater good for the survival of many. This highlights key Hasidic themes of redemption, the transformative power of faith, and the belief that even negative experiences can serve a higher purpose in God's plan.

passage_content: ויל"פ בהקדם מה שהעליתי בספר ויואל משה (מאמר א' פ' נ"ג) בפלוגתת הרמב"ם והראב"ד ע"ד בן כוזיבא איך נהרג. דהרמב"ם ס"ל שנהרג ע"י האומות והראב"ד השיג עליו מדברי הגמרא שמבואר דרבנן קטלוהו, והכ"מ והלח"מ כתבו שזהו פלוגתא בין הגמרא והמדרש, דבמדרש איכה (עה"פ בלע ה') דרשו ז"ל דנהרג ע"ו האומות, והרמב"ם הכריע כהמדרש, וביארתי שם דאפשר להשוות פלוגתתם עפי"מ דכתיב (בפרשת וישב) אצל יוסף את כל אשר הם עושים הוא היה עושה, ובתרגום במימרי' הוה מתעביד מבואר דמה שנעשה עפ"י דיבורו יקרא על שמו כאלו הוא היה עושהו, ומצינו כעי"ז בכ"מ, ואין שום סתירה ממה שאמרו בגמרא דרבנן קטלוהו, דאפשר שהי' ע"י קללת החכמים או ע"י מחשבתם ודעתם, ועכ"פ ע"י כחם הי' אף שבמעשה לא עשו מאומה, שוב מצאתי אח"כ שכן העלה האברבנאל בספרו משמיע ישועות, דאין הכוונה שקטלוהו בידים אלא שדנו אותו למיתה ונהרג ע"ו אוה"ע ואין בזה פלוגתא, עיי"ש באריכות.
translation: And it is explained in advance what I raised in the book Vayoel Moshe (Article 1, Chapter 53) regarding the dispute between the Rambam and the Raavad concerning how Ben Koziva was killed. For the Rambam holds that he was killed by the nations, while the Raavad disagrees with him based on the words of the Gemara, which clarifies that the Rabbis killed him. And the Knesset Hagedolah and the Lechem Mishneh wrote that this is a dispute between the Gemara and the Midrash, for in the Midrash Eicha (on the verse "He swallowed up") they expounded that he was killed by the nations. The Rambam ruled according to the Midrash, and I explained there that it is possible to compare their dispute according to the verse (in Parashat Vayeshev) regarding Joseph, "All that they do, he was doing," and in the translation, it is explained that what is done according to his word is called by his name as if he were doing it. And we find similarly in other places, and there is no contradiction to what the Gemara said that the Rabbis killed him, for it is possible that it was through the curse of the sages or through their thoughts and opinions, and in any case, it was through their power even though in action they did nothing. Later, I found that the Abarbanel also raised this in his book MeShmiya Yeshuot, that the intention is not that they killed him with their hands but that they judged him to death and he was killed by the nations, and there is no dispute in this, see there at length.
summary: The passage discusses the differing opinions of Maimonides (Rambam) and Abraham ibn Daud (Ra'avad) regarding the death of Bar Kochba, with Rambam asserting he was killed by the nations while Ra'avad cites the Talmud indicating he was killed by the sages. The author suggests that both perspectives can be reconciled, as the sages' condemnation could have led to his death through divine judgment, reflecting the idea that actions and intentions are interconnected. This highlights a key Hasidic concept of the power of thought and speech in shaping reality, emphasizing that even without direct action, the influence of the sages' will could manifest in Bar Kochba's fate.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ש רבינו בחיי ו)סו"פ מקץ) ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם רמז לעשרה הרוגי מלכות אשר עלו לשלום אל אביהם שבשמים אחר שנתלבנו ונצרפו מחטאו של יוסף וכו', וכן תמצא בפרקי היכלות אמר ר' ישמעאל אותו היום חמישי בשבת הי', כשבאת השמועה מכרך גדול שברומי שצוה לופינוס קיסר ותפשו ארבעה אנשים וכו', ובקשתי שאלה משר הפנים וכו' ואמר לי עשרה נכתבו בבית דין של מעלה. ונתנו לו לס"מ הרשע שרו של עשו וכו' להשלים גזירת וגונב איש ומכרו וגו' ושמורה לו להנקם ממנו וכו' אמר ר' ישמעאל כל ההתראות הללו וכל התנאין הללו התרו בו והתנו עם ס"מ הרשע, והוא אמר קבלתי עלי ויבחר עשרה מאבירי ישראל וכו' ור' חנינא בן תרדיון הוחלף בלופינוס קיסר ולופינוס הוא שנשרף, וכן כל השאר וכו' כן הוחלפו חכמי ישראל באחרים, ע"כ בפרקי היכלות, וכיון שטעמו טעם מיתה במה שנתפסו ונגמר דינם לכך, הם קבלו עונשם, והרי זה כאילו נהרגו, וכתב עוד רבינו בחיי ומפני זה נחתמה הפרשה ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם והי' יכול לומר לכו לשלום לדרככם. אבל הפרשה מבוארת באחי יוסף לשעה ורומזת לעשרה הרוגי מלכות לדורות אשר עלו לשלום אל אביהם שבשמים. עכ"ל רבינו בחיי זלל"ה. ואפשר לרמוז באומרו ואתם עלו לשלום וגו', עפ"י המבואר בגמרא (קודושין מ"א ע"ב) אתם גם אתם למה לי, סד"א הואיל ואמר מר אתם ולא אריסין ובו' אימא אתם ולא שלוחכם נמי קמ"ל, מבואר שתיבת אתם בא למעט שלוחכם, וזה שרמז להם יוסף ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, אתם דייקא ולא שלוחכם, שישלחו אחרים תחתיהם והם יסבלו עונש עשרה הרוגי מלכות אבל אתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם שבשמים ולא תסבלו גזירת המלכות.
translation: And we will also precede what our Rabbi Bachye said (at the end of Miketz), "And you shall go up in peace to your father," which hints at the ten martyrs who ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven after they were purified and refined from the sin of Joseph, etc. Likewise, you will find in the chapters of the Heichalot that Rabbi Yishmael said, "That day was the fifth of the week," when the news came from a great city in Rome that Caesar Lufinus commanded and captured four men, etc. And I asked a question from the Minister of the Interior, etc., and he told me that ten were inscribed in the heavenly court. And they gave to the wicked S.M. (Samael), the minister of Esau, etc., to complete the decree of 'and he who steals a man and sells him,' etc., and it is reserved for him to take revenge on him, etc. Rabbi Yishmael said that all these warnings and all these conditions were given to him and agreed upon with the wicked S.M., and he said, "I accept upon myself," and he chose ten of the mighty ones of Israel, etc. And Rabbi Chanina ben Teradyon was exchanged for Caesar Lufinus, and Lufinus was the one who was burned, and so were all the others, etc. Thus, the sages of Israel were exchanged for others. Therefore, in the chapters of the Heichalot, since they tasted the taste of death when they were captured and their judgment was sealed, they accepted their punishment, and it is as if they were killed. Rabbi Bachye also wrote that for this reason the passage was sealed, "And you shall go up in peace to your father," and he could have said, "Go in peace on your way." But the passage is clarified in the brothers of Joseph for the moment and hints at the ten martyrs for generations who ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven. Thus said Rabbi Bachye, may his memory be blessed. And it is possible to hint by saying, "And you shall go up in peace," etc., according to what is explained in the Gemara (Kiddushin 41b), "You, and you, why do I need it?" I might have thought since the master said "you" and not "your agents," and if it were to say "you" and not "your messengers," it teaches us that the word "you" comes to exclude "your messengers." And this is what Joseph hinted to them, "And you shall go up in peace to your father," specifically "you" and not "your messengers," that they should not send others in their place, and they will suffer the punishment of the ten martyrs, but "you shall go up in peace to your Father in Heaven," and you will not suffer the decree of the kingdom.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the ten martyrs of Jewish history and the biblical narrative of Joseph's brothers, emphasizing their ascent to peace with their Heavenly Father after enduring suffering. It highlights the idea that the martyrs, like Joseph's brothers, faced their fates with acceptance, and their deaths were seen as a fulfillment of divine justice. The text also underscores the importance of direct engagement with one's fate, as indicated by the phrase "you shall ascend in peace," which implies that the martyrs themselves, rather than their substitutes, faced their trials. This reflects a broader theological theme of martyrdom and divine retribution within the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content: העולה מדברינו דעונש עשרה הרוגי מלכות לא נתקיים בהם, שהרי הוחלפו אחרים תחתיהם, כנ"ל ברבינו בחיי, וזה היה ע"ו שיוסף הצדיק מחל להם, אבל אלמלי הי' ליוסף הקפדה עליהם היתה מתקיימת ח"ו גזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות בהם, והנה זה נעשה ע"ו רומי שהוא אדום שרו של עשו, ולפי"ז נאמר שהשבטים לא היו יראים מיוסף כי לא חשדו בו שהוא ירע להם ח"ו, כי היו מכירין גודל קדושתו וצדקתו, אבל היו יראים מהקפדתו שזה יגרום קטרוג ששרו של עשו יעשה נקמתו בהם, וכמו שהי' בבן כוזיבא דלפי שנדון למיתה ע"י החכמים נהרג ע"י האומות, וז"ש לו ישטמנו וגו' והשב זה יוסף שיהיה לו הקפדה בלב עלינו, עי"ז ישיב זה עשו היינו שרו של עשו ישיב לנו את כל הרעה אשר גמלנו אותו, ואמר את כל הרעה, בתוס' ריבוי על ריבוי, שאם הו' נשאר הקפדת יוסף עליהם, הי' נגמר העונש בעשרה הרוגי מלכות בתוקף הדין ר"ל, ובאופן יותר קשה, אבל לפי שיוסף לא הקפיד עליהם אלא מחל להם לכן הוחלף העונש באחרים.
translation: The implication of our words is that the punishment of the ten martyrs was not fulfilled upon them, for others were substituted in their place, as mentioned by our Rabbi Bachaye. This was due to the fact that Joseph the Righteous forgave them. However, had Joseph held a grudge against them, G-d forbid, the decree of the ten martyrs would have been fulfilled upon them. And behold, this was done because of Rome, which is Edom, the minister of Esau. Therefore, it is said that the tribes were not afraid of Joseph because they did not suspect him of wishing them harm, G-d forbid, for they recognized the greatness of his holiness and righteousness. Rather, they were afraid of his potential anger, which could cause a prosecution that the minister of Esau would take vengeance upon them, just as it was with Ben Koziva, who was sentenced to death by the sages and was killed by the nations. This is what is meant by "he will hate us," and the concern was that Joseph would have a grudge in his heart against us. Through this, Esau, meaning the minister of Esau, would return to us all the evil that we had done to him. And it says "all the evil," adding a multitude upon multitude, for if Joseph had remained angry with them, the punishment would have been completed in the ten martyrs with the full force of the law, so to speak, and in a more severe manner. But since Joseph did not hold a grudge against them and forgave them, therefore the punishment was transferred to others.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine mercy and the power of forgiveness, exemplified by Joseph's decision to forgive his brothers, which prevented the fulfillment of the harsh decree of the Ten Martyrs. It emphasizes that had Joseph held a grudge, the punishment would have been severe and directly linked to the spiritual forces represented by Esau's angel. The text highlights the importance of recognizing the holiness and righteousness of individuals like Joseph, which can mitigate divine judgment and transform potential calamities into acts of mercy. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound impact of forgiveness on the collective fate of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ומה שאמר להם יוסף אל תיראו כי התחת אלקים אני, נל"פ בהקדם אמרם ז"ל (ב"ר פי"ב) בתחלה עלה במחשבה לבראותו במדת הדין. וראה שאין העולם מתקיים הקדים מדת הרחמים ושתפה למדת הדין, והיינו דכתיב ביום עשות ה' אלקים ארץ ושמים דהעשיה היתה ברחמים עכ"ד ז"ל, וזה ירמוז מאמר השם בגזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות, כך עלה במחשבה לפני, ר"ל בעולם המחשבה ששם הוא תוקפא דדינא, וק"ז זלה"ה בתפלה למשה פו' הפסוק (תהלים ע"ו ט') משמים השמעת דין ארץ יראה ושקטה וזל"ק: עפימ"ש במק"א כי קביעת הדין הוא לטובת יושבי ארץ, שיראו ממנו ויזכרו וישובו, והיינו משמים השמעת דין כדי שעי"ז ארץ יראה ועי"ז ושקטה, וכ"ק אבא מארי זלה"ה בקדושת יו"ט פו' בזה מאמה"כ והאלקים עשה שיראו מלפניו ולא שיתנהג במדת הדין, וכן פי' בסידורו של שבת (בשורש הששי ענף ב') עיי"ש, נמצא שעי"ז שיראין מן הדין נמתק הדין, ורש"י פי' בפסוק ויזכור אלקים את נח זה השם מדת הדין הוא ונהפכה למדת רחמים ע"י תפלת הצדיקים, ורשעתן של רשעים הופכת מדת הרחמים למדת הדין שנאמר וירא ה' כי רבה רעת האדם וגו' ויאמר ה' אמחה והוא שם מדת רחמים ע"כ, והוא מדברי המד"ר שם.
translation: And what Joseph said to them, "Do not be afraid, for I am in the place of God," we can understand in light of what our sages of blessed memory said (Bereishit Rabbah 12) that initially it was in His thought to create the world with the attribute of judgment. And He saw that the world could not endure, so He preceded the attribute of mercy and combined it with the attribute of judgment. And this is what is written, "On the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens," that the creation was through mercy, thus far their words. This hints at the statement of the Holy One in the decree of the Ten Martyrs, as it was in His thought before, meaning in the world of thought where the power of judgment resides. And this is also hinted at in the prayer of Moses, as stated in the verse (Psalms 66:9), "From heaven He heard judgment; the earth feared and was quiet," which means: as explained elsewhere, the establishment of judgment is for the benefit of the inhabitants of the earth, so that they may fear Him, remember, and return. And this is "From heaven He heard judgment" so that through this the earth may fear and thus be quiet. And my holy father, may his memory be blessed, in the sanctity of the festival, explained this from the verse, "And God made it so that they would fear before Him" and not conduct themselves with the attribute of judgment. And so he explained in his Shabbat prayer book (in the sixth root, branch two), see there. It follows that through their fear of judgment, the judgment is sweetened. And Rashi explained in the verse "And God remembered Noah," that this name is the attribute of judgment, and it was transformed into the attribute of mercy through the prayers of the righteous. And the wickedness of the wicked turns the attribute of mercy into the attribute of judgment, as it is said, "And the Lord saw that the wickedness of man was great..." and the Lord said, "I will wipe out," and there is the name of the attribute of mercy, thus far. And this is from the words of the Midrash there.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the interplay between divine justice and mercy, emphasizing that initially, creation was conceived through the attribute of judgment, but was ultimately sustained by mercy. The text highlights that the establishment of judgment serves a purpose for humanity, prompting them to recognize their actions and return to righteousness. It also notes that the prayers of the righteous can transform judgment into mercy, while the wicked can reverse this process, leading to a harsher divine response. Overall, the passage illustrates the dynamic relationship between divine attributes and human behavior in the context of spiritual accountability.

passage_content: ונא"פ בזה מאמה"כ (סו"פ מקץ) אשר ימצא אתו מעבדיך ומת וגם אנחנו נהי' לאדוני לעבדים, ויאמר גם עתה כדבריכם כן הוא וגו' פרש"י אף זו מן הדין אמת, כדבריכם כן הוא שכולכם חייבים בדבר וכו', אבל אני אעשה לכם לפנים משורת הדין אשר ימצא אתו יהי' לי עבד, ויאמר יהודה וגו' הננו עבדים לאדוני גם אנחנו וגו', ויאמר חלילה לו מעשות זאת וגו'. ולכאורה יש להבין דאם הדין כן שכולם יהיו נתפסים מדוע אמר חלילה לי וכו'. ונל"פ דהנה מבואר בדברי חז"ל שמכירת יוסף הי' סיבה מן השמים והכרח לקיים גזירת הגלות, אמנם אעפ"כ צ"ב איך היתה סברתם לדונו ככה עפ"י דיני התוה"ק, והרבה פירושי' נאמרו בזה במפרשי התורה, ואיך שנאמר עכ"ח צ"ל שגם זאת היתה סיבה מאת ה' שידונו אותו בתוקף הדין כפי ראות עינם ושיקול דעתם בדין, והנה בחי' הדין הוא מעולם המחשבה, אבל בפועל המעשה מתנהג העולם במדת הרחמים כנ"ל, ואף הם שרצו לדונו בתוקף הדין הי' רק במחשבה ולא נתקיימה כן למעשה, ודיבור הוא בחינת דין כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל (סו"פ משפטים) עה"פ מי בעל דברים יגש אליכם פי' מי שיש לו דין כו דיבור הוא קשה, וז"ש יוסף גם עתה כדבריכם כן הוא, ופי' רש"י אף זו מן שהדין' אמת כדבריכם כן הוא שכולכם חייבים, ר"ל דלפי תוקף הדין כולכם חייבים, וכדבריכם, ר"ל כפי תוקף הדין שהתנהגתם עמו, כך ראוי למדוד לכם מדה כנגד מדה, אבל חלילה לי שמעשות" זאת להתנהג במדת הדין במעשה, כי בעשי' הקדים הקב"ה מדת הרחמים לדין, וע"כ אתנהג עמכם במדת הרחמים.
translation:
And even so, in this matter, from the verse (in Parashat Miketz) which states, "Whoever is found with your servant shall die, and we will also be slaves to my lord," he said, "Even now, as you have spoken, so it is..." Rashi explains that this too is true according to the law, "as you have spoken, so it is," that you are all liable in this matter, etc. However, I will act for you beyond the letter of the law: whoever is found with him shall be my servant. And Judah said, "Here we are, slaves to my lord, we too..." And he said, "Far be it from me to do this..." At first glance, it must be understood that if the law is such that all will be caught, why did he say, "Far be it from me..."? 

It appears that it is explained in the words of our Sages that the sale of Joseph was a cause from Heaven and a necessity to fulfill the decree of exile. Nevertheless, it is puzzling how they thought to judge him in this manner according to the laws of the Torah. Many explanations have been given by the commentators on the Torah regarding this, and as it is stated, it must be that this too was a reason from the Lord that they would judge him strictly according to the law, as they saw fit in their judgment. 

Now, the aspect of the law is from the world of thought, but in actual practice, the world operates with the attribute of mercy, as mentioned above. And even they, who wanted to judge him strictly according to the law, it was only in thought, and it did not materialize in practice. And speech is an aspect of law, as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains (in Parashat Mishpatim) on the verse "Whoever has a matter should approach you," meaning whoever has a legal matter, etc., speech is severe. Therefore, Joseph said, "Even now, as you have spoken, so it is," and Rashi explains that this too is true, that according to the strictness of the law, you are all liable, meaning that according to the strictness of the law, you are all liable, and as you have spoken, meaning according to the strictness of the law with which you have dealt with him, so it is fitting to measure to you measure for measure. 

But "Far be it from me to do this," to conduct myself with the attribute of law in action, for in action, the Holy One, blessed be He, preceded the attribute of mercy to the law. Therefore, I will conduct myself with you in the attribute of mercy.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine justice and mercy, particularly in the context of Joseph's brothers facing judgment for their past actions. It emphasizes that while the strict application of the law would hold them all accountable, Joseph chooses to act with mercy instead of enforcing the harshness of the law. This reflects the Hasidic belief that, despite the reality of judgment, God's overarching attribute is one of compassion, which ultimately prevails in human affairs. The text illustrates the idea that divine providence orchestrates events to fulfill a greater purpose, allowing for mercy to triumph over strict justice.

passage_content: וז"ש יוסף התחת אלקים אני, ר"ל וכי ראוי לי לעורר עליכם מדת הדין בחינת אלקים, ופי' התרגום ארי דחלא דה' אנא, דמדה"ד הוא רק כדי שיראו מלפניו כמ"ש הקדושת יו"ט זלל"ה והאלקים עשה שיראו מלפניו, וע"י שאני דחלא דה' נמתק מדה"ד וראוי שיתנהג העולם ברחמים, ואמר להם עוד ואתם חשבתם, כלומר שאתם דנתם אותי כפו בחי' עולם המחשבה ששם הוא דין. אבל אלקים חשבה לטובה דצדיקים מהפכים מדה"ד למדה"ר, וגם מדה"ד הסכים על ידם וחשבה לטובה למען שעשה כיום הזה כלומר שבעשי' הקדים מדה"ר למדה"ד, וזה אומרו כיום הזה לרמוז שעכשיו נמתק הדין כדי להחיות עם רב, כי אלולי זאת לא היו יכולין לעמוד בקיומם. אבל עוד יהיה זמן שהס"מ יתגבר ויתבע דין מעשרה הרוגי מלכות בתגבורת מדה"ד, ואף שלא יהי' בשלימות כנ"ל, מ"מ יהי' תוקפא דדינא, והנה בעוה"ר כבר ראינו בעינינו תוקפא דדינא, שנלקחו מאתנו כל הצדיקים ואלפי רבבות יראים ושלמים, ולא נשאר לנו על מי להשען, ורק על חסדי השי"ת אנחנו נשענים וברחמיו יתברך אנו בעוחים שיציל אותנו משיני אריות שלא יעשו בנו כלה ח"ו, ובימי השובבי"ם האלה נתאמץ לתקן כל אשר פגמנו ונזכה לתשובה שלימה ולעשות רצונו יתברך באמת ובלב שלם ונזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ובשמחתן בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And this is what he said: "Joseph said, 'Am I in the place of God?' Meaning, is it fitting for me to arouse against you the attribute of judgment, which is the aspect of God? And the translation explains, 'I am the one who has the power of God,' for the attribute of judgment is only so that they may see before Him, as it is written in the holiness of the festival, and God made it so that they may see before Him. And since I am the one who has the power of God, the attribute of judgment is sweetened, and it is fitting that the world be conducted with mercy. And he said to them further, 'And you thought,' meaning you judged me as if I were bound by the aspect of the world of thought, where there is judgment. But God thought it for good, for the righteous transform the attribute of judgment into the attribute of mercy, and even the attribute of judgment agrees with them and thinks it for good, for He made it as this day, meaning that in action, the attribute of mercy was advanced over the attribute of judgment. This is what he means by 'this day,' to hint that now the judgment is sweetened in order to sustain a great nation, for without this they would not be able to stand in their existence. But there will still be a time when the accuser will strengthen and demand judgment from the ten martyrs with the strength of the attribute of judgment, and even though it will not be in completeness as mentioned, nevertheless, there will be a force of judgment. And behold, in our evil days, we have already seen with our own eyes the force of judgment, that all the righteous and tens of thousands of the God-fearing and complete ones have been taken from us, and we have no one to rely on, only on the mercies of the Holy One, blessed be He, we rely, and through His mercies we are engaged in praying that He save us from the teeth of lions, that they should not completely destroy us, Heaven forbid. And in these days of Shovavim, let us strive to rectify all that we have blemished, and may we merit a complete repentance and to do His will, blessed be He, truly and with a whole heart, and may we merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy in the uplifting of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, may it be soon.
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the tension between divine judgment (Middat HaDin) and mercy (Middat HaRachamim), illustrating how righteous individuals can transform harsh judgments into compassion. The text reflects on the historical suffering of the Jewish people, acknowledging the challenges posed by the forces of evil, while expressing hope in God's mercy and the potential for redemption. It calls for introspection and repentance during the period of Shovavim, aiming for a complete return to God and the ultimate salvation of Israel. The passage concludes with a yearning for the revelation of divine glory and the restoration of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ויצוו אל יוסף לאמר אביך צו' לפני מותו לאמר כה תאמרון ליוסף אנא שא נא פשע אחיך וחטאתם כי רעה גמלוך, פרש"י ז"ל אביך צוה שינו בדבר מפני השלום, כי לא צוה יעקב כן שלא נחשד יוסף בעיניו. עכ"ל. ולכאורה צ"ב, דאיך יתכן שיאמרו כולם דיבורים שאינם אמת ח"ו, ולא יאות לקדושים כמותם להשתמש במידת השקר אפילו מפני השלום, ומה גם שהוא רחוק מהמציאות וחוש השכל יעיד על הפכו שלא צוה אותם אביהם על ככה, דהרי יוסף היה בנו אהובו חביב לו כנפשו, ומסר לו כל רזי סודותיו. והקדים לתת לו ברכתו לפני אחיו ומסר לו צוואתו, ואם היה ברצונו של יעאע"ה לצוותו על ככה, לא ימנע מאתו לאמר אליו הדברים האלה בעצמו פא"פ ולא ע"י שליח.
translation: And they commanded Joseph, saying, "Your father commanded before his death, saying, 'So shall you say to Joseph: Please forgive the transgression of your brothers and their sin, for they did evil to you.'" Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: "Your father commanded" — he changed the wording for the sake of peace, for Jacob did not command this, lest Joseph be suspected in his eyes. Thus far the text. And at first glance, it is difficult to understand, how could they all say words that are not true, Heaven forbid? It is not fitting for such holy ones to use the measure of falsehood even for the sake of peace, especially since it is far from reality, and common sense testifies to the opposite, that their father did not command them thus. After all, Joseph was his beloved son, dear to him as his own soul, and he entrusted him with all the secrets of his mysteries. He preceded to give him his blessing before his brothers and entrusted him with his will, and if it was the will of our father Jacob to command him thus, he would not refrain from saying these words to him directly, face to face, and not through a messenger.
summary: In this passage, the author grapples with the tension between truth and peace, questioning how Jacob could command his sons to convey a message to Joseph that contradicts their father's true feelings. The text emphasizes the deep bond between Jacob and Joseph, suggesting that Jacob would not have instructed his sons to misrepresent his sentiments. This highlights a key Hasidic concept: the importance of sincerity and authenticity in relationships, even when navigating complex familial dynamics. Ultimately, it reflects on the nature of divine communication and the integrity of one's intentions in the face of human conflict.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימי"ד בילקוט ראובני בשם רקנטי וציוני עה"פ האספו ואגידה לכם את אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים, רמז על מה שיקרא להם בעצמם בסוד הגלגול בעון מכירת יוסף, וגילה להם עונש עשרה הרוגי מלכות עיי"ש שנרמז בפסוקים מה שיארע לכל או"א, וכן אמרז"ל במד"ר ו)פ' נשא פר' י"ג סי' י"ד) שהי' מסורת ביד שבט יהודה חכמיהם וגדוליהם מן יעקב אבינו, כל מה שעתיד ליארע לכל שבט ועד ימות המשיח, וכן הי' ביד כל שבט ושבט מסורת כל מה שיארע לו עד ימות המשיח מן יעקב אביהם, עכ"ד המדרש. וכולם נרמזו בפסוקי הברכות בפ' זו. כן מוכח מדברי המדרש עיי"ש.
translation: And even though it is stated in the Yalkut Reuveni in the name of the Rekanti and the commentary on the verse "Gather and I will tell you what will happen to you in the end of days," it hints at what will happen to them themselves in the secret of the reincarnation due to the sin of selling Joseph, and it revealed to them the punishment of the ten martyrs, as is hinted in the verses regarding what will happen to each one. And so our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Naso, Parashah 13, Section 14) that there was a tradition in the tribe of Judah among their wise men and great ones from our forefather Jacob, about everything that is destined to happen to each tribe until the days of the Messiah. Likewise, each tribe had a tradition about what would happen to it until the days of the Messiah from their father Jacob. Thus is the conclusion of the Midrash. And all of them are hinted at in the verses of the blessings in this Parashah. This is also proven from the words of the Midrash.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic insights regarding the future of the Jewish people, particularly in relation to the sin of selling Joseph and its repercussions, as revealed in the Torah. It highlights the tradition passed down through the tribes of Israel, originating from Jacob, which details the events that will unfold for each tribe until the Messianic era. The text emphasizes that these future occurrences are hinted at in the blessings given in the Torah, reflecting a deep connection between past actions and future consequences within the framework of Jewish belief.

passage_content: ולפי"ז א"ש דהשבעים הקדושים אמרו אמת, אלא שאמרו בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין, ובכה"ג מותר מפני דרכי שלום, ומ"ש אביך צוה לפני מותו לאמר וגו', היתה כוונתם דלאו בפירוש אמר אבל נכלל כן בדברי תוכחותיו ובמה שגילה להם מידת עונשם בעון מכירת יוסף, בזה הורה לנו להתחנן אל יוסף ולפייסו עד שימחול לנו, כדי להקל מעלילו מידת החטא וענשו, וה"ה כאילו צוה בפירוש כן, וכעין שאמרז"ל בש"ס בכ"מ, הא לאו בפירוש איתמר אלא מכללא איתמר, ואעפ"כ הוי דרשא גמורה ולמדין ממנה להלכה ולמעשה אי לאו היכא דאיכא למיפרך דלא משתמע מיני' ולא מידי, וז"ש אביך צוה לפני מותו לאמר וגו', ר"ל ממה שצוה לפני מותו משתמע לאמר כה תאמרון ליוסף אנא שא נא פשע אחיך, ויוסף השיג כוונתם ונתאמת אצלו דבריהם הק' ומחל להם, ועי"ז נמתק קצת מדה"ד וכח הקטרוג.
translation: According to this, it is understood that the seventy holy ones spoke the truth, but they expressed it in a way that could be interpreted in two ways. In such a case, it is permitted for the sake of peace. And what is written, "Your father commanded before his death to say..." their intention was that it was not explicitly stated, but it was included in his words of rebuke and in what he revealed to them regarding the measure of their punishment for the sin of selling Joseph. In this, he taught us to plead with Joseph and to appease him until he forgives us, in order to lessen the severity of the sin and its punishment. It is as if he commanded this explicitly, similar to what our sages said in the Talmud in various places, that it was not stated explicitly but rather implied. Nevertheless, it is a complete teaching, and we learn from it for halacha and practice unless there is a place to refute it where it does not imply anything. Therefore, it is said, "Your father commanded before his death to say..." meaning from what he commanded before his death, it is implied that you should say to Joseph, "Please forgive the sin of your brothers." And Joseph understood their intention, and their words were confirmed in his eyes, and he forgave them. Through this, the measure of judgment was somewhat sweetened, and the power of the accusation was diminished.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of interpreting the words of the seventy holy ones, emphasizing that their statements, while not explicit, carry deep implications for understanding divine justice and mercy. It highlights the importance of seeking forgiveness from Joseph for the sin of selling him, suggesting that this act of humility can mitigate the severity of their punishment. The text illustrates how even indirect commands can hold significant weight in Jewish law and practice, reinforcing the idea that intentions and interpretations play a crucial role in spiritual matters. Ultimately, it conveys a message of reconciliation and the power of repentance to soften divine judgment.

passage_content: ואפ"ל באופן אחר עפי"ד רבינו בחיי ז"ל עה"פ ויבך יוסף בדברם אליו וז"ל הנה אחיו בקשו ממנו מחילה, ולא ביאר הכתוב שמחל להם, וכבר ביארו רז"ל שכל מו שחטא לחבירו ועשה תשובה, אינו נמחל לו לעולם עד שירצה את חבירו, ואע"פ שהזכיר הכתוב וינחם אותם וגו', מ"מ לא ראינו שיזכיר הכתוב מחילה ביוסף, ולא שיודה להם שישא פשעם וחטאתם, וא"כ מתו בענשם בלא מחילת יוסף, וא"א להתכפר עוונם רק במחילתו, וע"כ הוצרך העונש להיות כמוס וחתום להפקד אחר זמן בענין עשרה הרוגי מלכות עכ"ל ולפי"ז יתכן כו צוה יעאע"ה את השבטים בפירוש שיבקשו מיוסף מחילה, כי החוטא לחבירו צריך בעצמו לרצות את חבירו וזהו תיקונו לרצות עונו, ולא צוה ליוסף שא נא פשע אחיך, כי לא הי' נחשד בעיניו ח"ו שינקום מהם נקם.
translation: And even if in another way, according to our Rabbi Bachye, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And Joseph wept when they spoke to him," he writes: "Behold, his brothers asked him for forgiveness, and the text does not clarify that he forgave them. Our Sages have already explained that anyone who sins against his friend and repents is not forgiven until he appeases his friend. And although the text mentions 'and he comforted them,' we still do not see that the text mentions forgiveness from Joseph, nor that he acknowledged that he would bear their sin and transgression. Therefore, they died in their punishment without Joseph's forgiveness, and their sin cannot be atoned for except through his forgiveness. Thus, the punishment needed to be concealed and sealed to be accounted for later in the matter of the Ten Martyrs. According to this, it is possible that he commanded the tribes explicitly to ask Joseph for forgiveness, for one who sins against his friend must himself appease his friend, and this is his rectification to atone for his sin. He did not command Joseph to say, 'Bear the transgression of your brothers,' for he was not suspected in his eyes, Heaven forbid, of taking revenge on them.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the necessity of seeking forgiveness directly from the wronged party, as highlighted by the story of Joseph and his brothers. It emphasizes that true repentance requires the offender to appease the one they have wronged, and without this reconciliation, their sins remain unforgiven. The text suggests that Joseph's brothers needed to explicitly ask for his forgiveness, as their wrongdoing could not be absolved without his acknowledgment. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of interpersonal relationships and the importance of direct accountability in the process of atonement.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר כפל הלשון אביך צוה לפני מותו לאמר כה תאמרון ליוסף וגו', שמלת לאמר משמעותו בכ"מ לאמר לאחרים, ומה צורך לכפול עוד כה תאמרון ליוסף והוא מיותר, אכן אם הי' כתוב מלת לאמר בלבד, הי' מובן שכוונת הצוואה סובב ליוסף אלא שעשה ועאע"ה אותם שליחים לאמר ליוסף שא נא פשע אחיך. אבל באמת כוונת צוואתו הי' אליהם שהם דייקא יפייסו ליוסף לבקש מחילתו כנ"ל, וזהו טעם הכתוב אביך צוה לפני מותו לאמר כה תאמרון ליוסף וגו', שלא בתורת שליחות יגידו לו הדברים, כ"א יאמרו מפי עצמם לבקש מחילתו, אלא שהם אמרו בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין, שיבין יוסף ממשמעות דבריהם שאביו צוה לו שימחול להם, ובכגון זה מותר מפני דרכי שלום וכמו שכתב בספר הקדוש באר מים חיים (פרשת תולדות) דמה דאמרי חז"ל בג' דברים עבידי רבנן דמשני מילייהו, אין הכוונה שאומרים שקר ח"ו, אלא שמשתמשים בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין, וזה מותר מפני דרכי שלום וכו' עיי"ש
translation: And this will clarify the repetition of the phrase "Your father commanded before his death, saying, 'So shall you say to Joseph,' etc." The word "saying" implies in any context that it is to be said to others, and what is the need to repeat "So shall you say to Joseph," which seems superfluous? Indeed, if the word "saying" were written alone, it would be understood that the intent of the command was directed towards Joseph, but that he made them, may their memory be blessed, emissaries to say to Joseph, "Please forgive the transgression of your brothers." However, the true intent of his command was that they specifically should appease Joseph to request his forgiveness, as mentioned above. This is the reason for the verse "Your father commanded before his death, saying, 'So shall you say to Joseph,' etc.," that they should not convey the words in the manner of emissaries, but rather they should say from their own mouths to request his forgiveness. Yet, they spoke in a manner that could be understood in two ways, so that Joseph would understand from the meaning of their words that his father commanded him to forgive them. In such a case, it is permitted for the sake of peace, as it is written in the holy book "Be'er Mayim Chaim" (Parashat Toldot) that what our Sages say regarding three matters that the Rabbis acted in a way that changed their words, does not mean that they are saying falsehoods, Heaven forbid, but rather that they are using language that can be understood in two ways, and this is permitted for the sake of peace, etc. See there.
summary: The passage discusses the dual language in Jacob's command to his sons regarding Joseph, emphasizing that the term "saying" implies a directive meant for others. The repetition of "so shall you say to Joseph" indicates that the intent of the command was for the brothers themselves to seek Joseph's forgiveness, rather than acting merely as messengers. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the importance of personal responsibility in reconciliation and the concept of peace, as it allows for a nuanced communication that aligns with the principles of peace and understanding, as noted in the teachings of the Ba'er Mayim Chaim.
