passage_content: שי ויחי יעקב באמ"צ שבע עשרה שנה, כתב רשיז"ל למה פ' זו סתומה לפי שכיון שנפטר יע"א נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השיעבוד, ד"א שבקש לגלות את הקץ ונסתם ממנו וכן איתא בב"ר, והקשו המפורשים הרי ארז"ל דכל זמן שא' מהשבטים הי' קיים לא שעבדו המצריים בבנ"י, ואיתא במ"ר פ' שמות וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא, ללמדך שכ"ז שהי' קיים א' מאותן ע' נפש שירדו למצרים לא שעבדו המצריים בישראל, ובפרט כל זמן שיוסף הי' קיים שהי' מלך ומושל על מצרים, מבואר בדרז"ל שלא הי' עליהם משוי של מצרים כלל, ובסדר עולם איתא שכ"ז שהי' לוו קיים לא נשתעבדו, ולכאורה ראוי להבין במה פליגי כל הני מימרות ואיך יתכן שיחלוקו במציאות, ועוד קשה דלדברי כולם לא התחילה השיעבוד כי אם הרבה שנים אחר הסתלקות יע"א וא"כ צ"ב מ"ש רש"י ז"ל והמדרש שכיון שנפטר יעקב התחילה שעבוד מצרים על ישראל
translation: And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt for seventeen years. The author of the Reshiz"l wrote why this portion is closed: because when he passed away, may his merit protect us, the eyes and hearts of Israel were closed due to the distress of the servitude. Another explanation is that he sought to reveal the end, and it was concealed from him, as it is stated in Bereshit Rabbah. The commentators questioned, however, that our sages have said that as long as one of the tribes was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave the children of Israel. It is also stated in Midrash Rabbah, "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and all that generation," to teach you that as long as one of those seventy souls who went down to Egypt was alive, the Egyptians did not enslave Israel, especially as long as Joseph was alive, who was a king and ruler over Egypt. It is explained in the teachings of our sages that they had no burden of Egypt at all. And in the Order of the World, it is stated that as long as Levi was alive, they were not enslaved. At first glance, it is appropriate to understand how all these sayings disagree and how it is possible for them to differ in reality. Furthermore, it is difficult that according to all of them, the servitude did not begin until many years after the passing of our father Jacob. Therefore, it is puzzling what Rashi and the Midrash mean when they say that as soon as Jacob passed away, the Egyptian servitude began upon Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jacob's death and its implications for the Israelites' enslavement in Egypt. It highlights that the oppression began only after Jacob's passing, as his presence was a protective force for the Israelites. The text also explores the tension between various interpretations regarding the timing of the enslavement, emphasizing the belief that as long as a member of Jacob's family was alive, the Israelites were not subjected to oppression. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the connection between the patriarchs and the fate of their descendants, illustrating the protective role of the righteous in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ב) עוד איתא במד"ר דבר אחר למה היא סתומה שסתם ממנו כל הצרות שבעולם ע"כ, וצ"ב דהרי ראה יע"א ברוה"ק כל הצרות והגליות והחורבנות שעתידים לבוא על ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות כמבואר בדרז"ל, ואיך יתכן שנסתם ממנו כל הצרות שבעולם.
translation: B) It is also stated in the Midrash, another reason why it is sealed is that He sealed from Him all the troubles of the world. Therefore, it is questioned: How could He have seen, blessed be He, in the Holy Spirit all the troubles, exiles, and destructions that are destined to come upon Israel until the end of all generations, as explained in the teachings of our Sages, and how is it possible that all the troubles of the world were sealed from Him?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine concealment regarding the suffering and tribulations that the Jewish people will face throughout history. It raises a question about how the prophet could be shielded from the knowledge of all future hardships, despite having been shown many prophetic visions. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the balance between divine revelation and concealment, emphasizing that certain aspects of suffering are intentionally hidden to maintain hope and faith in God's ultimate plan for redemption. The text highlights the tension between the reality of suffering and the assurance of divine providence.

passage_content: ג) בזוה"ק איתא אמאי פרשתא דא סתימא, ר' יעקב אמר בשעתא דמית יעקב אסתימו עיניהון דישראל, ר' יהודה אומר דכדין נחתו לגלותא ואשתעבידו בהון, וכתבו מפרשי הזוה"ק דר' יעקב מפרש לי' על עסק התורה, שנסתמו מישראל מעיינות החכמה, שהי' יעקב אבינו מגלה להם, ואחר שנסתלק יעקב נפסק מהם השפעות הדעת והחכמה, ור' יהודה ס"ל דטעם הסתומה הוא מפני צרות השיעבוד, עוד שם ר"ש אומר מה כתיב לעילא ויאחזו בה ויפרו וירבו מאוד וכתיב ויחי יעקב וגו' וע"כ בא פרשה זו סתימה דלא אתחזי לאפרשא בין דא לדא, (שצ"ל מחובר לפרשה שלמעלה ולהקיש אלי') מה אינון קיימי בתפנוקין דמלכין וקבילו ענוגא וכו' אף יעקב נמי קיים בתפנוקי מלכין וכו' דכל יומוי בצערא הוו, ועלי' נאמר לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ויבוא רוגז, בתר דנחית למצרים חמא לכל בנוי זכאין צדיקים וכולהו בתענוגי ותפנוקי עלמא וכו' כדין ויחי יעקב, עכ"ד ר"ש בזוה"ק, ונראה שהי' קבלה לרז"ל שראוי להיות כאן הפסק פרשה (וכ"כ המזרחי ז"ל עיי"ש) וע"כ נתנו טעמים למה היא סתומה, ואפשר שדברי ר"ש בזוה"ק אתי' כמ"ד במד"ר הנ"ל שנסתם ממנו כל הצרות שבעולם, אלא שלא נתבאר במדרש כל צורכו, ובזוה"ק נתבאר יותר בחינה זו, אבל בכל אופן קשה למה צריך הסתומה ללמד ע"ז, וההיקש ל"ל, והרי מבואר כל זה בפסוקים שראה בניו ובני בנים, וארז"ל שלא נסתלק יע"א עד שראה ס' רבוא מבניו, ובוודאי שהי"ל תענוג גדול מזה, וגודל ההשפעה שנתן להם יוסף הצדיק תפנוקו מלכים ג"כ מבואר ומסתבר דבודאי לא יגרע יוסף מיעקב מאומה, אחרי שהיכולת בידו ולמה צריך לימוד ע"ז, וצ"ב כוונתם בזה.
translation: 3) In the Zohar it is stated why this section is closed. Rabbi Yaakov said that at the time of Yaakov's death, the eyes of Israel were closed. Rabbi Yehuda says that at that time they descended into exile and were enslaved. The commentators of the Zohar wrote that Rabbi Yaakov explains this in relation to the study of Torah, that the springs of wisdom were closed to Israel, which Yaakov Avinu was revealing to them. After Yaakov departed, the influences of knowledge and wisdom ceased from them. Rabbi Yehuda holds that the reason for the closure is due to the troubles of servitude. Furthermore, there Rabbi Shimon says, what is written above, "And they seized it and multiplied greatly," and it is written, "And Yaakov lived, etc." Therefore, this closed section comes, as it does not appear to separate between this and that (which must be connected to the section above and to be compared to it). What are they engaged in the delights of kings and receiving pleasure, etc.? Even Yaakov also existed in the delights of kings, etc., for all his days were in suffering, and concerning him it is said, "I have not had rest nor quiet, and trouble came." After he descended to Egypt, he saw all his righteous sons and all of them in the pleasures and delights of the world, etc., just as "And Yaakov lived." Thus said Rabbi Shimon in the Zohar, and it seems that there was a tradition among the sages that it is appropriate for there to be a break in the section here (and so wrote the Mizrachi, may his memory be blessed, see there). Therefore, they gave reasons why it is closed, and it is possible that the words of Rabbi Shimon in the Zohar come in accordance with the opinion in the Midrash mentioned above that all the troubles of the world were closed off from him, but it was not fully explained in the Midrash. In the Zohar, this aspect is explained more. However, in any case, it is difficult to understand why the closure is necessary to teach this, and the comparison is not needed, for it is clearly stated in the verses that he saw his sons and grandsons, and our sages said that he did not depart until he saw 600,000 of his sons. Certainly, he had great pleasure from this, and the greatness of the influence that Yosef the Righteous gave them, the delights of kings, is also explained and it is reasonable that Yosef would not diminish anything from Yaakov. After all, the ability was in his hands, so why is there a need to teach this? It is unclear what their intention is in this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the "closed" section in the Zohar, relating to the death of Jacob and the subsequent spiritual implications for the Jewish people. Rabbi Yaakov interprets this closure as a metaphor for the cessation of wisdom and knowledge that Jacob imparted, while Rabbi Yehuda attributes it to the suffering of exile. The text emphasizes the connection between Jacob's experiences and the spiritual nourishment provided to his descendants, suggesting that despite the hardships, there remains a divine connection and continuity of blessings through figures like Joseph. Ultimately, the passage reflects on the interplay between suffering, divine providence, and the enduring legacy of the patriarchs in Jewish thought.

passage_content: ועו"ק בין לדברי ר' יהודה שבזוה"ק ובין לדברי המד"ר, שטעם הסתומה הוח לפי שכיון שנפטר יע"א נסתמו עיניהם של ישראל והתחילה צרות השעבוד, לפי"ז הי' צריך להיות סתימת הפרשה אצל פטירת יע"א בסו"פ ויחי, ולמה נכתבה הסתומה שלא במקומה אצל ויחי יעקב, וגם לאידך פירושא שברש"י ז"ל ובמדרש, דטעם הסתומה הוא לפי שבקש לגלות הקץ ונסתם ממנו, לפ"ז הו' צ"ל הסתומה אצל האספו ואגידה לכם וכו' שדרשו רז"ל שרצה לגלות קץ הגאולה ונסתם ממנו ושם הי' צ"ל הסתומה ולא כאן אצל ויחי יעקב.
translation: And there is a question between the words of Rabbi Yehuda in the Zohar and the words of the Midrash, that the reason for the closed section is because when he passed away, may his merit protect us, the eyes of Israel were closed and the troubles of servitude began. According to this, the closed section should have been at the time of the passing of our teacher, at the end of Vayechi. Why, then, was the closed section written out of its place at Vayechi Yaakov? And according to the other explanation in Rashi and in the Midrash, that the reason for the closed section is because he sought to reveal the end and it was concealed from him, according to this, the closed section should have been at the gathering, "And I will tell you..." etc., where our Sages taught that he wanted to reveal the end of the redemption and it was concealed from him, and there should have been the closed section, not here at Vayechi Yaakov.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "סתימה" (sealing) in relation to the death of Yaakov Avinu and the subsequent suffering of the Jewish people. It contrasts interpretations from Rabbi Yehuda in the Zohar and the Midrash, questioning why the sealing appears in the context of Yaakov's death rather than at the moment of the revelation of the end of days. The text suggests that the sealing signifies a divine withholding of knowledge regarding the redemption, emphasizing the tension between human longing for understanding and the mysteries of divine providence. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound implications of suffering and the hiddenness of redemption in Jewish thought.

passage_content: ה) להלן בפרשה וירא ישראל את בני יוסף ויאמר מי אלה, פירש"י ז"ל בקש לברכם ונסתלקה ממנו שכינה לפי שעתיד ירבעם ואחאב לצאת מאפרים וכו' ויאמר מי אלה מהיכן יצאו אלה שאין ראוין לברכה, ויאמר יוסף בני הם אשר נתן לי אלקים בזה, הראה לו שטר אירוסין ושער כתובה וכו' וצ"ב דמאי תיקן בזה, וכי הי' נחשד בעיני יעקב שאין לו שטר אירוסין או כתובה, והלא ידע בצדקו כמ"ש אחרי ראותי פניך כו עודך חי, ופי' המפורשים דצדיקים נקראים חיים והכיר בצדקו שיוסף עדיין בבחי' חי וכל צערו של יעקב הי' מפני שראה דורות הרעים העתידים לצאת ממנו כמ"ש פרש"י ז"ל, וע"ז היתה שאלתו מי אלה שאינם ראוים לברכה, וא"כ לא תיקן יוסף כלום במה שהראה לו שער אירוסין וכתובה, ות"א פי' בני אינון די הב לי ה' הכא וצ"ב הכוונה בזה דמנפק"מ או הכא או במקום אחר, גם מלת בזה מיותר, וצ"ב.
translation: 5) Here in the section "And Israel saw the sons of Joseph and said, 'Who are these?'" Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that he sought to bless them, but the Shechinah departed from him because Jeroboam and Ahab were destined to come from Ephraim, etc. And he said, "Who are these? From where did these come who are not worthy of a blessing?" And Joseph said, "They are my sons whom God has given me here." He showed him the marriage contract and the ketubah, etc. And it is difficult to understand what he accomplished with this. Was he suspected in Jacob's eyes of not having a marriage contract or a ketubah? Surely he knew of his righteousness, as it is said, "After seeing your face, it is as if I have seen the face of God, and you are still alive." And the explanation of the commentators is that the righteous are called alive, and he recognized his righteousness that Joseph was still in a state of life. All of Jacob's sorrow was because he saw the evil generations that were destined to come from him, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains. And this was his question, "Who are these who are not worthy of a blessing?" Therefore, Joseph did not accomplish anything by showing him the marriage contract and the ketubah. And the Targum explains, "These are my sons whom God has given me here," and it is difficult to understand the intention of this, whether it is relevant here or in another place. Also, the word "here" is superfluous, and it is difficult to understand.
summary: In this passage, the focus is on the tension between Jacob's perception of his son Joseph's children and the future implications of their lineage, particularly concerning the wickedness of future generations like Jeroboam and Ahab. Jacob's question, "Who are these?" reflects his concern that they are unworthy of blessing, leading to Joseph's demonstration of their legitimacy through the presentation of a marriage contract. This act serves to affirm Joseph's righteousness and the divine blessing he has received, despite Jacob's initial doubts. The discussion highlights the Hasidic themes of divine providence, the significance of lineage, and the interplay between righteousness and the potential for future moral failure.

passage_content: ו) והענין בעצמו הוא פלא דמה נתחדש ליעקב עכשיו מה שלא ודע בה עד הנה, דמה שעתיד ירבעם ואחאב לצאת ממנו, דבר זה הי' ידוע גם להשבטים הק', כמו שארז"ל על הפסוק הנה בעל החלומות הלזה בא, שאמרו השבטים עתיד זה להשיאם לבעלים, שיצא ממנו ירבעם שושואם לע"ז, ומכ"ש שהי' ידוע ליע"א, כמבואר בדרז"ל בכ"מ במדרשים, שראה יעקב כל המאורעות והחורבנות, וכל מה שיארע לישראל עד סוף כל הדורות וחורבן בית ראשון הו' בעון ע"ז ושורש החטא הי' ע"י ירבעם, א"כ ידע יעקב מכל זה ואעפי"כ ברכם ונתן להם חלק ב' השבטים אפרים ומנשה כראובן ושמעון יהיו לו, ומה ניתוסף לו עכשיו ידיעה מחודשת, שאמר מי אלה שאינם ראויים לברכה, והרי כ"ז הי' נודע לו מכבר.
translation: And the matter itself is a wonder of what was newly revealed to Jacob now that he did not know until now, for what would come forth from him, Jeroboam and Ahab, this matter was known also to the holy tribes, as our sages have said on the verse, "Behold, this master of dreams is coming," that the tribes said this one is destined to lead them to idolatry, that Jeroboam would come forth from him, how much more so it was known to the Holy One, blessed be He, as is explained in the teachings of our sages in many places in the Midrashim, that Jacob saw all the events and destructions, and all that would happen to Israel until the end of all generations, and the destruction of the First Temple was due to the sin of idolatry, and the root of the sin was through Jeroboam. Therefore, Jacob knew all this, and nevertheless, he blessed them and gave them a portion of the two tribes, Ephraim and Manasseh, as Reuben and Simeon would have, so what new knowledge was added to him now, that he said, "Who are these that are not worthy of a blessing," when all this was already known to him beforehand.
summary: הקטע עוסק בפלא שבידיעתו של יעקב אבינו, אשר גילה דבר חדש על עתידו של עם ישראל, למרות שידע על חטאי ירבעם ואחאב והשפעתם על השבטים. יעקב היה מודע לכל המאורעות והחורבנות שיתרחשו, אך עדיין בחר לברך את השבטים אפרים ומנשה, מה שמעיד על אמונתו בחסד ובתיקון. השאלה "מי אלה שאינם ראויים לברכה" מצביעה על תובנה חדשה שגילה, הממחישה את המתח בין ידיעה מראש לבין חופש הרצון והאפשרות לתיקון.

passage_content: וביותר קשה מ"ש ז"ל שנסתלקה ממנו שכינה לפי שעתיד ירבעם לצאת ממנו, הלא אצל הבוי"ת לא שייך שום התחדשות, וגלוי לפניו ית' שעתיד ירבעם לצאת ממנו, ואעפי"כ הסכים השי"ת על ברכת ב' השבטים שנתן יעקב לאפרים ומנשה, כי הי' כדאי בזכות דורות הצדיקים שיצאו ממנו, יהושע וגדעון ועוד כמה צדיקים שעתיד להתקדש ש"ש על ידיהם, ומה נתחדשה עכשיו שנסתלקה ממנו שכינה ונמנע מהם הברכה.
translation: And even more difficult is what our sages of blessed memory said, that the Shechinah departed from him because Jeroboam was destined to come from him. Is it not true that with the Blessed One, there is no concept of renewal? It is revealed before Him, blessed be He, that Jeroboam would come from him, and yet the Holy One, blessed be He, agreed to the blessing of the two tribes that Jacob gave to Ephraim and Manasseh, for they were worthy due to the merit of the righteous generations that would come from them, such as Joshua, Gideon, and several other righteous ones who would be sanctified through them. So what was renewed now that the Shechinah departed from him and the blessing was withheld from them?
summary: The passage discusses the theological tension between divine foreknowledge and the withdrawal of the Shechinah (Divine Presence) from Jeroboam, despite God's awareness of his future. It emphasizes that even though God foresaw Jeroboam's emergence, He still granted blessings to Ephraim and Manasseh due to the merit of the righteous descendants, such as Joshua and Gideon. The text raises questions about the nature of divine providence and the implications of human actions on spiritual blessings. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of divine justice and mercy within the framework of Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ז) להלן בסוף הפרשה כתיב וינחם אותם וידבר על לבם וצ"ב כי אינו מבואר בפסוק מה היתה הנחמה ההוא, ומה דיבר אליהם, ולעיל מפורש כל דברי יוסף אליהם, ומה הוסיף הכתוב בכוונה כאן, ואם הי' זה דיבור נוסף על הנ"ל, הרי לא ביארו הכתוב מה הי' וצ"ב. גם מ"ש וידבר על לבם צ"ב דהול"ל וידבר אליהם, ורש"י פי' דברים המתקבלים על הלב אבל מ"מ אינו מבואר בקרא וטעמא בעי.
translation: 7) Later at the end of the parasha it is written, "and he comforted them and spoke to their hearts," and it is puzzling because the verse does not clarify what that comfort was, and what he spoke to them. Earlier, all of Joseph's words to them are explicitly stated, so what additional intention does the text have here? If this was an additional speech beyond the aforementioned, the text does not explain what it was, and it is puzzling. Also, regarding the phrase "and he spoke to their hearts," it is puzzling because it could have said "and he spoke to them." Rashi explains that these are words that are accepted by the heart, but nonetheless, it is not clarified in the verse, and the reason is needed.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the biblical verse that describes how Joseph comforted his brothers after their reunion, questioning the nature of this comfort and the specific words he spoke to them. The text emphasizes the ambiguity of the term "comfort" and the phrase "spoke to their hearts," suggesting a deeper, more profound communication that transcends mere words. The inquiry into why the scripture does not explicitly detail this comfort highlights the Hasidic belief in the importance of inner emotional and spiritual connection, as well as the transformative power of heartfelt dialogue. Ultimately, the passage invites contemplation on the nuances of divine communication and the healing that comes from genuine understanding and empathy.

passage_content: ולבאר כל הענין נקדים מ"ש בספה"ק בעלי ברית אברהם מבעל חסד לאברהם וז"ל מצאתי כתוב שכאשר הביא יוסף את מנשה ואת אפרים לפני יעקב לברכם, בא השטן והכניס צורת העגלים אאעתיד להעמיד ירבעם, והפסולים שעתיד להעמיד אחאב, והעמידם לפני יעקב, ואז נסתלקה ממנו שכינה, ע"ד לא יגורך רע, ואז גער הקב"ה בהשטן והוציא את העגלים לחוץ, ומיד חזרה השכינה ושרתה על יעקב עכ"ל, ובמדרש הגדול איתא ויאמר יעקב מו אלה בא עגלו של ירבעם ועמד כנגדו ואמר מי אלה עכ"ל. ולפי"ז יבואר קצת הענין דאע"פ שהי' גלוי וידוע לפניו ית' מעשה ירבעם ואחאב, אעפי"כ לא הי' מונע הוא ית' הברכה מהם, כי היו כדאי בזכות דורות הצדיקים שעתידים לצאת מאתם, אבל כיון שבא השטן וקטרג והביא צורות עגלים של ע"ז בביתו של יעקב, ע"כ נסתלקה ממנו שכינה בהכרח, כי אתך לא יגורך רע, ובקש יוסף רחמים כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל ובזכותו של יוסף הצדיק ובכח תפלתו, גער ה' בהשטן להוציאם, וחזרה השראת השכינה למקומה, ולא נתחדש עכשיו ידיעה מחודשת, וגלוי וידוע הי' לפניו ית' שירבעם ואחאב עתידים לצאת ממנו, אלא שגרם השטן סילוק שכינה ע"י צורות העגלים שהכניס.
translation:
To clarify the entire matter, we will begin with what is written in the holy book "Ba'alei Berit Avraham" by the author of "Chesed Le'Avraham." It is stated that when Joseph brought Manasseh and Ephraim before Jacob to bless them, the Satan came and introduced the forms of the calves that Jeroboam would establish, and the disqualified ones that Ahab would establish, and he placed them before Jacob. Then the Shechinah departed from him, in accordance with the principle that "no evil shall befall you." Then the Holy One, blessed be He, rebuked the Satan and cast the calves outside, and immediately the Shechinah returned and rested upon Jacob. Thus far the text. And in the Midrash Rabba, it is written that Jacob said, "Who are these?" and the calf of Jeroboam stood against him and said, "Who are these?" Thus far the text. 

According to this, we can explain somewhat the matter that although it was revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, the actions of Jeroboam and Ahab, nevertheless, He did not withhold the blessing from them, for they were worthy due to the merit of the righteous generations that would come from them. However, since the Satan came and accused and brought the forms of the calves of idolatry into Jacob's house, therefore the Shechinah necessarily departed from him, for "with You, no evil shall befall." And Joseph sought mercy, as Rashi, blessed be his memory, states, and by the merit of Joseph the righteous and the power of his prayer, the Lord rebuked the Satan to cast them out, and the resting of the Shechinah returned to its place. There was no new knowledge revealed now, for it was revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, that Jeroboam and Ahab were destined to come from him, but the Satan caused the departure of the Shechinah through the forms of the calves that he introduced.
summary: The passage discusses the incident when Joseph brought his sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, to Jacob for a blessing, during which the Satan introduced the forms of the future golden calves associated with Jeroboam and Ahab, causing the Shechinah to withdraw from Jacob. Despite God's foreknowledge of the future actions of Jeroboam and Ahab, He did not prevent the blessing due to the merit of the righteous descendants that would come from them. However, the presence of the idol forms led to the necessary withdrawal of the Shechinah, which was only restored through Joseph's prayers and merits. This illustrates the interplay between divine foreknowledge, human merit, and the impact of spiritual forces in the world.

passage_content: ויתבאר הענין יותר עפי"מ שפירשתי מ"ש חז"ל (סנהדרין ק"ג ע"ב) מנשה העמיד צלם בהיכל ויליף לה מקרא עיי"ש, ולכאורה יפלא דאיך יתכן שכל ישראל שתקו ולא מיחו בו ואיך עשו העבודה כ"ז שהי' ע"ז בהיכל, וא"כ נתבטלה העבודה ונתבעל התמיד, ולא מצינו כן בשום מקום לא בפסוקים ולא בדברי רז"ל, ופירשתי עפמ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל (מכות י' ע"ב) דממחשבת עבירה נברא מלאך רע, וממחשבת מצוה נברא מלאך קדוש, ופי' בזה מאמר הגמ' בדרך שאדם רוצה לילך מוליכין אותו, דאותן המלאכים שנבראו מרצונו וממחשבתו, מוליכין אותו לגמור מעשהו כפי דעתו ומחשבתו עיי"ש, ונקדים עוד מ"ש האוהחה"ק בפ' תשא (עה"פ ולא יהי' בהם נגף) וז"ל ומצינו שרז"ל אמרו כי מן השמים הכשילוהו לדהמע"ה בדבר שאפי' תשב"ר יודעים וכו' לטעם אמרו אם ה' הסיתך בי, ופי' דבריהם כי לצד שקרא לה' ח"ו מסית, נברא מלאך רע וכו' והוא מין העון ממש כמעשהו, ולזה נברא מלאך רע מסית שמו, והסיתו והטעהו לעשותן כן בסוד עבירה גוררת עבירה וכו' עכ"פ מבואר דהמלאך שנברא מהעבירה נקרא ע"ש העבירה, דמשם שרשו ובריאתו.
translation: And the matter will be explained further according to what I have interpreted regarding what our Sages said (Sanhedrin 103b) that Menashe set up an idol in the Temple and learned it from a verse, as stated there. At first glance, it is puzzling how all of Israel remained silent and did not protest against him, and how they continued to serve while there was an idol in the Temple. If so, the service was nullified and the daily offering was rendered invalid, and we do not find this anywhere, neither in the verses nor in the words of our Sages. I have explained according to what the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, said (Makkot 10b) that from the thought of a transgression a wicked angel is created, and from the thought of a commandment a holy angel is created. He explained this in light of the saying of the Gemara that "in the way that a person wishes to go, they lead him," for those angels that are created from his will and thought lead him to complete his actions according to his opinion and thought, as stated there. We will also precede with what the holy Ohr HaChaim wrote in Parashat Terumah (on the verse "and there shall not be a plague among them") that it is found that our Sages said that from Heaven they caused King David to stumble in a matter that even the most righteous know, etc., for the reason they said, "If the Lord has incited you against me." The explanation of their words is that because he called the Lord, Heaven forbid, an inciter, a wicked angel was created, etc., and it is a type of sin just like his action. Therefore, a wicked angel named "Inciter" was created, and he incited and misled him to do so, as the secret of sin leads to sin, etc. In any case, it is clear that the angel created from the transgression is named after the transgression, for that is where its root and creation come from.
summary: The passage discusses the troubling phenomenon of the Israelites' silence during King Manasseh's idolatry in the Temple, questioning how they could accept such a transgression. It references the concept that thoughts of sin can create negative spiritual forces, while thoughts of mitzvot generate positive ones, as explained by the Maharsha. The text emphasizes that actions are influenced by the angels created from one's intentions, and that a sin can lead to further transgressions, illustrating the profound connection between thought, action, and the spiritual consequences that follow.

passage_content: ואפשר שזהו כוונת הכתוב וכוונת דבריהם ז"ל במ"ש על מנשה שהעמיד צלם בהיכל לא שעשה כן בפועל ממש אלא שהי"ל מחשבת ע"ז בעמדו בהיכל ה', וברא במחשבתו מלאכים רעים מכוחות הטומאה, והיו מלאכים אלו בדמות הצלם ובחי' ע"ז ממש כמ"ש לעיל דמלאך הנברא מעבירה או ממחשבת עבירה ר"ל, שרשו ובחינתו הוא ממש כדמות העבירה ויקרא שמו בשם העבירה ההוא אשר נוצר ממנה, ואלו המלאכים שנבראו מקליפת ע"ז הי"ל בחי' הצלם ממש, ואותם הכניס מנשה בהיכל ה' ע"י מחשבת ע"ז, ובחי' זו לא יורגש לסתם בנ"א, ורוב ישראל לא הרגישו בו ולא ראו צורות אלו, ורק לזכי הראות ויחידי סגולה יש בכח ראיית שכלם להרגיש בזה, וע"כ לא נתבטל העבודה והקרבת התמיד בביהמ"ק, גם לא הי' מציאות למנעו מזה כי לא עשה מעשה הרע בפועל כ"א במחשבה.
translation: And it is possible that this is the intention of the verse and the intention of their words, may their memory be blessed, regarding Manasseh, who set up an idol in the Temple, not that he did so in actual deed, but that he had the thought of idolatry while standing in the Temple of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And he created in his thought evil angels from the forces of impurity, and these angels were in the form of the idol and in the essence of idolatry itself, as mentioned above, that an angel created from a transgression or from the thought of a transgression, its root and essence is truly like the form of the transgression, and it is called by the name of that transgression from which it was created. And these angels that were created from the shell of idolatry were in the essence of the idol itself, and those he brought into the Temple of the Holy One through the thought of idolatry. And this essence would not be felt by the average person, and most of Israel did not sense it nor see these forms, only those with clear vision and select individuals have the power of their intellect to perceive this. Therefore, the service and the offering of the daily sacrifice in the Holy Temple were not nullified, nor was there a possibility to prevent it, for he did not commit the evil act in deed, but only in thought.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that King Menashe's idolatrous thoughts, rather than physical actions, created negative spiritual forces, represented by angels formed from the impurity of idolatry. These angels, resembling the idol, were introduced into the Holy Temple through Menashe's thoughts, yet remained undetected by most people, except for the spiritually sensitive individuals. This highlights the idea that thoughts can have profound spiritual implications, even if not manifested in action, and emphasizes the ongoing sanctity of the Temple service despite the presence of such negative influences.

passage_content: וכמו"כ אפ"ל כוונתם ז"ל במדרש הנ"ל שהכניס השטן צורת העגלים שעתיד להעמיד ירבעם ואחאב, אין כוונתם ז"ל על העגלים ופסילים בפועל ממש, כי לא היו הצורות האלו עדיין במציאות בעולם, אלא שהכניס השטן צורת המלאכים מקליפת ע"ז העתידים להבראות ע"ו עגלי ירבעם ופסולי אחאב, והם בבחי' העגלים והפסולים ממש, ויש בכח השטן להראות צורות כאלו, כי הם מכוחו וכת דילי', ועי"ז גרם שנסתלקה שכינה כו אתך לא יגורך רע, וע"י שהכניס בחי' ע"ז לביתו של יעקב מנע השראת השכינה והברכה. ויעקב אבינו ויוסף הצדיק ראו הצורות והרגישו בהם, כי דבר זו יושג לזכי הראות, וע"כ אמר יעקב מל אלה שאינן ראויים לברכה, עד שבקש יוסף רחמים וגער ה' בשטן והוציאם, וחזרה השראת השכינה על יעקב אבינו וברכם.
translation: And likewise, one can say their intention, may their memory be blessed, in the aforementioned Midrash that the Satan introduced the form of the calves that Jeroboam and Ahab would eventually establish. Their intention, may their memory be blessed, is not about the actual calves and idols, for these forms did not yet exist in the world, but rather that the Satan introduced the forms of the angels from the klipah of idolatry that are destined to be created, namely the calves of Jeroboam and the idols of Ahab. They are in the category of actual calves and idols, and the Satan has the power to show such forms, for they are from his power and his faction. And through this, he caused the Shechinah to withdraw, as it is written, "With you, evil shall not approach." And by introducing the aspect of idolatry into the house of Jacob, he prevented the dwelling of the Shechinah and the blessing. And our forefather Jacob and the righteous Joseph saw the forms and felt them, for this matter can be grasped by those who are pure of vision. Therefore, Jacob said, "From these who are unworthy of blessing," until Joseph requested mercy and rebuked the Holy One, blessed be He, against the Satan and removed them, and the dwelling of the Shechinah returned to our forefather Jacob, and he blessed them.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the Satan introducing the forms of the future idols associated with Jeroboam and Ahab, not as physical entities but as spiritual representations that could disrupt divine presence. It emphasizes that these forms stem from the realm of idolatry and that the Satan has the power to manifest such images, which leads to the withdrawal of the Shechinah (divine presence) from Jacob's household. Jacob and Joseph, possessing spiritual insight, recognized these forms and sought to remove them, ultimately restoring the Shechinah and blessing to Jacob. This highlights the importance of spiritual clarity and the struggle against idolatry in maintaining divine connection.

passage_content: ואפשר שזהו כוונת הכתוב ויאמר יוסף אל אביו בני הם אשר נתן לי אלקים בזה, כי יוסף הצדיק כשראה מה עשה השטן ע"י צורות מלאכי העבירה שהכניס, שגרם עי"ז הסתלקות השכינה, ע"כ הכניס גם הוא צורות מלאכים קדושים, בדמות אותן המלאכים העתידים להבראות ע"ו דורות הצדיקים שיעמדו ממנו, וצורות המלאכים שעתידים להבראות ע"י תורתו של יהושע, וע"י קידוש ש"ש בכל העולם בהעמדת השמש והירח, וע"י גדעון ושאר צדיקים שיעמדו מבניו, ויוסף הי' שליט במלאכים הקדושים והי"ל מחנות של מלאכים שנבראו ע"ו תורתו ומצותיו ועבודת השי"ת שעשה כל ימי חייו, וע"כ הזמין והכניס צורות מלאכים קדושים, בדמות אותן המלאכים העתידים להבראות ע"י בניו ודורות הצדיקים שיעמדו מבניו. וז"ש בני הם אשר נתן לי אלקים בזה ות"א בני אינון די הב לי ה' הכא שהראה על אותן המלאכים וצורות הקדושות, ואמר אלו הם בני וראויים להשראת השכינה והברכה, ומדוייק מלת בזה ומה שת"א הכא כי הראה עליהם לומר זהו, והכא הוויין, והמשיך אור גדול בביתו של יע"א עי"ז, וחזרה השראת השכינה ונתקיימה שפיר השראת הברכה בשלימות.
translation: And it is possible that this is the intention of the verse, "And Joseph said to his father, 'These are my sons whom God has given me here,'" for when Joseph the Righteous saw what the Satan had done through the forms of the ministering angels that he introduced, which caused the withdrawal of the Shechinah, he also introduced forms of holy angels, in the likeness of those angels that were to be created from the 46 generations of the righteous that would arise from him, and the forms of the angels that were to be created through the Torah of Joshua, and through the sanctification of the Name in the world by the establishment of the sun and the moon, and by Gideon and other righteous ones who would arise from his sons. And Joseph had dominion over the holy angels, and he had a host of angels that were created from the 46 of his Torah, commandments, and the service of the Blessed One that he performed all the days of his life. Therefore, he prepared and introduced forms of holy angels, in the likeness of those angels that were to be created by his sons and the generations of the righteous that would arise from his sons. And this is what is meant by "These are my sons whom God has given me here," and the Targum translates, "These are the ones that the Lord has shown me here," indicating those angels and holy forms, and he said, "These are my sons and they are worthy of the resting of the Shechinah and blessing." And the word "here" is precise, and what the Targum means here is that he showed them to say, "This is it, and here they are," and he brought a great light into the house of his father, and through this, the resting of the Shechinah returned, and the resting of the blessing was established in completeness.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses how Joseph, upon recognizing the spiritual damage caused by the forces of evil, introduced holy angelic forms that represent the future righteous generations stemming from him. He emphasizes that these forms are connected to the teachings of Joshua and the sanctification of God's name, which ultimately restores the Divine presence and blessings in his home. The text highlights the significance of Joseph's actions in creating a conduit for holiness and the continuation of divine influence through his descendants.

passage_content: ואפ"ל רמז במ"ש רש"י ז"ל הראה לו שטר אירוסין וכו' דנוסח שער אירוסין הנהוג בכל תפוצות ישראל להתחיל במאמר המגיד מראשית אחרית, לכוונה שימשך ע"י זיווג זה אחרית טוב ובנין עדי עד, ואפשר שלכוונה זו הראה יוסף ליעקב שטר האירוסין, כי זכי הראות רואין מראשית אחרית דבר, ורמז לו האחרית הטוב ודורות הצדיקים העתידים לצאת ממנו, וע"כ ראויים הם אפרים ומנשה לברכה בזכותם.
translation: And even though there is a hint in what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote that he showed him a marriage contract, etc., the formula of the marriage contract that is customary in all Jewish communities begins with the statement of the Maggid from the beginning of the end, with the intention that through this union, a good end and an everlasting building will be drawn forth. It is possible that with this intention, Joseph showed Jacob the marriage contract, for those who are worthy of vision see from the beginning the end of a matter, and he hinted to him the good end and the generations of the righteous that will emerge from him. Therefore, Ephraim and Menashe are worthy of blessing by virtue of them.
summary: In this passage, the author highlights the significance of the marriage contract (sh'tar erusin) as a symbol of the connection between the beginning and the end, reflecting the Hasidic belief in the continuity of divine purpose through generations. The reference to the phrase "from the beginning to the end" emphasizes the idea that righteous individuals, like Joseph, can perceive the ultimate good that will emerge from their actions. This foresight is linked to the blessings bestowed upon Ephraim and Manasseh, who are seen as worthy due to their lineage and the future generations of righteous descendants that will arise from them.

passage_content: ודברי רז"ל במדרש הנ"ל המה מוסר השכל, ורעדה ופחד יאחז בשום אל לב, שהי' בכח השען לגרום סילוק השכינה מביתו של יע"א, ולמנוע הברכה ע"י שהכניס צורות המלאכים, העתידים להבראות לאחר כמה דורות ממחשבת ומעשה עבירה ר"ל, ומה נאמר ומה נדבר בעוה"ר, מי יודע כמה וכמה הבאים לביהכנ"ס וביהמ"ד, ורוצים להתפלל לפניו ית' בלב נקי ופנוי מהרהורים, אבל ע"ו שלא נטהרו מכתמי ילדותיהם ולא עשו עדיין תשובה על חטאת נעוריהם, ועדיין רושם החטא קיים, ע"כ יש כח בהשען להתגבר עליהם, ואם מידי מעשה יצאו אבל מידי מחשבה לא נטהרו לגמרי, וכשבאין לביהכנ"ס להתפלל וללמוד, ואינם יכולים לטהר מחשבותיהם כראוי, עי"ז מכניסין בעוה"ר צורות מלאכי עבירה בבכנ"ס ובתי מדרשות, והצורות האלו גורמין ח"ו סילוק השכינה, ומונעין תפלת הרבים מלהתקבל. עכ"פ צריך כ"א להשים על לבו חומר העון והפגם, ויכלול עצמו עם תשובת הרבים, וכתב ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה בפ' האזינו עה"פ ארפא משובתם אוהבם נדבה, דתשובת הרבים אף שע"פ הרוב, מן הנמנע שישובו כולם מאהבה, דאי אפשר שיהיו כולם במדריגה זו, ומסתמא תשובת הרבים הוא מיראה, אבל בכח זכותי' דרבים דנפיש, הקב"ה מקבלם כתשובה מאהבה עיי"ש, ובעוה"ר בחטא הידוע בניקל הוא שיזדמן להצטרף עם תשובת הרבים, כי רבים נכשלין בה, וזעירין אינון הנקיים ממנה, וע"כ במקהלות עם כשיש התעוררות תשובה על עון זה, הוא בבחי' תשובת הרבים כי רבים צריכין לה, והשי"ת יצרף תשובתינו עם אלו העושין תשובה שלימה לפניו ית' באמת ובתמים בכל לבבם ובכל נפשם.
translation: And the words of our Sages in the aforementioned Midrash are a moral lesson, and trembling and fear should seize the heart, for it was within the power of the watchman to cause the removal of the Shechinah from the house of the righteous, and to prevent the blessing by introducing the forms of the angels, who are destined to be created after several generations from the thought and action of sin, Heaven forbid. And what shall we say and what shall we speak in this generation? Who knows how many come to the synagogue and the study house, and wish to pray before Him, blessed be He, with a pure heart free from thoughts of sin, but due to their sins they have not yet purified themselves from the stains of their youth and have not yet repented for the sins of their youth, and the mark of sin still exists. Therefore, the watchman has the power to overpower them, and although they may have left the realm of action, they have not completely purified themselves from the realm of thought. When they come to the synagogue to pray and learn, and they cannot purify their thoughts properly, they thereby introduce, Heaven forbid, the forms of sinful angels into the synagogue and study houses, and these forms cause, Heaven forbid, the removal of the Shechinah and prevent the prayers of the community from being accepted. Nevertheless, everyone must place upon their heart the gravity of sin and flaw, and include themselves with the repentance of the community. And it is written in the holy book of the Yeshiva, may its memory be blessed, in the portion of Haazinu on the verse "I will heal their backsliding, I will love them freely," that the repentance of the community, even though it is based on the majority, it is unlikely that all will return out of love, for it is impossible for all to be on this level, and certainly the repentance of the community is out of fear. However, by the merit of the many who are numerous, the Holy One, blessed be He, accepts them as repentance out of love, as stated there. And in this generation, with the known sin that is easy to stumble into, it is likely to join with the repentance of the community, for many stumble in it, and few are those who are clean from it. Therefore, in gatherings of the community, when there is an awakening to repent for this sin, it is in the category of the repentance of the community, for many need it, and may the Blessed One join our repentance with those who are truly and sincerely repenting before Him with all their heart and all their soul.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound impact of individual and communal sin on the presence of the Divine, highlighting that even unintentional thoughts can lead to the removal of the Shechinah from sacred spaces. It underscores the importance of collective repentance, particularly in the context of communal prayer, where the majority may not achieve a pure state of heart. The text reassures that despite the challenges of achieving repentance from love, the merit of the community can elevate their prayers and facilitate divine acceptance. Ultimately, it calls for unity in seeking genuine repentance to restore the connection with God.

passage_content: ונחזור לבאר במה שהתחלנו למה פרשה זו סתומה ולמה נכתבה הסתומה אצל ויחי יעקב כקושיתנו הנ"ל, גם יתבאר לדרכנו סמיכות ויחי יעקב להפסוק ויאחזו בה וגו' כדברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל. ונקדים קושיא עצומה, דהנה נתרבו ישראל במצרים שלא כדרך הטבע ובדרך נס, שבאו למצרים ע' נפש, ובי"ז שנים שהי' יעקב במצרים העמיד ס' רבוא מבניו, כמ"ש רז"ל במדרש, שלא נסתלק יעקב עד שראה ס' רבוא מבניו וכו', ונתקיימה לו הבטחת השי"ת כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, ובארץ ישראל הוו יעקב והשבטים יותר מל' שנים, משהיו ראויים השבעים לנשואין ולהעמיד תולדות, ובכל אותן השנים לא העמיד אלא ע' נפש, ובדרך הטבע הי' צ"ל הרבה יותר, ובפרט באותן הדורות והי' נס שלא כדרך הטבע שלא הפרו והרבו שם, ובמצרים הי' הנס להיפוך, שנעשה להם נסי נסים ונתרבו שלא כדרך הטבע לס' רבוא בי"ז שנים, וטעמא בעי למה הי' צורך לנס זה שלא יפרו וירבו בא"י, ולא יתקיים הבטחת הגוי גדול כו אם במצרים, כמ"ש כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, הרי מצינו באברהם אבינו להיפוך, שא"ל השי"ת כאן אי אתה זוכה לבנים, ורק בא"י זכה לברכת הבנים, ומדוע הי' כאן להיפוך, וצ"ב. גם צ"ב מ"ש לו השי"ת במראות הלילה אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, ופירש"י לפי שהי' יעקב מיצר על שנזדקק לצאת לחו"ל, ולכאורה איך התנחם בזה, ולמה הוזקק לצאת מא"י, ומדוע לא הי' אפשר שיהי' לגוי גדול בארץ ישראל.
translation: And let us return to clarify what we began with regarding why this section is closed and why it was written closed next to "And Jacob lived," as per our previous question. It will also be explained according to our path the connection of "And Jacob lived" to the verse "And they took hold of it," etc., as stated in the aforementioned Zohar. We will begin with a tremendous question: Behold, the Israelites multiplied in Egypt not in the natural way but through a miracle, as they came to Egypt as seventy souls, and during the seventeen years that Jacob was in Egypt, he raised six hundred thousand from his children, as our sages said in the Midrash, that Jacob did not depart until he saw six hundred thousand from his children, etc. And the promise of the Holy One, blessed be He, was fulfilled for him, "For I will make you a great nation there." And in the land of Israel, Jacob and the tribes were there for more than thirty years, while the seventy were fit for marriage and to raise offspring, and during all those years, they only raised seventy souls. Naturally, there should have been many more, especially in those generations, and it was a miracle that they did not multiply there. In Egypt, the miracle was the opposite, as they experienced miraculous wonders and multiplied in an unnatural way to six hundred thousand in seventeen years. The reason is needed: why was there a need for this miracle that they should not multiply in the land of Israel, and that the promise of a great nation would not be fulfilled there, as it is said, "For I will make you a great nation there"? We find with our forefather Abraham the opposite, as the Holy One, blessed be He, told him here, "You will not merit children," and only in the land of Israel did he merit the blessing of children. Why was it the opposite here? This is a question. It is also a question what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him in the visions of the night, "Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you a great nation there," and Rashi explains that Jacob was distressed about having to go abroad. And at first glance, how could he be consoled by this, and why was he required to leave the land of Israel, and why was it not possible for him to be a great nation in the land of Israel?
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites' rapid population growth in Egypt, which occurred through divine intervention rather than natural means, contrasting it with their limited growth in the Promised Land. It raises questions about the necessity of this miraculous increase in Egypt to fulfill God's promise of making Jacob's descendants a great nation, especially since Abraham was told that he would only have children in the land of Israel. Additionally, it reflects on Jacob's apprehension about leaving the land and how God's reassurance of a great nation in Egypt serves as a complex theological insight into divine providence and the unfolding of Israel's destiny.

passage_content: ויתבאר כ"ז בהקדם קושיית המפורשים מה שתמהו, כי הנה הלוים הן הנה ידידי ה' ומשרתיו, ולא חטאו בעגל ולא נגפו במגפה, ולמה נתמעט מספרם כל כך, ולא הגיע אף לחצי שבט הקטן שבישראל, והרמב"ן ז"ל תירץ בב' אופנים (א') עפימ"ש רבותינו דשבטו של לוי לא הי' בשעבוד מלאכת מונרים, ולא היו בכלל וכאשר יענו אותו ע"כ לא היו גם בכלל כן ירבה, עוד כתב טעם אחר דאפשר שהזיק להם הקפדת יעקב אבינו עזה, והאוהחה"ק דחה תרווייהו וכתב טעם אחר עיי"ש בפ' במדבר, וגם הכלי יקר כ' כמה תירוצים עיי"ש ועדיין און הדעת מתיישבת בהם לכשתדקדק בדבריהם.
translation: And it will be explained, as is clarified in the 27th chapter, regarding the question of the commentators who wondered: Behold, the Levites are the friends of the Holy One, blessed be He, and His servants, and they did not sin with the Golden Calf nor were they struck by the plague. So why was their number diminished so greatly, not even reaching half of the small tribe among Israel? And Ramban, may his memory be blessed, answered in two ways: (1) According to what our sages say, the tribe of Levi was not subjected to the labor of the brickmakers, and they were not included in that count. And when they were oppressed, therefore they were not included in that count, so they would increase. He also wrote another reason that perhaps the strong anger of our forefather Jacob harmed them. And the Holy of Holies rejected both of these and wrote another reason, as mentioned in Parashat Bamidbar. And also the Kli Yakar wrote several answers, as mentioned there, and still, the mind finds satisfaction in them when one examines their words carefully.
summary: The passage discusses the puzzling decrease in the number of Levites, who are considered friends and servants of God, despite their lack of sin during the Golden Calf incident and the plague. It references Ramban's two explanations: one being that the Levites were not subjected to the labor of the Egyptians, and the other suggesting that Jacob's strong disapproval may have negatively impacted them. The text emphasizes the need for deeper understanding of these theological insights, as various interpretations exist regarding the Levites' unique status and their diminished numbers.

passage_content: וכבר אמרתי לפרש בכמה אופנים, והטעם הנוגע לענינינו הוא, עפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל עה"פ אך את מטה לוי לא תפקוד וגו' בתוך בנ"י, כדאי הוא לגיון של מלך להיות נמנה לבדו, ד"א צפה הקב"ה שעתידה לעמוד גזירה על כל הנמנין מבן כ' ולמעלה שימותו במדבר, אמר אל יהיו הלוים בכלל, לפי שהם שלו שלא טעו בעגל עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, ובמד"ר מבואר יותר וז"ל אר"י בר"ש לטובתן של בני לוי לא נמנו עם ישראל, שאת מוצא שישראל שיצאו ממצרים לא נכנסו לא"י, שנא' במדבר הזה יפלו פגריכם וגו' ואלו נמנה שבט לוי עמהם, היו גם הם בגזירה, שכך אמר הקב"ה וכל פקודיכם לכל מספרכם וגו', אבל לא נמנו עמהם ונכנסו לארץ, ולמה זכו שנכנסו כולן לארץ לפי שכשם שהיו צדיקים במצרים, כך היו צדיקים במדבר ונתנו נפשם על הקב"ה וכו', לפיכך א"ל הקב"ה למשה עשה הפרש בין ישראל לביניהם, ואי אתה מונה אותם עם ישראל, אבל אתה מונה אותם לעצמן עכ"ד המדרש. נמצא לפי"ז בהכרח ששבט לוי היו כולן צדיקים וקדושים, ולא הי' בהם אף א' שנתפס בעון העגל ובשארי החטאים שעשו ישראל במדבר, דאילו הי' גם ביניהם מתערובות טוב ורע, לא הי' מספיק עוד תקנה זו שנמנו שבט לוי לבדם, והי' הצורך לחלק גם שבט לוי לב' חלקים, וקצתם יהיו בכלל הגזירה, וקצתם יכנסו לארץ, ובאמת לא הי' כן, וגם אילו הי' גם בהם מתערובת הרע לא הי' אפשר שיתקיימו צדיקים ושלמים, וגם לא הי' בהם כח לעמוד בכל הנסיונות, כי מעבע האדם להמשך אחרי בני חבורתו, כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בה' דיעות, ע"כ הי' זהירות יתירה מן השמים ובדרך נס נמשך להם רק נשמות גבוהות וקדושות בלו תערובות רע כלל, וע"כ הי' בהם היכולת לעמוד בכל הנסיונות ולא נכשלו.
translation:
And I have already said to explain in several ways, and the reason relevant to our matter is, as Rashi, of blessed memory, said on the verse "But you shall not count the tribe of Levi among the children of Israel," it is fitting for the legion of a king to be counted alone. Another explanation: The Holy One, blessed be He, foresaw that a decree would arise that all those counted from the age of twenty and above would die in the desert, and He said that the Levites should not be included, for they are His, as they did not err with the calf. Thus said Rashi, of blessed memory. And in the Midrash, it is explained more clearly, as Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon: For the benefit of the children of Levi, they were not counted with Israel, for you find that the Israelites who left Egypt did not enter the Land of Israel, as it is said, "In this desert your carcasses will fall," and if the tribe of Levi had been counted with them, they too would have been included in the decree, for thus said the Holy One, blessed be He, "And all your counted ones, for all your numbers," but they were not counted with them and entered the land. And why did they merit to all enter the land? Because just as they were righteous in Egypt, so they were righteous in the desert and gave their souls for the Holy One, blessed be He, etc. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "Make a distinction between Israel and them, and you shall not count them with Israel, but you shall count them for themselves." Thus concludes the Midrash. 

It follows from this that it is necessary to say that the entire tribe of Levi were all righteous and holy, and there was not one among them who was caught in the sin of the calf or in the other sins that Israel committed in the desert. For if there had been a mixture of good and evil among them, this distinction that the tribe of Levi was counted alone would not have been sufficient, and it would have been necessary to divide the tribe of Levi into two parts, some of them would be included in the decree, and some would enter the land. And indeed, it was not so, and even if there had been a mixture of evil among them, it would not have been possible for the righteous and complete ones to endure all the trials, for it is human nature to be drawn after the company of one's peers, as the Rambam, of blessed memory, wrote in the laws of opinions. Therefore, there was an extraordinary vigilance from Heaven, and through a miracle, only high and holy souls were drawn to them without any mixture of evil at all, and therefore they had the ability to withstand all the trials and did not falter.
summary: The passage discusses the unique status of the Levites, who were not counted among the Israelites in the census due to their righteousness and purity, particularly in contrast to the sin of the Golden Calf. It emphasizes that all members of the Levite tribe were entirely righteous and free from sin, which allowed them to avoid the decree that affected the rest of the Israelites, ensuring their entry into the Promised Land. This distinction highlights the divine protection and special role of the Levites, as they were deemed capable of withstanding trials without succumbing to temptation, reflecting a higher spiritual elevation. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of holiness and the divine selection of the Levites as a model of unwavering faithfulness to God.

passage_content: ומעתה יתבאר קושיא הנ"ל, כי הי' ההכרח שיתמעט מספר הלוים, כי ברבוי עם א"א שיהיו כולם צדיקים, ומוכרח שיהי' ביניהם גם מתערובות הרע, ואופן הבריאה כן הו', דזה לעומת זה עשה האלקים, וכששולחים מן השמים נשמות קדושות לעוה"ז, נשלח עמהם גם כח הניגוד, נשמות מצד הקליפה והס"א, כדי לנסותן כדי שיגדל שכרן, וכן מצינו שנשארו דתן ואבירם מכל אותן רשעי ישראל שמתו בג' ימי האפילה, ויצאו עם ישראל למדבר, והי' ההכרח כן, שהם היו מופלגים ברשעתם, והיו זה לעומת זה בכח הניגוד נגד משה ואהרן שהיו מופלגים בצדקתם, דאלולי כן הי' נמנע בחירת הרע מכל ישראל לצד גודל קדושתן של משה ואהרן, וכן בכל דור ודור מועטין המה הצדיקים, וכנגדן יש ג"כ נשמות מחלק הרע והס"א זה לעומת זה, וכמ"ש ז"ל ראה הקב"ה צדיקים שהם מועטין עמד ושתלן בכל דור ודור, ועכ"ח ברבוי עם א"א שיהיו כולן צדיקים, וההכרח שיהי' ביניהם גם רשעים, ובמשך הדורות יצרפו ויתבררו כל רשעי הדורות האלו, ואותן שהן מחלק הרע לגמרי בלי נצוץ קדוש ידחו ויכרתו, והשאר יתוקנו ויתלבנו ויחזרו לשורשם לצד הקדושה, ומעתה מובן כו הו' ההכרח שיהיו הלוים מועטין במספרם כדי שיהיו כולם צדיקים וכשרים, כי אילו היו מרובין הי' בתוכן בהכרח, גם מתערובת הרע ונשמות שפלות והי' סכנה ח"ו לכל השבט.
translation: And from now on, the aforementioned question will be clarified, for it was necessary that the number of Levites be diminished, because with a multitude of people, it is impossible for them all to be righteous, and it is inevitable that there will also be a mixture of evil among them. The nature of creation is such that "this opposite that" has been made by God, and when holy souls are sent from the heavens to this world, the opposing force is also sent with them, souls from the side of the klipah and the Sitra Achra, in order to test them so that their reward may be increased. Likewise, we find that Datan and Aviram remained from all those wicked Israelites who died during the three days of darkness, and they went out with the Israelites into the desert. It was necessary that they were exceedingly wicked, and they were the opposite of the opposing force against Moses and Aaron, who were exceedingly righteous. For if not, the choice of evil would have been impossible for all of Israel due to the great holiness of Moses and Aaron. And so, in every generation, the righteous are few, and against them there are also souls from the side of evil and the Sitra Achra, this opposite that. As our sages of blessed memory said, "God saw that the righteous were few and placed them in every generation." Therefore, with a multitude of people, it is impossible for them all to be righteous, and it is necessary that there be also wicked among them. Throughout the generations, all the wicked of these generations will be refined and clarified, and those who are completely from the side of evil without a holy spark will be cast away and cut off, while the rest will be corrected and purified and will return to their root on the side of holiness. And from now on, it is understood that it is necessary for the Levites to be few in number so that they may all be righteous and proper, for if they were numerous, there would necessarily be among them a mixture of evil and lowly souls, which would pose a danger, Heaven forbid, to the entire tribe.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of a diminished number of Levites, emphasizing that in a large population, not all can be righteous, as the presence of evil is essential for the purpose of free will and spiritual growth. It highlights the divine principle that opposites coexist, with righteous souls sent alongside those from the realm of impurity to test and elevate the righteous. The text illustrates that throughout generations, the righteous are few, and the existence of wicked souls serves to challenge and refine the faithful, ultimately leading to the purification and return of some to their holy source. Thus, a smaller number of Levites ensures that they remain entirely righteous, free from the dangers posed by the presence of evil.

passage_content: ומעתה מתורץ קושיא הנ"ל מדוע לא נתרבו השבטים הק' בעודן בא"י ולא עלה מספרם למעלה מע' נפש, וכאשר ירדו למצרים נתרבו שלא כדרך הטבע לס' רבוא בזמן קצר. דהנה ארז"ל לא נפטר יע"א עד שראה ס' רבוא מבניו, ואותן שיצאו ממצרים הי' מספרם ג"כ רק ס' רבוא, ולחד מ"ד במדרש לא יצאו אלא א' מס' רבוא, והשאר מתו ונשארו במצרים, מפני שהיו רשעים ולא רצו לצאת, ולפי"ז נתרבו ישראל במצרים עד שעלה מספרם לס' רבוא פעמים ס' רבוא, דכשיצאו ממצרים לא יצא אלא א' מס' רבוא, ואעפי"כ עלה מספר היוצאים לס' רבוא, והנה גילה לנו האריז"ל בס' הלקוטים בפ' שמות, שנשמות דור הפלגה נתגלגלו בדור המבול, ואח"כ נתגלגלו בנשמות ישראל במצרים, והי' ביניהם הרבה נשמות שפילות ומלוכלכות בחטא דור המבול ודור הפלגה, ובמצרים בכור הגלות נתבררו ונתלבנו, עד שלא נשארו כ"א ס' רבוא הכשרים, והם יצאו ממצרים והשאר נשארו שם, דלא היו ראויים לצאת עכ"ד, וגם אותן שמתו ונשארו במצרים לא נדחו עולמית, ועתידין לבוא בגלגול בדרא בתראה, ויהי' להם תיקון במשך הדורות, וחלק גדול מהם יזכו לימות המשיח, וכמושאה"כ והנידחים מאמ"צ, ולא נדחו רק לפי שעה, מפני שלא הי' רצונו ית' שילכו עם ישראל במדבר, פן יגרמו הריסות, וכמו שסבלו ישראל מערב רב שגרמו לידי נסיונות וחטאים, וע"כ הי' ההכרח שידחו לפי שעה ויחזרו ויתוקנו לעתיד, עכ"פ הי' ערבוביא גדולה ברבוי העם אשר הי' במצרים, והיו צריכים לצירוף וליבון בתוך כור הברזל בגלות מצרים, ועוד יצרפו בגלות דרא בתראה עד שיבורר הטוב מן הרע כנ"ל.
translation:
And from now on, the above question is resolved: why did the holy tribes not multiply while they were in the Land of Israel, and their number did not rise above forty souls, whereas when they descended to Egypt, they multiplied in an unnatural way to six hundred thousand in a short time. Behold, our sages have said that he did not pass away until he saw six hundred thousand of his children, and those who left Egypt also numbered only six hundred thousand. According to one opinion in the Midrash, only one out of six hundred thousand left, and the rest died and remained in Egypt because they were wicked and did not want to leave. According to this, the Israelites multiplied in Egypt until their number reached six hundred thousand times six hundred thousand, for when they left Egypt, only one out of six hundred thousand came out, and nevertheless, the number of those who left rose to six hundred thousand. 

And behold, the Arizal revealed to us in the book of Lekutim in Parashat Shemot that the souls of the generation of the Tower of Babel were reincarnated in the generation of the Flood, and afterwards they were reincarnated in the souls of the Israelites in Egypt. Among them were many lowly souls tainted by the sins of the generation of the Flood and the generation of the Tower of Babel, and in Egypt, the crucible of exile, they were purified and refined, until only six hundred thousand righteous souls remained, and they left Egypt while the rest remained there, for they were not worthy to leave. Furthermore, those who died and remained in Egypt were not eternally rejected, and they are destined to come back in reincarnation in the last generation, and they will have rectification throughout the generations, and a large portion of them will merit the days of the Messiah, as it is written, "and the outcasts from the land of Egypt." They were not rejected except for a time, because it was not the will of the Blessed One that they should go with Israel in the desert, lest they cause destruction, just as Israel suffered from the mixed multitude that caused trials and sins. Therefore, it was necessary that they be temporarily rejected and will return and be rectified in the future. In any case, there was a great mixture in the multitude of people that were in Egypt, and they needed to be refined and purified in the iron furnace of the Egyptian exile, and they will be further refined in the exile of the last generation until the good is separated from the bad, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the reason why the number of the Jewish tribes did not increase while in the Land of Israel, yet multiplied significantly in Egypt. It explains that many souls from previous generations, particularly from the generations of the Flood and the Tower of Babel, were reincarnated in Egypt, where they underwent purification through suffering. Ultimately, only the righteous souls, totaling 600,000, were deemed worthy to leave Egypt, while the rest, who were unworthy, will have the opportunity for redemption in future generations, particularly during the Messianic era. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the cyclical nature of souls and the process of spiritual refinement through trials.

passage_content: אבל באותן הע' נפש שירדו עם יעקב למצרים, הו' ההכרח ורצון העליון מהשי"ת שיהיו כולם קדושים ונשמות יקרות, ולא הי' בהם מחלק הרע כלל, כי הם היו יסוד אומה הישראלי, וכמבואר בזוה"ק פ' ויחי (דף רט"ז ע"א) ועמך כולם צדיקים דא יעקב ובנוי, דנחתו למצרים ואשתכחו כלהו זכאין וכו', וע"כ הי' צורך לנס זה שלא יתרבו בכל אותן השנים שהי' יעקב בא"י, ולא עלה מספרם כ"א לע' נפש, כי ברבוי עם א"א שיהיו כולם צדיקים, ובהכרח מעורבים עמהם גם נשמות מהקליפות וחלק הרע זה לעומת זה, כי כן הי' תכלית וכוונת הבריאה, ואלו הם הגורמים צרות ונסוונות ומסיתים ומדיחים את ישראל, ומצינו שאותן הגרים שגיירו האבוה"ק והנפש אשר עשו בחרן, וכן יצחק ויעקב שקרבו הרבה גרים תחת כנפי השכינה כמובא בדרז"ל, וכולם לא רצו לקבל עליהם עול הגלות, ולא הלכו עם יעקב למצרים כ"א ע' נפש בניו ובנותיו, ואלו הגרים נדחו וחזרו לסורן ונשארו בארץ כנען, ומעתה אילו הי' רבוי עם בא"י קודם בואם למצרים, אפשר שהי' חלק גם מישראל שלא היו רוצים לקבל עול הגלות, ולירד עם יעקב למצרים, כי הן המה הרבוי עם אשר היו במצרים, ולא רצו לצאת משם כ"א א' מס' רבוא, ומעתה אילו נתרבו שלא כדרך הטבע בא"י הי' חלק גדול מהם נדחה ח"ו ע"י שהיו נשארים שם, ע"כ הו' צורך לנס שלא יהי' רבוי עם לפני בואם למצרים, ולא היו רק ע' נפש כולם צדיקים וקדושים נשמות גבוהות ויקרות, וכולם קבלו עליהם עול הגלות וירדו למצרים, ושם נתרבו רבוי עצום שלא כדרך הטבע ונצרפו בכור הגלות, ואלו שלא נתקנו במצרים ולא היו ראויים לצאת, נשארו שם ויתגלגלו בדורות העתידים עד שיתוקנו כמ"ש האריז"ל ולא ידח ממנו ית' נדח, ועוד טעם כו אלו נסתבב חטאים גדולים בא"י, ע"ו התערובות שברבוי עם, כמו שנסתבב במדבר ע"י הערב רב, הי' הפגם גדול מאוד, כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בפ' וירא וז"ל כו למעלת א"ו שהוא מנחלת ה' אינה סובלת אנשי רשע כי שם היכל ה', וע"כ הי' עונש סדום ועמורה גדולה כ"כ, ולא עשה ה' לשאר אומות ככה, אע"פ שהיו רעים וחטאים כמותם עכ"ל, ומעתה אלו היו חוטאין בא"י הי' הפגם ביסוד האומה גדולה מאוד ח"ו, ע"כ הי' צורך לנס שלא יתרבו בא"י ונתרבו רק אח"כ כשירדו למצרים.
translation:
But in those seventy souls that descended with Jacob to Egypt, it was the necessity and the supreme will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, that they should all be holy and precious souls, and there was no part of evil among them at all, for they were the foundation of the Jewish nation, as explained in the Zohar, Parashat Vayechi (page 416a), "And your people are all righteous," referring to Jacob and his children, who descended to Egypt and were all found to be innocent, etc. Therefore, there was a need for this miracle that they should not multiply during all those years that Jacob was in the Land of Israel, and their number did not increase except to seventy souls, for in a large population, it is impossible for all to be righteous, and necessarily there would be mixed in with them also souls from the klipot and this part of evil, for thus was the purpose and intention of creation, and these are the causes of troubles and trials and they incite and lead astray Israel. 

And we find that those converts whom the Patriarchs converted and the souls they made in Haran, as well as Isaac and Jacob who brought many converts under the wings of the Shechinah, as is brought in the Midrash, all of them did not want to accept the yoke of exile, and did not go with Jacob to Egypt except for the seventy souls of his sons and daughters, and those converts were rejected and returned to their folly and remained in the land of Canaan. 

From now on, if there had been a large population in the Land of Israel before their coming to Egypt, it is possible that there would have been a part of Israel who would not have wanted to accept the yoke of exile and to descend with Jacob to Egypt, for they are the multitude that were in Egypt, and they did not want to leave there except for one out of many myriads. Therefore, if they had multiplied unnaturally in the Land of Israel, a large part of them would have been rejected, Heaven forbid, by remaining there. Thus, it was necessary for a miracle that there should not be a large population before their coming to Egypt, and there were only seventy souls, all righteous and holy, high and precious souls, and all accepted upon themselves the yoke of exile and descended to Egypt. 

There, they multiplied immensely in an unnatural way and were refined in the crucible of exile, and those who were not rectified in Egypt and were not worthy to leave remained there and will reincarnate in future generations until they are rectified, as the Arizal said, "And no one will be cast off from Him." 

Moreover, another reason is that if great sins occurred in the Land of Israel, it was due to the mixture in the large population, as it happened in the desert through the mixed multitude, the blemish was very great, as the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote in Parashat Vayera, and he said, "For the merit of the land of the Lord does not tolerate wicked men, for there is the Temple of the Lord," and therefore the punishment of Sodom and Gomorrah was so great, and the Lord did not do so to the other nations, even though they were wicked and sinful like them. 

From now on, if they were sinning in the Land of Israel, the blemish in the foundation of the nation would be very great, Heaven forbid. Therefore, it was necessary for a miracle that they should not multiply in the Land of Israel, and they only multiplied later when they descended to Egypt.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the souls of the seventy individuals who descended with Jacob to Egypt were entirely righteous and holy, serving as the foundation of the Jewish nation. It argues that had there been a larger population in the Land of Israel before their descent, it would have inevitably included souls from the "klipot" (impurities), leading to spiritual corruption and challenges for the nation. The necessity of a miraculous reduction in numbers ensured that only these pure souls accepted the burden of exile, allowing for a subsequent miraculous growth in Egypt. Ultimately, this divine orchestration highlights the importance of maintaining the sanctity of the Jewish people and the potential dangers of spiritual dilution through intermingling with the unworthy.

passage_content: ומעתה יתבארו כל דברי רז"ל בטעם סתימת הפרשה, וכל הטעמים שבזוה"ק ובמדרשים על קוטב א' נאמרו, וכולהו איתנייהו, ואין שום פלוגתא ביניהם רק אלו ואלו דא"ח, כאשר יבואר ואגב יתורצו כל הדקדוקים הנ"ל. ונ"ל לדרכינו הנ"ל, דנסמכה הסתימה לסוף הפרשה שלמעלה שמסיומת ויאחזו בה ויפרו וירבו מאוד, שנתרבו ישראל ברבוי עצום שלא כדרך הטבע, עד שראה יעקב אבינו ס' רבוא מבניו, ונתיישבו במצרים בדרך התיישבות, כמ"ש התרגום יונתן ויאחזו בה ובנו להון פלטין ובתי מדרשין, ואחסינו בה אחסנת שדות וכרמים וכו', והצדיקים שבהם הבני עלי' וזכי הראות, ראו מיד תערובות הנורא השורר ברבוי העם, ורבוי כוחות הרע וכוחות הטומאה המעורב בהן, וכמ"ש ז"ל דרק א' מס' רבוא יצאו והשאר היו רשעים ופטרונין למצרים ולא רצו לצאת, ואלו הם שנתיישבו מיד בדרך התוישבות במצרים, והלכו בדרכי הרע של מצרים, ועי"ז ניתוסף כח גדול מצד הטומאה, והיו הנסיונות קשים מאוד לבנ"י הכשרים לעמוד בהם, עכ"פ זכי הראות ראו את הנולד, ומה שיוצמח ע"ו התערובות הזה, והשיגו התולדה מזה שעתיד להסתם מהם מעיינות החכמה והשפעת הדעת שנתגלה להם מיעקב אבינו ע"ה, ע"י שיהיו משוקעים בטומאת מצרים ר"ל, גם השיגו שיגרום כ"ז לשעבוד מצרים, כו ע"ו רבוי החטאים ר"ל אלו המלאכים המשחיתים הנבראים מעונות ונגעי בנ"א, הם מושלים על האדם ולוחמים בו ושר של מצרים אשר החטיאם ע"י קליפת מצרים הקשה, הוא הי' אח"כ המושל עליהם ושיעבדם תחת ידו, וכמ"ש האוהחה"ק בפ' שופטים כו תצא למלחמה וראית סוס ורכב עם רב ממך וגו' שע"י שנכשל האדם בעבירות ר"ל יתוספו כוחות הרע שנולדו ממעשיו הרעים, והן המה הלוחמים כנגדו, וז"פ עם רב ממך, שממך הם אלא שלאו כל אדם יש בו כח הראות לראותם, ואלו זכי הראות בני עלי' והצדיקים שבהם במצרים, ראו מיד אלו הכוחות שנבראים ע"ו הרשעים, והשיגו שעתידים אלו להלחם עמהם ולשעבדם, וז"ש נסתמו עיניהם ולבן של ישראל, פי' מהבני עלי' הנקראים ישראל שראו מיד צרת השיעבוד העתידה לבוא עליהם, וא"ש מה שנכתבה כאן הסתימה, לפי שנסמכה לפ' שלמעלה ויאחזו בה ויפרו וירבו מאוד, וזה גרם להם שנסתמו עיניהם ולבם כנ"ל, ואפ"ל רמז במ"ש הת"י ובנו להון בתי מדרשין דבעצם הי' זאת דבר טוב ועובדא טבא, אבל ע"ו רבוי העם ותערובות כוחות הרע, הכניסו בבתי מדרשות אלו צורות מלאכים רעים, שנבראו ממחשבות עבירה שהכניסו בבתי מדרשות כנ"ל, ולאו כל אדם יש בו כח לראות ולהכיר בצורות אלו, אבל הזכו הראות הצדיקים ראו את כ"ז, וע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם מחזיון הזה ומרוב צער, וע"כ נסמכה הסתומה לכאן אצל ויפרו וירבו מאוד.
translation: And from now on, all the words of our Sages will be clarified regarding the reason for the closing of the section, and all the reasons mentioned in the Zohar and in the Midrashim about the one pole are said, and they are all included, and there is no dispute among them, only these and those are true, as will be explained, and in the process, all the aforementioned nuances will be resolved. And it seems to me, according to our aforementioned path, that the closing is connected to the end of the section above, which concludes with "and they clung to it and multiplied greatly," that Israel multiplied in an immense increase, contrary to the natural way, until Jacob our father saw sixty myriads of his children, and they settled in Egypt in a manner of settlement, as the Targum Jonathan says, "and they clung to it and built palaces and houses of study," and they stored in it the storage of fields and vineyards, etc. And the righteous among them, the sons of elevation and those with clear vision, immediately saw the terrible mixture that prevailed in the multitude of the people, and the great increase of the forces of evil and the forces of impurity mixed among them. And as our Sages said, only one out of sixty myriads went out, and the rest were wicked and remained in Egypt and did not want to leave, and these are the ones who immediately settled in the way of settlement in Egypt, and walked in the evil ways of Egypt. And as a result, a great power was added from the side of impurity, and the trials were very difficult for the righteous among Israel to withstand. Nevertheless, those with clear vision saw what would emerge from this mixture, and they understood the outcome of this that would cause the springs of wisdom and the flow of knowledge that was revealed to them from Jacob our father, peace be upon him, to be submerged in the impurity of Egypt, so to speak. They also understood that all this would lead to the enslavement of Egypt, due to the great increase of sins, so to speak, those destructive angels created from the sins and afflictions of people, they rule over man and fight against him, and the minister of Egypt who caused them to sin through the harsh shell of Egypt, he was afterwards the one who ruled over them and enslaved them under his hand, as it is written in the holy Torah in Parashat Shoftim, "When you go out to war and see horses and chariots, a people more numerous than you," that through a person's failure in transgressions, so to speak, evil forces are added that are born from his evil deeds, and they are the ones who fight against him, and this is the meaning of "a people more numerous than you," that they are from you, only that not every person has the power to see them. But those with clear vision, the righteous among them in Egypt, immediately saw these forces that were created from the wicked, and they understood that these would fight against them and enslave them. And this is what is meant by "their eyes and the heart of Israel were closed," meaning from the sons of elevation who are called Israel, who immediately saw the distress of the future enslavement that was to come upon them. And it is clear why the closing is written here, as it is connected to the section above, "and they clung to it and multiplied greatly," and this caused their eyes and hearts to be closed, as mentioned. And it can be said that there is a hint in what the Targum says, "and they built houses of study," that in essence, this was a good thing and a good deed, but due to the great increase of the people and the mixture of evil forces, they introduced into these houses of study forms of evil angels, created from the thoughts of transgression that they brought into the houses of study, as mentioned. And not every person has the power to see and recognize these forms, but the ones with clear vision, the righteous, saw all this. And therefore, their eyes and hearts were closed from this vision and from great sorrow, and thus the closing is connected here to "and they multiplied greatly."
summary: The passage discusses the interconnectedness of the closing of a biblical section and the subsequent growth of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing the duality of their increase alongside the rise of evil forces. It highlights that while the righteous, referred to as "Zochei HaRoeh," perceive the spiritual dangers and the consequences of sin, the majority remain blind to these threats. The text suggests that the overwhelming presence of sin and impurity in Egypt led to a significant spiritual decline, resulting in the oppression of the Israelites. Ultimately, the righteous foresaw the challenges ahead, which caused their hearts and eyes to be closed in sorrow due to the mixture of good and evil within their community.

passage_content: אמנם בפועל ממש לא היו מעשיהם מקולקלים עד לאחר הסתלקות יע"א, כי אפי' אותן שהיו מחלק הרע, והנשמות השפולות שהיו בהם, כולן היו נכנעים ע"ו השפעת הקדושה של יע"א, ובכח קדושתו השפיע על כל בני דורו, וכל זמן שראו עוד צורתו של יעקב אבינו ע"ה, לא יצאו עוד ללהב הכוחות הרע שבהם, והוכנעו והושפלו מפני גאון קדושתו של יע"א, וע"כ נקטו רז"ל בלשונם לומר כיון שנפטר יע"א נסתמו עיניהם ולבם של ישראל מצרת השיעבוד, דבפועל לא הגיע הקלקול ולא נגע בהם, עד לאחר הסתלקות יע"א, אלא שזכי הראות השיגו הקלקול העתיד לבוא עליהם, וע"כ נסתמו עיניהם ולבם מיד כי ראו החורבן המעותד לבוא עליהם במצרים, ושרבים מישראל יודחו וישארו במצרים, וע"כ היו שרויים בצער, גם ראו הנסיונות הגדולים שיעמדו לנגדן בדור תערובות ופרוץ מרובה על העומד, ומזה נסתמה עיניהם ולבן, ומ"ש בזוה"ק דקיימו במצרים בתפנוקי מלכין הכוונה על פשוטי עם, שאין להם השגה במושכלות, ואינם בגדר להיות רואים את הנולד, ועיניהם רק לנוכח יביטו, ולפי שעה הי"ל כל טוב ארץ מצרים, וע"כ קיימו בתפנוקי מלכין כ"ז שהי' יעקב אבינו קיים, כו לא הי' עליהם שעבוד כלל.
translation: Indeed, in practice, their actions were not corrupted until after the passing of the righteous one, for even those who were of the evil faction, and the lowly souls within them, all were subdued by the holy influence of the righteous one. Through his holiness, he impacted all the people of his generation, and as long as they still saw the form of our forefather Jacob, peace be upon him, the evil forces within them did not emerge, and they were humbled and abased before the greatness of the holiness of the righteous one. Therefore, our sages used the expression that once the righteous one passed away, the eyes and hearts of Israel were sealed from the distress of servitude, for in practice, the corruption did not reach them and did not touch them until after the passing of the righteous one. However, the pure vision foresaw the future corruption that would come upon them, and thus their eyes and hearts were sealed immediately as they saw the destruction that was destined to come upon them in Egypt, and that many of Israel would be led astray and remain in Egypt. Therefore, they were in sorrow, as they also saw the great trials that would stand before them in a generation of mixture, where the evil would be more prevalent than the good. From this, their eyes and hearts were sealed. And what is stated in the Zohar that they remained in Egypt in the pleasures of kings refers to the simple folk, who do not have comprehension of intellectual matters and are not in the category of being able to see what is to come. Their eyes only look at what is present, and for the time being, they had all the good of the land of Egypt. Therefore, they remained in the pleasures of kings as long as our forefather Jacob was alive; at that time, they had no servitude at all.
summary: The passage discusses the profound spiritual influence of Yaakov Avinu (Jacob) on his generation, emphasizing that even those with lower spiritual states were subdued by his holiness. It suggests that the true spiritual decline and suffering of the Israelites only began after his passing, as they foresaw the impending hardships in Egypt. The text highlights the idea that the simple folk, lacking deeper understanding, were content in their material prosperity as long as Yaakov was alive, indicating that his presence shielded them from spiritual degradation and oppression.
