passage_content: ואפשר להוסיף נופך בהסבר דבריו ז"ל, דהנה עיקר חשיבות התשובה לפני הבוי"ת, כשישראל מתחילים לעשות אפי' תשובה קצת בשפלות הגלות, ואפי' בחי' קטנה של תשובה אע"פ שאינה בשלימות יקובל לקצון לפני הבוי"ת במשקל ק"ל דיעות ותא, פי הבוי"ת רואה בשפלותינו, כי אנוסים אנחנו תחת כוחות היצר ותוקף הגליות וזרם העולם וזרם הס"מ וכל חיילותיו, ואפי' בחי' קטנה של התעוררות תשובה קשה להשיג ולהגיע אלי'. משא"כ לעתיד כשיבוא אלי' להיישיר את לב ישראל לתשובה והבוי"ת יטהר את לבבנו ויקרב אותנו אליו, ומכש"כ לאחר ביאת המשיח כל ישראל יעשו תשובה עילאה, ויסיר הבוי"ת את לב האבן מקרבנו כמאה"כ ואת רוחי אתן בקרבכם, וכאשר יוסר מאתנו המניעות והנסיונות יקל יותר להשיג תשובה מעולה ושלימה. ועל כן בדין הוא שלפי ערך הנסיונות בכובד הגלות, אפי' תשובה קלה והתעוררת של תשובה, חשובה ומקובלת ורצוי' לפניו ית', והגם שאין בכוחינו לעשות תשובה מעולה ושלימה, עכ"פ עלינו לעשות גדרים וסייגים וידבק האדם בכל לבו אל התוה"ק, והיא סגולה גדולה להנצל מן ההרהור כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל אין ההרהור מצוי אלא בלב פנוי מן החכמה, וידבק בדרכי היראה וישמור עיניו וכל איבריו. ובזכות התשובה נזכה לביאת המשיח ולתשובה שלימה, שהבוי"ת יסייע אז בידינו ויוסרו המניעות, אלא שצריך לעשות הכנה לזה, ולהתחיל עכ"פ בכח התשובה כל מה שיש בכוחינו לעשות, והבוי"ת הבטיחנו פתחו לי פתח כפתחו של מחט, ואני אפתח לכם כפתחו של אולם. וע"כ הקב"ה מקבל תשובתינו גם עכשיו בגלות אע"פ שאינה ע"צ השלימות, ומצרפה ומחברה ע"ש העתיד, כי בערך הנסיונות וכובד הגלות גם בחי' קטנה של תשובה לרב יחשב, וגם כי היא הגורם להגיע אל התשובה הגדולה כנ"ל, וכעין שכתב ב"י זלל"ה בה' יוהכ"פ, דהטעם דאפקי' רחמנא לאכילה של ערב יוהכ"פ בלשון עינוי, לפי שהוא הכנה אל העינוי של יוהכ"פ עיי"ש, וכמו"כ לענין התשובה לפי שהתשובה של עכשיו בעודינו בגלות היא הכנה לזכות על ידה אל התשובה הגדולה דלעתיד, ע"כ הבוי"ת מצרפה ומחברה אל התשובה ההוא, וע"ש העתיד נתקבל מיד לתשובה שלימה. ולפי"ז אף שהחמירו בזוה"ק דלא מהני תשובה על חטא הידוע, כ"א תשובה שלימא דאתחזיוא לחפווא על כל עובדויי, ובעוה"ר קשה להשיג עכשיו בחי' זו של תשובה, אבל הבוי"ת מצרף ומחבר תשובתינו אל בחי' תשובה דלעתיד, ואז כל ישראל יעשו תשובה עילאה שיהי' מספיק להתכפר על כל החטאים, ועד"ז ראוי שיתכפר עווננו גם עכשיו, וז"ש למען שמך ד' ר"ל ע"י בחי' שם הוי' ות' שהקב"ה דן לטובה ע"ש סופו, ולכך וסלחת לעוני כי רב הוא, אף לעון שהוא רב ולא סגי כ"א בתיובתא סגי כמ"ש בזוה"ק, אעפ"כ יאות שיסלח לנו הטוב הסלח ית' ע"ש סופו.
translation: And it is possible to add a nuance to the explanation of his words, may his memory be blessed, that the main importance of repentance before the Blessed One is when Israel begins to make even a little repentance in the lowliness of the exile, and even a small aspect of repentance, although it is not complete, will be accepted before the Blessed One in the weight of a hundred and twenty opinions and more. The Blessed One sees our lowliness, for we are coerced under the forces of the evil inclination and the strength of the exiles and the currents of the world and the currents of the evil inclination and all its legions, and even a small aspect of the awakening of repentance is difficult to achieve and reach to Him. However, in the future, when He will come to straighten the hearts of Israel to repentance, the Blessed One will purify our hearts and bring us closer to Him, and certainly after the coming of the Messiah, all of Israel will make a supreme repentance, and the Blessed One will remove the heart of stone from our midst as it is written, "And I will give you a heart of flesh," and "I will put My spirit within you." And when the obstacles and trials are removed from us, it will be easier to achieve a superior and complete repentance. Therefore, it is just that according to the value of the trials in the heaviness of the exile, even a light repentance and an awakening of repentance is important and accepted and desired before Him, blessed be He. And although we do not have the power to make a superior and complete repentance, we must at least set up fences and boundaries and a person should cling with all his heart to the Holy Torah, and this is a great remedy to be saved from thoughts of sin, as Maimonides, may his memory be blessed, wrote that thoughts of sin are only found in a heart empty of wisdom, and one should cling to the ways of fear and guard his eyes and all his limbs. And by the merit of repentance, we will merit the coming of the Messiah and a complete repentance, that the Blessed One will then assist us and the obstacles will be removed, but one must prepare for this and at least begin with the strength of repentance all that we are able to do, and the Blessed One has promised us, "Open for Me a door the size of the eye of a needle, and I will open for you a door the size of a hall." Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, accepts our repentance even now in exile, even though it is not of the completeness, and He connects and unites it for the sake of the future, for in relation to the trials and the heaviness of the exile, even a small aspect of repentance is greatly considered, and also because it is the cause of reaching the great repentance as mentioned above. And similarly, as written in the Beit Yosef, may his memory be blessed, regarding the fast of Yom Kippur, that the reason for the allowance of eating on the eve of Yom Kippur is termed as affliction, for it is a preparation for the affliction of Yom Kippur, as stated there. Likewise, concerning repentance, for the repentance of now while we are still in exile is a preparation to merit through it the great repentance of the future, therefore the Blessed One connects and unites our repentance to that aspect of repentance of the future, and for the sake of the future, it is immediately accepted for a complete repentance. According to this, even though it is stringent in the Zohar that repentance does not help for a known sin, only a complete repentance that is revealed for all deeds, and in our current state it is difficult to achieve this aspect of repentance, but the Blessed One connects and unites our repentance to the aspect of repentance of the future, and then all of Israel will make a supreme repentance that will be sufficient to atone for all sins. And similarly, it is fitting that our iniquity should be atoned for even now, and this is what is meant by "For Your name's sake, O Lord," meaning through the aspect of the name of the Blessed One, that the Holy One judges for good for the sake of its end. And therefore, "And You will forgive my iniquity, for it is great," even for a sin that is great and not sufficient except for a good return, as stated in the Zohar. Nevertheless, it is fitting that the good and forgiving One, blessed be He, should forgive us for the sake of its end.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of even a small act of repentance (teshuva) by the Jewish people during their state of exile, highlighting that such efforts are valued by God despite their incompleteness. It asserts that in the future, with the coming of the Messiah, true and complete repentance will be attainable, as God will remove obstacles and purify hearts. The text underscores that current acts of repentance serve as preparations for this future redemption, and God accepts these efforts, linking them to the ultimate, perfect teshuva that will occur in the Messianic era. Ultimately, it conveys a message of hope, indicating that even in the challenges of exile, sincere attempts at repentance are meaningful and contribute to future atonement.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר מ"ש בספה"ק דברי חיים (בדרושים לחנוכה) שאפי' חטאים דלא מהני התשובה בהם, אבל בחנוכה יתקבל התשובה עליהם עיי"ש. ואפשר הטעם עפימ"ש קיז היש"מ זלל"ה בפ' וישב דנס חנוכה הי' נעשה ע"ו בחי' השראת שם הוי' ב"ה, דלא יתכן ברכה בדבר המדוד וידוע ומשוער, כמשז"ל אין הברכה שורה בדבר המדוד, וכיון שידעו בשמן שבפך שאין בו להדליק אלא יום א' לא יצוייר בו ברכה בהשגחה מסותרת בטבע, זולת ע"ו השראת בחי' שם הוי' שאינו מכוסה בטבע ושורה גם בדבר המדוד עכת"ד עיי"ש שהאריך, ועל כן בכל שנה בימי חנוכה נתעורר הבחי' ההוא כמו שהי' בימי הנס, ובבחי' שם הוי' ית' הקב"ה דן ע"ש סופו לטובה, ולכך מהני תשובה אפי' על חטאים דלא סגי כ"א תיובתא סגי כמבואר בזוה"ק הנ"ל, אבל הקב"ה מצרף תשובת העתיד שיהי' בבחי' גדולה תשובה עילאה, וע"כ יספיק למחילת כל עונותינו.
translation: And this will explain what is written in the holy book Divrei Chaim (in the discourses for Chanukah) that even sins for which repentance does not help, during Chanukah repentance will be accepted for them, as stated there. And it is possible that the reason is according to what is said in Kitzur Yesh Ma'aseh Z"L in Parshat Vayeshev, that the miracle of Chanukah was accomplished through the aspect of the Divine Name, blessed be He, that blessing cannot rest on something that is measured, known, and estimated, as our sages have said, "Blessing does not rest on something that is measured." And since they knew that the oil in the jug could only last for one day, it could not be imagined that there would be a blessing through hidden providence in nature, except through the aspect of the Divine Name which is not concealed in nature and rests even on something that is measured, as stated there at length. Therefore, every year during the days of Chanukah, that aspect is awakened as it was during the days of the miracle, and in the aspect of the Divine Name, may He be blessed, the Holy One, blessed be He, judges for the good in the end. And thus, repentance is effective even for sins for which there is no sufficient remedy except for a refutation, as explained in the aforementioned Zohar. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, combines the repentance of the future, which will be in a great aspect of higher repentance, and therefore it will suffice for the forgiveness of all our transgressions.
summary: The passage discusses the unique spiritual significance of Hanukkah, emphasizing that even sins that typically cannot be atoned for through repentance can be forgiven during this time. This is attributed to the miraculous nature of the Hanukkah miracle, where the divine presence (the Name of God) is revealed in a way that transcends natural limitations. The text suggests that during Hanukkah, there is a special opportunity for repentance that connects to a higher level of divine mercy, allowing for the forgiveness of all transgressions. Ultimately, it highlights the belief that God's future response to sincere repentance will be one of profound grace and forgiveness.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בחי' נחמה ולתרץ סתירת דברי חז"ל בענין התשובה הנ"ל, עפימ"ד במד"ר דברים (א' סי"א) א"ר אלעאי בש"ר יוסי בן זמרה מפני מה לא גילה הקב"ה לאברהם אבינו שיתן לבניו המן, ופי' המפרשים מדכתיב המאכילך מן במדבר אשר לא ידעון אבותיך, והרי גילה לו הגלות והגאולה ונתינת הארץ, ולמה לא גילה לו גם טובת המן. א"ר אבא בר כהנא כך הוא דרכן של צדיקים אומרים מעט ועושים הרבה וכ"ש צדיקו של עולם ב"ה, ועוד אמרו שם כך אמר הקב"ה לאברהם שיגאל את בניו בב' אותיות וכו' כשבא לגאלם, גאלם בע"ב אותיות וכו' ודרשו כן עה"פ ד' אלקיכם הרבה אתכם, ר"ל שהרבה אתכם טובה יותר משהבטיח לכם ע"ד צדיקים אומרים מעט ועושים הרבה.
translation: And even though there is another aspect of comfort and to resolve the contradiction in the words of our Sages regarding the matter of repentance mentioned above, as it is stated in the Midrash Devarim (1:11), Rabbi Eliezer said in the name of Rabbi Yossi ben Zimra: Why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, not reveal to Abraham our forefather that He would give his children the manna? The commentators explain that it is written, "He who feeds you manna in the desert, which your forefathers did not know," and He revealed to him the exile and the redemption and the giving of the land. So why did He not also reveal to him the goodness of the manna? Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: Such is the way of the righteous; they say little and do much, and certainly the Righteous One of the world, Blessed be He. Furthermore, it is said there: Thus said the Holy One, Blessed be He, to Abraham: He will redeem his children with two letters, etc. When He came to redeem them, He redeemed them with forty-two letters, etc. And they expounded this regarding the verse, "The Lord your God has multiplied you," meaning that He has multiplied you with goodness more than He promised you, in accordance with the principle that the righteous say little and do much.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine revelation and the nature of God's promises, particularly in relation to Abraham and the future of his descendants. It highlights that while God revealed the hardships of exile and the promise of redemption, He withheld the knowledge of the manna's goodness, illustrating that the righteous often speak little but accomplish much. This reflects a deeper theological insight that God's blessings can exceed initial expectations, as seen in the abundance promised to Abraham's descendants, emphasizing the theme of divine generosity and the hidden depths of God's plans for the righteous.

passage_content: ופירשתי דזה היתה טענת משרע"ה בתפלתו אתה החילות להראות את עבדך את גדלך וגו' אעברה נא וגו'. עפומ"ד בפדר"א (פמ"ה) שהבעיח הקב"ה למשה, שכל מה שהוא מבקש הוא עושה לו, חוץ משתי דברים מלהכנס בארץ ומיום המות עיי"ש, אמנם בטח משרע"ה במדת טובו ות', שמטיב הרבה יותר מהבטחתו ית' ע"ד צדיקים אומרים מעט ועושים הרבה, וכמו שעשה הקב"ה במן ובגאולתם של ישראל כנ"ל במדרש, ועל סמך זה התפלל אעברה נא ואראה וגו', כיון שהבטיח לו ות' למלאות בקשתו בכל חוץ מב' דברים אלו, א"כ על השאר כבר הובטח, ויאות שיעשה הקב"ה יותר מהבטחתו, ע"כ התפלל בכח זה לבטל הגזירה, וז"ש אתה החילות להראות וגו' את גדלך ואיתא במדרש את גדלך זה המן (הובא בדמש"א) ומשם ראי' דהקב"ה עושה יותר על הבטחתו ית' דצדיקים אומרים מעט ועושים הרבה, ועל סמך זה התפלל אעברה נא.
translation: And I explained that this was the argument of Moshe Rabbeinu in his prayer: "You have begun to show Your servant Your greatness," etc., "Please let me cross over," etc. According to what is stated in Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer (Chapter 35) that the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised Moshe that whatever he requests, He will do for him, except for two things: to enter the land and the day of his death, as mentioned there. However, Moshe Rabbeinu surely trusted in His goodness and truth, that He does much more than His promise, as the righteous say little and do much, just as the Holy One, Blessed be He, did with the manna and the redemption of Israel, as mentioned in the Midrash. Based on this, he prayed, "Please let me cross over and see," etc., since he was assured that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would fulfill his request in everything except for these two matters. Therefore, regarding the rest, he was already promised, and it is fitting that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would do more than His promise. Thus, he prayed with this strength to annul the decree. And this is what is meant by "You have begun to show Your greatness," and it is stated in the Midrash that "Your greatness" refers to the manna (as brought in the Damesek Eliezer), and from there is proof that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does more than His promise, that the righteous say little and do much. Based on this, he prayed, "Please let me cross over."
summary: In this passage, the author explains that Moses, in his prayer, appeals to God's greatness and goodness, believing that God can grant his request to see the Promised Land despite the divine decree against it. The text emphasizes the Hasidic concept that God often exceeds His promises, particularly in response to the prayers of the righteous, who may ask for little but receive much in return. This is illustrated through the example of the manna and the redemption of Israel, highlighting the idea that God's benevolence surpasses His commitments. Ultimately, Moses's prayer reflects a deep faith in God's capacity to act beyond the limitations of His promises.

passage_content: וכמו כן לעניננו על התשובה מראש הבטחתנו כמ"ש וישוב אל ד' וירחמהו ואל אלקינו כי ירבה לסלוח, וכתיב ושבת עד ד' אלקיך וגו' ושב ד' אלקיך את שבותך ורחמך וגו' וכתבו המפרשים שזו הבעחה, וכמו"כ מבואר בהרבה פסוקים שהבוי"ת הבטיח על התשובה שתהי' מקובלת לפניו ית'. א"כ על חטא זה הידוע שאמרו בזוה"ק דלא מהני בה תשובה, אף שאינו נכלל באותו הבטחה הכללית, אבל ממדת טובו ות' שמטיב יותר מהבטחתו ע"ד צדיקים אומרים מעט ועושים הרבה, ראוי שהקב"ה יקבל תשובתינו גם על זה, דהתשובה על כל החטאים כבר הובטח ממנו ית', ויאות לפי מדת טובו ית' שיוסיף על הבטחתו ויקבל תשובתינו גם על חטא זה, והשי"ת יעזור שנזכה לעשות תשובה ולהדר בזהירות בתורה ובמצות יותר מן החיוב, ואז יתעורר לנו מדתו ית' מדה כנגד מדה ויעשה לנו יותר ממה שהבטיחנו. עכ"פ בזה יתורץ קצת סתירת דברי חז"ל בענין התשובה על חטא זה, דאפשר דמצד הדין לא מהני תשובה ע"ז, ואינה נכללת בהבטחת התשובה אבל הבוי"ת יעשה לפנים משורת הדין כבחי' הנ"ל, או ע"י שידון ע"ש סופו ויצרף תשובתנו אל התשובה המעולה דלעתיד, ובדרך זה יקובל תשובתינו לרצון לפניו ית'.
translation: And likewise, concerning our matter of repentance, from the beginning of our promise, as it is written, "And he shall return to the Lord, and He will have compassion upon him, and to our God, for He will abundantly pardon," and it is written, "And you shall return to the Lord your God... and the Lord your God will restore your fortunes and have compassion upon you," and the commentators have written that this is the essence of the matter. Likewise, it is explained in many verses that the Blessed One has promised that repentance will be accepted before Him. Therefore, regarding this known sin, which is said in the Zohar that repentance does not help for it, even though it is not included in that general promise, from His attribute of goodness and the truth that He is more benevolent than His promise, as the righteous say little and do much, it is fitting that the Holy One, blessed be He, should accept our repentance even for this, for the promise of repentance for all sins has already been assured by Him. It is appropriate, according to His attribute of goodness, that He should add to His promise and accept our repentance even for this sin. May the Holy One, blessed be He, help us merit to repent and to be more careful in Torah and commandments beyond the obligation, and then His attribute will be aroused for us, measure for measure, and He will do for us more than what He has promised us. In any case, this will somewhat resolve the contradiction in the words of our Sages regarding repentance for this sin, for it is possible that from the perspective of strict judgment, repentance does not help for it, and it is not included in the promise of repentance, but the Blessed One will act beyond the letter of the law, as mentioned above, or by judging according to the end and combining our repentance with the superior repentance of the future, and in this way, our repentance will be accepted favorably before Him.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of repentance (teshuva) and God's promise to accept it, emphasizing that even for sins traditionally viewed as unforgivable, God's goodness may allow for their acceptance. It highlights the idea that while certain transgressions may not fall under the general promise of repentance, God's mercy surpasses His promises, enabling Him to accept sincere repentance. The text suggests that through sincere efforts in observing the Torah and commandments, one can invoke God's attribute of mercy, leading to a greater acceptance of their repentance. Ultimately, it reconciles the tension between strict justice and divine mercy, proposing that God may act beyond the letter of the law in response to genuine repentance.

passage_content: נחזור לעניננו לבאר הקושיא הנ"ל ממה שמצינו בזו"ח במדרש הנעלם שהפליגו בשבח בחי' נער, ובדברי חז"ל בש"ס מצינו ההיפך שהוא מדריגה פחותה ר"ל. אמנם מצינו כמו"כ הרבה לשונות משמשים לפעמים מן ההיפך אל ההיפך, כמו שהמשיל הכתוב יששכר לחמור גרם ע"ש שסובל עול תורה כחמור שטוענין אותו למשא, ובמקו"א דרשו חז"ל תיבה זו לגריעותא, שבו לכם פה עם החמור עם הדומה לחמור. וכמו"כ אמרו ז"ל במס' חולין (דף ה' ע"א) מן הבהמה להביא בנ"א שדומים לבהמה, מכאן אמרו מקבלין קרבנות מפושעי ישראל וכו', והקשו בגמ' וכל היכא דכתיב בהמה גריעותא הוא והכתיב אדם ובהמה תושיע ד' וכו' אלו בנ"א שהם ערומים וכו' ומשימין עצמן כבהמה פרש"י דכאי רוח, ותירצו בגמ' לחלק התם כתיב אדם ובהמה הכא בהמה לחודא ע"כ, אבל מעיקרא מאי מקשי אעכ"ח דהלשון סובל ומשמש למשמעות שניהם. וכמו"כ אמרו ז"ל בפסחים (מ"ט ע"ב) ע"ה מותר לנוחרו ביוהכ"פ שחל בשבת, וכתבו התוס' שם דמיירי שהוא ג"כ כופר ולסטים וחשוד על הדמים עיי"ש, עכ"פ המשילו במלת הארץ בחי' נמוכה ושפילה, ורש"י ז"ל בקהלת (א' ד') עה"פ והארץ לעולם עומדת הביא מדרש תנחומא, דכל צדיקי ישראל נקראו ארץ שנא' (מלאכי ג') כי תהיו אתם ארץ חפץ וכמו"כ הבאנו לעיל (קושיא י"ב) שהמשיל הכתוב בדגים ע"צ הטובה וע"צ ההיפך עיי"ש.
translation: We will return to our matter to clarify the aforementioned question from what we find in the Zohar in the hidden Midrash, which extols the quality of youth, while in the words of our Sages in the Talmud we find the opposite, that it is a lesser level, so to speak. However, we also find many expressions that sometimes serve from the opposite to the opposite, as the verse compares Issachar to a strong donkey, because he bears the yoke of the Torah like a donkey that is loaded with a burden. And in another place, our Sages interpreted this term as a derogatory reference, saying, "Sit here with the donkey, like one who is similar to a donkey." Likewise, they said in Chulin (5a) regarding the animal, to bring people who are similar to animals; hence they said we accept offerings from the sinners of Israel, etc. The Gemara questions, "And wherever it is written 'animal,' it is derogatory," and it is written, "Man and beast You save, O Lord," etc. These are people who are naked, etc., and make themselves like animals, as Rashi explains that this refers to the spirit. The Gemara answers that there it is written "man and beast," here "beast" alone. Nevertheless, initially, what is the question? Even so, the language bears and serves both meanings. Likewise, our Sages said in Pesachim (49b) that it is permitted to feed animals on Yom Kippur that falls on Shabbat, and the Tosafot there wrote that it refers to one who is also a heretic and a robber and is suspected of bloodshed, see there. In any case, they compared the word "earth" to a lowly and degraded quality, and Rashi, of blessed memory, in Ecclesiastes (1:4) on the verse "And the earth stands forever," brought the Midrash Tanchuma, that all the righteous of Israel are called "earth," as it is said (Malachi 3), "For you shall be a land of delight." Likewise, we brought above (question 12) that the verse compared fish in terms of goodness and in terms of the opposite, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the duality of interpretations found in Jewish texts, particularly regarding the concept of "youth" and its varying significance. It highlights how certain terms can convey both positive and negative connotations, as seen in the comparisons of individuals to animals, which can reflect both their spiritual state and moral standing. The text emphasizes the complexity of language in conveying theological ideas, illustrating that the same word can embody contrasting meanings depending on context. Ultimately, it underscores the richness of Hasidic thought in exploring the multifaceted nature of human and divine relationships.

passage_content: ויבואר כ"ז בהקדם מ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה בפ' האזינו לתרץ סתירת המקראות, דכתוב א' אומר (תהלים ק"ד) יסד ארץ על מכוני' בל תמוט עולם ועד, וכן כתיב והארץ לעולם עומדת וכמוהו פסוקים רבים המורים על נצחיות שמים וארץ, ומצינו להיפך בכתובים (ישעי' נ"א) כי השמים כעשן נמלחו והארץ כבגד תבלה וגו' ועוד יש הרבה פסוקים המורים על הפסד שמים וארץ וכבר האריך בזה הרמב"ם ז"ל בס' המורה. ותירץ ק"ז זלל"ה עפ"י המבואר בספרי חכמי האמת, כי קודם החטא הי' עוה"ז שהוא עולם העשי' במדריגה בחינת עולם הבריאה של עכשיו, וכן ראיתי כתוב שהארץ היתה ספירי' ומאירה כספיר, ואחר החטא נתלבש הכל בחומריות וגשמיות בלבוש עב וכן השמים וכו'. ולפי"ז יתיישב הכל דבאמת כאשר בראם הבוי"ת כך יתקיימו לנצח, אך הלבוש העב שנתלבש ע"ו החטא תבלה, אבל הנקודה הפנימיות כפי אשר נברא קודם החטא יתקיים לנצח ברצונו ית', והיינו דכתיב יסד ארץ על מכוני' וגו' רי"ל כפי אשר יסדה ות' היא בל תמוט עולם ועד, וכן מ"ש והארץ לעולם עומדת, היינו הארץ בה' הידועה כפו שהיתה קודם החטא יעמוד נצחי לעולם, וכן האדם חוזר לעפרו ונקודה הפנימיות יתקיים והלבוש החומרי לבד ותבלה, ועד"ז בכל מעשה בראשית וכן מ"ש השמים כעשן נמלחו היינו הלבוש שנתלבשו, וכן הארץ כבגד תבלה, הכי פירושו מה שהיא כבגד דהיינו רק הלבוש היא שתבלה עיי"ש שהאריך לבאר וסיים כנ"ל ברור ואמת.
translation: And it is explained, as mentioned earlier, what was said by the holy Rabbi, may his memory be blessed, in Parshat Ha'azinu to resolve the contradiction of the verses, for it is written that one says (Psalms 104) "He established the earth upon its foundations; it shall not be moved forever and ever," and it is also written "and the earth stands forever," and similar verses that indicate the eternity of the heavens and the earth. Conversely, we find in the scriptures (Isaiah 51) "for the heavens will vanish like smoke, and the earth will wear out like a garment," and there are many verses indicating the destruction of the heavens and the earth, and the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, has elaborated on this in the Guide for the Perplexed. The holy Rabbi, may his memory be blessed, resolved this according to what is explained in the writings of the sages of truth, that before the sin, this world, which is the world of action, was in the level of the world of creation as it is now. And I have seen it written that the earth was like a sapphire and shone like a sapphire, and after the sin, everything became clothed in materiality and physicality with a thick garment, and so too the heavens, etc. According to this, everything is settled, for indeed, as the Creator created them, so they will exist forever, but the thick garment that was clothed upon them due to the sin will wear out, yet the inner point, as it was created before the sin, will endure forever by His will. This is what is meant by "He established the earth upon its foundations," meaning as He established it, it shall not be moved forever and ever. And likewise, what is written "and the earth stands forever," refers to the earth in the known five, which was as it was before the sin, will stand eternally forever. Similarly, man returns to his dust, and the inner point will endure, while the material garment alone will wear out. And so it is with all the acts of creation, and likewise what is written "the heavens will vanish like smoke," refers to the garment that was clothed upon them, and "the earth will wear out like a garment," meaning that it is like a garment, that is to say, only the garment will wear out. There, he elaborated and concluded as mentioned above, clear and true.
summary: The passage discusses the apparent contradiction in scripture regarding the permanence of the heavens and the earth versus their eventual decay. It explains that prior to sin, the world existed in a spiritual and luminous state, but after sin, it became clothed in materiality. Despite this material degradation, the inner essence of creation, as originally intended by God, remains eternal and will ultimately endure. Thus, while the physical forms may perish, their spiritual core will persist forever.

passage_content: ובזה אפשר להבין כל אלו התחלפות הלשונות שבפסוקים ובדברי חז"ל, דלפעמים ירמזו וימשילו אל החיצונית ולבוש הגשמי שעליהם, ואז בחינתו גרוע מאוד, ולפעמים יהי' כוונת המשל על נקידה הפנימיות וניצה"ק המחי' אותו, ועל הבחי' שבראה הבוי"ת מתחילה שהיא כולה רוחניות, ועד"ז כוונת הנמשל לשבח ולבחי' גבו', ובדרך זה תבין כל אלה שהבאנו לעיל, דמה שהמשילו חז"ל צדיקי ישראל לארץ, כוונת המשל על פנימיות הארץ שהיא כולה רוחני ויתקיים לעד כנ"ל, ומה שהשתמשו במלת הארץ ע"צ ההיפך ולגריעותא, הי' כוונת המשל על הלבוש הגשמי שנתלבשה בסיבת החטא וזה מורה על מדריגה ובחי' נמוכה. ובדרך זה תבין כל אלה, וחז"ל דרשו בכל מקום לפי ענינו ובחי' הראוי' אליו.
translation: And with this, it is possible to understand all these changes of languages in the verses and in the words of our Sages, for sometimes they hint and compare to the external and the physical garment upon them, and then it is in a very low state. And sometimes the intention of the parable is on the inner aspect and the divine spark that enlivens it, and on the aspect that the Blessed One created initially, which is entirely spiritual. In this way, the intention of the analogy is to praise and to the aspect of elevation. Through this, you will understand all those we brought above, that what our Sages compared the righteous of Israel to the land, the intention of the parable is on the inner aspect of the land, which is entirely spiritual and will endure forever as mentioned. And what they used the word "land" in a negative sense, the intention of the parable is on the physical garment that was clothed due to sin, and this indicates a level and a low aspect. In this way, you will understand all these, and our Sages interpreted everywhere according to its context and the appropriate aspect to it.
summary: The passage discusses the varying interpretations of language in the scriptures and teachings of the sages, emphasizing the distinction between external, physical representations and their deeper, spiritual meanings. It suggests that while some references may indicate a lower, material state due to sin, others point to the inherent spirituality and eternal nature of the divine creation. The analogy of the righteous being compared to the land highlights the inner, spiritual essence of the land, which is everlasting, contrasting with the superficial, flawed aspects that arise from human failings. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of understanding the context and intended meaning behind the words of the sages.

passage_content: ואפשר לבאר בזה דברי הגמ' חגיגה (דף י"ד ע"א) י"ח קללות קילל ישעי' את ישראל, ולא נתקררה דעתו עד שאמר להם המקרא הזה ירהבו הנער בזקן וגו' ולכאורה אינו מובן דכי לא הי' ישעי' הנביא אוהב ישראל, ואיך נתקררה דעתו בקללתם ח"ו, וכבר העיר בזה המהרש"א זל בח"א, ועיין מה שפירשנו בזה פ' ויצא תשכ"ח). ולדרכנו נ"ל עפימ"ש דורשי רשומות וחכמי האמת דהתוכחות והקללות שבתוה"ק, תוכם רצוף אהבה, והפנימיות שבהם היא כולו טובות וברכות, וכמו"כ יש בהם צירופים אחרים, שלפי אותן הצירופים הם רק ברכה, וזה הטעם שאמרז"ל אין מפסיקין בקללות, ואין קורין את התוכחות קיצין קיצין, לפי שבדרך זה מפסיק ומפסיד הצירופים המרמזים על ענינים גבוהים וטובות וברכות. אלא שלבושי המקראות מורים על קללה ר"ל, ומזה סובלים ישראל בכל דורות הגלות בעוה"ר, ולעתיד יתגלה פנימיות התוה"ק והפנימיות של התוכחות ויהי' כולו רק ברכה, וכמ"ש ז"ל ראה אנכי נתן לפניכם היום ברכה וקללה, שרק היום יש כאן ברכה וקללה, אבל לעתיד יהי' רק ברכה.
translation: And it is possible to explain the words of the Gemara in Chagigah (14a) that Isaiah cursed Israel with eighteen curses, and his mind was not at ease until he said to them this verse: "The young will insult the elder," etc. At first glance, this is not understood, for was not Isaiah the prophet a lover of Israel? How could his mind be at ease with their curse, Heaven forbid? The Maharsha has already commented on this in his first part, and see what we have explained on this in Parshat Vayetze, 5738. According to our way, it seems to us, based on what the seekers of the hidden and the sages of truth say, that the reproofs and curses in the Holy Torah are all infused with love, and their inner essence is entirely good and blessings. Likewise, there are other combinations within them, which according to those combinations are only blessings. This is the reason that our sages have said that we do not interrupt in the curses, and we do not read the reproofs in sections, for in this way one interrupts and loses the combinations that hint at lofty matters and goodness and blessings. However, the garments of the verses indicate a curse, so to speak, and this is what Israel suffers from in all the generations of exile, may the Merciful One save us. In the future, the inner essence of the Holy Torah and the inner essence of the reproofs will be revealed, and it will all be only blessing, as our sages have said: "See, I have set before you today a blessing and a curse," for only today is there a blessing and a curse here, but in the future, there will be only blessing.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the curses and admonitions found in the Torah are ultimately rooted in love and contain hidden blessings. It emphasizes that while the external appearance of these texts may seem harsh, their true essence is positive and beneficial. The text suggests that in the future, the inner meanings of these teachings will be fully revealed, leading to a reality where only blessings exist, as indicated by the verse that presents both blessings and curses.

passage_content: ובזה נבין מה שנתקררה דעתו של ישעי' הנביא בפסוק זה ירהבו הנער בזקן, דהנה לעיל מני' ניבא ונתתי נערים שריהם וגו' וקראם נערים לשון רבים, ודרשו חז"ל אלו בנ"א שמנוערין מן המצות, וראה בנבואתו דרבים יהיו, ומיד בפסוק שלאח"ז התנבא בלשון יחיד ירהבו הנער בזקן שלא יהיו אלא יחידים בבחי' זו. אמנם ירמוז נבואה זו על בחי' פנימיות שהיא ברכה וטובה, ונער הוא ג"כ מדריגה ובחי' טובה כמ"ש בזוהר חדש הנ"ל, דמי שזוכה בזקנותו להיות בבחי' נער ה"ז זוכה למעלת שמואל הנביא, כנ"ל, והיינו מי שלא טעם חטא מימיו ה"ז בבחי' נער גם בזקנותו, וע"ד שדרשו ז"ל בן שנה שאול במלכו שהי' כבן שנה שלא טעם טעם חטא, ויתפרש הנבואה דימצאו עוד יחידים שיהיו בבחי' נער, וזכים ונקיים מכל זוהמת חטא, וירהבו בזקן להתחזק עליו ולהוכיחו על האמת, וע"ד שכתב בספה"ק נוע"א זלל"ה דחטאת נעורים ר"ל מסמין את העונים, וע"כ אלו שיש בהם בחי' גדולה זו שנקיים מחטא זה, יראו דרך האמת ויוכיחו בזקן שלא זכה לבחי' זו, אבל מועטין יהיו הזוכים לבחי' זו, וע"כ היתה הנבואה בלשון יחיד ירהבו הנער בזקן. אבל ברישא דקרא דכתיב ונתתי נערים שריהם, דקאי על בנ"א שמנוערין מן המצות כתיב לשון רבים, דימצאו רבים מבחי' זו. והגם שלפי הלבוש והפשעות גם ירהבו הנער בזקן עפימ"ש מורה על הקללה ודרשו ג"כ בו רז"ל אלו בנ"א המנוערין מן המצות, אבל השיג ישעי' הנביא שנאמרה אליו נבואה זו בלשון יחיד ירהבו הנער וגו', ע"כ קרובה יותר אל כוונה הפנימיות שבו, ומבחי' זו נתקררה דעתו.
translation: And with this, we will understand what caused the prophet Isaiah's mind to cool in this verse, "The youth will insult the elder." Behold, earlier he prophesied, "And I will give youths as their princes," and he called them youths in the plural form, and our Sages interpreted that these are people who are distanced from the commandments. And he saw in his prophecy that there would be many, and immediately in the following verse, he prophesied in the singular form, "The youth will insult the elder," indicating that there will only be individuals in this category. However, this prophecy hints at an inner aspect, which is a blessing and goodness, and a youth is also a level and aspect of goodness, as it is written in the aforementioned Zohar Chadash, that one who merits in his old age to be in the aspect of a youth, he merits the status of Samuel the prophet, as mentioned. This means that one who has not tasted sin in his days is in the aspect of a youth even in his old age, and according to what our Sages interpreted, "A year old is Saul in his kingship," meaning he was like a year old who has not tasted the taste of sin. And the interpretation of the prophecy is that there will still be individuals who will be in the aspect of a youth, pure and clean from all the filth of sin, and they will strengthen the elder and reprove him for the truth. This is in line with what is written in the holy book Nua"ah, that youthful sin, meaning it stains the offenders. Therefore, those who possess this great aspect of being free from this sin will see the path of truth and will reprove the elder who has not merited this aspect, but few will be those who merit this aspect. Therefore, the prophecy was in the singular form, "The youth will insult the elder." But at the beginning of the verse, where it is written, "And I will give youths as their princes," which refers to people who are distanced from the commandments, it is written in the plural form, indicating that many will be found in this aspect. And although according to the external appearance and interpretations, "The youth will insult the elder" implies a curse, and our Sages also interpreted it as referring to those who are distanced from the commandments, the prophet Isaiah understood that this prophecy was said to him in the singular form, "The youth will insult," therefore it is closer to the inner intention within him, and from this aspect, his mind was cooled.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic vision of Isaiah, contrasting the generality of youth leading the masses with the singularity of a youth overpowering an elder. It emphasizes that true spiritual elevation, represented by the "youth," signifies purity and a lack of sin, akin to the state of Samuel the prophet. The text suggests that while many may appear youthful in spirit, only a few attain this true inner purity, allowing them to guide and correct the elder, who may lack such spiritual merit. Ultimately, Isaiah's prophecy reflects a deeper understanding of spiritual dynamics, highlighting the rarity of genuine righteousness.

passage_content: ויתורץ בזה מה שבירך יעקב את מנשה ואפרים בלשון יברך את הנערים (עיין קושיא י' לעיל) ק"ז הייטב לב זלל"ה לפרש הפסוק ראה פניך לא פללתי וגו' ותו"ד שראה קלסתר פניו וזיו איקונין שלו דומה לדיוקנו של יעקב כמו שהי' מתחילה כמ"ש ז"ל עה"פ כי בן זקנים הוא לו עיי"ש, וז"ש ראה פניך לא פללתי, כי חששתי אולי נשתנה מכח איזה חטא חלילה, והנה הראה אותי אלקים, היינו את עצמי ודמותו וצלמי, לא מבעי' עליך אלא גם את זרעך, שגם הם יש להם דמות דיוקנו של יוסף הדומה ליעקב עכלה"ק. ומעתה ראה יעקב אבינו בשרטוטי פניהם שנשמרו מחטא כמותו, וע"כ קראם בלשון של שבח שהם בבחי' נערים ע"ד דאיתא בזו"ח הנ"ל, שהוא מדריגה גבו' מאוד, לפי הפנימיות והמכיון האמיתי שבו, וכמו"כ מה שברכם וידגו לרוב בקרב הארץ ג"כ הכוונה על בחי' הפנימיות שבדגים שנמשלו לטובה כאמרז"ל, וז"ש בקרב הארץ התכוין להמשילם לבחי' פנימיות של ארץ. כמ"ש בתנחומא דצדיקים נקראו ארץ, ופנימיות הארץ נצחי ולעולם עומדת כמו שהבאנו לעיל מדברי ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה, ועל דרך זה היתה כוונת ברכתו של יעקב אליהם, ומתורצים הדקדוקים שבענין.
translation: And it is explained here what Jacob blessed Manasseh and Ephraim with the words "He shall bless the youths" (see question 10 above). It is good to explain the verse "I have not prayed to see Your face" etc., and also that he saw the form of his face and the radiance of his countenance resembling the likeness of Jacob as it was at the beginning, as it is said, "For he is a son of old age to him," see there. And this is what is meant by "I have not prayed to see Your face," for I was concerned that perhaps he had changed due to some sin, Heaven forbid. And behold, God showed me, meaning my own self and his likeness and image, not only concerning you but also your offspring, for they too have the likeness of Joseph that resembles Jacob, thus is the matter. And from now on, Jacob our father saw in the outlines of their faces that they were preserved from sin like him, and therefore he called them with a term of praise, that they are in the category of youths, as it is stated in the aforementioned Zohar, which is a very high level, according to the inner essence and the true intention within them. Likewise, when he blessed them "and may they multiply abundantly in the midst of the earth," the intention is also regarding the inner aspect of the fish, which are symbolized for goodness, as our sages have said. And this is what is meant by "in the midst of the earth," he intended to liken them to the inner aspect of the earth. As it is said in Tanchuma, the righteous are called earth, and the inner essence of the earth is eternal and stands forever, as we brought above from the words of K"Z the holy, may his memory be blessed. And in this way was Jacob's intention in his blessing to them, and the nuances in the matter are clarified.
summary: In this passage, the author explains Jacob's blessing of Ephraim and Manasseh, emphasizing their spiritual purity and resemblance to Jacob himself, which reflects their preservation from sin. The phrase "I have not prayed to see your face" indicates Jacob's initial fear of change due to sin, but he is reassured by God's revelation of their true forms. The blessing that they should "multiply like fish" symbolizes their inner spiritual essence, connecting them to the eternal nature of the righteous, who are likened to the land itself. Ultimately, Jacob's blessing highlights the profound spiritual potential and purity of his descendants.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לבאר מאמה"כ ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם וגו' ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, ולדרכנו יתורצו כל הקשיות בענין, ונראה דל"ק קושית המפורשים דלא מצינו שהוליד יוסף עוד בנים ולא זכרם הכתוב בשום מקום, ונמצא שהי' ברכת הזקן ומתנתו לבעלה ח"ו. אמנם מצינו כי ברכותיו של יעקב אבינו היו רובם נבואה על העתיד, עיין פרש"י בהרבה פסוקים שנתנבא על ימות המשיח, ומפורש כן בכתוב ואגידה לכם את אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים, והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב בפ' בחקתי דכל יעודי הברכות שבתורה כולם יתקיימו רק לעתיד, וכן פרש"י כאן בסוף הברכות עה"פ איש אשר כברכתו וגו' ברכה העתידה לבא על כאו"א וכן פירשו כל המפרשים שברכם בברכת העתיד. והנה אמרז"ל במס' סוטה (דף ל"ו ע"ב) הי' ראוי יוסף לצאת ממנו י"ב שבטים כדרך שיצאו מיעקב אביו, שנא' אלה תולדות יעקב יוסף וכו' אלא ע"ו סיבה נמנעו ממנו עיי"ש. ובאמת לא הי' זה פגם רק לפי מידת גדלו ובחי' הגדולה ע"ד סביביו נשערה מאוד. אמנם לעתיד אחר עולם התיקון יתוקן הכל, ויחזור אליו מה שהי' ראוי אלי' מתחילתו, ויעמיד י"ב שבטים שהיו ראויים לצאת ממנו, כי אין טעם למנוע אותם ממנו אחרי שיתוקן הפגם, ועוד יתעלו מדריגתם של צדיקים לעתיד לבוא, וע"ד שכתב האוהחה"ק בפ' זו עה"פ איש אשר כברכתו וגו' עפימ"ש ז"ל עתידה עבודה שתחזור לבכורות, וכפי"ז כיון שקבע יעקב שם הבכורה לראובן באמרו ראובן בכורי אתה, אע"פ שנטלה ממנו לשעה, עתידה שתחזור אליו, ועתיד הוא לעמוד לשרת לעתיד לבוא עכת"ד ז"ל, וכמו"כ מ"ש יעקב אבינו ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם וגו' אע"פ שלא נתקיים כן לשעה ולא מצים שהי' לו בנים עוד, אבל כל דבריו היו על לעתיד ואז יתקיימו שעתידים לצאת ממנו י"ב שבטים, וע"ז קאי מאמר ומולדתך וגו' ע"ש אחיהם וגו' כמו שיתבאר להלן
translation: And now we will explain from our holy sources and your birthplace which you bore after them, etc., in the name of their brothers they will be called in their inheritance. And according to our path, all the difficulties in the matter will be resolved. It seems that the difficulty of the commentators is that we do not find that Joseph fathered any more sons, and the text does not mention them anywhere, and it turns out that it was the blessing of the elder and his gift to his wife, Heaven forbid. However, we find that most of the blessings of our forefather Jacob were prophecies about the future, as Rashi explains in many verses that he prophesied about the days of the Messiah, and it is explicitly stated in the verse, "And I will tell you what will happen to you in the end of days." And the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote in Parashat Bechukotai that all the prophecies of the blessings in the Torah will all be fulfilled only in the future, and so Rashi explains here at the end of the blessings on the verse "A man according to his blessing," etc., a blessing that is destined to come upon each one, and so all the commentators explained that he blessed them with a blessing of the future. And behold, our sages said in tractate Sotah (36b) that it was fitting for Joseph to have twelve tribes come from him, just as they came from his father Jacob, as it is said, "These are the generations of Jacob: Joseph," etc., but due to a certain reason, they were prevented from him, as stated there. And indeed, this was not a blemish, only according to the measure of his greatness and the level of greatness, which was greatly esteemed around him. However, in the future, after the world is rectified, everything will be corrected, and he will return to him what was fitting for him from the beginning, and he will establish twelve tribes that were worthy to come from him, for there is no reason to prevent them from him after the blemish is rectified. Furthermore, the levels of the righteous will be elevated in the future, as the holy author wrote in this parashah on the verse "A man according to his blessing," etc., as he said, may his memory be blessed, that the service will return to the firstborns. And similarly, since Jacob established the firstborn status for Reuben by saying, "Reuben, you are my firstborn," even though it was taken from him for a time, it is destined to return to him, and he is destined to stand to serve in the future, thus he said, may his memory be blessed. And likewise, what our forefather Jacob said, "And your birthplace which you bore after them," etc., even though it was not fulfilled at the time and we cannot find that he had more sons, but all his words were about the future, and then they will be fulfilled, that twelve tribes are destined to come from him. And this is what the statement refers to, "And your birthplace," etc., in the name of their brothers, etc., as will be explained below.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic nature of Jacob's blessings, emphasizing that many of his declarations were intended for the future, particularly regarding the lineage of Joseph. It suggests that although Joseph did not have additional sons during his lifetime, the potential for him to father twelve tribes remains intact and will be realized in the future, particularly after the world is rectified. The text highlights the belief that all blessings and prophecies will ultimately be fulfilled, reinforcing the idea of future restoration and elevation of the righteous.

passage_content: ונקדים לתרץ קושית הרמב"ן ז"ל על שיטת רש"י ז"ל דס"ל דנתחלקה איי למנין גלגלותם, א"כ מהו המתנה שנתן יעקב ליוסף נחלת ב' שבעים ונתן לו הבכורה, ונמצא שאין בכל זה אלא ענין של כבוד והכתוב אומר בנחלתם (עיין לעיל קושיא ז'). ואפ"ל עפי"מ שגילה לנו מהרח"ו ומרן האריז"ל, די"ב שערים עליונים ישנם שבהם תפלות ישראל עולים, וכנגדן י"ב שבעים, וכל שבט ושבע יש לו שער מיוחד, ועפי"ז כתב הדברי חיים והח"ס זלל"ה דאין לשנות נוסח התפלה מספרד לאשכנז עיי"ש בטעמם. ולכאורה כולנו בנו אברהם יצחק ויעקב אנחנו, ולמה הצורך לשער מיוחד לתפלת כל שבט ושבט, ובודאי טעם ענינים אלה הם סתרי סתרים, לא שתפזם עין רואה ואין לנו עסק בהם, אבל זה ברור כו עשה ד' ככה לטובת עמו ישראל אשר אהבם, ואפשר כדי שיהי' צנור מיוחד לקבלת השפעה ואורה לכל שבע ושבט כפי בחינתם בשרשי נשמתם, ובדרך זה ימשך לכאו"א תוס' השפעה ותוס' אורה מיוחד כפי מידת שרשו ובחינתו, בכל אופן ברור דכ"ז לטובת ישראל ותועלתן, כי הוא ית' בראן ויודע תועלתן. ועתה שהוסיף הקב"ה עוד שבט א' ליעקב באמרו ית' ליעקב גוי וקהל גוים יהי' ממך כפרש"י שעתיד א' מהשבטים ליחלק, הוסיף הבוי"ת עוד שער לשבט הניתוסף, ואותה המתנה נתן יעקב אבינו ליוסף שנתן לבניו ב' שערים עליונים,
translation: And we will begin to address the question of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, on the approach of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, who holds that they were divided according to the count of their wheels. If so, what is the gift that Jacob gave to Joseph, the inheritance of two sevens, and he gave him the birthright? It turns out that all of this is merely a matter of honor, and the scripture says regarding their inheritance (see above, question 7). And it can be said according to what was revealed to us by the holy Rabbi Chaim Vital and our master the Arizal, that there are twelve upper gates through which the prayers of Israel ascend, corresponding to the twelve sevens, and each tribe and seven has its own special gate. Based on this, the Divrei Chaim and the Chasam Sofer, may their memory be blessed, wrote that one should not change the text of the prayer from Sephardic to Ashkenazic, see there for their reasoning. And seemingly, we are all the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, so why is there a need for a special gate for the prayer of each tribe? Certainly, the reasons for these matters are secrets of secrets, not for the eye to see, and we have no business with them. But it is clear that the Holy One, blessed be He, did this for the good of His people Israel whom He loves, and perhaps in order that there should be a special channel for receiving influence and light for each seven and tribe according to their essence in the roots of their souls. In this way, an increase of influence and a special light will flow to each one according to the measure of their root and their essence. In any case, it is clear that all this is for the benefit of Israel and their advantage, for He, blessed be He, created them and knows their benefit. And now that the Holy One, blessed be He, added another tribe to Jacob by saying to Jacob, "A nation and a congregation of nations shall be from you," as Rashi explains that one of the tribes is destined to be divided, the Blessed One added another gate for the added tribe, and that gift that Jacob our father gave to Joseph was that he gave his sons two upper gates.
summary: The passage discusses the Ramban's question on Rashi's interpretation regarding the division of the tribes and the significance of Jacob's blessings to Joseph, emphasizing that these blessings are not merely for honor but serve a deeper purpose. It highlights the concept of twelve upper gates corresponding to the twelve tribes, each with a unique spiritual channel for prayer and divine influence, reflecting the distinct spiritual essence of each tribe. The addition of a new tribe signifies the creation of an additional gate, reinforcing the idea that God's arrangements are for the benefit of Israel, ensuring that each tribe receives tailored spiritual sustenance according to its unique qualities. Ultimately, this structure is seen as a divine design for the welfare and elevation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: וז"ש אפרים ומנשה כראובן ושמעון יהיו לי, שיהיו נמנין במנין השבטים לכל דבר לנשיא ולדגלים כמו שפירש רש"י ז"ל, ועוד שיהיה לכל אחד מהם שער מיוחד ומקום מעבר מיוחד לתפלתם, וצנור מיוחד להורדת השפע והאורה בכח התפלה, המיוחד כפו בחינתם ושרשם, והנה כח התפלה נקרא נחלה ע"ד שאמר הכתוב (ישעי' נ"ד) זאת נחלת עבדי ד' וגו' דמה שהם עבדי ד' הוא נחלתם, וגם שכל התפילות עולות דרך ירושלים לשערים העליונים, וירושלים נקרא נחלה כמ"ש ז"ל (בספרי) מנוחה זו שילה נחלה זו ירושלים, וע"כ כח התפלה נקרא נחלה ע"ש ירושלים וז"ש הכתוב ומולדתך אשר הולדת אחריהם, ר"ל שלעתיד שתוליד עוד וישלמו לך מנין י"ב שבטים שהיו ראויים לצאת ממך, אבל אלו לא יהיו במנין בני להיות להם שבט בפ"ע, אלא בתוך שבט אפרים ומנשה יהיו נכללים וז"ש על שם אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, שלענין נחלה זו, היינו כח התפלה ושער עליון המיוחד לעליית תפלתם יהיו נכללין בתוך שבעי אפרים ומנשה, ואפשר דמלת יקראו רומז על תפלה ע"ד שאמה"כ קוראים אל ד' והוא יענם. בכל קראינו אליו, וז"ש על שם אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, שיהי' מעבר תפלתם בנחלת אחיהם ובשער אפרים ומנשה.
translation: And this is what is meant by "Ephraim and Manasseh shall be as Reuben and Simeon to Me," that they shall be counted in the count of the tribes for all matters, for the prince and for the banners, as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained. Furthermore, each of them shall have a special gate and a designated place for their prayers, and a special conduit for the flow of abundance and light through the power of prayer, which is uniquely aligned with their essence and root. And behold, the power of prayer is called a heritage, as the verse states (Isaiah 54), "This is the heritage of the servants of the Lord," for what they are servants of the Lord is their heritage. Also, all prayers ascend through Jerusalem to the upper gates, and Jerusalem is called a heritage, as it is said (in Sifrei), "Rest is Shiloh, heritage is Jerusalem." Therefore, the power of prayer is called a heritage in the name of Jerusalem. And this is what the verse means, "And your birthplace, which you bore after them," meaning that in the future you will bear more, and the count of the twelve tribes that were worthy to come from you will be completed. However, these will not be counted among the sons to have a separate tribe, but rather they will be included within the tribe of Ephraim and Manasseh. And this is what is meant by "they shall be called by the name of their brothers in their heritage," for regarding this heritage, which is the power of prayer and the upper gate designated for the ascent of their prayers, they will be included within the seven of Ephraim and Manasseh. And it is possible that the word "they shall be called" hints at prayer, as it is written, "They call to the Lord, and He answers them. In all our calling to Him." And this is what is meant by "they shall be called by the name of their brothers in their heritage," that their prayers shall pass through the heritage of their brothers and through the gate of Ephraim and Manasseh.
summary: The passage discusses the inclusion of Ephraim and Manasseh among the tribes of Israel, emphasizing their unique roles in prayer and spiritual connection. It highlights that each tribe will have a designated space for prayer, through which divine blessings and light are channeled. The concept of prayer is described as a "heritage," linking it to Jerusalem, which serves as the ultimate destination for all prayers. Ultimately, Ephraim and Manasseh's descendants will be integrated into their legacy, with their prayers ascending through the gates associated with their lineage.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יתבאר קישור הסמיכות של מאמר ואני בבואי מפדן וגו' למאמר ומולדתך אשר הולדת וגו', ויתורץ קושית המפרשים דהי' ראוי שיזכיר זאת ההתנצלות בתחילת הפרשה בשעה שצוהו על הקבורה (עיין לעיל קושיא ע'). דהנה לכאורה לא יספיק התנצלות הזה, ועדיין הי' מקום ליוסף להרהר כי מדוע נבחרה אמו רחל לכך, וכמו"כ הי' אפשר שתהי' התפלה והעזרה לבני ישראל ע"י לאה או א' מאמהות שיבקשו עליהם רחמים, והשי"ת בודאי ישמע לתפלתם, כי כולם צדקניות היו וזכותן כדאי לכך, אמנם עכשיו שנתבשר יוסף הצדיק שלעתיד יזכה להעמיד אותן הי"ב שבטים שהיו ראויים לצאת ממנו, וע"כ ראוי' יותר רחל אמנו שתהי' לעזרה לבנ"י, ולבקש רחמים על גאולתם, ותכנסת בעובי הקורה יותר לאפושי ברחמין, כי עדיין לא נעלה חלקה להעמיד השבעים הראויים לצאת ממנה, משא"כ האמהות כולם כבר העמידו חלקם, וע"כ רחל מבכה על בני' מאנה להנחם על בני' כי איננו, והבוי"ת ישמע אל תפלתה כמאה"כ יש שכר לפעולתך ויש תקו' לאחריתך, כי יתקיים לך תקותך שהיתה מתאו' להעמיד שבעים, ובזכותה יהי' הגאולה ע"י משיח בן יוסף הבא מזרעה, וביוסף נרמז כח הגאולה כדאיתא בתנחומא (פ' שמות) יוסף ע"ש יוסיף ד' שנית ידו לקנות את שאר עמו (ישעי' י"א). וע"כ המתין יעקב אבינו בהתנצלותו ליוסף עד עכשיו אחר שבשרהו על העמדת י"ב שבטים במאמר ומולדתך וגו' ומעתה יובן לו שהי' צורך והכרח שתקבר רחל אמנו בחו"ל, כדי שתהי' לעזרה להתפלל על בני' על גאולתן, משא"כ קודם לכן הי' עדיין מקום הרהור ולא הי' מספיק בהתנצלות הזאת.
translation: And according to our path, the connection of the juxtaposition of the statement "And I came from Padan" etc. to the statement "And your birthplace that you were born" etc. will be clarified, and the difficulty of the commentators will be resolved, that it was fitting for this excuse to be mentioned at the beginning of the section when he was commanded regarding the burial (see above the difficulty 20). Behold, seemingly this excuse would not suffice, and there would still be room for Joseph to ponder why his mother Rachel was chosen for this, and likewise it could be that the prayer and assistance for the children of Israel could have been through Leah or one of the other mothers who would plead for them for mercy, and the Holy One, blessed be He, would certainly listen to their prayers, for they were all righteous women and their merit was sufficient for that. However, now that the righteous Joseph was informed that in the future he would merit to establish the twelve tribes that were worthy to come from him, therefore it is more fitting that our mother Rachel should be the one to assist the children of Israel and to plead for mercy for their redemption, and she would enter into the thick of it more to plead for mercy, for her portion had not yet been elevated to establish the seventy who were worthy to come from her, whereas all the other mothers had already established their portion. Therefore, Rachel weeps for her children, refusing to be comforted for her children because they are not, and the Blessed One will surely hear her prayer, as it is written, "There is reward for your actions, and there is hope for your future," for your hope will be fulfilled that she desired to establish seventy, and in her merit the redemption will come through Messiah son of Joseph who comes from her seed. And in Joseph is hinted the power of redemption, as it is stated in the Tanchuma (Parashat Shemot), "Joseph, for he will add, the Lord will again extend His hand to acquire the rest of His people" (Isaiah 11). Therefore, our forefather Jacob delayed his excuse to Joseph until now, after he informed him about the establishment of the twelve tribes in the statement "And your birthplace" etc., and from now on it will be understood that there was a need and necessity for our mother Rachel to be buried outside the land, so that she would be an assistance to pray for her children for their redemption, whereas before that there was still room for doubt and this excuse would not have been sufficient.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Rachel's burial and her role in interceding for the Jewish people. It emphasizes that Rachel, as the mother of Joseph, is uniquely positioned to pray for the redemption of her descendants, especially since she has not yet fulfilled her potential to bear the seventy souls that would emerge from her lineage. The text highlights that her tears and prayers are essential for the future redemption, linking her to the coming of the Messiah from Joseph's line. Ultimately, it reveals that Jacob's delay in addressing Rachel's burial was necessary to underscore her vital role in the spiritual welfare of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפשר לתרץ קושית האברבנאל עה"פ ויקרא בהם שמי וגו' דלא מצינו דאפרים ומנשה נקראים בשם האבות הק', אמנם לא מצינו אינה ראי', דכמו"כ לא מצינו מאמר ומולדתך אשר הולדת שנתקיים, אבל כל דיבורו של יעקב אבינו בברכותיו היו ע"ש העתיד כמ"ש לעיל, וכמו"כ מאמר ויקרא בהם שמי יתקיים לעתיד ובל"ס לא יפול מברכותיו של יעקב אע"ה שום דבר לבעלה, ויתקיימו במילואם לעתיד.
translation: And similarly, it is possible to answer the question of the Abarbanel on the verse "And I will call upon them by My name," that we do not find that Ephraim and Menashe are called by the names of the holy patriarchs. However, we do not find this to be a proof, for just as we do not find a saying "and your birthplace which you were born" that was fulfilled, so too all of Jacob our forefather's words in his blessings were in the name of the future, as mentioned above. Likewise, the saying "And I will call upon them by My name" will be fulfilled in the future, and certainly nothing from the blessings of Jacob our forefather will fall to the ground, and they will be fulfilled in their entirety in the future.
summary: The passage discusses the theological significance of Jacob's blessings, emphasizing that they are prophetic and will be fulfilled in the future. It addresses the question of why Ephraim and Manasseh are not explicitly named after the patriarchs, suggesting that Jacob's words carry a future-oriented promise. The text asserts that nothing from Jacob's blessings will be lost, and they will be realized in their entirety, reflecting a deep belief in the enduring power of prophetic words. This highlights the Hasidic concept of the eternal relevance of blessings and the divine assurance of their fulfillment.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יתפרש הפסוק ואני נתתי לך שכם וגו' על אחיך וגו' ושכם לשון חלק הוא כמו שפרש"י וכ"כ בתרגום אונקלוס, יהבית לך חולק חד יתיר על אחך, ולדרכנו הכוונה שנתן ליוסף ב' שערים, וחלק כפול בכח התפלה כנ"ל, אשר לקחתי מיד האמורי פרש"י מיד עשו שצד אביו באמרי פיו, ויובן עפימ"ש בדברנו (פ' תולדות) עה"פ בא אחיך במרמה וגו', דכל התגברותו של עשו ליקח הברכות הי' ע"ו מרמה, שצד אביו באמרי פיו להראות את עצמו לצדיק, וע"כ חשב יצחק אבינו כי הברכות מגיע אליו, והי' כ"ז סיבה מן השמים כמ"ש בזוה"ק כדי שיתברך יעקב בלא דעתי' דיצחק עיי"ש בדברנו. אבל יעקב אבינו התגבר עליו בחכמת תורתו ובכח תפלתו וזכה הוא בברכות, כמ"ש ז"ל במדרש בא אחיך במרמה בחכמת תורתו, והיתה ההתגברות זה לעומת זה, שעשו בא בכח אמרי פיו ברמאות, ויעקב אבינו התגבר עליו בדיבורי אמת תורה ותפלה, וכל מעשיהם של האבות הקדושים הו' לעשות הכנה ופועל דמיוני לדורות העתידים כמבואר בדרז"ל, ובזה הכין יעקב אבינו הכח לדורות ישראל להתגבר ולהנצל מיד עשו בגלות אדום ע"י כח התפלה, כמ"ש לו יצחק הקול קול יעקב ואין כוחם של ישראל אלא בפה כאמרז"ל, וכתיב בבכי יבואו ובתחנונים אובילם וגו', דע"י כח התפלה יזכו לגאולה העתידה.
translation: And according to our path, the verse "And I have given you Shechem, etc., over your brothers, etc." is explained, and Shechem is a term for a portion, as Rashi explains, and so too in the translation of Onkelos, "I have given you a single portion more than your brothers." According to our path, the intention is that he gave Joseph two gates, and a double portion in the power of prayer, as mentioned above, which I took from the Amorite, Rashi explains, from Esau who caught his father with the words of his mouth. And it will be understood according to what we said (in Parashat Toldot) regarding the verse "Your brother came with deceit, etc.," that all of Esau's strength to take the blessings was through deceit, as he caught his father with the words of his mouth to present himself as righteous. Therefore, Isaac our father thought that the blessings belonged to him, and all of this was a reason from Heaven, as stated in the Zohar, so that Jacob would be blessed without the knowledge of Isaac, as explained there in our discussion. But Jacob our father overcame him with the wisdom of his Torah and the power of his prayer, and he merited the blessings, as our sages said in the Midrash, "Your brother came with deceit" through the wisdom of his Torah. And the overcoming was this against that, as Esau came with the power of the words of his mouth through deceit, and Jacob our father overcame him with the true words of Torah and prayer. And all the actions of the holy patriarchs were to prepare and create a figurative effect for future generations, as explained in the teachings of our sages. And in this, Jacob our father prepared the strength for the generations of Israel to overcome and be saved from the hand of Esau in the exile of Edom through the power of prayer, as Isaac said to him, "The voice is the voice of Jacob," and the strength of Israel is only in the mouth, as our sages said. And it is written, "They shall come with weeping, and with supplications I will lead them, etc.," for through the power of prayer they will merit the future redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the blessings given to Jacob over Esau, emphasizing that Jacob's victory was achieved through the wisdom of the Torah and the power of prayer. It highlights the concept that the patriarchs' actions were preparatory for future generations, equipping them with the strength to overcome challenges, particularly from Esau in the form of Edom's exile. The text underscores that the true power of the Jewish people lies in their speech and prayer, which will ultimately lead to their redemption, as indicated by the prophetic promise of returning with supplications.

passage_content: וז"ש אשר לקחתי מיד האמורי, שכח התפלה שאני נותן לך זכיתי בה ולקחתי' מיד האמורי זה עשו שרצה להתגבר באמרי פיו, בחרבי ובקשתי בצלותי ובבעותי שהתגברתי עליו וזכיתי בכח התפלה, וכן אמרז"ל בגמ' ב"ב (דף קכ"ג ע"א) בחרבי זו תפלה ובקשתי זו בקשה ופי' הרשב"ם ז"ל שהתפלל יעקב על בניו, ושזכה לקנות הבכורה מעשו בתפלתו עיי"ש וכתב היפ"ת בב"ר (פ' ס"ג) דאע"פ שהבכורה לקחה בלחם ונזיד עדשים, לא הי' זה אלא לסתום פי עשו, אבל עיקרה מה שהסכים ד' בזה לא הי' אלא בזכותו ובכח תפלתו עיי"ש. ויעקב אבינו ע"ה הכין כח התפלה לדורות ישראל כנ"ל, ובאותו המתנה אני נותן לך חלק א' יותר והנה הגאולה העתידה תהי' ע"ו כח התפלה כנ"ל, וע"כ יוצמח ג"כ כח הגאולה ע"י זרעו של יוסף שהוא משיח בן יוסף. ונרמז בשמו כח הגאולה כמ"ש בתנחומא יוסף ע"ש יוסיף ד' שנית ידו וגו' כנ"ל, וכ"ז הי' מחלק הבכורה שנתן יעקב ליוסף ובזה יתבארו הכתובים קצת.
translation: And this is what is meant by "which I took from the hand of the Amorite," that the power of prayer that I am giving you, I have merited it and taken it from the hand of the Amorite, which is Esau who sought to overpower with the words of his mouth. With my sword and my request, through my prayers and my supplications, I have prevailed over him and merited the power of prayer. And thus our Sages of blessed memory said in the Gemara Bava Batra (23a), "My sword" refers to prayer, and "my request" refers to supplication. And Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that Jacob prayed for his sons, and he merited to acquire the birthright from Esau through his prayer, as noted there. And the Yefeh Toar wrote in Bereishit Rabbah (parashah 63) that although the birthright was taken with bread and lentil stew, this was only to silence Esau's mouth, but the essence of it, that which the Holy One, blessed be He, agreed to, was only by virtue of his merit and the power of his prayer, as noted there. And our forefather Jacob, peace be upon him, prepared the power of prayer for the generations of Israel as mentioned above, and in that same gift, I am giving you one additional part. And behold, the future redemption will also be through the power of prayer as mentioned above, and therefore the strength of redemption will also sprout through the seed of Joseph, who is the Messiah, son of Joseph. And it is hinted in his name the power of redemption, as it is said in Tanchuma, "Joseph," because the Lord will add His hand a second time, etc., as mentioned above. And all this was from the portion of the birthright that Jacob gave to Joseph, and through this, the scriptures will be somewhat clarified.
summary: The passage emphasizes the power of prayer as a means of overcoming adversaries, specifically referencing Jacob's victory over Esau through his prayers. It highlights that Jacob's acquisition of the birthright was not merely through physical means but was fundamentally rooted in divine approval granted through his supplications. The text also connects the future redemption to the strength of prayer, particularly through the lineage of Joseph, who is seen as a precursor to the Messiah. Ultimately, it underscores the enduring significance of prayer in the spiritual legacy of Israel.

passage_content: ויתבאר לדרכנו מאמה"כ בן פורת יוסף וגו' בנות צעדה עלי שור שרמז על בנות צלפחד שיטלו חלק בארץ ודברי הילקוט בזה עיין לעיל (קושיא וזזרי"ח). ונקדים לבאר ענין פרשת בנות צלפחד דכתיב בפ' פנחס ותעמודנה לפני משה וגו' אבינו מת במדבר וגו' למה יגרע שם אבינו מתוך משפחתו כי אין לו בן תנה לנו אחזה בתוך אחי אבינו, ואמרז"ל במס' ב"ב (דף קי"ט ע"ב) בנות צלפחד חכמניות היו וכו' אמרו לו אם כבן אנו חשובין תנה לנו נחלה כבן ואם לאו תתיבם אמנו, מיד ויקרב משה את משפטן לפני ד'. ועוד אמרז"ל יודע הו' משה רבינו שבנות צלפחד יורשות הן, ופי' הרשב"ם שהרי דינין נצטוו במרה ופרשת נחלות מכללן, ועוד דאיכא למילף מפ' יבמין שהבת כבן וכו' דהא בנות צלפחד משם למדו וכו', אבל לא הי' יודע אם נוטלות חלק בכורה וכו'. ולכאורה א"כ למה לא השיב להם משה רבינו מיד על עיקר שאלתם שהבת כבן ויורשת במקום שאין בן, ומה נשתנה הלכה זו שהקריב את משפטן לפני ד', גם למה המתין ולא צו' לבני ישראל פרשה זו איש כי ימות ובן אין לו וגו' עד שבא לפניו מעשה דבנות צלפחד.
translation: And it will be explained according to our path from the Holy Scriptures, "A son of a fruitful tree is Joseph" etc., "The daughters stepped upon the bull," which hints at the daughters of Zelophehad who will take a portion in the land, and the words of the Yalkut on this matter, refer to above (a question and Zazri"ch). And we will begin to explain the matter of the portion of the daughters of Zelophehad, as it is written in Parashat Pinchas, "And they stood before Moses" etc., "Our father died in the wilderness" etc., "Why should the name of our father be diminished from his family, because he has no son? Give us a possession among the brothers of our father." And our sages said in Tractate Bava Batra (page 119b) that the daughters of Zelophehad were wise, etc. They said to him, "If we are considered like sons, give us an inheritance like a son, and if not, let us sit with our mother." Immediately, Moses brought their case before God. And our sages also said that Moses our teacher knew that the daughters of Zelophehad were heirs, and the Rashbam explained that they were commanded about the laws in Marah and the portion of inheritances was included in them, and also that one can learn from the section of Yevamot that a daughter is like a son, etc., for the daughters of Zelophehad learned from there, etc. But he did not know if they would inherit the firstborn's portion, etc. And at first glance, if so, why did Moses our teacher not respond to them immediately regarding the essence of their question that a daughter is like a son and inherits in a place where there is no son, and what was different about this law that he brought their case before God? Also, why did he wait and not command the children of Israel about this section, "If a man dies and has no son" etc., until the matter of the daughters of Zelophehad came before him?
summary: The passage discusses the case of the daughters of Zelophehad, who assert their right to inherit land in the absence of a male heir, highlighting their wisdom and understanding of the Torah's laws. It emphasizes the theological principle that women can inherit like sons when there are no male heirs, reflecting a deeper understanding of divine justice and equality. The delay in Moses' response to their request suggests a divine purpose in bringing their case before God, reinforcing the idea that all matters of inheritance and justice ultimately rest with the divine will. This narrative illustrates the importance of seeking God's guidance in matters of law and the recognition of women's roles within the community.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר פ' וישב (פ"ד סי"א) כך הי' אבינו יעקב סבור שתחיית המתים מגעת בימיו, וכמו"כ מבואר במדרשי חז"ל שמשרע"ה הי' מצפה על זה, והאריך בזה בספה"ק מגלה עמוקות דמשרע"ה רצה ליכנס לא"י, ולתקן הכל ע"י זכותא דא"י, ולהעביר רוח הטומאה מן הארץ ולבטל כל הצרות שבעולם, ואלו הי' נכנס הי' העולם התקון ותחיית המתים בימיו, והי' הכל מיד באותו בחי' שיהי' אחר הגאולה, ולכל זה הי' משה רבינו מצפה, ומתפלל תקט"ו תפלות שירשהו השי"ת ליכנס לארץ, ולא הודיעו ית' שהגזרה מוחלטת כדי ליתן לו פתח שיהא עומד ומתפלל, לפי שהקב"ה מתאו' לתפלתן של צדיקים, עד שא"ל ית' רב לך אל תוסף דבר אלי עוד והי' עומד בתחי', בדבר הזה, כי אלו הי' מתפלל עוד תפלה א' הי' נענה, אלא שלא הי' רצון העליון ב"ה לכך, שלא הי' עדיין זמנו של התיקון השלם, ע"כ נמנע ממנו כח התפלה אז, סמוך למיתתו והודיעו ית' שהגזירה מוחלעת, (עיין בדברנו במקו"א שהארכנו בבחי' זו). עכ"פ אלו הי' משה רבינו נכנס לארץ לא הי' עוד מקום ספק בהלכה זו דבנות צלפחד, כי הי' תחיית המתים מיד בכניסתם לארץ, וצלפחד צדיק גמור הי' כאמרז"ל והי' מוליד עוד בנים כאמרז"ל עתידה אשה שתלד בכל יום, וכל ישראל יהיו נושעים בבנים גם אותן שלא זכו אלי' בעוה"ז, ומעתה לא נהי' במציאות כלל הלכה זו דאיש כי ימות ובן אין לו, שיצטרך להעביר נחלתו לבתו, גם בנות צלפחד לא היו יורשות אלא הבנים שהי' צלפחד מוליד עוד.
translation: And even though it is stated in the Midrash Rabbah Parashat Vayeshev (Chapter 4, Section 11) that our father Jacob thought that the resurrection of the dead would occur in his days, it is also explained in the Midrashim of our Sages that Moshe Rabbeinu was anticipating this. He elaborated on this in the holy book Megaleh Amukos, that Moshe Rabbeinu wanted to enter the Land of Israel and to rectify everything through the merit of the Land of Israel, to remove the spirit of impurity from the land and to nullify all the troubles in the world. If he had entered, the world would have been rectified and the resurrection of the dead would have occurred in his days, and everything would have been immediately in that state that will be after the redemption. For all this, Moshe Rabbeinu was waiting and praying 316 prayers that the Holy One, blessed be He, would allow him to enter the land, and He did not inform him that the decree was absolute in order to give him an opportunity to stand and pray, for the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous, to the point that He said to him, "It is enough for you; do not add to speak to Me anymore," and he was standing in this matter, because if he had prayed one more prayer, he would have been answered, but it was not the will of the Supreme Will, blessed be He, for the time for complete rectification had not yet arrived. Therefore, he was prevented from the power of prayer at that time, close to his death, and it was made known to him that the decree was absolute (see our discussion in other places where we elaborated on this aspect). In any case, if Moshe Rabbeinu had entered the land, there would no longer be any doubt in this halacha regarding the daughters of Tzelophehad, for the resurrection of the dead would have occurred immediately upon their entering the land, and Tzelophehad was a complete righteous man, as our Sages said, and he would have fathered more sons, as our Sages said, "A woman will give birth every day," and all of Israel would be saved through sons, even those who did not merit it in this world. From now on, this halacha that a man dies and has no son, so he must transfer his inheritance to his daughter, would not exist at all, and the daughters of Tzelophehad would not inherit, but rather the sons that Tzelophehad would have fathered.
summary: The passage discusses the belief that both Jacob and Moses anticipated the resurrection of the dead during their lifetimes, with Moses specifically longing to enter the Land of Israel to facilitate this redemption and eliminate worldly suffering. It emphasizes that had Moses entered the land, the resurrection would have occurred immediately, resolving legal uncertainties regarding inheritance, particularly concerning the daughters of Zelophehad. The text highlights the idea that the prayers of the righteous are cherished by God, and although Moses' prayers were not answered due to the timing of divine will, his intentions were aligned with the ultimate redemption and restoration of Israel.

passage_content: ואפשר דע"כ לא השיב להם משרע"ה על שאלתם שהבת יורשת אע"פ שכבר ידע בזה כאמרז"ל, דאה"נ שידע בעצם ההלכה, אבל הי' מצפה שישתנה מצב העולם לטובה ויהי' הכל בבחי' שלאחר הגאולה ולא יצטרך להעביר נחלה מבן לבת, ומה"ט לא אמר פרשה זו דאיש כו ימות ובן אין לו עד אחר מעשה דבנות צלפחד שצוהו ד' לצוות לבנ"י, כי לפי הבחי' שהי' מצפה אלי', לא הי' מציאות לזה להלכה ולמעשה, וע"כ הקריב משה את משפטן לפני ד', לשמוע מה יצו' ד' בענין הזה, ומזה רצה לשפוט ולידע אם הגזירה מוחלטת עליו שלא יכנס לארץ אם לאו, אמנם הבוי"ת ידע כי עדיין לא הגיע הזמן שיהי' התקון השלם בימיו, גם לא רצה הבוי"ת לגלות לו בפירוש שהגזרה מוחלטת עליו שלא יכנס, דהקב"ה מתאו' לתפלתן של צדיקים כנ"ל, ולא השיב לו ית' מענין ביאתו לארץ דברים ברורים, אלא הוראה לשעה בעצם ההלכה, וצוהו לצוות לישראל פרשה זו, ועדיין נשאר בספיקו והי' עומד ומתפלל על כניסתו לארץ, כי זה הא רצונו ות' כנ"ל.
translation: And it is possible that Moshe Rabbeinu did not respond to their question that the daughter inherits, even though he already knew this, as our Sages have said. Indeed, he knew the essence of the law, but he was hoping that the state of the world would change for the better and that everything would be in the state of after the Redemption, and he would not need to transfer inheritance from son to daughter. For this reason, he did not mention this section that a man will die and he has no son until after the matter of the daughters of Tzelophehad, which Hashem commanded him to instruct the Children of Israel. Because according to the state he was hoping for, there was no reality for this in law and practice. Therefore, Moshe brought their case before Hashem, to hear what Hashem would command regarding this matter, and from this, he wanted to judge and know if the decree was absolute upon him that he would not enter the Land or not. However, the Blessed One knew that the time for complete rectification had not yet arrived in his days, and the Blessed One also did not want to reveal to him explicitly that the decree was absolute upon him that he would not enter, for the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous, as mentioned above. And He did not respond to him clearly regarding his entry into the Land, but rather a directive for the moment regarding the essence of the law, and commanded him to instruct Israel in this section. Yet, he remained in his doubt and stood and prayed for his entry into the Land, for this was his desire and intention, as mentioned above.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Moses' response to the question of inheritance rights for daughters, highlighting his expectation for a positive change in the world post-redemption. Although Moses understood the halacha, he hoped for a situation where such laws would not be necessary, reflecting a belief in the ultimate rectification of the world. The text emphasizes that God did not provide Moses with a clear answer regarding his entry into the Promised Land, as He desired the prayers of the righteous, leaving Moses in a state of uncertainty while still commanding him to teach the law to the people. This illustrates the tension between divine decree and human prayer, as well as the hope for future redemption.
